column2: ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 10. -- The seventh annual meeting of the National Municipal League was brought to a close today with a full discussion of the subject of municipal accounting. Municipal government and the relations thereto of institutions of higher education had occupied the meeting during five sessions.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- The volume containing statements of appropriations, new offices created, and other things required by law to be prepared and published at the end of each session of Congress under the direction of the Committees on Appropriations of the Senate and House, has been completed for the second session of the Fifty-sixth Congress by Thomas P. Cleaves and James C. Courts, chief clerks, respectively, of those committees.

ANNA K. BARTOW, Astorla, L. I., writes gratefully to THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW: "I feel sure you will be interested in knowing the good result of your kindly publication in THE SATURDAY REVIEW, of our appeal for reading matter for the Church Periodical Club. Many letters have been received In response and a little money besides.

Robert M. Moore, counsel for Albert T. Patrick, David Short, and Morris Meyers, appeared before Judge Foster, in Part I. of General Sessions, yesterday to argue the demurrers made by him against the indictments filed against the three men last week, variously charging murder, perjury, and forgery.

Clad in his finest clothes, "Bill" Roddy, so-called Beau Brummell of the Oak Street Police Station, sauntered into that stronghold of law and order late yesterday afternoon. He had been summoned, thither, he knew not why, during his "off hours." As he entered the door he was surprised to see all his fellow policemen lined up in front of the Captain's room, with long faces.

LONDON, May 11. -- A more hopeful feeling is reflected in the financial articles in the morning papers to-day. It is expected that the bankers will furnish every reasonable facility for meeting the position, but there is certain to be considerable tension till the settlement is past.

In that monumental series in which Gen. Edward McCrady has chosen to portray with unexampled fullness or detail the history of the development of his native State, South Carolina, first under the proprietary and next under royal Government, he has at last arrived in this, the third volume, at the interesting period of the Revolution.
Edward Holzheu and Eugene E. Wegmann, doing business under the style of E. Holzheu, commission merchants at 78 Franklin Street, made an assignment yesterday to William L. Waring, without preference.

CREEDMOOR, May 10. -- The range was occupied to-day by the Forty-seventh Regiment, N.G.N.Y., under the command of Col. J.G. Eddy. There were about 375 officers and men present, of whom 250 qualified as marksmen and received the State decoration. The weather was miserable.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- Representative Latimer of South Carolina, who may enter into a contest with Senator McLaurin for the Senate, thinks that the request to Senator McLaurin to address the people of his State on his recent acceptance of some Republican policies has been misinterpreted, and is not to be accepted as an indication that the people of the South are prepared to adopt those principles.
Bar silver was quoted in London at 27 1/4d per ounce and in New York at 59 1/4c. Mexican dollars, 48 1/2c.

It is to be regretted that the injunction obtained from Judge GILDERSLEEVE, restraining, practically, the parties supposed to be responsible for the Northern Pacific corner from enforcing contracts for the delivery of stock, is not to be pressed. The full discussion of such an injunction would be interesting and instructive.

Acting in co-operation with the committee of the Forrest Monument Association of Memphis, Dr. John A. Wyeth of 19 West Thirty-fifth Street, this city, seeks contributions for an equestrian statue of Lieut. Gen. Forrest, the corner stone of which it is proposed to lay at the Confederate reunion in the last week in May.

In the House of Commons Mr. Herbert Lewis asked the Chancellor of the Exchequer whether it was a fact that British patents "are taken out at the risk of the applicants, it being left to every person to protect his own rights," and whether "Great Britain is the only country which issues patents without satisfactory proof that the inventions described have not been previously patented."

Gov. ODELL places his disapproval of the bill granting bridge and railway privileges to the North River Bridge Company on right grounds. He holds that the bill is essentially a city bill, and that it ought to have been submitted to the authorities of the city for the action required by the constitution for bills relating to the city.

BERLIN, May 11 -- Mme. Sembrich began to-day a short season with "Don Pasquale" at the Royal Opera, which was overcrowded. She was enthusiastically received, and showed that she has completely recovered her voice.

Charles R. De Freest, Secretary of the Democratic State Committee, died suddenly at his home, Ovington Avenue and Third Avenue, Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, on Friday night. Mr. De Freest left his office in the Park Row Building at 5 o'clock in the afternoon. He was feeling well, and had no difficulty in reaching home.

DEL MONTE, Cal., May 11 -- Ohio Congressmen and Gov. Nash's party, en route to San Francisco for the launching of the battleship Ohio, have clashed over a question of precedence. Californians have been cordial in their reception of the Ohio party, but naturally President McKinley has received the most attention, and Gov. Nash and his party, who are traveling on a separate train, have been a little in the background.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., May 11 -- With the victory of the Lakewood Freebooters over the Bryn Mawr Polo Club this afternoon on the Georgian Court Field, the tournament given by George Gould came to a close. It has been the most successful series of competitions ever played here. The Freebooters won in a splendidly played game by 11 goals to 9 1/4, and four of Bryn Mawr's points were allowed by handicaps.

LONDON, May 11 -- The slump in Wall Street must not be regarded as an unmixed evil, for it came in time to convince Britons that Americans are but fallible human beings after all. The typical American in British eyes has lately been an imposing and awe-inspiring figure, immensely powerful, and it seemed only a question of time when this creature would own the whole world.

GENEVA, N.Y., May 11 -- Dr. Edgar A. Bogart, a veterinary surgeon, until recently practicing in this place, who gave up his practice here to accept a position with the British Army in South Africa, reached there some time ago. A letter from him, dated at Cape Town, was received to-day. In it he says:

The Turks entered Constantinople one hour after midnight, May 29, 1453. The Greeks fled in defeat, and spread consternation everywhere through the city. In a moment the streets were filled with a crowd half-maddened with fear and alarm. According to a widespread belief, the Turks would be crushed by thunder-bolts from heaven if they attempted to pass the column of the cross.

The work of the United Hebrew Charities during April is given in reports of the various committees, which show that the total number of applications received and dealt with during the month reached 4,487, representing about 14,596 individuals. Of these, 3,735 applied to the Bureau of Relief and 752 to the Employment Bureau.
Wall Street's courage recovered. Wall Street's good sense once more operative, panic conditions -- grievous threats and more grievous possibilities -- disappear.

A woman who has broken the record in servants this season has had sixty of them. The trouble seems in this case to be not so much with the servants as with the mistress. She is a woman of enormous wealth and plenty of time to think. She utilizes this time to concoct schemes by means of which her wealth will bring her the most marvelous results.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., May 11 -- Rain this afternoon threatened the success of the annual parade of the Philadelphia Coaching Club, but after a delay in the start for about forty minutes the eight coaches left the Bellevue for their trip to the Park, while interested crowds lined the streets to witness the spectacle.

NEWPORT, May 11 -- By next Wednesday seventy-five of the cottages here will be opened. To-day all the moving vans and express wagons in Newport were engaged in moving the belongings of cottagers from boats and trains. Never before in the history of Newport have there been so many arrivals of cottagers as to-day.

Dr. Charles Rice, for many years head chemist in charge of the general drug department of the Department of Charities, was suddenly taken Ill in a call yesterday afternoon. Dr. Rice for some time has been a sufferer from asthma, and of late the disease had increased in violence, it was the doctor's custom dally to drive in a cab, as he was unable to walk without experiencing serious inconvenience from his ailment.

The Admiralty fixed many years ago and have never altered the hours at which the crews of all men-of-war shall have their meals. Breakfast of cocoa without milk, and bread or hard biscuit without butter or jam, is eaten at between 6 and 7 o'clock. At noon dinner is served, and at 4 in the afternoon all the year round "supper" is taken, consisting of tea, and again bread or biscuit.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Being a constant reader of your excellent and highly efficient paper, I did not fall to take notice of some of the remarks and letters of different people of prominence in that most admirable portion of your paper, namely, your editorial part, in regard to conferring the degree of Doctor of Laws upon William McKinley, President of the United States.

Lewis Nixon Roberts of Boston, just back from a tour of Europe, secured while abroad a bit of horseflesh that he expects will create a sensation at the Summer horse shows at Bar Harbor. Newport, and elsewhere this season. He is a high-stepper, a native of Seville, in Spain, where he was purchased for $10,000, and is called Admiral Cervera.

Three members of the Automobile Club of America, who started out on a run to Morristown, N.J., yesterday, found that it was a dangerous matter to go racing around New Jersey without being well posted in local speed regulations, and for that ignorance they paid the penalty of arrest and fine by a Justice of the Peace of Morristown.

The locomotive of Train No. 80, known as the Boston fruit express, fell through the draw of the bridge over West Farms Creek, on the Harlem River Division of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad yesterday afternoon. The engineer and fireman jumped from it just in time to save their lives, and no one was injured.
Mayor Carter H. Harrison says that experience in Chicago, at least, has shown asphalt or brick to be the ideal pavement for residence streets, and dressed granite block for heavy traffic streets.

Over 500 vehicles took part in the second annual parade of the Road Drivers' Association of New York on upper Seventh Avenue and the Speedway yesterday afternoon, and the remarkable turnout of fine horses and their drivers was witnessed by a crowd of over 10,000 persons, who lined the walks of the avenue and the Speedway, or stood upon the bridges and the high banks of the famous driveway.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Secretary Root has just indorsed an opinion rendered by Judge Advocate General Lieber which will carry consternation to many would-be pensioners against whom charges of desertion appear on the records. Gen. Lieber's opinion is to the effect that the War Department cannot "correct" the records of deserters who served in the war with Spain so as to remove the charges.

Although the New York Legislature adjourned over two weeks ago, THE NEW YORK TIMES, with good reason, considers it not too late to publish the names of those who voted for the repeal of the law of 1875, which was responsible for the wanton slaughter, early in April, of 20,000 pigeons by a Long Island gun club.

ALBANY, May 11 -- Gov. Odell has practically completed the work of disposing of the thirty-day bills, so-called, left on his hands by the Legislature. But two measures remain undisposed of To date he has signed 731 Chapters of the Laws of 1901, and has vetoed about ISO bills. He will dispose of the two bills remaining before him early next week.

As soon as it was definitely known that the President would pass through Memphis, the men of that wide-awake city began to get ready for his visit. They appointed a committee, of course: that's the correct American thing to do on all occasions. The Memphis women quietly appointed a committee, too.

LONG BRANCH, May 11 -- Arrangements have been made for theatrical features at Pleasure Bay the coming Summer. It was given out some time ago that there would not be any performances at that place of any description, but now the matter has been finally settled that George Starling of New York, who has a reputation as a manager of Summer enterprises, will be in charge of the place.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 11 -- Negotiations are in progress which it is believed will result in the abandonment of the plan to build a new short line between this city and Wellington, to connect with the Wheeling-Wabash system. It is said that arrangements shortly will be perfected whereby the Wheeling will use the tracks of the Big Four between the points named.

The body of a litle girl, discovered by William Hannigan, a boatman, in the East River at the foot of Forty-ninth Street, South Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon, was identified as that of Lena Pensack, who was reported missing from her home, 141 Attorney Street, Manhattan, on April 6.

Leaving out the races for the America's Cup, with the attendant trials and preparations of the three big ninety-footers, the present seasson would yet remain, as far as promise is concerned, the greatest in the history of American yachting.

Gustive Heller, seventeen years of age, of 40 Meeker Avenue, Williamsburg, died yesterday morning under circumstances which led Dr. A.E. Cordes of 450 Graham Avenue to refuse to give a certificate of death, and to notify the Coroner's office.

LONDON, May 11 -- At a general meeting of the Royal Yacht Squadron in London to-day the Marquis of Ormonde was elected Commodore, in succession to King Edward. The Duke of Leeds was elected Vice Commodore.

There is a farm in Bronx Park where radishes and lettuce are being planted and turnips, cabbages, and potatoes will be cultivated in due season. Already roosters are crowing over the luxuriousness of their surroundings and hens are cackling about eggs laid on grounds which a millionaire could not purchase for love or money.

ALBANY, May 11. Gov. Odell this afternoon vetoed the bill of Assemblyman Cotton authorizing New York City to reimburse the attorney fees to taxpayers, who began action at the instigation of Controller Coler, to prevent the payment of confessions of judgment against the city. In his veto messase the Governor says:

Killing from vengeance and for gain were distinguished, and murder in a church was held to be an especially odious crime, especially if the church was consecrated.

Bellevue Hospital was in an uproar last night through the disorderly conduct of intoxicated women attendants. Patients were seriously affected, and the scene was almost a repetition of that of last Monday night, when even the care of a dead patient was Intrusted to outside assistance, so many of the hospital attaches being either intoxicated or in fighting mood.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 11 -- In the most remarkable athletic meet ever held between Yale and Harvard the sons of Old Eli defeated the Crimson at Yale Field this afternoon in the annual track meet by a total score of 57 to 47. All expectations of the prophets were upset by a long line of surprises and one intercollegiate record was broken.

The coal fields of the world are estimated to Contain an area of 471,800 square miles. Over this an area of 200,000 square miles is credited to China and Japan, while 194,000 is found in the United States. The remainder is distributed as follows: India, 35,000; Russia, 27,000; United Kingdom, 9,000; Germany, 3,600; France, 1,800; other countries, 1,400.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Since the appointment of volunteet lieutenants to be regular army officers, recently announced, there have been many inquiries concerning the failure to receive appointments by some of the candidates from the ranks who had undergone preparation and examination and were reported to have qualified to the number of about one hundred.

The baseball teams of Columbia and Pennsylvania played for the second time this season yesterday at the Polo Grounds, and, as on the former occasion, Columbia was defeated -- this time by the score of 5 to 3, a much more creditable performance for Columbia than the first game, when the score was 22-2.

LONDON, May 11 -- All rumors to the contrary, Maude Adams will not act in London this year. Her new play in the Autumn will be pure comedy, with a buoyant and charming role of varied expression for the star.

Through the breaking of a derrick at the City Hall loop of the rapid transit tunnel yesterday morning a steel bucket containing a load of earth which had just been hoisted and was swinging thirty feet above the bottom of the excavation was precipitated among the workmen. Most of them jumped and saved themselves, but the mass struck three.

To the Editor of The New York Times: My few lines in your issue of April 27 on the Catholic parochial school question having brought out a column of comment, 1 trust you will consider the importance of the question entitles me to the space for this reply.

Second Lieut. Hugh S. Stranson, recently appointed, with rank from Feb. 2, is assigned to the Twenty-ninth Infantry, and will join that regiment at Furt Sheridan. Ill.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Controller of the Currency Dawes to-day received a telegram from New Orleans announcing that the teller of the Hibernia National Bank was short in his accounts $36,000. The United States Attorney was informed of the shortage and the teller was at once arrested.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass, May 11 -- Harvard won easily from Columbia at lacrosse today in her last home game of the season, the final score being 16 to 1. Harvard was Columbia's superior in nearly every point of the game and the play was in Columbia's territory the greater part of the game. Harvard was strong in her passing, especially long passes.

LONDON, May 11 -- Money was abundant and easy to-day, partly owing to the bill brokers' indisposition to do business. Fixtures over May 17, however, were in strong request. Discounts were firm and were strengthened by the quotations at which the Treasury bills were taken, together with the possibility of the withdrawal of American capital from here, as the result of the losses in the United States.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., May 11 -- Attorney General E.C. Crow and City Counselor Bernard Schnurmacher left at noon to-day for Washington, D.C., where they will file a supplemental petition in the suit of the State of Missouri against the State of Illinois and the Sanitary District of Chicago next Monday.

BOSTON, May 11 -- A letter was received to-day by Walter Gilman Page, Chairman of the Montgomery Memorial Committee of the Sons of the American Revolution, from Secretary Wurtele of the Literary and Historical Society of Quebec. It is the most resentful communication yet received on the subject, the writer suggesting, "If you and your people are wise, drop this Montgomery memorial business once and forever."

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- An attempt to sell the confidential communications between the Attorney General and the Secretary of War in the Neely case was unearthed to-day by Chief Wilkie of the Secret Service. Information was obtained through Judge John D. Lindsay. counsel for Neely, in New York, who had received a letter signed John B. Dickenson offering him copies of the correspondence.

Leeuwenhock seems to have been fascinated by the marvels of the microscopic world, but the extent and quality of his work lifted him above the level of the dilettante. He was not, like Malpighi and Swammerdam, a skilled dissector, but turned his microscope in all directions; in the mineral, as well as the vegetable and animal kingdoms.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 11 -- Rowing enthusiasm was let loose to-day on the famous course on the Severn River, and the most critical oarsman present saw a race that stirred every drop of sporting blood in his veins. Or, rather, it would be more truthful to say two races, for there were unusual incidents in both the races between the University of Pennsylvania and the Annapolis Naval Cadets.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 11.-- After a long and dramatic trial, Charles R. Eastman, the Harvard instructor, to-night was acquitted on the charge of murdering his brother-in-law, Richard H. Grogan, Jr., while at target practice on July 4 last. The jury, after listening patiently for nearly three weeks to a tremendous mass of testimony, followed by two days of argument, debated five hours and a half before reaching a verdict.

MONTREAL, Quebec, May 11 -- Sable Islands a long, low strip of bare sand, lying in the Atlantic, one hundred miles from Halifax and fifty miles from the nearest point on the Nova Scotian coast, is to be reclaimed for the benefit of the storm-tossed mariner.
Mrs. LAURA LANCASTER VINCENT, wife of Gen. Thomas M. Vincent, United States Army, for many years a resident of Washington, died suddenly in that city on Friday. She will be buried at Arlington.

The vaccination of the members of the police force, in accordance with Police Commissioner Murphy's recent order, was continued yesterday at the various stations. The police of the Arsenal Station, in Central Park, were vaccinated by Dr. Newhor. The command consists of 131 men. At the East Sixty-seventh Street Station 130 patrolmen, including the Sergeants and the Captain, were vaccinated by Dr. Shields.

Mr. LATIMER, a member of the House of Representatives from South Carolina, thinks that there is no danger that the Republican Party will make appreciable progress in the South, and he is sure that none will be made in South Carolina. "The people of the South," he says, "are Democrats by tradition and inclination, and it is Democratic principles for which they stand."

CREEDMOOR, May 11 -- The range was Occupied to-day by the Twenty-third Regiment, National Guard of New York, under the command of Col. A.C Barnes. There were about 550 officers and men present, of whom 425 qualified as marksmen. The sharpshooter range at 500 and 600 yards was open for those who desired to practice and had qualified as sharp shooters last year.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is gratifying to note the agitation for proper street signs. I am an old resident of New York, and I don't remember when our street signs were as unsatisfactory as at present. If THE TIMES will keep up the agitation we may be able to have some reform in this important matter.

BUFFALO, May 11 -- To the visitor during these early days of the Pan-American Exposition it appears that the electric illuminations will form one of the most prominent features of the big show. In preparation for the dedication day ceremonies a thorough test has been made during the past week of the illumination system on the grounds and in the buildings, and the extraordinary effects have provoked unbounded enthusiasm on the part of the spectators.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The speculative fever that developed so furiously here last week, and which spread with greater intensity at the beginning of this week, reached a climax on Thursday that has left many victims collapsed, with pocketbooks and bank accounts exhausted, and with the desire to indulge in speculation very perceptibly wasted, if not entirely eradicated.

CLEVELAND, May 11 -- The attention of Col. Myron T. Herrick was called to-day to newspaper aticles about a movement started to bring about his nomination for Governor at the Republican State Convention.

All they knew was that the girl, with tears in her eyes, was demanding of the pushcart man something she presumed he had stolen from her.

ALBANY, May 11 Gov. Odell has vetoed the Raines Bridge bill which allowed an elevated structure on West Street, New York City. He says the bill, while made general, is really a city bill and should have been submitted to the city authorities.

The Republican Club has purchased the property now occupied by St. Ignatius's Episcopal Church, 54 and 56 West Fortieth Street, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues, and will erect on it a new clubhouse. The Church will be torn down and the congregation will move to a new church to be erected on the southeast corner of Eighty-seventh Street and West End Avenue.

Lowe, President of the General Federation of Woman's Clubs, is in the city, and when asked what she considered the most important issue before the women of the country said: "With the women of Georgia it is the question of restricting child labor. Upon this we are concentrating our best energies."

Ex-Mayor Abram S. Hewitt, John E. Parsons, and Edward Cooper were the guests of honor last night at the ceremony of the unveiling and the presentation of a tablet of Peter Cooper by the students and the Alumni Association of Cooper Institute to their Alma Mater. Aside from these, several hundred students and members of the Alumni Association and their friends were present to witness the presentation of the memorial.
LONDON, May 11 -- Stories come from Austria of the continued opposition to the Roman Catholic rule there, and indeed from throughout Germany.

WASHINGTON, May 11.-- Charles M. Schwab, President of the United States Steel Corporation, was before the Industrial Commission to-day. He said that the United States Company controls eight companies by owning their stocks, and that while steps are taken to insure the good-will and the co-operation of all these companies, each one is left to conduct business in its own way.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 11 -- An unknown negro, supposed at the time to be James Brown, charged with assaulting a woman at Springville, was shot and killed this afternoon by a crowd of white men near Leeds, twelve miles from Birmingham. The Coroner expressed the opinion that the wrong man was killed.

PHILADELPHIA, May 11 -- Rain interfered with the first dual meet between Pennsylvania and Columbia at Franklin Field this afternoon by making the track very heavy and keeping the attendance down to a handful of spectators. Pennsylvania, despite her loss of many of last year's point winners, such as McCracken, Tewksbury, and Kraenzlein, easily won.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., May 9 -- The Hon. Robert Bond, Premier of Newfoundland, is now on his way from London to Montreal, en route to Ottawa, to sound the Canadian Government as to whether it will oppose a renewal of negotiations between the United States and Newfoundland for the ratification of the Bond-Blaine Convention of reciprocity with the United States.

A decision by the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court which affects assessments of $172,000,000 on real estate was received at the Corporation Counsel's offices yesterday. The question at issue was whether an assessment on real estate levied by the Department of Taxes could be reviewed by the courts on the ground of "inequality of assessment."

It was announced yesterday that the National Civic Federation, the Committee on Conciliation and Arbitration of which held a convention in this city last week, will open permanent headquarters here in June. The present headquarters of the federation are in Chicago, and it is said to be the intention to have headquarters both in that city and here.

LONDON, May 11 -- The Royal Society held its only public meeting of the year this week, when exhibits representing the scientific progress of the year were discussed and the whole field of science covered.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 11 -- Halstead Lindsley of Harvard won the intercollegiate golf championship to-day on the links of the Atlantic City Country Club, beating in the final thirty-six-hole round Charles Hitchcock, Jr., of Yale. Lindsley won by 2 up and 1 to play.

After twice seeking death beneath the wheels of electric cars in Thirty-fourth Street, just east of Third Avenue, yesterday morning, a well-dressed middle-aged man, supposed to be Henry Schroeder, formerly a grocer in Brooklyn, threw himself in front of a two-horse truck, which was carrying four tons of Jute to the Chelsea Mills.

DEL MONTE, Cal., May 11 -- The President and his party have enjoyed a comparatively quiet day. They came here for two days' rest to prepare for the trying programme laid out for them next week at San Francisco. The President and Mrs. McKinley spent the major portion of the day in their rooms at the hotel.

SAN JUAN, Porto Rico, April 30 -- When Acting Governor Hunt, the other day, was asked to express an opinion on the statements made by Borda and Balbas, the Porto Rico Commissioners, in the United States, his reply implied that these gentlemen are not representing conditions here as they actually exist.

Ten eight-oared shells were out, representing a half dozen different clubs, besides several eight-oared barges and numerous fours, doubles, and singles.

Copyright. 1901. LONDON, May 12 -- Your Wall Street excitement has found little echo here. Noisy crowds shouted in the Stock Exchange all day, and in the Street for an hour or two in the evening, but the general market remained calm, and only in Glasgow did anything approaching the excitement of panic occur.
CINCINNATI, Ohio. May 12. -- Hahn kept the nine hits made off his delivery well scattered, and was given good support, in to-day's baseball game with Pittsburg.

The open century run of the New York State Division, Century Road Club of America, which was held yesterday over a new course from Brooklyn to Hicksville, L. I., and return, was the first large run of the season and it is doubtful if it will be surpassed by more than one of the dozen or so of runs scheduled for the coming three or four months.

Charles Whitmore, nineteen years old, of 354 Tenth Avenue, is lying in a critical condition in the New York Hospital with a bullet hole through his left lung. His wound was received early yesterday morning, while trying to escape from Policeman Suy R. Cobaugh of the West Twentieth Street Police Station.

PHILADELPHIA, May 12 -- Capt. De Ramey De Sugny of the French cruiser D'Estrees, who was taken to the Medico-Chirurgical Hospital last week suffering from typhoid fever, has had a relapse, and his condition is so critical that no visitors are allowed to see him. The D'Estrees, which is on her way to the New foundland coast, arrived here last Sunday for a visit.

NEWARK, N.J., May 12 -- While playing the Italian game of bowling, in which the ball is thrown through the air toward the objective, Tony Bucino hit Tony Galiano on the head. The act was not intentional, but Galiano became enraged, drew a revolver, and fired at Bucino.

The return of an artist from a stay abroad may not profoundly interest a nation or even a city, but it is a matter of no little moment to himself and his circle of friends. It is like the launching of a graduate of college into the real world after years passed in the microcosm where professors and youths of prodigious promise play their several parts unknown to the outer world.
President Morris of the Republican County Committee had a long visit with Senator Platt at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday.

DETROIT, Mich., May 12 -- Panned by a thirty-five-mile-an-hour wind, fire this afternoon swept the west bank of the Rouge River, in Delray a suburb to the south of Detroit, for three-quarters of a mile and destroyed over $800,000 worth of property. The fire originated shortly after 1 o'clock on the roof of the Salliotte Furgason lumber mill.
One of the Coroners' physicians was in a talkative mood the other day and told of some of the weird, humorous, startling, and pathetic incidents connected with, his business.

LONDON, May 12 -- During the last week the attention of the Stock Exchange has been so absorbed in Americans that little has been done on other markets to which notice can be called. When the storm of excitement was tremendous it was soon seen, however, that the worst was over. Good buying followed, whereupon the feeling was much improved.

The body of Willie McCormick will be buried this morning. The services will be conducted in St. Mary's Church, in Nelson Avenue. High Bridge, by the Rev. Father Mullin, who will say a low mass and use the ordinary burial service.

Leonard Severynse, thirty-five years old, employed as a letter carrier in Station R, Westchester and Third Avenues, the Bronx, living at 556 East One Hundred and Fifty-sixth Street, was removed last night to North Brother Island suffering from smallpox.

The Swentieth anniversary of the opening of the De Witt Memorial Church, at 280 Rivington Street, was celebrated yesterday with special exercises. The church, which is conducted under the auspices of the New York City Missionary and Tract Society, is Evangelical in character, and makes special efforts to reach the large foreign population in its neighborhood.

The circulation department of THE NEW YORK TIMES met a team from the mailing department in a game of baseball yesterday at Commuuipaw, and defeated them by a score of 27 to 17. The features of the game were Mr. Koechlein's pitching, Pankey's catching and batting, and a triple play by the circulation department team.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- A general strike involving directly 150,000 machinists and indirectly 500,000 men in metal working trades is expected to take place on May 20 unless some arrangement is effected in the meantime. This is the statement made to-night by President James O'Connell of the International Association of Machinists, who has his headquarters in this city.

WIDESPREAD DESERTIONS IN THE TURKISH ARMY. -- According to the newspapers of the Young Turkey Party and Pro Armenia, the official paper of the Armenians, published in Paris, the whole Turkish Army is in a state of imminent dissolution. Within the last few months the number of desertions is said to have amounted to 3,000 or 4,000 men, who, as a rule, have joined Albanian.

Mrs. Edith Heathmere, known to her friends as "Lady" Heathmere, and her sixteen-year-old daughter, Lillian, who were committed to the insane pavilion at Bellevue by Magistrate Brann on Saturday, spent the greater portion of their Sunday in confinement reading, a source of wonderment to the physicians and nurses, as well as those who called upon them.

Is the Georgia peach crop a profitable One? There seems to be ground for asking this question in view or the fact that statements frequently appear in the public prints that unless the railroads reduce their rates for transporting the fruit to market the peach-growing business will decline in this State.

WILLIAM DAVIS WILLIAMS, alias John B. Dickenson, was until Friday the private and confidential stenographer of Col. EDWARDS, Chief of the Bureau of Insular Affairs in the War Department. He was formerly secretary of Mr. BLUMM, a member of Congress from Pennsylvania, by whose influence, it is reported, that he obtained an appointment to the civil service, outside of the rules requiring competition.

If all goes well with the rigging and general farewell touches to Constitution the new cup defender should have her first trial under sail the latter part of this week. Capt. William Butler Duncan, manager of the flier, says that work is proceeding at a satisfactory rate of speed on his charge, and he expects to be able to test her merits on Saturday.

A gathering of literary men and women was entertained last night at the home of Miss Alice McGowan, the Southern authoress, at 35 Vernon Avenue, Brooklyn, in honor of the completion of "Mistress Joy," a historical novel of the eighteenth century by Miss MacGowan's sister, Mrs. Grace MacGowan Cooke, and Mrs. Annie Booth McKinney.

The first monthly handicap games of the New West Side Athletic Club were held on the club grounds. West Fifty-fourth street, yesterday and were witnessed by crowd of several hundred people. The summary:

In the crowded entrance of the big tenement house at 41 Oliver Street, about midnight last night, Frank Siciliano, an Italian barger, thirty years old, fired five shots into the janitor of the tenement, another Italian, named Lotido, who was taken to the Gouverneur Hospital in a serious condition.

Herman H. Hauser, twenty-nine years old, the Treasurer at Koster Bial's, was locked up in the West Thirtieth Street Station last night on a charge of disorderly conduct preferred by Joseph M. Evanson, who is the Treasurer of a theatrical company and is stopping at the Morton House.

-- While the President of the United States Steel Corporation was proving to the little boys on the east side that a college education is of no value, he might, it seems, have given quite as good evidence that the training acquired in technical schools and by practical work in shops is also worthless or worse.

LONDON, May 13. -- The Stock Exchange Committee has received a petition from the members of the Exchange in favor of the delivery of Northern Pacific stock being deferred until the old shares can be dispatched to America and exchanged for new shares, or otherwise, to make the non-voting shares "good delivery."

ELIZABETH, N.J., May 12 -- Mrs Ella Karcher, sixty years old, early this morning routed two men who had broken into her home on the estate of United States Senator John Kean. She fired one man out of the house and ran the other out.

The late Prof. Huxley, who was as shrewd an observer of men as he was of nature, once remarked, after falling into an indiscretion which annoyed him, that when a man says what he has no need to say he is sure to blunder. The truth of the observation will hardly be questioned, unless by the very few, if there are any such, who never say more than there is necessity for saying.

It is difficult to say with confidence just how much or little significance attaches to the lull which has succeeded the great and protracted activity in iron and steel. Among buyers it seems to indicate the return of conditions which warrant great caution in placing orders for future requirements.

A fire which was regarded by Deputy Fire Chief Dale at probably of incendiary origin, occurred at about 9 o'clock last night in the four-story brick dwelling at 505 Clinton Street Brooklyn, in one of the better residential sections of that borough. The house has been occupied for some time by Mrs. Mary Reed, who rented rooms to lodgers.

BUZZARD'S BAY, Mass., May 12 -- The marriage of Miss Christie MacDonald, the actress, and William Winter Jefferson, the actor, fourth son of Joseph Jefferson, took place to-day at Crow's Nest, Joseph Jefferson's beautiful Summer house. It was a quiet home wedding, with only a few witnesses.

The Railroad Gazette, in a discussion of the question of the rates of fare offered by the railroads to the Pan-American Exposition, sounds a note of warning against a policy which is calculated to attract a larger movement of passengers than the railroads can handle safely and comfortably.

Many employers of large armies of employes are now seeking to aid and better their condition. It is but the natural outgrowth of the system or industrial progression, and fair-minded men who seek in some way to solve the problem of existing conditions are dally making it a study.

The annual serviees of the Church Association for the Advancement of the Interests of Labor were held last night in Holy Trinity Church, Eighty-eighth Street, between First and Second Avenues. The Rev. Dr. J.P. Peters, rector of St. Michael's Episcopal Church, Ninety-ninth Street and Amsterdam Avenue, preached a sermon in the interests of the association.

Of twenty-six young people who set out joyously from College Point for a starlight ride in a wagon on Saturday night, two were carried home dead yesterday morning, five are lying in Jamaica Hospital suffering from more or less serious injuries, and all the others are nursing cuts or bruises as the result of a collision with a trolley car which crashed into the wagon almost at full speed.

BERLIN, May 12. -- Throughout last week the German Boerses studied the Wall Street situation with the most intense interest, but with great reserve, and in expectation of a crash. The Frankfurter Zeitung now remarks: "The direct interest of German speculation in American securities is at present not great, and German bankers have largely reduced their American holdings of late."

It was announced yesterday by Emii Boas, General Manager in America of the Hamburg-American Steamship Company that the Atlas Steamship Line had been acquired by the Hamburg-American Line. The acquisition of this property gives into German control the only English line of steamships plying between this port and the West Indies.

It is not surprising that Mr. CHARLES M. SCHWAB, the President of the new Steel Corporation, should find, the tariff "entirely satisfactory as at present arranged " or that he should be opposed to the Babcock bill which proposes to take the duties from articles produced by trusts, so called.

SAN JOSE, Cal., May 13 -- The President came to San Jose this afternoon from San Francisco and made a speech in reply to the Mayor's address of welcome. He ran down from San Francisco in his special car, arriving here just as the Cabinet train pulled into the city from the south. But he remained only for the formal exercises.

Justice William J. Gaynor gave his views on the making up of the jury panel during a dinner given by the Phi Delta Phi Club at the Hotel Marlborough last evening. Charles Thaddeus Terry, the President of the club, who presided, while advising the members to act upon the suggestions of Justice Gaynor, criticised the Bar Association, "the bigger club of lawyers further up in the city."

To the Editor of The New York Times: The articles published in THE NEW YORK TIMES in favor of the "canteen" are most sensible. As a former resident of Montana, and having lived in the neighborhood of Fort Harrison, Fort Assinaboine, Fort Custer, Fort Maginnis, and Fort Keough, I think I am fairly qualified to give an opinion.

LONDON, May 14 -- The Right Hon. W. St. John Brodrick, Secretary of State for War, moved the Government's Army bill in the House of Commons yesterday. The scheme provides for six corps, with 50,000 militia as a reserve, and increases the number of the Yeomanry from 12,000 to 35,000 men.

Yesterday's business in the outside market was smaller than that recorded on-any recent day. Further recoveries occurred in a number of stocks, although naturally the advances were not continued on the same large scale as on Friday last immediately succeeding the severe declines of Thursday. Only three or four stocks showed any considerable activity, the changes in prices in the rest of the list being accompanied by few transactions.

ROSLYN, N.Y., May 13 -- Arthur Schwinz, twenty-eight years old, was shot and instantly killed this afternoon by John Boush of this place. Boush fled after the shooting, and is believed to be making his way toward the centre of the island.

LONDON, May 13 -- Money was in good demand to-day in connection with the settlement. Discounts were firm. The big cash displacements this week in connection with the Russian loan will have a disturbing effect on the market.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, May 13. -- Latonia opened its gates for the Spring season of 1901 under most favorable auspices. The track was fast, and the weather, although slightly chilly, was bright and clear. About 6,000 were in attendance.

Florence Earl, seventeen years old, of 503 Bloomfield Street, Hoboken, was arraigned before Recorder Stanton yesterday on complaint of her brother, who alleged that she had attempted to commit suicide on Sunday by taking a liniment containing laudanum. Mr. Earl also said that he believed his sister was demented.

Dr. Richard E. Jahr, Thomas J. Kelly, and William Necker of Union Hill, who were recently convicted at Jersey City of conspiracy to defraud the Colonial Life Insurance Company, were yesterday arraigned for sentence before Judge John A. Blair, in the Oyer and Terminer Court.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 13 -- Ethan Amos Jenks, seventy-four years of age, a veteran of the civil war, died of anginapectoris at his home in Johnston to-day. He was Captain of Company I, Seventh Rhode Island Volunteers, and was one of the few officers from this State who received promotion for distinguished service.

LONDON, May 13 -- The representatives of Oxford and Cambridge Universities who will compete with the representatives of the Universities of Harvard and Yale in the international games on the Berkeley Oval, New York City, Sept. 21, were chosen at a meeting held at the Queen's Club to-day.
LONDON, May 14. -- The Marquis of Salisbury, speaking last evening at the banquet of the Nonconformist Unionist Association, said:

Restoration of normal trading methods -- transactions in heavily reduced volume -- a last hour dull, uneventful -- a quiet close -- these were the features in Wall Street yesterday. A few stocks closed with gains, (notably Union Pacific,) but the majority sold steadily down from the high points of the morning.
NEWPORT, May 13 -- De Blois Eldridge have let for Mrs. J.P. Cooke her cottage in Gibbs Avenue to Clement C. Moore of New York for the season.

Dr. Charles Rice, for thirty-five years a chemist in the Department of Charities of this city and one of the best-known apothecaries in the country, died yesterday at Bellevue Hospital of cancer of the throat.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The general session of the National Conference of Charities and Correction to-day was devoted to a discussion of the division of work between public and private charity. Controller Bird S. Coler of New York delivered an interesting address on the subsidy problem in New York City.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- A new phase of the pension attorney business has been created since the volunteers began to come home. San Francisco has become the scene of such active business competition among pension attorneys that within a few months the business has become organized and systematized on a large scale.

The purchase of the Atlas Line, plying between New York and the West Indies, by the Hamburg-American Line, from its previous British owners, is probably a more serious event for the commerce of the world than the purchase, previously announced, of the Leyland Line by Mr. MORGAN.

A mass meeting which developed into an indignation meeting took place last night in the Manufacturers' Trust Building, in Montague Street, Brooklyn, where the Brooklyn Committee of Fifty had invited a large gathering of influential citizens to take part in the subject of the tunnel extension plans, which have been held over in the Municipal Assembly and will remain dormant, it is feared, unless the citizens of that borough use drastic measures.

Justice Maddox, in the Special Term of the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday vacated a temporary injunction restraining the Justices of the Appellate Division at the Second Department from appointing a Commissioner of Jurors in Kings County under the Elsberg law.

PHILADELPHIA, May 13 -- The North American will to-morrow say: "Control of the Bethlehem Steel Company, as the first positive step in the organization of the Vickers-Maxim-Cramp shipbuilding combination, will probably be definitely arranged for this week. Negotiations to this end, actively begun ten days ago, have reached a crisis, and, in the opinion of bethlehem stockholders, the deal will be closed this week.

"There was another proof in the result of the Eastman trial in Massachusetts last week," commented a prominent down-town attorney, who has given up the practice of criminal law for the more lucrative civil practice, "that the average juryman cares practically nothing for the testimony of the so-called experts on all sorts of subjects.

PHILADELPHIA, May 13 -- The Choctaws and American Railways were the features of the market to-day. American Railways, with a rise of 4, was sent to 47; Choctaw advanced 6 points, to 72. the preferred following with a gain of 3 1/2 to 59, both new high records. The buying was largely by a house representing the Drexels.
PRINCETON, N.J., May 13 -- In a seven-inning baseball game at Lawrenceville to-day the Princeton 'Varsity team defeated the Lawrenceville nine by the score of 21 to 0. The score:

In the opinion of Sir Charles Tupper, ex-Premier of Canada, the improved canal system of the Dominion will be largely used by producers of the United States in the shipment of grain and other products to the Atlantic seaboard.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I should be glad of an opportunity to say how beautiful the beds of tulips and other bulbs are in the Park this Spring. I hope it may not sound too critical if I add that I wish the many and large bare spots of ground in the Park could be as well cared for in grass.

CREEDMOOR, May 13 -- A detachment of the Twelfth Regiment National Guard of New York, First Battalion, composed of Companies A.B.D.F. and G, under the command of Major F.C. Buek, occupied the range to-day. There were about 300 officers and men present, of whom 264 qualified as marksmen and received the State decoration.

A south-bound electric car of the Metropolitan Street Railway Company collided with a two-horse truck at Columbus Avenue and Seventy-ninth Street at 1:10 o'clock yesterday afternoon. Both car and truck were partly wrecked. Four persons were more or less injured, and the cars on the street railway were delayed for nearly an hour.

SHIRLEY, Me., May 13 -- The murders which have startled the rural districts of Maine the past few months are almost overshadowed by a tragedy in this town yesterday, in which a family of three was put out of existence and fire used to hide the crime. The victims are J. Wesley Allen, a selectman; his wife, and their fourteen-year-old daughter.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- In view of the movement initiated by the International Association of Machinists for the establishment of a nine-hour workday, May 20, President Gompers of the American Federation of Labor called a conference of the officers of the organizations particularly interested in the machinery trades of the country, the conference taking place at the headquarters of the American Federation of Labor in this city.

"Say, Clarence, why don't you get mar- ried?" asked Mr Lineburgh of 890 Gates Avenue, Brooklyn, of his son, while they were at dinner on Friday evening. "You're thirty-five years old now, you know, and it's about time you thought of taking life seriously."

HARRISBURG, Penn., May 13 -- Charles M. Schwab, the President of the United States Steel Corporation, was to-day appointed guardian of Donald J. Bowman, son of H.L. Bowman, deceased, of this city. The amount of estate is $600, and Mr. Schwab will have to give a bond of $2,000.

LONDON, May 13 -- The Stock Exchange Committee and J. Pierpont Morgan have come to the rescue of the situation, and the difficulty in which operators and brokers who have given calls for Northern Pacific for the end of May and July found themselves is satisfactorily settled.
Full reports of the fire which destroyed the pier of the New York and Porto Rico Steamship Company at San Juan on April 30 were received yesterday by the officials of the company in this city.

HAVANA, May 13 -- The Cuban Constitutional Convention met to-day in secret session and formally considered the report of the commission that went to Washington to obtain more definite information regarding the intentions of the United States Government. Gen. Sanguily objected to the report on the ground of incompleteness, pointing out that the commission made no recommendations.

ALBANY, N.Y., May 13 -- Under the escort of a platoon of mounted police and surrounded by a mob of 2,000 angry men and women, 200 non-union men were taken at midnight to the Quail Street car barns of the United Traction Company, which is the main station of the Albany city lines of the United Traction Company.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 13 -- The annual interclass Caledonian games which were postponed last Friday on account of bad weather took place this afternoon on University Field, and were won by the freshman class with 68 1/2 points. The other classes finished as follows: Junior class, 40 points; seniors, 17 1/2, and sophomores, 17.

The next time it occurs to Commander Rodgers, the new head of the Equipment Department of the Brooklyn Navy Yard to test his men in fire drill without giving them notice before hand, it is very likely that he won't do so. Yesterday Commander Rodgers ordered a fire drill, and it was much more of a success than he had bargained for.

ALBANY, May 13 -- Gov. Odell has appointed Dr. Frederic Peterson of New York City the medical member of the State Lunacy Commission to succeed Dr. Wise. Dr. Peterson was largely instrumental in the organization of the Craig Colony for Epileptics, and is President of the Board of Managers of that institution.

A sealed verdict was ordered yesterday by Justice Blanchard, in the Supreme Court, in the action brought by the Earl of Yarmouth against The Daily Telegraph Publishing Company to recover $25,000 damages for an alleged libel. This ordering of a sealed verdict was done at 5:45 P.M., after the jury had been out for nearly two hours and had failed to agree.

The action of the committee of the London Stock Exchange in regard to engagements in Northern Pacific stock seems to have been taken in conference with Mr. MORGAN, but it was clearly taken in pursuance of a sound policy, for which there is no competent authority in the organization of our own Exchange.

Christian Science was fiercely assailed by the Rev. Dr. W.P. Odell, pastor of Calvary Methodist Episcopal Church, at the regular Methodist preachers' meeting at 150 Fifth Avenue yesterday, the stated subject being "The Theology of Christian Science." Dr. Odell spoke much of the time with Mrs. Eddy's book in his hand, and quoted liberally from it in support of his attacks.

LONDON, May 13 -- Archbishop Lewis of Ontario died on board the Atlantic Transport Line steamer Menominee on May 4. He embarked seriously ill, as the result of pneumonia, and intended to stay in London a short time and proceed to Egypt. He was accompanied by his wife and a trained nurse.

Whether or not the organic union of the Leyland and Atlantic Transport lines of steamships is a matter of the immediate future, it became known last night that a virtual community of interests had been established between them for the improvement of the docking facilities in London. Improvements are to be undertaken which will cost probably $10,000,000, and which are expected to yield anywhere from 12 1/2 to 25 per cent. upon the investment.

Not in a month of Sundays, and perhaps not in a dozen of them, is it our blessed privilege to print an official report at once so edifying, so interesting, and so amusing as was that from Capt. THOMAS FRANKLIN, Acting Commissary with the American force in China, which filled three of our columns on Sunday.

James P. Cruger was the principal witness before Surrogate Thomas yesterday in the contest over the will of William Jauncey Cruger, his brother. The witness is one of the contestants who allege that Mrs. Mary Fambrough Cruger used undue influence in getting her husband to will her his entire estate.

The ingenious Sydney Rosenfeld came to the fore again last night with a new burlesque made known to an admiring public at the New York Theatre. The title of the concoction is "The King's Carnival." Of course the author has attempted to write a review, and he has succeeded more than ordinarily well.

Drs. Wildman and Pitch, experts in insanity of the Bellevue Hospital medical staff, made an examination yesterday into the mental condition of Mrs. Edith K. Heathmere, known as "Lady" Heathmere, and her daughter Lillian, sixteen years old, who on Saturday last were taken to Bellevue to have their sanity inquired into.

GRAND TOWER, Ill., May 11 -- The steamer City of Paducah sank in twenty-five feet of water five minutes before 10 o'clock last night, in less than five minutes after striking a snag and while backing out from Brunkhorst Landing. The bodies of 2 passengers who were drowned have been recovered, and 22 members of the crew, most of them negroes, are missing.

Commissioner MURPHY'S definition of the status of Mr. DEVERY is somewhat difficult to follow. He says: "DEVERY is a private citizen; he has no standing in the uniformed police force; he is a Deputy Commissioner."

We do not, most of us, sufficiently celebrate or appreciate the sudden and great expansion of the means of locomotion made possible by the substitution of electrical for equine power. Only consider the number of new and short and interesting excursions which can be made every Sunday, from the heart of Manhattan Island, compared with those which could have been made ten years ago.

When the stock market resumed business yesterday after the Saturday holiday, it was with a new, though, in light of recent developments, rather mild, excitement on its hands in the form of a report that the Northern Pacific fight for control had been transferred to another important railway property, namely.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Postmaster General Smith has given up the lease of the house he has occupied in this city since he entered President McKinley's Cabinet three years ago, and the gossips have it that he intends within the year to resign his portfolio and go back to journalism. Before the re-election of Mr. McKinley, Mr. Smith expressed a desire to leave the Cabinet, but was prevailed on by the President to remain.

Moved by the statement attributed to Justice Jerome, to the effect that a Roundsman in the Police Department eligible for promotion had told him that he could not get his Sergeantcy because "he didn't have the stuff." Police Commissioner Murphy yesterday demanded of the Justice the name of the officer in order that he might investigate.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., May 13 -- President McKinley returned late this afternoon from San Jose, where he went to deliver an address, and he will remain here until to-morrow. If Mrs. McKinley's condition is still favorable to-morrow, the President will carry out the arranged programme with some curtailment.
Siawson Hobbs have sold to the Atlantic Realty Company the plot of six lots at the northwest corner of Eleventh Avenue and One Hundred and Eighty-fourth Street, 150 by 100.
CHICAGO, May 13 -- Money to-day was unchanged, the rates for call and time loans being 4 1/2 @ 5 per cent. New York exchange was at par before the call and at 10 cents premium after the call.

LONDON, May 13 -- Frank L. Perley, manager of the comic opera company headed by Miss Alice Nielsen, has sold to George Musgrove, lessee of the Shaftesbury Theatre here, the provincial and colonial rights of Herbert and Smith's "The Fortune Teller," "The Serenaders," and "The Singing Girl."

POUGHKEEPSIE, May 13 -- Out of doors, in a woody spot on the north side of the campus, Vassar students presented Shakespeare's comedy "As You Like It" this afternoon. It was the first time a play has been given in the open air at Vassar, and also the first time a play by Shakespeare has been performed at the college.

WEYMOUTH, May 13 -- In weather conditions all favorable for a fair trial, with the wind fresh and steady, the course clear of all obstructions, and no tides of any consequence, the Shamrock I. to-day beat Sir Thomas Lipton's new yacht by five minutes and five seconds over a triangular course of about twenty miles.
LONDON, May 14 -- George Conquest, Sr., the playwright and actor-manager, is dead from heart disease.
It seems idle at this late day to try to argue with the Municipal Assembly as to the need of the tunnel and rapid transit project which the Rapid Transit Commission has submitted to them.

BOSTON, May 14 -- In the interval between the Horse Show and the cup race. Boston is turning her attention to horticulture and is about to open her new Horticultural Hall with an eight-day exhibition of flowers that is expected to surpass any such exhibition ever held in the United States.

The last regular meeting of the Bar Association prior to the Summer vacation, was held last night at the cluhouse, 42 West Forty-fourth Street. The only occurrence outside of routine matters was the introduction of a resolution by John Brooks Leavitt, which was almost immediately voted down.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Millions of American money are invested in shipping, most of it under foreign flags, in consequence of the inducements offered by the navigation laws to purchase and sail foreign ships under other flags than that of the United States, but the number of "straight" American vessels engaged in the Atlantic trade with foreign ports is very small.

ALBANY, May 14 -- One of the recent amendments to the liquor tax law has been made oppressive to persons dealing in liquors by some authorities construing it to require the registry of every person who goes to get a drink or drinks where liquor is sold. Deputy and Acting State Commissioner of Excise Clement says that the law cannot be so construed.

The regular annual meeting and election of the Actors' Fund of America was held yesterday at the Madison Square Theatre. Owing to the absence of President Louis Aldrich, who is lying dangerously ill at his home, in Boston. Antonio Pastor, the Second Vice President, took the presiding officer's chair.

The criticism of the special jury panel embodied in a speech which Justice William J. Gaynor made during a dinner given by the Phi Delta Phi Club at the Hotel Marlborough on Monday evening caused considerable talk yesterday among lawyers, and among laymen interested in the administration of justice.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Acting under the orders of President McKinley, Richard Rathbone, Assistant Secretary of the National Museum, to-day turned over to Miss Mary Custis Lee, as the legal representative of her brother, G.W.P.C. Lee, those relics of Gen. Washington that have been in the custody of the Government since 1867, but which were never really the property of the Government.

Edwin L. Chetwood, the receiving teller of the international banking house of Brown Brothers Co., and for twenty years a trusted employe of that firm, was arrested yesterday morning charged with theft. According to a statement given by the bankers, the shortage, which amounted to $20,170,50, was disclosed by the teller himself, who, believing it impossible longer to conceal his crime, threw himself on the mercy of his employers and confessed.

Justice Freedman, in the Supreme Court, yesterday decided that Municipal Judge Hermann Bolte must file papers which were submitted to him in an action brought by Philip Stromberg against Samuel Jaffe to recover money due on two promissory notes.

The New York Staats-Zeiturg in to-day's issue will say that negotiations are drawing to a close between the Hamburg-American Line and the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad Company to establish in conjunction with that transcontinental road a steamship line between San Francisco and the Far East, touching Honolulu, Yokohama, Hongkong, and Shanghai.

PHILADELPHIA, May 14 -- Arrangements have been completed for the meeting of the one hundred and thirteenth Presbyterian General Assembly, which begins here on Thursday morning. The 500 Commissioners have received their cards of assignment to their places of entertainment, and the Rev. Dr. William H. Roberts, stated clerk of the assembly, has practically completed the roll for organization.

GENEVA, N.Y., May 14 -- Count Mitkiewicz, who died at Asbury Park yesterday, lived here with the Countess for three years in the seventies. He purchased a stock farm two miles northwest of this city. The enterprise resulted disastrously -- for other people -- for, in 1878, he left precipitately, leaving bills, notes, and judgments against him aggregating more than $100,000.
ALBANY, N.Y., May 14 -- The United Traction Company to-day made its longcontemplated attempt to operate its electric cars with non-union men in opposition to the efforts of its former employes.

TRENTON, N.J., May 14 -- The American Light and Traction Company, which filed articles of incorporation here six weeks ago, to-day filed a certificate showing it had increased its capital stock from $2,000 to $40,000,000. Of the whole 400,000 shares, 250,000 are preferred and the balance common.

NEW ORLEANS, May 14 -- Philip Schumacher, paying teller of the Teutonia Bank, a State Institution, was shot in the calf of the leg while at work in the bank counting the cash previous to a meeting of the Finance Committee early this evening. When assistance came he was lying on the floor, badly bruised, a pistol near him, and money scattered on the floor.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Admiral Bradford, Chief of the Naval Bureau of Equipment, to-day gave out the following extract from the report of the board which has investigated the question of transmitting messages by wireless telegraphy:

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 14 -- The Yale Corporation held its May meeting to-day. The following appointments were made: Frank K. Sanders, Ph. D. Woolsey Professor of Biblical Literature, appointed to be Dean of the Yale Divinity School; Henry Wade Rogers, LL. D., elected to be Professor in the Yale Law School. The resignation of John E. Clark, Professor of Mathematics in the Scientific School, was accepted.

LONDON, May 13 -- The situation on the Stock Exchange yesterday was the most remarkable known, as far as Americans were concerned. There was absolutely no trading, the arbitrage people not dealing, and quotations were entirely nominal.
Official announcement was made yesterday of the formation of a company which will acquire the larger cotton duck manufacturing concerns of the country.

Officials were appointed and other arrangements for the annual Long Island regatta on July 6, on Flushing Bay, were made at a meeting of the Long Island Regatta Association, held at the Carleton Hotel, Williamsburg, last night. The following clubs were represented by delegates: Seawanhaka Boat Club of Brooklyn.
CHICAGO, May 14 -- New York exchange was quoted at 10 cents premium to-day. Money for call and time loans was held at 4 1/2 @ 3 per cent.

The nervous gentlemen who lie awake o' nights trying to think out some way in which the capitalists can be prevented from piling up all the loose money in the world, and so depriving these victims of insomnia of their fair share, may find a sedative in the study of the list of assets and liabilities of Mr. JOHN E. SEARLES, bankrupt.

CHICAGO, May 14 -- A decision just rendered by the United States Supreme Court is a victory for the creditors of the bankrupt shoe firm of C.H. Fargo Co. over the United States Rubber Company. This decision affirms the ruling of the Northern Illinois Circuit Court ordering the assets of the bankrupt shoe firm distributed pro rata among all the creditors.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The Navy Department to-day sent orders to Rear Admiral Kempff, acting commander of the Asiatic Station, to send home during the latter part of the coming Summer the ships Concord, Marietta, and Castine. This is in pursuance of the policy announced some time ago of reducing the naval strength in the East.
LONDON, May 15 -- A dispatch from Gen. Sir Alfred Gaselee, the British Commander at Peking, reviewing the operations in China from last Aug. 14 to Jan. 17. has been Gazetted.

The change in feeling at Parts toward the Germans which was so conspicuous at the exposition last Summer has had another proof in the conduct of the affairs of that rather stiff old institution, the Bibliotheque Nationale, toward the historian Mommsen. The venerable and very outspoken writer is at work in Paris, where a German sculptor is living who is determined to model his bust.

The Brooklyns opened their baseball series against the Western clubs yesterday at Washington Park by winning an eleven-inning contest from the Cincinnatis by the score of 8 to 7. With the exception of McBride, every member of the Cincinnati team found the Brooklyn pitchers for one or more hits.

The upward movement in prices on the stock market, which had been in progress since the panic of Thursday last, came to a sudden end yesterday, when, under the pressure of liquidating sales, not great in volume, but persistent in character, quotations broke sharply, the close showing heavy losses throughout the list.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- A cablegram from W.W. Rockhill, the United States Special Commissioner at Peking, received at the State Department to-day, reports the receipt by the Ministers of the response of the Chinese plenipotentiaries to the demand for indemnity. The dispatch indicates briefly that the Chinese represent an annual payment of $10,000,000 as the full sum that China can pay.

Detective Sergeants Gargan and Barry saw a man yesterday afternoon in an Eighth Avenue car carrying what they thought was a suspicious looking bundle, and they followed him. Later he left the car and was joined by two others, and the three got into an argument. As they started away, the detectives placed them under arrest.

CREEDMOOR, May 14 -- The second detachment of the Twelfth Regiment, composed of Companies C, E, H, I, and K, field and staff officers, non-commissioned staff, Hospital Corps, and members of other companies under the command of Major T.W. Huston, occupied the range to-day.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 14 -- President McKinley made his official entry into this city, the objective point of his tour, this afternoon. After being formally welcomed by Mayor J.D. Phelan, he drove through the principal streets, attended by a military and naval escort. The President attended a public reception to-night in the large nave of the Market Street ferry depot.

New evidence tending to cast doubt upon the contention of the State that Samuel J. Kennedy killed Emeline C. Reynolds, in the Grand Hotel, on Aug. 15, 1898, was brought out during the first day of actual trial yesterday of the accused dentist, who is now making his third fight for life and liberty before Judge Newburger, in General Sessions.

To the Editor of The New York Times: On Thursday last Wall Street was convulsed with a panic; the worst, it is claimed, ever experienced there. Prices that took six months to rise were lost in six minutes. Fortunes were swept away in a twinkling. A "corner" in Northern Pacific, which sold up to $1,000 a share, was said to have suddenly precipitated the disaster.

EL PASO, Texas, May 14 -- For several weeks the American colonists at Chihuahua and Parral. Mexico, have been greatly stirred up over burglaries that have been perpetrated upon the Americans. The matter reached a climax when Francisco Dael was murdered at Parral April 25.
NEWPORT, May 14 -- Mr. and Mrs. Heber R. Bishop and Miss Bishop will spend the season here.

PARIS, May 15 -- Anydeclaration of policy by M. Delcasse, the Foreign Minister, in the Chamber of Deputies, was not expected yesterday, but M. Castelin (Republican) insisted on an interpellation on the subject of the Franco-Russian alliance, and M. Delcasse made a statement in regard to the events at Toulon which was identical with the semi-official explanation cabled to New York at the time.
BOSTON, May 14 -- The loaning rate at the Clearing House to-day was 4 per cent, and New York funds sold at 10 cents' discount and par. Exchanges, $27,499,149; balances, $2,420,030.

PHILADELPHIA, May 14 -- Republicans of the dominant faction from every section of the Keystone State paid homage tonight to United States Senator Matthew S. Quay in honor of his re-election to the upper chamber of Congress.

It was announced yesterday at a meeting of the New York Palisades Inter-State Park Commission, held in the building at 346 Broadway, that J. Pierpont Morgan is the donor of the gift of $125,000 received by the Treasurer of the commission, Ralph Trautmann, a few weeks ago. Mr. Trautmann said yesterday after the meeting that Mr. Morgan's name was withheld from publication at the time of the announcement of the donation by his request.

Plans have been drawn for the construction of a twenty-five-story building on the site of the Fifth Avenue Hotel and the ground now occupied by the Madison Square Theatre and one store on the north side of Twenty-third Street.

TRENTON, N.J., May 14 -- Gov. Voorhees appeared at the State House to-day for the first time since he was taken ill. He appointed Dr. Laban Dennis of Newark a member of the Board of Health of the State. Dr. Dennis succeeds himself. Former Congressman Cornelius Cadmus of Paterson was appointed a State Prison Inspector to succeed M.E. Stappes of Jersey City, who died recently.

The annual commencement of Union Theological Seminary was held last night in Adams Chapel, at the seminary, 700 Park Avenue. There were twenty-seven students in the graduating class. The presentation of diplomas was made by the President of the Board of Directors, John Crosby Brown.

Mass meetlngs were held yesterday by the four classes of the undergraduate schools of Columbia University to decide upon a course of action in regard to the suspension of six sophomores for participation in the fight with the freshmen last Wednesday.

James F. Goddard, Chairman of the Trunk Line Association and one of the highest authorities on railroad traffic in the United States, died on Monday at his home, in Brooklyn, of pneumonia, after a short illness.

-- Trolley line construction, in this vicinity at least, is nowadays both intelligent and substantial to an extent that insures a satisfactory margin of safety to the passengers. The rails used are heavy, the roadbed is well ballasted, and where retaining walls are necessary they are almost always of reassuring strength.

Changes were necessitated in all the Columbia eights except the freshman crew yesterday on account of the absence of several of the men. In the Ithaca crew Boyesen took the place of Southack at No. 4, and Bradley continued at stroke in place of Stephenson, who was still absent. The entire starboard side of the college eight, with but one exception, was changed.

New York's victory over Chicago and the defeat of the Cincinnatis by Brooklyn yesterday gave the New Yorks the lead in the race for the pennant, a position they have not held in many years. The members of the team are in a jubilant frame of mind, and, while none of them had serious thoughts at the beginning of the season of finishing in the lead, all now have pennant aspirations.

BOSTON, May 14 -- Dineen's unsteadiness nearly lost the game to Boston to-day, but in the last two innings he played well and the home team won by a run. Crolius had his finger split by a pitched ball in the second inning and was replaced by Brown, who played a beautiful frame, his one-handed, catch of Burkett's long fly in the third being a feature.

Gen. James McLeer, commanding the Second Brigade of the National Guard in Brooklyn, received an order from Major Gen. Roe. commanding the National Guard of the State, calling out the Twenty-third Regiment of Brooklyn for service in the Albany trolley line strike, which has developed rioting.

Two Irish girls appeared at the police trials at Headquarters yesterday and told Deputy Commissioner Devery a story of abuse to which they had been subjected by Policeman Cavenagh of the West Thirtieth Street Police Station, which will probably cost him his position. When all the evidence was in Devery said that he would recommend that Cavenagh be "broke."

Lord SALISBURY'S speech in London, night before last, is calculated to make a disinterested observer "sit up." What he said, in effect, was that the war in South Africa had increased the prestige of Great Britain. What every disinterested observer knows is that it has dissipated and gone near to destroy the prestige of Great Britain.

The question as to whether a will left by Frederick Akers, the well-known coffee merchant, was canceled prior to his death has raised a series of complications over his large estate. In addition to this there is a possibility that another will is locked up in some safe deposit box.

BRISTOL, R.I., May 14 -- Capt. W. Butler Duncan, manager of the new cup de- fender, the Constitution, this morning saw for the first time the boat with mainmast and topmast in position and bowsprit in its place. The yards just received at the Herreshoffs from the Ogdensburg firm are hollow and of wood.

Forty-five entries were received last night for the Produce Exchange golf tournament, which will be held to-morrow on the links of the Englewood Golf Club. Three prizes will be awarded, and the competition will be handicap, with separate events for both eighteen and thirty-six holes.

The extension of the rapid-transit tunnel to Brooklyn was discussed by the Municipal Assembly yesterday. Statements were made by the Tammany leaders in the Council and Board of Aldermen that the plans of the Rapid Transit Commission would be approved at the meeting to be held next Tuesday.

Continued liquidation of ante-panic purchases was the predominant influence yesterday, nor did this process seem to be completed at the close. The resultant declines were brought about without excitement -- nothing beyond the normal.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 14 -- As moral suasion has failed to induce the Directors of the Pan-American Exposition to close on Sunday, legal methods have been resorted to. A motion was made in the Appeliate Division to-day for an order to show cause why the two Buffalo Police Commissioners, Charles Rupp and John H. Cooper, and Mayor Conrad Diehl should not be removed from office on the ground of malfeasance, misconduct, and dereliction of duty.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- A proposition has been laid before Secretary Root for the establishment of a transport line from New York to Manila by way of the Suez Canal. The Secretary now has the matter under consideration, and will probably decide upon it shortly. The plan is, not to supersede the Pacific transport line, but to have two lines, and the chief argument in its favor is that of economy.

Eugene Stanislaus de Mitkiewicz, whose picturesque career covered a period of nearly forty years in this country, died suddenly at his Summer cottage, 209 Sixth Avenue, Asbury Park, yesterday. He had been a sufferer from heart disease for three years.

CHICAGO, May 15. -- May corn, which has been cornered on the Board of Trade, and which has been rather inactive for ten days past, advanced to a new high price record to-day, when it sold at 60 cents per bushel. This is the highest price since the corner of May, 1892. A net gain of 4 cents was registered at the close for May, which was at 38.

WASHINGTON, May 15. -- James F. Ayres, twenty-one years old, of Port Arthur, Mich., a clerk in the Census Bureau, was found dead in his room at a hotel here this morning. He had been shot in several places about the body. Coroner Nevitt examined the body, and concluded from the nature of the wounds in the leg and arm that the shots may have been fired by some other person than the victim.

WASHINGTON, May 15. -- Ex-Gov.
