McCreary, who is a candidate for Senator from there, to succeed Senator Deboe, does not find evidences of the tendency toward the Republican policies and party that have been noticed in the South by Representatives Bankhead and Livingston, and he does not expect to see those policies adopted by any considerable number of regular Democrats, of whom he declares himself one.

M. Gaston Deschamps, the French critic, author, and traveler, who was this season's lecturer in the Hyde Course in French Literature at Harvard University, returned to this city yesterday from Washington, ending a supplementary lecture tour that, has extended to nearly all of the prominent cities of the United States and Canada.

The science of "rooting" as demonstrated by the trained undergraduate "fans" of Manhattan College in the baseball game between the Manhattan and Columbia nines at Jasper Oval yesterday, really won the game for the Manhattans. though it took all the noise that the successful "rooters" were capable of to grain that result.

PARIS, May 16. -- Another convocation of the French Senate as the High Court of France is promised by the unexpected return to this country of the Marquis de LurSaluces, the well-known Royalist and ex-member of the Chamber of Deputies. In January, 1900, at the time of the conspiracy trials, he was condemned, in default of appearance, to ten years' banishment for treason.

Yesterday's trading in the market for outside securities showed little or no increase in activity. Prices were irregular, declining in some instances and advancing sharply in others. In general the closing prices showed recoveries from the lowest prices of the day, the curb market in this respect following the course of the Stock Exchange market.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S " for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage, except in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes payment of the mortgage.

An elevator service run solely for the accommodation of one man, a tenant of the sixth floor, in a dismantled Broadway apartment house, is something that will give Broadway food for thought. It is, however, only one of several services that must be maintained for this one tenant alone.

BERLIN, May 15. -- Officials here, discussing the answer of the Chinese Peace Commissioners, say the fact of prime significance is that the Commissioners agree to the indemnities demanded, and the withdrawal of the troops can now proceed forthwith. However, not all the foreign forces will be withdrawn at once.

Two richly dressed women and a man in evening dress were eating a late dinner in the Hotel Flouret, Fifth Avenue and Eighteenth Street, at about 10:30 o'clock last night, when others in the room noticed that a violent discussion had arisen. Suddenly the women rose and ran out into the street, where they called a cab driven by Patrick J. Cosgrove.

LONDON, May 16. -- Some dramatic details regarding English action during the panic in American stocks have come into the possession of a representative of The Associated Press. It appears that last Sunday the senior partner of the largest arbitrage concern summoned a meeting at a private house, where J.P. Morgan, Lord Rothschild, and others were present.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 13. -- Yale won from Lafayette to-day in an indifferent baseball game by a score of 10 to 1. The Blue hit Willis without difficulty, but fielded in careless fashion, the outfield finding it impossible to hold on to easy fly balls. Cook contributed the only run of the visitors by two glaring errors in the same inning.

PARIS, May 15. -- Intense interest is felt in sporting and cycling circles in the bicycle match for the world's championship between "Major" Taylor, the colored American cyclist, and the French rider Jacquelin, to be held to-morrow at the Pare des Princes, in the Bois de Boulogne. The distance is one kilometer.

-- Having acquired some information about West Point and its officials which it would have been judicious to secure before its recent remarks on the subject were made, Harper's Weekly now manfully confesses that there was no foundation of fact for the theory which it offered as a possible explanation of certain unfortunate happenings at the Military Academy.

TENDER Is NOT NECESSARY WHEN EXCESSIVE DEMAND Is MADE. -- In an action brought by Charles M. Alien against Charles T. Corby to recover possession of a horse, wagon, and harness of the value of $150, which plaintiff had purchased from a third person, Corby set up as a defense a lien for stabling the horse and storing the wagon and harness to the extent of $225.

BALTIMORE, May 13. -- The market here to-day virtually paralleled the movements in New York. Early fluctuations disclosed a paucity of buyers, resulting in a quick and pronounced dipping of prices. About the time local values reached a level sufficiently low to present tempting bargains, New York took a swing upward.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The students of the Normal College and the College of the City of New York are about to pass through a series of crucial, harassing, and superfluous examinations, set in motion by two "legal" functionaries, called, respectively, the City and State Superintendents, to whom official life has been given by the Legislature in Albany.

Delegates from every State and Territory in the Union, from Canada and from Central and South America, assembled at the second annual American Congress of Tuberculosis at the Hotel Majestic, in Central Park West, yesterday.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 15. -- At the Theological School Commencement to-day Charles W. Merriam of the graduating class spoke vigoreusly on the question of the Catholic Church in America. He said that it was "un-American because of its unwavering allegiance to the Pope, the abuses connected with its auricular confessional, its attitude on public schools.

In the serving of an injunction against the Broadway Publishing Company, forbidding the further circulation of the May number of The Broadway magazine, a comparatively new point in legal procedure has been called to public attention.

ALBANY, May 15. -- So serious is the situation here to-night over the traction company strike that Gov. Odell returned to the city, and at 5:30 o'clock was at the Executive Mansion. Two thousand armed soldiers are now within the city limits. The streets are thronged and excited men, women, and children, and the otherwise quiet day terminated in bloodshed.

Isidore J. Dietz, fifty-six years old a salesman employed by the American Thread Company and living at Harrison, N.Y., was arrested by Detective Sergeant Cuff of the District Attorney's office yesterday in the Essex Market Court, on a bench warrant issued by Judge Foster, charging him with perjury.

ALBANY, May 13. -- Adjt. Gen. Huffman dropped dead this afternoon while in consultation with Major Gen. Roe. He was in the Hotel Ten Eyck this afternoon about 2 o'clock, talking with Gen. Roe on the strike, when he felt a slight faintness and went to his room. Mr. Rennie, one of the clerks in the hotel, went up with him to his room.

The Board of Public Improvements held an exciting session yesterday. The Tammany members divided into two camps, and each side wrangled for parliamentary advantage. Property owners from the east side rubbed elbows with wealthy residents or up town districts. President Holahan tried his best to keep order.

The members of the New York Produce Exchange, by a vote of 578 to 208, have rejected a proposition that no part of the income of the Exchange accruing after May 1 shall be paid into the gratuity fund. The defeat of the proposition has given rise to some talk as to the possibility of contesting tickets at the coming annual election.

MATTEAWAN, N.Y., May 15. -- Gov. Odell and his legislative party were greatly impressed with their official visit to the Matteawan State Hospital for Insane Criminals to-day. Dr. Henry E. Allison, Medical Superintendent of the State Hospital, greeted the party at the ferry as it crossed from Newburg this morning and escorted it to the institution.

The cast of the "Prima Donna," which was seen in the matinee and evening performances at the Herald Square Theatre yesterday, suffered from the loss of two of its principal members. Miss Lulu Glaser, who plays the title role, was compelled to retire owing to an injury to her right ankle, and William Cameron, who, assumes the comedy part of McNab, the Deputy Sheriff, was also not present.

Justice O'Dwyer, in the City Court, yesterday afternoon rebuffed a lawyer for having delayed the proceedings of his court for over half a day. The lawyer was E. N. Bullowa of Bullowa Bullowa of 31 Nassau Street, counsel for Hodosa Kantrowitz, a wealthy woman, who was being sued for a meat bill.

Details concerning the site of the new ten-story building which R.H. Macy Co. is to build on Broadway, between Thirty-fourth and Thirty-fifth Streets, were announced last evening. The buildwill have a total floor space of 750,000 square feet.

To the Editor of The New York Times: What a shame for the citizens of New York to read of the goings on at the abovenamed hospital. Employes, both male and female, are allowed to get intoxicated and indulge in disgraceful brawls and fights. What kind of supervision does this state of affairs prove?

PHILADELPHIA, May 15. -- Senator Depew, at the Houston Club to-night, addressed the senior class of the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania. His subject was "Practical Politics." He said in part:

CREEDMOOR, May 15. -- The range was occupied to-day by a detachment of the Seventh Regiment, composed of Companies A, D, F. G, and K, field and staff, non-commissioned staff, and hospital corps, under the command of Major A. W. Conover. Three hundred and ninety-three officers and men qualified as marksmen and recieved the State decoration.

LONDON, May 16. -- A dispatch to The Daily Mail from Geneva asserts that, owing to the Steel Trust having caused a rise in prices, many Swiss manufacturers have agreed to join Austrian and German manufacturers to effect an American boycott.

That is a very curious showing that China has made of herself in tumbling into the arms of the allies, so to speak, and accepting their first demand instead of haggling about it. It shows that the Oriental habit of haggling and bargaining, which we are almost accustomed to regard as an Oriental instinct, has been overborne by the circumstances.

There is an excellent prospect that the second crew races between Columbia, Pennsylvania, and Cornell which are annually held on Memorial Day, will next year be held over the Speedway course on the Harlem River, in connection with the annual Harlem regatta.

In his first message to the Legislature Gov. ODELL, expressed his regret that the devices by which the burden of taxation is successfully shifted from one class of property to another had so often defeated the efforts of legislation to relieve real estate of an undue share of the general contribution to the expense of government.

Cincinnati played a fast, snappy game of baseball yesterday at Washington Park. Bergen was the only man on the team to make an error, and this, a poor throw to head McCreery off at second in the seventh inning, allowed Daly to cross the plate with the only run scored by Brooklyn during the game.

Identifications of Dr. Samuel J. Kennedy by waiters and negro bell boys as the man last seen with Emeline C. Reynolds as she entered Room 84 of the Grand Hotel, where her dead body was found the next day, about midnight on Aug. 15, 1898, were materially weakened by the accused man's lawyers at the dentist's third trial yesterday.

The Tammany district leaders do not believe that Richard Croker will return to New York before July. The statement that Mr. Croker had booked passage to return May 31 came as a surprise to the politicians. Corporation Counsel Whalen said:

WASHINGTON, May 15. -- Anxiety about Mrs. McKinley has been expressed by many persons here since the news from San Francisco has represented her as recovering very slowly, if at all, from the prostration that overcame her at Del Monte.

HAVANA, May 15. -- A majority of the Committee on Relations, Senores Tamayo, Villuendas, and De Quesada, are in favor of the committee making an immediate report advising the Constitutional Convention to accept the Platt amendment. Senores Gomez and Silva are strongly opposed to this action.

ST. LOUIS, May 15. -- Fifty-two blackhaired, brown-haired, yellow-haired, and tow-headed children from New York Roman Catholic foundling and orphan asylums filled a special car at the Union Station this morning, waiting to be adopted. No red-headed children or children with freckles were among them.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., May 15. -- Miss Minnie Reynolds, sister of Dolly Reynolds, who was murdered in New York, and for whose murder Dr. Kennedy is being tried, was the victim of an attempted assault in a place known as Edenwald, in the Borough of the Bronx, this afternoon.

PHILADELPHIA, May 13. -- Practically the whole of the Philadelphia market followed the course of Wall Street, opening weak, dragging through the day, and rallying sharply near the close, Choctaw common was an exception, rising from 70 to 74 in the forenoon. The greatest suffering was in the Steel stocks and the Readings, the latter getting down to last Thursday's figures.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The item referring to Earl Gulick, the boy soprano, in a recent issue of your paper serves to draw attention to the nature of the boy's voice and the methods of training and using it.

All the terms have been agreed upon in a transaction which will amount practically to a sale of the Wool Exchange Building, at West Broadway and Beach Street. The deal is not a sale, in that the property will not be transferred, but negotiations are well advanced for the purchase of a majority of the stock of the Wool Exchange, of which corporation the building in question is the principal asset.

SOUTHAMPTON, May 15. -- Designer Watson has reached the conclusion that the hull of the Shamrock II, is susceptible of improvement, and there is reason to believe that alterations are about to be made amounting practically to the remodeling of portions of the boat. The preparations at the dock where the challenger will be placed indicate radical changes not connected with the spars and canvas, which have hitherto been blamed for the boat's shortcomings.

BRIDGETON, N.J., May 13. -- The body of Ellison Riley, a lad of ten years of age, was found in the Cohanset River this morning. It is believed his death was the result of violence. There is a bad wound on the head and the face. Coroner's Physician Diament believes the lad was dead before his body was placed in the water.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 15. -- After dinner to-night the members of President McKinley's Cabinet called at the Scott residence. where Mrs. McKinley is lying ill. They reported Mrs. McKinley's condition as unchanged. When she is conscious she recognizes the President and asks for him.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., May 15. -- Judge S. A. Robinson of the Superior Court to-day filed his decision on the motion to strike out certain sections of the causes assigned for the appeal of Edward S. Percival and Edward L. Norton from the action of the Judge of the Probate Court in appointing the Bridgeport Trust Company as administrator of the estate of George F. Gilman, the tea merchant.

One hundred and nineteen unhappy persons seeking divorces, nearly as many lawyers and at least three times as many witnesses rushed into Part III., Special Term of the Supreme Court, as soon as it was opened yesterday morning. Every person in the throng was anxious that the ease he or she was interested in should be tried first.

FAIRMONT, West Va., May 15. -- Six miners lost their lives, five were fatally Injured, and three seriously burned in an explosion at the shaft of the Georges Creek Coal and Iron Company at Farmington, seven miles west of this city, on the main line of the Baltimore and Ohid Railroad, this morning.

While during yesterday's earlier hours the market encountered a vigorous continuation of speculative liquidation, it became later apparent that a point was reached where capitalists were ready to invest; spirited buying carried prices up with a rush which lasted to the close. Reference to the report of sales and quotations will show how numerous and substantial were the gains scored.

London, informs us by telegraph that the negotiations for a Nicaragua Canal treaty are proceeding on the basis of neutralization as a sine qua non. If this be conceded we learn that England will waive compensation through concessions in Alaska, and will consent to the abrogation of the Clayton-Bulwer convention.
A meeting of the School Board for Manhattan and the Bronx was held at the headquarters of the Board of Education, Fifty-ninth Street and Park Avenue, last night. President Miles M. O'Brien presided.

TROY, N.Y., May 15. -- The situation with reference to the street car strike here is unchanged to-day, and the city is quiet. The railroad tracks on the bridge crossing the Poestenkill, at Fourth Street, were torn up during last night, and the rails thrown into the crook. This act was the work of hoodlums, and is severely condemned by the strikers.

It was Matthewson day at the Polo Grounds yesterday, and, as usual, the young Bucknell collegian carried off all the honors by another masterly session in the box for New York. In the minds of the bleacherites happiness reigned even before the start of the game. They saw Matthewson warming up in front of the grand stand, and that to them was sufficient.
CHARLES B. TICKNOR, at one time Auditor of the Wisconsin Central Railway, and one of the best-known men in railroad circles in the Northwest, was found dead in bed at Racine, Wis., yesterday.
A. Stevane Company of New York City, to manufacture confectionery; capital, $10,000. Directors -- Albert Stevane. Arthur Essing, and Herman Henschil, New York City.

Henry Burr, Superintendent of the Society for the Prevention of Crime, of which the Rev. Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst is President, tendered his resignation yesterday. None of those concerned would speak as to the cause of the resignation. Mr. Burr intimated that bad health was his reason for resigning.

Motorman John Quinn, charged with killing David Forsyth, the conductor of his car, on the morning of March 8 last, at Fifty-ninth Street and First Avenue, yesterday admitted on the witness stand before Recorder Goff, in General Sessions, that he killed the man, but contended that he did so in self-defense.
NEWPORT, May 15. -- A movement is on foot to make Sept. 10 a holiday here, in honor of the memory of Commodore Oliver Hazard Perry.

Confidence in the development of the beautiful in the future in this country at large and in this city in particular was the dominant note of the proceedings at the fourth joint annual dinner of the National Sculpture Society and the National Society of Mural Painters, held last night in the rooms of the National Arts Club, in West Thirty-fourth Street.

That element in Wall Street which is always seeking argument for depression professed to see in the decrease in merchandise export values for February and March a turn in the tide which had raised the country's foreign trade to such important heights, giving the United States a commanding voice and respectful hearing among all commercial nations.

The Jacksonville Relief Committee of the Chamber of Commerce and the Merchants' Association yesterday received a dispatch from William Mills, Jr., the representative of the joint committee now in Jacksonville, announcing the receipt of four carloads containing cots and mattresses. These are the cars which left New York on Saturday night with the additional cots and bedding for which requisition was made by the committee in Jacksonville.

It is really almost a National misfortune that the President's official progress should have been interrupted by a private disaster, which threatens to become also a bereavement. Mr. McKINLEY'S political instincts, which we may call his American instincts, are so sound that they had already been vindicated by the progress of his official tour, so far as it had gone.
ST. PAUL, Minn., May 16. -- The Pioneer Press to-morrow will say:

zSOUTHAMPTON, May 16. -- Workmen were busy all day long in repairs about the rudder of the Shamrock II., and the crew were employed in reburnishing her manganese bronze bottom with an acid which leaves the surface as bright and smooth as when she first entered the water.

Manhattan's baseball team disposed of Bucknell at Jasper Oval yesterday by a score of 5 to 2. Matthewson, New York's star pitcher, coached his college mates from the bench, but even the presence of this great player was not sufficient to bring victory to Bucknell. The score:

Taunted by Justice Jerome, to whom he had just declared that he would be a stool pigeon for no person who ever lived, "The" Allen, the veteran sporting man, charged with running a poolroom at 80 Sixth Avenue, burst out vehemently yesterday with resentment at the Justice's insiluations, and in a dramatic manner revealed a forgotten chapter of his life.

Under the fire of questions of Lawyer Robert M. Moore. Maurice B. Mendham, a Bread Street broker, was compelled reluctantly to reveal yesterday the complete history of his acquaintance with Emeline C. Reynolds, for whose death Samuel J. Kennedy, now on trial for the third time, is hold responsible by the State.

PHILADELPHIA, May 16. -- The Presbyterian General Assembly, which began its one hundred and thirteenth meeting here to-day, disposed of two important matters during the afternoon session. The Rev Dr. Henry Collin Mintor of San Auselmo, Cal, was elected Moderator, and by an emphatic vote of the assembly, decided to accept the "Peoria plan" of choosing standing committees.

As May advances, there are fewer fashionable people to be met in town. Yesterday the coaching and polo and other amusements attracted any number of people to the country. The Deutschiand sailed with a large passenger list, including Mrs. Hermann Oelrichs and her young son, Mrs. Henry Clews, Mrs. Stephen Peabody and the Misses Peabody, Mrs. George Kingsland, and Miss Kingsland.

NEWARK, N.J., May 16. -- Chief Justice Depue stated to-day that he had notified Prosecutor Riker to warn the proprietors of the Vailsburg Cycle track that they must discontinue Sunday racing. He also instructed the Sheriff to send deputies to the track next Sunday to see that the law is enforced.

CHICAGO, May 16. -- Jules Cambon, the French Ambassador to the United States, was the guest of Chicago to-day, and from the time of his arrival over the Pennsylvania Road at 9 o'clock A.M. until late in the evening, when a banquet given in his honor at the Union League Club was concluded, he was the central figure in a series of receptions and feasts.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The good common sense of your timely editorial on "The New Ireland" in to-day's issue will, I think, appeal just about as strongly to all fair-minded American citizens as it does to the expatriate Irishman of the most Anglophobiac tendencies.

AUSTIN, Texas, May 16. -- The largest domestic charter ever filed in Texas was brought here this morning by Judge Robert A. Greer of Beaumont, and was approved by Secretary of State Tod and placed on record. It is that of the J.M. Guffey Petroleum Company, with a capital stock of $15,000,000.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 16. -- At 8:45 o'clock to-night Mrs. McKinley's physicians reported that her condition had improved decidedly since the morning. Her pulse and temperature were satisfactory, and she was resting easily.

PHILADELPHIA, May 16. -- The market was very dull to-day, but many of the laggard stocks showed improvement. There was heavy buying of Un,on Traction, the stock touching 37 7/8 the highest for many weeks. Choctaw was buoyant, the common selling at 75. Philadelphia Company showed some activity, and finally got up to par for the first time since March, 1899.

ELMIRA, N.Y., May 16. -- The funeral of Adjt. Gen. Hoffman will be held at the family residence in West Clinton Street tomorrow afternoon at 4 o'clock with military honors. The Thirtieth Separate Company of which he was an officer for many years will act as escort for the funeral cortege.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am another one of the numerous people who dissent from "the praise" you "have given to Commissioner Kearny's now abandoned plan of placing street names at right angles to the streets they designate." That plan was so palpably confusing and annoying in my experience that it is a surprise to find any one defending it.

The one thing of real importance in the situation at Albany is that the military force of the State as well as all the available police force of that city are now employed in protecting the right of peaceful and law-abiding workingmen to earn wages which they are ready to take in return for services they are competent to render.

Boston detectives who came to New York armed with a Massachusetts requisition, honored by Gov. Odell, for the apprehension of Alonzo J. Whiteman, once State Senator of Minnesota and ex-Mayor of Duluth, who is now awaiting sentence for grand larceny, though out on ball, were compelled to return without their man yesterday.

A respectably dressed woman who gave her name as Mrs. Charles Foote, forty years old, applied at the house of Mrs. Frank Airy, 177 West Seventy-third Street, yesterday afternoon for board and lodging. Mrs. Airy keeps a fashionable lodging house.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The action of the council of the New York University in its reorganization of the School of Pedagogy is awaited with deep concern by those interested in education the country over. The gravity of the problem can scarcely be exaggerated.
The Spring meeting of the State Federation of the Women's Clubs of New Jersey was held at Boonton, N.J., yesterday, with 500 women present.

The turf has entered upon a new era of prosperity if the re-cords of the Morris Park meeting in the matter of attendance go for anything. For the tenth day straight, the crowd yesterday numbered not less than 7,000 people, and that, aside from the several special days when the number of visitors was much larger.
NEWPORT, May 16. -- Thomas F. Cushing and Miss Cushing are hero for the season. Mayor Garrettson has gone to New York. C.L.F. Robinson has returned from New York.

It is a trite observation that the more facilities for passenger transportation are multiplied in this city the greater the business for the old as well as for the new lines. The surface railroads very quickly regained all that the elevated roads at first took away from them and soon increased their traffic beyond its former volume.

The improvement in the stock market, which began on "Wednesday afternoon, following the sharp decline that morning, was continued yesterday, with the result that at the close of the day net advances were so general on the list that but five conspicuous stocks closed lower than on the preceding day.

Two witnesses called in a divorce case before Justice Glegerich yesterday may have a hard time explaining their affidavits when the District Attorney is through with them. The Justice, after satisfying himself that the two men had sworn falsely, ordered the records sent to the District Attorney.

Up on the sixth floor of the dismantled Cumberland apartment house is Col. Winfield Scott Proskey, a big man, something over 6 feet in height, and near him on a table lies a Colts army revolver. Never very far from call are two burly Irishmen, who know the ways of the Colt and how best to use it.

The geographical fact that Great Britain is an island must be borne in upon every tourist to the Continent of Europe. One who did not love the British went so far as to say that they got their news from Europe via America. In political matters this smart saying is evidently false.

CHICAGO, May 16. -- The Northwestern Elevated, the Lake Street Elevated, the Union Loop Company, and the Metropolitan Elevated are to be consolidated. Positive announcement of the proposed deal was made to-day by one of the men interested in it. In about a fortnight the leading interests in these properties will meet in Chicago and arrange the final details of the merger.

-- In The Animals' Defender, a vehement little magazine the name of which ought to be The Anti-Everything-in-General-and-Vivisection-in-Particular, there appears an amusing illustration of the curious inconsistencies into which good folks with a tendency to run to extremes are always falling.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- Late advices received by President O'Connell of the Machinists' Association indicate that above 25 per cent. of the employing machinists throughout the country have agreed to the demands for shorter hours and increased pay. Contrary to an opinion which prevails in some quarters President O'Connell says there has been no new order issued from headquarters regarding Monday's proposed strike.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I desire to thank THE TIMES and accord to it its share of success through the publication of my letter on Saturday last in regard to Washington Market.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 16. -- Judge Troutt has continued until June 5 the contest of Charles L. Fair on the will of his father, James G. Fair. It was intimated in court that by that time the remittitur from the Supreme Court in this case will be sent down, and if such be the case the contest may be dismissed.

The Civil Service Reform Association, through its Secretary, George McAneny, has requested the State Civil Service Commission to veto the proposed exemption from the civil service rules of all positions under the newly created Board of Elections. The State Civil Service Commission meets at Albany to-day.

PHILADELPHIA, May 16. -- It was persistently reported here to-day that J. W. Seligman, bankers of New York, have in hand funds for the purchase of the Bethlehem Steel Company stock by the Vickers-Maxim combination. The amount, it is said, will be about $15,000,000, and will cover all funds needed in connection with the deal.

ROCHESTER, May 16. -- Three indictments were found by the Federal Grand Jury late this afternoon against three prominent Rochester men. One is against Edwin T. Hickey, Democratic State Committeeman from the east side, and a member of the tobacco firm of E. T. Hickey Co.; another is against Fred Lang, a Custom House Inspector, and a third against Austin Rush, a cartman.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- The stock brokerage firm of Gurley Johnson in this city has failed, and notice of the suspension of business will be posted on its doors to-morrow. The open accounts make up a total of $40,000. The liabilities are $190,000. Neither member of the firm would make a statement to-night.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In regard to the communications of "R. B." and "A Sufferer," published in your esteemed paper on May 4 and 14, respectively, about the nuisance of people standing in front of those who are seated in the open cars, of the Metropolitan Street Railway Company, allow me to say the following:

Much valuable mail matter lying over night in Station O of the Post Office, on the first floor of the Cone Building, 122 and 124 Fifth Avenue, was endangered last night in a fire which did great damage in the warerooms of E. H.T. Anthony Co., on the floor above. It included mail for most of the great stores of the retail shopping district.

CHICAGO, May 16. -- Robert Waddell further proved his right to be considered one of the greatest three-year-olds of the country to-day when he defeated H.B. Durham's Operator in a match race at one mile at Worth. He was conceding Operator thirteen pounds by the scale, but won with comparative ease.

For more than two hours and a half a man floated in the bay last night, expecting every moment would be his last. Brightly lighted ferryboats went past him and he shouted for help. Tugs puffed back and forth, and tows were constantly passing, but he shouted in vain. Twice he went down, to come to the surface strangling and choking.

ORANGE, N.J., May 16. -- Elvin M. Holmes, a well-known hotel keeper of 835 Broad Street, Newark, is a prisoner at the West Orange Police Station charged with attempting to kill Albert Haynes, a Newark truant officer, who is a son of the late Mayor Joseph Haynes of that city. Holmes found his wife and Haynes at a West Orange saloon drinking beer together.

Two runaways in upper Seventh Avenue last evening caused a great deal of excitement in that thoroughfare, and resulted in two persons being slightly injured and brave efforts on the part of mounted policemen.

Edward Raymond, known to the "world of graft" as "Abe" Randsky, took the witness stand in General Sessions yesterday, before Judge Foster, and in his expressive vernacular, "Blowed on me pals, who done me dirt."
NEWPORT, May 16. -- Report has it here that Peter D. Martin of San Francisco will shortly return to Newport to spend the Summer.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "RS" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage, except in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes payment of the mortgage.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- Tangible evidence that Gen. MacArthur is prosecuting an active campaign of education in the Philippines comes to the War Department in the shape of a number of copies of a condensed "history of the United States of America." which has been published under the military Governor's direction, and is being scattered broadcast for the enlightenment of the Filipino race.

Yesterday was one of the dullest days that the curb market has had in a long time. During most of the session business was at a standstill, and the few issues which were relatively active were not sufficiently so to attract more than occasional interest. The same conditions that have led to the very large decrease in business on the Stock Exchange are responsible for the falling off in business in the outside market.

In times past New Yorkers have paid large tuition fees to Chicago for instruction in the difficult art of speculating at a profit in provisions. Wheat, pork, lard, and corn are better understood in Chicago than anywhere else in the known world. It was natural that inquisitive New Yorkers should apply to the bright and active minds of the Western city for a deeper knowledge of the nature and behavior of those staples.

In compliance with the order of Surrogate Fitzgerald, William J.F. Morrison produced in the Surrogates' Office yesterday an alleged will of Frederick Akers, the coffee merchant. This order was obtained by James P. Niemann, District Attorney of Nassau County, who declares that the will is in full force, although Mr. Akers had marked it canceled.

Thoroughly disgusted with Wall Street in general, and the Stock Exchange in particular, Louise Otterman, a pretty, seventeen-year-old girl, appeared yesterday in the City Court, before Judge Delehanty and a jury, to recover $400 which she had "dropped" among "the nasty, horrid brokers," who failed to make allowance for a pretty girl who needed only a fortune to make her happy.

LONDON, May 16. -- Inquiries made at the Bank of England to-day show there is no truth in the statement that the Bank of Paris and the Credit Lyonnais of Paris Tuesday and Wednesday withdrew u3,000,000 from the London market, and that it was thought probable that u3,000,000 additional will be withdrawn to-morrow.

The Republican County Committee last night authorized President Robert C. Morris to appoint a committee of conference on municipal nominations in accordance with an invitation extended by the Citizens' Union.

The Century Realty Company, which recently acquired the old Sixth Avenue car stables property, between Forty-third and Forty-fourth Streets, has added to its holdings in that immediate neighborhood by buying 69 and 71 West Forty-fourth Street, 50 by 100.5.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 16. -- This afternoon the President expressed the opinion that the public was entitled to specific information regarding the nature of Mrs. McKinley's illness and the treatment she was receiving. The bulletins, issued at intervals since yesterday, have been of the briefest and most vague character, and the public has been largely in the dark as to the character of the trouble.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., May. 16. -- Attorney General J.P. Elkin, for the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, has instituted equity proceedings designed to block the plans of Albert L. Johnson to erect and operate a continuous trolley road from this city to New York. He attacks the charter of the Philadelphia, Trenton and Lehigh Valley Railroad Company, one of the lines Mr. Johnson proposes to use.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- The committee which has charge of the preparation for the coming Congress of American Republics had a meeting at the State Department to-day to consider the programme of subjects. Considerable interest attached to to-day's meeting, as some difference of opinion had arisen as to the extent to which international arbitration should figure in the discussion of the congress.

FALL RIVER, Mass., May 16. -- There is much speculation concerning the outcome of a special meeting of the Cotton Manufacturers' Association which has been called for Friday afternoon to consider conditions of business in the print cloth industry and to take such action as may be considered necessary.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- The Secretary of the Treasury to-day bought $15,000 3 per cent, bonds of 1904 at $108.87. This is the first lot of fives offered under the Secretary's recent offer to purchase bonds for the sinking fund.
Bar silver was quoted in London at 27 3/8d per ounce and in New York at 59 1/2c. Mexican dollars at 48 1/2c.

PARIS, May 16. -- In the bicycle match today for the world's championship, between "Major" Taylor, the colored American rider, and Jacquelin, the crack French cyclist, at the Paro des Princes, in the Bois de Boulogne, Jacquelin won.

The question of vice in the tenement districts of the east side takes up a large part of the annual report of the University Settlement Society of New York, published yesterday. The conditions confronted by the society's workers are set forth in plain, straightforward language. The report is a scathing arraignment of the police, wh are blamed for utter failure to perform their legal and moral duty in the district.

The Twenty-third Regiment of Brooklyn was severely condemned last night at a mass meeting of the Building Trades Council held in Cooper Union to protest against the decision of the Court of Appeals in declaring unconstitutional the prevailing rate of wages and the State stone dressing laws.

A formal meeting of the holders of voting trust certificates of the St. Louis and San Francisco Railroad was held yesterday at the office of the Standard Trust Company. The meeting was held for the purpose of ratifying the action of the Board of Directors for an increase in the road's capital stock.

CREEDMOOR, May 16. -- The range was occupied to-day by the second detachment of the Seventh Regiment, composed of Companies B, C, E, H, and I; part of the field and staff, non-commissioned staff, and Hospital Corps, under the command of Major C.E. Lydecker. The weather was favorable, with a light 5 o'clock wind.

STRIKERS CANNOT BE SUPPORTED OUT OF A POOR FUND. -- The latest volume of the English Ruling Cases (23) contains an interesting decision on the right of those engaged in a strike to support out of a poor fund. A strike of colliers occurred in South Wales, whereby many men besides the colliers were thrown out of work.

BOSTON, May 16. -- The loaning rate between the banks at the Clearing House today was 4 per cent., and New York funds sold at 20 and 16 2-3 cents discount. Exchanges, $30,988,964; balances, $2,424,781.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Apropos of your article entitled "A New Ireland," in which you express astonishment that Lord Salisbury should express himself with such confidence "that the empire was undoubtedly safer and the cause of peace more secure," I see no cause for you to be astonished, for, as you state, sixty thousand "farmers" kept the British Army at bay, "but what farmers!"
BOSTON, May 17 -- The loaning rate at the Clearing House is still 4 per cent. New York funds sold to-day at 16 2-3 and 15 cents discount. Exchanges, $29,434,525; balances, $2,636,775.

The eleven passenger coaches and two baggage cars, with the Ninth Regiment on board, yesterday left the Grand Central Station at 11:55 o'clock for the Albany strike. There was a big crowd at the station, and there was real cheering as the train rolled out of the station. Everybody seemed to be waving something.
The following named Paymasters are honorably discharged as Majors, (additional Paymasters.) United States Volunteers only, to take effect May 16:

PHILADELPHIA, May 17 -- Following close upon the resignation from journalistic routine of Col. A.K. McClure that he might devote himself to literature comes the announcement that Archdeacon Cyrus Townsend Brady will retire from his pastoral charge to give his whole attention to his literary labors.

The articles that have appeared in these columns from time to time relating to the curious efforts of foreigners to construct the English language in accordance with its complex and inconsistent requirements have brought to us from an interested reader a document which we think should not be restricted in its circulation even to the widely scattered group for whom it is intended.

The present "life study" of Robert Louis Stevenson, by an old Edinburgh school friend, Mr. H. Bellyse Baildon, is laid down with rather mixed feelings. The volume adds very little, if anything, to our knowledge of Stevenson as either man or author: nor do we find Mr. Baildon's critical estimate of Stevenson's work giving us a new point of view.

That the conduct of a great library has become a matter of scientific training and experience is apparent upon a cursory examination of the reports of any central institution. The dominant note of the older reports was the acquisition of books of a scholarly nature.
WASHINGTON, May 17 -- As a result of a meeting of the general officers of the National Association of Machinists here today, the following address to the craft was drafted and made public to-night:

CECIL JOHNSTON, 501 East Third Street, Mount Vernon, N.Y.: "Can any one of your readers quote or tell me where to find a poem by Bret Harte entitled 'The Rose'? It is a monologue, describing a woman telling her romance to a poet. I have failed to find it in his volume of collected poems."

LONDON, May 17. -- At the first day's racing of the Gatwick Spring meeting today the Alexandra Handicap, at six furiongs, was won by Richard Croker's Harrow, with Lester Reiff in the saddle, and C. D. Marnes's Veritas, ridden by Benjamin J. Rigby, came in second.

George Crocker, the banker, who owns the four-story brownstone building 70 Broadway, south of Wall Street, adjoining the sixteen-story building of the Manhattan Life Insurance Company, 64 to 68 Broadway, on the south, brought suit against that company for equitable relief, claiming that the northerly wall of its building projects over his boundary line from six to nine inches.
CHICAGO, May 17 -- Money was unchanged to-day at 4 1/2@5 per cent, for time and call loans. New York Exchange was quoted at 15 cents premium.

This is a collection of essays, or rather, notes of personal experiences in Japan, strung on the general motive of a study of the Japanese stage, and of certain sides of social life, which seem connected with our idea of the stage; as, for instance, the institution of the Geisha.

AUSTIN, Texas, May 17 -- It was announced here to-day on reliable authority that the St. Louis Southwestern Railway Company had purchased the Gulf and Inter-State Railroad. The latter line runs from Beaumont to Galveston, a distance of seventy-six miles. It suffered great damage by the storm of last September, and only about thirty miles of the line is now in operation.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 17 -- The last will and testament of Major Robert E. Hopkins of Tarrytown was filed to-day in the Westchester County Surrogate's office. He left real property to the value of $82,000. The value of the personal property is unknown. His whole estate is said to be worth $500,000.

LONDON, May 17. -- Of the American publishers who have recently been making their annual Spring visits to London, only one, George Haven Putnam, who is now visiting Oxford with his sister, Miss Ruth Putnam, who is still engaged on her translation of Blok's "History of the People of the Netherlands," will attend the forthcoming Publishers' Conference at Leipsic.

NEWARK, N.J., May 17 -- The bankruptcy proceedings growing out of the insolvency of Carley, Rosengarten Carley, the Wall Street brokers, came before Referee in Bankruptcy Frederick W. Leonard to-day for a brief hearaing.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., May 17 -- Thomas J. O'Brien, a prominent Criminal Court lawyer of Northern New Jersey, died at his residence; in Western Avenue, early this morning. About 11 o'clock last night he had a severe hemorrhage and sank rapidly. He leaves a widow and two daughters.

To tlte Editor of The New York Times: Somebody has said: "Perfection is made up of trifles, and perfection is no trifle." So far as this observation is true, it is nowhere better illustrated than in the art of acting. The actor's success, in a serious play, must be measured by the extent of the illusion which he creates.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- Mrs. Lyman J. Gage, wife of the Secretary of the Treasury, died at her residence, 1,715 Massachusetts Avenue. Northwest, at 9:30 o'clock to-night, after an illness of nine weeks duration. With her when the end came were her husband, her married daughter, Mrs. E. F. Pierce of Evanston. Ill., and Dr. W. W. Johnston, the attending physician.

There was gloom in Willoughby Street. Brooklyn, yesterday over the failure of the stock brokerage firm of G. Edward Graft Co., of which ex-Fire Chief Thomas F. Nevins of Brooklyn is a member. Mr. Nevins is a close friend of Hugh McLaughlin and other Democratic leaders of Kings County, and his firm acted as brokers for the speculating politicians of Willoughby Street.

LONDON, May 4. -- A preliminary "skimming" of Mr. David Christie Murray's new novel, "The Church of Humanity," showed me that it was unusually good work, and I fancy that I said as much a few weeks ago. Since then a careful reading of the book has filled me with admiration. To tell the truth, Mr. Murray has of late years disappointed me.

WORCESTER, Mass., May 17. -- The New England Intercollegiate Basket Ball League was organized in this city to-day. Harvard, Yale, Amherst, Williams, Trinity, and Holy Cross were represented. The officers elected were: President -- J.A. Wales, Trinity; Vice President -- J.F. Jennings, Harvard; Secretary-Treasurer -- E. R. Whitcomb, Yale;. Executive Committee -- A. E. Brosmith, Holy Cross; R. W. Maynard, Amherst; M. B. Berking, Williams. A schedule will be adopted later.

The annual address to students in connection with the London Society for the Extension of University Teaching was delivered a fortnight ago at the Mansion House by Sir Mountstuart Grant Duff, who took as his subject "They Poetry of the Victorian Age." There was a large attendance. The Lord Mayor occupied the chair.

Samuel R. Callaway, President of the New York Central Railroad, resigned that position yesterday in order to accept the Presidency of the American Locomotive Company, which is to be the name of the new locomotive trust, which has been formed and which includes the largest locomotive works in the United States.

The story of the queer domestic relations of ex-Sheriff James O'Brien and his wife, Ella Abigail O'Brien, was told in the Supreme Court yesterday, on the trial of Mrs. O'Brien's action for a separation from her husband, to whom she has been married for twenty years, on the grounds of abandonment and non-support.

Gen. ROE expressed the sentiments of every law-abiding citizen when he said, in relation to the lamentable Killing in Albany of citizens who were by no means rioters, that if such citizens "continue to let their curiosity take them into disorderly crowds they must accept the consequences."

PHILADELPHIA, May 17. -- An alleged conspiracy to hoodwink and defraud the Government was unearthed to-day when Secret Service Chief Wilkie arrested John L. Sample, a prominent criminal lawyer of Camden, N.J., on a charge of conspiring with others to make counterfeit twenty-dollar Hamilton head silver certificates.

Decided strength developed in the stock market from the opening yesterday, and was so generally well maintained up to the close that final figures showed substantial not gains throughout the list. So great, in fact, were many of these advances that they suggested nothing so much as the days before the panic, when prices were wont to go up anywhere from 3 to 10 points a day.

THERE WAS A VALID GIFT. -- The Atlantic Trust Company, after the death of the late Joseph Richardson, sold 200 shares of the stock of the New York, Lackawanna and Western Railroad Company, which he had deposited in his lifetime as security for a loan, retaining the surplus, amounting to about $10,000, which remained after payment of the amount due.

CHRISTIANIA, May 17. -- Independence Day was celebrated to-day with great enthusiasm.

Few persons in America had heard of Maurice Hewlett before the publication here, three years ago, of "Earthwork Out of Tuscany." brought out by G.P. Putnam's Sons. The singular meditative and literary quality of the work attracted many admirers. The author has now prepared a revision of this book which will enable his American publishers, the Macmillan Company, to present a new copyright edition of "Earthwork Out of Tuscany "uniform with Mr. Hewlett's other books.

MAETERLINCK ON BEES. -- Dodd, Mead Co., who have gradually come to be recognized as the authoritative publishers of Maurice Maeterlinck in this country, are now, bringing out the poet's "Life of the Bee." The book is not technical, but meditative and didactic. For twenty years M. Maeterlinck has been a keeper of bees, but the notes and experiments he has made during that period are to be reserved for a more technical work.

Mr. C.F. Abdy Williams, the well-known English writer on musical topics, has just put forth a new life of Handel, which is likely to be of service to some considerable portion of his fellow-men. The aim of the volume is to steer a middle course between the large and exhaustive works of Chrysander, Rockstro, and Schoelcher on the one hand, and the small and sketchy popular biographies on the other.
LONDON, May 18. -- A remarkable state of affairs in the Servian royal family was revealed by official telegrams from Belgrade yesterday.

LONDON, May 18 -- The incident at Tien-Tsin on May 4, when some German soldiers guarding a German bridge across the Pei-Ho, at the south end of the British concession there, fired on the British tug Ewo, woulding two of her crew, is assuming a graver character.

In a fire which occurred at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon and destroyed the varnish works of John W. Masury Son., at 187-191 Plymouth Street, between Jay and Bridge Streets, Brooklyn, one man lost his life and two men and a boy were seriously injured. The fire resulted from an explosion of material used in the manufacture of varnish.

PHILADELPHIA, May 17 -- The market was quiet to-day, but displayed much strength. The chief feature was the rise in American Railways, which advanced from 45 3/4 to 48 3/4 bid, on the announcement of the completion of the deal for the merging of the company with the Electric Company of America.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 17. -- President McKinley described the marked improvement in Mrs. McKinley's condition to-day as a transformation. Perhaps he may have overstated the case in his elation at the prospect of his wife's recovery. It is certain, however, that Mrs. McKinlry's condition last night improved to an extent that fairly astounded the doctors, brightened her anxious husband, and filled the city with joy and thanksgiving.

The season of outing has at last arrived, and to-day, yesterday, and during the last week many spent the days out of doors. Quite a number of coaches went up yesterday to Westchester, with spectators for the polo games at the Westchester Country Club. To-day there will be a large fashionable assemblage at the Morris Park races.

The nominations to be voted on at the coming election of the New York Board of Fire Underwriters promise no contest. The old officers and committees have been renamed without exception, save where changes are made necessary by reason of death or business changes.

Solomon Loeb of the firm of Kuhn, Loeb Co. signed contracts yesterday for the purchase of the five-story American basement dwelling 3 East Eighty-second Street. Pierpont Morgan. No catalogue has been printed, but each print has a clearly expressed card attached to it, so that he who strolls may read.

There was no increase yesterday in activity in the outside market. The dullness which succeeded the excited conditions of last week continued, and no indication appeared that there was any disposition to trade on a large scale. Prices, however, were firm and in some cases showed decided strength.

Enlargements and extensions form the order of the day in church work. Auditoriums are being found too small, new churches are demanded in suburbs, and old places of worship are being replaced by new ones. At least $1,000,000 will go into church betterments in this ciiy this Summer, and this besides the new churches already under construction.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- The celebrated Itata case, involving a claim of $320,000 against the Government of the United States, is about to be determined by the Chilean Claims Commission. The commission has cleared its entire docket of cases, with the exception of this one, which, by reason of its importance, was left until the last for special consideration.

TROY, N.Y., May 17 -- Despite the trouble in Albany, but six miles distant, this city was never in a more peaceful state than at this writing. All interest centres in the outcome of the negotiations now progressing at the capital. During the day the only gatherings upon the streets were groups of delegates in attendance upon the State convention of the Order of Foresters, which has just closed its session.

It serves to recall the earliest of modern popular fiction, written when letter-writing was regarded as the most elegant of arts, and was the only means of disseminating news, save by word of mouth.

BALTIMORE, May 17 -- The market to-day was decidedly dull, with a somewhat easier tone. The only notable gain was in Charlotte, Columbia and Augusta first 5s, which advanced from 111 to 114. Washington Street Railway bonds broke sharply on rumors of probable default on the accruing semi-annual interest.

Elliot T. Barrows, who has been a member of the Board of Managers of the New York Produce Exchange for eight years and President of that institution during the past two years, said yesterday that he would not be a candidate for re-election. The annual meeting of the Exchange will probably be held June 28.

LONDON, May 17 -- Money was much wanted to-day in connection with the loan payment, though considerable preparation beforehand modified the anticipated effect. Discounts were easier. There is little disposition to do business until the effect of the heavy repayments due the Bank May 20 are manifested.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 17. -- John W. Foster, ex-Secretary of State, delivered the last of his series of addresses in the Storr's course at the Yale Law School to-day. His subject was the Clayton-Bulwer treaty.

Phillips, the rector of St. Gabriel's Reman Catholic Church in Hazleton, Penn., who came to this city in March to intercede with J. Pierpont Morgan in behalf of the coal miners who were threatening to strike.

Contributions continue to flow in to the Joint Relief Committee of the Chamber of Commerce and the Merchants' Exchange for the benefit of the Jacksonville fire sufferers. Nearly $900 was received yesterday, although the day was very generally observed as a half-holiday.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., May 18. -- Arrangements are being made for the amalgamation of the Catholic Knights of America with all the Catholic organizations of the country. The project was decided on at the last session of the Supreme Council of the order, which closed its fourteenth biennial convention Friday at the Southern Hotel.

Interesting ceremonies will mark the unveiling of the tablets in the Hall of Fame on Memorial Day, May 30. Arrangements have been nearly completed, and the programme will be characterized by appropriate patriotic demonstrations.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 18. -- In response to a notice served on the Superintendent of Police, by counsel for the Buffalo concert hall proprietors, who have been prohibited from giving both instrumental and vocal concerts, the Police Department has issued orders to the Captain of the precinct in which the Midway of the Pan-American lies, that the ordinance must be enforced on the Midway as well as elsewhere in the city.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., May 18. -- The weekly play for the President's Cup at the Park Golf Club to-day did not change the order of the standing for that trophy. The honors were won by Allan B. Laing. Charles A. Reed was second and Fred P. Taylor third. Charles W. McCuthen still leads for the cup, with Morgan T. Townsend second.

Plans for Pabst Grand Circle Hotel and Park Theatre were filed yesterday at the Department of Buildings by Architect John H. Duncan, who has estimated the cost of both structures at $450,000. The theatre building will cover a plot 120 by 100.5 on Fifty-eighth Street, north side, 100.6 feet west of Eighth Avenue, and has been designed to contain an orchestra, balcony, and gallery.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- United States Consul Edwin N. Gunsaulus, at Pernambuco, Brazil, has cabled the State Department the news of the death of his wife with a request of a leave of absence to return immediately with her remains to the United States, which request has been, granted. Mr. Gunsaulus is a native of Ohio.

LONDON, May 19. -- The British Foreign Office still hopes that Great Britain and America will be able to effect a reduction of the Chinese indemnity. It is stated that the German objections continue to form the chief obstacle to this end.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., May 18. -- A number of the machinists in this valley are expected to go on strike on Monday morning, several are already strikers, while some have been granted the demands they made. The Vulcan Iron Company has granted the demands at all its shops, two in this city and one in Pittston.
LONDON, May 18. -- "I have no intention of disassociating myself from the Conservative Party, but I have every intention of upholding my attitude and continuing my fight for economy."

Trading in the outside market yesterday was practically void of developments of interest. Not more than two or three issues showed totals of as much as 1,000 shares, and by far the largest part of the recently active stocks were entirely neglected. For the most part the issues that were traded in showed strength and ended the day with net gains.

LONDON, May 18. -- At the Covent Garden opera this week, though the social success of the new season is indisputable, the chief artistic honors were won by Ernst Van Dyck for his superb histrionism as Tannhauser and Tristan.

CHICAGO, May 18. -- The end of Phillips's deal in May corn caused prices to sag. This, with heavy receipts, caused much liquidation among the scattered longs in the corn pit. May corn sold between 49 1/2 and 46, and closed weak, at 4 points under, last night, at 46 1/2.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., May 18. -- While fighting a fire which threatened destruction to a five-story brick building, late this afternoon, Edward Green slipped from a line of hose upon which he was descending from the roof to a ladder and was dashed to death on the stone pavement sixty feet below.

NEWBURG, N.T., May 18. -- Seth B. Howes died at his home, at Brewster, yesterday, aged eighty-six years. He was one of the oldest circus men in the country, and was really father of the American circus. When but a mere lad, with his older brother, the late Nathan A. Howes, he crossed the Allegheny Mountains with a menagerie.
LONDON, May 18. -- The Duchess of Cleveland, mother of Lord Rosebery, died this morning in Germany, where she had gone for her health.

LONDON, May 18. -- The shock of the suppression of the journal which said those cruel things about the King was somewhat relieved this week by the tale of his expression of sympathy for a housemaid taken ill at Marlborough House and removed to the hospital. The girl, whose name is withheld, has become quite a national personage.

After being driven to Bellevue Hospital in two closed carriages yesterday morning, three sisters named White, all unmarried and belonging to a well-known Harlem family, were confined in the insane pavilion that they might be examined as to their sanity.

After careful investigation of the death of the Rev. Father Edward S. Phillips, whose body was found on Thursday night in a room of an apartment occupied by "Doctor" Kirk Stanley, at 730 Ninth Avenue, the police, who at first were convinced that the priest had met with foul play, now incline to the theory that his death was due to natural causes.

BOSTON, May 18. -- The money market continues to grow easier. The recent disturbance in the stock market has made funds much easier to obtain. Call loans are 4@4 1/2 per cent; time loans, collateral, 4@4 1/2 per cent; time loans, mercantile paper, 4@4 1/2 per cent.; Clearing House loans, 3 1/2@4 per cent.

Work has been begun on the public library building which Secretary John D. Long is to present to his native town, Buckfield, Me. The building will stand near the spot where his father kept a country store for many years.

PHILADELPHIA, May 18. -- Cambria Steel, the Readings, Philadelphia Company, and United States Steel were the active issues on the Philadelphia market to-day. Immediately after the opening Philadelphia Company mounted to 53 1/4, its highest price on record, but later shaded off. American Railways, on its one sale, showed a gain of 2 points over yesterday's opening, due to the merger with the Electric Company of America.

There was a pleasant little afternoon tea in an up-town business building the other day. It was served in two charming corner rooms, one furnished in the Roycroft style with the plain furniture made at the Roycroft workrooms, a rag carpet on the floor, and a general air of simplicity, while the other room was furnished in a more conventional style in mahogany.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 18. -- Yale freshmen covered themselves with honors this afternoon in the Sprang regatta on Lake Whitney. They broke the record for the historic Yale course by 6 seconds, defeated the fastest crew Columbia ever put upon the water by more than a length, and finally won the Yale championship by defeating the seniors and sophomores in the day's closing race.

ALBANY, May 18. -- The great railroad strike, which lasted for twelve days, requiring the presence of 3,000 members of the National Guard in the city, costing the lives of two prominent merchants, and entailing an expense to the County of Albany of over $30,000, is amicably settled, and it the agreements are kept there will be no trouble for three years at least.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 18. -- The Triangle Club gave its first performance of the season before a Princeton audience in the Casino to-night. A large number of visitors from New York and Philadelphia were present, and special trains were run to those cities after the performance.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 18. -- The Yale freshmen and Princeton freshmen nines played the seccnd game of their series this afternoon in a driving rain. Yale led from the start, and barring two innings in which Patton went to pieces, played a fairly good game. The players were unable to do themselves justice at any time because of the rain-soaked condition of the diamond and the slippery ball.

PRINCETON, N. J., May 18. -- The baseball game between Georgetown and Princeton was won by the latter to-day by the score of 7 to 6 after the most interesting struggle seen here since the Yale game last season. Neither side scored in the first three innings. Then some bad errors by Cosgrave in the fourth proved a gift for Georgetown, five runs being netted.

LONDON, May 18. -- Only three days ago a generally stanch Government newspaper announced that it had not found a man, Conservative, Unionist or Radical, who could express a favorable opinion of Secretary Brodrick's scheme of army reform, yet the House of Commons voted by a large majority on Thursday in favor of that scheme without alteration or amendment.

His fuddled fancy grasped the poetic simile, and, repeating it several times, he declared that "flowing bowl" was a "buooful idea."

Motions have been made before judge FOSTER in Part L of the Supreme Court for an order removing the prosecutions of certain keepers of "dives" from the Special Sessions to the General Sessions. The applications are based on the ground that property right is involved in the trials, inasmuch as a conviction would result in the forfeiture of a liquor tax license.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 18. -- Conductors and motormen on the Ithaca Street Railway threatened to strike to-day unless Frazier Scott, a recent employe and non-union man, was immediately discharged. The company heard the complaint, but had not decided the question to-night. If the request of the men is refused a strike will probably result.

Loans decreased $24,204,800, deposits decreased $25,864,200, legal tenders increased $1,578,000, specie decreased $2,871,600, and surplus reserves increased $5,172,450.

BALTIMORE, May 18. -- The local market to-day continued dull. Though proportionally there was a little more activity than was noticeable yesterday, there was an absolute absence of aggressive buying, even though a bull movement in Cotton Duck was expected. Numerous inquiries on the street relative to the plans of the new combination demonstrated the popular misapprehension as to the exchange value of the securities.

Those who saw him at the Gatwick and Newmarket races this week describe him as thoroughly enraptured with racing and horse breeding. First under "Johnnie" Reiff and then under Lester Reiff, Mr. Croker's five-year-old bay gelding Harrow, purchased for u1,000 in 1900, has within a fortnight won u1,700 in stakes.

LONDON, May 18. -- At the second day of the Gatwick Spring race meeting, to-day, Sir E. Vincent's Sheerness, with Johnnie Reiff in the saddle, won the Prince's Handicap for three-year-olds and upward, at one mile and a half. Seven horses ran, including the American filly Lady Massey, owned by Frank Gardner, which was favorite.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- The marriage of Miss Genevra Norris, only daughter of the late Thaddeus Norris of Philadelphia, to Lieut. William Alexander Lieber, U.S. A., took place at 1 o'clock this afternoon at St. Paul's Episcopal Church.

LONDON, May 18. -- By way of Paris this morning there comes a queer tale of a real community of action between the Chinese and Russian Governments. The annexation of Manchuria is, it seems, only a small episode in the vast enterprise directed against Western expansion.

CREEDMOOR, May 18. -- The range was occupied by the Sixty-ninth Regiment, N.G.N.Y., under the command of Col. Edward Duffy. The weather was showery all day, but wind and light were favorable for shooting. Two hundred and seventy-five officers and men took part in the practice, of whom 229 men qualified as marksmen and received the State decoration.

PHILADELPHIA, May 18. -- Contrary expectation, the Presbyterian General Assembly did not discuss the report, of the Committee on Revision, which was to-day presented to the Commissioners. A minority report was also laid before the assembly, which fixed next Thursday at 10 o'clock A.M. for the hearing and consideration.

During my stay last month at Cambridge, the Harvard students held a noisy meeting to protest against the "mutton monotony " of their food at Memorial Hall. In a samilar way, but with a more serious purpose, the-Kieff students, excited by the fact that one of them had been brought before the Justice of the Peace for misconduct in the streets of that city, also held a meeting.

On Friday and Saturday the intercollegiate championship track and field meet will take place at Berkeley Oval, and as in addition the bicycle championship races will also be held at the same time and place, one of the greatest carnivals of amateur sport that has ever been held in New York or in America will result.

Cable cars will disappear from the city, except for the short line running from the Brooklyn City Hall to the Wall Street Ferry, on Saturday night next, when the big ropes of the Broadway line will be severed and hauled out of the conduits, and by Monday, May 27, the entire Broadway system will be operated by the underground trolley.

LONDON, May 18. -- Money was quiet today, and practically unlendable. Consequently discounts were easier. There was a disposition to work cautiously, in view of the heavy repayments to the Bank on Monday.

The local yacht racing season for open regattas was opened as usual yesterday with the special races of the Huguenot Yacht Club, sailed over the club courses on Long Island Sound. Despite the unfavorable weather, all the classes filled, and of the fifteen starters, only one failed to complete the course.

Police Commissioner Murphy yesterday issued an order abolishing the rank of Deputy Chief of Police, and those officials who held that position, including Moses W. Cortright, Ellas P. Clayton, P.H. McLaughlin, and William W. McLaughlin, their seniority being in the order named, were reduced to the rank of Inspector.

It might perhaps be going too far to say that the contest in designing between the yacht builders of Great Britain and this country has come to an end, but it is certain that the vessels prepared to contest for the America's Cup in the coming Summer do not show a vestige of the National peculiarities by which English and American types used to be recognized.

A delegation of four members of the May Grand Jury visited Believue Hospital yesterday. The delegation was composed of Seth W. Johnson, Frederick F. Woodward, Louis P. Sondheim, and George R. Johnston.

Section 5 of the rapid transit subway is divided into two parts, the first running from Park Avenue and Forty-first street, through Forty-second Street, to Broadway and Forty-seventh Street; the second from this latter point to the Circle, at Fifty-ninth and Sixtieth Streets, Broadway and Central Park West.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- Brief funeral services over the remains of Mrs. Gage will be held at the Secretary's residence on Massachusetts Avenue Monday morning at 9 o'clock. Dr. N.D. Hillis, pastor of Plymouth Church, Brooklyn, formerly of the Central Church, Chicago, a personal friend of the family, will officiate.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 18. -- Mrs. McKinley's condition continues to improve, and Secretary of the Interior Hitchcock said today that he considered her out of danger. At 8:30 o'clock this evening Secretary Cortelyou gave out the following statement:

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 18. -- Although the gates of the Pan-American Exposition have been open since the first day of May, Monday marks the real opening of the great fair, when, amid imposing ceremonies, barbaric pageantry, military grandeur, and oratory by men known all over the world, the formal opening and dedication will occur.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- Gen. Chaffee's recent elaborate and complete analytical criticism of an article about, the atrocities committed by the foreign troops in China, which article included assertions by the writer that he had witnessed atrocities that Gen. Chaffee proved he could not have witnessed, has excited much interest at the War Department, and none keener than that in the Signal Office, of which Brig. Gen. A.W. Greely is the chief.

The police of the West One Hundredth Street Police Station yesterday made another of their weekly descents on Waldron's dance hall in "Little Coney Island." Broadway and One Hundred and Tenth Street. They arrested Louis Waldron, one of the proprietors, and six male dancers. These were locked up on a charge of violating Section 265 of the Penal Code, which prohibits Sunday dancing in public halls.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., May 19 -- The suit brought by the Patchogrue Bank against the Patchogue and Port Jefferson Traction Company to recover on two notes, one for $500 and another for $1,200, came before Justice William M. Smith in Chambers yesterday. Justice Smith granted judgment against the traction company for the $1,200 note, and sustained its contention of not having authorized the drawing of the note for $500 by its officers.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 19 -- Gen. J.C. Bates, who has just returned from the Philippine Islands, is quoted as follows regarding his dealings with the Sultan of Jolo, and the manner in which he obtained the Sultan's good will after the islands had been ceded by Spain:

ST. PAUL, Minn., May 19 -- The abolition of the canteen at Fort Snelling has resulted in a deplorable condition of thing's. The guardhouse is full, desertions are more frequent, and trouble of all kinds has come upon the officers in command, the police, and the citizens of St. Paul and Minneapolis.

Congressman J. Hamilton Lewis of the State of Washington, whose nomination for Vice President was favored by many of the delegates to the Kansas City Convention, believes that the Democratic National ticket in 1904 wil be David B. Hill of New York for President and Tom L. Johnson of Ohio for Vice President.

PHILADELPHIA, May 19 -- The annual meeting of the Jewish Publication Society of America was held here to-day. In the absence of President Newburger of this city, Dr. Henry M. Leipziger of New York, presided. The proposed amendment to the by-laws of the society authorizing the establishment of a magazine was laid on the table.

An eventful week for the Eastern turf opens to-day, with the prospect of a good afternoon's sport at the Morris Park track, to end on Saturday with the running of the second of the great races of the year for all aged horses, the Brooklyn Handicap, on the opening day of the Gravesend Spring meeting.

There was a roll of drums, a blare of bugles, and Brooklyn's "Ours," the crack Twenty-third Regiment, "returned from the front," marched into its armory on Bedford Avenue yesterday afternoon, looking as spick and span as if it had been merely on holiday parade. As the soldiers swung into the big drill hall there was a wild flutter of dainty handkerchiefs and a warm, welcoming cheer.

Robert Gibbs, fifty-two years old, Superintendent of an iron molding works in Pittsburg, Penn., and a man of considerable wealth, was found dead in his room at 257 West Twenty-second Street, at 6 o'clock last evening. He had been asphyxiated by gas. The case was reported to the Coroner's office as one of suicide, but investigation is thought to show that the death was accidental.
On the Stock Exchange for the week ended Saturday, May 18, total transactions included 6,249,044 shares of stock, $21,190,000 bonds, including $24,500 Government and $7,000 State bonds.

BALTIMORE, Md., May 19 -- The love and respect in which the Rev. Dr. Babcock was held by the people of Baltimore were shown here to-day not only in the Presbyterian churches, but in nearly all the churches of Protestant denominations.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- President James O'Connell of the machinists, said to-day that he would not be surprised if 50,000 men "took, a holiday" to-morrow. "It is very difficult to estimate," he added, "and that is only approximate. I don't predict a protracted strike of a general character, and I think the great majority of the firms will be with the organization by the end of the week."

In the presence of a large congregation in the Church of Our Lady of Lourdes, Aberdeen Street and Broadway, Brooklyn, Morris Lavery, a thirteen-year-old boy, who has been unable to walk without crutches for eight years, yesterday threw away his crutches and walked about the church. His restoration is attributed to the holy water and prayers at the shrine of the church.
Both the Mason Builders' Association and the Bricklayers' Unions said yesterday that to-day will prove whether the general shut-down ordered by the mason builders is a success or a fizzle.

PHILADELPHIA, May 19 -- The Rev. Dr. J. Milton Greene, now stationed in Havana but formerly of San Juan, Porto Rico, where he organized Presbyterian missions, created a profound sensation in an address he delivered here this afternoon by severely criticising the conduct of United States soldiers in Porto Rico.

BERLIN, May 19 -- The weekly financial reviews all devote large space to Wall Street and the reflex influence here, admitting that business on the German Boerses was dominated wholly by New York last week, no department showing animation and transactions reaching only a minimum.

ALBANY, May 19 -- E. Le Roy Smith and William Walsh, the two victims of the strike who were shot by National Guardsmen, were buried this afternoon, but the pouring rain kept away the thousands of sightseers that otherwise would have attended. The funeral of Mr. Smith was devoid of incident, except that it was attended by city officials and Directors of the street railway people.

BOSTON, Mass., May 19 -- The general dreariness of Sunday with its accompanying rain, did not prevent hundreds of curious sightseers from visiting the Atlantic works, in East Boston to-day, to see the yacht Independence as she lay moored in the slip there.

Supreme Court Justice William J. Gaynor addressed the members of the Brooklyn Philosophical Association in the Long Island Business College on South Eighth Street, Williamsburg, yesterday afternoon. His subject was "The Charter of the City of New York; What Can Be Done Under It."
