Meetings of the different lodges of the New York District of the International Association of Machinists were held yesterday in various halls in New York and Brooklyn to hear final reports on the action of employers regarding their demands and the probable extent of the strike which is to go into effect to-day.

CHICAGO, Ill., May 19 -- A.V. Freeman is alive at Marinette, Wis., across the river from Menominee, Mich., and says he cannot account for the story of his death in New York. He has not been there for some time.

PHILADELPHIA, May 19 -- The custom of having visiting Commissioners fill the Presbyterian pulpits on Sunday in the city where the General Assembly is being held was strictly adhered to to-day. There probably was not a Presbyterian Church in the city that did not have one or more of the visitors at its services.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 19 -- Mrs. McKinley's condition was so far improved this evening that she was able to sit up a short time. This welcome news was given out shortly after 5 o'clock.

YOKOHAMA, May 19 -- According to advices from Seoul, the Korean Government has leased to Japan 450 acres of land to form a settlement at Mesampho.

Most signs augur continuance of cheerful sentiment in Wall Street. Current crop news, trade returns, traffic reports, and other routine data all favor resumption of the movement so rudely halted by the panic. Nothing is more significant of the return to optimism than the prevalence once more of rose-hued rumors and the willingness of speculators to give them attentive hearing.

The apparent coincidence growing out of cable dispatches from Naples, Italy, Saturday announcing the death of two American clergymen in that city has been explained. One of these dispatches, received by The Associated Press, said that "the Rev. Dr. Maltie of Davenport, Iowa," had committed suicide while an inmate of the International Hospital by severing an artery of his wrist and taking corrosive sublimate.

LONDON, May 19 -- We have had an exciting week, and although calmer now we are by no means easy in our minds. Something like stupor overtook the city when on Monday morning the announcement appeared that the Stock Exchange Committee had interfered to protect short sellers of Northern Pacific shares from execution and at the same time fixing prices at which bargains could be continued to the end of the month's settlement.

ITHACA, May 20 -- Pennsylvania and Cornell have agreed upon George Sargent of the University of Pennsylvania to referee the Pennsylvania-Columbia-Cornell boat race to be held here on Memorial Day, and the name is now with Columbia for her approval or disapproval. Mr. Sargent was one or the Quakers' greatest oarsmen, and now resides in Elmira.

Prom the Archbishops, it is planned to elect a metropolitan, who shall be the executive and constitutional leader of the Church in America.

What he did was to tell his hearers to take a lesson from the United States and attend to their home market first, devoting only surplus energies and resources to the acquisition of foreign markets.

CONTRACT OF SALE OP A LUNCH WAGON -- Robert M. Love and Amanda Love, vendees in a written contract for the sale of a lunch wagon, contended that the sale was made upon condition that the vendor, Ephraim Hamel, would not maintain a lunch wagon in the City of Ithaca or sell one to anybody else to be operated there.

PHILADELPHIA, May 20 -- The market was dull and narrow with the exception of the coal shares. The only life shown was in Cambria Steel and the Readings. Philadelphia houses were large buyers of Readings, notably the common and second preferred. The Street believes an early dividend on the latter will be realized.

PHILADELPHIA, May 20 -- With to-day's sessions the actual work of the Presbyterian General Assembly began. The report of the Revision Committee having been made the special order for Thursday and thereafter, a change was made in the regular order so that reports of special committees and church boards might be submitted and acted upon before the assembly proceeded to discuss revision.

RYDE, Isle of Wight, May 20 -- The two Shamrocks, in a trial of the challenger for the America's Cup, started this morning for a race over an open sea course, the first leg of which is a beat from Calshot Castle to a mark outside the Nab Lightship. The wind was steady from the east and was blowing a club topsail breeze.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., May 20 -- The cup defender Columbia arrived here this afternoon and dropped anchor off the Hawkins yard. Charles Bancker's sloop yacht Hebe was launched from the marine railway at the Woods yard after receiving an overhauling. J. Roger Maxwell's thirty-footer Oiseau has been slid from her Winter berth at the same yard after undergoing repairs.

CHICAGO, May 20. -- The machinists' strike in the Western and Central States is far from a general movement. In this city there are less than 100 men out. In St. Louis there is no sign of a strike, as is also the case in Columbus, Ohio. About 150 men are out in Indianapolis, but among these are none of the railroad or engine works employes.

The unseasonable weather has proved detrimental to many outing parties which had been planned. Down on the seacoast there has been a chill wind and rough weather. The coach Pioneer, however, went out yesterday. The races and the Westchester polo game were well patronized, particularly the latter, in which society takes an absorbing interest.

Announcement is made in insurance circles of the decision of the United States Steel Corporation to carry its own insurance by the maintenance of an underwriting' fund supplied by assessments on the plants of the constituent companies of the trust. The Carnegie and Federal Steel properties have carried their own insurance previously, while National Tube insurance has been carried by mutuals.

Army. Col. Albert L. Mills, Superintendent of the Military Academy, will proceed to Washington and report to the Adjutant General for a consultation on official business pertaining to the Military Academy.

The permanent organization of the Greater New York Democracy was formed last evening in Cooper Union. A platform was adopted, and all the speakers arraigned Tammany Hall and Richard Croker. There were hearty cheers for David B. Hill and a long-continued demonstration when John C. Sheehan offered a routine resolution.

The general strike of machinists throughout the United States for the nine-hour work day, with no diminution from the present rate of wages, went into effect yesterday morning, and was more or less generally observed. Of the 150,000 machinists, union and non-union men, in the country, it was estimated that between 40,000 and 60,000 quit work.

The latest piece of evidence we have about the effect upon the physical and moral welfare of the army of the abolition of the canteen comes in the dispatch we printed yesterday from Fort Snelling, Minnesota. The fort is the headquarters of the Eighth Infantry.

NEW ORLEANS, La., May 20. -- At only one establishment here, so far as reported, was there any trouble growing out of the demands of the machinists. That was at the Gardner Motor Works, where about seventy-five men are employed. Employers here have generally made concessions to the machinists.

BRISTOL, R.I., May 20 -- The Constitution is still an untried craft. All day long she swung to her moorings while Capt. W. Butler Duncan paced the quarter deck of the Mount Morris and sought for some sign of a kindly sail-drying sun that never came. The rain ceased early this morning, but the northeasterly wind was laden with dampness all day, and no chance offered to take the Constitution out for her builder's trial.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Apropos of the question "How is it that New York City, boasting of a progressive and enlightened population, allows its Government to be controlled by such a man as Croker?" the remarks of The London Spectator anent the power of Tammany Hall are enlightening to a remarkable degree.

The little block bounded by Trinity Place, Thames, Temple, and Cedar Streets, at the rear of the Boreel Building, has become a bone of contention between large real estate interests -- the Central Realty Bond and Trust Company on the one hand, and Frederick Ayer of Boston, principal owner, in the Trinity Building, on the other.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 20 -- Although Mrs. McKinley's condition has greatly improved, the physicians have named a week or ten days as the shortest possible time in which she can gather strength to make the trip across the Continent. The immediate members of the Presidential party will therefore remain here for that length of time, though it is probable that the others will leave for the East during the present week.
H.R. Drew Co. have sold to the Sterling Realty Company the two four-story dwellings 44 and 46 West Twenty-fifth Street, 53 by 98.9.

Disaster on a huge scale rewarded the betting crowd that made the trip to the Morris Park race track yesterday, for straight through the day not a single favorite was successful, the nearest thing to a winning choice being when in the fifth event The Rhymer, at odds only a fraction of a point longer that those against the public favorite, Arthur Featherstone's Black Fox, galloped home in front, winning easily by two lengths.

Justice Jerome, with two representatives of the Committee of Fifteen, appeared at the West Thirtieth Street Station House last night just before the twelve-o'clock platoon was about to be turned out by Capt. Flood.

ELMIRA, N.Y., May 20. -- All of the machinists and boilermakers employed in the Lackawanna Railroad shops here struck to-day. The machinists in the Payne Engine Works and I.B. Coleman's foundry also went out, making 200 in all.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Acting Secretary of State Hill has been laboring for several days to break the deadlock over the Pan-American Congress, which is to meet in the City of Mexico in October. As it stands now, the congress will meet without Chile, or else without Bolivia and Peru, and whichever party stands out will clearly indicate its refusal to abide by the decisions of the congress respecting arbitration.

Some time after midnight Sunday he entered the big office building at 1017-1019 Chestnut Street, but left the building incensed because there was little plunder loose. The thief was so discouraged that he wrote the following note and placed it in the desk of James L. Dillon, a photographer:

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial opinion that the respectable citizens killed by troops in Albany deserved what they got for their "idle curiosity" is rather startling. And, as calling out the troops to settle labor troubles is becoming common, the subject deserves further consideration from the remnant of respectable citizens who survive.

LONDON, May 21 -- Andrew Carnegie has given L2,000,000 to establish free education in four Scotch universities -- Edinburgh, Glasgow, Aberdeen, and St. Andrews. He stipulates than the beneficiaries be his "Scottish fellow-countrymen" only, no English, Irish, colonials, or foreigners. The fund will apply to medical as well as to other education, and will be placed in the hands of Trustees, who will pay the expenses of Scottish students benefited under the scheme.

J. Montgomery Strong, who is quite well known in society, and his brother Philip have been in a controversy for several years over the estate of their mother, who died in 1894. The facts of the dispute were only made public yesterday by the filing of the report of Referee Joseph P. Ryan in the Surrogate's office.

Samuel J. Kennedy's prosecutors, who charge him with the murder of Emeline C. Reynolds, in the Grand Hotel, three years ago, sprung a great surprise on the Staten Island dentist's defenders yesterday and forecasted an entire change of theory as to the murder.
NEWPORT, May 20 -- William E. Carter of Philadelphia has taken the villa in Clay Street belonging to Dr. F. Le Roy Satterlee. Mr. and Mrs. Carter spent the season here two years ago.

The advance sale of seats for the three special performances of the Goodwin-Elliott revival of "The Merchant of Venice" at the Knickerbocker Theatre, beginning next Friday night, was probably one of the largest sales of Its kind that have been held in this city for similar dramatic performances for many years.
LONDON, May 20 -- Money was much wanted to-day for loan repayments estimated at four millions and for various calls of upward of half a million. Discounts were steady.

Dr. JOHNSON once observed of some spectacle to which he had been allured that "it was worth seeing, but not worth going to see." The projectors of an international or a "Continental" exposition undertake to make it worth going to see. Not even a city so rich and populous as Buffalo can of its own resources sustain for six months an exposition so extensive and expensive as the Pan-American.

BALTIMORE, Md., May 20 -- The market to-day, while a little better than on Saturday, was still considerably below the average of the recent active days. The lift in money rates, together with the disposition to await New York's developments, continued to hold the speculative element in check.

Justice Gaynor's criticism of the manner in which the Rapid Transit tunnel is being built at the expense of the city, and largely, according to his views as expressed on Sunday afternoon, for the benefit of "fortunate if not favored" individuals, has moved members of the commission to make reply.
BOSTON, May 20 -- Money loaned between banks at the Clearing House to-day at 4 and 3 1/2 per cent., and New York funds sold at 10 2-3 and 10c discount, Exchanges, $18,888,191; balances, $1,546,648.

Patrick Jerome Gleason, ex-Mayor and quondam ruler of Long Island City, died last night. He had been in ill-health for years, suffering from heart disease and other troubles, and recently had several sinking spells. At 7:30 last night he realized that the end was near. Dr. Fitch, Thomas P. Burke, Miss Jessie Gleason, his daughter, and Father Thomas McGronan were summoned.

Contracts were signed yesterday in Charlotte, N.C., by which the Manufacturers' Commercial Company, a recently created organization with a capital of $750,000, will finance the local affairs of the Cotton Manufacturers' Commission Company. Contracts were also signed by the Commercial Company with representatives of the Wool Growers' Association, in which Boston people are largely interested.

The market for outside securities yesterday showed the same conditions which were noted on the closing days of last week. There was no increase in activity and no signs of any general renewal of interest on the part of the public. Prices were firm, some noteworthy advances being made, but naturally there were fewer changes of importance than usual, owing to the extreme dullness of the market.
LONDON, May 20 -- Sir Courtenay Boyle, K.C.B., Permanent Secretary to the Board of Trade, died suddenly yesterday morning.

The existing "lock-out" in the building trades in this city turns upon a point which is curious, if not novel. That is the demand of strikers that, before they return to work after a strike, they shall be paid the wages they would have earned if they had remained at work.

NEW ORLEANS, La., May 20 -- Louis Loy, better known among the Chinamen of New Orleans as Tai Hoo, who is under arrest in New York charged with having robbed the Fou Loy Tai Company of this city, exporters of dried shrimp, of $30,000, was the general manager of and equally interested with his brother, Tai Chong, in the company, which did a flourishing business in drying shrimps and exporting them.

BOSTON, May 20. -- New England probably feels the force of the strike less than any other section of the country. In many towns employers have decided to grant the men's demands and they remained at work. In this city about 60 per cent. of the machinists are out. The number of men involved is placed at about 1,500.
PRINCETON, N.J., May 20 -- The programme for the one hundred and fifty-fourth annual commencement of Princeton University was given out to-day.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The various suggestions made for street signs show how easy it is for persons to disagree even on small matters. For instance, President Guggenheimer had a plan to compel owners of corner buildings to put the name of the street up in five-inch letters.

WASHINGTON, May 20. -- According to the rough estimate of President O'Connell of the National Association of Machinists, approximately 50,000 machinists throughout the country struck to-day for a nine-hour day, a scale of wages equal to the present ten-hour per day scale, and other demands.

After a search of four days the police yesterday found the mysterious "woman with red hair" who has figured so prominently in the case of the Rev. Father Edward Stanislaus Phillips, rector of St. Gabriel's Church, of Hazleton, Penn., whose dead body was found last Thursday night in the apartments of "Dr." Kirke Stanley, a masseur, in the rear of the second floor of 730 Ninth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The War Department has redeived a petition presented to Gen. Chaffee by a mass meeting of several thousand Chinamen, who assembled in front of the office of the Provost Marshal at Peking last March 28. The petition is signed by 5,600 Chinese residents of Peking, and prays for the retention of the American troops.

PHILADELPHIA, May 20. -- It is estimated that not more than 1,000 machinists have quit work in this city, because of the refusal of their employers to grant a nine-hour day. The firms thus far affected are all small concerns, employing anywhere from ten to forty machinists. Thus far there has been no trouble at the Baldwin Locomotive Works, the Midvale Steel Works, or the Cramp yards.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Dr. Hillis was taking a short vacation in the woods of Mains when he learned that it was Mr. Gage's wish that he conduct the services at the funeral of Mrs. Gage. He hastily made preparations to reach Washington at the appointed time. He had been sojourning at Rumford Falls, a small town.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In regard to "strike riots" in Albany and elsewhere, I protest against soldiers firing into a mob; people have a right to traverse the streets, and it is just as likely that one so engaged peaceably will be shot or that some person in a building will be struck by the bullet fired by a soldier.

Lake-wood did all the polo playing yesterday at the Westchester Country Club in the second competition for the chief prizes, the Westchester cups. Two teams from the growing New Jersey organization were entered, both composed to some extent of the new recruits secured by George Gould for the present season.

BALTIMORE, May 20. -- Through Alexander Brown Sons of this city, Brown Brothers Co. of New York, and the Maryland Trust Company, the financial plans for the complete consolidation of the street railway interest of Pittsburg and vicinity has been completed.

It was announced yesterday that the large tract of land known as the Newark and Hackensack meadows, the sale of which had been rumored for some time, had at last changed hands, the price paid being about $3,000,000 and the nominal purchaser being Henry L. Sprague, the lawyer, with offices at 15 Broad Street.
PRINCETON, N.J., May 20 -- Diphtheria has made its appearance here, and many cases of the disease have occurred. There has been one death.
In The Evening Post of yesterday there appears a carefully prepared detailed statement of facts in regard to the extravagance and looseness of expenditure under Tammany rule.

By the account given in our financial dispatch from London yesterday morning, the homilies recently read to American speculators by the English press could with much more pertinence and profit have, been addressed to their own Stock Exchange.

The Herald Square Theatre has been prolific in productions in the season which is now rapidly approaching its termination, but it seems that even toward the end of May it was not too late to bring forward there yet another play. "The Brixton Burglary" was the title of the piece made known last night to the evident delight of a numerous audience.
PHILADELPHIA, May 21 -- The Press tomorrow will say:

More evidence tending to connect Samuel J. Kennedy with the ownership of the lead, and iron bludgeon with which Emeline C. Reynolds was killed three years ago was adduced by Assistant District Attorneys Osborne and O'Connor during Kennedy's third trial for his life, before Judge Newburgrer, in General Sessions, yesterday.

With the exception of Jan. 25, when recorded transactions were set down at 632,000 shares, yesterday was the dullest day on the Stock Exchange this year, total transactions barely passing the 555,000 mark. Indeed, at one time during the day it looked as if even the January low record would be surpassed and that the figures for the day would approach nearer to the low mark for December, 1900, which was 598,873.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 21 -- The suits of the Central Trust Company and others against the Manhattan Trust Company and four others, growing out of the receivership of the Ohio Southern Railroad, were filed in the Supreme Court this afternoon, all on error to the Circuit Court of Alien County.

The root of the trouble lies in the fact that Tammany is too powerful, and the plundering clique in the organization has so perfected its machinery that it works throughout the entire city. If the Republicans were as firmly in power here they would be just as bad, but it would take them years to get as strong and far-reaching an organization as their opponents now have.

Levering Garrigues, civil engineers and manufacturers of structural iron, filed a mechanic's lien yesterday in the County Clerk's office for $129,500 against the property of J. Newton Osorio, at 18 to 22 West Twentieth Street, extending through to 23 West Nineteenth Street. An eight-story brick and stone store and loft building is being erected on the site, and Levering Garrigues have the contract for the iron work.

BUFFALO, May 21 -- The formal opening of the Woman's Building occurred to-day. All day long the handsome structure was crowded by visitors, who admired the rich furnishings. The opening was signalized by a public reception this afternoon to Mrs. Theodore Roosevelt, wife of the Vice President of the United States.

PHILADELPHIA, May 21 -- The Philadelphia market was extremely dull to-day, earl, the whole movement being in four issue -- Cambria Steel, Philadelphia Company, the Readings, and Pennsylvania Steel. The rest of the market showed few changes. Choctaw common and Union Traction were lower.

In the chorus of querulous comment that has been raised in England over the purchase of the Leyland Line of steamers nothing has been more, pitiable as well as surprising than the demand frequently heard that the British Government shall come to the aid of British shipping and preserve it from the absorption which the Americans, sure, as they are said to be, of an ample subsidy, will otherwise shortly accomplish.

BALTIMORE, May 21 -- The market today became a Jitle more active, with a decided improvement in the general tone. The issue attracting chief attention was Cotton Duck income bonds, which ran up from 63 1/4 to 65 3/4. The last sale brought the highest figure. Seaboards likewise scored a net advance, the final sale of both common and preferred being above the preceding day's record.

An interesting feature of the strike in this city of the machinists has been that in spite of the strike friendly relations are still maintained between the men who are out and the employers. This was strikingly exemplified by an unexpected visit paid yesterday afternoon by Henry F. Devens, Secretary of the National Metal Trades Association, representing the employers, to the headquarters of the strikers' Executive Committee, in the Clason Building, 123 Duane Street.

Seven privates in the regular army absent without leave from Fort Ethan Alien, Vermont, have just been locked up in the military prison at Governors Island. They disappeared from their post immediately after pay day of this month, and their troubles are attributed by officers to the abolition of canteens.

Transactions in the outside market yesterday were somewhat larger than they were on Monday, but the total for the day was still a small one. There was some trading in several stocks not heretofore dealt in on the curb, but in these issues transactions were limited to a few hundred shares.

RYDE, Isle of Wight, May 21 -- The trial of the Shamrock II, and the Shamrock I. to-day was in many respects the most puzzling that has yet taken place. Instead of throwing additional light upon the abilities of the challenger, to-day's race makes it more difficult than, ever to estimate her speed.

NEWARK, N.J., May 21 -- The Rev. John Keller of Arlington was to-day re-elected as Secretary to the Bishop of the Diocese at the twenty-seventh annual convention of the Protestant Episcopal Churches of the Diocese of Newark, held in Trinity Church. While the members were at luncheon a telegram was received announcing his reelection as Secretary of the Alumni Association of the General Seminary in New York.

The plans for the eight-million-dollar extension of the underground rapid transit system to Brooklyn were approved by both branches of the Municipal Assembly yesterday. This action breaks the "hold-up" of the plans of the Rapid Transit Commissioners. Under the rapid transit law the Commissioners can now complete the details of the specifications and advertise for a bidder for the work and call upon the Board of Estimate for bond issues to pay the contractor.

Investigation of the expenditures for city supplies, manner of purchasing, and the means by which contracts are secured from all of the city departments will be begun by the Grand Jury, at the Instance of District Attorney Philbin, to-day, or upon some day of this week.

All application has teen made to Surrogate Thomas by John H. McCrahon, a lawyer of Syracuse, to intervene in the probate of the will of "Apple Mary," who was a wellknown character in the lower part of the city ten years ago. The Surrogate yesterday adjourned the hearing until Friday.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The largest battleship owned by any naval power is of a little more than 15,000 tons displacement. It is related that the largest cue present at the funeral demonstration in honor of Queen Victoria was a Japanese battleship recently completed and displacing 15,000 tons.

MINEOLA, L.I., May 21 -- The police are looking for Rose Murray, who was convicted of keeping a disorderly house near Glenhead, sentenced to five months imprisonment by Judge Seabury, and escaped from Officer Patrick Lamb while he was conducting her to the jail in Long Island City.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The Coroner's jury which has been investigating the murder of James S. Ayres, the young Census Office clerk, at the Hotel Kenmore last Wednesday morning, to-day brought in the following verdict:
NEWPORT, May 21 -- The deeds conveying Tower Top, the Francis P. Freeman estate, in Bellevue Avenue, to Mrs. W. Storrs Wells have been filed at the City Hall. The consideration named is $50,000.

A strong legal fight is promised against the securing of railroad franchises in the Island of Cuba by the Cuba Company, of which Sir William C. Van Home of Canada is President. Gen. JosS Lacret y Morlot, one of the best known of the insurgent Generals and a member of the Constitutional Convention, has taken the matter up, and certain strong New York interests are said to be with him.

PHILADELPHIA, May 21 -- The consideration of Church board reports was continued at to-day's session of the Presbyterian General Assembly. The report of the Committee on Home Missions, read by the Rev. Dr. Hugh K. Walker, Chairman, contained numerous recommendations, one of the most important being an earnest commendation of the proposed anti-polygamy amendment to the Constitution of the United States.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- President O'Connell of the National Association of Machinists said to-night that the advices received up to 6 o'clock at headquarters here indicated that an early settlement of the trouble between the machinists and employers will be effected. Information at hand showed that during the day over 120 firms had settled by granting the nine-hour day.

LONDON, May 22 -- In the House of Lords yesterday the Marquis of Lansdowne, Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, made a statement on the Chinese indemnity question. He declared that the Government desired to avoid an arrangement for the payment of the indemnity by which China would be compelled to contract separate obligations, but it could not agree to a joint guarantee of the loan.

DAYTON, Ohio, May 21 -- An alleged cops of the will of Josephine Kelat, an English-woman who recently died in France, has just been received here. The will bequeaths to Henry H. Hawthorne, a veteran in the Soldiers' Home, a fortune of $2,500,000, this being his reward for saving the woman from drowning.

BOSTON, May 21 -- At the Clearing House this morning money between the banks was in large supply at 3 1/2 per cent. One of the largest lending banks marked down its rates from 4 to 3 1/2 per cent. New York funds sold from 15 cents discount to par for cash. Exchanges, $29,167,621; balances, $3,432,220.
Police Commissioner Murphy got a lecture yesterday from Magistrate Zeller on the law and the conduct of the Police Department, to which he took sharp exception.

Ex-Assistant District Attorney Levi W. Naylor of Brooklyn was yesterday afternoon appointed by Justice Thomas, in the United States District Court, that borough, receiver for the stock brokerage firm of G. Edward Graff Co., which made an assignment last Thursday.
The plot 100 by 110 at the northeast corner of Fifth Avenue and One Hundred and Sixteenth Street, has been sold by the estate of David Wolf Bishop. It is said that the buyer is a Mr. McNulty.

From Dr. JOHNSON'S time and before him down to the present day the world has loved to have Its joke about Scotchmen. Mr. ANDREW CARNEGIE'S gift of ten million dollars to the Universities of Edinburgh, Glasgow, Aberdeen, and St. Andrews to make their teaching free to all Scotch boys and girls who can pass the entrance examinations is no joke, however.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 21 -- J. Luther Pierson, a faith curist of this place and an employe of the New York Central Railroad, was found guilty to-day, after a trial before Judge Lent, of a violation of the Penal Code in failing to provide medical attendance for an adopted daughter, two years old, who died recently from catarrhal pneumonia.

The baseball team of Fordham College for the second time this season defeated Holy Cross on the grounds of the former yesterday. The batting was free on both sides and Fordham's lead in the first inning was never overcome. The score:

FALL RIVER, Mass., May 21 -- The absolute refusal of outside mills to enter any curtailment agreement is the cause of a wide difference of opinion among local mill men for the time being, and the difficulties are being complicated by continued cutting of prices by mills in the South and in New England outside of Fall River.
LONDON, May 21 -- Sir John Edmund Commerell, V.C., Admiral of the Fleet, retired, is dead.

The sunshine brought with it quite a revival of interest in outdoor sports and in suburban amusements. The coach Pioneer went out in the morning with a stag party, the guests of W.L. Elkins of Philadelphia. Among these were Barclay Warburton, William E. Carter, Guy Ward, Edward Browning, Edward Crozer, S.M. Wright, E. Rittenhouse Miller, Richard Stockton, Edward Brooks, R. Penn Smith, and H. Pratt McKean.

In the presence of the Governor, representatives of the City Government, and several thousand persons, the cornerstone of the new Mount Sinai Hospital will be laid this afternoon at 3 o'clock. The structure is to occupy the city block bounded by Fifth and Madison Avenues and One Hundredth and One Hundred and First Streets.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Gov. Alien of Porto Rico has presented to the President, through the State Department, his first annual report. The Governor expresses the opinion that a scheme of colonial administration such as is followed in the Danish, French, and British West Indies might be safely instituted, with variations dependent upon the future policy of the home Government.

The petition presented to Gen. CHAFFEE by a mass meeting of Chinamen in the American Quarter of Peking is doubtless without any precedent in the history of the world. We have had something rather near to it, and also, like itself, creditable to the United States Army. That was the statement made, upon the eve of his departure from Cuba to Spain, by a Spanish private in behalf of himself and his comrades.
The United States Industrial Commission was in session all day yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Hotel, and will probably remain, here for the rest of the week.

The coal trade of the United States is watching with interest the outcome of a plan, conceived by one or two well-known promoters, to ship coal in large quantities from this country to the French markets.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 21 -- President McKinley to-day reviewed 45,000 school children of this city.

The Municipal Art Society made a tender of services to the city yesterday to assist in establishing a plan of designating streets by signs. The offer was referred to the Committees on Streets and Highways of the Board of Aldermen and the Council. Another public hearing will be held on the proposed street sign ordinance on May 31, and Chairman Bridges expects to determine on a plan for designating streets promptly after that meeting.

Soft coal is being used by so many manufacturers north of Fourteenth Street that it is impossible to look in any direction without seeing volumes of black smoke issuing from high chimneys. This was the experience of a representative of THE NEW YORK TIMES, who made a trip of inspection yesterday.

CREEDMOOR, May 21 -- The Twenty-second Regiment, N.G.N.Y., occupied the range to-day, under the command of Col. Franklin Bartlett. Three hundred and sixty-three men qualified as marksmen and received the State decoration. The weather was favorable, with a light 8 o'clock wind. Results:

BOSTON, May 21 -- Ex-Congressman Charles A. Boutelle of Bangor, Me., died to-day at the MeLean Asylum, Waverley, Mass., where he had been confined for a year suffering from brain trouble. Death was due primarily to pneumonia, which developed last Sunday. Mr. Boutelle's daughter, Grace, who has been at the head of the household since her mother's death, in 1892, was at the bedside to-day.

ALBANY, May 21 -- The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, Third Department, to-day handed down three important decisions upholding positions taken by the State Board of Tax Commissioners in the enforcement of the franchise tax law. The decisions determine the form and subject matter of writs of certiorari which corporations may obtain for a review by the Supreme Court of the valuations placed on their special franchises.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The District Court of Appeals to-day afirmed the decision of the lower court in the case of Lieut. Lewis E. Brown, the army officer who was dismissed from the army on charges of conduct unbecoming an officer. He was twice tried by court-maritial -- the first time acquitted and the second time convicted.

BOSTON, May 22 -- The canvas covering was laid on the deck of the yacht Independence to-day, nearly the entire crew being scattered over the deck, some applying the glue with brushes, others pressing down the thick white duck until it firmly adhered.
Jacob H. Schiff of the banking firm of Kuhn, Loeb Co. of Wall Street was the principal witness yesterday at the morning session of the United States Industrial Commission at the Fifth Avenue Hotel.

LAWRENCE, Kan., May 22 -- Gen. Frederick Funston and his followers, on their trip to capture Aguinaldo, were reduced to a diet of snails and octopus, according to a letter dated San Isidro, P.I., April 5, and received from the Kansan by Adna G. Clark of Lawrence to-day.

BALTIMORE, May 22 -- A request has been presented to President Charles C. MacGill of the Baltimore Chamber of Commerce by a number of leading members, to take up the question of allowing dealings in securities in addition to the regular grain business. This is a part of a move to establish a stock exchange at the Chamber of Commerce similar to the Consolidated Exchange of New York.

BAYPORT, L.I., May 22 -- Principal W. D. Miller of the Bayport Union School, who is accused of having inflicted severe corporal punishment upon Master Mortimer Greenough, the fourteen-year-old son of Dr. and Mrs. Greenough of this place, has been exonerated by the School Board.
NEWPORT, May 22 -- John A. Pinard has gone to New York for a few days.

Any man be he young or old, who knows a woman and is imprudent enough to chance to walk on the section of Broadway immediately above Forty-second Street after dark with her in these days, considers himself unusually lucky if at least a dozen occasions do not arise for prompt physical vengeance upon some cabman.

PHILADELPHIA, May 22 -- Outside of the Readings, Cambria Steel, and Union Traction, this was a very dull day in the Philadelphia market. The Readings profited by the movement in New York. Cambria was weak, owing to uncertainty regarding the exact terms for its recapitalization.

WEST POINT, May 22 -- This morning at 11 o'clock Capt. Edward Anderson, officer in charge for the day, notified five cadets of the Military Academy that they had been summarily dismissed, and six others that they had been suspended for one year. On the 1 o'clock train all of the men left West Point, with scarcely an opportunity to say good-bye to their comrades.

Mr. J. PIERPONT MORGAN has just done a considerable public service. The tariff on foreign works of art has long been a grievance to all American lovers of civilization. American artists there at one time were who regarded it as protective, and agitated for it. But, by the nature of the case, they were not very important American artists.

Appreciation of the Nation, the State, and the city, mingled with felicitation at the concrete beginning of an enterprise designed for the general weal, marked the ceremonies at the laying of the cornerstone of the new building for Mount Sinai Hospital yesterday. The patriotic note was voiced in the speeches, and it was manifest in the decorations.

Handwriting expert testimony as to the similarity between Dr. Samuel J. Kennedy's admitted writing and the indorsement on the $13,000 check found on the dead body of Emeline C. Reynolds, was yesterday adjudged competent and admissible by Judge Newburger, in General Sessions, at the third trial of Kennedy charged with murder.

The leaders of the New York district of the International Association of Machinists wre more confident of victory yesterday than at any other time since the strike began. Nearly 1,000 additional strikers gained their demands during the day, including the employes of the Incandescent Arc Light Company, Thirty-third Street and First Avenue, while the employes of one or two concerns who had been undecided since Monday decided to strike.
BERLIN, May 22. -- To a newspaper correspondent a German statesman, discussing the present relations between Russia and Germany, said:

With the single exception of the Distilling stocks, yesterday's market for outside securities was about as dull as that of any recent day. There was little activity and few important changes in prices. Quotations moved somewhat irregularly, but for the most part within a narrow range, and changes of as much as a point were exceptional.

PHILADELPHIA, May 22 -- The Commissioners of the Presbyterian General Assembly found much business awaiting them to-day, and the rapidity with which the various matters were disposed of evidenced the assembly's intention to have for consideration as little unfinished business as possible after the settlement of the creed revision question.

ST. PAUL, Minn., May 22 -- At the annual election of the Mason City and Fort Dodge Branch of the Chicago Great Western the officers were re-elected, and James J. Hill, President of the Great Northern, was made a Director.

BOSTON, May 22 -- At the Clearing House to-day money loaned at 3 1/2 @3 per cent., and New York funds sold at par and 5c premium, the first time that they have commanded a premium in months. Exchanges, $25,923,044; balances, $2,246,368.

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- President O'Connell of the International Association of Machinists estimates that the number of machinists engaged in the strike to-day is 40,000. He claims to be satisfied with the situation, and has confidence in the result.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage, except in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes payment of the mortgage.

The New Yorks won their second baseball game from Pittsburg yesterday at the Polo Grounds. No scoring was done by either side except in the sixth inning, masterly pitching by Phyle and Wiltse keeping the hits scattered. The Pittsburgs were the first to score.

The possible solution of one of the most obstinate electrical problems, the clearing up of which will mean the disentanglement of many difficult traction problems also, was made known Tuesday night when a paper by A.J. Kennelly was read before the American Institute of Electrical Engineers on the occasion of their annual meeting, announcing that Thomas A. Edison had invented a new storage battery combining all of the long-sought advantages of lightness, durability, and effectiveness.

With all the imposing ceremony of the Orthodox Russian Church, Bishop Tikhon yesterday, assisted by foremost dignitaries and in the presence of representatives of the Russian Navy and a large assemblage of believers, laid the cornerstone of the Church of St. Nicholas the Wonderworker, at its site, on Ninety-seventh Street, between Madison and Fifth Avenues.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The Interior Department to-day received by mail a communication from Indian Agent Nickerson of the Shoshone Agency, Wyoming, reporting that a faction of the Arapahoes on the agency is idle, restless, and defiant; that the agent is powerless to prevent the braves from holding a sun dance, in defiance of his orders, and asking the War Department for the assistance of the troops at Fort Washakie, Wyoming.
BERLIN, May 22 -- Between July 22 and Aug. 20 there will be given at Baireuth two performances of "The Ring of the Nibelungen," seven of "Parsifal," and five of "The Flying Dutchman."

LEXINGTON, Ky., May 22 -- The brood mare Bonita Belle and her weaning foal have been sold by Col. W.S. Barnes to Richard Croker. The youngster, now a yearling, has been named Beau Imperial, and will be raced in England, where he is well engaged. Bonita Belle will continue to make her home at Melbourne Stud, to be bred to Jim Gore, the sire of Beau Gallant.

To The Editor of The New York Times: I was much interested in the remarks made by Justice Gaynor in a recent trial to a jury that had, in his opinion, returned an excessive amount of damages against the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company. If any of those jurymen reside on the line of the Kings County Road above Franklin Avenue, I do not wonder at their verdict or the very appropriate remarks of the Judge.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Permit me to express my warm indorsement of the views stated in your admirable editorial yesterday entitled "Use for a State Police." It seems to me that perhaps the most important lesson to be drawn from the Albany strike and similar industrial disturbances which have occurred in recent years in many parts of our country is that which you draw in this editorial.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 22 -- Secretary Cortelyou has ceased issuing regular bulletins regarding Mrs. McKinley's condition. At 1 o'clock, however, Secretary Cortelyou gave out the following:

Judge Brown of the United States District Court has granted a discharge in bankruptcy to Albert B. Hilton, son of the late Judge Henry Hilton, and who was formerly in the dry goods business at Broadway and Ninth Street, under the style of Hilton, Hughes Co.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., May 22 -- In the athletic contests at Vassar College this afternoon, two new records were established in the one-hundred-yard dash and throwing the basket ball, but both were made by the young woman who held the previous records. A match game of basketball between the sophomores and freshmen ended in a tie, which will be played off to-morrow.

The shares of the Reading and Erie Railroad Companies suddenly developed yesterday into market leadership -- surprising with their buoyancy most observers, though it has for a long time been a popular Wall Street belief that the lower-priced coal shares were getting into position to become speculative favorites.

BALTIMORE, May 22 -- The market to-day passed through a period of uncertainty, followed later by a notable tendency toward firmness. The early declines were due to a speculative attack on Cotton Duck incomes, and the acute weakness of Mary land Brewing Company's issues. The attack on Cotton Duck incomes was forced with the view of working prices to a lower level, thereby enabling intending buyers to load themselves up at cheaper figures.
The annual commencement exercises of the Hebrew Technical-Institute, 36 Stuyvesant Street, were held last evening in the large hall of Cooper Union. There was a large crowd present.
CAIRO, May 22 -- Arabi Pasha, the famous Egyptian rebel, who was banished to Ceylon in 1882, has been pardoned.

SOUTHAMPTON, May 22 -- The most dramatic incident in the history of the America's Cup occurred to-day, when a sudden squall on the Solent completely wrecked the new challenger and endangered the lives of King Edward and several other distinguished persons, including Sir Thomas Lipton.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 22 -- Fred C. Foster of Cambridgeport, who was under suspicion by the police in connection, with the explosion which wrecked the Cambridgeport National Bank here yesterday, committed suicide by shooting to-day in the presence of a police officer who had called on Mr. Foster to make inquiries in connection with the case.

Although yesterday was cloudy, it was not cold, and many coaching parties went up to the races at Morris Park, to Ardsley, and to the polo at Westchester. To-day James Henry Smith will have the coach. There are no functions of any moment in town, the attention of every one at present being directed to suburban affairs and to the getting away from New York for the Summer.

Army. Major Louis Brechemin, Surgeon, will proceed to Fort Bayard, New Mexico, for temporary duty in charge of the United States General Hospital at that place, during the illness of Major Daniel M. Appel, Surgeon.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., May 22. -- A million dollars in damage has been done and at least eight lives lost in upper East Tennessee by the floods, caused by the recent heavy rains. The Doe River, the Watauga, the Holston, the Chuckey, and the French Broad are out of bounds, and growing crops have been swept away all along their courses.
LONDON, May 23 -- All the morning papers contain editorials expressing gratitude for the escape of the King and sympathy with Sir Thomas Lipton in his ill-luck.
Commenting upon the article printed in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Wednesday morning, calling attention to the violation of the smoke ordinance, Acting Chief Sanitary Inspector Betz said yesterday:

PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 22 -- The Trustees of the John Carter Brown Library, acting under the provisions of the will of the late John Nicholas Brown, has decided to present the library, with its $650,000 endowment, to Brown University. The formal offer will be made to the corporation of the university on the 20th of June.

To-morrow the heats and trials in the track, field, and bicycle college championships will take place at Berkeley Oval. The games will start promptly at 2 o'clock, and they will, be through at a little after 5 P.M. Harvard, Williams, Bowdoin, Michigan, Cornell, Amherst, Georgetown, and several other college teams will reach New York to-day so that they will be in good shape for the races to-morrow.

Disorderly scenes have occurred in and about the quiet little village of Westchester ever since last Saturday, when the Eightieth Company of Coast Artillery, stationed at Fort Schuyler, on Long Island Sound, and commanded by Capt. William R. Hamilton was paid off by the Government.

We like very much The Herald's application of wireless telegraphy to the useful service of conveying signals of incoming steamships from the Nantucket Shoals Lightship. This is legitimate newspaper enterprise. It increases the news-gathering efficiency of The Herald and puts the public under obligations to it for information of high utility supplied some hours earlier than it has ever before been obtainable.
PRINCETON, N.J., May 22 -- Holy Cross baseball team met defeat at the hands of the Tigers on University Field this afternoon, the score being 12 to 4.

BETHLEHEM, Penn., May 22 -- In this peaceful Pennsylvania town one of the most ambitious musical festivals of recent years will begin to-morrow night. It will last three days, and will consist of the performance of Sebastian Bach's Christmas oratorio, St. Matthew Passion and B minor mass, one each day.

MANILA, May 23 -- It is alleged that, as the outcome of a drunken quarrel in the officers' quarters at Camp Stotsenberg Tuesday afternoon, Lieut. James F. Howell of the Sixth Artillery shot Second Lieut. Charles R. Lloyd, Jr., of the same regiment, the bullet grazing the left side of Lloyd's head and inflicting a slight wound.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The revenue cutter Grant, under command of Capt. Dorr F. Tozier, left Seattle between the 15th and 18th of this month on a tour of the southeast coast of Alaska, from Sitka, along the coast of Alaska, to Unalaska, and from Unalaska to Bristol Bay, on Bering Sea, as far as the mouth of the Koskoquin River.

ALBANY, May 22 -- Under the M.E. Lewis act, which is Chapter 588 of the Laws of 1901, all foreign manufacturing corporations must pay a license tax of one-eighth of 1 per cent, on their capital stock employed in this State. Heretofore foreign corporations could enter New York State and do business without paying a license tax, which corresponds or is equivalent to the organization tax.

A correspondent whose name we forbear to print inquires why we call the Platt amendment a law. He calls it "a nullity," "an idle fulmination" with "none of the requisites of a law," and courteously adds that he is persuaded that THE TIMES calls it a law "for deception."

The backers of the New York and Brooklyn Railroad Company claimed yesterday that they had the franchise and the permit to build a tunnel under the East River from the New York City Hall to the Brooklyn Borough Hall, or even to Jamaica, it they so desired.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 22 -- The proposition for a settlement of the Chinese indemnity by an issue of bonds was presented first by the United States. President McKinley and Secretary of State Hay have been in constant communication with Washington during all their journey West. Dispatches from foreign Embassies have been continually arriving and the Chinese situation has received special attention.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The situation at West Point has assumed the proportions of a struggle between the cadets and the United States Government. Secretary Root will continue the fight until the Government is victorious. The view taken by him is that the cadets seriously believe they are entitled to run the military academy, and that this idea must be completely eradicated from their minds.

C.M. Hamilton, who recently won the championship of the Baltusrol Golf Club at Short Hills, N.J., stole the golf thunder of the recognized National and local champions yesterday in the opening round for the Metropolitan championship of the coming year, which began at the Apawamis Golf Club at Rye.

From time to time we have printed authentic reports from various military posts in the United States which have revealed a general falling off in the moral condition and discipline of the troops stationed at these posts since, by an act of Congress, absolute "prohibition" has been made to prevail at the army clubs of the private soldier.

The circumstance that the King was on board the challenger for the America's Cup when she was wrecked rather dislocates whatever essential moral there may be in that occurrence. From the British social or political point of view, the main fact is that his Majesty was in imminent danger of his life.
