OGDEN, Utah, May 26. -- The Presidential train traversed the State of Nevada today, and reached Ogden at 6:30 o'clock tonight. The route lay along the Humboldt River, then through the mountains and into the Salt Lake basin.

OGDEN, Utah, May 26. -- On the way back to Washington the President and the members of the Cabinet are devoting much time to the consideration of the Chinese situation. The refusal of the other powers to accept the suggestion of the United States to scale down the indemnity demanded of China was a great disappointment, though it could hardly be said that it was entirely unexpected.

-- One of the London papers, in the course of some eulogistic remarks about Mr. W.H. GRENFELL, M.P., makes, we are sure involuntarily, a revelation that can hardly fail to have serious international consequences -- perhaps it may have the most serious of all international consequences, consequences which we are not yet prepared to indicate more definitely.

ORANGE, N.J., May 26. -- The police here believe they have a clue to the persons who threatened to kidnap the daughter of Thomas A. Edison, the son of Warren Smith, and a daughter of Victor Bianchi. They think they know who wrote the 'remember' letters, and say an arrest will be made within a few days if further investigation confirms the theory on which they are now working.

LONDON, May 26. -- There is not much to report this week of the picturesque sort, but the last six-business days have not been without their interest and difficulties. I think the position slightly improved in some respects, but not essentially different from what it was when I last cabled.

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- Owing to the fact that the United States Supreme Court will adjourn to-morrow for the term, the opinion is quite general that the court will deliver its opinion in the insular cases, which were heard last Winter. In view of this probability Solicitor General Richards has prepared an unofficial statement explaining the questions involved in the various cases, which is as follows:

PHILADELPHIA, May 26. -- The debate in the Presbyterian Assembly on revision of the Confession of Faith, which took up the whole of three days last week, will be resumed to-morrow morning, and it is believed some definite action will have been taken before the Assembly adjourns for the day.

At the West End Presbyterian Church, One Hundred and Fifth Street and Amsterdam Avenue, the Rev. Dr. John Balcom Shaw last evening preached a sermon on "Political Perils in Our Municipal Life." He spoke in part as follows:

NEWPORT, May 26. -- Shortly after 9 o'clock this morning the big mainsail of the Constitution followed by the jib foretopmast staysail and flying jib were hoisted and majestically the big yacht left her anchorage, back of the torpedo station, for a short run up the bay with W. Butler Duncan, Jr., at the helm, with a light breese from the east.

The police of the Fifty-ninth Precinct of Brooklyn, centring around the station at Grand Avenue and Park Place, have been confronted for the past few Sundays with an unusual problem. There has been a great deal of rowdyism in the precinct on those days, but the rowdies have been of tender ages, and the police have been reluctant to formally arrest them.

BUFFALO, May 25. -- The name "Canadian Day" was well chosen for yesterday at the Pan-American Exposition, for everything was truly Canadian, even to the weather. Many Canadian visitors were in evidence on the fair grounds, and the grounds consequently presented a livelier appearance than on the preceding day.

Varied activity, in many lines, is illustrated in an exhibition of the work of the Educational Alliance which attracted a large number of visitors to its building at Jefferson Street and East Broadway yesterday. A flower show and an exhibit of pictures by east side artists supplements the institution's exhibit, which will be open to the general public throughout the week.

Controller Coler has addressed a letter to William F. King, President of the Merchants' Association, transmitting his personal check for $250 as a contribution toward the deficit caused by the Ramapo investigation conducted by that organization. The deficit originally amounted to about $40,000, which has been reduced to about $10,000.

PEKIN, May 26. -- The United States Legation Guard has had its first trouble with the Germans. Legation Street is being repaired near the legation, and the American sentry was placed at the point with orders to direct persons around by a side street. Everybody obeyed with the exception of the Germans, both officers and soldiers, who have caused the American sentries much annoyance.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., May 26. -- The will of Reuben R. Finch, who was one of the bestknown stove manufacturers in this country, has been probated. He died at his home here and was buried a week ago. His estate is valued at $500,000. iHs wife died some years ago and he leaves no children.

United States Army officers stationed at Fort Schuyler, on Long Island Sound, when interviewed yesterday regarding the statement made by Mrs. Lillia M.V. Stevens, National President of the Women's Christian Temperance Union, to the effect that there was a conspiracy among leading officers in the army to influence the public in favor of the reinstatement of the canteen, laughed at the idea, and in many cases declared the statement to be too ridiculous for discussion.

The committee of walking delegates who ordered the strike on the rapid transit tunnel last week succeeded yesterday in swinging the Central Federated Union into line with them. New demands are to be made to-day on the Rapid Transit Contractors' Association, and the question of whether the strike will be extended or not will depend on how the contractors look on these demands.

Senator TILLMAN, as was described in our dispatches yesterday morning, has been forced to an open fight with Senator McLAURIN for the leadership of the Democratic Party in South Carolina. The situation is interesting.

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- Chief Examiner A.R. Servens of the Civil Service Commission left here to-night by the way of New York for Honolulu, where he and Civil Service Commissioner Rodenberg, who will join him en route at Kansas City, will look into the civil service in Hawaii.

Letters relating to the rapid transit problem, written by Justice William J. Gaynor of the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, to Mayor Van Wyck and to Andrew H. Green were mailed last night. The Justice in his letter to the Mayor makes vigorous objection to the proposition to build a tunnel railroad in Brooklyn as an annex to the Long Island Railroad Company's system at the expense of the city.

DAPITAN, Island of Mindanao, April 8. -- For the past week the United States Commission has been steaming around the coasts of Mindanao, touching at its principal ports, to interview the leading inhabitants gathered in from the adjacent districts, and to declare to them the purpose of the United States Government concerning them.

LONDON, May 26. -- The shadow of the Northern Pacific excitement is still hanging over the London Stock Exchange. This, combined with the approaching holidays, has brought American dealings during the last week practically to a standstill, and home stocks were quiet in sympathy.
On the Stock Exchange for the week ended Saturday, May 25, total transactions included 4,276,574 shares of stock, $21,498,000 bonds, including $32,500 Government and $35,000 State bonds.

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- The news of the resignation of Senators Tillman and McLaurin of South Carolina has been received by Democrats here generally with evidences of contempt. There are no prominent South Carolina politicians here. Senator Butler, who usually lives in Washington, is in the South on business.

A series of reports by a committee of the Civil Service Reform League, of which Mr. WILLIAM DUDLEY FOULKE of Indiana is Chairman, is being published by the league. They give the results of investigation into the condition of the service as to the observance and enforcement of the requirements of the law of 1883, known as the civil service reform law.

ALBANY, May 26. -- Five persons were killed and over forty were seriously injured in a collision between two electric cars which were racing for a switch at forty miles an hour from opposite directions near here this afternoon.

BERLIN, May 26. -- Conditions on the Boerse last week were extremely dull, notwithstanding an easier money market than had been known for years. Many factors combined to produce a weak market. The Northern Pacific incident continued to react here, causing an almost total cessation of business in the American department.

COLUMBIA, S.C., May 26. -- Gov. McSweeney left here for Memphis this morning, accompanied by State Chairman Jones. His mail had not been opened, so he did not receive the resignations of Senators McLaurin and Tillman before leaving. He was inclined to look upon the outcome as a joKe and would make no statement.

PHILADELPHIA, May 27 -- By a unanimous vote the Presbyterian General Assembly to-day adopted the report of the special committee on the revision of the Confession of Faith. The debate on this important question had extended into the fourth day, and to the Rev. Dr. James D. Moffatt is due the credit of having brought the Commissioners to such a harmonious conclusion.
CHICAGO, May 27 -- New York exchange was quoted at 25 cents discount before and 30 cents discount after call. Money for call and time loans still stands at 4 1/2@5 per cent.

DAYTON, Tenn., May 27 -- At the Richland Mine of the Dayton Coal and Iron Company, two miles from Dayton, this afternoon a terrific explosion of gas, formed by the collection of coal dust, resulted in the death of twenty-one men, all white, and most of them married and with families.

A number of large book publishing concerns are anxiously looking for "a light-haired young man" who made Fort Lee, N.J., his headquarters for several months. The enterprising young man succeeded in getting enough valuable books out of the publishers to start a library.

BALTIMORE, May 27 -- It was learned here to-day that John K. Cowen has placed his resignation as President in the hands of the Baltimore and Ohio Executive Committee, and that he is to resume his old position of chief counsellor of that railroad. When he was chief counsellor under the Garret regime his salary was $20,000 a year.

The Arctic Freezing Company's warehouse, at 120 West Street, where 2,100 dead birds were seized last Thursday by Game Protector J.F. Overton, was left practically without surveillance yesterday for several hours, and during that time scores of barrels and boxes were carted away on trucks. Last week Mr. Overton declared that not a single box or crate would be permitted to leave the building without inspection.

BALTIMORE, May 27 -- Mayor Hayes returned yesterday from a careful inspection trip of the Western Maryland Railroad, and to-day virtually admitted that the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad was one of the two parties seeking to buy the road. He intimated that the Reading had offered over $8,500,000 the amount of the road's indebtedness to Baltimore City.

A meeting of the Challenge Committee of the New York Yacht Club was to have been held yesterday for the purpose of considering Thomas W. Lawson's letter with reference to the entry of his yacht Independence, in the trial races. The meeting, however, was postponed until 11 o'clock this morning, and will be held at Commodore Lewis Cass Ledyard's office in Wall Street.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- In the United States Supreme Court to-day opinions were handed down in all but two of the cases before that court involving the relation of the United States to its insular possessions. The two cases in which no conclusion was announced were those known as the fourteen-diamond-rings case and the second of the Dooley cases.

The American Theatre, though approaching the end of its season, is still prolific in the production of new plays. With only a week to run and very little time for rehearsal, these new plays are not offered with the same elaborate care in their preparation as one is accustomed to see at the Broadway houses, but they are fairly well put upon the stage and acted tolerably.

BOSTON, May 27 -- An idyllic comedy drama, "Priscilla," by Stanislaus Stange, with incidental music by Julian Edwards, was produced to-night at the Tremont Theatre before an audience which completely filled the house, and was very much delighted with what it saw and heard.

Senator J.B. Foraker of Ohio, author of the Jaw to establish a civil government for Porto Rico, and under the provisions of which the suit just decided was brought up, was seen at the Waldorf-Astoria last night. He said:
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The United States Supreme Court handed down its decisions in five of the insular cases. There were dissenting opinions in each one.

BALTIMORE, Md., May 27 -- The market to-day was decidedly dull, with no notable trend one way or the other. The buying element seemed indifferent toward the trading, there being little or no disposition to buy except at such concessions as would make purchases bargains. The general list was only fairly steady, the easing tendency, as the result of a dearth of support, affecting more than one security to the extent of a fraction.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read your editorial on "Non-Partisan Presidents" in THE TIMES of this date with much satisfaction, because it so faithfully describes the different characteristics of Presidents Cleveland and McKinley. In 1890, when the McKinley Tariff bill was being discussed in the Committee on Ways and Means, many delegations journeyed to Washington to oppose the proposed measure.

TORONTO, May 27 -- Invader, the Canada's cup challenger, was launched at Oakville this afternoon. Only invited guests were present. The boat is 51 feet 3 inches over all and 27 feet 6 inches on the load water line, 9 feet 8 inches beam, and draws 6 feet. She carries 3,483 square feet of canvas and three tons of lead.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 27 -- In the Supreme Court, Appellate Division, to-day a divorce, with the custody of the children, was granted to Mrs. Sallie Hargous Elliot, in her suit against Duncan Elliot. Mrs. Waltomar H.H. Hume also secured a decree. There were in all forty-one cases set for trial, among them that of Mrs. Henry W. Bowen against the recently appointed Minister to Persia.

It is no wonder that the published charge of the President of the W.C.T. U. should have excited the indignation of officers of the army. Some of them indicated their indignation in yesterday's TIMES. The gist of the accusation was contained in the following sentences:

PHILADELPHIA, May 27 -- The market was very dull, except for an excellent demand for Philadelphia Company on an advance to 54. At one period trading was at a standstill for perhaps thirty minutes. Consolidated of Pittsburg followed Philadelphia Company up, advancing 1 3/4, to 27. Fear of serious competition from Edison's new storage battery caused further declines in the Electric Storage Battery shares, the common falling to 55 and the preferred to 57.

CHICAGO, May 27 -- The Rev. S.B. Dexter defended the army canteen last night at the Humboldt Park Baptist Church. While disclaiming any intention or desire of championing intemperance in any form, he strenuously opposed the extremists, who demanded that Congress pass the anti-canteen law.

BOSTON, Mass., May 27 -- The Clearing House rate dropped to-day to 2 1/2 per cent. for a few loans, with, however, the most of the loans placed at 3 per cent. New York funds were firm at par and 5@10c premium. Exchanges, $15,401,552; balances, $1,647,918.

Two quick-time raids on alleged poolrooms were made yesterday by Justice Jerome and Robert Grier Monroe, counsel to the Committee of Fifteen, but the elusive John Doe is not yet taken. The places were at 125 Amsterdam Avenue, near Sixty-fifth Street, and 1,823 Broadway, four blocks below, both in the precinct of the West Sixty-eighth Street Police Station, where Capt. Kear is in command.
LONDON, May 28 -- The Copenhagen correspondent of The Daily Express says:

CHICAGO, May 27 -- The Wabash and Chicago and Alton Roads to-day agreed to allow the question of differential fares for the former road between Kansas City and Buffalo to go to arbitration. It was also agreed that all rates be restored to normal basis on June 7, pending arbitration.

The annual meeting of the stockholders of the City and Suburban Homes Company was held at the officer of the company, 281 Fourth Avenue, yesterday. The President of the company, Dr. Elgin R.L. Gould, occupied the chair.

The "Oldest Inhabitant" again came into public view yesterday and was moved to figure out some comparisons on the weather. After long and painful mental calculation he announced, in various parts of the city and under an infinite variety of depressing circumstances, that the present month up to date had proved to be about the wettest May that New York had ever experienced.

The Rev. Robert L. Paddock, vicar of the pro-Cathedral in Stanton Street, made some startling statements at the Metropolitan Temple last night. He said among other things that personal experience and investigation had proved to him beyond the shadow of a doubt that disorderly houses in certain portions of the city employed little boys and girls to distribute their cards, and that these cards had been distributed on the very steps of the church itself.

Contributions toward the defense of Samuel J. Kennedy, on trial for the third time, charged with the murder of Emeline C. Reynolds, three years ago in the Grand Hotel, became known yesterday, have been made by at least one member of the jury in the second trial of the accused dentist, in which there was a disagreement.

ORANGE, N.J., May 27 -- Although the police persist in saying that they have a clue to the man who wrote the letters threatening to kidnap the daughter of Thomas A. Edison and the son of Warren Smith and the daughter of Victor Bianchi they have not made an arrest. They refuse to say who they suspect, but predict that if an arrest is to be made it will prove a sensation.

Vice Chancellor Pitney, at Jersey City, yesterday heard further testimony in the suit of Albert Goldstein against Bernard M. Ewing, President of the Pneumatic Fire Alarm Telegraph Company of New York, to have declared illegal action taken by the Board of Directors at a meeting held on Jan. 23 last.

An unacknowledged daughter, a fortune of $200,000 awaiting a claimant, an adopted son long missing, and a romantic career embracing many climes, all the traditional elements of conventional romance, in fact, have come to light in a case that is now engaging the attention of the Public Administrator, William M. Hoes.

VERGENNES, Vt., May 27 -- Lieut.-Gov. M.F. Allen, Vice President and Director of the Farmers' National Bank, which recently suspended here, and J.W. Ketchum, a member of the Legislature from this place, were arrested to-day by United States officers, under indictments charging them with complicity with Cashier D.Q. Lewis in wrecking the bank.

READING, Penn., May 27 -- A conference of much importance in its bearing on the strike of the 3,000 Reading Iron Company employes was held here to-day. A meeting of delegates from the various labor unions along the entire system of the Reading Railroad was held for the purpose of considering the advisability of calling out the Reading Railroad's union employes in support of the strike of the Reading Iron Company's men.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 27 -- Rain fell all day, and the cup yacht Constitution remained at her moorings on the west side of the torpedo station. The downpour did not prevent sightseers from going afloat to look the stately yacht over, however. The sailors were about early, but it was a foregone conclusion before breakfast that there would be no spin during the day, although there was a good northeast wind prevailing.

The downpour of the past two days has been ruinous to entertainment in the suburbs. It interfered with all the Saturday programme, and also with the Meadow Brook polo yesterday. In fact, a bluer Monday in or out of town could scarcely be imagined. Those returning from the country house parties on the early trains brought tales of wet and cold.

The bad weather of yesterday made it more difficult than ever to tell the exact number of strikers on the rapid transit subway. As much work was done as there would ordinarily have been on such a day, and where pumping out water was required the sub-contractors had no trouble in securing laborers for the purpose.

Dripping, dismal, and cold weather, a track deep in slush and mud and a rather commonplace programme offered meagre attractions at the Gravesend race course yesterday, but, in spite or all, the attendance was up to the remarkable average of the Spring and a crowd of about 5,000 splashed about and put in an extremely uncomfortable afternoon, trying hard to pick winners and meeting with but a moderate degree of success.
ANNAPOLIS, Md.; May 27 -- Manager Porterfield of the Naval Academy football team to-day gave the following schedule of games for the navy team in the season of 1901:

The Rev. Dr. Alfred H. Moment again astonished the members of the Brooklyn Presbytery yesterday afternoon by unexpectedly appearing at the meeting of that body in the Central Church. As a result, there was a scene, which was characterized by an exchange of bitter sentiments, Dr. Moment referring to his treatment by the Rev. Dr. David Gregg of the Lafayette Avenue Church as "hypocrisy."

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The five dismissed West Point cadets spent an hour and a quarter with Secretary Root this afternoon, and were emphatically told by that official at the close of the conference that their case was hopeless, and the department's decision final. The cadets did not seem able to accept this decision, and when they left Mr. Root's office were apparently under the belief that something could still be done.
NEWPORT, May 27 -- Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt, Sr., is the guest of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred G. Vanderbilt.

Attention was recently called in these columns to the enormous increase in the country's foreign trade balance, the record introduced showing for five years -- 1897-1961 -- (estimating results for only two months, May and June this year) a credit on merchandise account amounting to $2,650,000,000.

Announcement was made yesterday of the marriage on Saturday evening last of Prof. George D. Herron and Miss Carrie Rand, the ceremony having been performed in the apartments of Dr. Charles Brodie Patterson, 59 West Forty-fifth Street. The Rev. William T. Brown, pastor of the Plymouth Church, Rochester, N.Y., performed the ceremony.

There is something pitiful in the utter helplessness with which hundreds of thousands of men and women have submitted during the past six weeks to misery and risk in riding in the open cars of the trolley lines, especially those that cross the Brooklyn Bridge. These cars began to make their appearance on the Brooklyn lines in the few warm days vouchsafed to us in the early part of April.

The Listing Committee of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, at a special meeting called for the purpose, listed $100,000,000 first lien convertible 4 per cent gold coupon bonds of 1911, Nos. 1 to 100,000 inclusive (and registered bonds of $1,000, $5,000, and $10,000 into which the coupon bonds may be converted) of the Union Pacific Hallroad Company, the listing to be effective on June 10.

Harlem was shaken by a terrific explosion at 111 and 113 West One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street, between Lenox and Seventh Avenues, at 1:20 o'clock this morning. The two-story brick building at that address was badly wrecked, the stores of Robert Gleason, jeweler, and Robert Howison, undertaker, on the ground floor, being blown into one and the interior filled With the wrecked stock of both.

To the Editor of The New York Times: You publish to-day a letter from James H. Bates, in which is the following passage: "What a mountain of conceit has grown up in England the world too well knows. The effect of this upon every detail of English life, from foreign policy down to individual manners, has given us experiences of a very painful character.

In an affidavit to he filed in the County Court House to-day by Strong Cadwalader, attorneys for the Cumberland Realty Company, attention is called to the fact that Cot Winfield Scott Proskey was adjudicated a bankrupt.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The United States Supreme Court to-day affirmed the judgment of the Supreme Court of the State of Washington in the case of Charles W. Nordstrom, under sentence of death on the charge of murder committed in that State, and directed that the mandate be issued at once.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., May 28 -- Heavy, lowering clouds that threatened to deluge the picturesque field at St. Martin's Green were the conditions that met the gaze on the second day of the Philadelphia Horse Show.
Dispatches from Hannibal, Mo., stating that the Atlas Cement Company of New York has bought 1,000 acres of land there and will build a plant at a cost of $1,500,000.

ALBANY, N.Y., May 28 -- Company C of the Twenty-third Regiment of Brooklyn, which was stationed in this city during the recent street railway strike, has presented to Mrs. J.A. Jones of 197 Quail Street a handsome silver tea service. The gift was to show the company's appreciation of the many courtesies shown its members by Mrs. Jones during the strike.

The Herald Square Realty Company was incorporated at Albany yesterday, with a capital stock of $1,000,000. The Directors are Hugh J. Grant, Henry Morgenthau, Charles W. Morse, Andrew Joseph Hernsheim, Ernest Ehrmann, and Isidore Hernsheim.

PHILADELPHIA, May 28 -- The Readings and Union Traction were to-day's features in the stock market. The list sagged in the morning, but there was considerable improvement and strengthening in the late trading. Pennsylvania Steel was strong, advancing to 38, while the preferred sold at 81.
The members of the New York Cotton Exchange, at their annual meeting yesterday, voted to reduce from $5,000 to $4,500 the amount of gratuity paid to the heirs of all members hereafter admitted.

As if to demonstrate how great is the gap betwen a really good horse and the selling class division, The Parader, at the Gravesend race track, yesterday, with an actual run of a quarter of a mile, and very badly ridden at that, won the Preakness Stakes, over a course of a mile and seventy yards, after looking as though beaten through the carelessness of his jockey twice in that last quarter.

"During an experience of forty years in the army," said Major P. Henry Ray of the Eighth Infantry, Commandant at Fort Snelling, "the character of the enlisted men has never been so good as it is at present."

Two children of Mrs. Pauline Schmidt, who lives at 1,115 Willoughby Avenue, Brooklyn, were seriously injured yesterday afternoon by falling from a fire escape from the third story to the yard. The eldest child, Christina, six years old, received probable fatal injuries, while the youngest, Alfred, a boy, two years old, was very seriously hurt.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., May 28 -- The world's champion amateur sprinter, Arthur Duffy of Georgetown University, and Irving K. Baxter, Pennsylvania's high jumper, will go abroad this Summer to compete in the English championships. These will be held on June 29. It is possible, too, that these athletes will go over to France to take part in the games in that country.
LONDON, May 28 -- Richard Croker's Viper, (J. Reiff,) won the all-aged maiden plate, distance six furlongs, at the Hurst Park Club Whitsuntide meeting to-day.

A Jewish university, with an income of $60,000 a year, is to be established in this city. Its projector is the Rev. Dr. Isadore Singer, who is also the projector and manager of a Jewish encyclopedia, the success of which makes in large measure the new university possible.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 28 -- Booker T. Washington, on behalf of his race, today presented to the Constitutional Convention an appeal for conservative action. The address reminds the convention that the negroes came here against their will, out have been benefited, trained, and Christianized. They did their duty in the civil war and in the Spanish war.

The Police Department, through Commissioner of Police Michael C. Murphy, yesterday took official cognizance of the utterances of the Rev. Robert L. Paddock, vicar of the Pro-Cathedral in Stanton Street, made Monday night at the meeting in the Metropolitan Temple of the Co-operative Legion for the Moral Protection of Boys and Girls.

The strength of the "cadet tradition" that has been allowed to grow up at West Point was pathetically illustrated Monday before the Secretary of War, when five cadets whose dismissal from the academy he had approved in advance came before him to plead for reinstatement. The tradition seems to be that the academy is managed by its officers according to law, subject to the advice and consent and approval of the cadet body.
New York Calendars -- This Day. SUPREME COURT -- Appellate Division. -- Recess. SUPREME COURT -- Appellate Term -- For the hearing of appeals from the City Court and Municipal Court. -- Recess.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 28. -- After he had attempted once to commit suicide by shooting himself in the abdomen on board the steamer Plymouth last night and had been landed here for medical attention Alvah W. Brown, a well-known insurance man of New York, shot himself a second time to-day and died instantly.

Henry Phipps has bought, through Herbert A. Sherman, the plot at the northeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Ninety-sixth Street, 100 by 100, together with the two adjoining lots on the street, 50 by 100. The total consideration was about $325,000. The four lots on the comer were sold by J. Stuart and the two on the street by Jacob Ruppert, represented by L.J. Phillips Co.

The Rev. Dr. MOFFATT, President of Washington and Jefferson College, is evidently one of those persons whom it is extremely desirable to have in a general convention, sacred or secular. He has the faculty of detecting the essential desire of the body, under all its superficial disagreements, and of putting in words the consensus of the majority of its members as to what it is that they really "wish to say."

An unexpected but extremely interesting development of the contest in South Carolina between the progressive element, represented by Senator McLAURIN, and the Bryan Democracy, represented by Senator TILLMAN, resulted from the joint debate on Saturday at Gaffney. This joint debate was not of Senator McLAURIN'S seeking.

The men who hail from Missouri and who make New York their home, organized a society last night to be known as the "Missouri Society of New York." They began with a banquet at the Waldorf-Astoria, Augustus Thomas, the playwright, presided, and the opinion was generally expressed that he will be the President of the organization when it reaches the point of the election of officers.

The decisions of the United States Supreme Court in the insular cases were subjects of considerable discussion among lawyers in this city yesterday. James C. Carter, when asked by a NEW YORK TIMES reporter to give his opinion of the decisions, said:

Though trading in the stock market yesterday continued on a small scale, little more than 600,000 shares being dealt in, there was a distinct improvement in tone, prices quite generally moving upward. Yet in spite of these advances, the nature of the dealings differed little from those of lately preceding days.
MILFORD, Ohio, May 28 -- James G. Miner, an Assistant Secretary of the Confederate Navy during the civil war, died in poverty here to-day, aged eighty-two years.

One of the reasons why the majority of the jurors at the second trial of Samuel J. Kennedy, charged with murdering Emeline C. Reynolds, favored his acquittal, was given yesterday by a juror who has contributed toward Kennedy's third defense. This juror, who is a prominent business man, wishes his name withheld.

COLUMBIA, S. C., May 28. -- Senator Tillman issued an address from his home, in Trenton, this evening to the Democratic voters of South Carolina. It is mainly in defense of "an extraordinary and unparalleled situation" that has arisen in the State, "and, as I am mainly responsible for this, I feel that a proper respect for you requires an explanation of my actions and motives."

NEWPORT, R.I., May 28 -- The cup defender Constitution left her moorings here shortly after 1 o'clock this afternoon and for several hours gave as pretty an exhibition of quick handling and fast sailing in a light wind as was ever seen on a racing yacht. The spin was not taken to bring out any of the finer points of the yacht, but merely to test her rigging and to stretch her sails.

SAN JUAN, Porto Rico, May 28 -- The first report of the Supreme Court's decision in the De Lima case, received here last night, which, was interpreted as declaring the taxation of imports from Porto Rico to the United States at 13 per cent, of the Dingley duties to be unconstitutional, was received here with great satisfaction.

PHILADELPHIA, May 28 -- The one hundred and thirteenth Presbyterian General Assembly was dissolved at 6:15 o'clock tonight by Moderator Minton after having been in session for nearly two weeks, during which time many matters of the utmost importance to the Church were considered. Chief among these was the question regarding the revision of the Confession of Faith.
CHICAGO, May 28 -- Money for call and time loans to-day was had at 4 1/2@5 per cent. New York exchange was quoted at 25c premium.

Better weather yesterday brought with it a revival of country and suburban sports. Polo was begun at Meadow Brook. Mr. and Mrs. Price Collier had a party on the coach, and there were a number of other smaller affairs. This evening there is the dance at Morristown. Last evening there was an informal dance at the clubhouse at Ardsley.

The members of the "crooked" fraternity of New York who had the temerity to remain in the city yesterday had an opportunity of looking over for purposes of future identification one of the largest and most varied assortments of Police Chiefs and detectives ever assembled in one body in this country.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 28 -- Jacob Lawson, an engineer, employed as night foreman of a gang constructing a sewer a mile east of Greenwich, was murdered at 9:30 to-night by three Italians whom he had discharged. The murder was a particularly brutal one. Lawson was stabbed in the abdomen, being nearly disemboweled.

CHICAGO, May 28 -- Machinery manufacturers composing the Administration Board of the National Metal Trades Association are in session at the Great Northern Hotel to-day, trying to devise ways and means whereby the general strike of machinists throughout the country may be brought to a close.

The Eighth Assembly District went into mourning yesterday over the death of Bernard Rourke, who for nearly forty years was practically its ruler. Nearly everybody in the district, which is one of the most thickly populated in the city, knew that he was dead and was sorry for it, for the old politician, by some favor or other, had made a friend of almost every one who came under his influence.

The Rev. Dr. Daniel S. Gregory, editor of The Homiletic Review, formerly President of Lake Forest University, and one of the best-known Presbyterian theologians in the country, was asked by a reporter for THE NEW YORK TIMES to explain the meaning of the action of the Presbyterian General Assembly in adopting the "majority report" of the Revision Committee.

BOONE, Iowa, May 28 -- The members of the Cabinet aboard the Presidential train united in a telegram to ex-Attorney General Griggs, congratulating him upon the action of the Supreme Court in sustaining the able argument he made before the court. The telegram said that the decision of the court in his favor would partly compensate him for the months of hard work he devoted to the preparation of the case.

The Rev. Dr. Wilton Merle Smith of the Central Presbyterian Church, in West Fifty-seventh Street, who arrived yesterday on the steamship Aller, was seen last night, at his home, 34 West Thirty-ninth Street. He was one of the party with which the late Dr. Maltble D. Babcock of the Brick Presbyterian Church traveled to the Holy Land, but he left the party at Naples, two days before Dr. Babcock's death.

It is to be hoped that the official view of the State Department is correct and that no international importance is to be attached to the collisions, which have taken place between individual Germans and individual Americans in Peking. It is also to be believed. That there is a high international tension there is not only credible, but was almost inevitable.

A few stocks yesterday showed larger totals than any recorded in the outside market within the last few days, but the majority of stocks remained as dull as they have been for a week or more. Prices were firm, and most of the day's changes were on the side of net gains. In several instances large advances were made.

In the Richmond County Supreme Court, at St. George, S.I., yesterday morning, the suit of Robert L. Cutting and others, who held stock of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad and the Staten Island Rapid Transit Railroad, and all concerned in the foreclosure against the Staten Island Rapid Transit Railroad Company, and the transfer of its property to the new Staten Island Rapid Transit Railway Company, was before Justice Joslah T. Marean, sitting in Special Term.

-- Evidently there was something more than a premature judgment of work only just begun in the recent complaint of one of our correspondents that the contents of the superb new greenhouses in Bronx Park are receiving so little, or such unintelligent, care that their condition suggests to sensitive visitors the necessity for founding a Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Plants.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The United States Supreme Court, in passing upon the case of the Homer Ramsdell Company vs. La Compagnie Generate Transatlantique, coming to the court on certificate from the Circuit Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, replied specifically to two questions relating to pilotage.

The conferrees representing the several political bodies opposed to the domination of Tammany Hall in municipal affairs held their first meeting, last night at the headquarters of the Citizens' Union at 34 Union Square East.

The New York Institution for the Instruction of the Deaf and Dumb has nearly a century of activity to look back on, having been established by charter in 1817. It can boast of being the first oral school for the deaf established in the Unitea States; it is free to all deaf children in the State of New York, part of its income being supplied by the State and part by endowment.
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Supreme Court of the United States:

ORANGE, N.J., May 28 -- The kidnapping scare in this place and West Orange is subsiding. The police say they have not discovered anything to warrant the belief that the person or persons who sent the letters to Thomas A. Edison and others had any intention of abducting any one in Orange. The object of the letters, they believe, was to get up a "fake" sensation.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The members of the Women's Christian Temperance Union and their friends can well afford to endure the vilification and innuendo cast upon them by THE TIMES, when they remember that fifty years ago the advocates of the abolition of slavery were treated in much the same manner, and this reminds me of an incident of those exciting times.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., May 28 -- Lieut. Gov. Martin F. Alien to-day made a statement in regard to his connection with the Farmers' National Bank of Vergennes, Vt. Mr. Alien was Vice President of the bank. He has been indicted, with John W. Ketchum of Vergennes, charged with conspiring to defraud the bank.

The Manhattan Theatre under its new management will open in September next, when Minnie Maddern Fiske will begin an engagement that will cover the Autumn and Winter season. It was announced yesterday that the first production will be a play by Anne Crawford Flexner, entitled "Miranda of the Balcony," founded upon A.E.W. Mason's novel of that name, the dramatic rights to which were secured by Mrs. Fiske several months ago.

WORCESTER, Mass., May 28 -- Georgetown's baseball team won from Holy Cross to-day through ability to bunch hits when they meant runs. Both pitchers pitched steady ball, and strike-outs were numerous on both sides. Georgetown played a clean fielding game. The score:

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The expectation that the Supreme Court would to-day announce its decision in the remaining insular cases before it led another large audience to gather in the Supreme Court chamber at noon, only to listen to the disposition of a number of certiorari cases, and the order for adjournment of the court for the term.

HAVANA, May 28 -- The Platt amendment was accepted by the Cuban Constitutional Convention to-day by a vote of 15 to 14. The actual vote was on accepting the majority report of the Committee on Relations, which embodied the amendment with explanations of certain clauses.

CHICAGO, May 28 -- At a meeting to-day of the Boards of Directors of the Northwestern Elevated Railway Company and the Union Elevated Loop Company, the Northwestern decided to offer the loop company $125 cash per share for all the $5,000,000 loop stock. This offer was accepted, pending its ratification by the stockholders on Aug. 1.

BOSTON, May 28 -- At the Clearing House this morning money was in good supply at 2 1/2 per cent. There were several lenders at this figure, but little money was wanted. Some loans are still outstanding at 3 per cent., though loans at this rate were paid off this morning. New York funds hold strong at 10, 12 1/2, and 15 cents premium.

Rewards and punishments were both dealt out by Police Commissioner Murphy at Headquarters yesterday when he ordered that Policeman Thomas Kelly of the Steamboat Squad and Policeman W.H. Ahrens of the East Twenty-second Street Station be made Roundsmen for bravery, and dismissed three men from the force.

PHILADELPHIA, May 20 -- Union Traction stock came on the market in considerable quantity to-day, nearly all in hundred-share blocks, the selling emanating from scattered sources. While the weakness was most marked, some local houses received advices from Harrisburg to the effect that legislation would be introduced there looking to a franchise for an elevated railway.

Trading in the outside market yesterday was again on a small scale, although in some parts of the list more life appeared than has shown on any day recently. American Can was much more active and several other issues shared slightly this increase in activity. In several instances prices advanced sharply, and as has been the case during the present dull period quotations in general held firm.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 29 -- The Supreme Court jury drawn to estimate the damages due Mrs. Augusta Lewin for the loss of a cheek bone amputated after an accident, from the Lehigh Valley Railroad Company, returned a verdict for $10,000 today. The suit grew out of the accident at the Town House crossing near Farmington, in January, 1898, in which the plaintiff's eighteen-months-old baby was killed and she and several others were severely iniured.

PHILADELPHIA, May 29 -- New York exhibitors almost swept the boards to-day at the Philadelphia Horse Show, which was continued at Wissahickon Heights. The weather cleared late in the afternoon sufficiently to allow an excellent exhibition of horsemanship by sixteen cadets from the Pennsylvania Military College, including a hair-raising cavalry drill.

Some excitement was caused by a witness who appeared before Justice Russell in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday in the suit for absolute divorce brought by Mrs. Helen E. Campbell, a wealthy woman, formerly residing in Buffalo, against Dr. Robert E. Campbell, a prominent physician of that city.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 29 -- The managers of the Pennsylvania, Columbia, and Cornell crews drew places to-night for the race of the second varsity crews to be rowed tomorrow. Columbia had her luck with her and drew the inner course next to the shore, Pennsylvania drew the middle course and Cornell the extreme outer course.

Not with the best grace in the world, but finally and fully, the Cuban Constitutional Convention has assented to the terms imposed by Congress as the antecedent condition to the transfer of the government and control of the island to its people. Of the report adopted by the convention the Platt amendment is the only part that is of binding force and authority that anybody is bound to respect.

Margaret Rennan, twelve years old, of 210 East Twenty-ninth Street, a stout girl with fat fingers, put her mother's wedding ring on the middle finger of her right hand last night and the finger swelled so she could not get the ring off again. The swelling was so painful that her mother took her to Bellevue Hospital, where two surgeons were unable to remove the band.

LONDON, May 30 -- The world at large stands to gain something by this momentous decision by which Congress may devise for the dependencies a form of government outside the American Constitution," says The Westminster Gazette, in discussing the United States Supreme Court's decision in the insular cases.

PASSAIC, N.J., May 20 -- The girl strikers of the Axheson, Hardern Co.'s handkerchief factory made another riotous demonstration this morning. They gathered in force at the factory at an early hour waiting for the girls who are employed in the mill. Only about 100 girls went to work this morning out of a force of about 500 hands.

Rain, wind, and cold weather combined yesterday to keep racegoers away from the Gravesend track and caused the first really small crowd that has attended the races this season. The betting element was well represented, however, and the ring did not suffer for want of patronage in spite of the fact that the crowd numerically was equal to only about half tlie ordinary figures for attendance this year.
CHICAGO, May 29 -- James K. Hackett said to-day:
GREENPORT, L.I., May 29 -- A large number of well-known yachts are now undergoing overhauling and repairs at the basin of the Greenport Basin and Construction Company here.

Thomas Kevelin of 102 Fifteenth Street, Brooklyn, will probably bring suit to get possession of his niece, Viola Oliver, an orphan, who ran away from his home on Easter Sunday. Mr. Kevelin is Superintendent or the Merritt Wrecking Company, and is wealthy, while the aunt with whom Viola is now living is poor.

BARTOW, Fla., May 19 -- Frederick Rochelle, a negro, thirty-five years of age, who at noon yesterday assaulted and then murdered Mrs, Rena Taggart, a well-known and respectable white woman of this city, was burned at the stake here early this evening in the presence of a throng of people.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 29 -- Constitution had two trial spins to-day, one in the forenoon and the other in the afternoon. In the latter, Capt. Duncan took the yacht outside for the first time since she has been here, and in her novel experience with a heavy seaway she acquitted herself most creditably.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- With the return to-morrow morning of the President and the members of the Cabinet who journeyed with him to San Francisco there will be a meeting of the Cabinet, and it is expected that the chief subject of discussion and action, if action be considered necessary, will be with reference to the decisions just handed down in the Supreme Court touching insular affairs.
The thirty-fifth annual regatta of the Harlem Regatta Association will be held over the Speedway course on the Harlem River to-day, beginning at 10 A.M. The order of events will be as follows:
BOSTON, May 29 -- At the Clearing House to-day money was in good supply at 2 1/2 per cent. New York funds sold at 15 cents premium for cash. Exchanges, $20,486,236; balances, $2,606,622.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., May 29 -- The jury in the case of James Tobin, accused of shooting his wife with intent to kill, found him guilty to-day after fifteen minutes' deliberation. Tobin on the stand denied all knowledge of the crime. He testified that Mrs. Tobin had repeatedly refused to live with him.

The first impression received by some readers from the perusal of the various opinions of the Justices of the Supreme Court in what are known as the "insular cases" is likely to have been that the Justices who sustained the Government were influenced in a considerable degree by the desire to justify what had actually been done and what in the nature of the situation was practically certain to be done.

That decision of the Supreme Court of the United States which was announced the day before yesterday was calculated to excite regret not unmingled with irritation. The announcement was that the court, "after a session of three minutes," had adjourned until the second Monday in October.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- There is reason to fear that the action of the Cuban Constitutional Convention upon the Platt amendment was not as satisfactory as was at first indicated. On the contrary, it is believed that the original majority report has been adopted without important amendment.

WORCESTER, Mass., May 29 -- Holy Cross baseball team defeated Cornell, 3 to 2, in a closely, contested game in this city this afternoon. Lyon outpitched Noone of Holy Cross, but the visitors erred too frequently in the field. Score by innings:

NEWPORT, R.I., May 29 -- Cornelius Vanderbilt's seventy-foot sloop Rainbow will be towed by her tender Mirage to City Island to-morrow, where she will be docked upon arrival. All her spars, sails, and equipments are aboard of her, and when she shall have been fitted out, she will return here and give Constitution a few races.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- A question has been raised here that will be unsettled until Gov. McSweeney of South Carolina has accepted the resignations of Senators Tillman and McLaurin. These resignations are so prepared as to give the Senators until Sept. 15 to back out of the position in which they are now seen by the public.

HARRISBURG, Penn., May 29 -- In the Senate this afternoon a bill was introduced which will give corporations the right to construct either underground or elevated railroads in cities, boroughs, and townships. Another bill introduced at the same time will give to street railway companies considerable more power than they now possess.
The first convictions of gamblers taken in raids of the Committee of Fifteen were obtained by Assistant District Attorney Schurman in General Sessions, before Recorder Goff yesterday.

ALBANY, May 29 -- An association of the alumni of the Albany Law School was organized to-day and 200 lawyers from this and other States are in attendance. President McKinley, who was a member of the class of '67, was elected Honorary President, and Chief Judge Alton B. Parker of the Court of Appeals, active President.

BOSTON, May 29 -- The libel suit for $150,000 brought by Josephine C. Woodbury against Mary Baker G. Eddy was put on trial to-day before Judge Bell and a jury in the First Session of the Superior Court, and hundreds of would be spectators, most of them women, were unable to gain admittance.

Charles T. Barney has acquired from Francis M. Jencks, a plot of about 101 lots, in the territory bounded by One Hundred and Thirty-fourth and One Hundred and Thirty-seventh Streets, Broadway and the proposed Riverside Drive extension. Mr. Barney already owned the westerly frontages on Broadway from 50 feet north of One Hundred and Thirty-fourth Street to One Hundred and Thirty-seventh Street.

Henry Van Arsdale Parsell. Henry Van Arsdale Parsell died yesterday at his home, 31 East Twenty-first Street, at the age of sixty-eight years. Mr. Parsell was one of the best known philanthropists and reformers in a quiet way that ever lived in the city. He was born in New Brunswick, N.J., and came to New York while a young man.

-- Though the eagle is obviously more decorative than the hen, and therefore, justly enough, more of a favorite with both poets and painters, we have our doubts about the wisdom of the eminent Mrs. ALICE STONE BLACKWELL in advising American women to make the mother eagle, rather than the mother hen, the representative of their aspirations.
NEWPORT, May 29 -- Mrs. J.R. Busk and Miss Busk arrived at "Indian Spring" for the season this evening.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., May 29 -- The second day's session of the Confederate Veterans' reunion opened in Confederate Hall by the singing of the Doxology by the delegates and the offering of a prayer. The report of the Committee on Credentials showed a total representation of 1,359 camps, with an aggregate attendance of 2,309 delegates.

BOSTON, May 29 -- Joel Goldthwait, head of the firm of Joel Goldthwait Co., carpet dealers, at 160 Washington Street, died this morning at his home at the Hotel Victoria. Born in Marblehead, in April, 1831, he came to Boston in 1847 and entered, as a clerk, the carpet store of Bates Goldthwait, which had been established by his elder brother, John.

BOONEVILLE, Mo., May 29 -- By the explosion of 1,000 detonating caps which set off 2,100 pounds of dynamite and 100 kegs of powder, the fourteen-ton freight boat Laurine, plying between this city and Rocheport on the Missouri River, was blown to pieces last night. Considerable damage was done to property for a mile around.

OSWEGO, N.Y. May 29 -- Prof. I.B. Poucher, Principal of the Oswego Normal School, to-day received a sold medal from the Paris Exposition officials in recognition of his work on the Normal School exhibit.

The Board of Directors of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad met yesterday and accepted the resignation of John K. Cowen as President of the road. L.F. Loree, at present Fourth Vice President of the Pennsylvania lines west of Pittsburg, was elected according to the prearranged programme to succeed Mr. Cowen.

CHICAGO, May 29 -- Through the mysterious death of a brother of Dr. August M. Unger in New York in September, 1899, under circumstances similar to those attending the demise of Marie Defenbach, the State's Attorney's office is seeking to throw some light on the identity of the mysterious packet transmitted to the unfortunate girl by Dr. Unger a few hours before her unexpected collapse.

The speech of Col. JOHN B. KNOX, President of the Alabama Convention to revise the Constitution of that State, on assuming the chair, is interesting and instructive. It leaves no doubt as to the attitude of the convention or what the delegates regard as their duty to the people of the State.

Memorial Day marks the boundary absolute between Winter and Summer, and town and country seasons. To-day, society has arranged a most attractive programme of outing, but if the present weather continues much will have to be abandoned. Last evening there was a dance at the Morristown Golf Club, and there is to be today, weather permitting, a polo game at Meadow Brook and golf at all the suburban clubs.

BERLIN, May 29 -- Emperor William, at the annual review to-day of the Brigade of Guards, led the attack in person for five hours. Then, at the head of the Color Company, he led the brigade through the city. His Majesty was accompanied by a brilliant entourage, including Major-Gen. Bonnat, Director' of the Ecole Superieure de Guerre, and the other French officers here.

John J. Bergen of 135 West Forty-fourth Street was so severely hurt early yesterday morning by being thrown from a Lexington Avenue car by some employes of the Metropolitan Street Rail-way Company that he had to be taken to Bellevue Hospital, where he remained until the afternoon.
CHICAGO, May 29 -- Money for call and time loans to-day was unchanged at 4 1/2 @ 5 per cent. New York exchange was at 10c premium.

BOSTON, May 29 -- A gray sky overhead and a chill in the air were rather dispiriting conditions to the collegians who had matches to play on the Longwood courts in the newly-formed New England Intercollegiate Tennis Tournament to-day. The chief encouragement was that the tournament finally got started after two postponements.

ST. LOUIS, May 29 -- Bettors at the Fair Association track to-day were staggered when Sans Pareil II., with the ions odds of 80 to 1 chalked against her, took the second event from the heavily played favorite, Helen Print, by a nose. Their surprise was intensified when Zonne at 40 to 1, galloped over a good field in the fourth race.

At dawn yesterday morning only a slight mist hovered over New York. There were rumors that there was a sun in the east. It was the usual hoax. The rain came about 9 o'clock, gradually increasing in ferocity until about 2 o'clock, when there came a downpour that made an habitual pedestrian remark that life, instead of being a "long, sweet song," had become a "sad, sweet swim."

Rain, mist, and fog did not deter the polo players from going on with their game yesterday at the Meadow Brook Hunt Club, near Westbury, L.I., and the opposing teams representing Meadow Brook First and the Country Club of Westchester lined up promptly on time in the third contest for the Hempstead cups.

The second day's session of the convention of the National Association of Police Chiefs of the United States and Canada was for a time disturbed yesterday by the presentation of a paper by Chief Deitsch of Cincinnati on police organization, in which the social evil was discussed. Chief Jansen of Milwaukee moved that the paper be spread upon the minutes.

Handwriting Expert Persifor Frazer, called by the State to show that Samuel J. Kennedy, charged with murdering Emeline C. Reynolds, wrote the indorsement on the thirteen-thousand-dollar check found on the dead girl's body, created a small sensation in Judge Newburger's courtroom yesterday by requesting the jury not to place too much reliance in what he had just said.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- The eightieth commencement of Columbian University took place at the National Theatre here tonight. The honorary degree of LL.D. was conferred on the Rev. Dr. August Schultze, President of the Moravian College at Bethlehem, Penn. Among the students who received degrees, were Chohei Shirasu of Japan, a graduate of Yale, and Colyer Meriwether, formerly a teacher in Japan.

PITTSBURG, Penn., May 29 -- When the President and his party end the long trip across the Continent upon their arrival at Washington to-morrow morning they will have been gone thirty-two days and will have traveled approximately 6,675 miles. The last day of the homeward journey was a ride across the President's native State of Ohio.
Being asked his opinion of the platform adopted last week by the General Committee of the German-American Reform Union, W. Bourke Cockran answered in a letter, in which he says:
DRESDEN, May 29 -- Paderewski's threeact opera "Manru" was produced at the Royal Opera to-night and was received with every sign of popular enthusiasm.

LONDON, May 20 -- Money was easier today, the supplies being fairly large and Stock Exchange money being cheaper than at the last settlement. The market's indebtedness to the Bank is believed to be cleared off. Discounts also were easier.

While the veterans of two wars, with their families, have planned to devote today to memorial exercises they by no means constitute the only element of the population that has come to look forward to the holiday with interest. It is essentially a day that interests amateur sportsmen and athletes, for by common consent some of the leading events and contests of the season are scheduled for May 30.

The Metropolitan Street Railway Company is about to break up and sell as old junk $1,600,000 worth of machinery which is as good as new, but which has become valueless since the change of the motive Power on Broadway, Lexington and Columbus Avenues from cable to electricity. This machinery is now located in the power-houses at Houston Street and Broadway, Lexington Avenue and Twenty-fifth Street, and in the Fiftieth Street power-house.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, May 29 -- The wages of the skilled and unskilled day men of the Youngstown, Girard, Warren, and Greenville plants of the American Steel Hoop Company, one of the constituent companies of the United States Steel Corporation, have been voluntarily increased from 10 to 20 per cent.

For the first time in its existence of thirty-five years the annual regatta of the Harlem Regatta Association yesterday was rowed not over the narrow and crooked course on the lower river, but over the long, straightaway upper reach, from University Heights to Washington Bridge. The superiority of the new course was admitted by all who took part in or witnessed the regatta.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 30 -- Cornell's second 'Varsity oarsmen rowed a magnificent race on Cayuga Lake this afternoon, and won from the second 'Varsity crews of Columbia and Pennsylvania by two and five lengths, respectively. The Cornell crew won because the men rowed in better form than did their opponents, and because at the finish they seemed to have an abundance of reserve power in them.

PHILADELPHIA, May 30 -- Thirty-two of America's leading chess players, representing the Manhattan Chess Club of New York and the Franklin Chess club of this city, participated in the first of a series of team matches for the possession of a challenge trophy at the rooms of the local organization in the Betz Building this afternoon and evening.

The New York Conference of the African Methodist Episcopal Church, which has been meeting in Brooklyn, had an exciting session yesterday. The excitement was due to the remarks of Dr. W.L. Hunter, a colored physician and member of the conference, who arraigned the Government for its treatment of the negro.

The four men who have been practically abandoned on Navassa Island, in the West Indies, since December last will be brought to New York on the steamship Alps, which is due here on June 12. The Alps left here for Cape Haitien on May 18 and was to stop for the men on her outward-bound trip, and it is expected that by this time they are off the island.

The Kaltenborn Summer concerts will begin at the St. Nicholas Garden to-morrow night. The orchestra, which will play under Franz Kaltenborn this season, is composed of forty-five selected musicians, a number of them members of the New York Philharmonic and the remainder experienced orchestral players.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- The weather finally cleared off here to-day, and the much-delayed tournament for the Southern championship in lawn tennis was continued under auspicious conditions. There is a tremendous entry list in the five events, and tour of them were pushed along to the semi-final stages to-day.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue of to-day Dr. Gregory in an interview makes a statement about the Lutheran Church, which in the interest of fairness to this large and influential body of Christians, as well as for the sake of truth, needs correction. Dr. Gregory says, that at the time of the framing of the Westminster Confession Lutherans taught "infant damnation.''

The residents of Port Richmond have a sensation, according to Melville E. Wygant, one of its prominent citizens. Somethins has happened which has been long expected -- the old Hatfield homestead, which has stood on Richmond Avenue since the days of the Revolution, has given up its treasure, a pot of gold.

BERLIN, May 30 -- Gen. Bonnat, Director of the French War School, is delighted at the reception accorded to the French officers by Emperor William, and at the interesting military sights witnessed. He said to-day:

POTSDAM, May 30 -- Queen Wilhelmina and her husband' arrived here to-day. They were received at the station by the Emperor and Empress, who accompanied them to the new palace. The visitors were warmly cheered.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As a subscriber to your otherwise excellent paper, I feel entitled to protest against the attitude you have assumed on the canteen question. You are seemingly making out a strong case against the new law by your description of pay-day orgies under the present condition.

-- In discussing the recent imposition at White Plains of a heavy fine upon a Dowieite fanatic who had allowed his little daughter to die without summoning a doctor or even a nurse, The New York Med-_ ical Journal makes clear the special atrocity of the homicide committed and the reason why the infliction of punishment in such cases should be commended, even by those most solicitous for the preservation of personal liberty.
NEWBURG, N.Y., May 30 -- The opening meet on the half-mile track of the Newburg Driving Park was held this afternoon. One thousand persons were present. The track was heavy. The summary:
MIDDLETOWN, Conn., May 30 -- Wesleyan's baseball team defeated Columbia here this afternoon by a score of 15 to 7. The game was marked by heavy batting and loose fielding. Score by innings:

John McCollough, twenty-two years old, a fine-looking Southerner, was arrested on board the steamship City of Augusta at the Savannah Line pier, No. 35, North River, yesterday, and taken away from his bride of a few days to spend the night in a cell at Police Headquarters. His bride was distracted, and friends had to care for her and take her away.

The baseball teams of New York and St. Louis broke even yesterday at the Polo Grounds, the New Yorks winning the morning game by the score of 6 to 4, and losing the afternoon game after a stubborn contest of ten innings by the score of 6 to 5. Only the most hardened rooters expected the playing of a game in the morning, and consequently but 2,500 visited the grounds.

Out of the earnings of her music-hall career Yvette Guilbert has built for herself a gorgeous residence on the Boulevard Berthier. The house is a large white stone building, built from blocks extracted from the famous quarries at St. Denis. From the outside the hotel discloses the identity of its fair occupant, for the main feature of the corbel of the drawing-room window is the head of the singer smiling at the passerby.

HAMILTON, N.Y., May 30 -- The fifth annual field meet of the New York State Intercollegiate Athletic Union was won by Colgate University this afternoon. The day was cloudy, but the new Whitnal Field was in superb condition and a large crowd was present. Rochester team was confident of coming out victorious.

Light and fluky winds yesterday turned the nineteenth annual regatta of the Harlem Yacht Club into more or less of a drifting match, when the yachtsmen, after using spinnakers on the first part of the last leg, finally had to beat home. Exasperating weather conditions aside, the yachtsmen had a fine day of it, and there were several races of interest, although none of the finishes was close.

Brig. Gen. Thomas Wilson, a retired officer of the United States Army and West Point graduate, died at a private hospital at 130 East Sixty-fifth Street at 7 o'clock last evening. He was about seventy-five years old. He had been sick for the last ten weeks, his trouble being due to general debility.

CHICAGO, May_30 -- Chicago's time-honored cycle road race was not run to-day, in deference to the wishes of the veterans of the civil war. In its stead was run the century bicycle contest, under the auspices of the American Century Wheelmen's Club. The start wag made at 5:30 o'clock in the morning, with less than 100 entries.

PHILADELPHIA, May 30 -- The horsy crowd was on hand with the opening exhibits at the Philadelphia Horse Show today. Mrs. John Gerkin of New York was photographed on My Lady Dainty, while Mrs. H.H. Good, also of New York, posed on L'Allegro.

It was a red-letter day for the members of the Greater New York Irish Athletic Association yesterday, when it held a carnival of athletic games and Gaelic football, interspersed with Irish reels and jigs and other social festivities. The occasion was the opening of the association's new pavilion at Celtic Park, and perhaps 5,000 people gathered to see the new building and witness the various events of the afternoon.
A good hour before even the official programme had fixed the time for the marching of the Memorial Day parade, a young women climbed into the reviewing stand at Twenty-fifth Street on Fifth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- An important conference on Cuban relations took place at the White House this afternoon. There were present with President McKinley, Secretary Root, Senator O.H. Platt, Chairman of the Senate Committee on Relations with Cuba, and Senator Spooner of Wisconsin.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 30 -- The Syracuse University freshman crew has secured a race with the second Cornell freshman crew on Onondaga Lake, June 14.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 30 -- The crew of the Constitution had a half holiday to-day after finishing the usual morning routine work. Shortly after 1 o'clock this afternoon the mainsail, staysail, and jib were set and the cup yacht sailed up the bay in charge of Capt. Rhodes for Bristol, where some slight repairs are to be made.

Standing just outside the tomb of a great American, an American audience listened yesterday while a Chinese diplomat told them of the virtues and valors of the man commemorated by the towering structure in whose shadow they were. The Chinaman could find no higher compliment than to liken the American to Li-Hung-Chang, he said, and his comparison was cheered at every possible interval.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- The attention of the War Department has been directed to an inquiry sent to THE NEW YORK TIMES by a lady opposed to the canteen at army posts, concerning the action of the department upon an offer extended to it by Francis H. Buzzacott, late Fifth United States Cavalry and Sergeant United States Volunteer Infantry in the Porto Rico campaign.

SAVANNAH, Ga., May 30 -- John McCollough, stenographer, in the office of Lester Ravenel, was married in Savannah, Tuesday afternoon to Miss Agnes Bell, and left at once. He is charged with having forged the name of the firm for $575, and with numerous other forgeries. Deputy Sheriff Sweeney left to-night to bring him back.

BETHLEHEM, Penn., May 30 -- In the most exciting game of baseball seen on Lehigh field this season, Pennsylvania went down before the Brown and White to-day by the score of 11 to 10. With the score 10 to 7 in favor of Pennsylvania, in the ninth inning Lehigh went to the bat and pounded Leary for 3 runs.

As the salute of twenty-one guns, fired in honor of the National memorial holiday at Governors Island, boomed forth yesterday a trim-looking ship of the French type arrived off Liberty Island and cast anchor. As the last gun on the island was discharged, from the side of the ship there immediately came forth another report, to which were added twenty more.

BOSTON, May 30 -- Six matches were played to-day in the New England intercollegiate tennis championship tournament at Longwood, five singles and a double, and the results put Bowdoin, University of Vermont, and Trinity out of the running. Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Brown are still represented, both in singles and doubles, while Wesleyan, Amherst, and Tufts have a chance in one of the other events.

An autopsy was held yesterday afternoon in the basement of the Museum of Natural History on the remains of "Dewey," the South African ostrich, which died last Monday in the Central Park Zoological Gardens, and it was found that the deceased ostrich came to his death from a grain of corn.

In the presence of a distinguished company of about 5,000 people, representing thirty or more scientific or patriotic institutions, the Hall of Fame was dedicated yesterday afternoon, and the twenty-nine tablets, each in honor of the name of a famous American, were unveiled. Senator Chauncey M. Depew delivered an oration in celebration of the occasion, and short addresses were made by representatives of different organizations.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 30 -- Cornell gave Princeton a surprise when the track teams of the two universities met on Percy Field this afternoon. The Ithacans scored 64 points to the Tigers' 40, and won the meet. Cornell had a winning lead after eight of the thirteen events had been run off, as then she had 55 points.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE TIMES of yesterday "G.S.L." attacks the position of Mr. Ellis J. Seymour regarding the "rights and duties of corporations in general and the Albany Traction Company in particular." I judge Mr. Seymour capable of defending his own position without assistance, but "G.S.L." asks a question which I can answer.
LONDON, May 30 -- Preparations on the Stock Exchange for payments of monthend requirements caused a good demand for money to-day. Discounts were easy.

Without doubt it is very interesting and very gratifying intelligence that the "Allies" are about to evacuate China. It is an announcement, in effect, that the Germans are satisfied that "their warfare is accomplished." So long as there was any manifest and obvious need of fighting in China they were unfortunately debarred from taking part in it.

The Rev. Dr. John D. Wells, for more than fifty years pastor of the South Third Street Presbyterian Church, in Williamsburg, is ill in the parsonage adjoining the church, suffering from chills and fever. Dr. Wells is over eighty years old.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., May 30 -- The thirty-third annual convention of the National Woman's Suffrage Association opened this afternoon in the First Baptist Church, with a large attendance of delegates and all of the National officers except Mrs. Catherine Waugh McCulloch of Chicago.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., May 30 -- A drifting race under a five-mile breeze opened the yachting season, the contest being the annual regatta for the Citizens' Cup, sailed off the Bridgeport Yacht Club's course. The contest was between the sloop Kit, Thomas H. MacDonald, and the sloop Tern, C.E. Perkins of the Park City Yacht Club.

Just as the pistol of the starter cracked, the signal for the annual twenty-five-mile bicycle road race between Irvington and Millburn yesterday afternoon, the sun appeared through the clouds for almost the first time in three weeks. From start to finish of the race the weather was fine, as it has been on every Decoration Day since the event was first established twelve years ago, with the single exception of that day in 1897.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I wish to call your attention as well as that of the reading public to the following incident which illustrates the true corrupt condition of the New York theatre box offices. Several days ago a general denial was made in THE NEW YORK TIMES by the manager of the New York Theatre of the alleged association of manager and speculators.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Bravo, TIMES! Tour canteen editorials are just right. As to the surprising complacency of the "W.C.T.U." and its "male accomplices" -- I quote you, how refreshing to read the words of Lecky in "The Map of Life"! "It is hardly possible to exaggerate the calamities that have sprung from misjudged unselfish actions."

BUFFALO, May 28 -- "The weather continues so cold," several Buffalonians have told me, "because the lake is still full of floating ice"; and on the strength of this chilly hint, I went down to the lake this morning to see how a lake looks when full of ice at a season when the water ought to be almost warm enough for swimming in.

CHARLESTON, S.C., May 30 -- Senator McLaurin issued an address to the people of the State from his home in Bennettsville to-day. He opens by saying that the recent address to the people by Senator Tillman makes it necessary that he should say something in explanation of his motives and actions and that "had it not been for Senator Tillman's intrusion upon the Gaffney meeting there would have been no necessity for it.
LAKE MOHONK, N.Y., May 30 -- The subject discussed at this morning's session of the Arbitration Conference was the influence of commerce and commercial bodies upon the peace of the world.

NEWARK, N.J., May 30 -- It was a great crowd that gathered at the Vailsburg bicycle track this afternoon for the Decoration Day races, the programme of which had been arranged with more elaborateness than usual. Long before the time for starting, the sun had come out, so the patrons of the place did not have the same suspense as did those who went out to see the Irvington-Millburn road race.
