NEW HAVEN, May 30 -- The first annual exhibition of work by graduates of the Yale Art School will open to-morrow evening, when a reception will be given in the Art School by the President and Faculty of the school. An address will be given by Frederick P. Vinton of Boston on "Some Old and New Masters," after which the exhibition will be thrown open.

BERLIN, May 30 -- Count Wilhelm von Bismarck, brother of Prince Herbert Bismarck, and second son of the late Prince Bismarck, died this morning, after an illness of six days. The cause of death was peritonitis.

Distinguished prelates of the Roman Catholic Church and scores of members of the laity prominently identified with the commercial, professional, and social life of New York, besides many prominent citizens who are not Catholics, thronged the home of the Catholic Club, 120 West Fifty-ninth Street, last night to join in honoring Sebastian.

PHILADELPHIA, May 30 -- A rowboat containing a party of eight young persons was swept over Flat Rock Dam, in the Schuylkill River, this afternoon and seven of them -- five girls and two boys -- were drowned.

ELIZABETH, N.J., May 30 -- The annual Horse Show of the Union County Hunt Club was held at the old Dwyer track to-day. Owing to the rain the crowd was slim, and very little interest was manifested. The track-in front of the grand stand, where the jumping and hurdling took place, was soft and muddy.

"Never better in my life, and not sick for an hour while away," was the remark made by Gen. Frederick D. Grant when he was approached by a NEW YORK TIMES reporter on his arrival at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday.
PARIS, May 30 -- The Marquis de Vogue and Edmond Rostand have been elected members of the Academy, in place of the Due de Broglie and Vicomte Henri de Bornier.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 30 -- The Indian Harbor Yacht Club to-day sailed its championship race of the season for the raceabout class and a handicap race for club yachts forty-three feet and under, the distance being ten miles. Frank Bowne Jones took the prize in the raceabouts, and the first and second prizes in the handicap were awarded to Vice Commodore Alfred Peats and C.S. Somerville respectively.

Several unexplained circumstances surround the arrest yesterday of Perry Tiffany on a warrant issued more than a year ago. Mr. Tiffany has been in the city almost continuously since the time the warrant was issued, and as he is well known surprise was expressed that the arrest was made at this late date.

The Georgetown University baseball team easily defeated that of Fordham College yesterday afternoon on the latter's grounds by the score of 10 to 1. The result of the game was in doubt until the seventh inning, when the visitors bunched their hits and scored 5 runs. The score:

BUFFALO, May 31. -- Henry E. Perrine, a well-known business man of this city, is dead. His second wife, who survives him, was Mrs. Folsom. mother of Mrs. Grover Cleveland. Mr. Perrine was seventy-four years of age.

Justice Andrews, in the Supreme Court, has just decided one phase of the dispute among Harlemites over lawn tennis. Another branch of the case in which the Lenox Tennis Club, on one side, and the New York Lawn Tennis Club, on the other, are interested, was argued last week before the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, but the decision has not yet been handed down.

The habeas corpus proceeding instituted on behalf of Heyman Cohen, a Hebrew butcher, of 199 Henry Street, who was arrested on last Sunday morning for having sold meat to a customer in violation of the law passed this year (Section 267 of the Penal Code) directing the absolute closing of butcher shops on Sunday, was yesterday dismissed by Justice O'Gorman of the Supreme Court.
LONDON, June 1. -- The Spectator, discussing the Supreme Court decisions, says:

For the first time since the expulsion of the five cadets from the United States Miltary Academy they have made a statement giving their side of the so-called mutiny which resulted in the dismissal of the men. The statement was issued last night at the Murray Hill Hotel by Birchie O. Mahaffey, formerly the President of the second class at West Point.

BIEBER, Cal., May 31. -- Details have been received here of the lynching of five men at Lookout, Modoc County, early this morning. The victims were Calvin Hall, seventy-two years of age; his three half-breed sons. Frank. James, and Martin, aged respectively twenty-six, nineteen, and sixteen, and B. D. Yantis, aged twenty-seven.

PARIS, May 31 -- The election of Edmond Rostand to the Academy yesterday almost brought about indirectly a duel between Maurice Bernhardt and Lucien Muhlfeid, a well-known Parisian dramatic critic. M. Muhlfeid wrote an article in the Gaulois opposing M. Rostand, and in the course of the brought in the name of Mme. Bern hardt in a way that her son deemed offensive.

HAVANA, May 31. -- The decision of the United States Government not to accept the Cuban Constitution as adopted by the Havana Convention caused great surprise and keen disappointment to those members of the Convention who voted in favor of the Constitution as adopted.

KANSAS CITY, May 31. -- A warrant for Dr. W. G. Woodruff's arrest on a charge of kidnapping was sworn out before Justice Kenny in Kansas City yesterday by Mr. Mover, who arrived here recently from Ohio. All concerned formerly lived in Lawrence, Kan. Moyer was a prominent druggist, and the Movers become acquainted with Dr. Woodruff when he came from the East to act as coach for the Kansas University football team.

It is reported that one of the associates of Mr. MCLAITGHLIN in the leadership of the Democracy in Kings County remarked, after an interview with the Mayor that he thought that the Mayor would approve the East River tunnel plans, but that he was not sure. His mind seemed to be " open."

NEWARK, N. J., May 31. -- In the Second Criminal Court to-day John Qualey, President of the United States Carbonate Company, was accused of having assaulted on Wednesday last Patrick Egan, former United States Minister to Chile, and a Mr. Wright of Philadelphia.

The historical romance has become almost a plague to the reader of fiction. The first wholesome impulse which led to the writing of books end adventure is over. Many of the first of these books had some historical basis, the details of which had been carefully studied by the author.

Dr. John L. Feeny, Assistant Sanitary Superintendent of the Health Department for the Borough of Richmond, is dead. Dr. Feeny lived all his life at Stapleton, S. I., where he was born in 1845 and where he passed away at 9 o'clock yesterday morning. For many years before his death he was a political leader, identified with the Democratic Party.

Miss Edith Wyatt baa written a book of short stories that are delightfully fresh and abounding in the most good-humored satire. Misa Wyatt is the apostle of the commonplace person who worries not at all about either his mind or his soul. On the other hand. Miss Wyatt amuses both herself and her readers by satirizing the unbearable people who are puffed up with pride of intellect.

LONDON, June 1. -- Exactly a year after Lord Roberts's entry into Johannesburg the country is startled by the receipt of news of desperate fighting and heavy British losses within a few miles of the Gold Reef City.

Mr. Churchill needs a large canvas; at the bottom of his mind there is a strong historical instinct which shows itself is his use of backgrounds. He moves freely along large lines, and his stories are elaborated not as the result of calculation, but because he needs room. He paints on a large scale, and must have space for many figures and varied movement.
NEWPORT, May 31. -- The steam yacht Niagara, with Mr. and Mrs. Howard Gould and F.L.V. Hoppin on board, arrived this evening. Mr. Hoppin went to the Muenchinger-King cottage.

BOSTON, May 30. -- "A Daughter of New France," Miss Mary Catherine Crowley's story of the founding of Detroit, has reached its fourth edition, following in the footsteps of all the novels really founded upon Parkman's history, which seems to have more vivifying power for writers of fiction than any history written in English.

CHICAGO, May 31. -- One of the bitterest labor struggles in the history of Chicago began to-day when the machinists presented their ultimatum to the manufacturers. Within two hours 1,000 men were out, and it was admitted by all persons concerned that the strike order had proved effective.

BRISTOL, R. I., May 31. -- The extra backstays attached to the Constitution's mast a week ago and the preventer backstays were to-day shortened several feet, owing to the spring of the mainmast head bringing the end of the stays too near the deck. The mast snaps loudly when the boat is sailing in a stiff breeze.

It was announced that Mr. and Mrs. Edward Wells, both well known socially, had obtained a divorce. The decree separating them was granted to Mrs. Wells in Mandan, N. D., on May 24, on the ground of non-support. In order that there be no question as to the validity of the divorce, Mr. Wells filed an answer containing a general denial, but failed to contest the action.

An extra Summer number of The International Studio will appear June 30, of which only a limited edition of 1,500 will be issued. The topic of the issue will be "Modern British Domestic Architecture and Decoration," with chapters on architecture, decoration, furniture, stained glass, metal work, and embroidery.

In the United States District Court, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon, Justice Thomas granted an order directing G. Edward Graff and Thomas F. Nevins of the stock brokerage firm of G. Edward Graff Co., which recently made an assignment, to deliver to Levi W. Naylor, the receiver for the concern, certain stock or show cause why they should not be adjudged in contempt of court.

NEW BRUNSWICK, May 31. -- "Ronnie," a terrier, owned by the Rev. Dr. A. A. Murphy, pastor of the Second Presbyterian Church, was fatally poisoned three days ago by some unknown person. Dr. Murphy, who is a bachelor, wrote the following open letter to-day to the poisoner:

The great book sales of the past Winter, and especially the McKee, French, and Arnold Bales, were noteworthy events in many respects. Some reference to them, now that the season has closed, will be interesting.

PHILADELPHIA, May 31. -- "When the judges finish making the awards to New York exhibitors there will he precious few ribbons left for local and other fanciers to divide among themselves," said an interested spectator at the Philadelphia Horse Show to-day at Wissahickon Heights.

Reflecting the increase in activity and decided strength of the Stock Exchange market yesterday, trading in outside securities was on a broader scale than any recorded during the past ten days. Transactions were large in only a few issue but there was a fair amount of trading a number of stocks which of late have received little attention.

The fair weather has promoted gayeties in the suburbs and the country. All the out-of-door festivities and entertainments, the house parties, and club dances planned are taking place. This afternoon there is a reception at the, Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Club at Oyster Bay, and there Will be a dance to-night.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As you are generally fair and impartial in your criticisms of those with whom you differ, it is somewhat strange that you should call the women of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union cranks and fanatics. All great reforms originate with individuals, or with small minorities.

NEWARK, N.J., May 31. -- Judge Swayze to-day refused to allow a compromise verdict to be returned in the suit brought by Bailey Dickerson, a minor, against the North Jersey Railway Company for $10,000 damages. The boy lost an arm and a leg by being run over by a trolley car. An agreement had been reached between counsel in the case and the boy's parents whereby a settlement was to be made for $1,500.

PHILADELPHIA, May 31. -- On Wednesday night last, at the Broad Street Theatre, the Browning Society of this advancing burgh produced Rostand's "Les Romanesques." This bald statement of fact is entirely inadequate. Not only did the performance enjoy added interest in that this was the first stage rendering in English of this comedy edition of "Romeo and Juliet."

More than 100 members of the Republican Organization of the City of New York met at Lyric Hall, Sixth Avenue, near Forty-first Street, last flight, to discuss action to be taken relative to the coming municipal campaign.

BERLIN, May 31. -- Queen Wilhelmina and her husband witnessed the review by the Emperor of the Berlin garrison this morning. The Queen afterward drove to the royal castle with the Empress, the Emperor riding at the head of the First Regiment of Guards, with the Prince of the Netherlands on his right hand.
CHICAGO, May 31. -- D. B. Robinson, ex-Vice President of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad Company, died at his home in this city this afternoon, after a protracted illness.

WILMINGTON, Del., May 31. -- Joshua Gillman, aged twenty-six years, was killed, Conductor Elmer Jones was fatally injured, and about a score of passengers were hurt in a trolley accident in this city early this morning. Conductor Jones died to-night at the hospital.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- Senator Morgan of Alabama and ex-Senator Chandler of New Hampshire disagree with the Supreme Court's decision in the insular cases. Mr. Morgan disagrees with the decision that a tariff is constitutional, and Mr. Chandler with the decision that the Dingley duties were unconstitutional.

The Rev. Dr. Alfred H. Moment, who unexpectedly appeared at the meeting of the Brooklyn Presbytery last Monday and made a bitter attack upon the Rev. Dr. David Gregg, pastor of the Lafayette Avenue Presbyterian 'Church, and Chairman of the Judicial Commission which suspended him some time ago, yesterday wrote a letter of apglogy to Dr. Gregg.

BOSTON, Mass., May 31. -- The proprietors of the Boston Athenaeum at a special meeting this afternoon voted to sell their property on Tremont Place to the Tremont Building Trust. It was further voted to authorize the Trustees to buy three estates in Arlington Street, corner of Newbury Street, or other estates elsewhere, as the site of a new building.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- The Spanish Treatry Claims Commission is daily receiving applications for awards by persons representing men who lost their lives by the destruction of the Maine, most of the applicants claiming large amounts. Upon the presentation of the first claim of this sort the question arose whether action upon it would not bring up the question of responsibility for the loss of the Maine and compel the committee to decide.
Charles E. Schuyler Co. have sold for George B. Tripler the five-story Americanbasement dwelling 31s West One Hundred and Second Street, 20 by 100.11, one of a row of three built by A. B. Kight.

ST. PAUL, May 31. -- By a decision of the State Supreme Court to-day Russell Sage comes into possession of about 30,000 acres of land in Stearns County, this State, and settlers who have resided on this land for twenty to twenty-five years find themselves homeless, and will have to vacate or be evicted or buy the land, which has become very valuable.

BOSTON, Mass., May 31. -- The yacht Independence will go out for her first sail to-morrow if the weather be of the sort for an untried boat. The sails were carried to the boat this morning, and the first thing in the morning the sailors will bend them on, so that by 10 o'clock the Independence ought to have her nose headed toward Boston Light.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- As foreshadowed in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Thursday, the action of the Cuban convention on the Platt amendment has proved unsatisfactory to the United States. It is so unsatisfactory that it has inspired anger among the President's advisers, and has led to the taking of a tone much less conciliatory toward the Cubans than any that has hitherto been taken.
CHARLESTON, S C., May 31. -- The correspondent of The News and Courier at Bennettsville to-day interviewed Senator McLaurin, who said:

About the time when the sun should have shown its strange face to the residents of Port Richmond, S. I., yesterday morning Melville E. Wygant, the liveryman, and John Redmond, the court clerk, dug up that mysterious pot of gold which was found in the cellar of the old Hatfieid homestead on Wednesday last.
CHICAGO, May 31. -- New York exchange was quoted at 15 cents' premium to-day. Money for call and time loans ruled at 4 1/2 a 5 per cent.

Mr. John Albee's ''Remembrances of Emerson" will be found of unusual value and interest. He does not so much attempt a new valuation of Emerson as he does a much more novel thing -- the presentation of a simple story of the influence exerted by Emerson upon the young men of his time, a class to whom Mr. Albee personally belonged.

Weaver, leaves Bangor on her first trip since being rebuilt at Belfast, she will bear the St angest name ever given to a vessel, and thereby hangs an interesting tale.

SOUTH AMBOY, N. J., May 31. -- Travel on the New York and Long Branch Railroad was delayed three hours this morning on both the Central and Pennsylvania Railroads by a wreck on the Raritan River Railroad.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- Frederick D. H. Engley, a conductor on the Washington Traction Company's lines, and his brother, Samuel E. Engley of Hyattsville, Md., whose arrests yesterday on charges of forgery revealed an alleged plot for flooding the city with bogus car tickets, were arraigned to-day and waived examination.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. T., May 31. -- The athletic contests for this year were concluded at Vassar College this afternoon, and four new records were established. The events in which the old records were broken were the 220-yard run, running high jump, running broad jump, and 300-yard relay race.

LONDON, May 31. -- J. Dawson, Jr's, brown filly Rambling Katie, four years old, a rank outsider, won the race for the Manchester Cup at the Manchester meeting to-day, 2,500 sovereigns, distance one mile and three-quarters, in hollow fashion by four lengths. Mr. Fairie's bay colt Parquetry was second and W. C. Whitney's Kilmarnock II., ridden by Lester Reiff, third.

BOSTON, May 31. -- Boston Museum was chosen by the Free Religious Association of America as the place for holding its annual meeting this year, and at the opening session to-day Dr. Lewis G. Janes, President of the association, presided. His address was on "The Signs of the Times," and he briefly reviewed the new century from the viewpoint of free religion.

HONOLULU, May 25, via San Francisco, May 30. -- The special Grand Jury called to investigate the charges of bribery in the Legislature has had as witnesses Gov. Dole. Attorney General Dole, Secretary of the Territory Cooper, and other high officials, and on the refusal of some of them to answer questions it has had them brought into court to show cause why they should not testify.

The New Jersey Riparian Commissioners yesterday announced that they had made several grants on the Hackensack River. The fact is considered noteworthy, because it establishes a price in connection with meadow property bordering the river for the first time.

On board the Hamburg-American liner Fuerst Bismarck, which arrived at Hoboken from Hamburg yesterday afternoon, was Henri Turot, a representative of the Paris Journal, who is racing around the world against a representative of Le Matin of Paris, who is traveling via the eastward route.

TARRYTOWN, N. Y., May 31. -- Gen. Samuel Thomas, who is ill at Dobbs Ferry, is much improved to-night, and the doctors extend hopes of his ultimate recovery.

BALTIMORE, May 31. -- L. F. Loree, the new President of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, arrived at the main office of the company here to-day, and after being cordially greeted by John K. Cowen, the retiring President, was introduced to the heads of the various departments. He immediately set at rest the anxiety of the officials as to whether they would remain in the service.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- Senator Platt of New York was a visitor at the War Department to-day, and it is understood that he called upon Secretary Root to make an appeal in behalf of ex-Cadet Kellar, dismissed from the Academy a short time ago, and for Cadet Harry Hawley, one of the suspended students.

LAKE MOHONK, N. Y., May 31. -- The Lake Mohonk Arbitration Conference adopted its platform to-day. The platform congratulates the people who are in favor of arbitration for the settlement of international disputes, saying that much encouragement is to be derived from recent events. The platform rejoices "with profound gratitude " over the creation of a tribunal through the instrumentality of The Hague conference, before which nations great and small may bring their difficulties.

ENGLEWOOD, June 1. -- The baseball team of the New York Athletic Club began the season in the Amateur League with a victory, the Englewood Field Club meeting defeat by the score of 10 to 6 to-day, on the local grounds. Each team played a rather loose game in the field, the Englewoods especially so, their poor fielding contributing largely to their defeat, as Vorhis pitched well.

Keene, will win the race for the Derby at Epsom this year, an unusually large number of visiting Americans, now waiting in London, will visit the famous Epsom Downs when the Derby is run next Wednesday.

LONDON, June 1. -- The King has now turned his renovating energy in a new direction. Cranbourne Lodge, a forgotten royal residence, which lies in a beautifully wooded glade between Virginia Water and Ascot, is to be made a fit habitation. The lodge is a quaint house, built in the reign of Charles II. by the famous Lord Rane- lagh, and has some interesting rooms of that period.

BOSTON, June 1. -- The racing at the Country Club at Brookline closed this afternoon, with practically a jumping card, only one of the events, a six furlong sprint, being on the flat. The leading feature was the second steeplechase for the St. Botolph Cup, in which six horses ran, and Decameron won after an exciting race to the wire.

CHICAGO, June 1. -- No effort was made to-day by the local manufacturers to run their shops without the machinists, and so far as is known no non-union men are being employed. A meeting of the employers was called by the Chicago Machinery Manufacturers' Association late this afternoon at the Great Northern Hotel to consider the situation with a view to deciding upon a uniform line of action.

WITH the approach of warm weather Capt. Samuel C. Lemly, Judge Advocate General of the navy, has begun to turn his thoughts toward the Mediterranean Sea, where a comfortable blue serge suit belonging to him is supposed to be wandering. The Judge Advocate General does not know whether to be measured for a Summer suit.

CHICAGO, June 1. -- John Alexander Dowie apparently has triumphed over the enemies of "Zion." The Grand Jury, after a thorough investigation into the deaths of Mrs. H.W. Judd and her child, to-day refused to indict Dowie and his followers.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 1. -- Everything is in readiness at the State Camp for the reception of Squadron A and Troop C, which are expected to arrive there some time to-morrow. Squadron A arrived at Ossining this afternoon and went into camp for the night in the Ossining Camp. Troop C went into camp at Kingsland Point.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., June 1. -- The first break in the strike situation in Plainfield came this afternoon, when Superintendent J.W. Leary of the aluminum plate and press works granted his men the nine hours a day with ten hours' pay schedule. The works employ 130 machinists.

The security market is once more feeling the impulse of speculative buying. Prices rose materially last week, and the volume of transactions largely increased. Commission houses are again willing to carry stocks on reasonable margins instead of the almost prohibitive rates demanded after the panic.

SANTIAGO DE CUBA, June 1. -- All busi- ness is suspended on account of the municipal elections. Gen. Whitside yesterday ordered American officers to act in each precinct as a Board of Supervisors of Elec- tion, serving continuously from 6 o'clock in the morning until the vote is counted and verified.

CHICAGO, June 1. -- Chicago is having its usual variety of amusements. Fitch's "Lovers' Lane" has begun a run at McVicker's, which the management hopes will last during the Summer. Its first week has proved that it has a certain popularity. At Powers's Theatre "Are You a Mason?" has begun a run which promises to extend into the warm weather, which certainly has not yet arrived.

BOSTON, June 1. -- Brown University carried off the championship in singles as well as doubles in the New England intercollegiate tennis tournament, Gross of the Rhode Island college defeating Plimpton of Amherst this afternoon in the finals with comparative ease, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 1. Brown has now a good lead for the intercollegiate tennis cup over the other colleges in the league.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., June 1. -- The Morris County gulf links, near Morristown, N.J., fairly swarmed with players to-day, all of whom were anxious to take advantage of the first clear Saturday that they have enjoyed for weeks. Two events were held, one being a special contest between the Yale and Princeton freshmen, while the members played the first round for the silver cup recently presented by Louis Thebaud.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- The unfavorable weather which has prevailed here all the week again interrupted the Southern championship lawn-tennis tournament this afternoon, and now it will take at least two days of next week to finish the meeting. LINCOLN, Neb., June 1. -- Taking for his text the words, " Emperor McKinley," W. J. Bryan to-night gave out an extended statement bearing on the Supreme Court's decision in the insular cases. He declares the Supreme Court has joined hands with the President and Congress in an effort to change the American form of Government, and he calls on the people to repudiate the verdict.

"IF ALL the copies of the first Direc- tory of New York that are brought here were originals," said Librarian Wilberforce Eames of the Lenox Library the other day, "there could be provided a copy for every prominent collector in the country. But the limited stock of two or three genuine Directories of 1783 in this city has not been materially increased, nor do I think it likely to be.

LOVERS of plant life will find count- less subjects of deep interest at this season of the year, not only in Central Park, but in all the parks of Greater New York. There are many beautiful trees and plants, and the return of warm weather has made them alive.

As the result of a runaway accident on Jefferson Avenue, Brooklyn, yesterday, Oscar Jacobson, fourteen years old, of 1,161 Fulton Street, was killed, and William Robright, twenty-one years old, of 1,072 Fulton Street, was injured. The boy was killed by jumping from the wagon after he had pluckily prevented the horse running down people in the street.

BALTIMORE, June 1. -- The market today, though unable to keep pace with New York, was decidedly more active and considerably firmer. The centre of interest was the Seaboard group. From start to finish they were in good demand, and closed with a net gain of 5/8 for the common and 1/8 for the preferred.

Major Frank B. McKenna, Inspector General, United States Volunteers, Captain, Twenty-eighth Infantry, is detailed as a member of the examining board convened at Chicago, vice Lieut. Col. Abiel L. Smith, Deputy Commissary General, relieved.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- Dr. Rixey was at the White House at 10 o'clock to-night and remained for a short time with Mrs. McKinley. He said after leaving the sick room that the patient was, if anything, somewhat improved, and that she had had a comparatively restful day. The situation did not call for consultation with the other physicians, and no bulletin was issued.

THERE is probably no better chance to study the various traits of the different cat animals at the Central Park Zoo than during feeding time. Whatever be the demeanor of these bloodthirsty species while lounging lazily in their cages in the sight of a curious crowd, it is when the smell of blood and raw meat first strikes them that their true nature crops out.

The upward movement in prices which started in the outside market on Friday was continued yesterday, with further increase in activity in several prominent issues. The whole list was strong, and in a number of inactive issues quotations were better than any that have been made in some time.

A lamp made a pleasant glow on the table, and the small fire in the grate looked cheerful, but he regarded both as though doubting his right to either.

BRISTOL, R.I., June 1. -- In a two hours' spin late this afternoon the Constitution had a pretty good test in reaching and beating to windward, with Capt. Rhodes at the wheel and Capt. Nat Herreshoff beside him to scan the spars, sails, and rigging as they underwent a tuning up. One thing determined by the trial was that the shortening of the back stay ends was an advantage.

After two postponements on account of bad weather, the fourth annual games of Public School No. 89 were decided yesterday afternoon at Olympia Field, One Hundred and Thirty-fifth Street and Lenox Avenue, in the presence of a large and wildly enthusiastic crowd of relatives and admirers of the juvenile competitors.

It was not strange, therefore, mat when John decided to enter the ministry James did likewise, and they came to the city together.
NEWPORT, June 1. -- Mrs. Jane Yardley and the Misses Yardley have gone to Saunderstown for the Summer.

Twice within the last few months I have seen a capital where every woman was in black. One was London, where the people were mourning their dead Queen; the other was Helsingfors, where people mourned their lost liberty. Every woman in Helsingfors bore the black symbols of personal woe.

LONDON, June 1. -- The much ado that has been made all the week about the engagement by Mr. Charles Frohman of Irene Vanbrugh is quite unwarranted by the facts. Miss Van- brugh is to act here in association with Dion Boucicault under Mr. Froh- man's management in new plays, but not for the present, at the Duke of York's Theatre, where Edna May will remain until Christmas.

NEWARK, June 1. -- New York oarsmen won five of the seven races in the annual regatta of the Passaic River Amateur Rowing Association to-day, leaving but two for the local crews, and of these two events one was won by a New York Club which was subsequently disqualified for an alleged foul, not apparent from the boat which followed the races.

Mayor Van Wyck was the central figure in an exciting scene yesterday when he attached his signature to the resolution of the Municipal Assembly approving the plans of the Rapid Transit Commissioners for an eight-million-dollar tunnel under the East River to Brooklyn. For nearly three hours a war of words had been waged.

-- "As touching the crooks here,"said our Deputy Commissioner of Police to the visiting Chiefs last week, in one of the rare moments when they were not engaged in those congenial forms of amusement which constituted what they delicately described as sightseeing --" As touching the crooks here, they're all driven away."

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., June 2 -- Information of the sudden death of the Rev. Dr. John Martin Philip Otts of Greensborough, Ala., has been received here. Dr. Otts was a successful writer on Scriptural subjects, and was widely recognized as an authority on the Bible and the Holy Lands.
NEWPORT, R.I., June 2 -- The cup yacht Constitution, in charge of Capt. Rhodes, came down from Bristol this morning under working sails with a light breeze, and no attempt was made to speed the boat.

YONKERS, N.Y., June 2 -- Lawyer Benjamin Adams, a member of the local Board of Education, was arrested this afternoon upon the links of the Saegkill Golf Club upon a charge of violating the law, in that he played golf on Sunday.
The Eastern clubs of the National league open the Western series to-day away from home. New York playing with St. Louis and Brooklyn with Cincinnati.

If some of our readers who sincerely believe that the National legislators were right in usurping the natural prerogative of the War Department and causing the abolishment of the army canteen will consider the history of the Prohibition Party in this country they may gain considerable information on the subject of attempting to promote temperance by enforced "total abstinence."

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- In a series of extracts from the forthcoming Volume II. of commercial relations dealing with United States trade in France, Consul Brittain of Nantes notes the development of the trade in American machinery in Western France. During the past season, he says, about 800 reapers, mowers, and horse hay-rakes arrived at that port.

Special services were held at the Crypt of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, on Cathedral Heights, yesterday morning at 10 o'clock, for the ordination of six young men to deacon's orders, and also the elevation of three deacons to the order of priesthood.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The majority of us, numerically, intellectually, and morally, desire a change in the management of our civic affairs. We are of different religious, political, and social beliefs, and of different degrees of intelligence and wealth. We are divided into different groups, each representing some particular idea, each in itself obviously impotent.

The annual commencement exercises and distribution of prizes at the Hebrew Orphan Asylum. Amsterdam Avenue and One Hundred and Thirty-sixth Street, were held yesterday. The prizes were originally founded by the late Moses Bruhl, in memory of his wife, Bettie Bruhl, and gave to the best boy and best girl at the institution during the year handsomely engraved certificates and $50 in money.

CHARLESTON, S.C., June 2 -- A dispatch from Bennettsville, S.C., the home of Senator McLaurin, says there are good reasons for believing that just prior to the meeting of Congress, in December, Senator McLaurin will resign and request Gov. McSweeney to appoint his successor. Should the Senator do this, which is most likely, he would expect the Governor to appoint a strong man representing the political views of Messrs.

Along toward the middle of yesterday afternoon expectation in began to manifest itself among the inmates of the Blackwell's Island Almshouse. Shabby old men in the faded brown of the uniform suit moved slowly with cane and crutch toward the water front.

BOSTON, June 2 -- The baccalaureate sermon to the graduating class of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology was delivered by the Right Rev. William Lawrence, Episcopal Bishop of Massachusetts, in Trinity Church this afternoon. The members of the senior class, having met in the corridor of the Rogers Building prior to the services, marched as a body to the church.

The last obstacle in the way of the prompt settlement of the strike in the rapid transit tunnel was removed yesterday by the Central Federated Union. It gave its committee which has been trying to settle the strike full power to act, and as the rapid transit contractors have given their settlement committee a like power, nothing remains but for the two committees to meet to-day and complete the settlement.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 2 -- Bishop Parley of New York City to-day confirmed 200 children and 30 adults in St. Gabriel's Roman Catholic Church, the Iselin Memorial. Among those confirmed was Miss Louise, daughter of Adrian Iselin, Jr. The sponsors were Adrian Iselin, Jr., John G. Agar, Miss Georgiana Iselin, and Mrs. Julius Herold.

LONDON, June 2 -- Our Stock Exchange trouble is, I think, surmounted and suspension of buying in rule will not be extended beyond June 10. In settling with the bears our half dozen arbitrage houses have made considerable additions to their wealth, which they try to conceal by continuing to grumble.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The negro citizen feels grateful for the interest in his welfare and advancement shown by some of the speakers who addressed the Gettogether Club a few evenings ago, but before we applaud the utterance of Dr. Lyman Abbott, that "the South needs sympathy in the work it has undertaken for the negro," Dr. Abbott must point out what the South has undertaken for the negro.

The Teachers College has its own department, in which drawing, modeling, painting, and the making of objects more or less artistic, but directly useful, are carried on by pupils. It also has the Horace Mann School, which includes a kindergarten and classes of older scholars up to sixteen or seventeen years of age.

BALTIMORE, June 2 -- Services were held in Music Hall this afternoon in memory of the late Dr. M.D. Babcock, formerly pastor of the Brick Presbyterian Church. New York, and at one time of Brown Memorial Presbyterian Church in this city. Many persons turned away unable to gain admission to the big hall.

About fifty couples danced merrily at Waldron's dance hall, in Little Coney Island," at One Hundred and Tenth Street, yesterday afternoon, and they were not molested by the police. The doors were thrown open promptly at 3 o'clock, and soon the dance was in full swing.

It is his clear right to do so, so long as he remains within the lines established by the Constitution and by the traditions of the American people. The advantage he will get from in it is another matter, and is very doubtful.

Mr. WILLIAM J. BRYAN has made a deliverance in relation to the McLaurin-Tillman contest in South Carolina which is characteristic of his talent for so stating things that those with a capacity for thinking cannot possibly agree with him. Mr. BRYAN expects and hopes to see Senator TILLMAN win and to see Senator McLAURIN defeated because " TILLMAN represents the man, while McLAURiN represents the dollar."

Among the inmates of the Home for Aged Colored Men in Brooklyn there is just now great fear and trembling. It is all because of a prize contest in bread-making held in the Girls' High School. By unanimous vote, all the bread baked was sent to the Home for Aged Colored Men.

If the Administration is informed or is convinced that the Government to be established under the new Constitution of Cuba will interpret the Platt amendment, not according to its letter, but according to the jumble of words added to the law by the committee and adopted by the convention, it has acted wisely in declining to accept the action taken as a substantial compliance with the conditions imposed by Congress.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 2 -- The sun was struggling through the mist and clouds this morning when the cavalrymen were roused out of their blankets in the camp at Ossining to get ready to resume the march for the State camp. The men had everything cleaned up and the camp equipment stowed away before breakfast, and when this was disposed of the men were ready for the march.

The Mayor has justified the confidence we expressed the other day in the soundness of his judgment as to the East River tunnel. Had he been so disposed, we do not see how he could have resisted the arguments of the President and counsel of the Rapid Transit Commission, of which he is himself a member.

The residence at 68 West Thirty-fifth Street, where up to Thursday last was the abode of "Prof." Fred Ries, the burner of the magic powder, through which, from the vapor arising, he could discern the most encouraging visions of future fluctuations of the stock market and other secrets of the future for the benefit of his many customers, was again besieged yesterday with women who desired to learn his whereabouts from the landlord, Louis Racien.
"Eddyism and Christian Science" was the subject of the sermon preached last night in Calvary Baptist Church by the assistant pastor, the Rev. Dr. F.K. Morse.

LONDON, June 2 -- All indications point to a rational resumption of business on the London Stock Exchange in the near future. There is no reason why this should have been delayed as long as it has, except that London recovers slowly, and therefore the effect of the recent panic has been a week during which transactions have been decidedly dull.

CHICAGO, June 2 -- "I am Elijah, the prophet, who appeared first as Elijah himself, second as John the Baptist, and who now comes in me, the restorer of all things. Elijah was a prophet, John was a preacher, but I combine in myself the attributes of prophet, priest, and ruler over men. Gaze on me, then; I say it fearlessly.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 2 -- Walter Greer, aged nine years, in play to-day pointed a double-barreled shotgun at his seven-year-old brother Harold, at his home, near Pleasant Valley, and when he pulled the trigger the contents of a shell were emptied into the breast of the little fellow. He lived ten minutes.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue of May 28 you print a letter from "A.H.S.," in which he sums up Mr. Cleveland's character in this manner: " If Grover Cleveland had been approached in like manner, he would have either refused a conference outright or there would have been one."

James A. Herne, the actor and playwright, died at his home, 79 Convent Avenue, this city, at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon of pneumonia. He was taken ill a little over two months ago while in Chicago, where he was appearing in his production, "Sag Harbor."

John Redmond's confession yesterday of how the gold put story was "cooked up," together with the serious turn which the "joke" is taking for Melville E. Wygant, his partner in it, proved yesterday to be the most interesting developments in the case which has kept the residents of Port Richmond in a state of doubt and uncertainty for nearly a week past.

Much interest was expressed yesterday in the announcement that John D. Rockefeller had contributed $200,000 for the foundation of an institute devoted to medical research. It was learned that the gift will maintain what is practically equivalent to scholarships in colleges where medical research has been carried on.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Mrs. McKinley continues very weak. Her condition is not greatly changed from that of yesterday, but each day that elapses without a gain in strength lessons her powers of recuperation. The complaint which came near ending her life in San Francisco is still present. It is in a slightly less aggravated form, but gives the physicians and the President much concern.

The committee appointed by the National Civil Service Reform League to investigate the condition of the Federal civil service makes charges of violation of the civil service law against Moses Dillon, Collector of Customs at El Paso, Texas. These are set forth in a report to the Council of the league, which is also informed of the steps taken for the removal of the Collector.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 2 -- W.H. Klensmire, whose wife was yesterday found dead in a shallow trench near their home at Holton, Kan., was arrested in Kansas City, Kan., to-day. Marks on the body, which is believed to have been buried since May 19, indicated that her skull had been crushed with a club, and suspicion was directed against the husband, who disappeared on that date.

In the forty-second annual report of Cooper Union, just issued, the Trustees point out that the main revenue from this time forward must come from the Endowment Fund, which may be expected to yield about $60,000 per annum. As the expense cannot be reduced below $70,000 per annum, an additional endowment of $300,000 will be needed to bring the revenue and expenditures to an equation.

BERLIN, June 2 -- It is a significant fact that the announcement of the withdrawal of the allied troops from China, which the Boerse long had expected would give an impetus to business, was almost without influence upon trading last week. Its only effect was to increase transactions in Chinese loans at rising quotations.
SOUTHAMPTON, June 3. -- The Shamrock II. will be dry docked to-morrow, and she will start for the Clyde Tuesday, June 11, to have her new steel mast fitted.

WILTON, N.H., June 3. -- George F. Pyne of Temple, N.H., was arrested at the railway station this afternoon as he was taking a train, on accusation of Harvey M. Whiting, the milk contractor, that he had attempted blackmail. Pyne had a preliminary hearing, and was held for the Superior Court in $3,000 bail.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read with much interest and with hearty accord your editorial of the 30th of May on the subject of "The law's delay," especially as it applies to the action of the Judges of the courts in this city, with their overburdened calendar, in taking a three months' vacation, during which the wheels of justice are stayed.

BALTIMORE, June 3. -- The market was stronger generally to-day, though Seaboard issues were by all odds the most conspicuous. There was strong buying of the group from New York and the South. The curb movements in New York played a governing part in the advance recorded here.

The ex-President of the British Iron Trade Association is either the victim of curious delusions or the British Ministry are afflicted with a novel Americomania that leads them to betray the interests of their own nation for the purpose of aiding the successful competition of foreigners.
BOSTON, June 3. -- Money loaned at the Clearing House to-day at 2 and 2 1/2 per cent., and New York funds sold from 12 1/2 to 16 2-3 cents premium.

WASHINGTON, June 3. -- Hope of slow improvement in Mrs. McKinley's condition was held out by the attending physicians after an hour's consultation this morning, in which Dr. William Osler of Baltimore joined. Dr. Osler is Professor of Medicine and physician to the hospital of Johns Hopkins University, and has a National reputation as a diagnostician.

CHICAGO, June 3. -- There was a double sensation in the Premier Stakes at Hawthorne to-day. Garry Herrmann, the Greater Derby colt, pulled up absolutely last, bleeding badly and has probably seen his best days as a race horse. Herrmann bled slightly after a short workout last Friday, but it was attributed to a slight cold and little fear was felt that he would become a bleeder.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, June 3. -- The Leader to-morrow will say:

There are rumors of serious dissensions among the organization Republicans in the Twenty-fifth Assembly District of this county. The workers allege that they are ignored by the "silk stocking" element and that the latter control Leader Mc-Dougall Hawkes and Assemblyman John A. Weekes, Jr., who manage the affairs of the district.

The Superintendent of the Outdoor Poor, George Blair, gave a dinner to labor leaders at the Democratic Club last night. It was rumored that he acted on the advice of Richard Croker who had cabled to him. Mr. Blair, it was reported, had been selected by Mr. Croker to aid in opening the Mayoralty campaign because of his interest in and his former connection with the labor cause of the State.

The members of the Decorating Committee of the Irish Society of New York, who had charge of the work of decorating the graves and monuments of illustrious Irishmen in this city and vicinity on Decoration Day, have been thrown into considerable indignation by what is construed as a deliberate insult to the Irish flag.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., June 3. -- For over three hours and covering fifteen innings, Schenectady and Utica wrestled to-day in a pitcher's battle. Both Villeman and Magee pitched strong games, and their support was good. The game was won by Betts's long three-base hit after two were out in the fifteenth inning, scoring Scheffler from first base.

DENVER, June 3. -- John D. Long, Secretary of the Navy, passed through Denver en route to Washington, after a visit of about two weeks with his family, now stopping at Colorado Springs. While here he gave out for the first time a statement of his views on the Supreme Court decision in the Porto Rican cases.

WASHINGTON, June 3. -- The Navy Department has received a complete set of plans for the rebuilding of the Reina Mercedes, one of the Spanish ships captured at Santiago, but it has not yet been decided whether the proposed changes will be made.

NEWPORT, June 3. -- In a strong southwesterly breeze and a rough sea. Constitution had her first trial spin outside this morning. While it was more to test ner sails, spars, and rigging in a good sea breeze, than to try her speed, nothing could have been more satisfactory than the yacht's behavior.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Director McMahon of the Cathedral Library, in his letter published in your issue of May 26, has ignored the main point at issue between us, viz.: State support of sectarian schools and libraries, and has denied my right to speak on this subject for others than myself.

In spite of an evident desire on the part of many influential members of the Brooklyn Presbytery to drop the matter, the Presbytery decided at its meeting yesterday afternoon to try the Rev. Dr. Alfred I. Moment, pastor of Immanuel Church, upon new charges. The meeting was an open one -- the first open meeting in which the subject of Dr. Moment's relations with the Presbytery has ever been discussed.

Another lawsuit growing out of the recent panic in Wall Street was commenced in the Supreme Court yesterday. In this action Christian B. Hollander of 1,123 Dawson Street, in the Bronx, seeks to recover $20,800 from John F. Douglass and Willard H. Jones, who formed the brokerage firm of Douglass Jones, 24 Broad Street.

Judge Rufus B. Cowing, in General Sessions, yesterday swore in the June Grand Jury, which will be asked by the District Attorney to make an investigation of the disbursements for supplies of the various city departments. The Judge, in charging the Grand Jurors as to their duties, laid particular stress upon the inquisitorial body's power to make investigations of city officials who might be found derelict in their official duties.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 3. -- Some interest was aroused here to-day among the members of the Constitutional Convention by the receipt of a paper published in Mobile by two prominent negro ministers. The publication contains a long article criticising the tone, temper, and sentiments of the appeal of Booker T. Washington, W. H. Council, and other leading negroes to the Constitutional Convention in behalf of their race.

TORONTO, Ontario, June 3. -- The annual convention of the International Machinists opened here to-day. The session promises to be important, as many questions of vital interest to the trade will be discussed, and settled if possible. About 200 delegates were present when President O'Connell called the meeting to order.

CLARKSBURG, West Va., June 3. -- Judge Nathan Goff of the United States Court for the Eastern District of Virginia to-day appointed Allan I. McDermott receiver for the Washington Traction and Electric Company. Application for the receivership was filed by the United States Mortgage and Trust Company of New York.

PORT JERVIS, N.Y., June 3. -- The special charter under which the Blooming Grove Park Association has existed in Pike County for a number of years, was declared in a measure unconstitutional by Judge Purdey at the opening of the regular June term of Pike County Court at Milford, Penn., this afternoon.
NEWPORT, June 3. -- Mrs. I. P. White sails for Europe this week.

The four-in-hand coach Reliance, with Richard F. Carman, the wealthy clubman and horse breeder, of Huntington, L.I., driving, accompanied by Louis Haight, a stock broker, of 58 West Fifty-eighth Street, and James T. Hyde, Secretary of the National Horse Show Association, and two grooms, was passing the rapid transit tunnel excavation at Eighty-first Street and Broadway at 10:30 o'clock last night.

William H. Hunt, Secretary of the Insular Government of Porto Rtco, arrived yesterday from San Juan on the steamship Ponce. One of his fellow-passengers was Dr. Jose Barbosa, a member of the Executive Council of the island and a leading physician of its capital. Mr. Hunt is staying at the Everett House, and Dr. Barbosa is being entertained at 221 West Fourteenth Street.

PHILADELPHIA, June 3. -- Drexel Co., who were managers of the syndicate which recently underwrote the plan by which the capital of the Pennsylvania Steel Company was readjusted by being increased to $50,000,000, announced to-day that they had sold to investors the stock of the company, both common and preferred, in their hands for the underwriting syndicate.

William H. Newman, President of the Lake Shore Railroad, was yesterday elected to the Presidency and a Directorship of the New York Central Railroad, to succeed S. R. Callaway, who resigned a few weeks ago. The election of Mr. Newman had been generally expected and occasioned no surprise.

The first afternoon of really good and pleasant weather that the Brooklyn Jockey Club's Spring meeting has enjoyed, though coming on an off day of racing, drew an exeptionally large crowd yesterday, though the weather was not the only attraction, the programme being one of uncommon promise.

Justice Gaynor, in the Supreme Court, Broooklyn, yesterday, granted an order requiring the Mayor to show cause why a writ of mandamus should not issue compelling him to appoint four Police Magistrates in Brooklyn in the places of Lewis R. Worth, William Kramer, Andrew Lemon, and Charles E. Teale, whose terms of office are declared to have expired on May 1 last.

BOSTON, June 3. -- Ex-Judge Septimus J. Hanna, the first reader of the First Church of Christ, Scientist, here, was a witness in the trial of the suit of Mrs. Josephine Woodbury against "Mother" Eddy today. Mrs. Woodbury, it will be remembered, seeks $130,000 damages for an alleged libel uttered by Mrs. Eddy soon after she was excommunicated for daring to differ with the founder of Christian Science.

NEWARK, N.J., June 3. -- About fifty men were put to work in the Crocker-Wheeler Company's works, at Ampere, this morning, and all day the plant was patroled by forty-seven armed private detectives, who kept the striking machinists from interfering with the men. The company has provided cooks, waiters, and a kitchen, and cots for the workers, and says it will board them for a year if the strike lasts that long.
