George Trimble Davidson, a lawyer, of 25 Pine Street, was again arrested yesterday, charged by Prank W. Savin. Jr., With misappropriating $14,575, left to Savin in trust by his mother, the late Mrs. Orriba Savin, wife of the banker of that name. Detective Farrington of the Centre Street Court squad took the lawyer into custody at his office and arraigned him later before Magistrate Flammer.

To anybody who regards the question of the army canteen as one to be dealt with according to the teachings of experience and from the point of view of practical expediency, the action of the army Surgeons at their convention last week in St. Paul will be entirely conclusive.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., June 3. -- The New York basebal Iteam had little trouble in disposing of the St. Louis team to-day by a score of 8 to 4. Van Haltren and Al Selbach were the star performers for the visitors, though the entire aggregation put up a wonderfully fine game, and only for the improved form of the St. Louis team it would have been beaten worse than it was.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 3. -- In the presence of many distinguished army and navy officers the session of 1901 opened at the Naval War College this morning. Frank W. Hackett, Assistant, Secretary of the Navy, delivered the opening address.

Particulars concerning dividends declared by the Rubber Goods Manufacturing Company the New York Central and Hudson River Railroad Company, and the International Elevating Company will be found in the advertisement columns.

STATE CAMP, Peekskill, N.Y., June 3. -- The first work day in camp was ideal. The men were well rested after their long ride from Manhattan and Brooklyn, and the day was just warm enough to make it comfortable to caper about on the horses.

CHICAGO, June 3. -- Edward Forshay of Kansas City, an actor and manager of theatrical companies, to-night shot and killed Miss Edna Stokes, an actress, whose home is at Sedalia, Mo., and with whom he professed to be in love. Forshay says he met Miss Stokes in St. Louis six years ago. They played in different cities until last Fall, when they became members of the stock company playing at the Victoria Theatre here.

The fifth week of the trial of. Dr. S.J. Kennedy opened yesterday before Judge Newburger, with experts for the defense on the stand endeavoring to offset the testimony of the State's experts, who swore last week that Dr. Samuel J. Kennedy wrote the indorsement on the $13,000 check found on Dolly Reynolds's dead body.

The men who have been at the head of the New York Produce Exchange for the last two years were defeated at the annual election yesterday after a heated and close contest, in which the management of the gratuity fund and the canal question were the chief subjects of difference.

BALTIMORE, Md., June 3. -- Harry Lehr and his bride surprised their many Baltimore friends by arriving in this city early this evening. They registered at the Stafford Hotel. Half an hour after their arrival Mr. Lehr hired a roundabout, and he and his bride drove to the Elkridge Kennels, where dinner for two was served in the private dining room of the club.

Representatives of the Merchants' Association and agents of large mercantile houses appeared before the Dock Board yesterday to ask it not to force the Stonington Line to leave its dock on the North River on four days notice. They protested and showed the great damage which would be done to the commerce of the city if the Sound line steamers were forced to dock on the East River.

WASHINGTON, June 3. -- The figures of H. Clay Evans, Commissioner of Pensions, showing the work of the Pension Bureau for the eleven months of the fiscal year ending June 30, present two interesting facts, and indicate the probability that the next Congress will be called upon to meet a deficiency in expenditures on account of pensions.

BALTIMORE, June 3. -- The United States Grand Jury in its report to-day dealt vigorously with the Federal census frauds and plainly intimated that politicians were back of the enumerators now on trial on charges of falsifying the returns. The Grand Jury says:

Herbert A. Sherman has sold for Charles T. Barney to John Henry Hammond, for $I50,000, the plot at the southeast corner of Fifth Avenue and One Hundred and Fourth Street. 100 by 150. About two years ago Mr. Hammond, together with his brother-in-law J. Abercrombie Burden, bought George F. Johnson's twelve lots at the northeast corner of Fifth Avenue and One Hundred and Second Street.
Not Brooklyn alone, but the entire great city, will be benefited by the construction of the tunnel under the East River, which the signature of the Mayor has now authorized.

WASHINGTON, June 3. -- Talk of an extra session of Congress continues active, and all kinds of predictions are made, but the question will remain in abeyance until Secretary Root and Attorney General Knox have rendered their opinions upon the effect of the insular decisions. They have not read them all yet.

Mrs. Tillie B. Brown, widow of Martin B. Brown, founder of the printing house that bears his name, and of which she had been manager since his death on Dec. 23, 1893, died at her home, 931 Madison Avenue, at 1 o'clock yesterday morning of apoplexy Mrs. Brown was also the successor of Mrs. Eugene Kelly as President of the Ladies' Auxiliary of St. Vincent's Hospital.

The engineers of the Rapid Transit Commission will begin at once a series of borings in the bed of the East River, and this will mark the beginning of work on the tunnel to Brooklyn. It was said yesterday that several months would be spent in surveys and the preparation of working plans before the contracts could be let.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your Wednesday issue appeared an article by F.N. Frost about the "Canteen and Drunkenness," from which the following is quoted: "THE TIMES seems to ignore entirely the one fundamental principle on which the Woman's Christian Temperance Union acts, and that is that the sale of liquor is a crime against God and man," c.

For the first time in several weeks there was some spirited brushing on the Harlem River Speedway yesterday afternoon. The roadbed, which has been a sea of mud for days, was thoroughly dried out and in prime condition for fast stepping, and this, coupled with the fine weather, attracted an unusual number of road drivers, who gave their favorites plenty of fast work, which they were sorely in need of.

There have been few more notable weddings in New York society this season than that which took place yesterday afternoon at Grace Church. It was that of Miss Anne Urquhart Potter and James Alexander Stillman. Miss Potter is the daughter of James Brown Potter, and Mr. Stillman is the son of James Stillman, the banker.

BOSTON, June 3. -- Another intended cup Defender, the pride and hope of Yankee land, the yacht Independence, was given an airing, nothing more than a jogging, to stretch her sails and rigging, in Massachusetts Bay to-day, and from what little actual sailing was done, the Crowninshield yacht certainly showed herself to be very speedy, particularly with started sheets.

On June 10 the first class of the West Point Military Academy will witness the performance of "Florodora" at the Casino. The party will number 100 in all, and for the occasion the management will decorate the auditorium with appropriate colors.

We have been for some time made familiar with the consciousness of the British that their Government made a mistake in assenting to the appointment of Count VON WALDERSEE as Commander in Chief of the allied forces in China without taking any precautions about the nature and extent of his authority.

Transactions in the outside market yesterday showed a larger total than had been recorded since the recent period of dullness began. The upward movement of prices which started the latter part of last week continued, and increased strength brought increased activity. The strength of the Stock Exchange market furnished the foundation for higher prices on the curb, and in few cases were there special causes to account for the gains made.

-- Hearty praise is given to the Metropolitan Railway Company by The Electrical World and Engineer for the remarkable speed with which the change from funicular to electrical traction was effected on Broadway. It calls the substitution "one of the most surprising things this city has seen," but that is going a little far.

Direct responsibility for the condition of child labor existing in Southern mills was charged last right by an Englishwoman who has been investigating the subject for Samuel Gompers to capitalists and mill owners in New York and other Northern cities. These capitalists, it was declared, had virtually said to the South: "We will not develop your resources, bringing our capital, unless you let us use your children."

Clarence Kennedy, the four-year-old son of Dr. Samuel J. Kennedy, now undergoing a third trial in General Sessions charged with the murder of Emeline C. Reynolds, was removed from the vicinity of Judge Newburger's court room entrance, by direction or Assistant District Attorney O'Connor, just before adjournment, yesterday.

In the swing of the pendulum that determines averages, six favorites were beaten at the Gravesend race track yesterday and a mournful crowd of racegoers on the homeward journey cogitated on the things that might have been had form been lived up to. All the reasoning that the betting element could bring to bear failed to explain how a number of the results came to be made.

Three prominent railway stocks at the present time paying 6 per cent. dividends, stocks representing properties whose traffic conditions are largely influenced by the country's agricultural output -- and Wall Street is just now devoting especial attention to crop reports -- are Chicago and Northwestern, St. Paul, and Illinois Central.

Strength still showed in the outside market yesterday, but the volume of business was much smaller than it was on Monday. Some few stocks remained active, but most of the list was relatively quiet. In some quarters of the market there was considerable, irregularity within a narrow range, but for the most part the net changes of the day were on the side of gains.

PHILADELPHIA, June 4 -- The market displayed great activity to-day, most of the trading being in Cambria Steel and the Readings, both of which were strong on heavy purchases. Cambria was up a full point before the announcement was made of a dividend of $1.50 a share. There was then some selling on the theory that the news had been discounted, but the offerings were absorbed quickly.
LONDON, June 5 -- The War Office last night published the following dispatch from Lord Kitchener, dated Pretoria June 4:

A man who, from papers and letters found in his pockets, is known to have been Robert Gibbens Bidwell of 1,425 East Adams Street, Jacksonville, Fla., jumped from the Brooklyn Bridge yesterday afternoon and at 6:15 o'clock P.M. his body was taken from the East River at the foot of Oliver Street.

NEWARK, N.J., June 4 -- The appointment of John R. Hardin as receiver of the United States Carbonate Company came before Vice Chancellor Stevens this afternoon for confirmation. John A. Quayle, who until three weeks ago was President of the corporation, through his counsel, Chauncey G. Parker and Police Judge George H. Lambert, took exception.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, June 4 -- The hundred-mile race from Cleveland to Erie to-day between the Cleveland passenger steamer City of Erie, Capt. Hugh McAlpine, owned by the Cleveland and Buffalo Transit Company and the Tashmoo. Detroit's crack passenger boat, Capt. B.S. Baker, owned by the White Star Company, was in many respects the most noteworthy contest ever sailed on fresh water.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 4 -- Off Brenton's Reef Lightship this afternoon a serious accident happened to the cup defender yacht Constitution. The boat was bounding along in a whole-sail breeze, with its three lower sails set, when, without warning, the starboard tower spreader, over the end of which ran two of the masthead shrouds, made of inch steel wire rope, collapsed or broke off at the mast.

After the rush of Monday, yesterday was very quiet. Many who were in town went back to the country. There were no formal arrangements for sports except for golf at Morristown. To-day there will be polo at Meadow Brook. There were several weddings, but none of them was as conspicuous for large gatherings of fashionable people as were the weddings of Monday.

The last plank connecting the foot bridge of the new East River Bridge, between Williamsburg and Manhattan, was laid at 11 o'clock yesterday morning, and the workmen from both sides of the river shook hands. A demonstration was made by the river craft, and everybody who happened to be passing at the time joined in.
GENEVA, N.Y., June 4 -- Toronto University defeated Hobart College at lacrosse to-day by a score of 5 to 2.
PRISTOL, R.I., June 4 -- The steam yacht Eugenia, owned by John Herreshoff, arrived to-night. Mr. Herreshoff said he did not know what the particular cause of the accident was.

Mental depression, due to heavy losses in speculation on the Produce Exchange, was said last night to explain the cause of the suicide of Joseph Abramson, a Produce Exchange broker, whose body was found yesterday morning lying across the grave of his mother-in-law, Mrs. Adolph Strauss, in Union Field Cemetery, on the outskirts of Williamsburg.

CAMP TOWNSEND, PEEKSKILL, June 4 -- Perfect weather and perfect drills mark the stay of the cavalrymen in the State camp this week. Both Major Oliver P. Bridgman and Major Gen. Roe commend the tactical work highly.

Every Irish flag removed from the Memorial Day decorations in St. Paul's Churchyard and other places is to be restored if members of the Irish Society of New York carry out their intention. Police Commissioner Murphy was yesterday asked to prevent their being interfered with again.

ST. LOUIS, June 4 -- Particular attention is called by Judge Horatio D. Wood in his instructions to the June Grand Jury to the reckless killing and maiming of human beings by careless and incompetent street railway employes. Judge Wood says:

Vice Chancellor PITXEY, in the case of the striking employes of the Paterson silk mills, charged with contempt of court in disobeying an injunction forbidding them to interfere with or intimidate other employes who want to work, declares that every person has the right to work or not to work as he or she sees fit, but no one has the right to keep another person from working.
PARIS, June 5 -- The Marquis de Lur-Saluces, the well-known Royalist and ex-member of the Chamber of Deputies, who unexpectedly returned to Paris about the middle of last month, has been arrested.

PITTSBURG, Penn., June 4 -- The annual meeting of stockholders of the Pennsylvania Company was held in this city today. The annual report for the year ended Dec. 31. 1900, was submitted, showing the following results on all lines directly operated by the Pennsylvania Company:

LONDON, June 5 -- The Times publishes a stirring poem by Rudyard Kipling, entitled "Bridge Guard in the Karroo." It describes the dreary monotony of troops guarding lines of communication. Picturing the arrival of a train, the poet says:

FAR ROCKAWAY, L.I., June 4 -- The wedding of Henri Crassons de Medeuil and Miss Leonore de B. Himely, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Alexander Himely and granddaughter of the late William H. Neilson, was celebrated at the residence of the bride's parents at noon to-day by the Rev. Father Wucher, pastor of St. Vincent de Paul's, New York City.

The Central Realty, Bond and Trust Company has sold, through Du Bois Smith, for about $100,000, the lot at the southwest corner of Madison Avenue and Fifty-third Street, 28 by 100, part of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church property. The buyer is Gilbert C. Brown, who will erect a modern fireproof dwelling on the lot, probably six stories in height.

WASHINGTON, D.C., June 4 -- The marriage of Miss Martha Hichborn, only daughter of Rear Admiral and Mrs. Hichborn, to James G. Blaine, Jr., took place at noon to-day at the home of the bride's parents. Owing to the wishes of both families the ceremony was simple, and only the immediate relatives of bride and bridegroom were present.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The Weather Bureau's weekly summary of crop conditions is as follows:

LONDON, June 4 -- "Mark my words," said Mr. Andrew Carnegie to-night, "the time is coming when the Continental powers will combine to smash up this little island of Great Britain. When that happens, she will have to turn to the United States for help. I feel certain it will not be refused.

THE NEW YORK TIMES improves the occasion of the adjournment of the United States Supreme Court until the second Monday in October without passing upon the status of the Filipino case by making some severe strictures upon the Judges, and United States Judges in general, for taking such long vacations and so many holdays at the expense of tedious delays to business and justice as well as of congested court calendars.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., June 4 -- Rain stopped the St. Louis-New York baseball game to-day in the seventh inning, when the score stood 4 to 2 in favor of the visitors. It was very hard for the St. Louisans that the rain came just when it did, for the New Yorks had been retired in their half and the local team had a man on third, and Jesse Burkett at the bat.

James Watson Gerard, son of the late James W. Gerard, and Miss Mary Augusta Daly, daughter of the late Marcus Daly, were quietly married at noon yesterday at the residence of the bride's mother, 725 Fifth Avenue, by Bishop Henry C. Potter of the Protestant Episcopal Church. The bride wore a gown of white mousseline de soie and lace over silk, and a point lace veil.

Outgoing steamers bound for England to-day, both from this port and Boston, will carry among their passengers many wellknown actors and actresses. On the American liner St. Louis Nat Goodwin and his wife, Maxine Elliott, will take their departure. They will go direct to their home at Jackwood Shooter's Hill, Kent, outside of London, where they will remain throughout the entire Summer, except for an occasional visit to Paris and nearby seaside resorts.

SAN JUAN, Porto Rico, June 4 -- Luis Moret Munoz, a relative of the ex-President of the Federal Party, Luis Munoz Rivera, was arrested here to-day by the police on the arrival of the United States transport McClellan from New York. He is now under detention at the residence of Chief of Police Bernos.

PHILADELPHIA, June 4 -- With the erection, shortly to begin, of a building to be devoted exclusively to the purposes of a medical library, the University of Pennsylvania will enter upon the construction of a group of buildings which shall be used only by the medical classes of the institution.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- President McKinley decided to-day not to call an extra session of Congress. This decision was based on Secretary Root's opinion that the President has power enough to go ahead with his plans for the Philippines.

ST. PAUL, June 4 -- President Charles A. L. Reed of Cincinnati to-day called to order the general meeting of the American Medical Association in the Metropolitan Opera House. Bishop Whipple of the Protestant Episcopal Church delivered the opening prayer. After a speech of welcome by Mayor Smith, preliminary reports of the Executive Committee and the Committee on Arrangements were read.

The war between William E. Melody, a Democrat, and Jacob Brenner, a Republican, for the possession of the office of Commissioner of Jurors in Kings County goes merrily on. The latest move was made yesterday by Mr. Brenner, who tried to cause the arrest of Mr. Melody. A Republican Justice signed the order of arrest and a Democratic Justice promptly stopped the order.

BOSTON, June 4 -- With the one hundred or more witnesses who have been summoned in connection with the trial of the $130,000 libel suit of Mrs. Josephine C. Woodbury against Mrs. Mary Baker G. Eddy, founder of Christian Science, in their places in the Superior Court room, the space left for spectators is meagre, and this morning, as on previous days, it was far too small for the crowd that wanted to get in.

Suit has been brought in the United States Circuit Court for the Southern District of New York, by George D. Mumford and St. George Lane Fox Pitt against the Ecuador Development Company and the Ecuador Equipment Association, formerly the Ecuadorian Association (Limited) of Scotland.

To the Editor of The New York Times: You publish daily letters from correspondents who get warm under the collar, and occasionally your own temperature in that region rises sufficiently to provoke an editorial, about "beautifying the city." It is a big subject, and a fruitful one, but as the said beautifying is being done, who shall protect us against our own vandals?

ST. PAUL, Minn., June 4 -- Delos W. Cooke, the newly appointed General Passenger Agent of the Erie, has been with the road since 1881, and is well known among railroad men. He is about forty years old. His appointment was brought about by an offer he received from the Central Railroad of New Jersey.

The grava of a King or chieftain who vas buried at Seddin in Russian West Priegnits, 3,000 years ago, has been carefully excavated and many bronze objects added to the provincial museum in consequence. There are beaten and cast bowls, iron pins, rings and knives Of bronze, neckaces with enameled beads, and bronze tubes, and other objects belonging to the Bronze Age.

BALTIMORE, June 4 -- The twenty-mile motor-paced cycle race at the Coloseum to-night between Edouard Taylore, the French champion, and Burns Please, the Canadian, resulted in a victory for Taylore by 3 1/2 laps. Time -- 36:16 4-5.

The strike on the rapid transit tunnel was formally declared off last evening by the walking delegates who ordered the strike. They are P. McMahon and James Stewart of the Amalgamated and Eccentric Engineers, Matthew McConville of the Safety Association of Engineers, James R. Green of the Rock Drillers' and Tool Sharpeners' Union, and the delegate of the double drum holsters.

BALTIMORE, June 4 -- The market today continued its forward movement in prices. Though there was no very great activity in trading, the market was far from dull. The demand was strong enough to carry the general list upward, the sentiment being quite bullish at the close. Seaboard again figured prominently in the more active contingent, securing net gains both for the common and preferred.

The Kings County lawn tennis tournament was continued yesterday afternoon on the club courts at Kingston Avenue and Bergen Street, Brooklyn. The men's doubles were started, but the first matches in women's singles and mixed doubles were held over until this afternoon on account of the long final at Washington between Miss Moore and Miss Jones.

Sir ROBERT HART is undoubtedly entitled to speak with more authority on Chinese politics than any other foreigner. With the possible exception of some missionaries, he is about the oldest foreign resident in the country, and his official position has given him a better opportunity than any missionary could have for knowing the ways of thinking and of feeling of the Chinese official classes.

Three-year-old William Newsham, whose parents, Mr. and Mrs. Henry Newsham, reside at 48 West Hamilton Place, Jersey City, fell twenty feet yesterday and escaped unhurt. Mrs. Newsham went to the roof of the house yesterday with some potted plants. The boy followed her. She was not awaare of the fact until she turned to descend, when she saw her son leaning over the edge of the roof.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., June 4 -- R.G. Bidwell, who jumped from the Brooklyn Bridge to-day, was the son of the late A.I. Bidwell, who, in his day, was a leading nurseryman of this State, and lived at Arlington, across the St. John's River from this city. Fifteen years ago he moved to Orlando, where he had a beautiful orange and fruit farm, and where in a few years he died.

ANNAPOLIS, June 4 -- The final standing of the graduating class of Naval Cadets has been determined. This embraces the marks in every subject for a four years course. The highest mark obtainable is 760.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As an ex-army officer during the civil war, I have been very much interested in the discussion that has been going on in your valuable paper on the army canteen question.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, June 4 -- Brooklyn won to-day's baseball game easily because of McFadden's poor work on the rubber. He gave eleven bases on balls, and was hit safely as many times. Sharp fielding kept the score down. Donovan was effective from start to finish.
CHICAGO, June 4 -- New York Exchange ruled at par to-day. For call and time loans the rates were 4 1/2@5 per cent.

The trial of the action for separation brought by Mrs. Annie Eugenie Taylor against Alexander Kirkland Taylor was commenced yesterday in the Supreme Court before Justice Clarke. Mr. Taylor is at brother of Talbot J. Taylor of the brokerage firm of Talbot J. Taylor Co. He is a member of the Union and Democratic Clubs.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Dr. Rixey was at the White House for an hour and a half this evening and on leaving at half past 10 o'clock said in answer to inquiries concerning Mrs. McKinley's condition:

CHICAGO, June 4 -- Liquidation was the feature to-day in wheat. July, after covering a range of 4 3/8 cents, closed weak and 1 1/8 cents lower. There was an exciting session, with an extremely large volume of business in the wheat pit. The remarkable strength which characterized the market yesterday was not maintained, for a pyrotechnical advance was followed by a decline which was quite as sensational.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., June 4 -- The Court of Appeals at Buffalo to-day handed down a decision in the case of Lillian Traver Carr of Poughkeepsie against the National Bank and Loan Company of this city. Mrs. Carr is the widow of the Rev. Charles M. Carr, who was killed by the accidental discharge of a gun while hunting in the Adirondacks, leaving about $13,000 insurance.

GRINNELL, Iowa, June 4 -- George D. Herron, former Professor of Applied Christianity in Iowa College, is no longer a Congregationalist. He was tried by a council of ministers and Elders of the church, representing eight organizations, sitting here to-day, on the charge of "conduct unbecoming a Christian and a gentleman."

Union Hill will not be a very profitable field for burglars just now, for the town has two police forces, though from yesterday's indications it may be that the warring officers will be too busy watching each other to pay any attention to lawbreakers. The situation came about through two ordinances adopted by the Town Council on Monday night.

LONDON, June 4 -- The American horses and jockeys started the first day of the Epsom Downs meeting in excellent form. Horses ridden by American jockeys won six firsts out of seven, and were placed eleven times out of twenty-one. Milton Henry made his first appearance to-day in England, in the race for the Wallington Plate, on Farceur, but did not get a place.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 4 -- The British steamship Ranald, from Trinidad, for New York, whose cargo of asphalt melted and caused the ship to list so badly that she anchored off here yesterday, sank early this morning off shore about a milo from Young's Pier. The ship lies in an easy position in six rathoms of water.

Bishop E.W. PARKER of the Methodist Episcopal Church in India, died at Naini Tal, where he had gone for his health, according to a cablegram received in this city yesterday. Bishop Parker had been suffering for a long time from an acute form of stomach trouble. His regular station was at Lucknow.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., June 5 -- Miss Helen Dillingham of Summit Hill, N.J., won the consolation singles in the women's Pennsylvania State championship tennis tourney here to-day, defeating Miss Dorothea H. Morris of the Merion Cricket Club in straight sets. Owing to a blunder of the scorer in the Larned-Harlan match of yesterday the latter was returned as winner, while Miss Lamed should have been announced as the victor.

PHILADELPHIA, June 5 -- The stock market was somewhat broader than for several days, and there was considerable trading, especially in the steel shares. Cambria dominated, though its volume of trading was somewhat reduced. It is generally assumed on the Street that Cambria now controls the Pennsylvania Steel Company, and that it is negotiating against the VickersMaxim people for the controlling interest of Bethlehem Steel.

George J. Gould made the deciding goal yesterday which gave his Lake-wood team possession of the Meadow Brook cups in what was the most sensational polo game of the present season. The match was the final game in the Meadow Brook Club tournament, and Lakewood met the same Rock-away contingent that beat the Lakewood Freebooters for the Hempstead cups last Monday.

LONDON, June 5 -- John Morley, one of the persons consulted by Mr. Carnegie regarding his gift of L2,000,000 to the universities of Scotland, told his constituents at Brechin to-night that it had been prematurely stated that the annual income of the fund, which is L104,000, would be devoted to the abolition of all fees at the Scottish universities.
NEWPORT, June 5 -- Dr. and Mrs. David Bell Birney of Philadelphia have arrived at Jamestown for the season.

CHICAGO, June 5 -- Continued heavy rains caused a weak wheat market to-day, and July closed 1 3/4c under yesterday. A soaking rainfall in the Spring wheat country, where it was most needed, was the dominant influence throughout the session. At no time did the support have the appearance of strength.

A further falling off in transactions occurred in the outside market yesterday, and at the same time prices were more reactionary than they have been at any time within the last tour or five days. Only a few stocks showed even relatively large totals, and the number of issues traded in was also smaller than had been the case on the first two days of the week.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., June 5 -- The Western Insurance Union, consisting of Presidents and General Managers of fire insurance companies known as the "Trust," met at the Cataract House here to-day. There are about 100 members of the union present. J.M. De Camp of Cincinnati, President, was the presiding officer.

Mrs. Marion S. Kennedy, wife of the Staten Island Dentist on trial before Judge Newburger in General Sessions charged with killing Emeline C. Reynolds, was not permitted, contrary to her usual custom, to see her husband in the prison pen at the noon recess yesterday.

BOSTON, June 5 -- At the Clearing House to-day money between the banks loaned at 2 1/2 and 2 per cent. There was little borrowing demand, while the supply was large. New York funds sold at from 15 cents premium to par for cash. Exchanges, $30,002,209; balances, $2,156,958.

PASSAIC, N.J., June 5 -- There was another outbreak on the part of the girl strikers at the Aheson handkerchief factory this morning. The girls who reported for work at the factory were attacked. Volleys of stones were fired at the buildings, and a number of the windows smashed. The two policemen on duty charged on the strikers, but were met with a shower of stones.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Assistant Secretary of the Treasury Taylor to-day sent a letter to ex-Representative Glynn of Albany in response to a recent communication from that gentleman, as a member of the Commission of Nine to direct the Government interests in the St. Louis Exposition to be held in 1903.

At a meeting of the School Board of the Boroughs of Manhattan and the Bronx last evening, it was decided that Martin H. Ray, who for thirty-five years has served as a Principal in New York public schools, would remain in his position, but that he would have to face charges to be made by the Board of Borough Superintendents.

The Rev. Father Ducey is convinced that Richard E. Murphy, the young Munchausen from Jefferson City, Mo., now in his charge, is demented. He will return him to his parents this week, but before sending him on his journey will have him examined by prominent alienists. He sent a dispatch, of which the following is a copy, to the boy's father, John E. Murphy:

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Representative Boutell of Illinois is very confident of the speedy expansion of the territorial greatness of the United States, predicting not only the acquisition of Cuba and the rest of the West Indies, but the whole territory down to the Nicaragua Canal and Canada on the north.

Wisconsin Central Railway securities were among the most conspicuous features in yesterday's Stock Exchange transactions. The bonds and shares alike advanced substantially, and in explanation of the quick suggestive appreciation Wall Street heard a variety of reports. One series of representations had it that the property is about to be absorbed by Northern Pacific, fulfilling the original Villard plan.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 5 -- Constitution was towed to Bristol early this morning by her tender, Mount Morris. Capt. Duncan returned here this afternoon on Rear Commodore Robinson's sloop Hester. When seen by the representative of THE NEW YORK TIMES he said: "Constitution has been thoroughly inspected to-day, and not a scratch was found on board as a result of the accident, except the damage to her mast.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 5 -- Much doubt exists here as to whether Thomas W. Lawson's yacht Independence will compete in the special races offered to the three big single stickers by the Newport Yacht Racing Association.

FLUSHING, L.I., June 5 -- Carl Gondeck, three years old, son of Albert Gondeck, a butcher at 51 Boerum Avenue, Murray Hill, died at his home in great agony today from the effects of a camphor ball which he had swallowed, evidently thinking it was candy.
CHICAGO, June 5 -- New York exchange was held at par to-day. Rates for call and time loans were 4 1/2 to 5 per cent.

If Messrs. Gilbert and Sullivan were both still alive and writing comic operas together, they would have long ago sought out Col. Winfield Scott Proskey, the plucky soldier who for the past few months has held the dismantled Cumberland apartment house against all comers.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 5 -- The desire of the country towns of Connecticut to keep their representation and to withhold any advantage which might be given to the cities defeated the long-discussed question of constitutional reform in the House of Representatives to-day, by a vote of 145 to 61.

NEW ORLEANS, June 5 -- The Rev. Michael Jevizoylon Karidis is pastor of Holy Trinity Church, on the corner of Dorgenols and Hospital Streets, here. His congregation is composed of Greeks. He came here from Bulgaria twenty years ago, and is supposed to have had some means. About eight years ago he showed signs of mental unbalance, and since then has been engaged in constructing a flying machine.

ST. LOUIS, June 5 -- Once more the redoubtable Mathewson, phenomenal pitcher of the New York baseball team, has gone down to defeat before the hard-hitting St. Louis team. To-day's game was a pitchers' battle, and the end of it all was a score of 4 to 3 in favor of St. Louis. Six hits were secured off Mathewson's delivery, and the same number off Harper, who was in the box for the home team.

Another will of Councilman Herman Sulser has been found. It was filed for probate in the Surrogates' Office yesterday by the lawyer who discovered it among other papers in his safe. As in the will filed just after Mr. Sulzer's death on March 16 last, this newly found testament cuts off both his wife and son, but his daughter is more liberally remembered.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- If Georgia listens to the arguments of Congressman Livingston of that State, it will not adopt any amendments to its Constitution designed to disfranchise the negro voters on account of any disqualifications objected to by other Southern States that are so amending their Constitutions as to exclude the negro from the suffrage.

BRISTOL, R.I., June 5 -- In the harbor, a short distance off the Herreshoffs' shops, Constitution now lies a dismantled craft, doomed to remain at her moorings for the next two weeks. The buckled mainmast was lifted out by Capt. Perry's derrick steamer Archer this afternoon at 4 o'clock, and landed on the Herreshoff pier.

GETHSEMANE, Ky., June 5 -- This was an unusual day at the abbey of the Trappist Monastery of Gethsemane. The injunction of silence was removed, and the monks were not only permitted to talk to whom and When they pleased, but they were also permitted to gaze upon the features of woman, who by the laws of the Trappists are forbidden in the abbey.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Dr. Rixey made his usual nightly visit to the White House shortly after 9 o'clock, and remained about an hour and a half. On leaving, he said: "Mrs. McKinley is resting very comfortably now. She has gained a little this evening, but there is no marked change. She is doing very well."

Charles J. Patterson, generally regarded as one of the leaders of the bar in the Second Department, died at his home, 33 Monroe Place, Brooklyn, at an early hour yesterday morning. His death was caused by nervous prostration. Mr. Patterson had been ill for some time, and his death had been expected for a week.

Uncertainty still exists as to the ultimate disposition of little Joe Phillips, the fifteen-year-old boy who was practically declared a vagrans and committed to the Catholic Protectory by Magistrate Pool on Monday, despite the fact that he has been supporting himself and his two little sisters.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Mr. Bayles's article in last Sunday's TIMES on the condition of the cotton-mill hands in North Carolina did not present all the facts that are necessary to a fairly accurate summary of the situation. Without for a moment questioning the honesty of that writer, I can assure THE TIMES that his facts were too few and his generalizations too hasty.

SAG HARBOR, L.I., June 5 -- The body of Edgar Wade, Treasurer of the local savings bank, was found in his room this morning, with a bullet wound in the head, which Is supposed to have been self-inflicted.

BOSTON, June 5 -- An action has been brought in the Supreme Court by C.H. Venner Co. against Kidder, Peabody Co., to prevent the respondent from transferring the stock of the Boston and Montana Copper and Silver Mining Company, deposited with them, to the Amalgamated Copper Company.

The dispatch from London saying that Lord ROSEBERY had been asked to take the place of the late Lord HERSCHELL upon the Anglo-American Joint High Commission is another sign that a serious effort is to be made to resume the work of that body, suspended two years since. It confirms the intimation given by the Ministry of the Dominion of Canada recently.

The yearling thoroughbred horses from the Melbourne Stud Farm of Kentucky, the property of W.S. Barnes, were sold by auction in the paddock of the Gravesend race track before the races yesterday, by the Fasig-Tipton Company. The prices realized were good, straight through, and made a fair average for the offering.
The City Club, at a largely attended meeting last night, unanimously decided to take an active part in the approaching municipal campaign. Wheeler H. Peckha m presided.

A yacht designer in Glasgow, not Mr. WATSON, is quoted by cable as saying that the use of steel spars had been brought about by the urgent desire to save weight, but that this saving was more than counterbalanced by their untrustworthiness.
LONDON, June 6 -- The total number of deaths from disease and military operations among the British troops in South Africa during the month of May was 25 officers and 709 men.

CINCINNATI, June 5 -- Rusie gave evidence of having recovered his old form in the game against Brooklyn to-day. Though he had to pitch a wet ball in a drizzling rain he made a splendid showing, allowing the visitors but a single run. The nine hits were well scattered in all but one inning. Rusie, too, was well supported.

BOSTON, June 5 -- After long argument to-day Judge Charles V. Bell directed the jury in the suit of Mrs. Josephine C. Woodbury against Mary Baker G. Eddy for $150,000 for alleged libel to bring in a verdict for the defendant. In announcing his decision, Judge Bell said:

Luis Moret Munoz, said to be a relative of Luis Munoz Rivera, ex-President of the Porto Rico Federal Party, was yesterday indicted by the Grand Jury upon a charge of grand larceny in the first degree. Gen. Uribe-Uribe, the Porto Rican insurgent leader, now stopping in this city, is the complainant against Munoz, who was arrested in San Juan, Porto Rico, June 3, as he was about to land from the United States transport McClellan.

LONDON, June 6 -- The banquet tendered by the London Chamber of Commerce to the delegates of the New York Chamber at Grocers' Hall last night was one of the handsomest affairs of the kind ever given in a city famed for lavish hospitality. No effort was spared to honor the American guests.

BOSTON, June 5 -- President William de Witt Hyde made a strong address at the commencement exercises of Boston University, which were held in Tremont Temple this afternoon. "Academic Freedom" was his subject. He said, in part:

KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 5 -- William J. Bryan addressed the Jackson County Democratic Club to-night, taking for his subject "The Outlook." The auditorium, holding 1,500, was not large enough to meet the demands of the occasion. Mr. Bryan was especially severe in his arraignment of the Supreme Court because of its recent decision.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Secretary Gage of the Treasury to-day mailed a letter to W.W. Griesser of the Buffalo Life Saving Station informing him that a gold life-saving medal had been awarded him for rescuing a man from drowning on Nov. 21, 1900. In recounting the circumstances of the rescue, Secretary Gage says:

Tyrannies of a revolution are often worse and more permanent than those of tyrants, as the readers of certain conservative Parisian journals are frequently reminded. And a few of these particular tyrannies have remained in France since '93, but, in many cases, have been so covered up or diverted as to be unnoticed by the average taxpayer.

At the forty-second annual commencement of Cooper Union Schools for the Advancement of Science and Art. Abram S. Hewitt last night emphasized his recent utterance in regard to the proper use of wealth. He did not exactly paraphrase Andrew Carnegie's assertion that "to die rich is to die disgraced," but he did say, bluntly, that to be rich and not to use wealth for the general good was to be disgraced.

CHICAGO, June 5 -- The use of a patented "bogus coin detector" only in slot machines operated for gambling purposes deprives the owner of the patent of standing in a court of equity to sue another man for alleged infringement on the device. This was the ruling of Judge Kohlsatt, in the United States Circuit Court, to-day in denying an injunction asked by George A. Fuller against Paul E. Berger.

The Hotel Endicott property, covering the entire block front on the west side of Columbus Avenue, between Eighty-first and Eighty-second Streets, was transferred yesterday by Isaac Anstatt and Cyrus C. Marble to the Hotel Endicott Company. The consideration stated in the deed is $499,500, besides the assumption of all liens on the property.

Contractor John B. McDonald had a plan to reduce the cost of equipment of the rapid transit railroad by about $1,000,000. He requested the Rapid Transit Commissioners to allow him to build intermediary power houses underground in City Hall Park, Union Square, and Long Acre Square. These power houses were to occupy 50 by 180 feet and have a depth for machinery of 30 feet.

An explosion which seriously interfered with the travel of several hundred thousand Brooklynites on their way from the Borough of Churches to Manhattan occurred yesterday morning shortly after 8 o'clock in the Eastern District power house, at the corner of Kent and Division Avenues.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 5 -- A Pan-American banking company that intends to do business also in the Philippines, Cuba, and Porto Rico, will be incorporated by the State Legislature in a few days. The new company is to be known as the International Company, with a capital stock of $300,000, which later may be increased greatly.

The wedding of Louis Warren Hill, son of James J. Hill of St. Paul, and Miss Maude Van Cortlandt Taylor, daughter of Cortlandt Taylor, now of St. Paul, but formerly of Staten Island, was celebrated at noon yesterday at the residence of the bride's brother, Walter Curzon Taylor, 9 East Eighty-first Street.

CAMP TOWNSEND, PEEKSKILL, N. Y., June 3 -- "Golly, dem fellahs are a wukkin hard for a game dey calls play," said a little colored chap, as he sat in the shade of a tent this afternoon watching the polo games. But then he did not know the exhilaration of riding a polo pony at a mad gallop.

COLUMBIA, S.C., June 5 -- Decidedly the most sensational development in the Senatorial tangle in this State is a letter which Gov. McSweeney sent to Senator Tillman to-day. In his communication, the Governor informed Senator Tillman that if he should "still wish to resign, and will send to this office an unconditional resignation, I will exercise the authority and power vested in me by the people."

To the Editor of The New York Times: A few years ago the City of New York, at great expense, acquired title to many buildings and lots situated between Hester Street on the north, East Broadway on the South, Essex Street on the west, and Norfolk Street on the east side thereof, said territory now being known as "Seward Park."

HAVANA, June 5 -- The official instructions from Washington regarding the Platt amendment have not arrived. The delay is causing annoyance to Gen. Wood, as he had promised that the convention would have the letter Tuesday, and a meeting was called for this afternoon to discuss the document.

The dry goods trade and real estate men may stop making predictions as to what will be the effect of the removal of the Macy store to Herald Square, because the corner of Sixth Avenue and Fourteenth Street promises to be more of a retail dry goods market than ever it was.

BUFFALO, June 5. -- "We can eat you, but we can't sleep you," is a common saying with London hostesses when the supply of sleeping rooms is limited. No such fiat need be feared by visitors to Buffalo this Summer. On the contrary, every visitor can feel sure of being both slept and eaten. Both restaurants and sleeping accommodations are plentiful as sands on the lake shore.

HANOVER, N. H., June 6. -- Dartmouth won handily in the baseball game with Columbia College this afternoon by the score of 16 to 3. Columbia fielded even more loosely than the error column shows, and, while Dartmouth batted hard, the visitors could do nothing with Rollins except in the fifth inning.

The banquet of the Chamber of Commerce of London on Wednesday at which the representatives of the Chamber of Commerce of New York were honored guests showed plainly enough that the art of ceremonial and high-occasional dining for which the New York Chamber has long been noted at home is shared with, possibly inherited from, what may be called the parent institution.

More complications over the estate of George Francis Gilman developed in the Supreme Court yesterday. Edward L. Norton, the New York administrator of the estate, asked for an injunction restraining George F. Hartford and Theophilus Oilman from disposing of any of the property of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company.

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- Miss Grace Louise Knowlton and Clarke Waggaman were married this afternoon at Valley View, the suburban home of Dr. and Mrs. Daniel E. Clarke. No cards of invitation were issued, and only the immediate relatives of the young people were bidden to the ceremony, which was one of the prettiest of the Summer.

William Kempen, sixteen years old, of 332 River Street, Hoboken, disappeared on May 26. His father yesterday told the police that he had trustworthy information to the effect that Richard Detmars, also sixteen years old, of 63 Third Street, had kidnapped his son and was holding him for a ransom of $10.

There were twelve men in Brooklyn yesterday who learned, with some pain of mind, that having fun with the dignity of the Supreme Court was anything but the mirthful business they thought it. The dozen men in question composed a jury, which, in order to escape being locked up for the night to, decide a case, handed in a sealed verdict to the effect that they had "agreed to disagree."

FAIRHAVEN, Ohio, June 6. -- Curtis Roberts, Superintendent of Schools of Fairhaven, was accidentally killed this afternoon while at target practice. With his sweetheart, Mary Alferton, and several other young persons, Roberts went into the woods to practice with a revolver. Miss Alferton fired the first shot, and the ball, striking the side of a stump, bounded off and struck Roberts in the side, inflicting a wound from which he died in a few hours.

CLEVELAND, June 6. -- Horace Pell of New York, a member of the stock company which is playing at the Euclid Avenue Opera House, attempted suicide by shooting himself in the right side in his room at the Wyandotte early to-day. The bullet went through his body and imbedded itself in the wall.

More expert testimony was adduced yesterday by Samuel J. Kennedy's lawyers at the trial of the Staten Island dentist, charged with murdering Emeline C. Reynolds, to show that the defendant did not write the indorsement on the check found on the dead girl's body.
NEWPORT, June 6. -- Mrs. Charles H. Malcolm and Miss Malcolm have gone to New York.

It is to be hoped for the sake of his own reputation that President HYDE of Bowdoin College is sure of his facts when he gives the name of "Rockefellerism" to what he regards as hostility to "academic freedom." Mr. ROCKEFELLER has given largely of his money for the promotion of education, and some of his gifts unquestionably have been marked by high intelligence.

BOSTON, June 6. -- A verdict for the plaintiff for $500 in each case in the suits brought by Miss Grace Effner of Albany, N.Y., against Joseph Middleby, Jr., and Robert Vickery, was returned by a jury in the United States Circuit Court, Judge Aldrich presiding, late this afternoon.
THE NEW YORK TIMES acknowledges the receipt of $2 from an anonymous contributor to start a fund to help "H.B.D." to get into a home for the aged.

LONDON, June 7. -- After a long and somewhat embittered discussion of the policy of the War Office in buying horses for use in South Africa, the House of Commons last night, by a vote of 159 to 60, granted the sum of u15,779,000 for transports and remounts.

BERLIN, June 6. -- The Tageblatt prints special correspondence from New Guinea combining an account of the massacre of the members of the first German South Sea expedition on the cannibal island of St. Matthias. They were all killed and eaten save Dr. Heinroth.

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- There was a slight improvement in Mrs. McKinley's condition this morning, but none during the day. Dr. Rixey left the White House at 10 o'clock to-night, after an hour and a half spent in attendance on his patient. He said:

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., June 6. -- Miss Elizabeth Lamed and Miss Helen Dillingham of Summit Hill, N.J., were defeated at Haverford to-day in the first round of the ladies' double championship tourney on the grounds of the Merion Cricket Club by Miss Lycett and Miss Chichester of the home club.

With the exception of the dance last evening at the University Gymnasium for the Senior class of Barnard College there were no entertainments in town. The weddings of the day brought in many from the country, but the season of outing and of suburban life has now set in and as tar as social life goes, the town is extremely dull.

Imprisoned for stealing an eight-cent bottle of milk when starving, Frederick Stewart, a paper hanger, of Newark, who was on his way to seek work in Holyoke, Mass., found justice and unexpected good fortune in the Court of Special Sessions yesterday.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 6. -- Ex-Chief Justice Thomas Durfee of the Supreme Court of the State of Rhode Island, died this afternoon from heart trouble following an attack of acute indigestion. He was seventy-five years of age and leaves a widow and one son.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., June 6. -- The Leyland Line steamer Assyrian, from Antwerp for Montreal, with 2,000 tons of cargo, went ashore off Cape Race at midnight. She has eleven feet of water in her forehold and is likely to prove a total wreck.

BOSTON, June 6. -- Charles S. Davis, forty years old, of 160 West Twenty-third Street, New York City, was arrested this morning in Post Office Square by Inspectors Harris, Gaddis, and Cronin on a warrant charging him with threatening an injury to his cousin, Edward D. Emerson, of 39 Gurney Street, Wellesley Hills.

BERLIN, June 6. -- One of the results of yesterday's tariff convention, it is learned, is that Prussia and a number of the larger German States have abandoned the idea of the so-called double tariff, that is to say, maximal and minimal, which commercial circles considered the main obstacle in concluding new and mutually satisfactory commercial treaties.

A sharp cry of "Fire!" heard in the students' corridors of St. John's College, Lewis and Willoughby Avenues, Brooklyn, at 1 o'clock yesterday morning, followed by the prolonged ringing of the alarm bells situated on all floors of the college building, threw the institution into excitement. From the little cell-like bedrooms students in undress rushed.

BOSTON, June 6. -- A bill in equity was brought before the Massachusetts Supreme Court this afternoon by James Forrester and John MacGinnis against A.S. Bigelow, W.J. Ladd, and J. S. Bigelow, stockholders owning a majority of Boston and Montana stock, and Kidder, Peabody Co.

It is probable that a great many Northern people who read of the recent reunion of Confederate veterans at Memphis, of the meetings held and speeches made on the birthday of JEFFERSON DAVIS, and of the more or less general observance of Decoration Day in the Confederate cemeteries, will attach more importance to these incidents than they are really entitled to claim.
Henry M. Fairchild has received an Eastern field appointment for the Traders' Insurance Company of Chicago.

The sixty-ninth annual commencement exercises of the professional and graduate schools of New York University were held last night in the Metropolitan Opera House, when diplomas were presented to 144 successful students in the presence of an audience of relatives and friends that taxed the capacity of the building.

Announcement was made yesterday of the completion of arrangements by which the New York Electric Vehicle Transportation Company obtains control of the recently organized Metropolitan Express Company, and thus insures the success of a plan for a parcel and package express.

The irregular price movement in the stock market continued all day yesterday with the volume of transactions falling materially off. Less than a million shares were traded in with seven stocks --on Pacific, Southern Pacific, United States Steel, Atchison, Erie, American Tobacco, and Continental Tobacco - contributing practically one-half of the entire transactions.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., June 6. -- Miss Mabel Lawrence Burt of Bridgeton, N.J., twenty-one years old, for three years a student at Smith College, was arrested last night on the charge of having robbed her fellow-students of money and Jewelry to the amount of $3,000.

NEWBURG, N.Y., June 6. -- The funeral of Capt. J. Alfred Walker, one of the best known river men in this section, took place to-day. In addition to a floral design, Gov. Odell sent a telegram of sympathy to the widow in which he said, "May God sustain you in your hour of mourning, in the death of your husband.

LONDON, June 6. -- Appreciation of the cordiality of the sentiments Americans and British are now so frequently exchanging is the burden of the comments of the afternoon newspapers on yesterday evening's Chamber of Commerce banquet.

-- It is only a few days ago that, at the request of the officers of the Arnold Arboretum, we briefly described the work done and planned by that most admirable and valuable institution and directed attention to the need for an immediate and material increase of its endowment if the Arboretum is to perform in something like full measure the priceless public services which its wise and generous founder had in mind.

The bronze statue of Gen. John B. Wooward was shown yesterday to subscribers to the fund, at the museum near Prospect Park, Brooklyn, whose portico of many columns is almost ready to admit visitors through the grand entrance. It is modeled by Frederick MacMonnies and cast by E. Gruet, modeling and foundry work having been done in Paris.

PHILADELPHIA, June 6. -- Cambria Steel and the Readings were the most active issues to-day. Otherwise the market was dull and narrow. Cambria went to 31 3/8 a new high record. Bethlehem was benefited to the extent of 3/4, but Pennsylvania Steel yielded points, to 48, while the preferred rose half as much.

More than 125 bankers of Georgia, with their wives and families, arrived in this city in two installments yesterday afternoon on the Old Dominion steamers Guyandotte and Princess Anne from Old Point Comfort, Va., where for two days the tenth annual convention of the Georgia Bankers' Association has been in session.

BERLIN, June 6. -- A sensational case began to-day in the First District Court of Berlin. The plaintiff, Anna Milewski, was formerly Lady in Waiting upon the late Princess Amalia of Schleswig-Holstein, and the defendant is the brother of Empress Augusta Victoria, Duke Ernst Guenther.

LONDON, June 7. -- The stockholders of the Metropolitan District Railway, at a special meeting held yesterday, sanctioned Charles T. Yerkes's plan for the introduction of electricity as the motive power of the road. In explaining his plan in an interview last night Mr. Yerkes said:

Many Chinese who have been for years in this country have made little progress in learning English. They have not had time to go to school, and there have not been books gotten out by any Chinese Oldendorf in English and Chinese and Chinese and English for their benefit. At last this long-felt want has been supplied.
BRISTOL, R.I., June 6. -- The iron workers employed on the buckled mast of the Constitution made so much progress today that the spar is now in two sections.

The mysteries of baccarat, rouge-et-noir, roulette, and "craps" were explained, and illustrated with appropriate paraphernalia, by Assistant District Attorney Schurman to Judge Warren W. Foster and a jury in the Court of General Sessions yesterday.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "RS" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage, except in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes payment of the mortgage.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., June 6. -- The Chattanooga, Rome and Southern Railway and the Central of Georgia Railway Company to-day recorded in this city a bond issue of $2,400,000 on the Chattanooga Division of that road.
First Lieut. William P. Pence, Artillery Corps, is detailed as recorder of the examining board convened at Fort Monroe, vice Capt. Henry D. Todd, Jr., Artillery Corps, hereby relieved.

BOSTON, June 6. -- The Lawson yacht Independence in her second sail trial to-day met with her first accident, a not very serious jamming of the steering gear, but sufficent to stop the trial after an hour and a half of splendid sailing, during which she attained a speed on a reach of a little over three miles of 13 1/2 nautical miles an hour.

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- The Ambassadors from most of the European countries were in conference within Secretary Hay today, mainly because it was Diplomatic Day, which afforded an opportunity for discussing the state of the Chinese negotiations. It is understood that the middle ground, or modus vivendi, as it is being termed, concerning the form of paying the indemnity, is likely to be adopted with a joint and several guarantee.

LONDON, May 26. -- The impression of original talent one derives from the acting of Mrs. Patrick Campbell in Mr. Pinero's uncommonly clever and ingenious play of "The Notorious Mrs. Ebbsmith" is strengthened when she is seen in Senor Echegaray's very ordinary and illogical piece, called "Mariana."

It is understood that the middle ground, or modus vivendi, as it is being termed, concerning the form of paying the indemnity, is likely to be adopted with a joint and several guarantee.

LONDON, May 26. -- The impression of original talent one derives from the acting of Mrs. Patrick Campbell in Mr. Pinero's uncommonly clever and ingenious play of "The Notorious Mrs. Ebbsmith" is strengthened when she is seen in Senor Echegaray's very ordinary and illogical piece, called "Mariana."

CAMP TOWNSEND, Peekskill, June 6. -- The weather to-day was uncomfortably hot for Squadron A's sports, and the breeze blowing over the parade ground was not very cooling. Visitors -- and there were a host of them -- crowded the sloping hill to the north of the field, but the trees did not cast shadows broad enough to provide shade for all, and many had to sit in the sun, to the ruination or complexions.

One of the prettiest of the many June weddings was celebrated yesterday afternoon at 4 o'clock in the Church of the Incarnation, when Miss Edith Knowlton became Mrs. Allan Appleton Robbins. By 4 o'clock the church was well filled with a large and fashionable crowd of wedding guests.

A correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, a member of the legal profession, writes to that paper to protest against the methods of a street railway corporation against which he has been conducting litigation. He says that there has been "loud complaint among the members of the bar that in these accident suits the railway company does not hesitate to produce witnesses whose testimony clearly shows that they have committed perjury."

BALTIMORE, Md., June 6. -- The details of the plan for the formation of the Metropolitan District Electric Traction Company in London, engineered by Charles T. Yerkes of Chicago, with whom were associated officials and experts of the Maryland Trust Company, were made public in this city to-day. The Maryland Company will be the American financial agent of the enterprise.

Deputy Commissioner Devery promulgated some principles in bankruptcy procedure while sitting in judgment on delinquent policemen at Headquarters yesterday. Policeman Matthew M. Murphy of the Macdougal Street Station was before him for failing to pay a debt and also for being off post.

Gov. Odell and other prominent persons yesterday afternoon reviewed the annual parade of Sunday school children and teachers in Brooklyn. The children belonged to forty schools embraced in the Eastern District Sunday School Association. The line of march was from Bedford and Division Avenues along Bedford Avenue to Flushing Avenue and return to the starting point.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Now that the Philippine and South African wars are over (I mean over where they always were,) and everybody is getting rich -- except the sundry millions who are getting it "in the neck" -- allow me to suggest that you couldn't do a more politic and philanthropic thing than to give the restaurant keepers of this town a good stirring up.

Business in the outside market yesterday was almost at a standstill. Some few issues attracted attention, but for the most part the interest shown was slight. Notwithstanding the dullness of the market, prices held fairly firm, and in some instances closing quotations were substantially above those of the previous day.

The fourth International Publishers' Congress begins to-morow in Leipsic, and will last until, and including, next Wednesday. It will convene under the Presidency of Mr. Albert Brockhaus. George Haven Putnam will be the only American representative, we believe.

The Committee on Law of the Board of Aldermen gave a hearing yesterday on a proposed ordinance to restrict the speed of automobiles to not more than eight miles an hour. A number of representatives of automobile clubs were present, and the upshot of the hearing was that the Aldermen were invited to go touring around New York in automobiles to see what limit of speed should be fixed.

The Token." the writer was sufficiently impressed by the "singularity" of three articles to extract three columns from one of them. Thereon Hawthorne wrote home. "My worshipful self is a very famous man in London." but as the articles were anonymous the notice did not prevent his remaining for some time yet "the obscurest man of letters in America."

Politicians yesterday had a great deal to say with regard to the resignation of several well-known members from the Plaza Club, one of the strongest and most Influential Republican organizations in this county.

The stock market yesterday was dull and almost featureless, only a few stocks showing any life. Trading was on an even smaller scale than on the preceding day, total transactions approximating but three-quarters of a million and suggesting the listless trading that was the order about ten days ago. Save and except the official announcement of the consolidation of the tobacco companies there were no specially important developments during the day.

CAMP TOWNSEND, Peekskill, June 7. - -Cavalry week ends to-night and to-morrow the Eighth Regiment, in command of Col. J.M. Jarvis, and the First Battery; commanded by Capt. Louis Wendel, will occupy the tented plain. Both organizations will come by train, the Eighth, leaving the Grand Central Station at 10:30 and the battery entraining at the Thirty-third Street station, where they leave at 9 o'clock.

It happened that many persons, widely scattered, formed soon after Whitman's death a "Whitman Fellowship, International," which has just held in this city its eighth annual convention its chosen date May 31 -- was appointed for Whitman's birthday, and on this occasion nine hours were set apart in exercises in commemoration of the man and his work.

Charges of deliberate misrepresentation on the part of Chancellor MacCracken are freely made by the professors of the School of Pedagogy of New York University, who recently resigned because of dissensions in that institution in a statement just issued. It is a long document, admittedly provoked by the Chancellor's address at the commencement Thursday night.
Further correspondence between the New York Yacht Club and Thomas W. Lawson concerning the entry of the Boston millionaire's yacht as a possible defender of the America's Cup is at an end.

WASHINGTON, June 7. -- Representative James Rankin Young of Pennsylvania, who was in Washington to-day, announced that the Pennsylvania delegation would fight Chairman Babcock's attempt to pass a Republican tariff reform bill. "In Pennsylvania," said Mr. Young, "any attempt to reduce the tariff strikes home to every individual, for the interests of the people are so closely allied with the policy of protection as to be almost inseparable.

LONDON. June 7. -- Another of Britain's great racing trophies has been captured by America. Foxhall P. Keene having won the Oaks at Epsom with Cap and Bells II., ridden by Milton Henry. The owner, horse, and jockey are all thoroughbred Americans, so the victory was not diluted, as it was in the case of the Derby.
WASHINGTON, June 7. -- Mrs. McKinley's condition remains practically unchanged. As Dr. Rixey left the White House to-night at 10:30 o'clock, he said that his patient was resting comfortably.

READING, Penn., June 7. -- A large number of the 3,000 Reading Iron Company employes now on strike went into camp on an island in the Schuylkill River to-day to economize in the cost of living. It is stated that many of the strikers are anxious to go back to work.

HOUSTON, Texas, June 7. -- As the result of an indictment charging hog theft, a shooting affray occurred here to-day in which Thomas Payne and L.D. Echols were killed and J.B. Perkins was fatally and David Echols badly wounded. Payne's son was on trial, and the Echolses had been summoned as witnesses.

LONDON, June 7. -- Money was steady today, and the supply was fairly large. The demand was comparatively small. The reduction of the bank rate had little influence, having been fully discounted. A considerable number of operators opine that the reduction is merely temporary, and that the rate soon will be 4 per cent, again.

"George Brown Goode was born at New Albany, Ind., on Feb. 13, 1831, and died at his house. In Washington, on Sept 6, 1896. after a life of forty-five years, than which few human lives have ever been better filled." In this way Prof. Langley, the Secretary of the Smithsonian Institution. snccintly summarizes the record of one of the notable men of our time.

LONDON, June 7. -- Lord Mayor Green and the Sheriffs of London received the delegates of the New York Chamber of Commerce at the Mansion House this afternoon. About twenty of the delegates were presented to the Lord Mayor, and were escorted through the Mansion House. Several members of the London Chamber of Commerce, including Lord Brassey and Sir Albert K. Rollit, were present.

Mr. Abran English Brown, who is a member of the New England Historic-Genealogical Society, and author of various historical works, has prepared an interesting volume dealing with Faneuil Hall and its market, and with the romantic fortunes of the Faneuils. The first chapter will be found a sort of essay on the French Huguenots, in which the causes leading to their exile are clearly and rapidly set forth.

CONCERNING that itinerant Russian novelist, Maxim Gorky, Mr. Christian Brinton said in The Critle of last November: "Ten years hence those cleansed of Tolstoyism and Christian Anarchy may find an hour for 'Forma Gorayeeff.' for Gorky's bosiaky, who are as masterful in their way as Rembrandt's beggars or Raffaelll's rates."
"A revolution in Mexico is scarcely a possibility; a successful revolution there is an impossibility."

CINCINNATI, Ohio, June 7. -- The New Yorks were unable to hit Newton in today's baseball game, and lost to the Cincinnatis after a ten-Inning struggle. Had the Gotham batters been even moderately successful, they would have taken the game, as Newton was free with his passes to first, and Doheny was holding down the local team.

On other pages of this issue will be found an interesting article by Moneure D. Conway, concerning severi uncolleeted, and heretofore unknown, writings of Nathaniel Hawthorne. Mr. Conway. many years ago. published a biography of Hawthorne which gives to a paper of this character from, his hands special title to consideration.

His friends know this much, and they know that he died Thursday; but if any of them know where he died they refuse to say. The greatest mystery is being made about the place of his death.

PHILADELPHIA, June 7. -- Bishop Willlam Rufus Nicholson of the Reformed Episcopal Church in Philadelphia, died at his home in this city to-night. He was successively rector in Protestant Episcopal churches in New Orleans, Cincinnati, Boston, and Newark, N.J. in 1874 he became a member of the Reformed Episcopal Church, and was consecrated a Bishop in 1876.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., June 8 -- Three events were held on the course of the Hillside Tennis and Golf Club to-day. In the opening of the all-season contest for the George P. Mellick Cup for women, the winners were the Misses Margaret Goddard, 115 -- 12 -- 103; Lida Van Herwerden, 114 -- 0 -- 114, and Adelaide Ball, 124 -- 10 -- 114.

PHILADELPHIA, June 8 -- The second bicycle race meeting of the season at Woodside Park to-day, drew a large crowd, the principal attraction being the thirty-mile motor-paced race between "Jimmy" Michael, Burns Pierce, and Archie McEachern. The race, which was hotly contested, was won by Pierce in 48 minutes, 58 seconds.

BALTIMORE, June 8 -- The market to-day was rather quiet and featureless, without any special movement one way or the other. The interest centred around Seaboards again, without producing any significant changes. There was a disposition toward the average Summer half-holiday listlessness and the averseness to trading became all the more pronounced after the New York bank statement.

BOSTON, June 8 -- At the Clearing House to-day money between the banks was in abundant supply at 2 per cent., and New York funds sold at par. Exchanges, $22,876,632; balances, $2,295,825. The bank statement issued yesterday shortly before the close of business was a very decided surprise to the Street because of the enormous expansion in loans and the large decrease in surplus reserves.
