NEWARK, N.J., June 8 -- Three arrests were made here this forenoon in connection with an alleged conspiracy to commit arson. The prisoners are Sylvan Friedlander, his wife, Carrie, and Daniel H. Bogert.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The Secretary of the Navy to-day approved the recommendations of the Naval Board of Awards concerning medals of honor and letters of commendation to a number of officers and men of the navy and Marine Corps who distinguished themselves during the campaign in China.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., June 6 -- The growth of the cotton manufacturing industry in the Southern States is very clearly shown by the tables prepared by the Department of Agriculture. Probably these figures are more accurate than those given in my letter on this subject, which were intended to be of popular rather than of statistical interest.

MELBOURNE, May 11 -- The long-expected event is over, and the Australian Commonwealth has tendered to her royal visitors a right royal welcome. For weeks Melbourne had been preparing for the reception, and visitors from far and near have poured into the city. Nearly all the British possessions sent representatives, and stately battleships of all nations came to honor the great occasion.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There have been several letters in THE TIMES recently complaining more or less good-naturedly about the children in the streets and in the public parks. Games in the streets are objected to because they obstruct pedestrians, and joking and singing in the parks near private residences are declared a nuisance.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- It is rather early in the year, and too warm to talk politics seriously, but there are politicians here who do not find it too early or too warm to anticipate the contentions of next Winter and to discuss such immaterial propositions as who shall be leader of the minority in the House.

SOME of the results of trout fishing -- fly casting -- in the streams of the Ulster County watershed, including the Beaverkill, Willowemoc, and Neversink, have been proof of the fallibility of angling entomological lore, as it has been uniformly difficult to discover the taking "color" in making up casts of flies.
Three of Maine's four Representatives in Congress are said to favor the Hon. William T. Cobb of Rockland in his aspiration for the Republican nomination for Governor of the State.

A GOOD part of Joaeph Holland's career as an actor was spent in California about sixteen years or so ago. He was-in a company which included such sterling actors as McKee Rankin. D.H. Harkins, Jack Wallace, Frank Mordaunt, Theodore Hamilton, Len Stockwell, George Osborne, Mrs. McKee Rankin, Ellie Wilton, Clara Jean Waters, Adele Waters, and others.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Will you permit me to say a few words on the article entitled "The Position of Organized Labor," which appeared in last Sunday's TIMES?

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- Senator McLaurin of South Carolina was in Washington to-day, and said he was confident that his ideas would be upheld by the people of his State and that he would succeed in his fight. He said he was in Washington to look after business matters connected with his State and constituents.

Over fifty members of the New York Stock Exchange took a holiday yesterday and spent it in chasing the elusive golf ball over the links of the Knollwood Country Club near White Plains. The event was the fifth annual handicap tournament of the Stock Exchange golfers, and a big delegation of brokers was on hand to see the fun.

"SEEMS like a pootty big question for Ogunquit," Uncle Silas Larrabee remarked, when the Post Office loungers called on him last night to say whether the United States Supreme Court decided the insular cases wisely.

LONDON, June 8 -- From a commercial point of view the season has thus far been the worst on record for the artists in public sales. Modern paintings have invariably brought small prices, and private sales have been few and unsatisfactory.

To the Editor of The New York Times: My attention has been called to a communication of Israel Ellis printed on your editorial page of June 6, in which the writer discusses at length the present condition of Seward Park. Evidently Mr. Ellis, as well as a considerable portion of the public, suffers from an imperfect knowledge of the facts in the matter.
PLAINFIELD, N. J., June 8 -- Proud and fond of their railroad tramp cat are the yard men of the New Jersey Central. The cat is a demure pussy, maltese in color and independent in character.

INTERMITTENTLY an article appears in the public prints not only describing the pistols used in the Burr-Hamilton duel fought at Weehawken July 11, 1804, but giving the name or their present owner, his residence, and a circumstantial account of how the historic weapons came into his possession.

Elections in Holland. The Parliamentary election of Holland will be held next Wednesday, preceded by the municipal and provincial elections. At present probabilities point to an increase in both Socialists and Catholics, but chiefly the latter at the expense of the old Liberal or Moderate Party.

Justice JEROME has qualities that make him just now a very useful citizen indeed. He has sense, he has public spirit, he has pluck. He is engaged in making an investigation on his own account, and in the line of his official duty, which may have as important an influence upon the next municipal election as the investigation had which ran away with LEXOW and elected Mayor STRONG.

PARIS, June 8 -- The death in prison of Mme. Monnier, a wealthy but miserly landowner in the neighborhood of Poitiers, forms the climax in a drama the pathos and horror of which has been the sensation of the week in Paris.

LONDON, June 8 -- The week has doubtless been an exceedingly cheerful one for Winston Spencer Churchill, M. P., who pluckily pursues his task of reforming the Conservative Party from within, if with no perceptible effect upon that time-honored organization yet with much increase of public admiration for himself and his powers, of oratory.

BALTIMORE, June 8. -- Through Baltimore men directly interested it was reported in financial circles here to-day that the arrangements for the formation of the new corporation which will combine the Atlantic Transport Company, the Leyland Line, and other steamship companies, have practically been completed, and that the papers will be signed soon after the arrival in London of President B. N. Baker of the Atlantic Transport Company.
The Equitable Life Assurance Society has established a total abstinence class of policy holders, as the consequence of a petition presented to President Alexander.

LONDON, June 8 -- The canvas on which Luke Fildes will begin his portrait of the King next week will be eleven feet high. No fewer than twenty replicas will be required of this official portrait of his Majesty, many of them for the various embassies. The sittings will be in the artist's own studio on Medbury Round, Kensington, in sight of the historic Holland House.

During a raid made at midnight on an alleged policy shop in the basement of 211 West Twenty-eighth Street, one of the men in the place fired a shot from a revolver. Capt. Cooney of the West Thirty-seventh Street Station was asked by Frank Moss, one of the raiders, to order the crowd in the place to lay down their arms.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- Accounts about the travels in the Philippines of military officers, scientists, newspaper men, and others have some time since ceased to have the charm of novelty. Interest in the islands has come to be chiefly concerning the result of the experiment in hand to constitute a Government there in which the natives shall have the largest possible and safe share in the administration of their own affairs.

Hardly any of the proclaimed measures taken during the last two years for the purpose of absorbing the Grand Duchy of Finland by the empire of the Czar -- destroying its social, fiscal, and political autonomy, almost obliterating the characteristics of the race itself -- have served to enlighten the foreigner concerning the ways of the people thus menaced.

CAMP TOWNSEND, Peekskill, June 8 -- Hospitality strove with hospitality last night, but it was a dead heat. Neither Troop C nor Squadron A could outdo the other, and the evening's entertainments resolved themselves into one grand love feast.

PHILADELPHIA, June 8 -- Heavy selling of Union Traction, due to the recent rapid transit legislation at Harrisburg and the organizing of new transit companies, was the feature of the local market, and the stock fell to its lowest. Union Traction opened at 29 yesterday and closed last night at 27 3/4.

ZAMBOANGA, Mindanao, April 20 -- If the Civil Commission in its tour of the Philippines were to undertake to reach conclusions in regard to the diverse human problems, apart from politics, that present themselves at every stage, a report might be written that would be quite as investing, if not as valuable, as anything yet embodied in permanent form.

LONDON, June 8 -- There was difficulty to day in finding profitable employment for the plethora of money, and discounts were correspondingly weak. Business on the Stock Exchange opened with a rather better tendency, but the attendance was meagre, accentuating the usual Saturday slackness.

Gen. SHERMAN astride of a thoroughly American horse that is moving along as if it and its rider had a long campaign ahead, SHERMAN accompanied by a winged Victory leading the way, is looking for a site in New York. The sculptor is ST. GAUDENS, and the group in plaster held the centre of interest among the statuary in the covered courtyard of the Fine Arts Building at the Paris Exposition last Summer.

IT was during the cold weather we have been having up to the last few days, and the woman was in the street car. It was evening, and the man who sat in the same seat with her in the open car noticed without giving the matter a thought that she was holding her wrap closely about her.

Although the mother of Joe Phillips, the fifteen-year-old boy who was committed to the Catholic Protectory, has been released from the workhouse, the boy is still at the institution. Magistrate Pool, who had arranged to have the boy enter the home of Dr. and Mrs. Coe, sent an order for his release, but the lad decided that he would remain where is is rather than be separated from his mother and sisters.

The races in the annual Columbia commencement regatta yesterday on the Hodson River were full of unexpected and exciting happenings. One eight-oared crew, composed of graduates, was swamped, and its members forced to jump overboard. In the Varsity crew, R.B. Bartholomew broke his oar lock and jumped overboard, and in the sophomore four P.B. La Roche smashed his outrigger the accident shutting out his crew from almost certain success.

LONDON, June 8 -- The captains and kings of American finance and commerce are slowly departing or losing their identities in the vast crowd of their undistinguished fellow-citizens now invading these islands. Their week of honors began with a reception by royalty and ended gorgeously in the presence of an illustrious successor of Whittington.
PHILADELPHIA, June 8 -- It is officially denied at the office of the President of the Pennsylvania Railroad that that company has purchased the Wheeling and Lake Erie and the Wabash Railroads.
A GRAY-HAIRED alumnus of Columbia, on from a Western State for the graduating exercises, chatted of the days when he was at Columbia.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., June 8 -- To-day was the opening day at this resort for some of the hotels. Among those flying flags were the West End Hotel cottages, the Hollywood, the St. Charles, the Pannacci Hotel, and the Elberon. The other hotels will open about one week later, with the exception of the large Howland Hotel at West End, which will not open its doors this season.

DID you ever know what an inexpensive thing a trip to New York can be made by one of us provincial school teachers?" asked a pedagogue from North Carolina the other day. The speaker had been in the city for a few days, and, according to the story he told, he didn't have to spend half a dollar in every twenty-four hours that he had been here.

Richard Mansfield, the actor, who closed his season at Portland, Me., on Saturday, returned to this city last night and staid at the Holland House. He is in excellent health.' Regarding the theatrical season he said:

To the Editor of The New York Times: There are women and women. This was never more strikingly illustrated than by the marked difference between the election of officers in the convention of the Daughters of the American Revolution and in the convention of the National Woman Suffrage Association, just held in Minneapolis.

Frightened by an automobile, and closely followed by an electric trolley car, a horse attached to an open buggy in which were seated a man, woman, and child ran away on Jamaica Avenue, near Highland Park, yesterday morning, and but for the Rev. C.R. Fisher of the church at Chestnut Street and Glenmore Avenue the occupants might have fared badly.

BERLIN, June 9. -- Throughout last week the Boerse continued under the influence of New York, and this fact, coupled with the considerable depression existing in business, made the week one of the dullest known for years.

A scene enacted in the Grand Central Station yesterday morning had all the elements of melodrama. The characters included a tall, well-dressed man of foreign appearance, a distinguished-looking woman, whose rich gown admirably set off a fine figure, and two men in plain clothes not designed to either attract attention or occasion comment.

YONKERS, N. Y., June 9. -- Golf and baseball players indulged in their favorite sports to-day without police interference. The golf links had players on them all day, and every field that could be converted into a baseball field was utilized.

BOSTON, June 9. -- The Independence had another short sail in the bay late this afternoon, and the breeze being only moderate the big yacht spread more canvas than has yet been hoisted. The sea was smooth and again she proved her wonderful reaching qualities besides showing considerable ability in windward work.

A GREAT RUSSIAN RAILWAY SCANDAD IMMINENT. -- The Russian Minister of Public Works and Railways, Prince Hilkoff, has just returned to St. Petersburg after making a most thorough inspection of the Trans-Siberian Railway. He was accompanied by a large corps of experts, together with representatives of the Ministries of Interior and Finance.

PITTSBURG, June 9. -- Major W.H. Daly, a Surgeon on the staff of Lieut. Gen. Miles in Porto Rico, and who gained National prominence in the Spanish war through filing a report which started the "embalmed beef" inquiry, committed suicide at his home here to-day by shooting himself in the right temple.

WASHINGTON, June 9. -- The extensive reports of United States Consul Covert at Lyons, France, relative to the success of cannon firing in France as a means of protecting orchards and vineyards from hailstorms, and also for the purpose of mitigating or nullifying the effects of frosts upon vegetation, have prompted numerous inquiries by horticulturists in this country as to when, if at all, our Government would adopt similar methods of protection.

The Rev. Dr. H.D. Von Brockhuizen of Pretoria, South Africa, the minister who closed the Volksraad with prayer after President Kruger's historic ultimatum had been read to that body, is in the city, staying at 12 West Twenty-first Street. He was banished from Pretoria after that capital fell, but not until he had spent ten days in jail, where he says he was kept on a diet of bread and water.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., June 9. -- Two prominent physicians in this section of the State had reported that Miss Mabel L. Burt of Bridgeton, N.J., a former Smith College student, who is under arrest in the county jail on the charge of larceny of money, watches, and jewelry, to the value of $3,000 from the students of Smith College, is suffering from mental derangement and should receive treatment.

Another police descent was made upon the dance hall of Louis Waldron, at 256 West One Hundred and Tenth Street, yesterday afternoon, and two waiters were arrested on the charge of violating the excise law. There were about fifty couples on the floor dancing at the time, but no attempt was made to stop them.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 9. -- To-day was Baccalaureate Sunday of the one hundred and fifty-fourth commencement of Princeton University. President Patton preached the annual sermon to the members of the graduating class, Alexander Hall being crowded with the seniors and their guests. The Trustees and Faculty members occupied the rostrum.
NEWPORT, June 9. -- Mr. and Mrs. Pembroke Jones went to New York this evening on the steam yacht Narada.

BUFFALO, June 9. -- On account of the large number of visiting newspaper men and women expected at the Pan-American Exposition this week, Wednesday. June 12, is announced by Director General Buchanan as "Editors' and Publishers' Day." It is believed the meeting of the National Editorial Association and of several State associations will bring to the Exposition this week the largest number of editors ever gathered together.

Energetic efforts to depress the stock market at the close of business last week failed to create apprehension. Some quotations fell substantially, but careful observers were of the opinion that such changes were due generally to the pressure of short selling. The bank statement with its $7,000,000 decrease in surplus reserves was made much use of by bear traders, though among many bankers the exhibit was declared to have no unsatisfactory elements in it.

Dr. Louis Albert Banks, pastor of Grace Methodist Episcopal Church, delivered a brief prelude before his Sunday evening sermon yesterday on "Alexander Dowie, the 'New Elijah,' and Mary Baker Eddy, the 'Mother of Christian Science,' as Specimen Fungus Growths of Modern Civilization."

ALBANY, June 9. -- In his annual report to the Regents of the State University Director of the State Library Dewey states that the expenditures for the year for home education, including public libraries, traveling libraries and collections, study clubs and extension teaching, were $56,533, being an increase of $6,553 over 1899.

Senator Thomas C. Platt yesterday treated with derision the story that he has entered into a combination with, the practical politicians on the anti-Tammany Conference Committees to force the nomination of John D. Crimmins as the union candidate for Mayor at the approaching election.

-- A convincing demonstration of exactly where the responsibility for every case of lynching should be placed was made at Carrollton, Ga., last week, when a Sheriff with a real determination to do his sworn duty had no difficulty at all in defending his prisoner and putting to flight the usual crowd of "infuriated citizens."

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., June 9. -- The baccalaureate sermon to the graduating class of Union University was delivered this evening in the First Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Dr. A.V.V. Raymond, D.D., LL.D., President of the University. The commencement exercises will be continued to-morrow and Tuesday evening will conclude with the Chancellor's address by Chief Judge Alton B. Parker of the Court of Appeals.

PARIS, June 9. -- The Grand Steeplechase de Paris, four miles and a half furlong, run to-day at Auteuil, was won by Calabrais, with Caralman second and Vlau third. Thirteen ran. President Loubet was enthusiastically cheered by immense crowds on his arrival at the race course and on his departure.

WASHINGTON, June 9. -- The slight improvement in Mrs. McKinley's health which manifested itself the latter part of last week continues, and the reports from the sick room up to a late hour to-night were decidedly encouraging. Dr. Rixey appeared well satisfied with the patient's condition.

Some time between 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon and 7 o'clock last evening two United States Army prisoners who were serving sentences in Castle Williams, on Governors Island, for desertion, escaped. They embarked upon an improvised raft and drifted away from the island on the strong flood time in Buttermilk Channel.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., June 9. -- Rescuers and wrecking crews worked until afternoon to-day at Vestal, ten miles west of here, where an explosion of dynamite in a Delaware, Lackawanna and Western freight car wrecked two colliding trains, killed five trainmen, and injured several others.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., June 9. -- The unchristianity of Christian Science was the subject of the sermon which the Rev. C.E. Herring preached in the First Presbyterian Church here to-night. The preacher denied with all the vigor of which he is capable the claims which Mrs. Eddy's cult makes to a foundation upon the Scriptures.

Copyright, 1901. LONDON, June 9. -- We have got the bank rate down and the market has now steadied somewhat. The efforts made toward the end of last week by the Eastern banks to sell their bills under 3 per cent. were unsuccessful, and the brokers struggled for 3 1/8 per cent., sometimes getting it.

Edward Moran, marine and landscape painter, died yesterday at 3:30 o'clock in his apartments and studio, 384 Fifth Avenue, from a complication of diseases from which he had been suffering for about a year.

Perhaps the happiest man in Brooklyn yesterday was Detective Keelan of the Adams Street Police Station. For three days he had one Augustus Rathbone, an innocent from San Jose, Cal., on his hands, but yesterday was relieved of the care of him.

From all present indications the field of horses that will start for the eighteenth Suburban Handicap, to be run over the Sheepshead Bay race track on Saturday, as the chief event for the opening day of the Coney Island Jockey Club's Summer meeting, will be one of the smallest, if not actually the smallest, that has ever faced the starter for that great and popular turf fixture.

The troopers of Squadron A and Troop C, looking brown, and expressing themselves as feeling invigorated, reached their armories yesterday after nine days of camp life and long marches. Save for one mishap which befell Troop C pleasant experiences in the main would remain to be told.

NEWARK, N.J., June 9. -- The largest crowd of the season, estimated at 8,000 to 10,000 persons, gathered at the Vailsburg track to-day, and fully 2,000 persons were compelled to stand for lack of seats. Many of them crowded upon the track and seriously interfered with the riders. There were twenty-five starters in the ten-mile open race, which was won by Floyd McFarland by twenty yards.

SCRANTON, Penn., June 9. -- Fire of the charters granted in Harrisburg yesterday under the new Quay trolley acts are for companies which propose to operate electric street car lines in and about Scranton and Wilkesbarre. The three Scranton companies will have seventy miles of tracks, the Wilkesbarre company fifty-four miles, and the Nanticoke-Pittston company nineteen miles.

CINCINNATI, June 9. -- The New York baseball team made 31 hits and 25 runs in the game here to-day, and three local pitchers were used without avail.

To the Editor of The New York Times: My communication in relation to the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals did not elicit from its President the full explanation which my charges seem to demand. His saying that the contents were "false and malicious" cannot be construed into a satisfactory answer.

On the French Line steamship La Lorraine, which arrived here yesterday from Havre, there were sixty-two native Africans, bound for the Pan-American Exposition at Buffalo. They left for that city yesterday afternoon, as soon as Commissioner Fitchie was convinced that they did not come within the provisions of the contract labor law.

Joseph Waldo of 221 East One Hundred and Seventh Street, who keeps a coal and ice stand in a cellar at One Hundred and Seventh Street and Third Avenue, was arrested yesterday charged with an assault with a razor upon Frank Cullen, a plasterer, who lives at 183 East One Hundred and Ninth Street.

WASHINGTON, June 9. -- Secretary Long will approve the recommendation of the Board of Awards that Rear Admiral Sampson's face be reproduced upon the Santiago medal. He has before him two designs for the reverse side. In considering this question the board had to face the fact that the flagship New York did not take a prominent part in the battle of Santiago, and therefore was hardly entitled to a place on the medal.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The problem of street car traveling is the important subject of the period, involving, as it does, the transportation of human being's in a safe, decent, healthful, and comparatively comfortable fashion, either for business or pleasure.

It was an anti-Tammany day at yesterday's meeting of the Central Federated Union. Tammany politicians were denounced right and left, and a few Tammany men who tried to speak a word in favor of Tammany Hall were borne down by the tide of denunciation.

CHICAGO, June 9. -- The Brooklyn baseball team won a close but rather loosely played game here to-day, the errors on both sides being costly. Waddell was effective in all excepting the opening inning, but lost his own game in the fifth, his failure to field a bunt and his wild throw, followed by a long single, giving the visitors three runs.

To the Editor of The New YorK Times: When Lord Roberts was Commander in Chief in India, he did not abolish the canteen, but he so arranged matters that three-fourths of the European troops in Hindustan became pledged teetotalers.

CAMP TOWNSEND, Peekskill, June 9. -- Sundays in camp are days of reflection rather than of action, of telling fair visitors deeds of valor done rather than adding additional laurels by new feats of arms. And in reminiscences the Eighth is rich. According to official records it is more than 100 years old.

PATERSON, N.J., June 9. -- Andrew Johnson, the man convicted in the Quarter Sessions of robbery at the jewelry store of Friedmann, on Market Street, is to be sentenced next Friday by Judge Barkalow. Special Officer John Quinn captured Johnson with a bundle containing two clocks and other plunder taken from the jewelry store.

It is perhaps a little harsh to say that the Cuban delegates who recently visited Washington have practiced willful deceit upon the officers of the Government with whom they conferred. They grossly misused their privilege of consulting with Secretary ROOT, not only betraying his confidence but drawing up a false statement of what he said to them and making it public as a part of their official report.

This happened about 7:15 o'clock last night. Policeman William W. Duggan of the Charles Street Station, while walking along West Street, heard a yell and saw Molloy jump from the bulkhead into the river.

The week's festival of the Plattdeutscher Volksfest Verein of Brooklyn was opened yesterday afternoon in Ridgewood Park, L.I. An address of welcome was delivered by Frederick Meyer, the President. Fully 10,000 persons were upon the grounds. Before the festival was formally opened there was a monster parade by the German societies through the park.

More testimony tending to prove Samuel J. Kennedy's statements regarding his movements on the night Emeline C. Reynolds was murdered was given by several witnesses called by the defense in the Staten Island dentist's third trial yesterday. Judge Newburger rebuked Lawyer Moore several times.

CHICAGO, June 10 -- Dr. August M. Unger and F. Wayland Brown, on trial for conspiracy to defraud insurance companies through the death of Miss Marie Defenbach, were this evening found guilty and sentenced to the penitentiary under the indeterminate act. Frank H. Smiley, indicted with Unger and Brown, pleaded guilty and turned State's evidence.
LONDON, June 10 -- Robert Williams Buchanan, poet, critic, and novelist, is dead.

Charles F. Wilson, an ex-employe of Gouverneur Hospital, in whose behalf powerful influences have been exerted to prevent his trial, was yesterday arraigned before Justice Fursman in the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court, charged with attempted subornation of perjury.
LONDON, June 10 -- Robert James LoydLindsay, first Baron Wantage, is dead.
LONDON, June 10 -- Sir Walter Besant, novelist, died yesterday at his residence, Frognal End, Hempstead, after a fortnight's illness, from influenza.

NORWALK, Conn., June 10 -- Sunday shaving is a necessity. This is the decision of Judge Edward M. Lockwood of the Norwalk Town Court in the case of the State vs. Eberhardt Apell, the Norwalk barber Who was arrested upon complaint of the Norwalk Barbers' Union, the allegation being that he kept his place of business open and was doing secular labor and business on the Sabbath.

PHILADELPHIA, June 10 -- A decline in Union Traction adversely affected the entire local list. Within the first quarter hour Union Traction sold at 24 1/4, as compared with Saturday's close of 20. This is the lowest price the stock has reached since it has been $17.50 paid. Between 10 and 12 o'clock probably 12,000 shares were marketed.

The Committee of Fifteen has decided to diminish its activity in the suppression of gambling houses in New York, and after the first of July its principal energies will be devoted to the ferreting out of evil in tenement houses and the banishment possible of women of bad character from the tenement districts.

Mr. Smith was the only bidder, and the property was knocked down to him for $1,000,000. It is generally considered that the Wabash Railroad Company, which has operated the road under a ninety-nine-year lease, is the real purchaser.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 10 -- The class day exercises of the one hundred and fifty-fourth annual commencement of Princeton University began this morning at 10:30, when the Annapolis Naval Band, under the direction of Prof. Zimmerman, gave its initial concert on the front campus. Class day exercises were held in the Alexander Hall.

A report, which may be premature, is sent from Rome that Cardinal GIBBONS has effected "a settlement of the question of the properties of the religious orders in the Philippines." This he is said to have accomplished in conference with Cardinal RAMPOLLA, the Papal Secretary of State, and Archbishop NOZALEDA of Manila.

CAMP TOWNSEND, PEEKSKILL, June 10 -- The Eighth Regiment has gone to war, and to-night is on the extremest frontier at Lake Mohegan, eight miles away, where it will be exposed to all sorts of dangers until Wednesday, when it will return to Camp Townsend flushed with sunburn.
A plain Panama hat which is next thing to a man's in style costs $2.95. It has a narrow black band and a wider rim than a man would wear, with a smaller crown.

BOSTON, June 10 -- The Independence did not leave her berth to-day, as there were many minor details about her deck fittings to be attended to. The lead of the head sheets and topsail sheets was altered The tear in the mainsail was also sewed up. The balance rudder has been found not to be satisfactory, and the sternpost rudder will be shipped and used instead.

BOSTON, June 10 -- Money between the banks loaned at the Clearing House to-day at 2 1/2 and 2 per cent., with the supply abundant, and New York funds sold at par. Exchanges, $16,218,686; balances, $1,713,226.

The yearling thoroughbred horses, the produce of H.P. Headley's Beaumont Stud Farm of Kentucky, were sold by auction in the paddock of the Gravesend race track yesterday by the Fasig-Tipton Sales Com pany, and brought a fair average. The choicest of the colts and fillies sold were the get of the good race horse Ornament, these bringing, the top prices.

CHICAGO, June 10 -- The Brooklyns batted Bason safely in every inning excepting two in to-day's baseball game with Chicago, bunching two doubles and two singles in the third inning, a homer and five singles in the sixth.

NEWPORT, June 10 -- Miss Greta Pomeroy, whose daring riding in the fox hunts last season aroused much comment, to-day tried out a new hunter which arrived recently. The horse is a magnificent animal, and cost $2,000.

PHILADELPHIA, June 10 -- The seniors of the University of Pennsylvania to-day celebrated their exit from studies in the exercises of "Class Day." Robert Smith Gawthrop, President of the class, delivered the salutatory. De Witt Dukes Barlow was the historian, and Frank Brooks Evans, Jr., read the class poem, which was written by Samuel Crowther, Jr. The ivy planting exercises were held on the campus.

LEWISTON, Me., June 10 -- A dispatch from Augusta, Me., says that J.H. Manley has announced that he is a candidate for the nomination for Governor of Maine at the conclusion of Gov. Hill's term. Mr. Manley declares that he favors a one-year term for the Governor and the suppression of the whisky traffic.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is gratifying to note in your columns of yesterday that Capt. N.H. Hall has been brevetted Major for bravery in the presence of the enemy at the siege of the legations in Peking last year. The complete vindication of Capt. Hall is most welcome to all lovers of fair play.

BERLIN, June 10 -- The Kleines Journal to-day publishes a dispatch from The Hague saying that Queen Wilhelmina's recent visit here was meant to obtain Emperor William's consent to end the South African war, both the Zweibund and the Dreibund being willing to do so, through The Hague Arbitration Court.

The London stock brokerage firm of Crews, Lichtenstadt Co., comprising Charles Thomas, Daniel Crews, August Lichtenstadt, George Henry, Martin Whish, Frank Alder, and Cecil Edward Byers, have brought suit in the United States Circuit Court against George A. Kessler of this city to recover $182,508,60, the balance alleged to be due on stock transactions carried on by them for Mr. Kessler between March 14 and May 21 of this year.

Mrs. Annie E. Garrison finished telling her history yesterday before Justice Leventritt in the Supreme Court in her action against ex-Judge Leicester Holme and others to have a deed of trust for $20,000 set aside.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 10 -- Collector of the Port Stratton to-day recommended to the Treasury Department that Su Shih Chin, the Chinese reformer and scholar, be allowed to land under Section 6 of the Exclusion act, as a trader. Su Shin Chin is the leader of the Reform Party, which is seeking to place Emperor Kwang Hsu on the throne, instead of the Dowager Empress.

PORT ROYAL, Penn., June 10 -- The Pittsburg Coal and Coke Company's shaft No. 2 at this place is again on fire, after steady running for seven years, and over thirty men are in the mines, many of whom, it is feared, will never be heard from again. The names of all those known to be entombed cannot be learned.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., June 10 -- The new Cary Smith designed schooner yacht Oonas, recently completed at Shooter's Island for a New York Yacht Club member, to race this season against W. Gould Brokaw's Amorita, arrived in tow to-day and dropped, anchor off the Jacob yard. The yacht has not yet gone into commission, but will probably do so after bending sails and receiving other necessary attention.

The senior class of the West Point Military Academy, attired in their full-dress uniforms, occupied fifty seats in the auditorium of the Casino last night, where they witnessed the performance of "Florodora."

ORANGE, June 10 -- Play in the annual New Jersey State championship lawn tennis tournament began to-day on the courts of the Orange Lawn Tennis Club at Mountain Station with three matches, the first round of the men's singles. There are only sixteen entries, but they are almost without exception well-known players, whose high standard of play gives promise of good competition.

BALTIMORE, June 10 -- The market to-day was exceptionally dull, due entirely to the early offishness in New York. The market lapsed into a stagnant condition the moment it was noted the Seaboard group was quiet. Though this group yielded slightly, as the result of a little ready selling by the more willing speculative crowd, there was a strong bullish sentiment, particularly on the common.

Deputy Sheriff Radley received three executions, aggregating $18,074, against the Hoffman House in favor of Edward S. Stokes as receiver, growing out of the litigation which has been going on for several years past. On Jan. 20, 1898, Mr. Stokes obtained a judgment for $27,677 against the Hoffman House, which was appealed.

BOSTON, June 10 -- The line of the Boston Elevated Railway Company from Dudley Street, Roxbury, to Sullivan Square, Charlestown, about five miles in length, was opened to the public to-day. The management found themselves face to face with the problem of handling nearly 25,000 passengers at each terminal.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The thanks of all friends of "liberty, equality, and fraternity" are due to the Rev. Howard Wilbur Ennis of the Reformed Church of Brooklyn, corner of Bedford Avenue and Clymer Street, for his Christian courage in inviting the children of the Beth-Elohim Synagogue to be the guests of his school in the annual Sunday school parade of the Brooklyn Sunday School Association.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am a lawyer, and I write to thank you for your discussion in editorials and elsewhere recently of the condition of courts in New York, the frequency of perjury, and the immunity it enjoys.

Actors and churchmen attended, in large numbers, the second annual meeting of the Actors' Church Alliance, which was held at Berkeley Lyceum last evening. Business and pleasure were mixed in the evening's programme. Bishop Potter presiding over all, announcing both the musical numbers and the reports of the officers of the organizatlon.

CHICAGO, June 10. -- Melville Chester, Jr., of Boston is under arrest on a charge of forgery. Twenty-five charges are said to have been made against him. He was arrested this afternoon by Detective Sergts. Bock and De Sousa of the Central Station, after a chase of over six blocks in the down-town district, and was finally captured in the courtyard of the Auditorium Annex after he had given the detectives a desperate fight.

Schedules in bankruptcy of the Deer Park Brewing Company of Port Jervis, N.Y., against which creditors filed a petition here on April 15, were filed yesterday by Kuft Rudolph Sternberg. The schedules are incomplete, the valuation of several items in the assets not being given. The total liabilities are $208,516, of which $859 are for wages to employes, $77,347 are secured by realty mortgages, chattel mortgages, and conditional bills of sale, and $130,310 are unsecured.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- In response to messages from the President, sent out after a talk with the Secretary of State, all the members of the Cabinet now in this city assembled at the White House at 8 o'clock this evening. There were six of them present. They came in eveningdress.

It must seem strange to New Yorkers that there should be a question in New Jersey whether a company operating a trolley line has such an interest in the highway over which it passes as is taxable as real estate. Still more strange does it seem that the question should only just now have come up for judicial decision.

Mayor Van Wyck yesterday appointed four City Magistrates in compliance with Justice Gaynor's writ of mandamus. Democrats were named to succeed Republicans, and the appointees will hold office until Jan. 1, 1902, when their successors, who are to be elected this Fall, will take office.

Greene Taylor have sold for the Central Realty, Bond, and Trust Company the plot on the south side of Fifty-third Street, 28 feet west of Madison Avenue, 79.6 by 100. The buyer, Charles Buek, will erect thereon three American basement dwellings. The price paid for the plot is reported at $250,000.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage, except in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes payment of the mortgage.

-- By offering policies on specially advantageous terms to total abstainers, one of our great insurance companies has set an example which undoubtedly will be followed in time by all its competitors, and thus there will be brought to bear upon the general public another of the thoroughly practical influences to which the cause of temperance has owed so much of its recent advance.

LONDON, June 10 -- Money was very easy to-day, but there was little doing. The movements of the next few days will probably be slight, apart from those connected with the Stock Exchange settlement, pending which there is little disposition for fresh speculation.
CHICAGO, June 10 -- New York exchange was quoted at 5 cents' discount to-day. Money for call and time loans brought 4 1/2 @ 5 per cent.

Louis Waldron, proprietor of "Little Coney," at 216 West One Hundred and Tenth Street, who was arrested several times by the police on various charges, has assumed the offensive, and is going to fight the entire police force, and ask the Governor to dismiss Commissioner Murphy for alleged hounding and persecution.

As the result of an alleged attempt to steal an iron shutter, an unidentified man died in the Hudson Street Hospital from a fractured skull last midnight. A companion Who was with him escaped, and the efforts of the police to locate him have been futile.

TRENTON, N.J., June 10. -- The Supreme Court to-day decided the case of the Mayor and Aldermen of Newark against the North Jersey Street Railway Company, holding that street railway franchises in New Jersey are taxable as real estate, thus adding to the State revenues several millions annually.

It was a foregone conclusion that any effort from the outside to end the war in South Africa would fail. It is doubtful whether even those English politicians who have most steadily opposed the war, Mr. JOHN MORLEY, for instance, would countenance the project of referring it, or anything connected with it, to any foreigner.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 10 -- The second annual golf match between the graduates and undergraduates of Princeton for the cup presented by C.C. Cuyler, 74; resulted in a victory for the undergraduates by a score of 19 to 17. The teams and scores:

"The papers have been marrying me to widows and heiresses for five years," remarked Senator Chauncey M. Depew yesterday when a TIMES reporter called his attention to current rumors that he was engaged to a widow now abroad.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 10 -- Joseph W. Kay of Brooklyn, Past Department Commander of New York and Chairman of the Committee on Legislation of the National Encampment, Grand Army of the Republic, said to the representative of The Associated Press to-day:

BRISTOL, R.I., June 10 -- As many riveters as could conveniently work without getting in one another's way began operations this morning at the Herreshoff works riveting the plates which are to replace the buckled section of the Constitution's mainmast. The steelworkers, a few minutes after the plant opened, were energetically hammering away with a diligence which promised well for rapid completion of the work.

It is odd, in some ways, to see such papers as The Brooklyn Eagle and THE NEW YORK TIMES, Gold Democrat, encouraging Senator McLAURIN of South Carolina. McLAURIN is a high protectionist, while those papers used to be for tariff reform in the Cleveland days. And the tariff issue seems to be assuming shape again. -- The Springfield Republican.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 10 -- Vassar College chapel presented a charming scene to-night when Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler of Columbia University delivered an address before the Phi Beta Kappa Society. The speaker was given an enthusiastic reception by the students who thronged the chapel.

GALES FERRY, Conn., June 10 -- The 'Varsity crew went out to-night at 7 o'clock and covered the four-mile course against time. The time is given out as around 22 minutes, and, as was the case Saturday night, the coaches are not pleased with the work of the men.

At the election of the Merchants' Association of New York yesterday D. Le Roy Dresser, head of the silk and hosiery commission house of Dresser Co., was unanimously elected to the Presidency to succeed William F. King, who declined another term, as being no longer able to discharge the duties of the office.

We fear that Police Commissioner MURPHY is not so well informed as he ought to be in the matter of which he complains to the Civil Service Commission or the city. He is an old gentleman whose active years have been passed in occupations to which the merit system is unrelated.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., June 11 -- Pennsylvania closed its baseball season to-day with a game with Columbia, the Quakers winning by the score of 20 to 0. The game was absolutely devoid of interest and many spectators left before it was completed. It was alumni day at Pennsylvania, and one of the largest crowds of the season was in attendance.

LONDON, June 11 -- The Anglo-American trap shoot opened to-day at the Middlesex Gun Club range. The weather was bright and there was a fair attendance, including many ladies. A high, gusty wind prevented good records.

ANSONIA, Conn., June 11 -- Twenty workmen have been crowding around the windows of the machine room of the Farrel Foundry and Machine Company in Ansonia to-day, claiming they are locked in and cannot get out. They were brought here last night to take the places of the Strikirg machinists and roll turners, 500 of whom are out.

ORANGE, N.J., June 11 -- In the second day's play in the annual New Jersey State championship lawn-tennis tournament, on the courts of the Orange Lawn Tennis Club, at Mountain Station, to-day, the first round was completed, with the exception of the match between F.B. Alexander and Lawrence Grant, and one match was played in the second round.

Patrick Coyle, a parricide, was himself found murdered at the side door of the Hickory Cafe, at Ninth Avenue and Sixteenth-Street at 3 o'clock yesterday morning. He had been stabbed in the throat, and the knife had severed the jugular vein. Coyle had only recently been released after serving a long sentence for killing his father, Matthew Coyle, a Grand Army veteran, and the police had accused him of many other crimes.

The closing hours yesterday, in Judge Newburger's Court of General Sessions, of Samuel J. Kennedy's third effort to disprove the charge against him of murdering Emeline C. Reynolds, were full of unexpected happenings.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 11 -- The great society event of the year in Princeton, the annual commencement reception of the sophomore class to the graduating class, took place to-night in the Casino, which was beautifully decorated for the occasion. Dancing continued until a late, or, rather, an early hour, to the strains of Zimmerman's Annapolis Band and orchestra.

WILLIAMSPORT, Penn., June 11 -- Sheriff H.W. Osler to-day evicted the families of two of the locked-out miners of the State Line and Sullivan Railroad Company's colliery at Bernice, Sullivan County. No show of force attended the eviction on either side. The goods of the evicted miners were placed in the street and subsequently carried by their owners to the homes of friends at Mildred.

There will be at least one wedding in town to-day -- that of Miss Robbins and Dr. Theodore S. Hart -- which will attract society and which will bring a great many people in from the out-of-town resorts. In the suburbs there will be the Country Festival at Springhurst, near Dobbs Ferry, in aid of Zion Church.
PHILADELPHIA, Penn., June 11 -- A high official of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company to-night practically admitted that his company had secured control of the stock of the Pennsylvania Steel Company.

Cherry Hill is sorrowing. "Dr. Mansfield," the quaintest character of that once famous locality, has been committed to the insane pavilion of Bellevue Hospital by Magistrate Flammer, who was deaf to all considerations of local tradition.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., June 11 -- In the Superior Court to-day Rush Gates and Frank Johnson, white, and Ben Foster and Harry Mills, colored, were found guilty of burglary in the first degree. Under North Carolina law the penalty for burglary is death. All four men will be sentenced to be hanged before the term of court ends.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Mrs. McKinley's improvement to-day was less marked than it has been of late, though at a late hour to-night it was stated that, on the whole, taking the day and night through, she had a little more than held her own. The weather here to-day was very warm, and to this, it is thought, may be attributed the check on her recovery.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Some criticism of the Navy Department for deciding to place the likeness of Rear Admiral Sampson on the Santiago medal has provoked an explanation from the department that it is not to be, a "Santiago medal" at all. It is a West Indian medal, and does not commemorate the battle of Santiago, according to the official explanation.
WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Senator Quay was very much interested in the announcement that President McKinley would not be a candidate for a third term.

LONDON, June 11 -- A Blue Book was issued to-day containing the report of the Transvaal Concessions Commission. It is clear, the commission avers, that a State which has annexed another is not legally bound by any contracts made by the State which has ceased to exist, and that no court of law has jurisdiction to enforce such contracts, if the annexing State refuses to recognize them.

PHILADELPHIA, June 11 -- Without the pretense of a debate and in just forty minutes, the select council's Street Railway Committee this afternoon listened to the reading of fourteen ordinances to give franchises to new rapid transit companies, and referred them all to the council with the recommendation that they be passed.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., June 11 -- This was alumni day at Union University. Gov. Odell was present at the annual alumni dinner in Nott Memorial Hall this afternoon and made a speech that was received with cheers. After the last course had been par-taken of, Toastmaster W.H. McElroy, 61, called on President A.V.V. Raymond of the college to make an address.

Two Customs Inspectors from Surveyor Croft's staff seized thirty-three uncut pigeon-blood rubies, valued at about 19,000f., ($3,800) at the Grand Union Hotel yesterday afternoon. The owner of the jewels was M. Wacrenier, on whose person they were found by the Inspectors.
PHILADELPHIA, June 11. -- The annual convention of the Southern Industrial Association was formally opened in Horticultural Hall this morning, and will continue in session until Friday.

Just as the slips of the afternoon drawing were being distributed to the east side circuit of policy shops by the "runners" raids were made on seven of the small rooms in which a pamphlet known as the "Policy Players' Dream Book" is the only volume consulted.
LONDON, June 11 -- Edmund Archibald Stuart, Earl of Moray, is dead.

TUSCALOOSA, Ala., June 11.-- Gov. Willlam J. Samford died at 10:55 o'clock to-night. The Governor rested fairly well last night and maintained his own during the day. This evening, however, he grew worse. His entire family was at the bedside.

PITTSBURG, Penn., June 11 -- Mathewson was the magnet that drew one of the largest crowds of the year, in spite of threatening rain, this afternoon to the baseball park for the scheduled game between New York and Pittsburg. His appearance in the box for the New Yorks had been discussed for the past forty-eight hours, until the "fans" were at a keen edge.

BUFFALO, N.Y., June, 11 -- The National Editorial Association began its sixteenth annual convention in the Temple of Music to-day. This association includes editors from all parts of the United States. Hundreds of delegates were present, most of them accompanied by members of their families.

Picturesqueness, mixed with pathos, marked the thirty-fifth anniversary of the Home for Incurables, Third Avenue, between One Hundred and Eighty-first and One Hundred and Eighty-fourth Streets, yesterday. Bishop Potter and Senator Depew, who were among the speakers, however, provided a compensating share of humor to the occasion, both indulging in good-natured banter that occasioned much laughter.

PHILADELPHIA, June 11 -- There was a much more cheerful feeling in the market to-day than for several days past. This was due to strong inside support. Union Traction, against which great pressure has been brought on account of adverse State and municipal legislation, was fairly steady around 25 1/2, and a general improvement in the street railway family benefited the whole market.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., June 11 -- There were lively interchanges at the Council meeting at Bradley Beach last night. Both Rev. Mr. Hayter and Mr. Benner, rival claimants for the same seat, were in attendance, the courts not having as yet decided between them. The trouble arose over the tickets which are given to those carting gravel on the street improvements now going on.
The retirement of Mr. WILLIAM F. KING from the Presidency of the Merchants' Association is a fitting occasion to recognize the great service which he has rendered to this community.

Louis S. Hays, thirty-four years old, the son of Simon Hays, a wealthy real estate operator living at 14 East One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street, yesterday assaulted and attempted to rob George F. Mellert, sixty-nine years old, a bank messenger for the Bronx Borough Bank of East One Hundred and Seventy-seventh Street.

From an observation of reform movements in this city extending over many years we deduce and firmly hold the conclusion that the chief danger that threatens them is imbecility. Through other perils they have often passed safely -- that one is always fatal.

-- We find it more than difficult to understand why the Navy Department's Board of Award should have recommended to Secretary LONG that a picture of the Oregon be placed on the Santiago medal, but it is very easy indeed to understand why the Secretary has refused to take the board's advice and has ordered it to try again.

BENJAMIN TURNER, a prominent brick manufacturer of Kingston, N.Y., died there yesterday, aged seventy-one years. He was formerly a storekeeper for the Delaware and Hudson Canal Company and accumulated a large fortune.
WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The following is the Weather Bureau's weekly summary of general crop conditions:
DEXTER, Kan., June 11 -- Cashier Watkins of the local bank committed suicide to-day. The bank is closed pending action of the Bank Commissioner.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 11 -- Hamilton Storrs Bigelow, a Harvard freshman of Buffalo, N.Y., was run over by a fire engine and instantly killed at 9 o'clock to-night. A fire was found by one of the Harvard professors among a pile of boards near the Harvard architectural building. An alarm was rung in, but before the firemen responded Prof. Hollis and students had put out the fire.

NEWARK, N.J., June 11 -- Henry Sohaub, a barber of this place, murdered his wife and six-weeks-old daughter this afternoon, and cut his own throat. Then he wrapped a couple of towels around his throat and walked to a saloon half a block away, where he bought a bottle of whisky. Next he returned to the house and sat down and proceeded to drink it.
NEWPORT, June 11 -- All the improvements at Spouting Rock Beach have been completed, and the first of next month the place will be opened for the season.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The aphorism "What are you going to do about it?" Is so familiar to all New Yorkers as a synonym for "Crokerism," as it exists in the metropolis, that when I read such an excellent article on "Some Requirements of City Railway Travel," as that published in your issue of to-day, I am not surprised that the writer signing himself "Mantup" lives in Brooklyn.
INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., June 11 -- Dr. Joseph M. Britton of Newark, Green County, has filed suit in the Circuit Court in Bloomington, this State, against sixteen men, charging them with whitecapping him.

The four Baltimoreans, who since October last have been marooned on the phosphate island of Navassa, in the Caribbean Sea, off the coast of Trinidad, arrived in New York on the Atlas Line steamship Andes yesterday afternoon. They were James A. Woodward and W.T. Pumphrey, white, and John Hill and John A. Bell, negroes.

BOSTON, June 11 -- The International Jubilee Convention of the Young Men's Christian Association was opened to-day. Although the first formal meeting of the series, which will continue from to-day until Sunday, was not held until 3 o'clock, a business meeting which began at 11 o'clock saw nearly every member in his place.
LONDON, June 11 -- Money was plentiful and cheap to-day.

BOSTON, June 11 -- The most striking incident of the Young Men's Christian Association Convention occurred late in the day in the circulation of a protest signed by Bishop Mallalieu and others, protesting against the use of the Museum of Fine Arts to-morrow night for a reception to the delegates and friends, tendered by the Trustees of the Museum and the Women's Auxiliaries of the Massachusetts and Rhode Island associations.

WEST NEWTON, Penn., June 11 -- Not a practical miner in this district believes that one of the sixteen men entombed in the Port Royal Mine by the explosion last night is still alive. There is no fire in the mine, to judge from appearances at the pit mouth, but the force of the explosion was so great that none of the men, so the miners say, could have survived the shock.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 11 -- Over 2,000 persons witnessed on the Vassar College campus this afternoon the most picturesque and most interesting class day exercises in the history of the college. The members of the graduating class, 142 in number, were seated on a monster stage built on the campus northeast of the main building.
BOSTON, June 11 -- Money at the Clearing House loaned to-day at 2 per cent and New York funds sold at par. Exchanges, $24,116,226; balances, $1,961,465.

BOSTON, June 11 -- The action brought by Clarence H. Venner of this city to restrain the absorption of the Boston and Montana and the Butte and Boston Mining Companies by the Amalgamated Copper Company, was heard in the Supreme Court, before Judge Knowlton, to-day, but decision was reserved.

The special convention of the National Metal Trades Association, which opened in the Gilsey House yesterday, to take action on the strike of the machinists, put itself on record before adjournment for the day as absolutely and unalterably opposed to any further dealings with the Machinists' Union.

The President has no reason to be ungrateful to Gen. GROSVENOR. It was Gen. GROSVENOR who referred to the tradition against a third canvass for the Presidency of the United States as an outworn superstition and ventured to predict that Mr. MCKINLEY would be re-elected in spite of it.

PETERSBURG, Ky., June 11 -- A runaway accident occurred near here to-day, in which one person was killed and two others were seriously injured. Lystra Smith, his wife, and daughter were seated in a vehicle descending a steep hill. The team of horses attached to the wagon became frightened and plunged madly down the slope.

ROME, June 11 -- The report cabled to the United States that the Pope is again ill is without foundation. His Holiness is well, and yesterday granted audiences to the Belgian and Dominican Ministers. To-day he had a long conference with Cardinal Gibbons.

The number and earnestness of the complaints we have received since a recent article upon "The Law's Delay" show at least the depth and extent of the public interest in the subject. There is, it seems, a widespread belief that the manner in which justice is administered according to law constitutes a public grievance.

There appeared at the Sheepshead Bay race track yesterday morning a sturdy pony-built race horse who galloped under the direction of John E. Madden with one of the Madden stable boys on his back, and who, though he did not gallop fast enough to attract any particular attention, still commanded notice by the style in which he moved.
BERLIN, June 11 -- The Baireuth programme for the approaching season of Wagnerian performances has been finally settled, and the operas selected, with the dates for presentation, are the following:

To the Editor of The New York Times: So much has been said of late in your columns in adverse criticism of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union that no doubt many readers not familiar with its purposes and work are forming unjust opinions of the organization. In the interest of fairness I beg a little space for the other side.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE TIMES of June 9, under the heading, "Methods of Christian Science," a contributor quotes from a book printed in London in 1837, showing that "disorders like 'Christian Science' are not a new affliction." Quotations from a much older book having a more direct bearing on the serio-comic "Science" may be of interest.

An event of some interest in the outside market yesterday was the introduction of two new stocks -- American Locomotive and United States Cotton Duck. Otherwise, however, the day's business was about as dull as any recently recorded. Prices in some parts of the list showed improvement, but few of the net changes were more than fractional.

One fact which should be borne in mind in addition to the consideration of railway rate stability (as this is indicated in the centralization of railroad control) is that there is not in progress any of that reckless building of new lines which has done so much in the past to precipitate trouble.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., June 11 -- George J. Gould's crack Lakewood polo team conceded the Devon players five goals to-day in the match for the Valentine Challenge Cup on the Devon field and was beaten by the score of 15 goals to 8 3/4. The visitors were defeated in actual play, the home team scoring 10 goals, while the Lakewood quartet only managed to score 9, losing a Quarter goal on a safety by "Lairy" Waterbury.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 11 -- Mystery surrounds the alleged kidnapping yesterday and the arrest to-day of the alleged kidnapper of Eddie Ross, thirteen years old, son of William Ross, who is a second cousin of the father of Charlie Ross, the boy kidnapped from Philadelphia years ago.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., June 11 -- The Grand Jury this afternoon found an indictment against Mabel L. Burt, the former Smith College student, on eleven counts for the larceny of money and jewelry. She was arraigned before Judge Pierce, and on motion of counsel waived the reading of the indictment and pleaded not guilty, retracting her plea of guilty in the lower court.

CINCINNATI, June 11 -- A combination of the piano manufacturers, embracing the entire output of the country, is, in process of organization. Marc A. Blumenberg, head of The Musical Courier Company of New York, is in the city promoting the scheme. He claims that the purpose of the combine is to reduce the selling expenses, which are now $75 for every piano made.

At the annual meeting of the stockholders of the Farmers' Loan and Trust Company yesterday, the following Directors were elected: Samuel Sloan, Moses Taylor Pyne, Robert C. Boyd, Robert F. Ballantine, Cleveland H. Dodge, David H. King, Jr., John L. Riker, W.S. Bogert, and Edwin S. Marston.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 12 -- Syracuse University's commencement exercises were held this morning, when 162 seniors of the four colleges were graduated. The address of the occasion was made by William De Witt Hyde, President of Bowdoin College. His subject was "The Cardinal Virtues: Wisdom, Justice, Temperance, and Courage."

The Rev. Herman P. Faust, the converted Jewish rabbi, who has been doing missionary work among the Jews of the east side, made a reply yesterday to the Rev. Dr. A. Woodruff Halsey's explanation of the reasons why the New York Presbytery had refused further pecuniary aid. Mr. Faust said:

ORANGE, N.J., June 12 -- The second round in the annual New Jersey State championship lawn tennis tournament on the courts of the Orange Lawn Tennis Club at Mountain Station was completed to-day. To-morrow the semi-finals will be played between W.A. Lamed and Richard Stevens and Calhoun Cragin and F.B. Alexander.

PHILADELPHIA, June 12 -- With orders to sit until midnight, if necessary. Common Council passed sixteen traction ripper bills to-day, and thus completely banished any hopes Albert L. Johnson may have ever had of entering this city with his three-cent car lines.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The story told by the Rev. Van Brookhuizen is not very good reading for anyone. The state of affairs in the Transvaal is, no doubt, bad, and on account of bringing them to the camps many women and children are suffering. This is a condition of things brought about by the conduct of the Boers.

RICHMOND, Va., June 12 -- Virginia's Constitutional Convention opened here today, while the temperature was higher than that of any other city in the country. This fact did not prevent that body from being ushered into existence with a highly interesting debate, in which Senator Daniel and many of the ablest members of the convention took part.
The annual statement of the Anaconda Mining Company, filed at Butte, Mont., was published in Wall Street yesterday, and showed, among other things, as follows:

PRAGUE, Bohemia, June 12 -- Emperor Francis Joseph arrived here to-day for a visit of five days. It is the first visit he has made Bohemia during the last ten years, and he is now here in the interest of German-Czech conciliation. His Majesty is accompanied by a suite of 300 persons.

BUFFALO, June 12. -- That woman is doing her full share toward making the PanAmerican Exposition a success, is evident to every visitor here. What she has done officially the visitor sees only on reaching the Exposition grounds, but the moment he alights in one of the railway stations, he sees that she is encouraging the big fair with her presence.

PHILADELPHIA, June 12 -- The rapid transit scare has somewhat lessened in effect upon the local market, and the street railway family is regaining lost ground. Tne rest of the market is better in sympathy. Union Traction started in to-day at 25 1/4 and steadily moved up to 26 3/8. Philadelphia Traction and Electric and People's fours were up to 94 and 95 respectively.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The debilitating effect of the shipyard strikes upon the work on the vessels now under construction for the navy is summed up in the latest statement from the Naval Bureau of Construction, showing the degree of completion upon the various craft on the first of the present month, as compared with their standing on the first of May.

POUGHKEEPSIE, June 12 -- The University of Pennsylvania crews arrived this afternoon, their shells and other effects having arrived in the morning. Josh Ward lost no time in putting his athletes in mind of the object of their visit to Poughkeepsie, and after dinner set them to work. The oarsmen, themselves unloaded their boats.

Frazier Gilman, the half-brother of the late millionaire tea merchant of Bridgeport, George Francis Gilman, reached this city yesterday from Georgia to confer with certain of the full-blood relatives with a view to settling the dissensions among the various members of the family upon the subject of the deceased merchant's estate.

According to Washington dispatches the returns of the geological survey just completed show that all records were broken in the production of coal in the United States in 1900, and that the United States still leads the coal-producing countries of the world.
SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., June 12 -- A number of appointments and changes are announced as likely to be made in the Newark Catholic Diocese. Among them are the following:

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., June 12 -- The commencement exercises of Seton Hall College were held here to-day. Bishop-elect O'Connor, with the Rev. John A. Stafford, President of the college; the Rev. John A. Westman, the Vice President; the Faculty of the institution, several visiting Church dignitaries, and the Rev. George Doane O'Neill, acting Chancellor of the Newark Diocese, occupied seats on the porch of the main college building.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 12 -- Frauds the extent of which neither army nor police officials have yet determined have been discovered in the Quartermaster's and Commissary Departments here. Two civilians are already under arrest and several other persons, including some army officers, are said to be under surveillance.

The auditorium of the Educational Alliance, Jefferson Street and East Broadway was crowded last night by an audience assembled to hear the purposes of L'Alliance Israelite Universelle. David Blaustein presided, and in his opening remarks referred to the fact that the organization is representative of all shades of the Jewish belief.

The Democratic City Convention to nominate the candidates for Mayor, and other municipal offices will, be held on Oct. 3 at 7:30 o'clock in the Grand Central Palace. There will be approximately 631 delegates, representing the five boroughs of the city.

Representatives of organized labor last night took the initial steps to secure the adoption of amendments to the State Constitution recognizing the legality of the laws making eight hours constitute a day's work and of the statute providing for the payment of the prevailing rate of wages.

With simple but impressive services the last tribute to the Rev. Dr. Maltbie B. Babcook was paid yesterday at the Brick Presbyterian Church, where a congregation assembled that taxed the capacity of the building. Mrs. Babcock, the widow of the dead pastor, was present. The platform was banked with roses, wreaths, and palms, and large wreaths of rhododendron were placed at intervals about the gallery.
The stockholders of the Atlanta Home Insurance Company have voted down a proposition to reduce the capital stock of the company from $500,000 to $200,000.

By some private investigation in a divorce case which was before him, Justice Giegerich managed to surprise the parties concerned and unearth what he believed to be evidence of collusion. As a result, he refused to give the plaintiff a divorce.

George H. Corey, the Commissioner in this city appointed by the Supreme Court of Montana to take testimony regarding the sufficiency of the Delaware Surety Company, brought his hearings to a close yesterday.

BOSTON, June 12 -- Mechanics Hall was filled to-day at the various sessions of the Young Men's Christian Association international convention. In opening the convention this morning. President William E. Dodge implied repudiation on behalf of the convention, of the remarkable circular issued yesterday by a few members of the association condemning the Boston Museum of Fine Arts as an improper place for the young people to meet in at a reception.

The convention of the National Metal Trades Association, which began its sessions in the Gilsey House on Tuesday, adjourned sine die yesterday afternoon, and most of the delegates left the city last evening. The association, which had a membership of 163 firms when the convention began, has now a membership of 320 firms, all pledged to fight the demands of the machinists for a nine-hour work day with ten hours' pay.

CAMP TOWNSEND, Peekskill, June 12 -- The Eighth reluctantly broke camp at Monegan this morning and returned to Camp Townsend, where they will be quartered the remainder of the week. It would have pleased them better to have remained in the field, for Camp Townsend is too much like a military school.

Otto Gemunder, youngest son of the late George Gemunder, the famous maker of violins, died in the Brooklyn Home for Consumptives, Kingston Avenue and Douglass Street, on Monday night. He was thirty years, old. Up to the time of his father's death, which occurred in Astoria, two years ago, Otto Gemunder was his constant companion.

W.E.D. Stokes, the millionaire builder and contractor whose new apartment hotel at Seventy-fourth Street and the Boulevard had no sooner been delivered from a strike of the bricklayers than it became involved in a complicated strike of other trades, visited the Board of Walking Delegates at their meeting yesterday to see what could be done.

There was not a quorum of members of the Committee of Fifteen present yesterday afternoon at the meeting which had been so extensively advertised and at which it was expected would be determined the future policy of the organization. The two members who have been regarded as the chief objectors to the methods of Justice Jerome -- Charles Stewart Smith and Jacob H. Schiff -- were not present.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The news of the adoption of the Platt amendment by the Cuban Constitutional Convention was received with genuine gratification here. The Administration officials all along have felt confident that its ratification would be accomplished when the Cubans realized that this Government was firm in its attitude regarding the amendment, and that its acceptance would be necessary before the United States would consent to withdraw its supervision from the island.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 12 -- A sharp debate was precipitated in the Reformed Synod here this afternoon, near the close of its session, by a proposition totally unexpected. The Committee on Overtures reported that it had received a memorial asking that the teaching of the Heidelberg Catechism in the churches be made optional instead of mandatory.

Denials of Pennsylvania Railroad officials that the railroad had bought control of the Pennsylvania Steel Company were regarded in the financial district in this city yesterday as technical, it being asserted on what purported to be inside authority that if the purchase had not been made by the railroad itself, it had been made by interests in control of the railroad.

BERLIN, June 12 -- Contrary to newspaper statements that a serious hitch has occurred in Peking regarding the indemnity question, it is asserted in authoritative quarters in Berlin that the negotiations are making "satisfactory progress." and that there is no doubt of an agreement being reached between the Ministers of the powers themselves and between them and the Chinese plenipotentiaries, even if the negotiations should be prolonged for a week or two more.

Max Marx has sold through Warren Skillin to Henry R.C. Watson the following properties: No. 34 White Street, north-east corner of Church Street. 25 by 55; also the six-story building 289 Bleecker Street, 28.3 by 75; also the five-Story apartment house 460 Manhattan Avenue, 27 by 94.10; also a tract of about four acres on Palisade and independence Avenues, in the Riverdale section.

The stock market yesterday was one largely of specialties, though throughout there was a strong undertone and a fair demand for good stocks. The day, however, was distinctively one of "features," in which the independent steel and iron stocks were most prominent. Colorado Fuel and Iron, for instance, rose at one time over 15 points, while Tennessee Coal, and Iron advanced 4 1/2. American Car and Foundry 2, and Republic Iron and Steel 1 1/2.

HALIFAX, N.S., June 12 -- Disabled over two weeks ago, far south of the track of ocean travel, the British steamer Border Knight, bound from Cape Verde Islands for New York in ballast, drifted and sailed 400 miles north in a zig-zag course and was then picked up by the Spanish steamer Durance, bound from Philadelphia for Billbao, and towed another 300 miles to Halifax, arriving this afternoon with tail shaft broken and propeller gone.

At the annual luncheon of the alumni of Columbia University, held yesterday in Alumni Memorial Hall, in dedication of the new building. President Seth Low announced an anonymous gift to the university of $100,000 for the purpose of founding a Chinese department, for the study of Chinese history, language, customs, and manners.

Just a year ago wheat began to advance until a rise of 20 cents per bushel had been scored on a crop scare emanating from the Northwest, where drouth and scorching weather did enormous damage. Drenching rains at harvest time caused further deterioration. Added to this the Winter wheat gathered from the great fields of the Central States amounted barely to half an average crop.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The attitude of THE TIMES on the anticanteen law is right, as is its position on most questions of public interest. Permit me herewith to add a word of testimony to the many others, and incidentally to present a phase of the deleterious results of the law, which applies solely to the service in the Philippines.

The decision of the Supreme Court gave Congress discretionary power over the economic status of our dependencies, but not over the personal conditions of their inhabitants. Said Justice BROWN, it does not follow that they are "in the matter of personal rights unprotected by the provisions of our Constitution, and subject to the merely arbitrary control of Congress.

The strain of the long engagement of Miss Ethel Barrymore in "Captain Jinks of the Horse Marines," at the Garrick Theatre, is beginning to tell on this young aspiring actress. For the past week it has been evident that the vocal cords of Miss Barrymore's throat have been greatly affected, her lines being spoken with a huskiness that at times made it almost impossible to understand her.

On account of the commencement exercises at Columbia yesterday the morning practice of the crews was omitted, but the 'Varsity eight rowed in the afternoon in the usual order, except that Eyer took the place at bow of Jackson, who is ill with a cold. The freshmen also practiced in the afternoon, but in fours and not as an eight.
