The apparent failure of a Central Office detective to serve a warrant issued by Justice Jerome for a "wardman" of the Fifth Street Police Station, charged with felony, aroused the ire of the Justice and the representatives of the District Attorney's office last night. The warrant was issued at 3 o'clock.

William O'Neill, sixty years old, a veteran of the civil war, member of the Grand Army of the Republic, and also a noted criminal, whose picture is in the Rogues' Gallery, was arrested at his home, 415 Canal Street, by Capt. Foody of the Macdougal Street Station yesterday on suspicion of being concerned in the murder of Patrick Coyle the parricide.

A petition in bankruptcy was presented for filing at the office of the Clerk of the United States District Court just before closing hours yesterday afternoon by Marie Dressier, the actress. Emanuel Friend is Miss Dressier's attorney. Her liabilities are said to be about $14,000, and her available assets are given in the petition as $12 cash in bank.

In the presence of a large gathering or notable naval officers, naval attaches, and engineers, the Holland submarine torpedo boat Fulton was launched yesterday afternoon at Lewis Nixon's Crescent Ship Yard, Elizabethport, N.J. The Fulton is the latest improved pattern of the Holland, the first submarine torpedo boat launched and sold by the Holland Torpedo Boat Company to the Government.
MANILA, June 12 -- Lieut. Henry T. Mitchell of the Forty-first Regiment has been arrested and will be tried by court-martial on the charge of embezzling at Bacolor $227 of the public funds.

The marriage of Dr. Theodore Stuart Hart and Miss Mary Ayres Robbins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Wolcott Robbins, was celebrated yesterday afternoon at 4 o'clock in the South Reformed Church, Thirty-eighth Street and Madison Avenue, by the Rev. Edward H. Robbins of Baltimore, uncle of the bride.

The People's Municipal League campaign of 1890 cut a wide swath, and grew in promise and potency up to the week preceding the election Tammany felt that it was beaten, and the upholders of the principle that the office of Mayor is a public trust were confident that Mr. SCOTT would be elected.

Each day now the proportion in New York of fashionable people grows smaller. The long-deferred hot wave which arrived yesterday drove every one out of town who could go and was not obliged to be here on account of important social engagements. There were five weddings, but only one of these was a large affair.

To the Editor of The New fork Times: The letter of "A Practicing Lawyer" in Sunday's TIMES, which you have aptly headed " A Plea for the Justices," is one with which most practicing lawyers will heartily agree, except in so far as it ascribes all of the congestion of the court calendars to lagging lawyers and lax legislation.

The new Anti-Policy Society, of which Capt. F. Norton Goddard is President, continued its raiding of policy shops yesterday afternoon, its corps of detectives descending on four places scattered over the east side of the city from Twenty-ninth Street to Harlem.
NEWPORT, June 12. -- Bowling is to be quite a fad among the women of the cottage colony this season, and a complete and handsome alley will be built here.

On the next departure of the North German Lloyd steamship Kaiser Wilhelm der Grosse, at 10 A.M. Tuesday, June 25, from Pier 52, North River, and of the Hamburg-American steamsnip Auguste Victoria, at 10 A.M. on Thursday, June 20, from Hamburg Pier, Hcboken, N.J., the North German Lloyd and the Hamburg-American Line will adopt measures to obviate the complaints frequently made with reference to the enormous crowds visiting the piers and steamships on their departure.

New Yorkers can revel in strawberries throughout the season at reasonable prices if growers will cultivate the fruit as Mr. Powell of Briarcliff Manor gave directions at the meeting of the Horticultural Society of New York at the New York Botanical Garden yesterday afternoon.
Discussing the condition of the iron and steel trades, the Iron Age will to-day say:

LEXINGTON, Ky., June 12 -- A threatened disruption of the American Secular Union is the result of the Western members making a combination in Cincinnati during the recent congress there and defeating Eugene Macdonald of New York for the Presidency. They elected J.B. Wilson of Cincinnati President.
LONDON, June 12 -- The conditions governing the money market were not altered to-day.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The announcement in your columns yesterday of the especially melancholy death of Mr. Louis Stern, late of the Consular Service at Bamberg, Germany, has put me under a constraint that I cannot resist to make the incident the text of an address, through your courtesy, to the public.

BUFFALO, June 12 -- Secretary of War Elihu Root was shown The Associated Press despatch from Havana to-night, announcing the adoption of the Platt amendment by the Cuban Constitutional Convention. He said:

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The wires at the White House were kept busy last night and to-day with messages to the President from persons in various parts of the country, commending him for his announcement concerning a third term. They were all in symapthy with the President's action, and it is understood that some of the messages came from Democrats who are personally very friendly to the President.

LONDON, June 12 -- London seldom had a finer spectacle than was witnessed on the Horse Guards' parade this morning, when King Edward presented medals to 3,000 soldier participants in the South African campaign. The great square was lined with Guards, drawn from the various regiments. In the centre of the ground was a purple-covered dais surmounted by an Indian tent with silver corner poles.
Besides the motor-paced attraction at the Vailsburg board track, Newark, on Sunday, there are two big professional events and three races for the amateur riders, Over 100 riders have entered so far.
Harry B. Smith has been engaged to write the lyrics for John J. McNally's new vaudeville farce, "The Rogers Brothers in Washington."

Thirty-seven women from nine clubs in the metropolitan district have entered for the open tournament to begin to-day on the links of the Essex County Club at Orange, N.J. The competition will be a three-day event, and the match this morning will be an eighteen-hole qualifying round, from which three sets of eight will be picked in order of scores to continue at match play for three trophies.

Cries for help from a drowning boy caused commotion among a lot of boy swimmers at Toole's dock, on the North River and One Hundred and Twenty-sixth Street, late yesterday, but the first to take action was ten-year-old Winn Romaine of 100 1/2 West One Hundred and Thirtieth Street.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage, except in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes payment of the mortgage.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., June 12 -- The Gentlemen's Driving and Field Club of Monmouth County informally celebrated the opening of the club's new race course, Elkwood Park, to-day. Many road drivers of New York, whose trotters and pacers, have gained more or less renown on the Harlem River speedway, participated in the celebration.

PITTSBURG, June 12 -- Phyle's first defeat proved disastrous for the New York baseball team. It cost the lead in the pennant race, as but one point separated the Pittsburg and New York Clubs before the game. Phyle was wild, and his lack of accuracy was fatal to his team's chance, for at least two runs came from his bases on balls.

A quick succession of unlooked-for and startling testimony and legal moves in the great battle for the life of Samuel J. Kennedy marked the last day of testimony-taking in the Staten Island dentist's third trial, before Judge Newburger, yesterday, on the charge of killing Emeline C. Reynolds.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Special Commissioner Rockaill's proposition to submit the Chinese indemnity question to The Hague tribunal, it is now learned, carries with it the adjustment of the total of the indemnity. Through a misunderstanding which appears to have been purposely created the sum of 450,000,000 taels was supposed to have been finally agreed upon by all the powers as the total of indemnity to be demanded from China.

Columbia University celebrated its one hundred and forty-seventh annual commencement yesterday in the university gymnasium. Six honorary degrees and something over 700 degrees in course were granted. About 4,000 persons obtained entrance, while nearly as many more were turned away.

Miss Julia C. Bennett, daughter of Charles C. Bennett, a wealthy resident of the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn, began an action in the Supreme Court before Justice Betts yesterday to recover $50,000 damages from the Brooklyn Heights Railroad Company for injuries received in September, 1899.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The recent criticisms of Justice William Travers Jerome by John D. Crimmins, which appeared in THE TIMES and other morning papers of the 11th inst., seem to the writer to merit a reply. The fact that the article by Mr. Crimmins was prepared lays him open to a more exacting criticism than if the statements contained therein had emanated from an interview.
BOSTON, June 12 -- Money was loaned at the Clearing House to-day at 2 per cent, and New York funds sold at par. Exchanges, $25,840,344; balances, $1,876,118.

BRISTOL, R.I., June 12 -- The plates of the splice in the Constitution's mainmast are nearly all in position, and to-day it was estimated that three more days' work would be necessary before it could be removed from the shop. Her new topmast has been shaped out by the sparmakers to a diameter and length identical with that of the spar broken in the accident.
Army. Major Morris C. Hutchins, Quartermaster, United States Volunteers, will report to the Quartermaster General at Washington for consultation on official business.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Coincident with the graduating exercises of nurses of the class of 1901 at Providence hospital to-day ground was broken for the new addition to the institution and Nurses' Home, which are to cost $300,000. A distinguished gathering of Government and District officials and prelates of the Catholic Church witnessed the exercises.
Buy the straw buckles for trimming your hat ready to put on. They are only 25 cents apiece.

PHILADELPHIA, June 12 -- Horticultural Hall was crowded to-night when Wu Ting-Fang, the Chinese Minister, addressed the Southern Industrial Convention on "American Trade with the Orient." He said in part:

An army correspondent of ours the other day used a pertinent phrase concerning the canteen controversy. It was advice to a clergyman who had been writing about drunkenness in the army to "keep out of affairs he knows nothing about."

Mrs. Cacelea Curtis, twenty-one years old, in the Lee Avenue Police Court, Williamsburg, yesterday accused her husband, to whom she has been married But six months, with having threatened her life. Curtis is forty-six years old, and lives at 1,069 Myrtle Avenue. He was a widower with six children when he married a second time.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The Washington Times publishes an interview with an unnamed prominent member of the Ways and Means Committee of the last House, in which Representative Babcock, author of the Anti-Trust Tariff bill, is made to appear to lack the courage of his opinion that the tariff ought to be reduced on products protected for the benefit of trusts.

The Brooklyn police are looking for two colored men, who at a late hour on Tuesday night brutally assaulted Herman Zimmerman, an old man employed as ticket agent at the Nostrand Avenue Station of the Fulton Street elevated road, and stole the money taken at the station during the day, amounting to $11.30. Zimmerman's injuries may prove fatal.

POUGHKEEPSIE, June 12 -- President Taylor of Vassar College gave diplomas today to 142 members of the largest graduating class in the history of the college. The commencement exercises were held in the chapel. On the platform were seated President Taylor and the members of the Faculty, and in the choir balcony were the instructors.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 12 -- To-day was commencement day of the class of 1901 of Prineeton University. The Seniors, 219 in number, received their diplomas, and the Trustees and Faculty bestowed many honorary degrees, notably the degree of Doctor of Laws upon Foster M. Voorhees, Governor of New Jersey.

BALTIMORE, June 12 -- The market today was almost a complete duplication of yesterday's record. There was an absence of activity, but the tone held fairly firm, with a mixture of gains and losses. The same two groups which held the positions of prominence were again the leaders.

In the outside market yesterday trading was somewhat broader than it was on the first two days of the week, although only a few issues were traded in to any considerable extent. Prices were somewhat irregular, but as a whole they held fairly well, and in some instances even advanced above Tuesday's final quotations.

NEWBURG, N.Y., June 13. -- The third and last day's racing in the opening meet of the Hudson and Mohawk Valley circuit was held this afternoon on the half-mile track of the Newburg Driving Association. A big crowd saw the contests. The 2:40 class, unfinished on Wednesday, was run off. Summary:

BOSTON, Mass., June 13. -- The will of Mary B. Carret of Medford, which was filed to-day provides for a public library at Trinidad, Cuba. The testatrix says that this and other legacies depend upon the recovery of the estate in Trinidad which her father owned and left. The will, says: "The library shall be called the 'Joseph Carret Library,' in memory of my beloved father.

Cyril Arthur Pearson, proprietor of the London halfpenny newspaper, The Daily Express, and of, a score of weekly and monthly publications. including Pearson's Magazine, was taken from the Oceanic of the White Star Line yesterday afternoon by a tug. His leaving was without the permission of Capt.

It looked yesterday to the visitors to Public School No. 1, at the corner of Oliver and Henry Streets, as if the domestic science problems of the city were solved. The school has a model kitchen on the top floor of its building, and there the other schools of the city which have domestic science departments gave an exhibition of what the young cooks they have trained could do.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., June 13. -- This afternoon the Leyland Line steamer Assyrian, ashore off Cape Race, swung around on the rocks with the tug Petrel on the inside. Both are now in a very critical position. The Assyrian is pounding to pieces. A northeast gale is raging, a heavy sea is making fast, and it is feared that the two vessels will become complete wrecks during the night.
LONDON, June 13 -- In the King's Bench Court to-day a compulsory winding-up order was made against the British-America Corporation.

PHILADELPHIA, June 13. -- The Philadelphia market showed strength in spots to-day, but most of the list was dull. Union Traction made a further recovery of 1/2, touching 27. Apart from that stock, the greatest interest was taken in Pennsylvania Railroad. That stock was taken freely by two houses with prominent New York connections, but the prices varied only to a slight extent.
CHICAGO, June 13. -- Mrs. Lynne Pullman to-day filed suit in the Cook County Circuit Court for divorce from George M. Pullman on the ground of desertion.

WASHINGTON, June 13. -- The attention of the Treasury Department has been attracted by a St. Petersburg dispatch to a New York paper containing some Russian comments upon the results of the imposition by the United States of a countervailing duty on Russian sugar, in consequence of the payment by Russia of what the Treasury Department has held to be a bounty on sugars exported to the United States.

BOSTON, June 13 -- The big steel mast of the Independence was unstepped at the Atlantic Works, East Boston, to-day. It now rests on the dock ready for the workmen. It has been decided to take five feet off the heel of the mast instead of four, as was originally intended. The topmast will be shortened six feet.

MANILA, June 13. -- Gen. Sumner has returned here, and has reported to Gen. Wade the failure of the negotiations for the surrender of Cailles, the insurgent leader in Laguna Province. The Fillpino apparently believes he can hold out, now that the rainy season has begun.

WASHINGTON, June 13. -- Although the "Incident" is said to have been closed by the firm and emphatic course of Rear Admiral Crowninshield in opposing an action of Assistant Secretary of the Navy Hackett that Admiral Crowninshield regarded as derogatory to his rank and station, it continues to be discussed at the Navy Department.

Prof. Truman H. Safford. Truman Henry Safford, Field Memorial Professor of Astronomy at Williams College, died at 8:30 o'clock yesterday morning at the home of his sons, 112 Broad Street, Newark, N.J. Prof. Safford suffered a stroke of paralysis seven years ago, and for the past year his health has precluded any activity in the duties of his position.

NEWARK, N.J., June 13 -- A hearing in the suit of the C.H. Venner Company of Boston and Alvin O. Geer against the Amalgamated Copper Company to restrain it from acquiring the Boston and Montana Company and Butte and Boston Company was held before Vice Chancellor Stevens in this city to-day.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Among the various blessings enjoyed (or otherwise) by the average Harlemite are the hopes of rapid transit and the Harlem Mere; the one a blissful possibility, the other a foul nuisance.

PHILADELPHIA, June 13. -- The Philadelphia rapid transit franchise fight is one of the most remarkable political conflicts in the history of Senator M.S. Quay. He is the central figure in it. For years he has been seeking an opportunity to deliver a blow to P.A.B. Widener, who has more than once unhorsed him in business and political deals.

A meeting of the Executive Committee of the Independent Democracy was held in the Astor House yesterday afternoon. The invitation extended to the organization by the Citizens' Union anti-Tammany conference to elect delegates to attend future conferences and represent the Independent Democracy was read and accepted, and Samuel Greenbaum and John P. Kelly were elected as delegates, and Messrs.

BUFFALO, June 13. -- Secretary of State Hay was the guest of honor at a dinner given this evening by the Board of Directors of the Pan-American Exposition to the National Editorial Association. One thousand covers were laid in the great dining room in Statler's Hotel, the banquet being the largest in the history of the city.

There is no topic that is of more interest in commercial circles to-day than the recent decision of the Supreme Court relating to the necessity of surrendering moneys innocently received by creditors from insolvents as a prerequisite to the proof of their claims against bankrupts. While the Western courts have been enforcing this rule for some time, it was challenged and not observed by the courts in this locality.

Mrs. Annie McGrory, wife of the ex-concert hall keeper, more familiarly known as "Billy McGlory," appeared in the Supreme Court yesterday for examination in supplementary proceedings on a judgment for $2,500 which had been obtained against her by Kenneth McLeod. "Billy" was with his wife, and as the lawyer asked her questions as to her property he frequently joined in the answer or else made an explanation.

George Bissert, a detective, of the Fifteenth Police Precinct, commanded by Capt. Diamond, was arrested yesterday morning by Detective Sergeant McNaught, upon the warrant issued Wednesday afternoon by Justice Jerome, charging the policeman with levying blackmail.

PHILADELPHIA, June 13. -- Topics of National interest were discussed at the third day's session of the Southern Industrial Convention. One of the most important of these was "The Nicaragua Canal -- Why Has it Not Been Built?" and during the debate on this question many arguments were advanced in favor of the speedy construction of the waterway.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Whenever an Englishman has a grievance he does not bear it, in silence, but gives expression to his discontent in a letter to The Times. I think if the longsuffering American public were to follow the example of the Englishman, and whenever he sees a wrong which can be righted, give expression to his conviction in a letter to THE TIMES, great good would be accomplished.

Samuel J. Kennedy's third fight for vindication of the charge of murdering Emeline C. Reynolds was ended by Lawyer Robert M. Moore yesterday with an earnest appeal to the jury for the Staten Island dentist's acquittal. Mr. Moore reviewed at length the evidence adduced by the prosecution against Kennedy; tried to show the State had proved no motive for the crime, and had absolutely failed to prove him guilty beyond a reasonable doubt.
RED TOP, Conn., June 13. -- The Harvard 'Varsity went a mile and a half down the river to-night, making two stretches of the trip, and on the way back went a half mile under the watch in 2:35.

The forty-third annual report of the Chamber of Commerce was issued yesterday. It includes the proceedings of the Chamber for the year ended April 30, 1901, together with the roll of members, list of officers and committees, the constitution and by-laws, extended trade reviews, and statistical statements of trade and finance.

SHREVEPORT, La., June 13. -- This city and vicinity have been in a state of feverish excitement and unrest since yesterday, when John Gray Foster, a prominent planter, brother-in-law of Gov. McMillin of Tennessee, was shot and killed by Prince Edwards, a negro employed on the Foster plantation, five miles east of this city.

PHILADELPHIA, June 13. -- Ex-Postmaster-General John Wanamaker to-day huried a bomb into the camp of the Quay-Ashbridge municipal ring when he sent to Mayor Samuel H. Ashbridge a letter offering him $2,500,000 for the powers, rights, and franchises granted under the fourteen rapid transit ordinances which were yesterday "ripped" through councils, and which now await the signature of the Mayor.

It is early yet, but one can keep it in mind. Look out another year for clasps on your pretty strapped slippers or sandals. In 1902 they are to take the place of buttons on some shoes, and if they are made without too much elaboration they will be likely enough worth while.

The stock market yesterday developed better all-round strength than on any day in the last few weeks, and, what is more, maintained that strength until the close of business. WASHINGTON, June 13. -- Having expected from the first that the Cubans would eventually accept the Platt amendment as it was offered, the Administration is not elated or surprised at the news from Cuba of the unconditional acceptance of the stipulations required by the United States to assure the permanency of Cuba's independence after it shall have been fully acquired.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 13 -- A bill of importance that was passed by the Legislature to-day will have important consequences. It provides that every political caucus shall have the party members enrolled according to party preference. WEST BADEN, Ind., June 14 -- The Mineral Springs Hotel was destroyed by fire early to-day. No person was injured. The fire broke out at 1 A.M. The large frame structure burned so rapidly that the guests had difficulty in escaping with their lives.

BALTIMORE, June 15. -- The market today, while enjoying only a moderate activity, developed several points of sustaining strength during the course of trading. BERLIN, June 16 -- The Boerse has had another black week. The Frankfurter Zeltung says: "Seldom have fear, distrust, and anxiety been as pronounced as during these days."

POLITICAL OUTLOOK IN AUSTRIA. -- When a few weeks ago the Austrian Canals bill was introduced in the Austrian Reichsrath it was intimated in these columns, on the strength of advices from Vienna, that the measure might so far toward healing the breach which existed between the religious and purely political factions of the Austrian Parliament, which for the last three years had made practical legislation next to impossible.

LONDON, June 16 -- We have now, with a 3 per cent, bank rate, probably reached the lowest point of the year. Money is much below that figure in the open market, where lending has been done some days at 1 2/4 per cent. or less for week to week advances. Discount was also almost 2 1/2 per cent., although brokers struggle to get half a crown more.

A number of instances have been recorded of land birds appearing near vessels far out at sea, and apparently overcome with fatigue, they would perch for several hours in the rigging before proceeding on their journey, or desperate with hunger, would fly fearlessly down to the deck, where food and water is never refused them.

NEWARK, N.J., June 16 -- Tittle, the seven-year-old daughter of Edward Engler of 43 Schalk Street had a button removed from her nose yesterday by Dr. Robertson at his Eye and Ear Infirmary. The button had been there for about six years.

Much is likely to be heard during the present week of important deals close to consummation in the railway world. In the development of the community of interest idea in the Northwest public attention has been fixed on the negotiations between the great systems, overlooking the very serious phase of the existence of a number of minor independent roads which have been annoying and disturbing factors in the past.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Well directed efforts are being made in various ways to beautify New York City and its environments, and all good citizens, rich and poor alike, take a pardonable pride in each and every improvement as it is prosecuted to a finish.

Thomas Curtis Clarke, one of the best-known civil engineers in America, died in this city on Saturday after a short illness. The funeral will take place at noon tomorrow from his late residence, 146 East Thirty-eighth Street.

The second annual memorial service of the Actors' Church Alliance was held last night at St. Chrysostom's Chapel, corner of Thirty-ninth Street and Seventh Avenue. The church was well filled with actors and their friends. Of the clergy Bishop Potter, who is President of the organization, was not present.

CHICAGO, June 16 -- In railroad circles to-day the sudden departure of E.H. Harriman for the East, accompanied by John J. Mitchell, President of the Illinois Trust and Savings Bank, was accepted as support of the assertion that the Harriman combination has secured control of the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Road.

For four years Frederick S. Moffett, a Chicago lawyer, has lived in the woods of Arkansas with canary birds for his sole companions. He is now on his way home with his birds on his first visit. He has a wife and two sons in Chicago.

BERLIN, June 16 -- The Bismarck statue, facing the Column of Victory in front of the Reichstag Building, was unveiled at midday to-day in the presence of the Emperor and Empress, Prince Herbert Bismarck, Count von Billow, Prince Hohenlohe, the Ministers, the members of the legislative houses, and the Memorial Committee.

More trouble has broken out in the rapid transit tunnel, and according to reports at yesterday's meeting of the Central Federated Union, there is a strong likelihood of the strike fever breaking out again in the tunnel in a virulent form. Complaints were made regarding other city contracts, and the blame was laid on Tammany Hall and politicians generally.

Perry Belmont, who returned from Europe last week, declared yesterday that the expulsion of Richard Croker and William J. Bryan from control of the Democratic Party is necessary if the Democracy is to succeed.

ITHACA, N.Y., June 16 -- James Churchill, a farmhand who worked near Ithaca, early this morning murdered his wife. Minnie Churchill, at her father's home in Newfield, a village nine miles distant from this place. He crushed her head with a heavy bar of iron while she slept beside her seven-year-old daughter.

There is still too much speculative excitement in the Texas oil field to permit a development along lines which will show to what extent the kind of oil which the wells of the Beaumont field are yielding is a factor in the industrial prosperity of the South. The literature which emanates from the offices of promoters or which reflects their lurid prospectuses must be taken with a liberal allowance for shrinkage.

Two accidents, similar in nature, befell the Iron steamboat Perseus yesterday. Both affected the steering gear, the breaking of a chain of which rendered the rudder useless and left the boat drifting.

Women will occupy the leading place in the local golf world during the coming week. The second annual championship tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association will begin to-morrow morning at the Nassau Country Club, Glen Cove, L.I., and it will continue throughout the balance of the week.

Although many of the crack trotters and pacers were missing from the Speedway yesterday morning, there was some lively sport for a couple of hours before noon, furnished by the roan pacer Moth Miller, 2:07; George Wallace, 2:17 1/4; Vera G, 2:14 1/4; Kingwood, 2:17 1/4; Chance, and several others.

LEBANON, Ill., June 16 --A remarkable record, illustrating what may be accomplished by pluck and perseverance, is that of W. Duff Piercy, valedictorian at McKendree College this year. After five years' study he is graduated in the classical course, having paid all the expenses of his own education and that of his wife also, who is a member of the class of 1902, by acting as newspaper correspondent for metropolitan papers and teaching school.

A declaration was recently made by the Commander in Chief of the Grand Army of the Republic which, if it is sincere and correct, points the way for that organization to redeem itself in public opinion, and rid itself of the distrust which has so long attached to it.

-- It is not at all remarkable that men upon whom falls the moral and financial responsibility for such an accident as that which happened to the transport Ingalls should transmute much of their apprehension into irritability and show scant courtesy in postponing as long as possible the inevitable explanations and admissions the case demands.

A notable incident occurred in this city Sunday, June 9, and there is a pathetic and historical interest attached to it, showing as it does that the brave soldier of the Lost Cause honors and respects the brave soldier on the other side.

Three Mormon Elders who for several months past have been seeking converts to the Church of Latter Day Saints in the Borough of the Bronx have stirred the congregation of the Port Morris Congregational Church, One Hundred and Thirty-third Street and the Southern Boulevard, and its pastor, the Rev. Claude M. Severance, to the highest pitch of indignation by converting two of the most prominent women in the church.

YONKERS, N.Y., June 16 -- Two baseball players were arrested at the Saw Mill River grounds this afternoon. It was unexpected, but Capt. McLaughlin has decided to try to make a test case in the matter of baseball playing even though the Adams golf case was decided against the police.
In an article on the restriction of negro suffrage at the South, THE NEW YORK TIMES says:

BOSTON, June 16 -- The Rev. Dr. J.M. Buckley, editor of The Christian Advocate of New York, preached at Park Street Church this morning on "False Religions." All the religous sects that were in Europe at the time Columbus discovered America were now to be found fully established in this country.

It is announced that some of the opponents of the recent scandalous action of the Pennsylvania Legislature and the City Government of Philadelphia intend to carry their opposition into the United States courts. The particular case which is supposed to come within the jurisdiction of these courts is that of a company formerly enjoying rights in Broad Street, winch was some time since withdrawn from their use and devoted in perpetuity to purely public uses.

LONDON, June 16 -- The Shamrock II, arrived at the Clyde this evening, and docked at Greenock. Her mast will be stepped and her spars fitted to-morrow. It has been arranged that the challenger shall sail in two races on the Clyde, one June 27 and the other July 6. Afterward the yacht's headquarters will be at Lamlam for a fortnight's daily racing against the Shamrock I.

No less than five large regattas, not to mention smaller events, will be sailed during the week, and yachtsmen will have a chance to get a surfeit of their favorite pastime if such a condition be possible.

BRISTOL, R.I., June 16 -- Billman and his force of riggers, with several members of the Constitution's crew, practically completed the rigging of the Constitution this evening, enabling the crew to once more hoist the yachting ensign, the New York Yacht Club pennant, and the owner's absence sign.

The approach of the Summer heats will remind very many of our readers of the inevitable sufferings of the poor each year in the crowded tenement districts. Various efforts are made to give the children of the working classes and of the very poor a short breathing space at the seaside or in the mountains.

LONDON, June 16 -- The London Stock Exchange was roused only slightly last week from its long-continued lethargy. The air seemed to have been cleared from the effects of the recent American crisis, but business remained painfully dull. Professional traders are merely following New York at a safe distance and are continually alert for pitfalls.

The air seemed to have been cleared from the effects of the recent American crisis, but business remained painfully dull. Professional traders are merely following New York at a safe distance and are continually alert for pitfalls.

CHICAGO, June 16 -- John Alexander Dowie announced at his meeting in Zion Tabernacle to-day that certain physicians of this city had formed a plot to kidnap him, lock him in a detention hospital, and beat him on the head and back till he should lose all his reasoning powers and become really insane.

After a lingering illness of more than a year's duration, Mrs. Susanna, Bradwell Hewitt, mother of the Rev. John Hewell Hewitt, rector of St. Paul's Church, died Tuesday at the residence of her son, in the eighty-second year of her age.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have always admired and enjoyed reading your worthy paper, especially because of your motto, "All the News That's Fit to Print." I regret, however, that occasionally some stuff that is not fit to print is given place in your instructive columns. The letter of Alexander Brownlie evidently belongs to this class.

In a race full of flukes and surprises yesterday at the Larchmont Spring Regatta, Frederick K. Brewster's new seventy-five-foot schooner Elmira came home a winner by nearly three minutes over H.F. Lippitt's Quissetta, after the latter had the race won by good margins. Amorita, the Brokaw crack winner of most events for her class last season, was third.

It will be hard to fill Mr. PLATT'S place in the Senate. His qualification for the United States Senate is probably quite unmatched among the Republicans of the State of New York. He stands upon an eminence that puts him above all rivalry. No Republican was ever jealous of his distinction.

PHILADELPHIA, June 17. -- Lakewood was obliged to concede the Philadelphia Country Club polo team 12 goals by handicap to-day in the second match for the Pembroke Cups on the Bryn Mawr Polo Club field, and lost the match by the score of 16 1/4 to 15 1/2, in one of the fastest games ever witnessed in this vicinity.

LONDON, June 17. -- Earl Russell was arrested to-day on the charge of having contracted a bigamous marriage in the United States. He was met at the railway station, upon his arrival from the country, this morning by detectives with a warrant, and was taken to the Bow Street Police Court.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- Senator Elkins sweeps away with a free hand the pretensions of all Senators to be candidates for the office of President. In what is referred to as a "casual conversation," and not an interview, he suggested that when a man gets into the Senate he might as well shake hands and say good-bye to his Presidential aspirations.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- Representative C.H. Grosvenor of Ohio, upon whom has been placed the responsibility for provoking the declaration by President McKinley that he will not be a candidate for a third term, has written a characteristic letter to The Washington Post to explain how he came to be loaded with a share of the ridicule that should, he believes, all belong to Senator Depew.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., June 17. -- Class day at Smith College to-day was attended by a larger number of spectators than usual. The 250 seniors, gowned in white, and each carrying a bunch of white daisies, were escorted to the campus by a double line of juniors, who marked their pathway with a rope of evergreen, and the ivy exercises wire held in front of Seelye Hall.

One can imagine the disgust and discouragement with which the account of the latest "Boer victory" has been read in England. It was not much of a victory. The Boers might win, and indeed they have won, a hundred such in a campaign which nevertheless turned out a disastrous one for them and victorious for the invaders.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- The following changes in diplomatic posts were announced to-day: Francis B. Loomis, Minister to Venezuela, has been transferred to be Minister to Portugal, vice John N. Irwin of Iowa resigned.

An apparently well-informed American, who has lived some years in China and who is an ardent and sympathetic admirer of the Chinese people as a race, in the course of an interview in The Commercial Advertiser yesterday predicts enormous progress in wealth for China when the country is allowed to be opened, as he believes it will be if the Emperor assumes real power.

DENVER, June 17. -- Conferences of labor leaders are being held in this city to investigate the reported theft from the official files of what is known as the Employers' Liability bill passed by the last Legislature in the interest of the wage earners.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- The United States and Chilean Claims Commission completed its work to-day. The last case to be decided was that involving the seizure in 1891 of the Chilean vessel Itata by the authorities of the United States on the ground that she was carrying a cargo of contraband and arms to Chile.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- Capt. Sigsbee was incorrectly represented in a Washington dispatch to-day as having exploded the "Bill" Anthony story in a lecture before the Union Veteran Legion, and as having said that Anthony never made his famous report that "The vessel has been blown up and is sinking."

With entire respect for the spirit of his criticism of the acceptance of Mr. CARNECIE'S libraries, we think that Dr. PERCY GRANT, in his baccalaureate sermon on Sunday to the graduating class of the College of the City of New York, mistakes the nature of that gift and its probable effect.

AUSTIN, June 17. -- The killing of Sheriff Robert M. Glover of Gonzales County, Sheriff W.T. Morris of Karnes County, and "Tony" Schnabel, a well-known ranchman, by Mexicans, during the last few days, has aroused the authorities of every county in Southwest Texas, and large posses of determined men, headed by the Sheriffs of Travis, Hays, Bee, Bexar, Falls, Bastrop, Kerr, Kendall, Star, Atascosa, Webb, and several other counties are hunting for the guilty men.

DETROIT, June 17. -- Frank C. Pingree, brother of ex-Gov. Hazen S. Pingree, who is dangerously ill in London, started for New York this afternoon, accompanied by Mrs. H.S. Pingree and her daughter. The party will sail for London on Wednesday.

CAMP ROE, near Lake Mohegan, June 17. -- The corps of cadets of the United States Military Academy and the Seventh Regiment, National Guard, New York, are lying in camp in adjacent fields at Camp Roe to-night with only a stone wall between them. But earlier in the day, before this peace was established between them, the sight of either was the occasion for an attack by the other and the burning of much gunpowder.
LONDON, June 17. -- Sir Thomas Lipton said to a representative of The Associated Press:

The trial of Thomas G. Barker of Arlington, N.J., charged with shooting from ambush and with intent to kill the Rev. John W. Keller, rector of Trinity Mission Church of that town, on the morning of Sunday, Feb. 3, of this year, was begun yesterday before Judge John A. Blair in the Hudson County Court of General Sessions in Jersey City.

BUFFALO, June 17. -- The Court of Appeals to-day heard the first argument for a new trial for Roland B. Molineux, the young New York clubman, athlete, and chemist, under sentence of death for poisoning Mrs. Katherine J. Adams in December, 1898, who was the unintended victim of an alleged design to take the life of Harry Cornish, at one time manager of athletic sports of the Knickerbocker Athletic Club.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 17. -- Charles Arthur Moore, Jr., of Brooklyn, whose father is President of the American Protective Tariff League and was with the Presidential party on the trip to the Pacific Coast, is preparing to make his third trip to the extreme Northern regions, this time heading a party of nine Yale students, whose object, aside from that of pleasure, is to secure specimens of rare birds.

Apart from the fact that the transportation companies in most sections of the country have for a long time past been able to place on record the most gratifying evidence of the Nation's growing prosperity in the form of increases in their gross earnings, security holders have also had this progress impressed upon them by the way in which they have seen their share certificates enhance in value under the stimulus of expanding profits.

FAIRMONT, West Va., June 17. -- The Watson coal interests, associated with a few capitalists from New York whose names are not yet given out, to-day consummated a new organization which will be known as the Fairmont Coal Company, with a capital of $12,000,000. Four million dollars in bonds were issued, and have practically all been placed.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- A Philippine mail brings to the War Department the records in eleven cases wherein Filipinos were tried by military commissions on charges including the murder, kidnapping, assault and battery, burglary, and violation of the rules of war.

HAMLET, N.C., June 17. -- Last night about 10 o'clock the north-bound Seaboard Air Line Atlanta special turned broadside off a trestle into a pond, about a mile north of Rockingham. There were on board about twenty-five or thirty passengers, all of whom were more or less injured, several seriously, and two, a white man and a negro, probably fatally.

PARIS, June 17. -- Dispatches received at the Foreign Office from Peking say that, at the close of the meeting of the foreign Ministers on Saturday, two points regarding the indemnity remained to be settled. First, the fixing of the value of the tael, which is tending to depreciate; second, the claim advanced by powers whose credit is low, such as Russia and Japan.

The attendance at the Sheepshead Bay racetrack yesterday, like all other things connected with racing this season, violated tradition, the tradition that always after a great race day the crowd remains at home. As a matter of fact, the gathering was larger than the average, though the programme offered was rather commonplace.
Jesse C. Bennett Co. have sold for John Schreiber to a client the three-story brownstone dwelling 312 West Seventy-first Street, 18x57x102.2, for $25,000.

PITTSBURG, June 17. -- In the United States Circuit Court to-day John K. Cowan presented his resignation as receiver of the Pittsburg and Western Railroad Company, and upon its acceptance Judge M.W. Acheson appointed L.F. Loree, President of the Baltimore and Ohio, as his successor.

It was entirely appropriate that BISMARCK'S successor in the Imperial Chancellery of Germany should be the eulogist chosen for the "inauguration" of his monument. If we considered the two men only, the later statesman would seem to denote a great political advance upon the earlier.

Business was almost at a standsill in the outside market yesterday. Transactions being few, fluctuations were insignificant. The bigger general market of the Stock Exchange broadening out ssemed to command practically all of Wall Street's attention.

BOSTON, June 17. -- Will Stinson won the thirty-mile motor-paced race at Charles River Park this afternoon, Johnnie Nelson was second, and Jimmy Michael was two miles in the rear. Fully 15,000 people saw the race, and for a time it was thrilling. Nelson was booked to win, but he went so fast that his motor tandem simply slid from beneath his pacemakers.

ATHENS, Ga., June 17. -- At the celebration of the centennial of the University of Georgia to-day Oscar S. Straus delivered an address entitled "An Historical Retrospect, or the Development of Religious Liberty in the United States." In the course of his remarks Mr. Straus said:

HELENA, Mont., June 17. -- Oil discoveries are reported from two widely separated sections of Montana, the extreme North-western and Eastern. It is stated at Kalispel that if the Kintla Lake oil district has been properly estimated by a party of oil prospectors, who have just returned from a six weeks' stay in that country, then there will be one of the biggest oil booms around there soon that the country has ever known.

The sale of the Rancho del Paso thoroughbred yearlings, the property of J.B. Haggin, and the produce of his California breeding farm, went into its third day at the Fasig-Tipton Company's sales paddock, Sheepshead Bay, yesterday, with prices averaging quite as large as on the opening day.

Freedom or a fourth trial for Samuel J. Kennedy, once convicted of murdering Emcline C. Reynolds, three years ago, now depends upon the decision of District Attorney Philbin. The District Attorney, after a conference with Lawyers Moore and Cantwell yesterday, announced that he would make known his decision in the matter to-day, after he conferred with Judge Newburger, who was out of town yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- The following promotions and appointment by the President were announced to-day: Charles W. Rae, to be advanced three numbers in rank on the list of commanders in the navy, for eminent and conspicuous conduct in battle.

HAMILTON, Mass., June 17. -- Willie Anderson won the title to-day of open golf champion of the United States for the coming year. He beat his rival, Alec Smith, who tied with him on Saturday at 331 strokes for the seventy-two-hole match, by 1 stroke in an eighteen-hole round to play off the competition.
NEWPORT, June 17. -- Clarence W. Dolan has arrived for the season.

The State Civil Service Commission will decide to-day whether subordinates employed by the recently created Bureau of Elections shall be classified as exempt, non-competitive, or competitive under the rules of the civil service law. The commission met at the Hotel Victoria yesterday, all the members, William M. Collier of Auburn, John E. Kraft of Kingston, and Cuthbert W. Pound of Ithaca, being present.
WICHITA, Kan., June 17. -- Col. Montgomery Bryant, United States Army, retired, died at his home in this city to-day.

To The Editor of The New York Time: The sermon by Dr. Charles H. Eaton, reported in your issue of to-day, affords an instance of that bravado spirit of broadness which makes thinking men look upon religion and its exponents (professional) with contempt. "The only religion worth anything is the religion intellectually chosen by free and enlightened men and women," says the preacher.

Although the clerk of the weather did not provide roof garden opening temperature last night, there was an audience of good size at the first performance on the aerial stage of Koster Bial's music hall in West Thirty-fourth Street. Most of those present had apparently assembled in the hope of welcoming Charmion on her return to this country, but they were doomed to disappointment.

The Missouri Pacific Railway, by a vote of the Board of Directors, which met yesterday, resumed the payment of dividends which had been permitted to lapse since 1891. A resolution was also passed authorizing the issue of the new stock to the amount of 15 per cent. of present holdings of stockholders, but nothing was said about the rumored Southwestern consolidation.

PHILADELPHIA, June 17. -- The market was strong, but owed its activity almost exclusively to Cambria Steel warrants. All the Readings were in good demand. Southern Cotton Oil, which last week sold at 50 1/4, commanded 60, advancing from 54 since last Saturday, on rumor of a merger with the American Cotton Oil Company.

Alfred L. Dolson, theatrical press agent, residing at 78 Manhattan Avenue, has filed a petition in bankruptcy, with liabilities of $21,550 and no assets. He filed the petition to get rid of his debts individually and as a partner in the firms of Barlow, Dolson Powers Minstrels, Barlow Brothers' Minstrels, "Daughters of the Poor" company, and the "Two Old Cronies" company.

NEWPORT, June 17. -- The cup yacht Constitution, after an overhauling and repairing her mainmast at Bristol, arrived at her moorings to the westward of the torpedo station, having come down the bay under three lower sails, with the tender Mount Morris following and taking up her anchorage close to the yacht.

LONDON, June 18. -- Replying to questions in the House of Comons yesterday, the Right Hon. W. St. John Brodrick, the Secretary of State for War, said there were 40,229 persons in the concentration camps of the Transvaal and Orange River Colonies. The deaths in these camps for the month of May numbered US men and women and 318 children.

Divers worked all day yesterday at the hull of the wrecked ferryboat Northfield, but no more bodies were found. The men were ordered early in the day to discontinue the search for bodies, as the swift currents caused by the tides where the wrecked hulk lies make a systematic search impossible.

District Attorney Philbin sprang a surprise on Capt. Diamond's wardman, Bissert, charged by Lena Schmitt with levying blackmail yesterday, when the policeman was arraigned for examination before Magistrate Mayo in the Yorkville Police Court.

CHICAGO, June 17. -- "We stay with them to the finish," is the expression used by officials of the International Association of Machinists and by those of the National Metal Trades Association to-day. Officials of the International Association of Machinists assert that they will obtain enough agreements from employing firms to make the manufacturers tremble.

William C. Walker of 534 High Street, Germantown, Penn., was arrested at the corner of Fifty-sixth Street and Sixth Avenue yesterday afternoon by Deputy Sheriff Nathaniel Metzger and lodged in Ludlow Street Jail. The arrest was made on an order of arrest in a civil action begun by the American Surety Company of this city against Walker for the fraudulent conversion of $6,369.28.

-- There are anti-vaccinationists in this country, but their number is very small and their influence on the general public amounts to practically nothing, since they are regarded as hopeless cranks to whose jabberings no attention need be paid. Yet, despite the almost universal belief in vaccination, the events of the past few months have shown that smallpox can both obtain and retain a foothold in many, if not all, American towns.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 18. -- The Constitution made her first spin to-day, after her repairs to her mainmast. The big boat got under way at 10:20 o'clock, with the wind light from the southwest, and under her working sails, with a No. 2 clubtopsail and baby jibtopsail set she stood out of the harbor with Capt. Rhodes at the helm and Capt. Duncan aboard.

LONDON, June 18. -- American horses and owners had a prominent part in the opening of the aristocratic race meeting at Ascot Heath to-day, one of the events of the day, the Ascot Stakes, going to Foxhall Keene's Sinopi, ridden by "Danny" Maher, and the Trial Stakes, going to William C. Whitney's Watershed, ridden by J. Reiff, while American horses and jockeys were placed in several other races.

PHILADELPHIA, June 18. -- An official statement regarding the sale of the Bethlehem Steel Company to the Vickers Sons Maxim Company of London is now being prepared and will be made public within the next ten days. Officers of the Bethlehem company admitted to-day that the deal is about to go through.

The movement of prices on the Stock Exchange yesterday was decidedly irregular, the result largely of the conflicting elements at work in the market. Where on the day previous sentiment had been almost generally bullish yesterday the room traders from the outset assumed a bearish attitude and at not infrequent occasions during the day offered stocks down whensoever they detected or thought they detected weak spots.

The resumption of dividends at the rate of 2 1/2 per cent. semi-annually by the Missouri Pacific Railroad after a long period of ten years, during which the road has paid no profits to its stock-holders, is an event of note and moment. It is of interest not merely to the owners of shares in the railroad, but to the whole country as solid proof of the remarkable prosperity of its industries.

Yonkers is not the only place where the Sabbath breakers have recently worsted the Sabbath defenders. The wicked Yonkers golfer has a worthy companion in no less a personage than Lord BALFOUR OF BURLEIGH. His crime consisted in that, being Secretary for Scotland, he did willfully, maliciously, and knowingly open the Edinburgh Museum of Science and Art upon the Sabbath day.

KEYSER, West Va., June 18 -- An avalanche unparalleled in the West Virginia mountains occurred last night at Hopeville. Grant County, thirty-eight miles from here. Great sections of the mountain side along the Potomac River for two miles rushed down into the beautiful valley. Thousands of tons of forest trees, immense rocks, and earth came down, and the home of Mrs. Andrew Ours, a widow, was wrecked.

Business in the outside market yesterday broadened somewhat, but only a few issues showed totals larger than the recent average. Favorably influenced by the strength displayed by the Stock Exchange market during the morning, prices on the curb at first advanced, but later transactions to some extent reduced the early gains.

BUFFALO, N.Y., June 18. -- Early this morning fire destroyed all the buildings on Squaw Island, that front on the Niagara River, from the foot of Ferry Street to a point nearly a mile north. The loss is in the neighborhood of $260,000.

BOSTON, Mass., June 18. -- In a smooth sea and under a southeast breeze varying from 10 knots at the start to 18 at the finish, the Independence was given her sixth trial in Massachusetts Bay. On form she certainly seemed better than during her previous trials, and she showed fine speed, at one time fully 14 knots, when reaching the lightship to Thieves Ledge.

CAMP ROE, Near Lake Mohegan, N.Y., June 18. -- At 4:30 this morning, an hour when only milkmen are presumed to be abroad, reveille sounded in the camp of the cadets at Lake Mohegan. One might suppose that after yesterdays march the men would have liked sleeping a little longer even upon the ground.
CLEVELAND, June 18. -- A dispatch to The Leader from Youngstown, Ohio, says:

QUEENSTOWN, June 18. -- The American Line steamer Waesland, from Philadelphia, June 8, for Liverpool, arrived in this port to-night, having on board among other passengers the Pennsylvania University crew bound for Henley.

NEWPORT, June 18 -- A number of cottage-hunters were in the city to-day. The demand for residences continues. Some cottages never let before have been pressed into the market by the real estate agents.

BALTIMORE, June 18. -- President Underwood of the Erie Railroad was in Baltimore to-day. This was his first visit here since he retired as Second Vice President, of the Baltimore and Ohio Road, to take the Presidency of the Erie. He called on his former associates in the Baltimore and Ohio.

In an effort to arouse its countrymen from what it thinks is perilous attachment to the principles of free trade and to incite them to meet, before it is too late, "the full force of the present American commercial concentration," The Saturday Review paints a vivid picture of the advantages America enjoys in any business contest with the Old World.

The second day of the trial of Thomas G. Barker, charged before Judge John A. Blair in the Hudson County Court of General Sessions, in Jersey City, with shooting with attempt to kill the Rev. John Keller on the streets of Arlington, N.J., on the morning of Sunday, Feb. 3, last, closed yesterday afternoon in the midst of one of the most sensational legal battles ever fought in the courts of the State.

NEWARK, N.J., June 18. -- The Court of Appeals has reversed a decision rendered by Judge Swayze of this city in an ejectment suit brought by Joel W. Condit against David Reynolds. Incidentally the Court upsets the will of the Rev. Horace Smith Bishop, rector of Christ Episcopal Church at East Orange.
