Reduction in the Imperial Bank of Germany's rate of discount from 4 to 3 1/2 per cent.

By a deed recorded yesterday, Erasmus D. Carnsey transferred to Herbert B. Turner the building 51 and 53 Maiden Lane, 39.2 by irregular. Mortgages on the property for $400,000 at 4 1/2 per cent, for five years to the Equitable Life Assurance Society, and for $116.500 at 6 per cent, to Boehm Coon, payable in December, 1902, were also recorded.

LONDON, June 18 -- Craig-y-Nos Castle, the residence in Wales of Mme. Adelina Patti, (Baroness Rolf Cederstrom,) was put up at auction this afternoon at the Mart, in this city. The place was bought in for u43,000, after a dramatic scene caused by a false bid of u50,000, which was the reserve price.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 18. -- The conditions for rowing were unfavorable today, the river being rough and choppy: but the Columbia and Pennsylvania Clubs rowed as usual in both the morning and the afternoon. Columbia was handicapped in practice, as the yacht Walla-Walla could not be had, and their own launch, the Columbia, was not ready for use, so that Hanlan had to coach from a single.
LONDON, June 18 -- Ex-Gov. Hazen S. Pingree of Michigan died here to-night at 11:35 o'clock.

Whitehouse Porter have sold for D.O. Mills to Isaac H. Clothier the block front in the east side of Fifth Avenue, between One Hundred and Fourth and One Hundred and Fifth Streets, together with four lots adjoining in One Hundred and Fourth Street, and one lot adjoining in One Hundred and Fifth Street.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., June 18 -- Maurice B. Perkins, Professor of Chemistry of Union College, died suddenly early this morning. Prof. Perkins was born in New London, Conn., March 14, 1836. He studied chemistry abroad, spending the year 1860-61 at the Universities of Gottingen, Heidelberg, and Tubingen.

Diplomas were delivered to 525 young girl graduates of the Normal College of the City of New York at the thirty-second annual commencement exercises of that institution, held in Carnegie Hall, last night. For the first time in over a quarter of a century the graduating exercises were held outside of the college buildings, the change being on account of the unusually large graduating class, the largest in the institution's history.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 18. -- Two Yonkers men, Frank Evans and George Edwards, both of whom have been in the prize ring, and the former of whom claims to have secured a draw with Terry McGovern early in the letter's career, are prisoners here charged with larceny. They were arrested near the Larchmont line this evening, after a struggle.

The branch office of the Adams Express Company at Madison Avenue and Forty-ninth Street was robbed of about $7,000 worth of diamonds and jewelry on Sunday night last. Three night clerks employed by the company were arraigned, charged with the theft, in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday.

BOSTON, June 18 -- On call money rules from 3 to 4 per cent., mostly at 3 and 3 1/2 per cent. Time money is quiet. The choicest collateral loans will find buyers at 3 1/2 per cent, for all dates. From this level rates range up to 4 1/2 per cent., according to the character of the collateral. The best business paper is quoted at 3 1/2 @4 per cent.
CHICAGO, June 18 -- New York exchange was at 5 cents premium to-day. Money for call and time loans unchanged at 4 1/2 @5 per cent.

William L. Coston, the Coston signal manufacturer, of West Brighton, S.I., applied to the courts on June 12 for a summons for his wife, Anna L. Coston, charging her with having acted in a disorderly manner, and with interfering with his business.

BALTIMORE, June 18 -- The market today maintained the momentum given to its activities Monday, and closed strong in harmony with the trading. The feature of the day was Seaboard preferred, which, on heavy absorption, advanced a full point from 48 to 49, the latter figure being the record high price on the local Exchange.

PHILADELPHIA, June 18 -- At the opening, Cambria Steel was extraordinarily active, but a reaction set in in sympathy with New York, and nearly everything was dropping except Electric Storage Battery, Welsbach Light, and Indianapolis Passenger Railway, which made striking gains. The Choctaws yielded to 50 for the preferred and 70 for the common.

Miss Genevieve Hecker, the present metropolitan champion and who now represents the Essex County Club of Orange, N.J., led the field yesterday in the opening round of the second annual tournament for the championship of the Women's Golf Association. The competition began on the links of the Nassau Country Club, at Glen Cove, and it will be continued through the week.

ALBANY, N.Y., June 18. -- The Long Island Extension Railroad Company was incorporated to-day, to construct and operate an underground tunnel railroad four miles long from the property of the Long Island Railroad Company in the Borough of Queens under the East River to a point south of Fiftieth Street and west of Broadway, in the Borough of Manhattan.

DETROIT, June 18 -- Hazen Senter Pingree was born in Denmark, Me., in 1840. At an early age he removed to Hopkinton, Mass., and found employment in a shoe factory. In 1862 he enlisted in the First Massachusetts Heavy Artillery, and served until the end of the civil war, when he settled in Detroit and embarked in the manufacturing of shoes.

NEWARK, N. J., June 18. -- Upon a warrant issued upon an indictment for larceny by the New York Grand Jury, John A. Qualey, ex-President of the United States Carbonate Company, was arrested here today. The warrant charges him with being a fugitive from justice. It was served by Detective Sergeant Long of the New York Detective Bureau and Detective Sergeant Cuff of the District Attorney's office in New York.

NEWARK, N.J., June 18 -- A friend discovered William Nelson, thirty-eight years old, at the latter's boarding house, 41 Lincoln Street, last night after Nelson had attempted suicide by severing an artery, and instead of summoning a physician, he bound up the arm and then began praying for Nelson's recovery.

Dr. Samuel J. Kennedy, for twenty-one months under sentence of death in Sing Sing, who was tried three times for murder in the first degree on the charge of having killed "Dolly" Reynolds, was admitted to $10,000 bail yesterday afternoon shortly before 3 o'clock by Judge Cowing, in Part I. of the General Sessions Court.

GENEVA, N.Y., June 18. -- This, the third day in the seventy-sixth commencement week of Hobart College, in this city, was signalized by the dedication of Bishop Coxe Memorial Hall, a white stone structure, erected to perpetuate the memory of the late the Right Rev. Arthur Cleveland Coxe, Bishop of Western New York.

The student of the tendency of Southern thought on economic Questions finds it difficult to understand the growth of a pro-tariff sentiment, of which he sees so many indications, or to reconcile this with the fact that the industrial prosperity of the Southern States is so largely dependent upon exports.
CHICAGO, June 18 -- "I have notified those interested in business with me that within two years I shall retire from commercial life. I shall then be sixty years old, and ready to quit work."
LONDON, June 18. -- The American trapshooters were entertained at a farewell banquet in the Cafe Royal by the Middlesex Gun Club to-night.

CHICAGO, Ill., June 18. -- When a surgeon is performing an operation on a person under the influence of an anaesthetic, and finds that another operation, not contemplated before, is necessary, he has the legal right to perform the second operation without waiting to get the consent of the patient. Judge Kavanaugh so ruled to-day in the suit of Mrs. Agnes Mulhern against the Post Graduate Medical School and Hospital.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., June 18. -- Despite the fact that the Rockaway Polo Club first team was conceded seven goals by the crack Bryn Mawr players to-day in the third polo match for the Pembroke cups, it was defeated by the score of 15 3/4 goals to 12.

John Cristy, 'longshoreman, lies dead in Bellevue. A Coroner's physician found him in the Morgue yesterday morning. He died of acute exhaustion, the hospital people told Dr. Philip O'Hanlon, who went there from the Coroner's office. When Dr. O'Hanlon made an investigation he found that the body before him showed these marks: Two ribs fractured, bruises on the chin, chest, knees, arms, left side of head, and stomach.

WILKESBARRE, Penn,, June 18. -- Unless the Temple Iron and Coal Company discharges one carpenter, 3,300 men may be thrown into idleness and seven coilleries be closed down. All the employes of the Temple Iron Company met to-day and prepared a request for the non-union man's discharge, which was later presented to the company.

CHICAGO, June 18. -- At the University of Chicago the convocation exercises were held to-day. John D. Rockefeller, founder of the institution, which is now celebrating its decennial anniversary, addressed the large audience of students and visitors. Several other addresses were delivered. President W.R. Harper made his decennial statement and then conferred the degrees.

Heeling over the finish line, with her lee rail buried in flashing foam, H.F. Lippitt's seventy-five-foot schooner Quissetta defeated F.K. Brewster's new Elmira by five seconds yesterday in the Atlantic Yacht Club's annual regatta. So close were the competing boats after a twenty-five-and-a-half-mile battle with wind and wave that when they crossed the line the foremast of Elmira and the mainmast of Quissetta were about even when their time was taken.

The interest of society yesterday was principally suburban. The golf contest at Glen Cove was the subject of much interest to those who are fond of the game. The Meadow Brook people are interested in practice games of polo, and there was the usual match at Bryn Mawr. There was nothing on the social calendar in town.

The State Civil Service Commission last night decided to place the thirty-eight appointments within the gift or the new Bureau of Elections in the exempt list of the classified class. The commission was in session at four different times before this result was reached, and the delay was due to the failure of the Municipal Civil Service body to send in a report.

BOONEVILLE, Mo., June 19 -- A disastrous storm of rain and wind visited Booneville to-night. Tobe Fisher was killed by the falling walls of a two-story brick building. The roofs were blown off several business blocks and many houses. A large brick foundry near the river front was destroyed.

The Rev. Dr. James J. Dougherty, pastor of St. Monica's Church, who delivered the address to graduates at the fifty-sixth annual commencement of St. John's College, Fordham, yesterday, referred to the administration work in the Philippines in a vein of criticism from the point of view of a Romah Catholic.

CHICAGO, June 19. -- The first performance of Miss Mildred Dowling's dramatization of "Lorna Doone" will be given tomorrow night at the Grand Opera House. Lorna Doone will be impersonated by Miss Olive May, John Ridd by William Courtleigh. Carver Doone by Ralph Delmore, Counselor Doone by Prank Burbeck, Sir Ensor Doone by R. Peyton Carter, Charleworth Doone by "William Harcourt, Reuben Huckaback by Bart W. Wallace, and Lizzie Ridd by Mabel Taliaferro.

The Board of Elections met at Police Headquarters yesterday, Secretary Page being absent, and took action in the same line as the State Civil Service Board on Tuesday, excepting the thirty-nine employes from the civil service rules, so as to make the force bi-partisan.

Morris K. Jesup, President of the Chamber of Commerce, was among the passengers who landed in New York from the White Star liner Teutonic last night. Mr. Jesup is one of the first to return of the delegation of members of the Chamber of Commerce who went to London to attend the banquet of the London Chamber of Commerce, and who were later received by the King.

BALTIMORE. June 19. -- The market's interest to-day circled around two issues chiefly, though there was a fair share of buying all along the line. The United Railways group, which for a week had been subjected to more or less pressure, was one of the most prominent bull features. The bonds and stock both advanced, though the common stock was the most conspicuous.

WASHINGTON, June 19. -- The War Department to-day made public two telegrams dated yesterday relating to the alleged clothing frauds at San Francisco. The first is a message from Adjt. Gen. Corbin to Major Gen. Shafter asking for information on the subject and stating that "it is desirable from every point of view that detailed facts of any importance be given the department before being exploited in the newspapers."

WASHINGTON, June 19. -- The excess of receipts over expenditures for the fiscal year that will end June 30 promises to be very close to the estimates made by Secretary Gage in his annual report to Congress. Some doubt has been expressed as to whether the excess would reach the $80,000,000 anticipated, but the doubt is not entertained at the Treasury Department.

All things centred about one undersized and very thin lad at the Sheepshead Bay race track yesterday, that same small individual. Shaw by name and a jockey by trade, making the betting the majority of the events on the card, and also making the results in four of the five that he rode in.

BOSTON, June 19. -- On call, money rules from 3@4 per cent., mostly 3@3 1/2 per cent. Time money ranges from 3 1/2@4 per cent., according to the character of the collateral. In business paper the average run of names oasses from 3 3/4@4 per cent. The very choicest names would probably pass at 3 1/2 per cent, for four months.

Darkness interfered with the playing of the baseball game between New York and Pittsburg yesterday and it had to be called at the end of the ninth inning, with the score a tie. The two runs necessary to tie were scored by Pittsburg in the ninth inning.

TRENTON, N.J., June 19. -- The Valvoline Oil Company, to develop lands containing oil and kindred substances, was incorporated here to-day. The capital stock is $1,500,000. Incorporators: William Dixon Ellis, New York City: Pedric R. Boult. Liverpool, England; George A. Ellis, Brooklyn; William James Goulding, New York City; Elliott Greene, Jr., Jersey City.

WASHINGTON, June 19. -- Treasury officials protest against the assumption in some quarters that the department has taken up the question of the duty on petroleum imported from Russia and decided it adversely to that country, well knowing that little or no petroleum is brought from there into the United States.

Jersey City yesterday won a victory over the Erie Railroad in a decision given by the Court of Errors and Appeals. The result will be to compel the company to pay to the city about $450,000 in bacK taxes. For many years the company claimed that its big grain elevator near its Jersey City station was exempt from local taxation because it was used for railroad purposes and paid taxes to the State.

Richard M. Montgomery has sold for the Merchants' National Bank and the Mechanics' National Bank to W.K. Aston 41 and 43 Wall Street, extending through to and including 43 and 47 Exchange Place. The Exchange Place property has a frontage of 3o feet 2 inches and is occupied by old five-story stone-front buildings.

According to a fashionable neologism commerce is war. To make this saying a statement of fact instead of an idle proverb it will suffice to show that the securing of profits is matter of life and death, not figuratively, but in actual destruction of human flesh and blood. This is what they are saying in England about our competition in the coal markets of the world.

CUXHAVEN, June 19. -- At the conclusion of the regatta held yesterday on the lower Elbe, a dinner was given on board the Hamburg-American yacht Victoria-Luise, at which Emperor William made a speech. His Majesty, in reply to the Burgomaster's toast, said:

CAMP TOWNSEND, Peekskill, June 19. -- The second battle of "Cemetery Ridge" has been fought, and with great glory to the Seventh, which passed through all the danger of the fray and marched into camp in the best of order and with no lives lost. It all came about in the working out of a tactical problem planned by Col. Appleton, without any of the plans being given out beforehand.

The dissensions among Republicans in the Twenty-fifth Assembly District of this county, to which attention was recently called, are rapidly nearing an acute stage. The Twenty-fifth is one of the six Republican districts in the county. It has a large negro population.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 19 -- J.C. Stubbs, Third Vice President and Traffic Manager of the Southern Pacific Railroad, arrived from the East to-night. He confirmed the report that he had accepted the position of Traffic Manager and Adviser of the Harriman syndicate of railroads. Mr. Stubbs will leave for Chicago in July.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "RS" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage, except in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes payment of the mortgage.
SHREVEPORT, La., June 20 -- 12:30 A.M. -- Two negroes, "Prophet" Smith and F. D. McLand, have just been lynched.

CHICAGO, June 19. -- "I do not believe the man who tells me that trade relations and Business exigency will prevent future wars among the civilized nations. It is intellect that will stop them, and Intellect alone. Education makes for peace more than all the business in the world."

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 19. -- The one hundred and thirty-fifth annual Commencement of Rutgers College was concluded here to-night with the exercises of the graduating class. This afternoon a meeting of the College Alumni Association was held and John W. Herbert, '72, of New York City was elected an Alumni Trustee.

Prices were very irregular in the outside market yesterday, although very few stocks showed much activity. At times during the day there was practically no business being transacted and even the stocks recently placed on the curb attracted little attention. A few stocks were decidedly strong, advancing considerably and ending the day at about the best prices recorded, while elsewhere in the list rather sharp declines showed in the final quotations.

Schooners, sloops, yawls, and steam craft will Keep old Neptune dodging when the fifty-fifth annual regatta of the New York Yacht Club is sailed to-day out and around the Sandy Hook Lightship and back.

LONDON, June 20. -- Thousands of people began collecting outside Queen's Hall two hours before the advertised time of the pro-Boer meeting held there last evening. When the doors were finally opened, the pressure of the surging mob was so great that many people fainted. There was considerable disturbance, and windows were broken during the attempts made by persons without tickets to gain admission.

WASHINGTON, June 19. -- The Division of Military Information of the War Department is preparing for publication reports of various officers who have recently had opportunities to observe military events and campaigns. One of these is Capt. Carl Reichmann, Seventeenth Infantry, who went from the Philippines to South Africa and for seven months observed the operations of the Boer Army.

John F. Carroll sailed for Europe yesterday on the Oceanic, and his destination is Wantage. Charles W. Morse, President of the American Ice Company, was on the same steamer, going abroad to spend a honeymoon in travel on the Continent.

STAMFORD, Conn., June 19. -- Sudden illness prevented the wedding here to-day of Alfred J. Larwill of 172 Eldert Street, Brooklyn, and Miss Ella Mae Herring of 14 Pleasant Street. The Herring dwelling had been decorated for the marriage, when George Larwill, a brother of the prospective bridegroom, arrived with the news that the latter was too ill to leave his bed.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 19 -- Mr. and Mrs. James Clinch Smith of New York arrived at their cottage, the Moorings, on Harrison Avenue, about a week ago, for the season, and to-day a slight case of smallpox developed in one of the servants. The Board of Health removed the patient to the pest house, and quarantined all in the house, which is well away from the other cottages.
MINEOLA, L.I., June 19 -- The first day of the thirty-fifth exhibition of the Queens-Nassau Counties Agricultural Societies witnessed some excellent trotting and pacing on the track. Summary:

BUFFALO, N. Y., June 19. -- The fate of Roland B. Molineux, convicted of murder, as the poisoner of Mrs. Katherine J. Adams at New York in December, 1898, is in the keeping of the seven Judges of the Court of Appeals, who for three days past have been listening to the arguments for and against a new trial.

The arrival of the Kaiser Wilhelm der Grosse brought many of the fashionables, including Mr. and Mrs. John R. Drexel and Mr. and Mrs. William P. Thompson. Mr, and Mrs. Drexel remained in town yesterday. They will go to Newport later. Miss Blight was in town to meet her sister, Mrs, William P. Thompson.

A lot of securities belonging to William B. Filer, former cashier and bookkeeper for Kohn Co.,. bankers and brokers of 46 Broadway, who disappeared in January, 1900, and has, It is said, never been heard from, were sold at auction yesterday by Adrian H. Muller. Son at 111 Broadway by order of William Alien, trustee in bankruptcy of Mr. Filer.

Miss Marion Oliver of the Baltusrol Golf Club, at Short Hills, N.J., was the star of brilliance yesterday in the second day's play of the women's metropolitan golf championship at the Nassau Country Club's links, Glen Cove, L.I. Miss Oliver, who a few years ago was the champion of Albany, put Miss Hecker's record-breaking figures of 95 on the previous day in the shade.
Statement that a large majority of Cambria Steel Company stock has already assented to the reorganization plan.

NEWPORT, June 19. -- As Henry Rogers Winthrop was returning to his home from the Golf Club in his new locomobile this afternoon, the vehicle ran against a boundary stone and turned over. Mr. Winthrop was only slightly hurt, but the locomobile was badly damaged.

MOUNT HOLLY, N. J., June 19. -- Twenty-five masked men assembled in the vicinity of ex-Judge B. P. Willis's house last night bent on treating Harry Allen Baxter, the fiance of Miss Willis, to a coat of tar and feathers. Entering the large yard, they made an effort to enter the rear door. Then something happened.

BOSTON, June 19. -- It was announced here this afternoon that the National Shawmut Bank had received a majority of Boston and Montana and Butte and Boston copper shares deposited for the purpose of the carrying out the transfer of these properties to the Amalgamated Copper Company. It was believed that there would be no delay in the further steps necessary to complete the transaction.

SANTIAGO DE CUBA, June 19. -- Sir William C. Van Horne, Chairman of the Board of Directors of the Canadian Pacific Railroad Company, who has been in Cuba for some time past supervising his railroad interests, sailed for Boston on a fruiter this morning. He said he was greatly pleased with the progress of railroad construction in Cuba.

KANSAS CITY, June 19. -- The Allied Third Party movement, which its promoters hope will result before 1904 in a National organization strong enough to name a Presidential nominee, was launched here this afternoon. It was the outcome of a conference of reformers from the ranks of the old parties and its principles are said by some to have been adopted with a view to fitting the views of William J. Bryan.
CHICAGO, June 19 -- Half a hundred men were at work to-day putting the Washington Park race course in condition for the American Derby, which is to be run here next Saturday.

John Christy's death on Tuesday at Bellevue Hospital was yesterday the subject of several investigations. None resulted in establishing that his end was due to violence, while there was no clearing up of the fact that a post-mortem examination found fractures of three ribs. There was no evidence to directly establish that superficial injuries on the body were inflicted in the hospital.

Dr. Frank L. Christian, formerly a house physician at Bellevue Hospital and more lately medical officer of the Eastern District Reformatory, has been appointed Medical Superintendent of Elmira Reformatory. He has resigned from Eastern District Reformatory.

Ever since the progress of artillery made walled towns useless for defense and those which had walls leveled them, turning "boulevards" from towered defenses into broad avenues, the cities have wandered at their own sweet will into the fields and the old suburbs have been incorporated with the parent town.

CHICAGO, June 19. -- Congressman Henry S. Boutell addressed the graduating class of the Armour Institute at the commencement exercises to-night. In speaking of the advance made in the nineteenth century and the possibilities of the future, he said :

When a "celebrated" criminal case comes up for trial in New Jersey the vague and chronic suspicion or laymen that there is something serious the matter with the administration of justice in criminal cases, in the State of New York, becomes an acute conviction.

Five of the eight golf matches played yesterday on the Nassau Country Club links at Glen Cove for the women's metropolitan championship and the consolation cup were won by the slim margin of one hole. The tournament is now narrowed down to the semi-final round in eaeh case. and the close finishes show how evenly the leaders are matched.

Armed with pistols and many rounds of ammunition improvised from blank cartridges and wire nails, the "Cuckoo Row Kids" moved in force last night on their enemy, John McDonald of 528 West One Hundred and Fifty-ninth Street, who is employed by the New York Central Railroad to watch the yards at Sixtieth Street and North River.

ALBANY, June 20 -- The Court of Appeals has handed down a very important decision in the case of the People ex rel. A Klepstein Co. vs. James A. Roberts, State Controller. It has decided that a foreign corporation is taxable on its capital stock under the corporation tax law of this State if it transacts business in this State, although the business is in the nature of inter-State traffic.

STRQUDSBURG, Penn., June 20 -- Suffering from temporary insanity Miss Susan B. Spring of New York jumped from a Delaware, Lackawanna and Western train near Henryville this afternoon and sustained serious injuries. Miss Spring, who resides at 121 East Thirty-sixth Street, New York, was on her way to the sanitarium at Dansville, N.Y., accompanied by Miss J.L. Hammon, a trained nurse.

Errors and inability to hit the Pittsburg pitcher, Chesbro, caused the defeat of the New Yorks at the Polo Grounds yesterday by the score of 7 to 0. In all, but three hits were made from the delivery of Chesbro, while the error column of the New Yorks showed a total of 7 after the game.

PHILADELPHIA, June 20 -- The stock market was languid to-day, but prices held strong. The volume of sales was about one-third of that of Monday or Tuesday. Not a transaction of Union Traction was recorded until 2 o'clock, when 15 shares sold at 26. Cambria Steel got down to normal, varying less than 1/2 point all day.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 20 -- Harvard, 7; Yale, 3, was the score of the first baseball game of the Harvard-Yale series, which was played on Soldiers Field this afternoon -- a game witnessed by 10,000 persons and finished by the biggest celebration that Cambridge has witnessed in years.

The meeting held in Boston yesterday looking to an intelligent readjustment of the financial affairs of the Mexican Central Railway has consequence suggestive beyond the boundary lines of that one corporation. In this movement shows indication of the disposition upon the part of large capitalists to undertake properly the development of Mexico's phenomenal resources.

PHILADELPHIA, June 20 -- Republican conventions were held here to-day to nominate candidates for county offices to be filled this Fall. The ticket chosen was as follows: District Attorney -- John Weaver; Judges of Court of Common Pleas, No. 5 -- J. Wlllis Martin, Robert Ralston; Controller-John M. Walton; Recorder of Deeds -- W.S. Vare; Clerk of Quarter Sessions -- Henry Brooks; Board of Revision of Taxes -- Alexander Colville, John E. Hanifen.

HENLEY, England, June 20 -- Great interest attached to the first appearance of the Americans on the water this afternoon. They took a spin to the starting point, with the, stream, and back to their quarters. The average rate of their stroke was thirty to thirty-two to the minute. They covered the regular regatta course in 7 1/2 minutes.
GLASGOW, June 20 -- The Shamrock II.'s new mast was stepped to-day.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 20 -- The Hudson River continued rough all the afternoon, and the Pennsylvania crews did not enter their shells at all. Instead, they took a short walk for exercise.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 20 -- The harness racing was again the feature on this, the last day of the Summer fair of the Nassau-Queens Agricultural Society here. In the free-for-all class Democracy, owned in Chester, Penn., broke the track record of 2:14 by pacing the mile in 2:12 3/4. Summary:

Plans were filed with the Building Department yesterday by Robert W. Gibson, architect, for the proposed hotel for women to be built by the Woman's Hotel Company of 1,123 Broadway. The building will be twelve stories in height and will occupy a plot 75 by 197 1/2 feet at 29 East Twenty-ninth Street. It will be of fire-proof construction throughout and will have a facade of brick.

The report of Richard M. Henry, referee in the final accounting of Alfred Hayes, Jr., as assignee of the stock brokerage firm of Seymour, Johnson Co., was filed in the County Clerk's office yesterday.

It was a just boast of the late Laureate that England is A land where, girt with friends or foes, A man may speak the thing he will. But it seems that pretty much, the whole police force of London must have been required on Wednesday evening to secure this privilege for those Englishmen who are known as the "pro-Boers."

Two large windows of stained glass by Mr. Walter Janes are shown at the stained glass shops, 46 Washington Square South, which are destined for Minneapolis. They are to commemorate Mrs. Webster and Mrs. Snyder, two daughters of the Hon. John D. Pillsbury, formerly Governor of Minnesota.

Controller COLER'S indictment of "professional reformers" in the current number of The Independent would be more valuable if it were more specific. He says that the term applies "to those well-meaning but narrow-minded men who are constantly agitating for the correction of political or social conditions in large cities."

Mr. WILLIAM J. GIBSON of this city, for six years counsel of the Treasury Department before the Board of General Appraisers, has been removed from that office and Mr. A.H. WASHBURN of Boston, formerly private secretary to Senator HENRY CAROT LODGE, has been appointed in his place.

Mrs. Anne McGrory, wife of "Billy" McGrory, objects to too much publicity. She was to have continued her examination in supplementary proceedings in the County Court House yesterday, but refused to give testimony in such a public place. A compromise was made, and she continued her testimony in the law office of Campbell Hance.

RICHMOND, Va., June 20 -- The Constitutional Convention to-day decided to hold all of its sessions in Richmond, and, with the possible exception of a few days' recess from time to time, that the sessions shall be continuous. NEW ORLEANS, June 20 -- Quiet prevailed to-day at Shreveport, where "Prophet" Smith and F.D. McLand, negroes, arrested in connection with the murder of John Gray Foster, were lynched last night.
NEWPORT, June 20 -- Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Childs of New York, who have taken the Pumpelly cottage, are here for a short visit, to prepare the place for occupancy.

MATEWAN, West Va., June 20 -- The trouble long anticipated has at last taken place, and the strained relations between the union and non-union miners have resulted in bloodshed. To-day several hundred union miners, who were on strike, marched in a body against the Maratime mines of this place, where non-union men were at work.

CLEVELAND, June 20 -- Contrary to general expectation, harmony prevailed at the Republican county convention to-day. Senator Hanna occupied a seat on the platform and made a strong speech in favor of peace between the two factions of the party.

GALE'S FERRY, Conn., June 20 -- All four Yale crews were out on the river for three-quarters of an hour to-night, but the work of the 'Varsity and freshmen was light, because both crews still show the effects of the grueling four-mile row of Tuesday night.
Every now and then some question comes up as to the chagres of athelsm and infidelity made against Thomas Jefferson.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The Navy Department has taken cognizance of the action of the commander of the battleship Massachusetts in going through Hell Gate to-day on his way from New York to Newburyport.

KALAMAZOO, Mich., June 20 -- United States Senator Julius C. Burrows, Chairman of the Committee on Elections and Privileges, says he will prepare a constitutional amendment to be introduced at the next session of Congress to remedy the evil of non-representation in the Senate when a State Legislature like that of Delaware fails to elect.

With her big mainsail and spinnaker drawing like a team of wild horses, H.S. Redmond's British yawl Ailsa sailed home a winner over Percy Chubb's old cup defender Vigilant by five minutes in the fifty-fifth annual regatta of the New York Yacht Club yesterday.

"It is a damned outrage," said Justice Jerome last night when his attention was drawn to the sentence of ten days each imposed yesterday by Judge Warren W. Foster on four gamblers captured in a raid on the gambling house at 111 East Fourteenth Street last April.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Representative L.F. Livingston of Georgia has come out in direct opposition to Chairman Jones of the Democratic National Committee in stating his opinion as to what will be the dominant issue in the next Congressional campaign.

The legal fight between Frank B. Weyant, a ranch owner, living near Lincoln, Neb., and his brother, Henry S. Weyant of Brooklyn, for the possession of the former's child, has been won by the father. Yesterday the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, rendered a decision reversing Justice Maddox in the case and awarding to the father, Frank B. Weyant, the custody of his daughter, Gladys, an infant.

Emma Gerlandt, seven years old, who lives with her widowed mother Lizzie at 1,766 Second Avenue, was playing last evening in a pile of sand near the subway at Second Avenue and Ninety-third Street with Frieda Kaufmann and her sister Lillie, both of whom live in the rear part of the third floor in the same house as Emma, when a Second Avenue car approached.

LONDON, June 21 -- The Right Hon. Herbert H. Asquith, the ex-Liberal Home Secretary, speaking at a Liberal dinner last evening, protested against the pro-Boer resolutions adopted at Queen's Hall on Wednesday evening being accepted as a pronouncement of the Liberal Party. He declared that Boer independence was impossible, and said the Liberals favored a free, federated South Africa, on the lines of Canada and Australia

BUFFALO, June 20 -- The eighth annual convention of the New York State Bankers' Association was called to order this morning by the President, John B. Butcher of Pawling. After prayer by Bishop Walker, the reports of the various officers were received. President Dutcher's report dealt with the welfare of the association and the principal events of the last year bearing upon the financial situation.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., June 20 -- There were riotous times near the Pond Tool and Machine Works here to-day. Riotous demonstrations occurred at noon, and again this evening, and on the latter occasion four arrests were made.

LONDON, June 20 -- George Edwardes's bay colt Santoi, by Queen's Birthday-Merry Wife, won the Gold Cup, value 1,000 sovereigns, with 3.000 sovereigns in specie in addition, at the Ascot meeting to-day. The distance for this race is about two miles and a half. William C. Whltney's four-year-old brown colt Kilmarnock II. (bred in the United State, L,. Reiff,) was second.

BALTIMORE, June 20 -- The Seaboard group was in heavy demand to-day; the preferred went considerably above the highest it ever before attained, while the common was carried for the first time above the best figure attained during the boom period of last Spring. Nashville Railway issues came into sudden prominence to-day, by reason of the termination of a network of litigation in favor of the company.

St Joseph, Mo., is the seat of an industry quite sui generis. It is the teaching of canary birds to sing some particular song instead of running scales from daylight until dark, as has been their wont. This genius in ornithological voice culture taught one of his pupils to sing "Yankee Doodle," und has recently sold the bird in Chicago for $1,200.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- A short time ago a Republican member of the House of Representatives who has rendered conspicuous service on the Invalid Pension Committee, when the fact was mentioned that a certain officer in the Union Army from New Hampshire had applied for a pension, declared with savage emphasis: "I'll give you $10 for every veteran you'll find in New Hampshire who has not been pensioned already."

PHILADELPHIA, June 20 -- The annual cricket match between the veterans of New York and Philadelphia was played here to-day on the ground of the Belmont Cricket Club, at Elmwood, and resulted in a victory for the Quaker City aggregation by 75 runs. The score:

Yesterday was an off day in the metropolitan championship lawn tennis tournament at the West Side Tennis Club for both of the semi-final matches in the championship men's singles were too one-sided to be interesting. Little found Talbot rather easy, and Wyeth was a poor match for Paret.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 20 -- Palmer J. Jones, the Principal of the Port Washington School, was attacked by highwaymen while riding late last night on his bicycle to his home, at Manhasset. Two men sprang out from behind trees on the roadside and one of them struck him with a club, or some kind of a weapon, inflicting a severe cut on his head.

MANILA, June 20 -- Washington has been asked for an appropriation of $10,000 to defray the expenses of fifty Filipino teachers, who are to study for a year in normal schools of America, these schools having offered them free tuition.

The golf contest at Glen Cove continued and had also a large attendance of those interested in the women's metropolitan championship. In fact, the amusements of society just now are so closely allied with sport that the names of those present at any of the daily events reads like a list of those present at some great town entertainment in Winter.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Several New York tea dealers to-day petitioned the District Supreme Court for a writ of certiorari against the Secretary of the Treasury and the Unlted States Board of Tea Experts to require the production of the acts, proceedings, and regulations of the board in selecting, preparing, and submitting to the Secretary the standard samples of teas for the year 1901.

KIEL, June 20 -- A monument to the Great Elector was unveiled to-day in the Naval Academy Park here with much ceremony and in the presence of the Emperor and Empress. His Majesty made a speech, in which he again emphasized his wishes and aims in regard to the navy.

The marriage of Edmund Pendleton Kennedy of Virginia and Miss Josephine Marie Martelle of this city, daughter of Dr. John B. Martelle of Burlington, Iowa, was celebrated last evening at 8:30 o'clock in Trinity Chapel, West Twenty-fifth Street, by the Rev. John H. Logie of Trinity Parish. The bride entered the church with her uncle, John Adrian Bowers.

The commission of William J. Gibson as counsel for the Treasury Department before the Board of United States General Appraisers here was revoked yesterday by Attorney General Knox, and A.H. Washburn of Boston was appointed in his place.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Justice Bradley to-day denied the application of Lone Wolf and other Indians for an injunction against the Secretary of the Interior to restrain him from opening the Kiowa, Comanche, and Apache lands in Oklahoma to settlement. The Court held that the question was purely a political one with which the Court had no power to deal.
BOSTON, June 20 -- At the Clearing House to-day money loaned at 2 per cent and New York funds sold at par and 5s discount. Exchanges, $22,435,437; balances, $1,616,486.

CHICAGO, June 20 -- State's Attorney Deneen to-day signed a petition in quo warranto attacking the charter of the Chicago. Masons and Builders' Association on the ground that the association retricts its members to the purchase of brick and stone from certain companies which belong to the Chicago Pressed Brick Association.
CINCINNATI, June 20 -- The sixth annual convention of the National Wholesale Liquor Dealers' Association ended to-day after a most successful meeting.

BELVIDERE, N.J., June 20 -- After plunging three times in the swift current of the Delaware River, and being rescued each time by Deputy Sheriff Cole, Jonathan Hines, a prisoner confined in the Warren County Jail for embezzlement, was safely lodged behind the bars. Hines begged to be let out to do anything that the Sheriff might have to do about the yard, and the Sheriff set him to work whitewashing outside the jail.

Representatives of The Players and The Strollers' Clubs essayed "Hamlet" last night at The Strollers Club. It was what the programme termed "A Shakespearean contest for points." Harrison Blake Hodges of The Players and Edward Fales Coward of The Strollers, supported by a partial cast, gave two scenes from the play, that in which the Dane learns that his father's ghost has appeared, and the scene between Hamlet, the Ghost, and Queen Gertrude.

LONDON, June 21 -- In the course of the discussion of the clauses of the Finance bill in the House of Commons yesterday, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, Sir Michael Hicks-Beach, informed the mover of an amendment providing for a preferential duty on sugar from the British colonies that he had no intention of embarking on such a policy.

CHICAGO, June 20 -- Official confirmation is made by the Illinois Central respecting the Iowa, Central and Minneapolis Railroad deal. The plan contemplates the taking over of the Iowa Central by the Minneapolis and St. Louis on a basis of two shares of the former for one of the latter and the guarantee of a 5 per cent. dividend by the Illinois Central for the securities of the consolidated road.

SARATOGA, N.Y., June 20 -- The Fourth Judicial District Republican Convention to-day accomplished the feat of holding two session and not taking a single vote. The time was devoted to a series of conferences between the eleven delegates and also between the delegates and politicians from all parts of the district.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The recent accident to the ferryboat Northfield, and which terminated so luckily, considering the number of passengers and the excitement which naturally prevailed, has evidently stirred the people of Staten Island as they have not been stirred for years.
WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The Secretary of the Treasury to-day bought $118,000 4 per cent. short-term bonds at 113.3757, and $5,000 short 5s at 109.03.

Fifty men fled for their lives when the rotary of one of the high-tension converters burst on the basement floor of the Edison Heat, Light, and Power Company, in the building extending from 53 Duane Street to 331 Pearl Street, last night.

So far as one can judge the work from this distance, Judge TAFT'S commission is doing it very well. It is making good the President's promise to admit the Filipinos to the largest practicable participation in their own government. The quality of Filipino that it selects must be a subject of very anxious consideration with it.

MONTEREY, Mexico, June 21. -- The action of the Mexican Central Directors at their meeting held yesterday in Boston, in authorizing the purchase by that company of the Monterey and Mexican Gulf Railway, is looked upon here as of great importance.

The Caradoc Press. Recent English catalogues have been predicting a future for the issues of the Caradoc Press, which was established by H.D. and H.G Webb at Bedford Park, Chiswick, England, in the Autumn of 1899. Its first issue was a small calendar for 1900, containing verses by Hesva D. Webb, which went out of print in a week.

That a population of more than 76,000,000, many of whom are of foreign birth or origin, should supply a large market for foreign books is not a surprising fact. The extent of the demand is not very well ascertained, and the trade figures throw only an indirect light on the situation.

Conditions in the outside market yesterday were more favorable than any that have shown recently. The market was broader and more active, and, although there were declines in a few important stocks, most of the list closed above the previous day's figures. Sharp advances occurred in several issues which of late have been somewhat depressed, and the accompanying transactions were larger than those recorded on any recent day.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Last Friday's collision between the ferryboats Mauch Chunk and Northfield at South Ferry calls attention to the condition of affairs that exists there. There are five ferry lines running from that point, and the five ferry slips are adjoining. Beginning on the west, or Battery, side, they are the Staten Island, the New Jersey Central, the Hamilton Avenue, the Atlantic Avenue, and the Thirty-ninth Street lines.
LONDON, June 21. -- Admiral Sir Anthony H. Hoskins is dead.

PAUL REVERE is so conspicuously known in American history as the man who made that famous midnight ride on the eve of the battle of Lexington, for which he is deeply indebted to Longfellow's celebrated poem, that it is almost the exception in associate him with any other act in life.

PHILADELPHIA, June 21. -- The Reading issues saved the Philadelphia market from dullness, most of the buying being in the common stock. There was some demand for the independent steel issues. Indianapolls Passenger Railway was the strongest stock, going from 38 to 41, while the bonds got up to $2, against 79 1/2 a few days ago.

LONDON, June 21 -- John Murray returned to London this week greatly pleased with the result of the fourth International Publishers' Congress at Leipsc. The social side of the meeting, he says, was delightful -- the concert in the Gewandhaus, the dinner trip to Berlin, and last, but not least, the classical Bierabend were incidents to be remembered.

ST. LOUIS, June 21. -- A deal was closed yesterday whereby 31,000 shares, or a controlling interest in the Columbia Lead Company, was purchased by Eastern capitalists at $14 a share, and there is an open bid for the remainder of the stock at the same price. The Columbia Lead Company's property was owned by St. Louis investors.
NEWPORT, June 21. -- Lieut. and Mrs. John F. Hubbard gave a tea on board the training ship Newport this afternoon.

The Surrogates' Court was the scene yesterday of a bitter tilt between two wellknown lawyers. One of these lawyers claimed that he had practically been accused of stealing $97,000, and in a most dramatic manner he demanded that Surrogate Thomas give him an opportunity to vindicate himself.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 21. -- The De Forrest oratorical contest at Yale University took place this afternoon, and the Faculty, as judges, to-night announce that Walter Bruce Howe, 1901, of Washington, D. C., has been awarded the gold medal. His subject was "Louisiana Before 1850."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 21. -- In spite of occasional showers that now and then drove the crowds indoors, to-day's Harvard Class Day exercises were a great success. The feature of the occasion was the programme rendered by the senior class in Sanders Theatre. In these exercises a mild sensation was created by the reference in the speech of F.R. Du Bois, the Ivy orator, to the possible fate of each member of the class.

BOSTON, June 21. -- Action has been brought before Chief Justice Mason, in the equity session of the Suffolk Superior Court, by Charles F. Bruce and others against the Liquid Air Power and Automobile Company, a West Virginia corporation, with a factory in Cambridge, asking for the appointment of a receiver.

Wardman Bissert of Capt. Diamond's precinct, who is under indictment for levying blackmail on Lena Schmitt, a disorderly house keeper, will not be tried next week, as the District Attorney had arranged.

HOUSTON, Texas, June 21. -- A special train bearing the Houston Cavalry Company and a part of the Light Guard has just left hero for Trinity, Texas, where the remainder of the Light Guard are guarding a negro named Spencer, who was to-day identified as having attacked a woman last week.

The field af Icelandic literature is one in which the fancy may roam with great delight. Messrs. Eirikr Magnusson and William Morris have conferred lasting pleasure upon English readers by their translations of the works of the remote Northern isle. Their English rendering of the Volsunga Saga is well known to all students at mythology and elementary legends, as well as to lovers of epic poetry.
BERLIN, June 21. -- At the Kiel regatta to-day seventy-four yachts participated in the races.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., June 21. -- Orphans in Roman Catholic asylums cannot be deprived of secular education. The effort of James Sargent, leader of the A. P. A., to gain this end, has been defeated. Supreme Court Justice Rich has handed down a decision denying the writ of injunction restraining the Board of Education of this city from paying salaries to four sisters in St. Mary's Orphan Asylum, petitioned for by Mr. Sargent.

The New Yorks played much better baseball yesterday than they have been playing for some time. Taylor also pitched a fine game of ball, and, in consequence, the New Yorks broke even with Pittsburg on the series, winning yesterday's contest at the Polo Grounds by the score of 3 to 2. Pittsburg, however, came dangerously near tying the score in the ninth inning.

LYNBROOK, N.Y., June 21. -- The Sag Harbor express, due here at 4:20, killed two children between here and Valley Stream. They were Rosie Metzler, nine years old, and John Metzler, five years old, children of Mrs. Rosie Metzler, a widow living midway between the two villages.

CAMP TOWNSEND, Peekskill, June 21. -- Camp Townsend is likely to be a very quiet place after the Seventh is gone, for it is hardly probable the First Regiment, which comes to-morrow, will be engaged in as many battles. Throughout the week just closing these hills of the Highlands have rung with rifle shots and artillery fire, until mother birds have been driven almost frantic.

ROME, June 21. -- Cardinal Gibbons started this morning for Florence, for a stay of a week. At the railway station he bade farewell to the Procurator General and to the brothers of St. Sulpice, whose guest he was while here.

BELOW will be found a second series of letters from John Jacob Astor relating to his trade in furs in the Mohawk Valley in 1791 and 1792, a first series having appeared in these columns on May 25. They are addressed to Peter Smith.

YOKOHAMA, June 21. -- Hoshi Toru, who was Minister of Communications in the last Ito Cabinet, was stabbed to-day at a meeting of the City Assembly, and died shortly afterward. He was formerly Japanese Minister at Washington and President of the House.

To the Editor of The "New York Times: That old, acidulous compound John Randolph of Roanoke, rising in his seat in Congress when some measure for the creation of a public debt was under discussion, said, "Mr. Speaker, I have discovered the philosopher's stone; it is, 'Pay as you go.' "

Threatening weather with about the cheapest programme of races of a consolation character had no effect toward keeping down the attendance at the Sheepshead Bay race track yesterday. Both grand and field stands were comfortably filled, the public seemingly having determined to have as large a share as possible of the remarkable success that has fallen to the lot of the favorites since the meeting opened.

As far as can be learned, Mrs. Alma L. Larnes, who disappeared on Thursday while in the custody of a nurse, had not been found up to a late hour last night. At the Hotel Margaret, Brooklyn, where Mrs. Larnes had been stopping, it was said she had not returned. William C. Beecher, her counsel, was not at his home when a reporter called, and it could not be learned when he would return.

BALTIMORE, June 21. -- The market to-day was absorbed chiefly in Seaboards. The preferred reached 54 and the common 31 1/2. At those points the market turned downward under the influence of profit taking. The stocks closed below the highest for the day, but each secured a net gain.

WASHINGTON, June 21. -- Walter Schumann, United States Consul at Mainz, Germany, has sent a special report to the State Department on the German leather industry. He says: "From year to year the German leather industry becomes less profitable. This is due almost entirely to American competition.

READING, Penn., June 21. -- Shortly before noon to-day 925 employes of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad Company's car shops here, blacksmiths, boilermakers, and laborers, went on a strike. It is generally known that these men struck from sympathy with the 3,000 Reading Iron Company employes who went on strike about five weeks ago.

WASHINGTON, June 21. -- "This season," said a leading Washington bookseller, "is not only interesting for the activity of buyers at the dullest time of the year witt, us, when many persona given over to book-buying are away on Summer vacations, but for the reason that buying is directed to a greater number of authors.

LONDON, June 12. -- The decision in the action which Pearsons' have brought against Mr. Hall Caine will be awaited with much interest. As every one knows, the Penrson firm bought Mr. Caine's new serial for the sum of u2,080, and published several installments of it in The Lady's Magazine.

WORCESTER, Mass., June 21. -- Charles S. Porter of Detroit, Mich., defeated Nat Butler and Benny Monroe in the three-cornered fifteen-mile motor-paced race at the Coliseum this evening. Porter's time for the race was 25:16 3-5.

Starring of 1455 Massachusetts Avenue, to-day returned a verdict of not guilty and the defendant was set at liberty.

John Keller in the streets of Arlington on Sunday morning, Feb. 3 last, was found guilty yesterday afternoon of assault with intent to kill, as charged in the indictment.

WICHITA, Kan., June 21. -- Word was received in this city to-day to the effect that the Indians in the Kiowa-Comanche country had held a council and decided to use force if necessary to keep the whites from settling upon their lands when the President declares them open for settlement.

Miss Genevieve Hecker, the woman's metropolitan golf championship holder, and Miss Ruth Underhill, the National champion two years ago, will meet to-day on the Nassau Country Club links, at Glen Cove, to determine who shall hold the metropolitan championship for the coming year.

The Jersey jury was as singly bent as the Jersey Judge upon doing justice according to law. The complete failure of the attempts of the defense to obfuscate their minds was shown in the promptitude with which the verdict was rendered.

LONDON, June 21. -- Although the supply of money was fairly large to-day the demand was more active and will probably be more pronounced on the approach of the half-year end. Discounts were inclined to be harder and there was not much business done. The allotments of the Treasury bills checked the downwardness.

PHILADELPHIA, June 21. -- Hugh Jennings, the long-sought-for and much-talked-of ex-Brooklyn baseball player, arrived in Philadelphia to-day, and, much to the surprise of the baseball enthusiasts, made his appearance in uniform at the Philadelphia National League grounds. Jennings and John I. Rogers, Treasurer of the club, had been together in the morning, and before the interview had ended the red-haired infielder had signed a contract to play with the Phillies.
BOSTON, June 21. -- At the Clearing House to-day money between the banks was in good supply at 2 per cent. New York funds sold at par. Exchanges, $27,395,876; balances, $3,621,518.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In to-day's TIMES there appears a letter under the heading "Temperance Union's Merits," in which the writer made an assertion that" the Old Testament plainly teaches total abstinence, and Jesus came not to destroy its teaching," The writer was obviously wrongly informed of the Old Testament's teaching regarding the use of wine and manufactured strong drinks.

PATERSON, N.J., June 21. -- Exploding fireworks wrecked the four-story frame building at 440 Main Street, this city, shortly after noon to-day, killing a number of persons, and injuring many others. It is impossible to say just how many persons lost their lives, but it is known that at least eighteen perished.

WASHINGTON, June 21. -- Most of the time of the Cabinet to-day was spent in a discussion of the action of the Treasury Department in imposing a countervailing duty on certain Russian products. Secretary Gage explained in detail the action which the department had taken, and the Cabinet unanimously approved of what he had done.

The Pennsylvania contingent were on the water only, the freshmen going out first about 3 o'clock.

Foederer, one of those to whom the franchises were granted, offering him $500,000 for the franchises, in addition to giving to the city the sum already offered.

Johnson, belong to the Society of St. Paul; three of them, the Rev. Messrs, McCool, Mullen, and Delany, are from the Archdiocese of Boston, and the Rev. Edward Clarke of New York is unassigned.

PHILADELPHIA, June 22 -- The local stock market was dull and heavy at the opening, and suffered from absenteeism, but in the final trading there was some activity. PHILADELPHIA, June 22 -- The opening of the annual polo tournament for the cups offered by the Philadelphia Country Club at Bala this afternoon drew a crowd of nearly 6,000. The programme originally called for matches between the teams of the Philadelphia Country Club, but at the last moment Rockaway entered, with the result that there were two of the liveliest matches ever witnessed on local fields.

NEWARK, N.J., June 22 -- Floyd A. McFarland beat Arthur W. Ross in a twenty-mile motor paced race at the annual race meet of the Atalanta Wheelmen of this city at the Vailsburg track to-day. The finish was one of the most sensational ever seen on the track, as McFarland won by only about three yards, and had to ride the last mile in 1:26, breaking the local track record.

HENLEY, England, June 22 -- The warm weather drew great crowds to the Henley course this afternoon. The Pennsylvanians were below Regatta Island again, but they rowed over the course at a slow stroke.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provided that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage, except in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes payment of the mortgage.

BERLIN, June 22 -- The so-called Kiel week, which began Thursday, has thus far been interesting. But the wind has been unsatisfactory. Yesterday at the great yacht race all of the seventy-four yachts contesting were becalmed when but a few hundred yards from the goal after three hours' splendid sailing.

PITTSBURG, Penn., June 22 -- Contracts have been awarded by the Colonial Steel Company for the buildings and a portion of the big crucible steel plant to be erected by James W. Brown, George A. Howe, and other former stockholders of the Crucible Steel Company of America, at Colonia, a new town on the Ohio River adjoining Monaca.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., June 22 -- Locomotives were used as engines of war in a battle between two corporations early this morning. The Iron Mountain Railway Company attempted to lay rails on four blocks of Wharf Street, South St. Louis. Success would mean the cutting off of the Wiggins's Ferry Company, whose tracks lie between the new tracks of the Iron Mountain Road and the Mississippi River.

CAMP TOWNSEND, Peekskill, June 22 -- Saturday has brought about the usual change in the personnel of Camp Townsend. The Seventh has given place to the First, and thirteen companies, from as many different cities and towns of the State, have been concentrated here for a week's tour of duty.

LONDON, June 22 -- In a tentative, easy-going sort of way the Cabinet has begun to consider the Nicaragua treaty matter. Lord Pauncefote has explained many things to Lord Lansdowne, the Foreign Secretary, and the latter is once more grappling with the problem. It is needless to say that the Foreign Office has no intention of hurrying, and in the course of a month or so it may come to a decision.

To the Editor of The New York Times: This seems to be the age of "commissions." We incessantly hear of reform and probing committees until the public becomes thoroughly disgusted with them, and now a new committee -- a "milking" commission -- has sprung up, which intends to say much and do nothing.

During the past week people traveling back and forth from West Hoboken to Hoboken have been witnessing a daily transformation, which completely bewildered them. Painted in large white letters on the side of the cliff the passengers in the cars one day saw "St. John's Excursion August 8."

Despite the declaration that he would appeal, made by Lawyer Van Winkle at the conclusion of the trial of Thomas G. Barker, who was found guilty on Friday of attempting to kill the Rev. John Keller, no definite decision on the matter has yet been reached. Mr. Van Winkle yesterday made the following statement:

Mrs. Annie Holley and George Lotz, alleged elopers, were arrested in Guttenberg late Saturday afternoon by Constable John Bancier and brought to Jersey City that night. The couple, it is claimed, eloped from the home of Theodore J. Holley at 19 Straight Street, Jersey City, one week ago.

CAMP TOWNSEND, Peekskill, June 23 -- Until to-day the First Regiment has not come wholly under the eye of Col. Robert P. Emmet, since it was in Honolulu, during the Spanish-American war, if the Admiral Dewey parade can be excepted, for the Thirty-third Company of Walton did not arrive last night until darkness had fallen.

From The London Globe. A small child was asked the other day who were the survivors from the flood. "Noah, Shem, and Ham," she said. "Yes," replied her mother, "and who else? " The child paused for a moment in thought. Then a brilliant idea struck her, "and," she added, "Joan of Arc."

BOSTON, June 23 -- While coming into the harbor this forenoon on her regular trip from Maine ports, the steamer City of Bangor of the Bangor Steamship Company's line during a dense fog ran down and sunk the naphtha launch Estelle, which had anchored off Deer Island Beacon directly in the steamer's path.

BLUEFIELD, West Va., June 23 -- This entire region has just been visited by a flood the extent of which, in point of loss of life and damage to property can only be roughly estimated. Shortly after midnight yesterday morning a heavy down-pour of rain began, accompanied by a severe electrical storm, and steadily increased in violence until 10 o'clock A.M., then ceasing for several hours, and again starting up with renewed violence.

From The Burlington (Vt.) Free Press. The greatest find of relics ever known on Lake Champlain was made Wednesday afternoon by J.G. Falcon of Evanston, Ill., and a force of men who have been employed for some time by the city water works. Mr. Falcon is a diver of much experience, and has devoted some time to searching for relics and doing all sorts of work under water.

The seven prisoners captured by Capt. Cooney of the West Thirty-seventh Street Police Station in rooms at 239 West Thirty-first Street on Saturday night were discharged in the West Side Court yesterday morning.

CHICAGO, June 23 -- According to Zeal, the organ of the Federation of Young People's Societies, cigarette smoking among women is growing to be a menace in this country. The paper quotes a manufacturer saying:

From The London News. Another historic sight is added to those which draw the traveler to the French capital. It may be described with accuracy as a human document. A coachman who appeared before one of the courts in Paris on Thursday was found to have his person decorated with a complete record of the Dreyfus affair, tattooed in blue, red, green, and black.

Adalbert S. Hay was the eldest son of the Secretary of State, and was born while the latter was living in Cleveland, about twenty-five years ago. His second name is Stone, which he bears in memory of the late Amasa Stone, his maternal grandsire.He was educated in the private schools of Cleveland and prepared at St. Paul's Academy, in Concord, N.H., for Yale.

COLUMBIA, S.C., June 23 -- The striking machinists and their sympathizers attacked the Southern Railway's shops in this city about an hour before daylight this morning and caused the first bloodshed in a strike in South Carolina. The rioters were all masked. Between 100 and 150 men marched silently through the streets and broke into the wooden fence surrounding the shops.

ROANOKE, Va., June 23 -- Much anxiety was felt here to-day on receipt of the report that a cloudburst and flood had swept over the Elkhorn coal region in West Virginia. This territory is near the Virginia line, and is about 125 miles west of Ronaoke and 25 miles west of Bluefield, West Va. The region visited by the flood is said to be devastated, and the Pocahontas coal fields are reported in ruins.

NEWPORT, June 23 -- The yawl-rigged yacht Navahoe, with the mast formerly used by the sloop yacht Defender, was tried for the first time this afternoon with a run up the bay for a rigging test. Everything worked well, and the boat showed a considerable gain in speed under her new spar, which she used with her old set of sails.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Secretary Hay learned of the death of his son within an hour and a half of the tragedy through Secretary Cortelyou. The latter had been called up on the long-distance telephone at his residence about 3 o'clock in the night by Proprietor Mosely of the New Haven House, the scene of the tragedy.

From The London News. We shall soon be in a position to congratulate M. Jules Verne on the achievement of his century. " I am now beginning my ninety-ninth book," he said, in an interview which we report to-day. It is a magnificent record, and another year, at his ordinary rate of production, should sea the novelist past the goal of three figures.

BERLIN, June 3 -- A slight improvement set in last week on the Boerse, beginning Thursday, which was the first day in some time that no failures or more important financial difficulties were reported. The general tone of the market improved slightly, and a quite bullish movement followed, on London advices, in Canadian Pacifies.

Michael J. Muldoon, alias James Monroe, whose picture is said to be No. 4,856 in the Rogues' Gallery, and who says he lives at 141 West Forty-second Street, and Thomas Kerr, who gives the Hotel Vendome as his residence, were arraigned before Magistrate Cornell in the Centre Street Police Court yesterday and held in $1,000 bail each for examination on a charge of carrying on a scheme to swindle.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Surgeon General Wyman has issued a general circular to medical officers of the Marine Hospital Service calling special attention to the importance of insects as factors in conveying diseases. The circular says there is no longer doubt as to the relation of the mosquito to malarial diseases and to filariasis.

The programme for the Brighton Beach Racing Association's Summer meeting, to open on Saturday, July 6, and continue for twenty-five days, has been issued. The schedule for the running of the stake fixtures is as follows:

In a report to the National Civil Service Reform League the committee appointed to investigate the condition of the Federal civil service calls attention to an example of the recurrence of evils which existed in connection with the census ten years ago, and which are attributed to the system of patronage appointment and partisan control.

Henry Fink, President of the Norfolk and Western Railway Company, was seen in his apartments at the Plaza Hotel last evening in reference to the West Virginia disaster. Mr. Pink was in receipt of a dispatch from General Manager L.E. Johnson of the system, Mr. Johnson's headquarters are in Roanoke, Va., from which place he telegraphed.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 23 -- The First Presbyterian Church of this village celebrated the seventy-fifth anniversary of its existence to-day. The anniversary sermon this morning was preached by the Rev. J. Ritchia Smith of Harrisburg, Penn., who was pastor of the church here for twenty-two years.

Following are the returns of foreign commerce at the Port of New York for the week ended Friday last, as compared with the corresponding week last year. In the case of the exports of general merchandise the returns are for the week ended Tuesday:

Notwithstanding the fact that surplus reserves were further decreased by Saturday's bank statement and are now down below the seven-million mark -- the lowest figure in any week but one of the present year -- Wall Street in no wise is affrighted; is not in the least concerned over the money market outlook.

WHITESTONE, L.I., June 23 -- The Second Division of the First Naval Battalion, Naval Militia. State of New York, carried off the honors in the rowing and swimming races in connection with the reunion of the battalion at Point View Park, near this place, to-day, winning first place in the two cutter races and the first four places in the swimming race.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Pension Commissioner Evans was not surprised to-day to read the dental by Gen. D.E. Sickles of the assertion made here yesterday by "Corporal" Tanner, that Gen. Sickles has in his possession a promise made in writing by the Republican National Committee, that Commissioner Evans was to be removed immediately after the election.

The Central Federated Union was wrought up into a state of white-hot indignation yesterday over the granting by the Park Commissioners to a speculator of the privilege of supplying chairs in Central Park to be let out for a small sum to parties who want to keep together.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 23 -- The colony of college oarsmen training for the races on July 2 was augmented to-day by the arrival of Cornell University's delegation, comprising a Varsity eight-oared crew, a 'Varsity four, and a freshman eight. The Ithacans brought the eightoared cedar shell in which the 'Varsity rowed last year, and which is now being used by the freshmen, and also a new cedar shell for the 'Varsity.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Rev. Charles H. Eaton objects to Sunday laws based on religious grounds, but favors Sunday laws based on economic grounds. He says: "The man who works six days a week should by law be assured of rest on the seventh. This should be a National law."

PEKING, June 23 -- There has been, no meeting of the Ministers of the foreign powers at Peking since last Tuesday, but the Ministers themselves all profess satisfaction with the present course of events.

In disclaiming knowledge of, participation in, and sympathy with the third party movement started at Kansas City Mr. BRYAN should not be taken too seriously. It may very well be that there is "not a word of truth" in the premature report that it is organized to maintain his perennial candidacy for the office of President, or that he is the author of its declaration of principles.

Jersey City had a case early yesterday morning that looked for a few moments as though it might be in a measure a repetition of the Barker drama. Mrs. Augusta Edwards, thirty years old, of 76 Grand Street, went to New York on Saturday to visit a relative who is ill. She was detained until after midnight, and she reached the Cortlandt Street Ferry in time to catch the 2 o'clock A.M. boat.

SAYVILLE, L.I., June 23 -- William K. Vanderbilt's mansion Idle Hour, which was only recently completed, to replace the one destroyed by fire a couple of years ago, had its basement flooded last night. There was a heavy and continued rainstorm during the night.

PATERSON, N.J., June 23 -- A woman supposed to be a Mrs. Drehier attempted suicide late last night by jumping into the Passaic River 100 yards south of the Sixth Avenue Bridge. Whether Drehier is her proper name, or where she lives is not known, as she refuses to reveal her identity.

OCEAN GROVE, June 23 -- The Summer religious season in this Methodist resort began to-day, and the several meetings held on the camp grounds were attended by thousands of worshippers from all parts of the country.
NEW HAVEN, June 23 -- Yale's programme for commencement week opened to-day when President Hadley delivered his Baccalaureate address on " Success and Fellowship."

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 23 -- The Republican State Convention, which will convene in this city to-morrow, will renominate for second terms Gov. George K. Nash, Lieut. Gov. John A. Caldwell, Attorney General John M. Sheets, State Treasurer Isaac B. Cameron G.W. Johnson, member of the State Board of Public Works, also will be renominated.

From The London News. Now that the "sailor " hat is an established thing for a lady's costume when riding, it is of interest to look back upon the history of the riding habit. Time was when women rode in a costume little different from that they wore on ordinary occasions, with none of those points of resemblance to men's garments that are universal now.
From The London Express. Is there any quarter of the globe left to explore, apart from tire Polar regions? The answer is yes, despite the diverse wanderings of intrepid travelers.

A correspondent calls attention to the fact that work is being carried on at the site of the new Stock Exchhange on Sundays, and comments on the fact, pointing out that it is of interest in the face of the discussion with reference to Sunday golf, baseball, and other games. He inquires why the Stock Exchange should not be required to observe the law as well as others.

From The London News's Paris Telegram. Comte Henri de la Vaulx, the champion French balloonist, famous for his trip in the air from Paris to a place in Russia beyond Kieff. had a remarkable experience recently. His balloon landed him in Paris, and he says he wishes he may never land here again.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 23 -- The Newport Yacht Racing Association has completed all arrangements for the four races for the ninety-footers to be sailed off Newport July 6, July 8, July 10, and July 12. A cup will be presented to the winner of each race provided two or more yachts start. The races will be sailed under the racing rules of the New York Yacht Club, except for the following modifications:

SOUTH NORWALK, Conn., June 23 -- Col. Thomas E. Sloan of New York City, the Major of the Old Guard, was drowned in a yachting accident off Keyser's Island, South Norwalk Harbor, this afternoon. Mr. Sloan and his daughter went out in a thirty-foot sloop belonging to William Edwards of this city, and when rounding the island noticed the approach of a squall.

There can be little doubt that the publicity which has attended the conversion of Mrs. Thomas H. Blair and Miss Lizzie Dickinson to the Mormon faith has considerably interfered with the rurther success of the missionaries in obtaining converts to that faith in the Bronx.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 23 -- John Hay, Secretary of State, after a trip of nearly nine hours from Washington to New Haven, and nearly prostrated by grief at the untimely end of his son, here this morning, reached this city at 5:45 o'clock this evening. He was accompanied by his secretary.

TOPEKA, Kan., June 23 -- The Democratic State Central Committee of Kansas has refused an invitation from the Populists to Join in the formation of a new fusion party under a distinct name. This action was taken last night at a meeting here of the Democratic committeee, presided over by J. Mack Love, State Chairman.

Six detectives are at work investigate the circumstances of the death yesterday morning of Robert Harper, thirty-nine years old, of 401 East Forty-eighth Street, as the result of a fractured skuil, and five men are under arrest in the East Fifty-first Street Police Station on suspicion of knowing something of what the police declare to be a case of homicide.

Copyright, 1901. LONDON, June 23 -- Most people were surprised that there was no pressure for money on the consols installment one day last week. Had the market not told so much about it, the occurrence would have slipped by unnoticed. Why was this?

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 23 -- The Norfolk and Western Railroad officials here have no information regarding the disaster in West Virginia, beyond the fact that great damage has been done to the road in the Pocahontas district, a number of bridges having been washed away. Orders have been issued to accept no perishable freight for shipment to points on the eastern end of the line.
At Weehawken yesterday the West New York nine defeated the team of the Murray Hill Baseball Club of New York by a score of 8 to 2.

There is something confusing and apparently investigable about the award of the contract for the masonry of the new Public Library. At the meeting of the board the Mayor insisted upon the acceptance of a bid which was not the lowest. The reason he assigned was that the bid he preferred specified the marble which the architects preferred, and that he deferred to their judgment.

From The Chicago Record-Herald. "Gentlemen," said Tomlinson, the official photographer, " I struck a curious phenomenon to-day, a strange reminiscence of the past, a relic of barbarism so absurd, so ridiculous -- "

CHICAGO, June 24. -- Fred Austorf, a farmer, would have bought the Auditorium Hotel this morning if he had had $100 instead of only $50 in his old wallet. When he arrived in the city he induced Thomas Hughes to show him the sights. After they had visited a number of places, Hughes took him to the Auditorium, which he offered to sell for $100.
LONDON, June 24. -- Charles Kensington Salaman, the composer, is dead.

HUNTINGTON, West Va., June 24. -- Today a posse of Deputy United States Marshals, led by A.C. Hufford of Bluefield, were fired on by the striking miners and forced to flee from the coal fields at Matewan. Yesterday afternoon the deputies, under the leadership of A.C. Hufford, set out from Bluefield to reach the scene of the miners' riots.
