Several hundred east side children were clustered in the street at East Broadway and Jefferson Street for at least two hours yesterday afternoon, waiting with impatience for the Educational Alliance roof garden to be opened. The opening had been set for 3 o'clock, but long before that time boys and girls in all sorts of attire and of all ages and colors began to congregate in front of the building.

NEWARK, N.J., June 24. -- Vice Chancellor Emery announced his decision this morning not to allow the filing of a petition by the International Power Company, seeking to have the recent sale of the Rogers Locomotive Works in Paterson to Elliott G. Smith and Francis H. Holran for $602,000 reopened.

PATERSON, N.J., June 24. -- The investigation of the explosion in the Rittenberg store last Friday, which caused the death of seventeen persons and injury to many others, began this morning. Coroner John S. Yates, impanelled the following jury: Alderman Joseph S. Lang, foreman; Joseph Mosley, John D.S. Goodridge, Adam Jeffrey, Fred E. Beggs, James M. Denton.

WASHINGTON, June 24. -- The State Department this afternoon received from Mr. Babcock, confidential secretary of Secretary Hay, who was with him in New Haven, a telegram stating that the funeral of Adelbert S. Hay will be held at Cleveland, and will be strictly private. No official representatives will be expected.
The plans for the first international trust to be actually launched are almost ready for announcement. An official of the National Salt Company said yesterday:

PHILADELPHIA, June 24. -- The stock market was dull, with the exception of Electric Storage Battery and Reading common. The former was the topic of the day. This stock, which gradually has been aspiring to a higher level, moved in earnest to-day, advancing 5 1/4 to 74 for the common and 7 for the preferred, the former yielding in the final trading.

LONDON, June 25. -- A dispatch to The Times from Peking, dated June 24, says that all the Ministers of the foreign powers, with the exception of Sir Ernest M. Satow, the British Minister, have agreed to the Russian proposal to increase the Chinese tariff on imports to 10 per cent. in the event of a deficiency in the means of payment of the indemnity.

We have heard a dreadful story about the Hon. GEORGE P. HOAR, senior Senator from the State of Massachusetts, which nothing but a stem and cold-blooded sense of public duty could extort from us. It will be remembered that Senator HOAK Joined with Senator PLATT of New York and Senator PLATT of Connecticut in requesting the appointment of Senator LODGE'S private secretary. Mr. A.H. WASHBURN, as counsel before the Board of General Appraisers.

The injunction issued in Milwaukee, Wis., against the general organization of the machinists will, when it comes up for hearing, afford a better opportunity than has yet been had to get an authoritative declaration of the courts as to the rights and duties of trades unions and their members.

L.J. Phillips Co. have sold for Benjamin Stern to an investor, for $350,000, the plot of eight lots at the northeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Ninety-seventh Street, being 100 feet in the avenue and 200 feet in the street.

There is nothing new in the latest attack of the pension attorneys on Commissioner EVANS except that they seem to have won over the venerable DANIEL E. SICKLES, and to have induced him to take the thankless post of leader in their wholly disreputable movement.

WASHINGTON, June 24. -- Acting upon the unanimous recommendation of the naval board of awards, Secretary Long to-day approved the designs for the two medals provided for by Congress to commemorate the achievements of the United States Navy in the campaign in the West Indies during the Spanish-American war.

WASHINGTON, June 24. -- Secretary Long to-day administered a reprimand to Paymaster John R. Martin of the navy, who recently was convicted by court-martial at the Philadelphia Navy Yard of a violation of the statute in regard to the use of Government funds for private purposes. Mr. Long's letter makes some general statements as to the need of scrupulous care in handling Government funds.

Considerable activity showed in the out side market yesterday, but prices were more Irregular than they were at the close of the week. Some of the more active issues advanced and closed with net grains while others were under selling pressure and closed below Saturday's final quotations.

HUNTINGTON, West Va., June 24. -- The high water in the Tug River caused by the storm along its headwaters on Saturday is unprecedented in the history of that region, and the damage to property along the Elkhorn and Dry Fork and down the Tug River to Us mouth is believed to be very heavy.

WASHINGTON, June 24. -- Republicans here who have been opposed to any change in the Pension Bureau that will let down the bars and bring on a repetition of the scandalous conditions that compelled the removal of Commissioner Tanner, say that the production of the so-called "pledge" must inevitably defeat the very purpose in view in producing it.

ROANOKE, Va., June 24. -- Such reports as have reached this place from the storm-swept coal regions in West Virginia leave the loss of life by the flood a matter of conjecture. The most conservative estimates of the number of dead range from 50 to 200. One of the officials of the Norfolk and Western Road places the number drowned at seventy-five, and the property loss at $500,000.

The heat of yesterday deterred many from coming to the city for their regular Monday rendezvous at the different restaurants. Mr. and Mrs. John R. Drexel are in town for a short time. The Sultana dropped anchor at the harborage near Twenty-sixth Street, East River, in the morning. This afternoon there will be quite a number going out to Greenwich, where, at Indian Field, Miss Marie Melville Truesdale and Richard Bissell will be married.
CHARLESTON, West Va., June 24. -- After a consultation late to-night with Secretary of State Dawson and Adjt. Gen Baker, Gov. White issued the following appeal to West Virginians only:
BOSTON, June 24. -- Money loaned at the Clearing House to-day at 2 per cent. and New York funds sold at par. Exchanges, $16,433,317; balances, $1,889,498.
"The veterans demand that Pension Commissioner Evans shall not be retained in office, and I say 'Amen,'" Gen. Daniel E. Sickles remarked to a TIMES reporter yesterday.

The Rev. Dr. Alfred W. Moment, pastor of Immanuel Church, Brooltlyn, whose alleged transgressions have agitated the Brooklyn Presbytery for nearly a year, yesterday returned to the Presbytery his call to Immanuel Church, pleaded guilty to the charges of untruthfulness and contumacy that had been preferred against him, and threw himself upon the mercy of the Presbytery.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 24. -- Yale's class day morning dawned beautifully and the hearts of all seniors and their hosts of visitors were filled with happiest anticipations for the successful carrying out of the various features of the programme.

Police Justice James J. Murphy, who presides in the Second Criminal Court, Jersey City, visited the West Side Driving Park on Saturday to witness a series or private trotting matches. He afterward denounced both the races and the management. When he opened court yesterday the first prisoner arraigned was Joseph Smith. He was charged with drunkenness.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 24. -- This morning, John Hyslop, the official measurer of the New York Yacht Club, went on board the Constitution and measured her in full racing trim with all conditions, as if she were to enter in races immediately. The water line measurement is 89.96. The official racing measurement as given out by Mr. Hyslop is 104,765 feet.

Floyd A. McFarland of San Jose, Cal., was badly injured in his fifteen-mile motor-paced race with John Nelson of Chicago at the opening of the Madison Square Garden cycle track last night. In the fourth lap of the thirteenth mile McFarland's pace-making tandem slipped on the steep banking of the lower turn and fell over, rolling down to the bottom of the incline.

SANTA CRUZ, Province of Laguna, P. I., June 24. -- When Gen. Cailles surrendered here to-day, with 650 men and 500 rifles, he entered Santa Cruz to the music of native bands, which were drawn up in six lines in the churchyard. Cailles and his staff entered the church, where mass was celebrated by Chaplain Hart of the Eighth United States Infantry.

Mayor Van Wyck, Controller Coler, and the "Commonalty of the City of New York" will have to decide in a short time whether a new drinking fountain will be erected in this city or whether the petition of a young widow of Yankton. S.D., that the money it would cost be given to her instead, be granted.

A Summer season was begun at the Knickerbocker Theatre last night, when what the programme described as a musical comedy, entitled "The Strollers," was produced. This niece would be more fitly called a farce with music interspersed. It is taken from "the German of L. Krenn and C. Lindau, and in many of its scenes and incidents it shows the nature of its birth.

The predictions made last week by bullish cotton interests that the new crop cotton would sell at 8 cents before the termination of the July deal was realized nearly yesterday on the strength of Texas weather reports, which showed a continued absence of rain in that section. August cotton opened at 7.92, and went to 8.02, closing at 7.99 bid.

Continuing talk of gold exports is not likely to cause alarm, although the outgo -- however slight -- may seem puzzling to many, in view of the enormous international credit we are presumed to have been setting up lately, merchandise exports exceeding in value merchandise imports for the late month by no less a sum than $45,849,170, and for the eleven months of the fiscal year by the enormous total of $630,149,951.

In Carnegie Music Hall last night a large audience heard the commencement exercises of St. Francis Xavier College. On the stage were many, church and college dignitaries. Archbishop Corrigan had the seat of honor and led the procession of graduates. Faculty, and alumni that filed into the building and occupied the stage.

WASHINGTON, June 24. -- The deepest sympathy for the Secretary of State and his family in their affliction is expressed at the White House. The President had a high estimate of Adalbert S. Hay's talent and capacity, and desired him to accept the position of assistant secretary, to which he was about to appoint him.

PARIS, June 25. -- The Senate assembled yesterday afternoon in its capacity as a High Court of Justice to try the Marquis de Lur-Saluces, the well-known Royalist and ex-member of the Chamber of Deputies, who returned unexpectedly to Paris last month, after having been condemned in January, 1900, in default of appearance, to ten years' banishment from France for treason.
LONDON, June 24. -- Eugene Zimmerman of Cincinnati has put his son-in-law, the Duke of Manchester, in a position to make an offer to the Duke's creditors of 12s. 6d. in the pound.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 24. -- The Republican State Convention convened here this afternoon with a large attendance. At the conferences during the forenoon, interest centred in the control of the new State Committee, the construction of the platform, and the fight that the State Anti-Saloon League was making against the renomination of Lieut. Gov. Caldwell.

The hard luck streak which seems to have been following Mathewson of late was broken yesterday, and the New Yorks, with the aid of his pitching, were able to win the baseball game with St. Louis. Davis was also in the game for the first time in some days, and his return immeasurably strengthened the team play of the home men.

NEWPORT, June 24. -- Members of the Newport Casino and Newport Golf Club are said to be in favor of consolidating the two organizations. The Golf Club has been run at a loss every year, although the loss was less last year than before.

Laboring under the hallucination that his friends were trying to oust him from his position and that his wife thought him insane, Charles Lamb, thirty-five years old, attempted suicide by shooting himself yesterday afternoon in front of the office of the Consolidated Gas Company. One Hundred and Fourteenth Street and Third Avenue, where he was employed.

Tammany opinion of Justice JEROME'S raids on the gambling houses was made known by the rage of DEVERY. It was difficult for even that voluble official to find words of abuse fit to express his detestation of this violent interference with a business from which there is much reason to believe that men prominent and powerful in Tammany -- some of them perhaps holding places in the Police Department -- derive a comfortable revenue.
ST. PETERSBURG, June 24. -- On competent authority it can be stated that the Russian Ministry of Finance regards Secretary Gage's explanation of the petroleum question to be beside the point.

MONTVALE, N.J., June 24. -- Charles Houston, a young graduate of Columbia College, has just closed his first year as Principal of the public school in this place. Mr. Houston has had an interesting experience with some of the youth of this locality, and will remember especially one of his pupils, little Paddy Hayes.

STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 24. --The First Regiment marched out of camp this morning at 9:30, an hour later than was planned. The officers find it somewhat difficult to get things working smoothly owing to the men being unaccustomed to moving in large bodies, in battalion and regimental formations.
Gov. Odell was in conference with Senator Platt at the Fifth Avenue Hotel for several hours yesterday.
OYSTER BAY, L.I., June 24. -- Vice President Roosevelt leaves in the morning for Boston to attend the commencement exercises at Harvard University.

HENLEY, England, June 24. -- Some fast trials were accomplished on the Thames here this afternoon by the crews who are training for the annual regatta. The Pennsylvania University crew covered the full course in seven minutes three and one-fifth seconds, and half the course in three minutes twenty-five seconds.

"Pittsburg Phil" and his jockey, Shaw, stood out conspicuously in the racing and results at the Sheepshead Bay race track yesterday, and little else was talked of by the general public. There seemed to be a fascination in the subject, and if rumor could be believed, the winnings of the plunger on the horses ridden by Shaw amounted into the hundreds of thousands.

BALTIMORE, June 24. -- The market today achieved nothing special, but enjoyed a fair share of activity with a decided firmness of tone. The Street watched the Seaboards to catch a hint as to the prevailing sentiment, and the steadiness of that group helped to quicken the confidence of holders generally.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., June 24. -- The Alabama coal operators and miners met in joint convention this morning, and each side submitted scales for the year beginning July 1. That of the operators contained the following propositions: A minimum of 40 cents with pig iron at $8 a ton, and a maximum of 50 cents with pig iron at $11 a ton; no distinction between union and non-union labor.

Among those who sailed for Europe on the Kaiser Wilhelm der Grosse yesterday was Sir Claude Macdonald, late Minister of Great Britain to China, and now holding a similar position to Japan. Lady Macdonald accompanies him. They are on their way to England and expect to stay there for about six months, when Sir Claude will return to his post in the East.
WASHINGTON, June 25. -- The Secretary of the Treasury to-day purchased $263,000 short term 4 per cent. bonds at 113.9080 $90,000 fives at 100.0557, and $90,000 fives at 109.0608.

ROANOKE, Va., June 25. -- The damage in the coal fields begins at Coaldale, which is fifteen miles west of Bluefield. At that place great embankments supporting the railroad tracks have been washed out. The branch road leading from Mayberry to the Norfolk and Delta collieries has suffered heavy damage.
WASHINGTON, June 25. -- The Weather Bureau's weekly summary of crop conditions is as follows:
BERLIN, June 25. -- The failure of the Leipziger Bank was a complete surprise to the members of the Berlin Boerse, where yesterday the bank's shares were quoted at 140.

Trading in the outside market yesterday was lighter than for some days past and at the same time considerable irregularity showed in the course of prices. In the afternoon the market was unfavorably affected by the break in the Stock Exchange market resulting from the reports in regard to one or more local banks being in trouble, exaggerated accounts of which were given on the curb.

LONDON, June 25. -- A Parliamentary Committee to-day discussed the bill to authorize the introduction of electricity as the motive power of the Metropolitan District Railway by arrangement with the new company now being formed by Charles T. Yerkes.

WASHINGTON, June 25. -- Pension Commissioner Evans read to-day with interest and surprise the "rectification" by Gen. Daniel E. Sickles of his statement to a reporter of THE NEW YORK TIMES in Sunday's paper. His surprise was caused by the possession of assurances in writing held by him that Gen. Sickles has until now, so far as the Commissioner has known, been his warm friend and approver.

Dr. George Hosmer Magness died at his home at White Plains, N.Y., yesterday morning after a long illness. He was born in New York City in 1851. He was of French descent. Dr. Magness spent the first fourteen years of his life in South America, where he had gone with his father, who was largely interested in commercial enterprises.

PATERSON, N.J., June 25. -- Much excitement was caused among the striking weavers this morning by the arrest of sixteen of their number, former employes of the Paragon Silk Mill, and many of them girls, accused of annoying non-union hands at the mill. They will be given a hearing on Thursday next.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 25. -- The commencement exercises of Radcliffe College were held in Sanders Theatre, Cambridgre, this afternoon. In all there were eightyeight to receive degrees. Twenty-three or these received the degree of A.B. without spcial honors. Twenty-five received the degree Cum Laude, and twenty-four Magna Cum Laude.

PHILADELPHIA, June 25. -- New York's fall caused a decline in the local market, especially in the arbitrage stocks, Pennsylvania declining 5/8, the Readings 1/2 to 5/8, and United States Steel 1/2. In the strictly local family, the impression made on prices was of little moment, except for Cambria Steel, which sold off over a point at one time, the warrants yielding to the same extent.
RICHMOND, Ind., June 25. -- William D. Foulke of this city has received a letter from Judge Taft relative to the operation of civil service in the Philippines, in which the writer says:

Justice Jerome says he knows who is back of the payment of money to the police for protecting disorderly houses. The Justice has said before, that he knew who constituted the syndicate paying the police for the non-molestation of gambling houses, but had never alluded to disorderly house tributes.
BOSTON, June 25. -- Money loaned at the Clearing House to-day at 2 per cent. and New York funds sold at par. Exchanges, $25,729,181; balances, $3,060,081.

James T. Cowan, who gave his address as Greystone Park, Lynn, Mass., engaged a room at the Continental Hotel, Hoboken, on Monday last, and retired at 8 o'clock P.M. He did not respond when called yesterday morning, and the door of his room was forced open.

NEW HAVEN, June 25. -- The blue of Yale was trailed in the dust this afternoon, Harvard for the second time beating Yale at baseball, thus winning the series between the colleges. The victory was due to a slightly built, sandy-haired lad, the scion of a famous baseball family. His name is Clarkson, and the exhibition of pitching he gave was most superb.

WASHINGTON, June 25. -- The President to-day pardoned Charles W. Mussey, former cashier of the National Bank of Rutland, Vt., who was convicted last year of the misapplication of $100,000 of the funds of the bank and sentenced to seven years in the House of Correction.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., June 25. -- The woman's National championship lawn tennis tournament began on the grounds of the Philadelphia Cricket Club at Wissahickon Heights to-day. The fact that Miss Marion Jones, Miss Bessie Moore, and Miss Juliette Atkinson are all playing in the one tournament insures tennis of the highest order in the struggle for the championship.

With the game well in hand yesterday the New York baseball team took Phyle out of the box and substituted Taylor with disastrous results. The sun shining down upon Phyle during the game had made him a trifle dizzy, and he had asked to be taken from the box. Though a trifle wild he had pitched good ball, keeping the St. Louis hits well scattered.

Probably there is nothing in the way of dress that is more to a woman's fancy than coats. The more elaborate of these are only for the rich, and are made for society functions. The best and daintiest of materials go into them, and the most original of ideas. One charming member of the three-quarter length coat family is of a beautiful shade of fawn-colored silk.

BALTIMORE, June 25. -- The stock market to-day held with remarkable steadiness in view of the weakness of New York. Sea-boards were inclined upward during the major part of the day, but the persistency with which Wall Street remained weak caused the buying demand to shrivel enough to permit a small fractional shading.

The fact that the Norfolk and western Railroad Company's property has been damaged through the floods in the Elkhorn River Valley on the Ohio Division of the road, and that earnings may for a time suffer somewhat in consequence, draws attention to the large expansion which has been in progress in those earnings -- one of the noteworthy features of the property's emergence from the bankruptcy of half a dozen years ago.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 25. -- The feature of crew practice this evening was a time trial by the Cornell 'Varsity crew for four miles, and a race of this eight with the Cornell freshmen for two miles. It was an excellent exhibition of watermanship, and was much admired by a number of visitors who followed the crews on the launch at Coach Courtney's invitation.

Allowing Ailsa and Vigilant, the ninety-foot yawls, about 10 minutes and 45 seconds over a fifteen-mile course, the old cup defender. Columbia, beat the pair with all the ease in life in the race for the Glen Cove Cup, held by the New York Yacht Club, off Glen Cove, L.I., yesterday.

Dr. Alvah H. Doty, Health Officer for the Port of New York, returned yesterday from Washington, where he had been in consultation with Surgeon General Wyman in relation to the suggested modification of quarantine regulations against Havana and other Cuban ports. On his return he gave out the following official statement:

CLEVELAND, Ohio. June 25. -- In a grave on a magnificent hill that overlooks the city in beautiful Lake View Cemetery, the body of Adelbert Stone Hay was laid to rest this afternoon. The funeral party arrived in Cleveland from New Haven at noon, and the funeral services were held in the \Vade mortuary chapel a few hours later.

An Episcopalian clergyman has written a letter of remonstrance to our esteemed contemporary The Sun upon an editorial article which it printed last Sunday upon the "Moral Purity of the Christian Ministry." The gist of the article is The Sun's assertion that the question of the guilt of Mr. KELLER "of the atrocious offense of which he is accused in a circumstantial statement the authenticity of which is apparently unquestionable still remains open."

The first steps have been taken toward the accomplishment of the plan of the Pennsylvania Railroad for a bridge over the North River. For the last few days officials of the Pennsylvania Railroad have been conferring with prominent banking houses in an endeavor to reach an agreement by which these bankers would undertake to finance the scheme for such a bridge by capitalizing a company for that purpose.

LONDON, June 25. -- While artillery practice was in progress on the Isle of Wight to-day the breech of a twelve-pound rifle blew out, killing Capt. A. Le M. Bray of the Royal Artillery and one enlisted man and wounding eight other men, three of whom will probably die. Col. A.J. Nixon, R.A., was slightly wounded by the explosion.

Chief Engineer Birdsall of the Water Supply Department was an attentive listener at the meetings of the Council and Board of Aldermen yesterday. He appeared as the advocate of an issue of bonds amounting to $100,000 for an investigation of the watersheds around New York City to decide whence the future source of water supply for the city should be drawn.

If plans are followed, to-day will be interesting at Meadow Brook. There is to be a polo pony race with gentlemen riders at William C. Whitney's place on the Wheatley Hills. There will also be polo at Seabright and at the Philadelphia Country Club, where the match games are being played.

READING, Penn., June 25. -- Not a dozen out of the 1,000 striking shopmen of the Philadelphia and Reading Company returned to work to-day, as they had been urged to do by President Baer, in his letter of Saturday. Instead of the men out returning to work, some of those who had not struck joined the strikers.
BUFFALO, June 25. -- The following, over the signature of William J. Bryan, appears in The Times, Norman E. Mack's paper, this afternoon:

GALES FERRY, June 25. -- Hard work for the rowing season of 1901 closed to-night and at both Red Top and Gales Ferry everything is in suspense awaiting the last test that is to be held on Thursday afternoon. Not before in recent years has there been such suspense among the oarsmen who are to participate in the great race, or the coachers and graduate oarsmen who crowd both quarters to their last capacity.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., June 25. -- Postmaster General Smith addressed the graduating class of Wesleyan University tonight during the commencement exercises. Mr. Smith spoke of the wonderful progress and development of America in the last thirty years.

WASHINGTON, June 25. -- The Cabinet meeting to-day was brief. Much of the time was spent in talking over the deep affliction which has come to Secretary Hay. The President had had a short note from Mr. Hay advising him that after the funeral at Cleveland he would return to Newbury, N.H., with Mrs. Hay and his children.

The twenty-second race for the Tidal Stakes, one of the famous fixtures of the Sheepshead Bay Spring meeting, run yesterday, was less a race than an exhibition of the excellence of the swift black horse Watercolor, the star of the dispersal sale of the stable of Charles Littlefield, Jr., to be held to-day.

SEATTLE, Washington. June 25. -- John W. Considine, one of the owners of the Standard Gambling House and the People's Theatre, shot and killed ex-Chief of Police W.L. Meredith this afternoon. Meredith was a son of W.M. Meredith, chief of the National Bureau of Engraving and Printing.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 25. -- The Republican State Convention to-day nominated the following ticket:

The Municipal Council debated the questions yesterday whether passengers should be fined for standing between seats of street surface cars, and whether the conductors of cars should be fined for allowing passengers to so stand. The resolutions were introduced by President Guggenheimer.

BLUEFIELD, West Va., June 23. -- Another twenty-four hours have passed and the full extent of the vast damage done by the flood cannot yet be accurately stated. All over this section there is great relief expressed at the announcement that the loss of life is not so great as at first believed. Many of the missing who were mourned as dead by their friends have turned up.
According to a detailed and authorized article in The Brooklyn Eagle, the plans of the Pennsylvania Railroad with reference to Long Island are far-reaching and of great importance in many directions.

Alderman Goodman wants to send at least 5,000 of the unemployed men and women of New York City to the fields of Kansas and other Western States to help harvest the crops. This matter was discussed seriously by the Board of Aldermen yesterday.

Holding an office created by the Constitution, a United States Senator is authorized to look with contempt on a member of the Cabinet, whose humble office is a creation of statute law. Nevertheless, the head of one of the executive departments occupies a place of no little dignity.

The Seventh National Bank, at the southeast corner of Broadway and John Street, was in financial difficulty much of the day yesterday because of its debit balance at the Clearing House, which amounted to $983,000 and which was only paid after 2 o'clock.

OTTAWA, June 25. -- The Government is getting ready another invitation for tenders for a fast steamship line between Canadian ports and the United Kingdom. The advertisement will be sent out in a few days, and in the meantime a correspondence is springing up which shows a revived interest in the undertaking.

Joseph Cook of Boston, well-known as an author and lecturer, died last night at Cliff Seat, his country home, in Ticonderoga, New York, of Bright's disease. Mr. Joseph Cook's reputation as a lecturer was international. He was known almost as widely as a defender of the Congregational faith.

PATERSON, N.J., June 25. -- Lydia De Graw of 31 Straight Street, who is charged with bigamy by her husband. Richard De Vreese, who alleges that on Saturday last he called at the house where she was living and was told by her that she was married to another man, a certificate being shown to back up her statement, was sent to jail by Justice Romaine on complaint of her husband.

The blow which has fallen upon the Secretary of State is a blow especially hard to bear. The future of an aging father is in the work of his children. His own life, successful or not, prosperous or not, is finished, in the sense of being defined. He knows that he cannot be or do anything radically different from what he is and has done.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 25. -- The Constitution was never more thoroughly tested than she was to-day, when after two thorough trials -- one with a light breeze and the other in a stiff one -- she was proved to have fast-going qualities in both.

With bank books in his pockets showing a total balance of more than $5,000 to his credit, Georga W. Schmedes, twenty-five years old, a cigar dealer of 302 Elizabeth Street, tried very hard to end his life early yesterday morning by jumping into the North River from the Pennsylvania ferryboat New Jersey, while that vessel was made fast to her Jersey City slip.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 25. -- The wedding of Miss Marie Melville Truesdale of New York and Richard Merwin Bissell of Chicago took place to-day at Indian Field, the Summer home of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Truesdale. About 200 of the 2,000 persons invited were present. A majority of the invitations were sent to persons in the West, where the Truesdales lived until a few years ago.

WASHINGTON, June 25. -- The President and Mrs. McKinley are evidently preparing for an early visit to Canton. A pair of the White House horses, a carriage, several servants, and some packages have been forwarded to the Canton home.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The fact that I am a constant reader of THE TIMES should be sufficient evidence of sanity and intelligence on the part of the writer, and yet I frequently have to apply other tests which seldom fail to prove the opposite. I am a sheet metal worker employed in New York City.

John Hull Browning has bought from Priscilla C. Drinker the four-story dwelling 201 West Fifty-sixth Street, on lot 22 by 75.5. Mr. Browning owns the Hotel Grenoble at the northwest corner of Seventh Avenue and Fifty-sixth Street; also the six-story apartment house 205 and 207 West Fifty-sixth Street.

F.C. La Monte writes to THE NEW YORK TIMES that the lien filed on June 24th, 1901, reading "113th Street, 233 and 235 E. Pasquale Ventimiglia against Frank La Monte, owner and contractor," is not valid, as he does not owe him any money. The lien has been bonded.

PHILADELPHIA, June 26 -- Nearly everything was a trifle lower in the Philadelphia market to-day, and there was a tendency running toward liquidation in the Readings and Cambria Steel. The volume of trading, however, was small, and the changes were narrow. In the last hour Choctaw fell 2 points.

HENLEY, England, June 26 -- The Pennsylvania University crew did a full course trial to-day in 7 minutes 11 seconds. The Dublin crew rowed the course in 7 minutes 36 seconds. The other crews were all out, but none of them made better time than the Pennsylvanians.

Nothing, in its way, could be more explicit and gratifying than the letter of Judge TAFT to Mr. FOULKE of Indianapolis, respecting the civil service in the Philippines. It appears to have been written to repel some injurious rumors that the places in the civil service were going by favor.

LONDON, June 26 -- Stafford House, the London residence of the Duke and Duchess of Sutherland, was to-night the scene of the most brilliant charitable function of many seasons. It was given in aid of the National Lifeboat Institution. Unlike the American lifeboat service, the British service is not a Government institution, and is dependent upon voluntary contributions.

LONDON, June 27 -- The election to fill the vacancy in the House of Commons for the Stratford-on-Avon Division of Warwickshire caused by the death of Victor Milward (Conservative) resulted as follows:

The third day's play in the New York Lawn Tennis Club's open tournament drew a goodly crowd of spectators to the club grounds, at One Hundred and Twenty-third Street and St. Nicholas Avenue. The feature of the afternoon's play was the exciting match in the preliminary round of the doubles between Cragin and Bostwick, the in-door National champions in doubles, and Wright and Grant, the interscholastic players.

Business in the outside market yesterday was conducted within, narrow limits, and very few stocks were even fairly active. The market was rather reactionary, and a number of declines occurred, although in most cases the day's losses were not heavy. A few stocks notwithstanding the general tendency of the market showed decided strength and closed at prices considerably above those quoted at the close of the previous day.
MONTREAL, Quebec, June 26 -- A syndicate headed by Messrs. W.H. Davis and David Russell of Montreal, has purchased nearly 1,100 square miles of the finest pulp and timber lands in this province.

COOPER, West Va., June 26 -- Heavy rain to-night in the head of the Elkhorn has washed out much of the new work, and is likely to delay traffic to-morrow. The bridge on Mill Creek, west of Cooper, is washed out.

"I will give 10 per cent, of my income and 5 per cent, of my entire capital to- ward the continuation of the work of eradicating protected crime and vice in New York if any body of citizens as representative as the Committee of Fifteen will give each 1 per cent, of their capital and 2 per cent, of their income for the same purposes.

Justice Gaynor in the Supreme Court in Brooklyn yesterday granted the application of the receivers of the Anglo-American Savings and Loan Association, at 257 and 258 Broadway, Manhattan Borough, to transfer all its assets to the Empire State Realty Company.

Senator Chauncey M. Depew sailed on the American liner St. Louis yesterday on his twenty-seventh pilgrimage to Europe in search of health and recreation. The Senator was accompanied by his son, Chauncey M. Depew, Jr., and his niece, Miss Paulding. The party expects to remain abroad until September, and the reason for the trip, according to the Senator from New York, is that he may have a rest and refresh his gray matter.

MONTREAL, June 26 -- Although the Canadian Pacific management maintains that the road is not inconvenienced by the trackmen's strike, it is evident that it has much difficulty in running western trains. The Imperial Limited, west-ward bound, was delayed for several hours at Calgary yesterday, because the company could not obtain men to fix up washouts.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 27 -- 1 A. M. -- Fifty citizens of this city, six police officers from New Rochelle, and thirty or forty men from Mount Vernon, including all the police from that city that can be mustered are closing in upon a burglar in the woods between this city and Mount Vernon, or at least they think they are.

Since the establishment of the Stock Exchange Clearing House the practice of overcertifying bank checks has dwindled to about one-fourth of its former proportions. The clearance system in stock transactions operates precisely as it does in the business of the banks. A broker's settlements are measured, not by the entire volume of the day's buying and selling, but by his debit or credit balance -- that is, the difference between sales and purchases.

Police Commissioner Murphy yesterday sent to the Corporation Counsel the letter which he received from President Clausen of the Department at Parks some time ago, suggesting that there ought to be an understanding between the Commissioner of Parks and the Commissioner of Police concerning the control of the police force in the parks.
BOSTON, June 26 -- Money loaned at the Clearing House to-day at 2 per cent., and New York funds sold at par and 5 cents premium. Exchanges, $23,447,760; balances, $1,618,794.

BERLIN, June 26 -- The meeting to-day of the creditors of the Leipziger Bank was attended by representatives of the Reichsbank and other leading banks. It transpired at the meeting that it was impossible to arrange a moratorium. The balance sheet of the Leipziger Bank shows that the gross liabilities are 92,000,000 marks, while its assets are 159,000,000 marks.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 26 -- President Eliot announced at the Harvard Alumni dinner to-day that J. Pierpont Morgan had given more than $1,000,000 for the erection of three of the five buildings planned for the Harvard Medical School on land now held in trust for the university on Huntington Avenue, in Boston.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 16 -- The Harvard commencement exercises to-day followed the usual programme. The Board of Overseers held its regular meeting, and the formal vote was taken, granting the honorary degrees. From 10 to 4 the polls were open at Massachusetts Hall for the election of Overseers.

An illustrated souvenir volume of the semi-centennial anniversary of the National Bank of North America has been issued. It gives the history of the bank and an account of the semi-centennial dinner. The volume also contains many interesting illustrations, showing Wall Street, lower Broadway, and a number of prominent buildings in this city in 1851, as well as portraits of Presidents and other officers of the institution, including Warner Van Norden and William F. Havemeyer.
NEW ORLEANS, June 26 -- The British mule transport Monterey, from Cape Town, arrived in port last night after a terrible experience with fire at sea.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In view of the wild inaccuracy of the press reports of the accident to our sister, Miss Susan B. Spring, may we ask you in justice both to her friends and her attendant, to state the facts of the case.

The Seventh National Bank, which was in difficulty with the Clearing House on Tuesday, opened for business as usual yesterday and was subjected to but a slight run, only about $25,000 being withdrawn by depositors through apprehension. It was soon announced that the bank had met its morning obligations at the Clearing House.

ST. LOUIS, June 26 -- A search for a three-year-old child which began in New York City and will be extended across the continent, was revealed to the Police Department of St. Louis to-day when Miss Emelie Goebel of 388 East Ninety-sixth Street. New York, requested Chief of Detectives Desmond to help her locate her little foster sister Annie, who, she claims, was kidnapped from her and her mother, Mrs. Augusta Goebel, on April 2.

PITTSBURG, Penn., June 26 -- The storm which struck Pittsburg and vicinity this afternoon was short in duration but terrific in power and disastrous in result. The lightning and thunder were practically continuous for, about thirty minutes, the wind attaining a velocity of thirty miles an hour and .46 of an inch of rain fell.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 26 -- The anticipated trouble with the strikers came this morning. The marching men, numbering about 1,000, clashed with the police at Mill and Commercial Streets at 9:30 o'clock, and many heads were broken. A volley was fired over, the heads of the strikers when the policemen were assaulted with bricks, stones, shovels, and pieces of wood.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, June 26 -- The conference of American Tin Plate Company's officials with representatives of the Amalgamated Association of Iron, Steel, and Tin Workers has resulted in the signing of a new wage scale to go into effect July 1. Under the new scale the workmen will receive an advance of 2 per cent.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Consul Mahin of Reichenberg, Austria, has sent the State Department an article recently contributed to the Munich Allgemeine Zeitung by Dr. Alexander von Peez under the title "The Struggle for Industrial Supremacy":

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage, except in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes payment of the mortgage.

-- Tuesday was indeed a great day for the town of Concord, N.H., for on that day was gathered the annual harvest of dollars which reconciles the somewhat pachydermatous inhabitants of the place to its unenviable reputation as the headquarters of a colossal bunko game and the Mecca of the cult just now most attractive to weak-minded credulity.

BURLINGTON, Vt., June 26 -- At the annual graduating exercises of the University of Vermont to-day, honorary degrees were conferred as follows: LL. D., Henry Holt of New York and Burlington, and A.H. Waterman of Chicago; D.D., the Rev. W. B. Atwell, pastor of Trinity Church, Shelourne, Vt.

United States District Attorney George H. Pettit of Brooklyn yesterday received a deed from Abram S. Hewitt, in which Mr. Hewitt transfers to the Government 640 acres of land on Plum Island at the east end of Long Island Sound. The consideration named in the deed was $64,700 and revenue stamps to the amount of $65 were affixed to it.

PERU, Ind., June 26 -- Sixteen persons were killed and about fifty were seriously injured in a wreck of Train 3, the west-bound Wabash limited, nine miles west of this city, at 12:30 o'clock A.M. to-day. The dead are all Italian immigrants en route to Colorado. Many of the injured undoubtedly will die.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 26 -- The Constitution started this forenoon upon her first cruise to-day when she left for New London to attend the Harvard-Yale boat races. When she went out there were only light westerly airs, and she was carrying her No. 3 club and No. 2 jib topsail in addition to the usual sail.

New York won the opening game of the present series with Cincinnati yesterday at the Polo Grounds. The Cincinnatis have been losing steadily of late, and on this account they were not the attraction they were earlier in the season when they held first position, a small-sized crowd for the home grounds turning out to see the contest.

There was an unusual operation and a lively time yesterday afternoon at the Central Park Menagerie when Alice, the old lioness, almost blind, who is kept in the last cage nearest the south entrance of the lions' house, had her claws cut. This was done because for some time the animal had walked lame, and it was thought that her claws must be growing into her pads.

ROANOKE, Va., June 26 -- The news from the flood-swept district in West Virginia shows no reason for increasing the estimates of either fatalities or property losses. Fifty is the outside limit of lives lost. The reports from all over the section are to the effect that while many poor people have lost all yet there is no danger of suffering for want of food.

Gen. Daniel E. Sickles yesterday reaffirmed his statement that he has the written pledge of the Republican National Committee that Pension Commissioner H. Clay Evans would not be reappointed. The pledge he showed to a reporter for THE NEW YORK TIMES.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- An official statement from the Italian Government was communicated to the State Department today to the effect that Italy paid no export duty on sugar. This action by the Italian authorities follows eight days from the issuance of Secretary Gage's order suspending the liquidation of all sugar imported from or produced in Italy, on the ground that the Treasury had information leading to the belief that Italian sugar received a bounty.

The heat makes the country so agreeable that no one is left in town except those who cannot get away. Yesterday was an ideal day for open-air sports. There was polo at Philadelphia, and there was also a race for polo ponies and gentlemen riders at William C. Whitney's place in the Wheatley Hills.
PARIS, June 27 -- The Senate, sitting as a High Court of Justice, yesterday concluded the trial of the Marquis de Lur-Saluces, charged with treason.

It has been determined by a number of prominent persons interested in the subject to have in this city during the Winter of 1901 and 1902 an American Jewish Historical Exhibition similar in some departments to the Anglo-Jewish Historical Exhibition held in London in 1887. When the American Jewish Historical Society held its last meeting in Philadelphia a committee was appointed with full powers to plan for this exhibition.

The statement of Commissioner EVANS is, as to the merits of the case against him, at once conclusive and superfluous. Nobody doubts that he is an honest, efficient, and fair-minded Commissioner of Pensions, and that the attacks upon him are made precisely for that reason. Neither he nor any one of his predecessors has ever erred upon the side of resistance to just and lawful claims.

President Miles M. O'Brien announced at the meeting of the Board of Education last night that at his request Hubbard R. Yetman, Superintendent of Schools for the Borough of Richmond, had resigned the Chairmanship of the Richmond delegation to the conference of Tammany bodies which are planning the approaching campaign, and which recently met in the Democratic Club.

Irving Lehman, third son of the late Meyer Lehman, and Miss Sissie Straus, only daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Straus, were married at the residence of Mr. Straus, 27 West Seventy-second Street, at 6:30 o'clock last evening. The Rev. Dr. Kauffman Kohler and the Rev. Dr. Gottheil officiated.

PHILADELPHIA, June 26 -- At to-day's meeting of the Directors of the Pennsylvania Company, which operates the lines of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company west of Pittsburg, Effingham B. Morris of this city resigned from the board, and L. F. Loree, President of the Baltimore and Ohio, was elected a Director in his place.

Pedestrians on Park Row were startled last evening by the appearance of a small newsboy on that thoroughfare. There were scores of other small newsboys in the vicinity, but this particular boy was unique in that he wore no clothes whatever.

STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 26 -- The First Regiment made record time in getting into camp this morning. The command left Lake Mohegan at 7:15 A.M. and reached the State camp at 10:30. There were several halts, but only long enough in each case to let the men "get their wind."

The Oregon and Oriental Steamship Company, which operates a fleet of steamships between Portland, Ore., and ports in the Philippines, China, and Japan, is seriously considering the establishment of a line from New York to the Far East.

PARIS, June 26 -- The keenest interest is taken here in the automobile race between Paris and Berlin, which starts at 3:30 o'clock to-morrow morning from the cross roads of the village of Champigny, twelve miles east of Paris. This starting place has been chosen because Champigny is secluded, thus enabling the autocars to start at full speed, which would be impossible were the start made from Paris.

BALTIMORE, Md., June 26 -- The twenty-miles motor-paced cycle race here to-night between " Bobby" Walthour and Arthur Ross was won by Walthour by a little less than a lap in 32 minutes and 11 seconds, Walthour made the last mile in 1:28 3-5, lowering the track record one second.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 26 -- The corporators of the Newport Yacht Racing Association, who are John Jacob Astor, Woodbury Kane, Arthur T. Kemp, William Gammell, Royal Phelps Carroll, Herman B. Duryea, Winthrop Rutherford, Reginald Brooks. Frederick P. Sands, Henry P. Eldridge, and Frederick P. Garrettson, held their first meeting this afternoon, with Mayor Garrettson acting as Chairman and Herman B. Duryea as Secretary.

We find in the London newspapers telegrams from France and Switzerland echoing the British complaints telegraphed here of the inferiority of the American engines sold abroad. This looks almost like a cabal against our goods. What American builders would like is a bill of particulars.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., June 26 -- The Orient Steam Navigation Company's steamer Lusitania, Capt. McNay, from Liverpool, June 18, for Montreal, having more than 350 passengers on board, was wrecked last night off Capt. Ballard. All the passengers were saved by taking to the lifeboats.

NEWPORT, June 26 -- The stockholders and Directors of the Casino, the Spouting Rock Beach Association, and the Golf Club are discussing the proposal to consolidate all three companies. The financial condition of the Spouting Rock Beach Association is excellent, and the Casino has also a good financial report to show, but the Golf Club has shown a loss every year since it was formed.

To the Editor of The New York Times: My attention has just been directed to a letter printed in your issue of 16th inst. anent alleged conditions at North Brother Island. Having myself been a patient there in the very recent past, perhaps you may permit me to say a few words in refutation of the statements contained in "J.E.'s" letter.

NEW HAVEN, June 26 -- The one hundred and ninety-ninth commencement of Yale University was held to-day with favoring skies and the most pleasant of conditions generally. Battell Chapel was crowded to the doors with members of the graduating classes, their friends, and members of the reunion classes, and never has the need of a greater auditorium been more felt at Yale than to-day.

The sixth annual report of the American Scenic and Historic Preservation Society, submitted to the Legislature, has just been issued. The report shows a large amount of work during the year in preserving American landmarks and scenery and the perpetuation of names, as well as the cultivation of public sentiment by meetings, publications, and correspondence.

Miles McDonnell's arch-enemy, Thomas Kennedy, a well-known Harlem gambler, took the witness stand in the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court, yesterday to testify against McDonnell in the trial of the latter on the charge of murdering George Price in the Onawa Cafe last December.

If the fine ladies and gentlemen of New York society should receive from the President and Directors of the New York Central Railroad an invitation to afternoon tea in the tunnel they would bristle with indignation at an unpardonable social affront or shake with laughter at a highly original joke, according to their several temperaments.

The women who since Saturday last have been discussing various subjects in University Temple, Prohibition Park, Borough of Richmond, yesterday took up the subject of the canteen. This particular discussion was under the auspices of the Women's Christian Temperance Union of the State of New York.

A thrilling rescue of a child from death under the wheels of a trolley car at Broadway and Reid Avenue, Brooklyn, last night, filled a large crowd or spectators of the feat with the wildest enthusiasm. Among the large gathering of residents of the neighborhood who had witnessed the departure of a trolley excursion at the point named was four-year-old Emil Kroner, the son of Isidor Kroner, a tailor, of 1,088 Broadway.

Has Gen. SICKLES made himself rightly understood in his apparent controversy with Pension Commissioner EVANS? Is it not probable that he is making the strongest possible arguments all the time for Mr. EVANS, but making them with such subtlety of sarcasm that the country has missed the point?

In a fine true breeze from the southwest Percy Chubb's yawl Vigilant defeated H. S. Redmond's Alisa by 1 minute and 31 seconds yesterday in the opening regatta of the Seawanhaka-Cortnthian Yaeht Club off Oyster Bay. The big yawls were close together all over the twenty-three-and-one-half-mlle course and grave additional proof that their meetings will be a feature in the season's sport.
BOSTON, June 27 -- At the Clearing House this morning, money between the banks loaned at 2 per cent. New York funds sold at par. Exchanges, $21,570,882; balances, $2,515,591.
Bryan L. Kennelly has sold for Kate T. Richie the three-story and basement brownstone house 302 West Eighty-seventh Street, 17 by 100.8.

The Young People's Society of Christian Endeavor of the Port Morris Congregational Church took decisive action on Wednesday evening looking to the exclusion from its membership of Mormons and those who have announced their conversion to the Mormon faith.

In the following list " mtg " stands for mortgage and " R S " for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This " consideration " has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage, except in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes payment of the mortgage.

The warm wave of the past few days, with its invitation to bathers, was probably responsible yesterday for one death by drowning and two narrow escapes. The drowning occurred at Dyker Beauh, at the foot of Bay Eighth Street, and the rescues at Coney Island.

BRUNSWICK, Me., June 27. -- At Bowdoin College commencement to-day the honorary degree of LL.D. was conferred upon United States Senator Paris Gibson of Montana and ex-Senator W.D. Washburn of Minneapolis, Minn, The degree of Doctor of Letters was conferred upon Saran Orme Jewett, author.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 27. -- Yale celebrated the great victory on the Thames to-night in the most elaborate style in years. The college and the town were wild with enthusiasm over the Yale crews' work. Crowds thronged the streets and jammed the railroad station, where each incoming train from New London was greeted with cheers.

Thomas G. Barker, who shot the Rev. John Keller at Arlington on Sunday, Feb. 3, was yesterday arraigned before Judge John A. Blair, in the General Sessions Court, at Jersey City, and sentenced to serve five years in State Prison at hard labor. No fine was imposed, that being left to the discretion of the Court.

The general sense which accompanied the trial of BARKER that justice, according to law, was being done in New Jersey, will attend also the announcement of his sentence. Five years is not too long a period for the expiation of his offense in disabling and blinding another man for life, having intended to kill him.
WASHINGTON, June 27. -- Controller Dawes to-day grave out the following statement concerning the closing of the Seventh National Bank of New York:

c. -- Joseph Ladue, the founder of Dawson City in the Klondike, died last evening at his home in Schuyler Falls. Mr. Ladue had been ill since his return from Alaska, and spent last Winter at Colorado Springs. He finally fell a victim to consumption, contracted in the severe northern climate.

CINCINNATI, June 27. -- The 500 delegates to the international convention of the Knights of St. John began their last day's session this morning. A strong fight was made against the adoption of the report of the Committee on Ritual, but it was carried by a close vote. Hitherto there has been no ritual used in the initiations, but the action of the convention now makes this obligatory on every Commandery.

The New Yorks and Cincinnatis each won a baseball game at the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon, and the slight drop thus made in New York's percentage was sufficient to cause them to lose second place in the pennant race, as Brooklyn won from Pittsburg.

Dr. ALEXANDER VON PEEZ, the German publicist, from whose recent article in the Munich Allgemeine Zeitung we published significant extracts yesterday, has an extremely clear and sound idea of the real nature and origin of the American competition, but, we think, a somewhat narrow view of the policy toward it which Europe, including Great Britain, should or can adopt toward it.

Probably the hottest place in all New York yesterday was the trial room at Police Headquarters, where Deputy Commissioner Devery dispensed justice to a batch of delinquent policemen, and it is quite likely that the Deputy Commissioner himself was about the hottest man in town. The subject of his ire was Capt. Stephen O'Brien of the Leonard Street Station, who, in the reform days, was the head of the Detective Bureau.

St. Ignatius Loyola is the large church built massively of gray granite on Park Avenue, at Eighty-fourth Street, which adjoins an extensive rectory occupying the whole of the block to Eighty-third Street, and may be remembered for its truncated square towers. So far as the main church is concerned, it is a comparatively new building designed by William Schickel.

PHILADELPHIA, June 27. -- Thoroughly aroused and ready to act, more than 10,000 indignant Philadelphians turned out this evening to attend the town meeting which was called to renominate P. Fred Rothermel Jr., for District Attorney. Less than 5,000 could fight their way into the great auditorium of the Academy of Music, and of this number about 1,800 were women.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 27. -- The Forty-third Regiment, the last of the volunteers to leave the Philippines, arrived here today on the transport Kilpatrick, 23 days from Manila.
The Seventh National Bank closed its doors yesterday. Clearing House officials do not predict that it will resume business. Its counsel, however, hints that it may be reorganized.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 27. -- United States Minister Francis's journey from Greece to secure the entry of his son, John M. Francis, in the single scull race as a representative of Cornell has been in vain. Official announcement was made here this afternoon by Chairman Durrand of the Athletic Council of Cornell that John M. Francis had withdrawn his entry, as a personal sacrifice because of his love for Cornell.

The oppressive heat in town kept many people at their suburban homes. Mrs. Letter is to arrive in town to-day and will sail for England to-morrow to visit Lady Curzon, who is in London. Mrs. Letter has been at her Summer place near Chicago. She will return to this country in the Autumn.
LONDON, June 27. -- A portrait of Lady Louisa Manners, afterward Countess of Dysart, by Hoppner, was sold at auction this afternoon for 14,750 guineas, (about $77,500.)

While fighting each other, through their lawyers, in the courts, Alexander Russell and his wife are living most amicably together in their home at Seventh Avenue and Garfield Place, Brooklyn. When the case came to trial yesterday afternoon in the Brooklyn Supreme Court not even the learned Justice could tell what, the trouble was all about.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I was greatly surprised and disappointed by your small-type article last Saturday morning on the case of the Central Park policeman whom Commissioner Devery fined on Thursday for arresting a lady who, with five small children, was sitting on the grass.

Miles McDonnell, on trial for his life in the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court, charged with murdering George Price, was yesterday dramatically denounced as a, murderer by the widow of the dead man. who was called to the witness stand to testify against the prisoner.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Another oldtime Democrat, ex-Senator Pugh, who is cured of Populism as completely as Senator Daniel, has taken advantage of his acquaintance with the President to assure him that he does not agree with some of his party associates in denouncing policies adopted and followed by the Republicans.

PHILADELPHIA, June 27 -- Except for the asphalt group, the Philadelphia market closely followed New York's decline and subsequent recovery. Asphalts advanced on the unexpected report that the high court of Venezuela had decided in favor of the trust. There was heavy trading in the Reading issues, and all of them, ignoring the May statement, declined 1/2 point or so.

Three indictments will in all probability be handed up to Judge Cowing. in General Sessions, to-day, by the Grand Jury, which finished yesterday the investigation under way for the past week into the manner in which purchases of supplies are made by the Fire Department.

The market for outside securities was not very active yesterday, but in some parts of the lists a good deal of strength was shown. The general tendency of the market was reactionary, but in several stocks net gains were made sufficiently large to call for special attention. Even in the issues which suffered somewhat from the general conditions prevailing during the day the net declines were not heavy.

BOSTON, June 27. -- The oration on "Ideals in Politics," which Wayne MacVeagh delivered before the Phi Beta Kappa at its annual meeting at Cambridge to-day, contained some striking passages. In one place he said:

Justice JEROME is more and more looming up as a valuable citizen and a practical reformer. We confess that we are unable to understand upon what ground any body of professed municipal reformers can have justified themselves for withdrawing from the Justice their financial and moral support.

Mme. Schumann-Heink, the famous contralto of the Metropolitan Opera Company, had a narrow escape from injury yesterday. The singer was in a carriage drawn by two spirited horses, and was racing to catch the steamer Columbia of the Hamburg-American Line, on which she was to sail for Europe.

YONKERS, N.Y., June 27. -- Joseph F. Daly and his wife, who lived at 461 Warburton Avenue, died within three hours of each other this afternoon. Heart disease killed both. Mr. Daly was one of the leading lawyers of Westchester County, and an authority upon municipal law.

ATLANTA, Ga., June 27. -- It is believed that the only Atlanta depositor with the Seventh National Bank in New York is Judge J.T. Pendleton, receiver of the Southern Home Building and Loan Association.
ST. LOUIS, June 27. -- The June Term Grand Jury made its report to-day on the street car service of St. Louis. The report says in part:
M.L. Roeder has been appointed Newark General Agent of the accident department of the Maryland Casualty Company.

PARIS, June 27 -- From midnight, on during the early morning hours, a stream of bicyclists and automobiles marked the road from Paris to Fort Champigny, a dozen miles east of the city, the start of the automobile race between Paris and Berlin, at 3:30 this morning, attracting unusual interest.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read with pain your editorial article in to-day's issue attacking the character and membership of the Grand Army. I am not surprised that you are the champion of Commissioner Evans, because, unfortunately, he seems to entertain the same opinion of the veterans of the country that you have expressed.

Although the bank that closed its doors yesterday was not an institution of the first rank or importance, its failure at the present time is necessarily somewhat disquieting to the general public who pay little heed to the differences in standing, growing out of the differences in management, that are well enough known in financial circles.
LONDON, June 27 -- Money was in active demand to-day. The Bank of England controlled the market, charging 4 per cent, for loans, which caused grumbling among the brokers. Discounts were firm.
BLOOMFIELD, N.J., June 27 -- The explosion of an oil stove this morning resulted in the death of a child and the injuring of her mother and of the Chief Engineer of the Fire Department.

Polo men will begin to gather at the Rockaway Hunting Club, at Cedarhurst, next Week for the annual polo tournament. An unusually large number of entries have been received, and as all of the prominent local teams will appear, with the addition of Bryn Mawr and the Philadelphia Country Club, some interesting sport may be looked for.

New Jersey golfers were well represented yesterday on the links of the Englewood Golf Club when the second annual championship tournament of the New Jersey Golf Association began. The event practically defines the championship of the State, and competitors are required to be residents as well as club members.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In my opinion THE TIMES is to be greatly commended for its courageous stand in defense of Pension Commissioner Evans as opposed to the looting of the United States Treasury in the name of patriotism. I spell this kind of that desirable article advisedly with a small " p."

PROVINCETOWN, Mass., June 28 -- The yacht Independence dropped her anchor in Provincetown Harbor at 5:25 o'clock this afternoon after a beautiful run across Massachusetts Bay on her way to New London. She left Boston at noon, being towed from her docks to almost abreast of Minot's Light, when she hauled off the wind, and, with mainsail, headsails, and working topsail, started to Provincetown.
To The New York Times Saturday Review. I notice that you admit into your correspondence column observations on knotty points in Shakespeare. Perhaps the following may be worthy of insertion:

LONDON, June 28 -- Money was in active demand to-day, in connection with the settlement. It was the general impression that the high level so suddenly attained was not likely to last long. The failure of banks in Germany and the United States engenders a cautious attitude on the part of bankers in other centres.

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., June 28 -- Lewis B. Cambron got Judgment in the Supreme Court this morning for $15,000 against the Omaha and St. Louis Railroad Company for the loss of both legs, due to the negligence of the company and its employes. In this case the Supreme Court upholds the constitutionality of the fellow-servant law of this State, recently passed.

Mr. Theodore Wores has found in Honolulu another Inspiration like that which he discovered some years ago in Japan. He hopes to fix on canvas various phases of Hawalian life which are fast passing away, and to that end he will go about the islands in search of people who are less affected by the leveling spirit of "civilization" than the degenerate dwellers in towns.

ALBANY, June 28 -- The State Land Board to-day made several grants of land under water within the limits of Greater New York. The most important of these was a grant of seventeen acres of land under water at Coney Island to Michael J. Dady of Brooklyn, for which he pays 1,685.

There was a sad case presented this week in one of the New York police courts. It was that of a lady who had been arrested at the suit of her landlord for trying to defraud him of a board bill. The defendant pleaded that she had written an immortal work, or, if not Quite that, a work which was to be "the book of the day."
To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read with great interest and attention your editorial in THE TIMES this morning, entitled "White and Negro in the South."

Contrary to the common belief, boils are not indicative of blood disease. They are really indications of local poisoning by pusbearing germs, and the boil is an abscess. Every pus prick, every scratch, every abrasion, every cut with a razor or pocketknife, every splinter that enters the skin may cause a boil.

ON June 10-14 Sotheby, WilKinson Hodge sold in London the late Earl of Ashburnham's fine Barrois collection of manuscripts, the G28 lots realizing u33,217 6s 6d. The magnificent Ashburnham library commenced in 1814, when a Westminster schoolboy, bought for one and sixpence a copy of the " Secrets of Albertus Magnus," is now a thing of the past, as the present Earl (the fifth of his line) has nothing more to sell.

The finest copy of Nathaniel Hookes's "Amanda," 1653, that has occurred at public auction in many years fetched u37 at Sotheby's recently. It was in the original sheepskin, and had the original frontispiece, the rare leaf before the title page with the word "Amanda" printed across it, also the errata on the back of A4, and the two blank leaves, viz., G5 and H1.
