The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage, except in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes payment of the mortgage.

Justice to the public required us a day or two ago to deprecate, if not to denounce, the tortures dally inflicted upon large numbers of persons within the peace of the State of New York by taking them through four miles of the mephitic atmosphere of the tunnel from the Grand Central Station to the Harlem River.

From The New Orleans Times-Democrat. Many interesting entries are to be found in the old inventory books and other volumes of record of the New Orleans Gas Light Company, which furnish hitherto un-published history of the second oldest gas company in America, during the cloudy and tempestuous days of the early sixties in the South.

There was an exciting scene, in the Hudson County Oyer and Terminer Court, Jersey City, yesterday. Justice Collins presiding, and at the end of it Hudson County was without a Grand Jury. As one of the Grand Jurors forcibly expressed it:, "We were summarily bounced."

From The Fourth Estate. Newspaper men will be interested in the work that was done by the new proprietor, who is the principal owner of THE NEW YORK TIMES, when, within a period of two hours, on May 7, he transformed The Philadelphia Times from a discredited freak to a sane newspaper.

Learning that the co-respondents whom she had named in her suit for a divorce, which she brought some time ago against her husband, Walter Taylor, were innocent women, Mrs. Kate L. Taylor yesterday, before Justice Gaynor, in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, withdrew in open court the charges she made, Mrs. Taylor submitted the following affidavit to the Court:

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- The latest in the series of agrgressions upon Finland by Russia may cut some figure in the Russian-American tariff muddle. The Czar's Government has, it is reported, taken steps to secure control of the Finnish Custom Houses, with the evident purpose of making the tariff uniform with Russia's.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I desire to express, on behalf of a number of Episcopal clergymen, their sense of the justness of your view of Mr. Keller's case, expressed in your able editorial of this morning. There seems to be a misapprehension in the public press regarding Mr. Keller's public duty in this matter.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As an old soldier of the Union during the civil war, let me congratulate you on the editorial in to-day's TIMES on " Mr. EVANS and Gen. SICKLES." You state some plain truths plainly that ought to be driven home among old soldiers. It is my belief that the pension payments annually are now at least double what they ought to be.

NEWPORT, June 28 -- At noon to-morrow the cornerstone of the new Emmanuel Church, which is being built as a memorial to the late John Nicholas Brown by his wife, will be laid, in the presence of the entire congregation. Bishops Clark and McVickar and the Rev. Emory H. Porter, rector of Emmanuel Church, will be present.

A beautifully made little volume, the work of the Riverside Press, containing a reprint of the essay "Of Friendship," by Henry David Thoreau, has lately been issued which should take high rank among the works of the year as a fine piece of book making.

The Stock Exchange banking and brokerage house of Henry Marquand Co., at 160 Broadway, made a general assignment without preferences at 9:50 o'clock yesterday morning to Frank Sullivan Smith of 54 Wall Street and Angelica, Sullivan County, N.Y.

One of the immortal songs in the English language, (and it was the only one that made its author famous.) which has stirred humanity profoundly by its sweeping, conquering inspiration, is Dr. Sanford Fillmore Bennett's famous hymn, known everywhere and in all languages as "In the Sweet By and By."

When Miss Kilmansegg "took a part in 'Rich and Rare Were the Gems She Wore,' accoraing to her biographer." "the gems were there, like a song with an illustration." When Miss Kate Stephens writes to The Atlantic Monthly of "The New England Woman," and Miss Caroline Ticknor of "The Steel Engraving Lady and the Gibson Girl," and the two articles appear in the same number of The Atlantic Monthly, each illustrates the other.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., June 28 -- In September, at Winchester, England, which is the burial place of King Alfred the Great, the millenary of that monarch will be celebrated by the unveiling of a colossal statue.

"They That Took the Sword" is a story of Cincinnati in 1862, at the time when Confederate sympathizers within the city and without were conspiring to aid a small Confederate force in taking possession, and it is one of the first books to treat the civil war with absolute freedom from partisanship.

ST. PAUL, Minn., June 28. -- Heavy storms with more or less damage are reported all over this section this afternoon and the loss will run well up into the thousands, while a number of people have been injured and much live stock killed. The worst storm was that which passed through a large district south of New Richmond, Wis.

Mrs. Miles McDonnell, whose husband is on trial in the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court, charged with murdering George Price, in the Onawa Cafe, in December last, broke down and wept when her husband was not discharged from custody yesterday.

GEORGETOWN, Ga., June 28 -- A young negro on John Whitaker's Plantation, in this county, made an attempt to enter Miss Whitaker's room by raising the window. The noise awoke Miss Whitaker and the negro was recognized by her. She immediately told her father, who had the negro arrested and placed in jail.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: The habit of accumulating old books and magazines when once indulged is one that is cherished for its associations and surprises. The finest stories I ever read were found between the leaves of discarded periodicals, and when once the source became marked without overlooking the latest ethics I embarked on many a mental voyage hunting for antique curios and gems in the magazine line.

HANOVER, Prussia, June 28 -- Fournier was again first to arrive at the end, here, of the day's stage of the motor race from Paris to Berlin. Dekuyff was second and Girardot was third. The start to-day was made from Aix-La-Chapelle, 276 miles away, with 73 motors in the race at the beginning of the second day.

Henry D. Winans May have sold for L. V. Harkness the southeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Seventy-fifth Street to a buyer who, it is understood, will build a dwelling on the site. The property has a frontage of 57.2 feet on the avenue and 120 feet on Seventy-fifth Street. It was acquired by Mr. Harkness two years ago.

Christie's in London has just sold the important library of the late Sir Henry Hope Edwardes of Wootton, Ashburne, Derbyshire. This concluded the book auction season of 1900-01. The 665 lots realized the large total of L11,003 17s, and included many rarities. Chief among them was a fine copy of the first book printed at Oxford, which has not been offered at auction for a long period.
ALBANY, June 28 -- William H. Johnson, President of The Argus Company, died at his home here to-day. Death followed a long period of invalidism. His family was present when he passed away.

Entries for the Atlantic City Horse Show, to be held the second week in July, have closed with more than four hundred and fifty nominations for the sixty-five classes. This will cause the addition of an extra day to give officials time to judge the exhibits, and the show will begin Monday, July 8, instead of July 9, and continue the following five days.
Fouls and collisions of competing craft marked the regatta of the Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Club, which was sailed yesterday on Long Island Sound, off Oyster Bay.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 28 -- Ex-Secretary of the Navy Hilary A. Herbert, addressed the State Bar Association to-day on the duties of the American lawyer in the twentieth century. The Constitutional Convention adjourned, gave up its hall to him, and made the larger part of his audience. It was rewarded with the first plea for absolute independence in politics that ever surprised a gathering of Alabama politicians with whom party fealty is almost a religion.

To the Editor of The New York Times: So you don't think the negro is treated right in the South, and you don't think the Southern people understand him? Well, how about the Northern people -- is he better understood and treated in the North, say in New York?

If Mr. Almon Dexter, the author of "And the Wilderness Blossomed," hoped to make his readers envious of the paradise he has succeeded in creating, and desirous of following in his footsteps, he may be said to have succeeded admirably. His book, which is dedicated to Ferdinand W. Roebling, "and the others who have been there," describes most alluringly the building of a home on an island hitherto unimproved, in Insley Lake, Me.

BUFFALO, June 28 -- Lieut. Commander James H. Bull, United States Navy, who was so seriously injured in a fall from the Government Building at the Pan-American Exposition grounds on June 8, is again at the General Hospital in a precarious condition.

LONDON, June 28 -- The sale of the surplus wine from the royal cellars was concluded to-day. The bidding for the last lots was sensational, several lots of pale sherry, from Windsor Castle, bottled in 1820, fetching as much as 570s. ($142.50) a dozen.
WASHINGTON, June 28 -- "If Gen. Sickles has any written pledge from me, such as he describes in his statement in THE NEW YORK TIMES, he has my permission -- my invitation -- to publish it."

It is the intention of several mission boards in this city to begin religious work in Havana this Fall. The Presbyterian Board of Home Missions is one of them, and the Congregationalists and Episcopalians will enlarge work already begun there. All intend to build churches.

Fire Commissioner John J. Scannell and "Agent" William L. Marks were yesterday indicted by the Grand Jury as a result of the ten days' investigation into the manner of purchasing supplies by the Fire Department, which the official inquisitors completed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- The Star today says: "President N.E. Young of the National Baseball League this morning made application at the District Commsioner's office for a permit to reconstruct the stands, entrances, and fences at National Park, the old League grounds, at the head of Seventh Street.

W.L. Glenny and Allan N. Kennaday will meet this morning on the Englewood Golf Club links to determine the championship of the State of New Jersey. Glenny represents the Hillside Tennis and Golf Club and Kennaday hails from Montclair. Both are young golfers, but Kennaday has somewhat the greater reputation in the metropolitan field.
HACKENSACK, N.J., June 28 -- Frank B. Poor, Junior member of Marquand Co., has extensive interests hereabouts, and is one of those who have displayed the most interest in Bergen County.

LONDON, June 28 -- The late Charles Kensington Salaman, the eminent musician and composer, wrote one serious work, "The Jews as They Are Published," nearly twenty years ago, which is especially interesting for its ingenious chapter entitled "Shylock from a Jewish Point of View."

WE are confident that readers will be glad to See reproduced in these columns several striking paragraphs from the paper which Mr. Frederic Harrison has contributed to the current number of The Nineteenth Century giving his "Impressions of America."

Banks are now informing their depositors how money paid to the United States for unused check stamps may be recovered, and the process is similar for all unused revenue stamps. The banks begin by assuming it is none of their business, as the matter is asserted to be wholly between the depositor and the Treasury.

The Chinaman paints an eye on the prow of his junk. This eye plays the part of the lookout man; thus collisions are prevented. It has been suggested that this is the primal form from which the European figurehead was evolved. John Chinaman does not appear to have cultivated to any great extent the taste for going down to the sea in ships; that would account for the elementary character of the Chinese figurehead.

DR. HENRY VAN DYKE will publish in the Autumn a new volume entitled. "The Ruling Passion." He is quoted as having recently described it as "fiction pure and simple, out-of-door stories, plain humanity in action on nature's stage. What I wish to do is not to paint a historical period or a section of the country, but just to get hold of the real drama of a few men and women.

THE recent appetite for information about China has so far been satiated by the mass of literature fur which the Boxers are indirectly responsible that there is now no excuse for a new book on the subject unless it possesses special features.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: There is not really such a lack or children's books, but there is a real lack of the opportunity of children getting hold of them. There are many libraries, and many libraries intended especially for children, that contain very few books that children care for.

The investigation into the sinking of the Staten Island ferryboat Northfield by collision with the New Jersey Central Railroad ferryboat Mauch Chunk June 14, was begun yesterday morning in the Federal Building before Capts. Barnett and Petrie, local representatives of the Board of Steam Vessel Inspectors.
From The London Express. Some very striking figures are contained in the preliminary report on the census of Ireland, which was issued on Saturday.

President Eliot's radical remedy for the extravagant time now demanded for an education, both collegiate and professional, is, as our readers are aware, to cut down the period for the college proper to three years. In this he is warmly supported by Justice Simeon E. Baldwin, the Professor of Constitutional Law at Yale, in an article in The International Monthly.

It has been said of Bishop Doane by a clever Englishman that he was "an American Bishop with the manners of an Oriental Prince." The contrasts in his character that elicited this remark are shown in his varied verse. In the preface to his daintily white and sold bound volume the author modestly disclaims the birthright of poet, designating his poetical fancies as "rhymes."

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Samuel Gompers, President of the American Federation of Labor, was severely injured last night while stepping from a street car, and there is only a slight chance of his recovery. He is suffering from concussion of the brain. His physician, Dr. Edward Calloch, says his condition is critical.

BAY SHORE, L.I., June 28 -- A novel handicap foursome or series of foursomes will be played here to-morrow on the Hyde estate, where the Bay Shore Golf Club has its links. The matches will be medal play, handicap, but it will be a blind or sealed handicap. No player will know what his handicap is until the matches are finished.

HELENA, Montana, June 28 -- The United States Government to-day commenced another suit in the Federal Court against the Bitter Root Development Company, the Anaconda Copper Mining Company, and the Marcus Daly estate to recover more than $350,000 for timber, said to have been illegally cut upon the public domain.

The Commencement season is now at an end and the college poet has shut up shop and gone home, where his rhythmic adaptations of old saws and modern instances will find admirers among his friends and family. And the close of the college verse season suggests one or two thoughts.

BERLIN, June 28 -- Herr Bodel, President of the Board of Overseers of the Leipziger Bank, who was absent in the United States on business when the failure of the bank was announced, has cabled from New York that he has started for Germany.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 28 -- The drawing for positions in the races of next Tuesday took place this evening, and if there is any advantage in the outside position, where the current is a little the strongest, Georgetown has it in the 'Varsity race, with Cornell next. Then come Wisconsin, Columbia, Syracuse, and Pennsylvania in the order named.

Henry Johnson is a negro about fifty yars old, a hard worker, but poor. Henry has become a very important man during the past few weeks. He has prevented the erection of a building to cost about $40,000. And thereby hangs a tale.

LONDON, June 28 -- Maurice Grau said to-day that he expected to retire from the management and present lease of the Metropolitan Opera House of New York in 1902. Mr. Grau left London yesterday for Carlsad, where he will take a month's rest. His ernhardt-Coquelin season here has been lost successful, the receipts exceeding lose of any previous season of either oquelin or Bernhardt.

PARIS, June 29 -- The Premier, M. Waldeck-Rousseau, has carried the most important project of his Ministry, the Law of Associations bill, which now only awaits the signature of President Loubet to become law.

PHILADELPHIA, June 28 -- There was a decided improvement in the stock market to-day. The Readings, Lehigh Valley, Electric Storage Battery, and Union Traction, were all better. The last named, after dragging around 26 all the morning, was whirled up toward noon to 27 1/2 inside of ten minutes.
WASHINGTON, June 28 -- The Secretary of the Treasury to-day bought $151,000 short-term 5 per cent, bonds at 109.709, $97,340 3s at 109.9601, and $1,500 4s at 113.9187.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- The Census Office to-day issued a bulletin giving the number of persons of school age, males of militia age and voting age, and citizenship of foreign-born males twenty-one years of age and aver for a group of States and Territories comprising Alabama, Alaska, Arizona, Arkansas, California, Colorado, and Connicut.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 28 -- The suits against Philip Finnegan, ex-Collector of Taxes of Greenwich, and his thirteen bondsmen, have been dropped by the payment to the town of $21,750. At a conference of all parties interested yesterday at Bridgeport an agreement was reached and the suits for $150,000 were dropped.

VANCOUVER, B.C., June 28 -- The steamer Islander from Skagway to-day brings news of an exciting flag episode at Skagway. E.S. Busby, Canadian customs agent there, acting on instructions from Ottawa, hoisted the British flag on a pole above his office.

Judge John A. Blair in the Orphans' Court at Jersey City yesterday began taking testimony in the suit brought by Mrs. Edna C. Muir to set aside the will of her mother, Mrs. Edla J. McPherson, widow of John R. McPherson, United States Senator for New Jersey.

THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW briefly referred this Spring to the private sale of Albert J. Morgan's fine library to George H. Richmond, who did not long retain possession of the choicest items, the magnificent Kipling set being secured by George M. Williamson at $6,000 we believe. Mr. Richmond has recently printed an attractive catalogue of the Morgan books, which although evidently hastily prepared is invaluable in many ways.

NEWPORT, June 28 -- The cup yacht Constitution returned from New London this afternoon in a spanking breeze which the yacht fell in with while off Watch Hill. Up to that point the Constitution encountered but light winds and made the run in four hours. Mr. and Mrs. James A. Stillman were guests of Mr. Duncan on board, and upon arriving here were driven to the Stillman villa on Narragansett Avenue.

PHLADELPHIA, Penn., June 28 -- Miss Bessie Moore of the Kings County Tennis Club to-morrow will compete with Miss Myrtie McAteer for the title of National champion in the women's championship tournament. To-day at Wissahickon Heights she met and defeated Miss Marion Jones in the final round of singles.

NEWPORT, June 29. -- The new Summer home of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Berwind. The Elms, on Bellevue Avenue, is one of the most beautiful in Newport. It is constructed of white stone in the style of Louis XIV., with a central pavilion projecting beyond the two wings. The architecture is sober and yet graceful, and the architect, Horace Trumbauer of Philadelphia, has taken care that all the details have been perfectly executed.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 29. -- A suffrage and elections article for the proposed new Constitution was submitted to the Constitutional Convention to-day. It provides that, to vote at any election, a citizen shall have resided in the State at least two years, county one year, and precinct or ward three months preceding the election, and he shall have been daly registered and shall have paid all poll taxes due.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., June 29. -- An attempt to kill Miss Carlotta Barney, granddaughter of Jay Cooke, the famous financier of war times, was frustrated by the watchfulness of Charles Storm, a coachman employed by her father, Charles D. Barney, the banker, who detected the gun powder which sifted through the wrappings around an infernal machine mailed to the young woman.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 29. -- Maier Zunder, one of the oldest merchants of this city died to-day of gastritis and exhaustion, induced by the heat of the last two days. BAR HARBOR, Me., June 29. -- During a severe thunderstorm Toppinwold, the home of Francis W. Lawrence, brother of Bishop Lawrence of Massasetts, was struck by lightning, set afire, and destroyed. The cottage of William C. Allison of Philadelphia was struck and the roof and side wings destroyed.
CAPE MAY, N.J., June 29. -- All the hotels are now open here, the last of them opening to-day. The others have been entertaining guests for the last three weeks.

LONDON, June 29. -- The sale of Hoppner's portrait of Lady Louisa Manners, a good work but not great, for $70,000, at Willis's rooms, this week, was merely another illustration of the present tendency to overvalue old paintings.

The somewhat belated hot weather, which has arrived in all its glory and strength during the past week, has caused three of the city theatres, which had had phenomenally successful runs, to darken their houses for the Summer.
SCHENECTADY, N.Y., June 29. -- At noon to-day the thermometer registered 98, the highest point reached during the hot wave. There have been two prostrations, and one will result fatally.

LONG BRANCH, June 29. -- The Summer season at this resort is now in full swing. All the hotels and boarding houses are open, the boat lines are all running, and the Summer schedules of the railroad companies are in effect.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 29. -- A suffrage and elections article for the proposed new Constitution was submitted to the Constitutional Convention to-day. It provides that, to vote at any election, a citizen shall have resided in the State at least two years, county one year, and precinct or ward three months preceding the election, and he shall have been daly registered and shall have paid all poll taxes due.

Gen. Maximo Gomez, Cuba's Commander in Chief of the Army, and military leader, in many skirmishes and battles, arrived in New York yesterday afternoon on the Atlantic Express over the Pennsylvania Railroad from Tampa, Fla. With him upon his arrival in this city were Urbano Gomez, the General's son, and Alexander Gonzalez, the private Secretary of Gen. Leonard Wood, who is acting as interpreter for Gen. Gomez during his present visit.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., June 29. -- The cadet corps of the Twenty-third Regiment of Brooklyn arrived here at noon to go into camp for one week. There, were twenty-one members of the command, and they made an excellent appearance. The cadets left Brooklyn at 8:30, coming by the Patten Line to Ocean Grove and proceeding thence to the camp.

It is equally our duty to live up to our ideals in private and in public life and to seek to raise the standard of conduct wherever our influence extends.
CAPE MAY, N.J., June 29. -- All the hotels are now open here, the last of them opening to-day. The others have been entertaining guests for the last three weeks.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., June 29. -- The hot weather of the past week has started a number of the cottagers preparing for Newport and other seashore resorts, and the first week of July will see many cottages vacated for the Summer, but this week Tuxedo was almost as full as last.

NEWPORT, June 29. -- The new Summer home of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Berwind. The Elms, on Bellevue Avenue, is one of the most beautiful in Newport. It is constructed of white stone in the style of Louis XIV., with a central pavilion projecting beyond the two wings. The architecture is sober and yet graceful, and the architect, Horace Trumbauer of Philadelphia, has taken care that all the details have been perfectly executed.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., June 29. -- An attempt to kill Miss Carlotta Barney, granddaughter of Jay Cooke, the famous financier of war times, was frustrated by the watchfulness of Charles Storm, a coachman employed by her father, Charles D. Barney, the banker, who detected the gun powder which sifted through the wrappings around an infernal machine mailed to the young woman.

DANBURY, Conn., June 29. -- The party of excursionists who were on board the Mohawk arrived safely here at 10 o'clock tonight. Everybody was accounted for There was a large crowd at the station to receive the party and there was a great demonstration of delight when they descended safe and sound from the cars.

It was announced yesterday that a financial syndicate, consisting of Dr. W. Seward Webb, Chairman of the Rutland Railroad; J. Wesley Allison, President of the National Leather Company; Col. A.B. Chandler, President of the Postal Telegraph-Cable Company, and H.L. Burrage, Vice President of the Eliot National Bank of Boston, has become associated with the Cramps in their big steel plant at Collingwood, Canada.

About a ton of brick and cornice work fell from the wall in the rear of the tenement house at 242 Monroe Street last evening, slightly injuring one person, John Descher, but not seriously, and creating a panic among the inmates, which resulted in the Fire Department being called out.
TRAVEMUNDE, June 30 -- The Meteor, with Emperor William on board, won today's yacht race in Lubeck Bay.

BUFFALO, N.Y., June 30 -- The Week beginning to-morrow will be an Interesting one at the Pan-American Exposition. To-morrow will be Dominion Day. The Forty-eighth Highlanders of Toronto, one of the two kilted regiments of Canada, arrived at the Exposition 500 strong in a special train to-day.

LONDON, June 30 -- Our money market has been in a bad humor all the week. It thinks that the Bank of England has used it unfairly in charging 4 per cent. for seven-day advances, when money in open market was, up to midweek, under 3 per cent.

YONKERS, N.Y., June 30 -- Bessie Robert, seven years old, of 130 Clinton Place, this city, was killed by a trolley car of the Union Traction Company on Riverdale Avenue this evening directly in front of her home. Bessie was sent by her mother to a fruit store on the same side of the street in which she lived.
NEWPORT, June 30 -- To-day was the warmest day yet experienced this year. At noon the thermometer registered 89 degrees in the shade.

"Who's the Mayah of this yer town, Suh?" asked a long-haired individual with a lean face and figure to match, of Sergt. Norton at the West Thirtieth Street Station last night. "Is his name Hirchcliff, Van Cliff, Van Cleave, Van Dyke, or what?"

There has been a good deal of inexpensive wisdom talked about the inevitable displacement or subjugation of the "lower" by the "higher" races, and our own course in the Philippines has been justified on the theory that we are the helpless instruments of forces which we neither originate nor can guide.

BERLIN, June 30 -- The German Boerses were dominated wholly last week toy the failure of the Leipziger Bank, the influence of which was stronger than any other incident for years. The Frankfurter Zeitung says the lack of confidence is now greater perhaps than at any other time since the panic of 1873, being reinforced by the continually unfavorable report regarding general business.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 30 -- A large company of military men and civilians met today at Black Point to witness the transfer of the command of the Department of California and the Columbia from Major Gen. William R. Shafter to Major Gen. S.M.E. Young. Gen. Shafter made an address, in which he dwelt on his forty years of service and the results that have followed the Spanish war.

NEWARK, N.J., June 30 -- One of the largest crowds of the season witnessed the cycle races at the Vailsburg track today. The principal event of the day was a five-mile professional handicap in which W.S. Fenn of Waterbury, last year's amateur champion, won from the 100-yard mark in a close finish with Frank Kramer of East Orange, who was on scratch.

THE TIBETAN MISSION TO RUSSIA -- The mission from the Dalai Lama of Tibet to the Court of Nicholas II., which is now somewhere between Odessa and St. Petersburg, has been long in preparation, and is, in the opinion, of most European diplomatists, fraught with considerable importance for the destiny of Southwestern China.

A granite monument erected by the North German Lloyd Steamship Company in memory of the 171 victims of the Hoboken steamship fire was dedicated at Flower Hill Cemetery, North Bergen, N.J., yesterday, the first anniversary of the disaster.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., June 30 -- There appeared in a New York morning paper today the marriage announcement of the wedding of William T. Hawes to Minnie L. Wilson. The appearance of the notice was the first intimation most persons here had of the wedding, which took place on May 6.

With the beginning of the new fiscal year in many important corporations new and comprehensive plans will go into operation. Among the most important of these, as Wall Street hears on what may be considered official authority, will be the actual beginning of the anthracite coal combination.

NEW ROCHELLE, June 30 -- The sunken Mohawk lay all day Just as she did last night immediately after she sank with 900 excursionists on board. The wreck was thoroughly examined yesterday morning by Merritt-Chapman divers, and they reported they found no trace of any bodies. They sent up a lot of stuff belonging to the excursionists which had been abandoned by them when the steamboat sank.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The State of South Carolina, acting through the Governor and the Attorney General, has initiated proceedings before the Commissioner of Internal Revenue to test the question whether the State can be legally required to take out special tax stamps as wholesale and retail liquor dealers under the State dispensary laws, and has made a demand upon the Commissioner for a refund of all such taxes hitherto paid amounting to $4,916.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- An interesting extract from the volume entitled "Commercial Relations of the United States for 1900" was made public to-day by Frederic Emory, Chief of the Bureau of Foreign Commerce, State Department. The extract deals with American trade with Switzerland.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There was a time when the majority of the American people opposed the discussion of such questions as the slavery system, a stronger navy, a monetary standard, a National paper currency, and a uniform bankrupt law within the United States. All these burning questions were answered some time ago adversely to the aims of the majority of bygone times after a protracted and expensive agitation.

It is estimated that fully 150,000 visitors were entertained at Coney Island yesterday. Many of them were there before daybreak. Thousands had remained over from Saturday and snatched what sleep they could lying on the beach and under the piers, in preference to braving the heat of the city.

OCEAN GROVE, July 30 -- The "National Sabbath" was approppriately observed here to-day. Thousands attended the various meeting's held throughout the day on the camp grounds, and at every service patriotic prayers were offered and patriotic songs were sung. Despite the intense heat, the young people's meeting and the holiness meeting, both held at 9 A.M., were well attended.

Within the next fifteen days two new and important bridges in the Borough of the Bronx will be declared open by Commissioner Shea. On July 4 the new City Island Bridge, which is a steel structure connecting City Island with the mainland, will be opened with informal ceremonies. This bridge takes the place of the old wooden structure that for years had done duty at this point.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., June 30 -- The Rev. Dr. William B. Brown, pastor emeritus of the First Congregational Church of Newark, celebrated his eighty-fifth birthday at his home, 87 Chestnut Street, this city, yesterday afternoon. A reception was given to him by the members of the Newark High School Alumni Association, over 100 members of which called at his house in the afternoon.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 30 -- The first of the New York Yacht Club's special races for the Constitution and Columbia will be sailed to-morrow at 11:15 A.M. These are called tuning-up races, and as they will give Constitution her first opportunities to measure speed with a vessel of known ability they promise to be extremely interesting.

CATSKILL, N.Y., June 30 -- The Rev. Dr. Byron Sunderland of Washington, D.C., died of cerebral embolism this forenoon at the home in this city of his son-in-law, Orrin Day, President of the Tanners' National Bank.

The funeral of Eliza Rogers Jacob, wife of Bishop Henry C. Potter of the Diocese of New York, will take place in Grace Church at 10 o'clock to-morrow morning. The Rev. Dr. William R. Huntington, rector of Grace Church, will officiate. At the termination of the exercises the body will be taken to Poughkeepsie, where the interment will be.

BUFFALO, N.Y., June 30 -- A notice was posted on the door of the City National Bank to-day to the effect that the bank is in the hands of the Controller of the Currency, and that it will not open its doors for business to-morrow morning.

The body of George R. Sheldon, who died at Fordham Hospital Saturday night from the effects of jumping off High Bridge, was removed from the hospital yesterday morning and taken to Boyd's undertaking establishment in Fordham. Sheldon's mother, who lives in Hartford, Conn., has been telegraphed for, and the body is held awaiting directions from her.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 30 -- This was the last day of absolute rest that the oarsmen who represent six American universities will know until the great struggle of Tuesday is over. All of the crews were kept off the water because of it being Sunday, and the custom of resting on that day has been adhered to.

LINCOLN, Neb., June 30 -- To-day was the seventh during which the mercury has reached more than 99 degrees, and the fourth during which it has reached 100. For eight days the State has suffered from drought and south winds. Oats, potatoes, and hay crops have been badly injured, corn began to curl and wither to-day in the eastern part of the State.

In distributing among the owners and agents of dwellings designed for a multiple tenancy a circular setting forth some of the provisions of the law relative to tenement houses which goes into effect July 1, the Board of Health of this city has called attention in a way which a great many people will be likely to consider more zealous than discreet to its own exigent duties in matters pertaining to tenement house purification.

HENLEY-ON-THAMES, June 30 -- The Pennsylvania crew to-day enjoyed a thorough rest, their only exercise being a three-mile walk in the morning. "Bob" Cook, Yale's celebrated coach, arrived last night. He said of the crew: "I consider Pennsylvania in better physical condition than any other American crew who ever reached the eve of the Henley races.

It is believed that the decision rendered in Boston on Thursday last by Judge BROWN in the United States Circuit Court, in a suit involving the validity of the second Berliner patent, will have the effect of ending the monopoly of the Bell Telephone Company and opening the business to such competition as its promise of profit may invite.

The Rev. Dr. Thomas Gallaudet, rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of St. Ann's, at One Hundred and Forty-eighth Street, near Amsterdam Avenue, celebrated his fiftieth anniversary of work as a minister of the Gospel among deaf-mutes at that church yesterday, and a large congregation of deaf-mutes from far and near assembled to do honor to the venerable ecclesiastic.

According to the story told by Dennis Maroney in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday morning, there were riot and bloodshed at the picnic given by the Hugh Dennis Outing Association at Kroebel Park, Boulevard, Union Hill, New Jersey, on Saturday. Maroney was arrested after accompanying Thomas Dennis to the New York Hospital yesterday morning.

The heat of the past few days has driven hundreds of men and boys to bathe in the East, North, and Harlem Rivers, with the result that several cases of drowning have been reported to the police.
SCHENECTADY, N.Y., June 30 -- William Van Epps. one of the oldest locomotive engineers on the New York Central Railroad, who was sunstruck on Friday, died to-night, aged seventy-two years.

ROTHESAY, June 30 -- Kenneth M. Clark, a member of the Royal Ulster Yacht Club and owner of the cutter Kariad, who has witnessed all the trials of the two Shamrocks since the challenger was refitted, has asserted doubt whether the Shamrock II. is good enough to send to American waters in challenge for the America's cup.
WINNIPEG, Manitoba, June 30 -- Word reached the city to-night of the wreck on Lake Superior of the steamer Preston, Capt. Barlow, of Toledo.

MATTOON, Ill., June 30 -- Edward J. Walsh. Sr., President of the Mississippi Glass Company and of the St. Louis Terminal Company, and prominently identified with other St. Louis enterprises, died at 2:30 o'clock this afternoon from heat prostration on board a Big Four train between Gays and this city.

Peter Brown is the name given by a man under arrest by the police at Rockaway Beach. He is charged with attempting to pass worthless checks. He was caught at a hotel on the Boulevard kept by Mrs. Louis Gottlieb.

The finding of the mangled body of a man in the Coney Island Creek yesterday morning satisfied the police of the Coney Island Precinct that reports made to them of the killing of two men by cars were true. The railroad company has never been free with information concerning the accidents which happen on its lines, and the cases in point now show that the policy is still unchanged.

Wall Street is much interested in the meeting of the Directors of the United States Steel Corporation, to be held to-day to take action on the matter of dividends on the stocks of the company. A story heard in the Street yesterday was that the meeting might be adjourned until after Mr. Morgan's arrival here, but this could not be confirmed.

There is very likely a real distrust at the bottom of the reported refusal of the Empress Dowager to return to Peking, now that the Allies have swept and garnished it for her. Indeed, she has some reason for thinking that she might not be safe there, with a minimum of five thousand foreign troops intrenched and watching her proceedings.

Vice Chancellor Pitney at Jersey City yesterday heard argument on the application of Benjamin Meyer to restrain the New York Electrical Vehicle and Transportation Company from levying on its stock an assessment of $10 per share.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., July 1. -- The Rockaway Polo Team had Bryn Mawr beaten twice in the final match for the Morrell Cups on the field of the Philadelphia Country Club at Bala to-night, but lost, the game by a desperate spurt of the local players in the last period by the score of 16 3/4 goals to 13.

WASHINGTON, July 1. -- The hot weather continued unabated here to-day, the climax coming in the afternoon, when the local record for this time of the year was broken, the Weather Bureau thermometer recording a temperature of 102 degrees. Fortunately there was not much humidity. There were fifty cases of heat prostration reported, and two resulted fatally.

PITTSBURG, July 1. -- As a result of the refusal of the representatives of the American Sheet Steel Company and the American Steel Hoop Company, subsidiary companies of the United States. Steel Corporation, to sign the new wage scale of the Amalgamated Association of Iron, Steel and Tin Workers, the strike ordered by President Shaffer of the Amalgamated Association is now on.

The long and determined fight of Herbert C. Wadman's wife and sister to prove that his death in Manhattan State Hospital on March 5 resulted from the ill-treatment of hospital attendants proved finally successful yesterday, when a Coroner's jury returned a verdict in accordance with their belief.

WASHINGTON, July 1. -- The comparative statement of the Government receipts and expenditures shows that during, the fiscal year ended June 30, 1901, the total receipts from all sources amounted to $585,848,309, and the disbursements to $509,983,310, leaving a surplus for the year of $75,864,999.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The most outrageous piece of official impudence that any body of political servants has usurped recently is the leasing of the Park highways for some conniving schemers to make capital from. The placing of chairs in all the desirable shady places and charging to sit in them is the latest result of the superior intrinsic ability possessed by the Park Commissioners.
MANILA, July 1. -- Several insurgent officers and 350 bolomen have voluntarily taken the oath of allegiance at Cuino, Province of Bataan.

LONDON, July 1. -- Lord Strathcona and Mount Royal presided to-night at the Dominion Day dinner at the Hotel Cecil, which was attended by 300 persons, the company including the Right Hon. Joseph Chamberlain, Lord Aberdeen, and other ex-Canadian Governors General, Sir Louis H. Davies, David Mills, Sydney Fisher, and the other Canadian Ministers now in London, Gen. Ian Hamilton, Rear Admiral Douglas, Gilbert Parker, and other well-known men.

ALLENHURST, N.J., July 1. -- The Allenhurst Inn, one of the finest hotels alone the Atlantic Coast, in this State, was destroyed by fire this evening. The flames swept through the great frame structure and leveled it. The 165 guests were left homeless. With the hotel went three cottages close by.

ALBANY, N.Y., July 1. -- The thirty-ninth annual convention of the University of New York State opened to-night in this city, and is being attended by several hundred educators representing all of the colleges, academies, high schools, and other educational institutions in the State. A number of addresses were made at the opening session.

OMAHA, Neb., July 1. -- The critical period in the affairs of Nebraska grain men passed to-day and the State was drenched with showers after five days of most extraordinary weather. Eastern grain men, commission firms, and railroads have kept busy the wires through Nebraska and to Kansas points during the last forty-eight hours trying to ascertain the extent of the damage by high winds and high temperature.

In yesterday's Stock Exchange market the securities of the New York, Chicago and St. Louis Railroad -- popularly styled the Nickel Plate -- were conspicuous for the strength they showed in a market generally weak. Wall Street heard a variety of reports to account for the new activity and its advances.
Sonn Brothers have sold the block front on the east side of Amsterdam Avenue, between One Hundred and Forty-first and One Hundred and Forty-second Streets, to Thomas J. McGuire.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., July 1. -- A small, squealing pig and an Aldermanic Magistrate who saw a chance to emulate King Solomon, brought about a marriage to-day under peculiar circumstances. Miss Matilda Parkinson and Hiram Johnson have adjoining farms near Hudson and both are well over the half century mark.

ATLANTA, Ga., July 1. -- Application was made in the office of the Secretary of State this morning to increase the capital stock of the Savannah, Florida and Western Railway Company from its present capital to $25,000,000.

Through timely batting the New Yorks won the baseball game from Chicago yesterday at the Polo Grounds. The heat made the game somewhat monotonous, and it was not until after the ending of the sixth inning that the spectators had a chance to awake from their lethargy. "Jack" Doyle, now Captain of the Chicagos, but formerly first baseman of the New Yorks, was the cause of the awakening.

NEWPORT, July 1. -- Newport to-day again suffered from the heat, the thermometer at noon registering 88 degrees in the shade. Admiral Higginson early in the morning signalled to the ships of the North Atlantic Squadron orders that the officers be careful in regard to drills, holding only those that could be carried on without exposure to the sun.

DETROIT, July 1. -- George W. Radford, a member of the Detroit Public Library Board, has received a letter from Andrew Carnegie, stating that Mr. Carnegie will contribute $750,000 toward a new public library building in this city.

New Jersey sweltered yesterday under a burning sun which rushed the thermometers up to points between 85 and 104 in various parts of the State. The State Weather Bureau, with headquarters at New Brunswick, where the agricultural experimental station is located, pronounced the last two days record-breakers for all corresponding days.
ABERDEEN, S.D., July 1. -- Senator James H. Kyle died at 6:05 o'clock this evening.

PHILADELPHIA, July 1. -- The rise in Consolidated Lake Superior, at the close of the market, was the feature of the local market to-day. The warrants leaped from 2 3/4 to 5 1/2, and the common stock from 29 1/2 to 31, the preferred meantime touching 49, against 46 7/8 Saturday. This supplied the only real incident worthy of comment outside of Electric Storage Battery common, which was elevated 4 points.

LONDON, July 2. -- The Earl of Selborne, First Lord of the Admiralty, announced in the House of Lords yesterday that he had great gratification in informing the House that the hospital ship Maine had been presented as a free gift to the British Navy.

ORANGE, N.J., July 1. -- The fifteenth annual lawn tennis tournament for the championship of the Middle States, under the auspices of the National Lawn Tennis Association, was begun this afternoon on the courts of the Orange Lawn Tennis Club, at Mountain Station, N.J. On account of the absence of several well-known players who are now abroad, the entry list is smaller than usual, but the standard is fully maintained, and excellent matches are anticipated.

-- An article in The American Anthropologist on the health conditions in which DARWIN accomplished his colossal work has prompted The Medical Record to venture the suggestion that the great formulator of the evolutionary hypothesis was something of a hypochondriac. Until the age of twenty-two, when his voyage on the Beagle began, DARWIN was in excellent health, and devoted to out-door life and vigorous exercise.
EL PASO, Tex., July 1. -- Goronimo Parra, who was hanged in this city in January, 1900, is now claimed by reliable authority to have been wholly innocent of murder.

CHICAGO, July 1. -- Ten persons were killed and another was probably fatally injured this afternoon by a single bolt of lightning. The victims comprised four men and six boys. They had been in swimming in Lake Michigan, at the foot of Montrose Boulevard, on the North Side, and at the time were resting on a pier.

LONDON, July 1. -- The final round of the all-comers' doubles in the all-England lawn tennis championships, which began at Wimbledon last Monday, was played to-day. D. Davis and H. Ward, the Aemrican players, defeated Agger and Simond by 7 -- 5, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4. In the singles championship contest A.W. Gore defeated R.F. Doherty by three sets to one.

The most revolutionary order affecting the National Guard of New York State since that of 1886, which provided for the disbandment of the divisional organization of the guard and placed it on its present basis, was received at all brigade and regimental headquarters in the State last night.

WIFE'S PIN MONEY. -- Pin money given by a husband to his wife, and spent by her, cannot be reached by the husband's receiver in supplementary proceedings, is the decision of the Second Appellate Division. The question arose in an action brought by Matthew A. Broderick against Merritt L. Archibald and Camille E. Archibald, his wife, as third party.
BOSTON, July 1. -- Money loaned at the Clearing House to-day at 3 per cent. and New York funds sold at par. Exchanges, $18,395,306; balances, $2,341,702.

Our own automobilists must look with admiring despair upon the record of the automobile racing between Paris and Berlin. The first flight of the racers, "the tourist contingent," seems to have covered the distance between the two capitals at the rate of between forty and forty-five miles an hour.

Mites McDonnell's lawyers opened their client's defense of the charge of murdering George Price, in the Onawa Cafe, in December last, after the prosecution rested its case yesterday, before Justice Fursman, in the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court, by eliciting much favorable testimony from a witness the State privately examined but failed to call.

Harry Simmons, sixteen years old, who lives with his parents at East Thirteenth Street and Avenue D, Parkville, was killed at 7:30 o'clock last evening by being run over by a trolley car of the Brooklyn and Coney Island Railroad Company, at Avenue E and Coney Island Avenue, near Coney Island.

Business in the outside market yesterday was small and presented very little change in the conditions which ruled at the end of the week. In no stock were the transactions large, and most of the changes showing in the final quotations were of small importance. Probably more advances occurred than declines, but in neither direction was there any decided movement.

If there is any sign of the times which would give support to Mr. WAYNE MACVEAGH'S gloomy predictions of coming violence and revolution it might be found in the sentiments to which Mr. MATTHEW BARR, President of the Amalgamated Sheet Metal Workers' Association, gave expression in a letter to THE TIMES published in our issue of yesterday.

CLEVELAND, July 1. -- The Leader to-morrow will say that before Sept. 1 all of the big companies producing bituminous coal in the United States will have been gathered into one organization similar to the United States Steel Corporation. The capitalization, it is said, will be enormous, probably second only to that of the big Steel Trust.

July sizzled into town yesterday as a record breaker, sending the mercury up the official tube at 3:10 o'clock in the afternoon to the 98 degree mark. Not only was it the hottest day of the Summer, but it was the hottest July 1 in the history of the Weather Bureau, the previous high record being in 1872 when the thermometer recorded 95 degrees.

The youngsters will have the honor of opening the polo tournament season of the Rockaway Hunting Club, at Cedarhurst today. The first of seven competitions for the Blizzard cups will be played and the opposing teams will be the second and third of the home club. The second team will be composed of Lauranee B. Rand, 2; Cortlandt R. Dixon, 2d, 2; Albert Franoka, 4; W. Blanchard Rand, 1. Total -- 9.

BUFFALO, July 2. -- State Superintendent of Banks F.D. Kilburn to-day closed the doors of the Niagara Bank, a State institution. The first that the depositors knew of the bank's trouble was when the notice closing it was posted. The clerks of the institution were as much surprised as the depositors.

Several months ago a correspondent of THE TIMES presented at some length and with sufficient detail to be perfectly intelligible a plan for putting New York in a position of advantage as compared with cities near great water powers in the matter of cheap and ample electrical currents for light and power.

The figures given out by the Department of Taxes and Assessments will encourage the advocates of personal taxation to indulge further in the delusions of hope. The increase in the assessments of real estate is $69,245,061 as compared with last year, and the increase in personal assessments is $64,617,014.

The Directors of the United States Steel Corporation at a meeting held yesterday afternoon at the offices of the corporation, 71 Broadway, placed both the preferred and common stocks of the company on a dividend basis by declaring 1% per cent, on the preferred, payable Aug. 7, and 1 per cent, on the common, payable Sept. 14.

BOSTON, July 2. -- Cincinnati batted Pittinger's pitching hard and often to-day and won easily. Hahn was effective at all times. An odd double play, in which Lowe succeeded in running down two Cincinnati men on the base line, was the feature of the game. Murphy of New Haven played his first game for Boston and made a good impression. Score:

OSSINING, N.Y., July 2. -- A tornado swept through the village this afternoon and along the shore at the Hudson, cutting a swath two miles long and several hundred feet wide. Trees were uprooted, buildings unroofed, and windows caved in as if made of tissue paper. No houses were blown down, but many were damaged by trees falling against them.

PHILADELPHIA, July 2. -- Excessive heat caused the smallest attendance of the year in the Philadelphia Exchange, and trading was in very small volume. The only event that disturbed the placid surface was a 3 1/2-point rise in the ElectricStorage Battery shares. Not a sale of Cambria Steel was recorded.
BOSTON, July 2. -- At the Clearing House to-day money loaned at 3@3 1/2 per cent. and New York funds sold at 10 cents discount. Exchanges, $34,319,417; balances, $3,521,093.

John D. Quincy, Assistant Corporation Counsel, assigned to the Board of Building Commissioners, died on Monday in Brooklyn after an illness of three months, in his fifty-seventh year. Mr. Quincy was born in Boston, and his family came of the famous Quincys of Revolutionary stock. He was educated in Baltimore, but after his marriage he came to this city and engaged actively in his profession of law.

Hot weather upset Wall Street notions of dignity yesterday. Among the many coatless men were the partners of J. P. Morgan Co., President Truesdale of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad; Deputy Assistant Treasurer Marlor at the Sub Treasury, and brokers galore in the larger offices.

MEXICO CITY, July 2. -- The public mind is much excited over the students' anticlerical demonstration yesterday. The students to the number of 300 held a public meeting. Speeches denouncing recent alleged immoralities of a few priests were made. It was charged that former Archbishop La Bastida was a traitor to his country.

New Jersey baked again yesterday until local showers in the afternoon caused a decided drop in the temperature, but in the evening after the storm had subsided there was a disposition on the part of the mercury to rise again. The outlook last night was for another scorcher to-day.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 2. -- The New York Inter-Urban Water Company filed articles of incorporation in the County Clerk's office to-day. This company bought the property and franchise of the New York Suburban Water Company under foreclosure sale on May 3, under proceedings brought by the Atlantic Trust Company.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The Secretary of the Treasury to-day bought $97,100 short-term 4 per cent, bonds at $112,9402, $12,000 5s at $109,0904, and $400 3s at $108,9803.

PHILADELPHIA, July 2. -- This city passed through another period or torture to-day, and to-night at least fifty-two persons lie dead as a result of the excessive heat and more than 300 others were prostrated. The official record of temperature made yesterday, 102 degrees, was eclipsed to-day when the Government thermometer at 3 P.M. touched 102 8-10 degrees, which now stands as the city's record.

It took much courage to indulge in field sports in the open yesterday, and piazzas and fans were much more comfortable. The warm weather began at Newport on Sunday, and reports from there and other resorts, although cool nights are claimed, are rather reassuring to those who have had to stay in town.

Trading on the stock market yesterday was practically at a standstill all day. Because of the great heat many operators were absent from the Street, while commission houses were almost deserted. The result was that the day's dealings were the smallest of any day this year, aggregating less than 200,000 shares.

Fire that is generally believed to have been caused by a stroke of lightning last evening completely destroyed the elevenstory brick and stone apartment house in course of construction in Ninety-fifth Street, near West End Avenue, spread to many apartment houses and private residences in the vicinity, and caused much excitement and fear among the residents of those places.

ORANGE, N.J., July 2. -- Despite the intense heat, some excellent play was witnessed in the annual Middle States championship lawn tennis tournament, under the auspices of the United States National Lawn Tennis Association on the grounds of the Orange Lawn Tennis Club at Mountain Station to-day.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The timely editorial in to-day's issue of THE TIMES, condemning the management of the New York Central and Hudson River Railroad Company for its wanton treatment of passengers carried through the Fourth or Park Avenue tunnel, ought at least to have the effect of abating that stiffling nuisance forthwith.

NEWPORT, July 2. -- Newport to-day was sweltering from early morning till late in the afternoon. At noon in the shade on Bellevue Avenue the thermometer read 89. The cottagers were noticeably absent from the avenue until the dining hour. During the driving hour the weather had become cooler, and many of the handsome horses and stylish traps belonging to the cottagers were out.

The yearling thoroughbred horses from L. O. Appleby's Sllverbrook breeding farm in New Jersey were sold by auction in the sale paddock at Sheepshead Bay yesterday, the offering drawing a good attendance and spirited bidding. The prize of the sale was the chestnut colt, full brother to All Green, by Knight of Ellerslie-Lizzie Pickwick, who went to D.C. Johnson for $4,800.

CLAYTON, Del., July 2. -- Special Agent I. N. Mills of the Philadelphia, Wilmington and Baltimore Railroad has just completed compiling the estimates of railroad agents in the Maryland and Delaware peninsula as to the peach crop of 1901.

Those overworked Titans, the trial Judges of the Supreme Court in this department, staggering under the too vast orb of their fates, laid down their burdens on Monday with sighs of relief for a brief respite. One of them, it is true, stays for a while, to be replaced anon by another, in order to take care of the ex-parte applications.

NEWPORT, July 2. -- Columbia's injury has been repaired, and she is ready for tomorrow's contest with Constitution. Her spare boom arrived here about 3 o'clock on a Chapman steamer, and was at once put on board. The crew at once set to work to bend the mainsails, and the work was completed before 6 o'clock.

"Captain" Godolphin Finney Burslem, a distinguished looking Englishman, with a cork leg, whose career, the police-say, is one of the most picturesque recorded in the annals of Scotland Yard, was committed to the Tombs by Recorder Goff yesterday in default of $1,000 ball, charged with stealing $40 from Mrs. Caroline W. Kramer or 271 West Fourteenth Street.

CHICAGO, July 2. -- While the Stanton Avenue police and Miss E. Valentine Smith, a representative of the Anti-Cruelty Society, stirred about to-day endeavoring to save the life of a canine hero, Scot by name, a policeman's bullet killed the animal.

Over 200 deaths in all the boroughs and over 300 cases of prostration in Manhattan alone, two heat records smashed to smithereens, and two furious black squalls which brought some relief was the result of yesterday's meterological record.
LONDON, July 2. -- Money was plentiful to-day, and the demand slackened materially. Loans were obtainable on practically the borrowers' terms. Discounts were disorganized.

Keeper Michael Carroll of the Manhattan State Hospital and an attendant, John Foley, of the same institution were arrested last night by Detectives Hallahan and Reed of the East One Hundred and Fourth Street Police Station charged with being implicated in and accessories to the death, on March 5 last in the institution with which they are connected, of Herbert C. Wadman.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., July 2. -- Cornell sympathizers should be satisfied with the glory of the Red and White to-night, for her men rowed victoriously in two races on the Hudson to-day, beating the former record and even the previous fastest time that four miles has ever been rowed over the Poughkeepsie-Highland course.

The one great topic of conversation among members of the National Guard yesterday was the order of the Acting Adjutant General, Brig. Gen. Fred Phisterer, consolidating the First and Fifth Brigades, thereby placing Brig. Gen. McCoskry Butt and his staff on the supernumerary list.

By winning yesterday's baseball game from Chicago, the New Yorks have a comfortable hold on second place, with which to start their second Western trip. In the first three innings of the contest the sun was out. Then the wind became puffy, clouds began to gather, and the Chicago's played dilatory ball in the hopes of rain, much to the disgust of the rather small crowd.

WASHINGTON, July 2. -- Reports received at the Weather Bureau in this city from throughout the entire area affected by the intense heat show a continuation of very high temperatures save in a few localities where more moderate weather resuited in consequence of thunderstorms or other local atmospheric disturbances.
HUNTINGTON, West Va., July 2. -- A fire raged in the heart of this city from 11 o'clock this morning until 5 o'clock this evening, resulting in a loss of $200,000.

As a problem in corporate finance, the question of the wisdom or unwisdom of the decision of the Directorate of the United States Steel Corporation, to pay a dividend of 1 per cent. on its issue of common stock, is a good deal like one of the problems in casuistry which the Oriental sages were fond of propounding to their pupils.

CHICAGO, July 3 -- Two new telescopes are being constructed at the Yerkes Observatory. One is a two-foot horizontal reflecting glass of 165 feet focal length, and from it much is expected. Images of the heavenly bodies will be brought into physical laboratories, where delicate instruments, which are useless in the open dome, can be employed.

Mrs. Paul L. Thebaud, who died yesterday at the New York Foundling Asylum, was the widow, of Paul L. Thebaud, who died recently. She was Miss Caroline Gibert, a member of the well-known French family of that name, and an aunt of Mrs. Hugo Fritsch, the Misses Gibert, and Mrs. James B. Townsend.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., July 3 -- S.A. Vilson died at his home here yesterday from the effects of the heat. Mr. Vilson was born in Sweden in 1851. He had a hardware business in Brooklyn for many years, but sold out recently, intending to pass the remainder of his days in this place.
A severe thunderstorm passed over New Jersey yesterday afternoon, during which two persons were killed by lightning bolts and many houses and barns were set on fire by the same cause.
An application in bankruptcy proceedings was filed yesterday in the United States District Court, this city, on behalf of Jerome Byron Wheeler, now living at the Union League Club, New York.

RICHMOND, Va., July 3 -- There was a pathetic incident in the Constitutional Convention to-day. Soon after the body met Delegate Thornton proposed that an additional page be appointed, and suggested the name of Walter Moncure.

LONDON, July 3 -- The Dohertys retain the tennis championship by the consistent, safe game they played to-day, at Wimbledon against the brilliant display of Davis and Ward, the Americans. The latter gained their points by magnificent strokes, Davis scoring frequently with hard smashes and back-hand volleys, such as had never been seen at Wimbledon, and which elicited rounds of applause.
Pocher Co. have sold for John H. Tonyes to an investor the five-story apartment and store 877 Second Avenue, south-west corner of Forty-seventh Street, on lot 25 by 73.

PHILADELPHIA, July 3 -- Only a handful of brokers were on the floor to-day. Most prices were a little above those of last night. There was a jump of 1/2 in Union Traction without intervening sale. Near the close the price reached 27 3/2. There was a moderate demand for Cambria Steel, and the buying was of an excellent character.

PHILADELPHIA, July 3 -- Wu Ting-Fang, the Chinese Minister, arrived here from Washington to-night for the purpose of delivering the Fourth of July oration in the public exercises at Independence Hall to-morrow, and is a guest at the Hotel Walton under the watchful eyes of city detectives.

Thunderstorms, with resulting cool breezes, came to the relief of New Jersey yesterday afternoon. Up to midday the boat was almost, as intense as on the previous day, but at that hour thunderheads began to manifest themselves and clouds overspread the sky so that the heat was mitigated, and when the storms broke during the afternoon there was a respite for a few hours.

The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25-cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,5OO and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

Frederick Fries, forty-two years old, a wealthy coal dealer, living at 283 Hart Street, Brooklyn, was killed yesterday by falling from the third-story window of his house into the rear yard. His sister, Miss Barbara Fries, who occupied a room on the third floor of the dwelling, heard her brother at a window of an adjoining room and then she heard a heavy fall.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- It is reported here on quite good authority that Col. Myron Herrick of Cleveland, Ohio, friend and business associate of Senator Hanna, is to receive an appointment in the diplomatic service. Italy is named as the place to which he will be sent, though just now George V.L. Meyer of Massachusetts is the United States Ambassador to Italy.

Raids on three handbook poolrooms situated in saloons in the down-town district were engineered yesterday by the New York Society for the Enforcement of the Criminal Law, of which Joseph A. Britton is Superintendent. The places raided were at 67 Beaver Street, 55 Whitehall Street, and 85 South Street.

DENVER, July 3 -- The bad feeling engendered in the mining region near Telluride by the labor troubles came to a head to-day in an outbreak at the Smuggler-Union Mine. A dispute between a striker and a non-union miner ended in shooting. It is not known which fired the first shot, but soon the camp was in an uproar. Both sides were armed, and the shooting was general.

LONDON, July 3 -- The American oarsmen from the University of Pennsylvania more than justified the assertions of their trainer and coach to-day at the formal opening of the Henley Royal Regatta by winning their first heat in the race for the Grand Challenge Cup, with an ease and in a style that compelled even the most partisan of the English rowing experts to admit their quality.

BOSTON, July 3 -- At the Clearing House to-day money between the banks loaned at 3 per cent. The supply was large, and money was taken home. New York fund's were heavy with sales at 10, 12 1/2, and 17 cents discount for cash -- mostly 10 cents. Exchanges, $29,991,038; balances, $2,182,714.

HUDSON, N.Y., July 3 -- Samuel Moffat, the oldest brother of David Moffat of Denver, Col., died in Goshen yesterday. In 1857 he established the Bank of Nebraska, said to be the second founded west of the Missouri River, making the journey there on horseback and carrying $50,000 in gold. In 1874 he established the State Bank at Chatham, N.Y., and retired from active business in 1878.

The Directors of the Seventh National Bank met yesterday morning, as announced, and discussed a plan to pay all depositors in full, to take up the Marquand loan, and to re-establish the bank on a solvent basis.

First Lieut. Tenney Ross, Third Infantry, upon his arrival at Vancouver Barracks, Washington, and the completion of his duties with recruits, will report to the commanding officer of that post for duty with the Twenty-eighth Infantry.
ROTHESAY, Firth of Clyde, July 3 -- In the race between the two Shamrocks to-day the Shamrock I. finished a minute ahead.

Practically no business was transacted on the curb yesterday. More thought was given to the approaching three days' holiday than to the execution of orders, and few of these found their way to the market. As was natural under the circumstances prices were irregular and without feature. A few changes of importance occurred, but for the most part variations from the previous day's figures were small.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- The George Washington Memorial Association to-morrow will issue a general appeal for assistance in the erection of a memorial building to be sacred to the memory of Washington. The society numbers 1,500 members, and it has the co-operation of the National Academy of Sciences and the Washington Academy of Sciences.

In the discussion that is allowed to find its way to the public as to the plans of Tammany for the judicial nominations this Fall, there has not appeared as yet at all conspicuously the name of Justice MORGAN J. O'BRIEN. It may be that it is taken for granted that the "regular" Democratic organization will not throw away the advantage it could surely obtain by so obviously good a nomination.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- A remarkable story of Filipino cruelty comes to the War Department in the shape of a general order containing the records of the trial before a military commission convened at Nueva Caceres of seven natives charged with abduction, assault with intent to kill, murder, and guerrilla fighting in violation of the rules of war.

The windstorm of Tuesday evening played havoc with the telegraph wires all over the New England and Middle Atlantic States, and after the large forces of linemen sent out by the companies had succeeded in partially restoring the service, the storm of yesterday afternoon appeared and undid much of the work.
BINGHAMTON, N.Y., July 3 -- Two of the three races on the card of the Central New York circuit were quite long drawn out here to-day. Good time was made in the respective classes. Summaries:

NEWPORT, R.I., July 3 -- The rose show of the Newport Horticultural Society was held in Masonic Hall to-day, and was the most successful exhibition of its kind, artistically and financially, ever held in Newport. Much of the success is due to the efforts of Mrs. Burke Roche, who not only contributed prizes, but interested in the event a large number of the cottage colony.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 3 -- The sum of $30,000, in bright, new twenty-dollar gold pieces, are missing from the Cashier's vault of the United States Mint. Although the mint officials have been working on the case for four days, they have no clow to the disappearance of the coin.

MANILA, July 3 -- Representative Hull of Iowa, Chairman of the House Committee on Military Affairs, who accompanied Gen. Chaffee on his Southern tour, characterizes the rapid establishment of provincial governments as "hothouse plants, unable to withstand adversities." He said that there will be many difficulties under the dual civil-military government, which will be inaugurated to-morrow.
LONDON, July 4 -- In the course of the debate in the House of Commons yesterday on the naval estimates, the Cabinet Ministers were heckled on all sides regarding the condition of the navy.

The completely independent and integral nationality of the English people counts from the Norman Conquest, nearly a thousand years. That of the French is much older, as is that of the Spaniards whom we were fighting a couple of years since.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 3 -- An unsuccessful attempt to sail the second race between Constitution and Columbia was made to-day. The failure was due to an accident on the Columbia. She was sailing like a witch at the time and was more than holding her own with the newer vessel. The conditions of the day were such that a thoroughly satisfactory trial was expected, and the accident caused the greatest disappointment.

CINCINNATI, July 3 -- Judge A.C. Thompson of the United States Court to-day allowed a temporary injunction against the striking machinists. The action had been anticipated, and as Judge Thompson is to sail for Europe next Saturday it was expected that Judge Clark would hear the case.
Bar silver was quoted in London at 27 1/8d per ounce, and in New York at 59 1/8c. Mexican dollars at 47c.

Wall Street has witnessed wonderful developments since the Fourth of July last year. Then there was trepidation throughout the financial world, politics was bothering, much effort was being made to create the impression that National election results were in doubt, that cheap money and repudiation were actual impending dangers.

With the arrival of the boating and bathing season the U.S. Volunteer Life-Saving Corps of New York has sent broadcast through the mails a printed circular giving many practical instructions tending to lessen the danger of aquatic accidents and for the saving of life after such accident has taken place.

To-day is the "glorious" Fourth. With the vacation on the Stock Exchange, it means that every one who can get out of town will do so and will remain away until Monday. All the resorts have arranged extra attractions, a programme or summary of which was given yesterday. There are also many yachting parties.

PARIS, July 3 -- A Yellow Book issued to-day covers the Chinese negotiations from the end of 1900, when the joint note was presented to the middle of last month, when the Ministers decided the question of indemnity. The dispatches deal chiefly with the discussions in regard to the total of the indemnity and how China should pay it.

TACOMA, Washington, July 3 -- It is definitely announced to-night by interests closely connected with the Northern Pacific Railroad that J.P. Morgan Co. have purchased of George B. Dodwell, Frederick Dodwell, and Hugh C. Wallace the Northern Pacific Steamship Company and the Washington and Alaska Steamship Company.
Because of the extraordinary heat the floating hospitals of St. John's Guild will make their first trip of the season to-morrow, Instead of on Monday next, as had been planned.

Central Office detectives yesterday arraigned in the Jefferson Market Police Court three prisoners who had been arrested for connection with the robbery of the cloak manufacturing house of Levi Brenner at 194 Greene Street.

Henry Murray, a horseshoer, who lives with his sister, Mrs. McCann, at 309 East Sixty-fifth Street, was waylaid by live men at Washington and Barrow Streets last night, as he was coming from his smithy, which is located at king and Washington Streets. As a result of the attack upon him Murray lies in St. Vincent's Hospital, his head swathed in bandages.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., July 4. -- Owing to the rain the Canadians were enabled to draw the game at Haverford this afternoon. As was generally expected, Scattergood declared his innings closed, and the Canadians went to the bat, but made a very poor showing, owing to the very fine bowling of Lester, who obtained six wickets for 11 runs, a remarkable performance.
BROCKTON, Mass., July 4. -- In a twenty, mile motor-paced race this afternoon Ben Munro of Memphis, Tenn., defeated John Dubois of this city, the time being 3224.

A mass of bunting from stem to stern in honor of the anniversary of American independence, the great Hamburg-American liner Deutschland arrived at the bar from Europe yesterday morning about 8:30 o'clock. Two and a half hours later she was tied up at the piers in Hoboken and her 934 passengers landed.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read with much interest your editorials and other articles regarding the New York Central Railroad tunnel, and I sincerely hope that the agitation will soon prompt the Board of Health to take some action to relieve the sufferings of the thousands who daily have to travel through it.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Apologizing for troubling you with what may be considered a personal matter, I venture to make a request for space in THE TIMES in order to explain how I came to send a "garbled statement about the bylaw" of which Mr. Barr complains.

MONADNOCK, N.H., July 4. -- George E. Leighton of St. Louis died at his Summer home here yesterday. Mr. Leighton was perhaps St. Louis's most representative citizen. He was a lawyer, a business man, an economist, and a litterateur.

The establishment of a qualified form of civil government in the Philippines, which was formally inaugurated yesterday, cannot be called a complete reversal of our policy there, but it is so marked a development in that policy, and is due to such a great change in the condition's that the contrast with even a few months since is very striking.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Believing that it is the wish of the press to report according to facts, I take the liberty of calling your attention to the errorn and misstatements contained in the published accounts of the fire at Alienhurst, N.J., on the night of July 1.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Col., July 4. -- A fiery beacon, 500 feet long and blazing for hundreds of feet in the air, was set off on the summit of Pike's Peak at dark tonight. The immense sheet of flame over 14,000 feet above sea level, was visible from Cheyenne, nearly 200 miles north, to New Mexico, the same distance to the south.

PITTSBURG, July 4. -- A brilliant victory in the morning and a crushing defeat in the afternoon was the lot of the New York baseball team to-day. The victory in the morning regained for the New Yorks the lead in the pennant race, while the afternoon's defeat put them back in second place.

ORANGE, N.J., July 4. -- Play in the lawn tennis tournament for the championship of the Middle States, under the auspices of the United States National Lawn Tennis Association, was continued to-day on the courts of the Orange Lawn Tennis Club, at Mountain Station, and the time lost on account of yesterday's storm was almost entirely made up.

NEWPORT, R.I., July. 4. -- Independence Day was celebrated by the cottagers here with many entertainments, which practically marked the opening of the season's Summer functions. ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 4. -- John Helnrich, Professor of Music at the University of Rochester, while celebrating the Fourth this afternoon, fired an inch-and-a-half cartridge from a breech-loading brass cannon. He says he aimed the cannon toward an open field and directly at an oak tree. The explosion threw the cannon in the air.

PARIS, July 4. -- The United States Embassy and Consulate and a majority of the American business houses and stores here were decorated to-day with the Stars and Stripes and the French tricolor, hung together.
