The bursting of a twelve-inch water main at Broadway and Ninety-sixth Street yesterday morning liberated thousands of gallons of water which, forming a geyser, tore up the ground for a considerable distance, almost uprooted a huge tree by its force, and swept along the east side of Broadway like a river, and filled every cellar from Ninety-sixth to Ninety-seventh Street, doing thousands of dollars worth of damage.

MANILA, July 8 -- The United States Philippine Commission has ordered H. Pheips Whitmarsh, the Governor of Benguet Province, to come to Manila and submit to an investigation, owing to the allegation that he has been using his position to his personal advantage, in acquiring land and mining rights from the natives.

SPRINGFONTEIN, Orange River Colony, May, 4 -- Such a night as can only be experienced in South Africa -- the stars great, liquid, white points of fire in the blue-black dome, and just enough moon to show where sky and veldt begins.

William J. Stillman, at one time Consul at Rome, died on Saturday at his English home, Frimley Green, Surrey. He was born in Schenectady, N.Y., June 1, 1828, and was graduated from Union College in 1818. He at once began the study of landscape painting under Frederick E. Church, and a year later paid his first visit to Europe.

Domenico Salamando, a drug clerk, twenty-eight years old, living at 1,271 Prospect Place, Brooklyn, was found dead, with a bullet in his brain, in the street a few doors away from his home early yesterday morning. No pistol was found near the body, and it was evident, from the position of the wound in the head, that it was a case of murder.

It was learned last night that one of the men implicated in the shooting of Theodore Johansen, in Leggett's Lane, Saturday night, surrendered Sunday evening to Capt. Weigand of the Morrisania Police Station. After invoking the protection of the officers he grave the names of his confederates.

Isaaca H. Ciothier has bought from John W. Salter and the Bradley estate the plot on the north side of Ninety-fifth Street, 100 feet east of Madison Avenue. Mr. Clothier purchased last week a plot on the south side of Ninety-sixth Street, 200 feet east of Madison Avenue.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Robert J. Trace-well, the Controller of the Treasury, has decided that the Secretary of the Treasury has authority under the law to refund to Lascelles Co. of New Tork the duties paid by them on sugar imported from Porto Rico between the date the Treaty of Paris took effect and the date of the approval of the Foraker act.

BUFFALO, July 8 -- Two records were broken in the A.A.U. handicap swimming contests in the Pan-American Park lake this afternoon. In the 220-yard handicap E.C. Schaeffer of the National Swimming Association of Philadelphia lowered the American record for the distance, formerly held by himself, from 2:53 3-5 to 2:50 4-5.

BOSTON, July 8 -- The Wilson and Furness-Leyland Line steamer Cambrian, Capt. Lee, arrived at 5 o'clock this morning from London, having on board the shipwrecked crew of the Norwegian bark Hanna, which was wrecked by collision with the Cambrian in a dense fog early on the morning of July 4.

Yesterday marked the close of the large house parties which were given over the Fourth of July, It also marked the most interesting day of the yacht races at Newport, to which all yachtsmen have gone. There were more than the usual number of people in town, going from one place to another.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., July 8 -- In an unexpected and rather humorous way County Treasurer William Haubennestel of Dutchess County was to-day made an unvilling witness in an excise case.

Commissioner NAGLE must be set down as one of the most efficient anti-Tammany workers now in the field. The moral malaria for which the Police Department is responsible on the east side is not so readily perceptible nor so immediately disgusting as the physical stenches which arise in consequence of the inefficiency of the Street Cleaping Department.

PATERSON, July 8 -- Interest in the provable litigation over the will of Jacob S. Rogers was revived here by rumors that in due time there would appear among the claimants to the eccentric locomotive manufacturer's millions a young woman, a daughter of the deceased, and one whose existence up to now has not even been suspected.

PARIS, July 8 -- Inquiries made regarding a report, circulated in the United States, that Mrs. Ogden Mills was seriously ill here, show that she is stopping at the Hotel Continental, and was recently operated upon as the result of an attack of appendicitis. Mr. Mills said to-day that his wife was improving and was in no danger.

Except in three or four stocks, trading in the outside market yesterday was at a standstill. The weakness of the Stock Exchange market influenced unfavorably the course of prices on the curb, and even where there were few or no transactions, quotations dropped off. Practically none of the active stocks showed any advance for the day, the downward movement of prices being more decided than on any recent day.

Andrew Carnegie, from his castle in Scotland, has notified the Republicans of the Twenty-first Assembly District of this county that he has not the time to accept a nomination for the Mayoralty of New York.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- It was ascertained at the War Department to-day that it is not the intention of the United States Government to interfere in Cuba to the extent of preventing the payment of Cuban bonds, should the new Government of Cuba determine to assume the bonds issued by the former so-called government and junta.

The pay of eleven Police Captains of the sixteen promoted by the old Police Board is going to be "held up" until the courts establish whether legally they were advanced from Sergeantcies. Whether the entire sixteen will be involved has not been settled. Five of the Sergeants promoted are veterans, and it was said yesterday that their standing would not be contested by the Civil Service Reform Association.

Several hundred boys and girls standing in front of Public School No. 1, at 8 Henry Street, early yesterday morning, looked with interest on the sign conspicuously posted, "Vacation Schools and Playgrounds Open To-day." In other parts of the city similar crowds collected before the school houses.

It is reported to be the intention of Postmaster General SMITH to use the utmost powers of the department to check the use of the mails illegally for private advantage. The law is not entirely clear, and heretofore the department has preferred to try to get it made more specific and stronger before proceeding fully to enforce it.

ST. LOUIS, July 8 -- Umpire O'Day was mobbed here to-day after the baseball game between the local team and Brooklyn, and he was roughly handled, coming out of the melee with a split lip and several unimportant scratches. For a while it looked as though O'Day's baseball days were at an end, as the crowd was fearfully incensed at one of his decisions in the eighth inning, which practically gave Brooklyn the game.

Bids were opened yesterday by Commissioner of Highways Keating for asphalt work which will cost the city about $500,000. The most important contract to be let is that for the asphalting of Broadway from Canal Street to Fourteenth Street. The estimated cost of this work is $200,000. There were two bids for the job.

Dorothy, wife of William Conquest, a worker in wicker for baby carriages, of 504 Humboldt Street, Brooklyn, lost her life in a singular way last Sunday night. The responsibility for her fate rests with the Long Island Railroad Company's agents, as she fell from a train on the railroad platform at Howard, on the Rockaway Beach trestle, and death came slowly from drowning.

WASHINGTON, July 9. -- Director Merriam said to-day that he expects to complete the work of the 1900 census by the 1st of next July. This means the publication of ten volumes of statistics on the subjects of agriculture, manufactures, population, and vital statistics.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, July 4. -- The Boer prisoners, recently transported here, are, as a whole, a fine-looking lot of men. The Free Staters, who number about 800 men, have been placed on Darrell's Island, and the Transvaalers, a less contented crowd, whose confessed desire is to be free to fight again, and who number about 130 are on Burtt's or Moses's Island.

PATERSON, N.J., July 9. -- The will of Jacob S. Rogers was made public to-day by the executors of the estate. It was executed on June 23, 1892. It was witnessed by John Havron of Paterson, George E. Hanna of Brooklyn, and F.J. Shadler of New York. The first codicil was added on Dec. 11, 1894; the second Dec. 5, 1898; the third on May 4, 1890, and the fourth on Oct. 2, 1900.

SHARON, Penn., July 9. -- After many vexatious delays and litigation, covering several years, Jonathan and Charles Eaton of Hickory Township, Mercur County, are now about to secure possession of an estate in Minnesota which is worth about $1,000,000.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 9. -- Peter F. Meyer, Richard Croker's business partner, is having trouble here on account of his dogs. He has five of them, and has stead-fastly refused to obey the strict laws which are in force here regarding the licensing of canines. So Prosecuting Attorney James F. Walsh instructed Constable James J. Nedley to arrest Meyer to-day.

LONDON, July 9. -- The much-discussed meeting of Liberals called by Sir Henry Campbell-Bannerman, the Liberal leader in the House of Commons, to ascertain whether he still retains the confidence of the party, was held at the Reform Club this afternoon, and resulted in the adoption of a vote of confidence in the leader of the Opposition. All factions of Liberals attended.
Gen. Burnett, the United States District Attorney for the Southern District of New York, talking yesterday of his investigation of the affairs of the Seventh National Bank, said:

NEWPORT, July 9. -- The most interesting race of the thirty-foot class yachts took place this afternoon over a windward and leeward course, twice over, with the start from Rose Island and the outer mark at Bishop's Buoy, the finish, a distance of six miles. Five boats started and two finished.

LONDON, July 9. -- Business on the Stock Exchange to-day was almost stagnant in all departments. First-class securities were weak, partly due to a large bull account and uneasiness as to the financial situation abroad.

BERLIN, July 9. -- Although the United States Ambassador, Andrew D. White, quite recently denied that he intends to resign, a close personal friend of Mr. White now says that he will resign next year, upon reaching his seventieth year. Mr. White's decision to resign was taken before the news of his son's suicide reached him.

The judgment for $5,323.32 awarded to Frank D. Mowbray on a verdict of a jury in his action in the Supreme Court, before Justice Giegerich, against Howard Could, has been reversed unanimously by the Appellate Division, in an opinion by Justice McLaughlin, which will be handed down to-day.

David Stephen du Plooy, a young Boer soldier, who served under Cronje, and then was a prisoner of war, arrived in New York a stowaway on the steamship Trinidad from Bermuda yesterday. He was not of the 900 Boer prisoners recently landed at Bermuda by the British military authorities.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 9. -- The McLean-Kilbourne element at the district meetings this afternoon secured control of all the committees and will accordingly have everything their way at the Democratic State Convention to-morrow. They were so strongly in the majority that there was no friction.

BOSTON, July 9. -- An operation for cancer was performed upon Rear Admiral Francis M. Bunce, United States Navy, retired, of Hartford, Conn., at the Eliot Hospital yesterday, entailing the removal of nearly the whole of his tongue.

The wrestling match between Gus Ruhlin and Bob Fitzsimmons last night in Madison Square Garden came dangerously near being decided on pugilistic lines. Ruhlin won the match in straight falls, but only after a vigorous if not altogether scientific encounter.

ALBANY, July 9. -- Appointments to State scholarships in Cornell University for the year 1901 were made by State Superintendent of Public Instruction Charles R. Skinner. These scholarships entitle their holders to a four years' course of instruction in Cornell University free of tuition.

The recent recourse to violence of the farmers of Osage County, Kan., in order to secure the labor needed to enable them to gather their harvests is one of the most curious and instructive incidents in contemporaneous industrial history. The farmers of that district are very much in need of field hands through the harvest season, and knew of no way to get them.
BOSTON, July 9. -- At the Clearing House to-day money loaned at 3 per cent., and New York funds sold at par, with some few sales at 5 cents premium. Exchanges, $24,524,503; balances, $2,525,349.

ROTHESAY, Firth of Clyde, July 9. -- In the first five miles of the racing trial between the Shamrocks this morning, both yachts apparently were sailing for all they were worth, and the challenger beat the Shamrock I. quite a half mile. The boats started to windward with a steady, gradually strengthening breeze, about sufficient to cover the America's Cup course.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 9. -- W. Butler Duncan, Jr., manager of Constitution, was seen to-day and spoke in regard to yesterday's race. He said that it was not a fair test of the comparative merits of the three yachts.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 9. -- Joseph M. Gates, a playwright, had a narrow escape from being drowned last evening. He and several theatrical friends were bathing at the foot of Fifth Avenue. Mr. Gates was some distance out from the beach when he was taken with cramps. He called for help and sank.

NOTTINGHAM, Ohio, July 9. -- One of the worst wrecks on the Lake Shore Road in years occurred at 2:30 o'clock this morning in the centre of this village, ten miles east of Cleveland. The Southwestern Limited, on the Big Four, from St. Louis, Cincinnati, and other Western cities, was ditched through collision with a portion of a freight train.
J. Romaine Brown Co. have sold for an estate to M.A. Ruling, for about $25,000, the four-story brownstone front dwelling 112 West Forty-ninth Street, 21.4 by 100.5.

Fashionable interest centres in Newport, where the yacht races are being held. Wednesday brings around the weekly dance at many of the suburban resorts, and polo at Seabright. To-day in town there will be a number of well-known people, relatives and friends of the Lorillard family, who are to pay the last tribute of respect to the late Pierre Lorillard at Grace Church this morning.

LONDON, July 9. -- Two horses owned by the American turfman William C. Whitney were winners at the Nottingham July meeting to-day. The Shibboleth filly won the Bingham Plate, five furlongs, for two-year-olds, and Holstein won the Basford Plate, one mile and a half, for three-year-olds and upward.

WASHINGTON, July 9. -- Another important exchange of correspondence has occurred between the Russian Government and the United States relative to the tariff. The Russian Minister of Finance, M. de Witte, has proposed that Russia will vacate all of the additional duties levied on American goods since the imposition of the sugar differential, if the United States will vacate its action on the sugar differential.

LONDON, July 10. -- Great heat extends throughout Western Europe, from Spain to Scandinavia. Heat prostrations are reported from many places. They have been very numerous in Paris, and in Copenhagen yesterday there were twenty deaths attributed to heat. Violent hailstorms have ruined the crops in the Province of Salamanca, Spain.

The order of Justice Scott of the Supreme Court providing for punishing Councilman Stewart M. Brice by fine and imprisonmen for not obeying a mandamus, secured by the Hall of Records contractor, John Pierce, compelling him and certain other Councilmen to vote for a bond resolution, was yesterday modified by the Appellate Division by eliminating from the order the provision for imprisonment.

The appeal taken by Theodore Allen, familiarly known as "The" Allen, from the order of the Special Term of the Supreme Court refusing to discharge him and several others on writs of habeas corpus, was yesterday dismissed by the Appellate Division. No opinion was written by the Court.

Nothing could be more absurd than the storm that has been stirred up about the introduction of chairs in the public parks. We have had an all-day riot about it already, and we are likely to have more of the same until the permission of Mr. CLAUSEN to a concessionaire to put seats in the parks and charge for them is formally and finally withdrawn.
CAPE TOWN, July 9. -- Four Boer prisoners who were to-day brought into Bloemfontein report that Gens. Botha, Delarey, and De Wet recently held a conference at a point on the Vaal River.

The accession of RICHARD OLNEY to the office of Secretary of State in June, 1895, a few days after the death of Secretary GRESHAM, was coincident with the beginning of a new stage in the Venezuela boundary controversy. From that moment we began to assert our own position in the matter with greater and increasing firmness, and forces were set in motion that urged the ancient dispute forward swiftly to its peaceful settlement.

ALBANY, July 9. -- Coroner H.J. Plantz to-day rendered a verdict in the case of the killing of William J. Walsh who was shot May 16th on Broadway, in this city, during the United Traction Company's strike, by a member of the Twenty-third Regiment of Brooklyn. After reciting the main facts connected with the strike, the Coroner finds:

One need not be a yachtsman in order to rejoice, in a mild way, to see Mr. LAWSON of Boston balked of his ambition. Mr. LAWSON'S ambition, in its original form, was to own the defender for this year of the America's Cup. That was a perfectly proper and legitimate aspiration, which every American citizen who can build and run a racing machine is entitled to cherish.

ST. LOUIS, July 9. -- Padden's single, which scored Burkett and Murphy, gave St. Louis to-day's game over Brooklyn after the score had been tied for five innings. O'Day did not umpire owing to injuries received in yesterday's riot. Two players officiated, as Warner did not arrive in time.

DETROIT, Mich., July 9. -- The report of the Committee on a National University was submitted to the National Council of Education this morning by Dr. William R. Harper of Chicago. It was stated in the report that at one of its earlier meetings the committee adopted the following declarations:

Real rapid transit from the Borough of the Bronx and points in Westchester County is promised by the New York and Portchester Railway Company. Portchester is on the Connecticut State line, twenty-five miles from Harlem, and the representatives of the new corporation promise to carry passengers from Portchester to the City Hall in Manhattan in fifty-four minutes at one-third the cost of the current rates.

John Fisher, twenty-four years old, the janitor of the house at 106 West One Hundred and First Street, was arrested yesterday afternoon by Capt. Wiegand and Detectives Everett and Foster of the Morrisania Police Station, charged with shooting Theodore Johansen of 722 Brook Avenue last Saturday night while Johansen and his friend, Frederick Haffner, were passing through Leggett's Lane, in the Bronx.

LONDON, July 9. -- Both the Americans and the British have been congratulating themselves on the fact that the Henley regatta passed off without international friction of any kind. The congratulations were premature. Friday night the Leanders gave a dinner to the Pennsylvanians. All the prominent rowing authorities were present.
President George C. Clausen of the Park Board early this morning at the Plaza Hotel gave out the statement which follows:

The crop of assaults, robberies, disorder, and even murders in the rural districts of the State has been rather larger than usual this season. Whether the criminal or semi-criminal classes are subject to abnormal irritation from the heat, or whether, in obedience to the speculative impulse prevailing, they are overdoing their business, we cannot say.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25-cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

TRENTON, N.J., July 9. -- De Witt C. Blair, son and executor of John I. Blair of Blairstown, N.J., who died in 1899, filed in the Court of Chancery a bill to have the will reconstrued. The matter was before the Chancellor to-day on a motion for the appointment of a guardian for the infant heirs pending the decision.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 9. -- Mrs. Virginia Heinisch, the half sister of Jacob S. Rogers, in an interview to-day said that she had already seen her lawyer, a prominent member of the Newark bar, in reference to bringing suit to break the millionaire's will. She said she thought the other relatives would take similar action.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 9. -- Vernon H. Whitehead and Mrs. Georgianna Van Doren of South River, N.J., were arraigned in court here to-day for sentence for improper conduct. Previous to sentence Lawyer George Silzer, counsel for the prisoners, asked that clemency be shown them because Mrs. Van Doren had not lived happily with her husband.

NEWARK, N.J., July 9. -- Friends of Thomas G. Barker, who yesterday began serving his five-year term in State Prison for shooting the Rev. John Keller, have announced their determination of forcing, if possible, the clergyman to take some action to clear himself of the charges made against him by the prisoner's wife.

CINCINNATI, July 9. -- Case, the local amateur, turned in a winner to-day, at the expense of Phyle and the New Yorks. The youngster had some mysterious curves up his sleeve that were too much for the visitors. However, bad fielding early put the New Yorks in the lead, and the Cincinnati's did not rally till the last innings.

BUFFALO, July 9. -- The National Amateur Athletic Union swimming championships on the Park Lake at the Pan-American Exposition grounds ended to-day. It has been one of the most successful in the history of the Amateur Athletic Union. Many records were broken to-day. They began to go in the mile event when the men had passed the half-mile mark, with Otto Wahle of the New York Athletic Club in the lead.
DOUGLASS, Ga., July 9. -- Jake Devoss, a negro laborer on James McKinnon's plantation, was working a team of mules this morning. The mules balked and Devoss flew into a rage.
NEWPORT, July 9. -- James Brown Potter has gone, to Mexico, where he intends to spend the Summer.

ALBANY, July 9. -- The largest corporations of Rochester and Buffalo have agreed to pay their franchise taxes for the last two years. This is the first instance since the enactment of the Franchise Tax act that any corporations have shown a disposition to pay taxes thereunder, and the State authorities look upon this step as a most important one in the administration of the law.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 10 -- A futile attempt to sail the third race of the Newport Yacht Racing Association's series was made to-day. The wind was light and unsteady, and before the yachts had gone far they were enveloped in a fog. Columbia and Independence rounded the outer mark, fifteen miles to windward from the Brenton Reef Lightship, but Constitution abandoned the struggle early, and went home rather than risk racing in a fog.
The Associated Veterans of Farragut's Fleet have received the following letter from Rear Admiral Schley acknowledging the receipt of the Farragut Medal conferred upon him:
R.B. McCotter has sold for Ella Jenkins to W.P. Snyder the six-story apartment house, known as the Elenore, on One Hundred and Tenth Street, 200 feet east of Seventh Avenue, 75 by 100.

CHICAGO, July 10. -- The Chicago-Missouri River rate war will probably be brought to a sudden close to-morrow, so far as all the roads interested are concerned, with the possible exception of the Chicago Great Western. President A.B. Stlckney of the latter line says that he is determined to maintain the independence of his road in freight rates under the present circumstances, and that there is no possibility of it being forced into any combination.
John Wocher has been appointed Indianapolis agent of the Traders' Insurance Company of Chicago.

A number of opinions in which the Metropolitan Street Railway is involved were handed down yesterday by the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court. In the great majority of the cases the decisions were against the company, including several in which large amounts for damages had been awarded.
BOSTON, July 10 -- Money loaned at the Clearing House to-day at 3 per cent, and New York funds sold at par and 5 cents premium. Exchanges, $25,998,148; balances, $1,711,007.

If the officers of the New York Central and Hudson River Railroad Company can be takan at their word, they are wholly incapable of intelligently administering the affairs of a great public corporation. They have declared that "it is simply impossible for the company to do anything to abate the nuisance of the Park Avenue tunnel as. it now exists."

There was a Gruber outing yesterday without some of the features that have commonly in the past added to the gayety of these fetes. The regular Republican organization of the Twenty-first Assembly District sent its women and children, to the number of 6,500, off on the steamboats Columbia and Sirius.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 10 -- The town of Lincoln, in the northern part of Middlesex County, once the pride and the hope of the woman's suffrage agitators, was sold to-day under the auctioneer's hammer for $16,000. The town was founded five years ago by Silas Drake, a land owner, who organized the New Jersey Realty Company, which purchased a big farm and cut it up into building and factory sites.

ALBANY, July 10. -- The State Board of Charities, at a meeting held in this city to-day, adopted a resolution calling upon the City of New York to erect a new and modern hospital to take the place of Bellevue Hospital, and also that the salaries of the staff be so increased as to secure competent and satisfactory employes.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- Revision of the tariff law by next Winter's Congress is a subject which is already being pressed upon the attention of President McKinley. The discussion which is going on has moved certain influential Senators and members of Congress to interview the President and learn what course he favors.

Miles McDonnell's trial,for killing George Price in a shooting affray in a Harlem saloon in December last, which has been progressing, with many delays, before Justice Edgar L. Fursman, in the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court, since June 21 last, was yesterday adjourned again under peculiarly mysterious circumstances.

GREENVILLE, Tenn., July 10 -- Mrs. Martha Patterson, the last of the children of President Andrew Johnson, and who was mistress of the White House during the Johnson Administration, died to-day at her home here. Mrs. Patterson was born Oct. 25, 1838. Her death leaves only five survivors of the Johnson family.

The convention to revise the Constitution of Alabama, which has been sitting in Montgomery, has given the Nation an agreeable surprise by adopting an article relative to the duties of the Executive which, among other things, provides that when a Sheriff allows a prisoner to be taken from his custody and lynched, the Governor shall immediately institute impeaphment proceedings against such officer and suspend him from duty pending the trial of the charges.

COLUMBUS, July 10. -- The Ohio Democratic State Convention to-day named Col. Kilourne for Governor, placed the three Johnson planks on franchises, steam and electric railroads, and corporation taxation in the platform, rejected Frank S. Monnett as a candidate for Attorney General, and by a vote of 944 to 6 refused to reaffirm the Kansas City platform and express its confidence in Mr. Bryan.
LONDON, July 10 -- Money was plentiful to-day, but a temporary stringency is possible after to-morrow's payment of the loan installment.

While some 10,000 people were celebrating President Clauaen's decision to remove the Spate pay chairs from the parks last night, Mr. Spate and his counsel were taking measures to prevent Mr. Clausen from carrying out his intention. In order to do this in injunction was obtained from Justice McAdam of the Supreme Court, and this injunction will be served on President Clausen and the other members of the board early this morning.

There are times in Wall Street when apparently reason is abrogated and hysteria reigns. Such a period has lately been witnessed. Yesterday's market emphasized it. Upon rumor of corn damage, for example, St. Paul is sold down over 10 points, despite the fact that St. Paul's most important tonnage is Spring wheat, for which the prospects are flattering.

NEWBURG, N.Y., July 10 -- The wedding of Dr. Frank Richard Oastler of New York and Miss Maude Matthews, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Matthews, took place here to-day at Graystone, the residence of the bride's parents. The ceremony was private, only the particular friends of the bride and bridegroom being present.

Creditors of Reuben, Rosenberger Co., manufacturers of women's underwear at No's. 101 and 103 Wooster Street, and of Solomon Reuben, doing business as S. Reuben Co., in the same line of business at 7 and 9 West Eighteenth Street, were very active yesterday trying to protect their interests. Deputy Sheriff Burnes received six writs of replevin against Reuben, Rosenberger Co. aggregating $4,878, and seven against S. Reuben Co., aggregating $3,684.

CREEDMOOR, L.I., July 10 -- The range here was occupied to-day by the Fourteenth Regiment of Brooklyn, the date having been assigned to them on account of the storm of May 9, the day set originally for their rifle practice. There were about 430 officers and men present under the command of Col. A.L. Kline.
WASHINGTON, July 10. -- The State Department has received the amount of the American indemnity claim against Turkey -- $95,000 -- through the American Legation at Constantinople.

ELIZABETH, N.J., July 10 -- The estate or the late Charles Hyde of Plainfield is to be kept intact by the family, and for this purpose the Union County Investment Company filed articles of incorporation here today with the Clerk of Union County. The company is capitalized for $300,000. The shares are $100 each.

LONDON, July 11 -- The Manchester Daily Dispatch says that the Duchess of Albany will accompany King Edward on his approaching visit to Scotland, and that the betrothal of her Royal Highness to Lord Rosebery will be announced at the time of their visit or immediately after the return of the royal party.

CHICAGO, July 10 -- Followers of John Alexander Dowie made an attempt to convert the citizens of Evanston to-night and failed, as on former occasions. They visited the place in greater force than ever before, there being fully 200 of them, but their increased numbers only brought them a greater defeat.

GIBRALTAR, July 10 -- The British cruiser Minerva, which, with the British cruiser Hyacinth, a sister ship, sailed from Devonport on July 6 for the purpose of putting the respective merits of the Belleville and Scotch boilers to a final, decisive test, arrived here this afternoon.

Democrats in the Thirty-fifth Assembly District not in hearty accord with the present organization have formed an association with the following officers: President -- M.F. O'Brien; First Vice President -- Dr. James L. Gillesple; Second Vice President -- John Zellweger; Treasurer -- Thomas Farley; Recording Secretary -- Henry Goggin, Jr.; Secretary -- H.H. Riley.

LONDON, July 10 -- While the physicians at King's College Hospital stated early this morning that A.H. Hummel, the New York lawyer, who was injured in a carriage accident while driving down North-umberland Avenue last evening, was in a very bad state, it was announced in the afternoon that Mr. Hummel was regarded as being out of danger.
While more than a thousand people locked on Policeman Franklip H. Powers of the Harbor Police heroically rescued a young woman from drowning off Pier 1 last night.

NEWARK, N.J., July 10 -- The Rev. John Keller must undergo a third operation, so there is little likelihood, according to his friends, that he will be able to take any steps toward obtaining vindication until the Fall.

Rockaway's second polo team failed of its expectations yesterday, and allowed the first team of the Rockaway Hunt Club to defeat it in the final match for the Blizzard Cup. The game was played on the club's field at Cedarhurst. L.I., and was viewed by a large crowd of members, and cottage residents.

BALTIMORE, July 10 -- The market today was demoralized by conditions in New York. The market was rather narrow all day long, there being comparatively no speculative trading in evidence. The Seaboard group suffered the severest set-back in prices, those issues being the ones most directly Influenced by the New York Situation.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The letter of your correspondent FRITZ W. HOENINGHAUS, on the work done by the trial Judges during their vacations is true with regard to Special Term or equity cases, in which the Justice "reserves decision." But it has no application to your editorial, nor to the trial term parts with juries.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., July 10 -- Squadron A won the second match to-day on the Rumson Club's polo field near Seabright, and became possessors of the cup given by Theodore L. Myers for the best two out of three competitions. The squadron quartet beat the home team by 4 goals to 2 1/4. The game was played without handicap, but Rumson lost three-fourths of its 3 earned goals for safety penalties.

PROVIDENCE, July 10 -- The question whether a person can maintain a legal action for damages for injuries before he was born has been decided in the negative by Judge Rogers of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court here, in the suit of Patrick German against Robert E. Budlong.

Walter W. Smith of the Kings County Wheelmen, the sixteen-year-old, lad who holds the world's amateur record for one mile at 1:28, showed that he is still riding in championship form by distancing a field of six of the fastest local amateurs in the ten-mile motor-paced race at the Manhattan Beach cycle track last night.

TOPEKA, Kan., July 10 -- There has not been a general rain in Kansas for three months, and the local rains have been so light that there has virtually been a drought in the State during all that period. Fortunately there was an abundance of rain or snow before that which saved the wheat, and the farmers have about completed one of the largest harvests in the history of the State.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- Preliminary returns to the statistician of the Department of Agriculture on the acreage of corn planted indicate a reduction of about 400,000 acres, or .5 per cent., from the area planted last year. Of the 22 States having 1,000,000 acres or upward in corn in 1000, 12 show a decrease of about 1,300,000 acres, while in the remaining 10 an increase of about 900,000 acres is shown.

The Kansas corn crop is destroyed, of course -- all burned up by hot winds and blazing suns; and it is now known that there will be no rain in the corn belt until Christmas. It is shameless and mendacious to pretend that the steel strike can be settled or that the Atchison cut rate Circular will be withdrawn.

ALLENTOWN, Penn., July 10 -- At a meeting of the Lehigh Valley Traction Company, held here to-day, Robert E. Wright of Allentown was chosen President, to succeed the late Albert L. Johnson. Loflin E. Johnson, son of Tom L. Johnson, was elected Vice President.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 10 -- Six persons were killed outright, ten received injuries from which they have since died, and about twenty-five others were more or less-seriously hurt as the result of a head-end collision between passenger and fast live stock trains on the Chicago and Alton Railroad near Norton, Mo., at 7 o'clock this morning.

CINCINATI, July 10 -- Taylor and Hahn both pitched excellently to-day, but the honors of winning fell to the New Yorker. Taylor was at his best, as four widely scattered hits testify. Cincinnati got no furthre on the road to the home plate than second base, and but one man reached there.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A very temperate letter signed "L.E. M." appeared in to-day TIMES relative to the National Guard-labor question, defending the position taken by the Sheet Metal Workers' Association, mainly on the ground that corporations are constant law breakers.
CHICAGO, July 10. -- John A. Hinsey was ordered to-night by the Supreme Lodge of the Knights of Pythias to appear before that body and show cause why he should not be expelled.

Unable to obtain a promise from her husband to return and live with her again, a woman who described herself as Dora Bernstein, thirty-two years old, and living at 285 West Tenth Street, attempted to end her life last evening by throwing herself in front of a rapidly approaching Broadway electric car at Tenth Street.

NEWPORT, July 10 -- Mrs. W. Storrs Wells gave a large luncheon at her cottage to-day. Mrs. A. Cass Canfield also entertained at luncheon, her guests including Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt, Jr., Miss Martha Johnson, Miss Anna Sands, and Miss Burden.

-- Attention is called by one of the English trade papers to a new and peculiar trouble among the cotton operatives in Lancashire, a result of the shorter working day which the labor unions of the district have succeeded in establishing. A system of overdriving is said to be growing up, and according to the reports of the labor leaders it is fast becoming intolerable.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., July 10 -- Mrs. Irene Beach Vassar, widow of Matthew Vassar, Jr., died at her home in this city last night. Several weeks ago she was operated on for appendicitis by New York specialists, and although the operation seemed successful, she failed to recover from its effects and grew gradually worse until the end.

SPRINGFIELD, Penn., July 11 -- Nine men were killed as the result of the collapse of a Nickel Plate Railroad bridge, which was undergoing repairs here. The accident occurred while a local freight train, bound west, containing two cars of stone to be left at the bridge, went through it.

As a result of a final competition between six architects, plans for the National Home for Disabled Volunteer Soldiers, to be erected near Johnson City, Tenn., have been accepted from Joseph H. Freedlander, one of the younger members of the profession in this city. The announcement was made yesterday, and after consultation with Gen. John T. Richards of Maine, the Superintendent of Construction, Mr. Freedlander will proceed with the working drawings.

Rattlesnake Bill, a cowboy with the Brule Indians, showing at Glen Island, says he was assaulted on July 4, by one of a party that he had ordered from the camp for insulting the Indian women. The man, the cowboy says, struck him from behind with a pair of brass knuckles, rendering him unconscius.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A great many unhappy patrons of the New York Central "inferno," Park Avenue, will echo the sentiments of your correspondent who suggests that the "high officials" at Forty-second Street try the plan of making close connection between Hudson River trains and those of the Putnam Division, so that passengers who wish to take the elevated express at One Hundred and Fifty-fifth Street can conveniently do so.

CHICAGO, July 11 -- The case of Dr. Emma N. Warne, who brought suit against the estate of Francis T. Wheeler, ex-President of the Union Bag and Paper Company, to recover $100,000, was heard in Probate Court to-day.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Perhaps no more important service has been rendered by the unions than the present agitation against the militia. No action of theirs could so imperatively show the necessity of uniting all the forces that make for order. Perhaps at last society at large will recognize its own lack of courage and firmness in dealing with the vagaries of unions.

Everything points to the conclusion that the differences between the Amalgamated Association and the managers of the mills in which the strike was begun about a fortnight ago will be adjusted to the satisfaction of both interests. The most satisfactory feature of the situation is that the executive officers of the union have learned that there is such a thing as talking too much, and are discreetly silent as to their plans and purposes.

We have been commenting, perhaps more freely than some of our readers thought becoming and proper, upon the ways of the trial Judges of the Supreme Court in this department. It is true that, so long as the pretense that a court makes of administering "justice according to law" is decently plausible, it is a kind of public offense to diminish the public respect for such a tribunal.

NEWPORT, R.I., July, 11 -- Columbia gave both Constitution and Independence a substantial beating to-day in a fair sailing breeze and a long sea, while the Boston yacht showed her gait and made a fine race with Constitution. The new Herreshoff yacht defeated the Crowninshield production by only 2 minutes 15 seconds in a fifteen-mile thrash to windawrd and return.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25cent Stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.
How strongly does Mr. McKINLEY really desire to get through the Senate some tangible concessions of reciprocity?

VANCOUVER, B.C., July 11 -- The developments in the Fraser River strike situation during the last twenty-four hours have been startling. The union fishermen have now the upper hand. As a result of a battle of small boats out of the gulf, a battle in which many shots were exchanged, but in which no combatant was killed, sixteen Japanese were taken prisoners by the strikers.

MORRISTOWN, N. J., July 11 -- Freeholder William R. Cook, who was formerly a member of the Street and Water Board of Jersey City, has been made the victim of an Official Joke. He is now a resident of Morristown, and represents one of, the wards in the Morris County Board of Freeholders.

NEWPORT, July 11 -- Capt. and Mrs. Chadwick gave a dinner this evening at the War College in honor of Bishop Satterlee of Washington, who is their guest. Those present included Mr. and Mrs. Robert Ludlow Fowler, Mr. and Mrs. Seth Barton French, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Sedgwick, Mrs. Francis J. Higginson, Capt. Caspar F. Goodrich, and Mrs. John Bleeker Miller.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- The Census Office issued a bulletin to-day concerning the urban population of the country. It shows that 28,411,698 people in the United. States live in cities and towns of over 4,000 population. This is 37.3 per cent. of the entire population, a gain of almost 5 per cent. since the census of 1890, when the percentage was 32.9.

PHILADELPHIA, July 11 -- Democratic State Chairman Creasy, who arrived here last night, put in a busy day at the Stratford Hotel talking with leaders of the local Democrats and Independent Republicans. The State Chairman came to find out what are the prospects for a fusion against the Quay machine, not only in this city, but throughout the State.
WASHINGTON, July 11 -- The Navy Department has taken no action in the matter of Commodore Schroeder's criticism of United States marines at Guam.

NEWARK, N.J., July 11 -- One of the detectives employed by the counsel for Unity Lodge of Good Templars in the war on Sunday liquor selling pursued somewhat peculiar methods in securing evidence for use in the crusade, and he took care to arrange for unwitting corroboration.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- The Naval Bureau of Construction made public to-day its monthly progress report showing the degree of completion of the vessels building at shipyards throughout the country. Generally speaking, the report shows a marked let down in the work oh navel vessels as a result of the shipyard strikes.

ALBANY, Mo., July 11 -- An accident in which three children, a pet frog, and some dynamite figure here to-day resulted in one death, the injury of two persons, and the partial wrecking of a dwelling. The three children of George McCurry, a contractor, found some dynamite in the cellar of their home, and, thinking it was putty, fed it to their pet frog.

PATERSON, N.J., July 11 -- Paterson is to have a new bank. The stock has been oversubscribed. There has been $150,000 issued, and there will be a surplus of an equal amount. The shares thus far fetch $200. The institution will be a trust company, and as such has applied to the State for a charter.

ST. LOUIS, July 11 -- Secretary Charles A. Walsh of the Democratic National Committee says there will not be any turning down of men or principles by the reconstructed Democratic Party, but there is liable to be a lot of forgetting. Mr. Walsh has returned to St. Louis to-day from a trip to Iowa.
LONDON, July 12 -- Official corroboration of the charges that the Boers murdered the British wounded at Vlakfontein is forthcoming.

Society was dull in town yesterday. There was absolutely nothing doing. There were a few departures on the ships, including those of Mrs. Starr Miller and Miss Miller, which had not previously been mentioned. To-day, being Friday, will, as usual, be very dull. There is nothing whatever on in town.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., July 11 -- The Democrats of the First Assembly District of Jefferson County to-day nominated L.W. Day of Sacket's Harbor for member of Assembly. The delegates to the Congressional Convention were instructed for Col. W.H. Powell, retired, formerly commanding officer of the Ninth United States Infantry.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., July 11 -- The invitation lawn tennis tournament was continued here again to-day, and the championship singles narrowed down to the final stage. The feature of the day was the semi-final match between Davidson of Washington and Paret of New York. Paret captured the first set by clever volleying, but Davidson's fast ground strokes passed him at the net too often after that, and the Washingtonian pulled out an exciting match.

Maggie Ehrlich, twenty years old, and Martha Leismann, eighteen years of age, both of whom live on Grant Avenue, Grandview, Hudson County, were seriously injured yesterday by dropping from a boat swing. Two other women, whose names were not given, also fell, but escaped with a shaking up.

Continuing liquidation, largely forced by exhausted margins, was the feature of the stock market yesterday, with prices quite generally declining. Over night the news from the corn belt had not been encouraging to the bulls on the market, the reports telling of continued drought and of consequent further damage to the growing crop.

DES MOINES, Iowa, July 11 -- For the third day in succession the maximum temperature here to-day was 101, breaking the record for continued extreme heat since the establishment or the weather office here in 1872. The hot wind has moderated this evening. The loss to crops will be very great.
BOSTON, July 11 -- Money loaned at the Clearing House to-day at 3 per cent, and New York funds sold at par. Exchanges, $26,766,101; balances, $2,011,108.

Isaac G. Reed, who years ago was prominent in this city as a magazine writer, author, and newpaper man, is in the insane pavilion of Believue Hospital. Aside from his mind being impaired, his physical condition is such that he probably will die.
PATERSON, N.J., July 11 -- Nicholas Lalli, an Italian bootblack, tried to kiss eighteen-year-old Mary L. Filli, to whom he had been making love. She sued him for $500 damages in the District Court.

PHILADELPHIA, July 11 -- William Butler, prominent in the East as a grocer, and a pioneer in the cash grocery business in this city, died to-day as the result of an operation for appendicitis. Mr. Butler was born in Ireland forty-three years ago, and came to this country when a young man and located at Springfield, Mass.

SARATOGA, N.Y., July 11 -- Emanuel Hayman, better known as "Harry Mann," a theatrical man who since last April has been a sufferer from Bright's disease, and who came to Saratoga two weeks ago, died here this afternoon after being unconscious more than thirty hours.
The John M. Thompson Company has sold for the estate of Nicholas Low the six old dwellings 2 to 12 Hancock Street, on plot 88 by 112 and irregular. The purchasers are Mandelbaum Lewine.

ISLIP, L.I., July 11 -- Mrs. Edwin B. Meeks of this place was seriously hurt this afternoon. An iron hook on the end of a hay-rae pole was driven into her back and a great jagged wound eight inches long was inflicted.

Persons with grievances against policemen obtained little redress at the trials conducted by Deputy Commissioner Devery yesterday afternoon. There was an unusually long calendar, as the last regular trial day fell on the Fourth of July, and Devery, with so much work on hand, was more abrupt than is his wont, and hurried the cases through in brief order.
The most noteworthy thing in the proceedings of the Ohio Democratic Convention was the trampling on the portrait, the platform, and the pretensions of Mr. BRYAN.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- Reports made public by Lieut. Gen. Miles contain copies of some telegrams which indicate that there was friction between Gen. Otis and Gen. MacArthur when the former commanded the army in the Philippines, and that Gen. Otis was on one occasion called upon to rebuke his subordinate for offering advice on a question of National policy.

A new and formidable candidate for the United States District Judgeship made vacant by the resignation of Addison Brown has come to the front, to the consternation of what are known as the members of the regular organization.

The memorial to Francis Parkman for the park system of Brookline, Mass., which now includes the former site of his house, is to be a gateway or door, formed of the monoliths that will span one of the paths where his home used to stand. The two uprights, with superincumbent' stone, are roughly hammered from the rock.

Miles McDonnell, on trial for his life, charged with killing George Price in the Onawa Cafe last December, told the story of the affray to Justice Fursman and the jury in the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court yesterday. Not the least remarkable portion of his narrative was the frank admission that he did shoot Price to save his own life.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- An increased internal revenue, following the wholesale reduction of the war taxes, is the anomaly presented by the Treasury receipts for the first ten days of the new fiscal year. The total receipts at the close of business on July 10 amounted to $10,084,495.01; the receipts for the same period a year ago amounted to $8,681,381.16, an increase for the new year of $1,403,113.85.

KINGSTON, N.Y., July 11 -- Gabriel Crandall, a violinist of Deep Hollow, recently gave a solo under extraordinary and somewhat trying circumstances. He was crossing the mountains on his way to Halstead, when he discovered a big rattlesnake directly in his path. The road at this point is very narrow and winds around a sharp spur of the mountain.

ASBURY PARK, N. J., July 11 -- Edward P. Walkup, against whom a complaint was lodged with the police last night by Harry White, a boy in his employ, was fined $3 for assault this morning by Justice Borden.

As a result of the meeting at the headquarters of the Citizens' Union last night of conferrees appointed by non-nominating anti-Tammany bodies, the conferences to be held to select municipal tickets will occur at a much earlier date than that originally set, Sept. 18.
BLAIR-GOWRIE, Scotland, July 11 -- Harry Vardon to-day beat James Braid, (who won the open golf championship of Great Britain, June 6,) by 2 up and 1 to play, in a thirty-six-hole match.

While a south-bound City Hall train on the Third Avenue Elevated Railroad, crowded to the platforms, was standing at the Fifty-ninth Street station at 7:20 o'clock yesterday morning, a South Ferry train crashed into the rear car. The shock was not sufficient to throw the car from the rails, but the front of the engine was badly damaged, and a few seconds later one of the cylinder heads blew off with a loud report.
Everybody in authority seems to be favorable to the project for restoring and maintaining "Fraunces's Tavern." Mr. HOLAHAN has made friends by his cordial support of the project.

LOUISVILLE, July 11 -- Henry Watterson in The Courier-Journal to-morrow in an editorial apparently answering a remark of the St. Louis Globe-Democrat will really pay his respects to Mr. Bryan and applaud the action of the Ohio Democratic Convention. Mr. Watterson will say in part:

Seventy graduates received their diplomas from the Baron de Hirsch Trade School, at 222 East Sixty-fourth Street, last night, and in the course of the evening's exercises A.S. Solomons, general agent of the Baron de Hirsch Fund, announced that many members of the class had been promised already remunerative positions.

To the Editor of The New York Times: If those who demand more cars on Broadway would look into the Metropolitan's system they would find that the congestion complained of was not the lack of cars, but rather the abominable system of diverting traffic from all over the city on to this line.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 11 -- Contrary to general expectations, the steel workers' strike was not settled to-day. The officials of the Amalgamated Association of Iron, Steel and Tin Workers met the representatives of the employing corporations and after two sessions adjourned late this afternoon without coming to a conclusion.
LONDON, July 11 -- Charles T. Yerkes presided to-Right at the anniversary festival of the Salters' Company. Mr. Yerkes is the first American to occupy the chair upon such an occasion.

WORCESTER, Mass., July 11 -- Rain interrupted the races at the Barber's Crossing track this afternoon, but not till two races had been completed, two heats run off in the third, and one heat finished in the fourth event on the card.
Commissioner of Charities John W. Keller announced yesterday that he would ask the Board of Estimate and Apportionment to set aside at least $2,000,00 to build a new Bellevue Hospital.

It gives us pleasure to note that the views expressed in these columns when the generous gift of Mr. CARNEGIE for the endowment of a technical school in Pittsburg was announced as to the direction in which the money could be most profitably expended anticipated the conclusions reached by the managers of the fund.
HAVANA, July 11 -- Gov. Wood passed a good night and is feeling well this morning. He has hardly any fever. His case is not critical, and his physicians are confident of his recovery.

The decision of the members of the Associated Manufacturers' Mutual Fire Insurance Company to discontinue active underwriting operations and go into voluntary liquidation is said to be due to the indisposition of some of the members to approve the plan to reorganize the company as a joint stock corporation and their insistence upon the division of assets as an alternative course.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I think that your paper has taken a timely stand in treating the important subject of trades unions and the militia.

PHILADELPHIA, July 11 -- The stock market is dull and firm, appearing to take no notice whatever of outside dealings. To-day the Wall Street stocks were weak, but much of the depression disappeared later in the day. The steel stocks, led by Cambria, all sought a lower level, but the specialties were stationary all day.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., July 11 -- Excellent golf characterized the two rounds finished to-day on the links of the New Haven Country Club for the championship of the State of Connecticut. The survivors of the day's conflict for the championship were Charles H. Seeley, the young player form the Wee Burn Club, and T.L. Cheney of the Cheney family of golfers, from Orford, South Manchester.

DETROIT, July 11 -- Despite strong efforts on the part of those opposed to a National university, the National Educational Association to-day adopted a resolution reaffirming its former declaration in favor of such an institution. The resolution, which was offered by President R.H. Jesse of the University of Missouri, reads:
LONDON, July 11 -- Money was in improved demand to-day and somewhat disturbed by the payment or the Consol installment, causing the transfer of nearly five millions. Discounts were easier.

The baseball and Gaelic football teams of the Sixty-ninth Regiment will be busy on Sunday afternoon at Celtic Park, Long Island City. At 3 o'clock the Maroons of King's Bridge will be their opponents at baseball, and two hours later the Young Irelands of New York will tackle the regimental kickers.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 12 -- The series of races of the Newport Yacht Racing Association for the three ninety-footers came to an end to-day with a fine contest over a triangular course. Columbia was again victorious over her sister ship, as Constitution may well be called, and also over the Boston boat.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 12 -- Only the enthusiasts sat out the whole of this afternoon's session of the horse show. The unpropitious weather was entirely to blame. When the last class was Judged, about 6:30, there were not more than fifty people on the grounds. Despite the lack of sunshine the stands at times waxed enthusiastic, and Frank Gould came in for a personal ovation.
BOSTON, July 12 -- Money loaned at the Clearing House to-day at 3 per cent. and New York funds sold at par. Exchanges, $25,483,707; balances, $2,318,759.
BAR HARBOR, Me., July 12 -- To-day has been a busy one for society here, among the many entertainments given being several large dinner parties by prominent New Yorkers.

Lafayette Conover, one of the most widely known residents of Monmouth County, died yesterday at his home, in Marlborough township, New Jersey. He was seventy-nine years of age. Besides a widow, he leaves a son, Charles E. Conover, of Marlborough, and a daughter, the wife of Charles H. Millspaugh of Brooklyn.

ALBANY, July 12 -- Reports of trust companies organized under the laws of New York and doing business in this State, for the first six months of the year, are being examined in the office of the State Superintendent of Banking. The statements of thirteen of these institutions, whose home offices are in New York City, were passed upon to-day as correct.

Prof. Hudson's volume will be found to present a particularly good sketch of the life, character and literary aspects of Sir Walter Scott, written from the standpoint of one who knows his subject particularly well, has long been under the spell of Scott's genius, and yet, withal, can see the faults as well as the virtues of both the man and the writer whose career he is depicting.

PARIS, July 12 -- M. Santos-Dumont's cigar-shaped balloon, driven by a motor, had a trial to-day from St. Cloud, across Paris, around the Eiffel Tower, and back to St. Cloud. The papers say that the trip was quite successful and that the balloon ascended and descended apparently at the will of the aeronaut.

The regulars of the "rain or shine" variety made up all the attendance at the Brighton Beach race track yesterday, the clouds and damp keeping away the occasional visitors and the fair weather portion of turf patrons, but for those present the overcast sky and the drip of rain that fell steadily throughout the afternoon were as things that had no existence.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 12 -- A crowd of 2,500 excited men and boys surrounded the County Jail here to-night, clamoring for vengeance against three negroes, who assaulted Miss Grace Davis Wednesday night in a populous and respectable neighborhood. Eight suspects, two of whom have been identified, are held at the jail, and it is thought that Marshal Maxwell will be able to protect the prisoners.
SUBJECT -- Noah saved in the ark. -- Genesis, vili., 1-22.

For the third successive day prices on the Block market yesterday broke sharply under the pressure of heavy liquidating sales, chiefly due to exhausted margins. The decline, as was that of Wednesday and Thursday, was general, no one class of Blocks escaping. Standard railway shares, industrials, street railway stocks -- all went down, the breaks in representative shares extending generally from three to twelve points.

We have not the pleasure of knowing "Holland," the New York correspondent of The Philadelphia Press. But, from a recent letter of his, we should infer that he has what the lively Gaul would describe as "an acquaintance with things," and that he is not entirely whirled off his feet by a literary success.

We trust that no one of our regular readers missed reading the report we printed yesterday of the trial of McDONNELL for murder. For the satisfaction of all curious readers, as well as for the interests of justice, it is well that Justice FURSMAN had recovered from his indisposition and was able to try the case.

NEWPORT, July 12 -- At Crossways this evening Mrs. Stuyvesant Fish gave the largest function in Newport so far this season. It was a dinner, at which forty-four guests were present. All the guests were seated at one square table, which was decorated in a novel and beautiful manner.

Transactions in the outside market yesterday were a little smaller than they were on Thursday, but the course of the market continued downward. In some cases the selling movement was checked, but in the majority of instances prices closed with net losses which in some stocks were quite substantial.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., July 12 -- Through eleven long innings of to-day's baseball game between New York and St. Louis 5,000 people watched the masterly struggle between Pitchers Mathewson and Powell. At the end of the game, when the score stood 3 to 2 in favor of St. Louis, honors were about even with the pitchers.

At a meeting of the Board of Estimate yesterday the proposed five-year contract of the New York Sanitary Utilization Company for the removal and disposal of garbage in Manhattan was rejected. The company wanted $232,000 a year, and Controller Coler made a report showing that this sum was much more than was now being paid by the city for the same work.

CHICAGO, July 12 -- The Chicago-Missouri River freight rate war is ended, and full tariff rates will be restored on Monday on all lines entering the Missouri River district. The withdrawal of the proposed cut in rates scheduled by the Atchison road opened the way to this.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Cardinal Gibbons has received a letter from Pope Leo XIII., of which the following is a translation:

Mr. Thorpe in his preface, claims for this volume that it is "a simple, compact, and comprehensive history of four centuries of American history without entering upon a discussion of controversial topics." The first chapter treats of the Indians, whom he considers one of the oldest races on the earth.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Having read with great interest your recent editorials upon the remissness of the Judges of the Supreme Court in Manhattan, and being especially pleased with the one published to-day, I beg leave to call to your attention the remedy for much of the disregard which the Justices have for the rights of the unermined citizen.

PORTLAND, Me., July 12 -- The condition of Mrs. Jefferson Davis, widow of the President of the Confederacy, was reported to-day as greatly improved over that of yesterday. Her illness is not considered at all serious.
To The New York Times Saturday Review: In an address on "Science and Art is Education," Huxley said:

After the recent sale of the Barrols collection of manuscripts, secured in 1819 by the late Earl of Ashburnham. Mr. Hodge, the auctioneer at Sotheby's, humorously announced that " Mr. Archer," who gave u1,800 for the beautiful fourteenth century manuscript of "San Graal et Lancelot du Lac," was "just beginning to form a library."

LAWRENCE, L. I., July 12 -- William Hensler of this place has been missing from home since July 5, and his wife has been unable to obtain any trace of him. Miss May Shaw, sister of Mrs. Hensler, is also missing. She disappeared the same day Hensler did.

THE members of the American Library Association, who assembled in Waukesha. Wis., July 3-10, heard last Monday an Interesting paper read by Mr. George Iles of this city on "The Trusteeship of Literature." Mr. Iles gave a general view of the development of the public library idea in this country, which took practical form in Boston in 1832, when that city "opened the doors of the first tree public library established in an American city."

WASHINGTON, D.C., July 12 -- The Secretary of War has decided not to sell the transport Rawlings at present, unless the price fixed by the Board of Officers, $250,000, is offered for her. When she was pur up for sale no bids were made. The McPherson will be offered for sale soon.

John Oxenham, author of the recent novel, "Our Lady of Deliverance," which was suggested to him by the Dreyfus case, was born in Manchester, England. He is however, well acquainted with the United States, though he has not as yet used this country for "copy."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., July 12 -- Charles H. Seeley, the young golfer from the Wee Burn Club, Noroton, Conn., won the amateur championship of the State of Connecticut to-day in the final round played on the links of the New Haven Country Club. He defeated, in a thirty-six-hole match, characterized by grand golf, T.L. Cheney of the Orford Golf Club by 8 up and 7 to play.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Trouble is brewing for somebody over the manufacture of boxes for the rural free-delivery service. A Congressional investigation is promised for the purpose of discovering if there is not a "fourteen boxmakers' trust," protected by certain officials of the Post Office Department.

Sentence day in Recorder Goff's Court of General Sessions yesterday brought out several pleas for clemency from self-confessed and convicted lawbreakers, and spread upon the court records some earnestly told tales of former good repute and in one case of deeds of bravery in behalf of the Nation and the community.

Two burglars, heavily armed and equipped with the most modern and effective tools for housebreaking, were captured alter a long struggle by Roundsman Pierce and Patrolman Hunt of the King's Bridge Station at Van Cortlandt Park, in the height of the storm, soon after 3 o'clock yesterday morning.
