President Clausen of the Park Board filed his answer yesterday to the action brought against him by Abraham B. Cohen for false arrest growing out of the Spate chair riots. Cohen is a boy and sues through John R. Caldwell, who was appointed his guardian. Louis Lues, a policeman, who arrested Cohen, is also made a defendant.

MR. George Haven Putnam, to whom we are indebted for material used in the report given below, has returned from the Publishers' Congress in Leipsic stimulated with the joy of the occasion and satisfied with the scope and importance of the business performed.

The expedient of a Michigan citizen who asked for and obtained an injunction restraining another citizen from taking any steps or performing any acts calculated to disturb the temporarily satisfactory focusing of his wife's affections upon himself has the interest of novelty, at least.

A serious disaster to the corn crop would be a calamity of grave consequence to the country, from whatever point of view regarded. It is an easy matter, however, under existing conditions, greatly to exaggerate the damage this crop has suffered from the intense heat and the prevalence of drying winds over portions of the corn belt.

Miles McDonnell was acquitted atter a few minutes' deliberation by the jury before Justice Fursman in the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court yesterday of the charge of murdering George Price in the Onawa Cafe in December last. The Jury took only two ballots. The first was 11 to 1 for acquittal.

PHILADELPHIA, July 12 -- The depression in Wall Street was reflected in the local market to-day for the first time, and pretty much the whole of the Philadelphia list suffered slightly. New York sold here freely Pennsylvania, the Readings and United States Steel. Their weakness resuited in a slow sagging movement.
LONDON, July 12 -- Money was in fair demand to-day, and discounts had a tendency to be easier.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: Your interesting sketch of Paul Revere and of the plate by which he is best known as an engraver -- "The Boston Massacre" -- might be made more interesting by this additional information. The original design of this plate was made by Henry Pelham.

PATERSON, N.J., July 12 -- Vice Chancellor Pitney to-day adjudged strikers, who have been on trial before him for contempt of court, guilty as charged, and imposed fines, and upon two he imposed detention in jail. The persons in contempt were men and women who went on strike from Frank Dugan'a silk mill last Spring.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Controller Dawes received the preliminary report from the receiver of the Seventh National Bank of New York City to-day. The receiver states that his estimate of the value of the assets is, of course, only approximate. He estimates the amount which finally will be recovered for the depositors from the assets, including stockholders' assessment, at about 80 cents on the dollar.

To the New York Times Saturday Review: Dr. William Pool, who died a few years ago, a distinguished physician of Elizabeth City. N.C., was for many years in the habit of spending some weeks of Summer at Nag's Head, a surf-bathing resort on the narrow strip of sand known as the Peninsula, separating the great inner sounds of North Carolina from the Atlantic.

Mr. Howells discourses in the July "Easy Chair" of the failure of New York "society," in the accepted sense that is, our people of great wealth who entertain one another -- and what he calls "the best company" -- the representatives of achievement in literature, art, and other higher callings -- to assimilate.
FESTUS" has been called the poem of the age's hope, as "Sartor Resartus" is the prose record of the age's experience.

ON MARCH 21, 1769. The Public Advertiser, a London journal, which stood in a direct line of descent from Defoe's Daily Post, Published a letter signed "Junius," and from that time to this the identity of Junius has been a subject of eager, often passionate, debate. Many have owed their confidence to that of Macaulay expressed in one of his most brilliant essays.

The will of Pierre Lorillard cannot, under the laws of the State of New Jersey, be offered for probate there until next Thursday. It may, however, be offered for probate in any State where the testator held property, so that, for instance, it could be offered for probate in New York City, in which case a copy of the Instrument would be sent to New Jersey.

ALBANY, N.Y., July 12 -- The Court of Appeals did not decide the constitutionality of the eight-hour working-day law in denying the appeal of Eugene Lentilhon, a contractor, against Controller Coler. The court simply decided that the Controller might be sued in a common law action to compel him to pay the amount due to the plaintiff for contracts performed, and refused a writ of peremptory mandamus.

THE revival of Interest in long-forgotten heroes has turned the attention of historical students to Dr. Timothy Dwight's vacation "Travels in New England and New York." Dr. Dwight's case is a singular instance of the evanescence and uncertainty of literary aspiration or fame.

The movement of prices on the stock market yesterday continued distinctly downward, though at the close, for the first time in some days, there was manifestly a better feeling. So far as yesterday's developments were concerned, they followed logically enough after the happenings of previous days.

ADMIRERS of "Vesty of the Basins," not to mention those who for love of romance or curiosity in a literary lawsuit were attracted toward cape Cod Folks," will be glad to hear that Mrs. Sarah P. McL. Greene's new novel, upon which the author has been at work for the last three years, is near enough completion to assure its publication in early September by Harper Brothers.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Much fault is found with the system of the Metropolitan Railway, but it seems to me that the system of some of its critics is much more disorderly. Take, to illustrate, the alleged facts and the arguments of Mr. Patrick McGinnis. He says that the total number of power cars of the company is 1,336.

The arrival of Mrs. Astor and Mr. and Mrs. W. Bayard Cutting, Jr., and Mrs. Ladenburg will be the event of to-day. These New Yorkers have been abroad some time. Mrs. Astor has been away since February and Mrs. Ladenburg sailed early in the Winter. Mrs. W. Bayard Cutting was Lady Sibyl Cuffe, and this will be her first visit to this country.

Through a letter which was made public yesterday by Lawyer William O. McDowell, who was a close friend and business associate of Jacob S. Rogers, the fact was brought out that the idea of giving the greater part of his vast fortune to the Metropolitan Museum of Art was entertained by Mr. Rogers for some time before his death.

LONDON, July 12 -- Prof. Goldwin Smith of Toronto argues in to-day's Times in favor of a uniform copyright law for the whole British Empire and a common adherence to the Berne Convention. Through him and similar writers are the resolutions, quietly passed by the Publishers' Congress last month in Leipsic, likely to become widely known.

Robert H. Newell, who, under the name of Orpheus C. Kerr, had a National reputation as a humorist, was found dead yesterday at his home, 128 First Place, Brooklyn. He is believed to have died about ten days ago from the effects of the heat. Newell boarded with his sister-in-law, who occupied apartments on the top floor of the building, an apartment house.

LONDON, June 25 -- The Women Writers' Club had a meeting or a dinner or a high tea or something of the kind the other day, at which speeches were made and papers read. No doubt the women enjoyed themselves, and no doubt they thought that they were fully justifying their claim that in literature there is and should be no distinction of sex.

PITTSBURG, July 12 -- After two more sessions the conference between representatives of the American Sheet Steel, Steel Hoop and Tin Plate Companies and the Executive Board of the Amalgamated Association was adjourned at 4:30 P.M., to meet again to-morrow morning. President Shaffer of the Amalgamated Association said that nothing definite had been accomplished.

POUGHKEEPSIE, July 12 -- Prof. Nicolas Heredia of the University of Havana died on a New York Central train near here to-day. He left New York at 9:40 A. M. on his way to Saratoga. His wife, his nephew, and his brother-in-law, D.S. Zanetti of New York were with him.

Thirteen-year-old Otto May of 230 willow Avenue, Hoboken, who on Thursday night beat his eleven-year-old brother, George, fracturing his skull, was arraigned before Recorder Stanton yesterday. He showed no contrition, and said He had not beaten George for pushing him out of a wagon, as he confessed when arrested.

BUFFALO, July 12 -- As a result, it is said, of the failure of the City National Bank, the Schauroth Shoe Company has applied for the appointment of a receiver. The liabilities are not given, but President Schauroth says the company is perfectly solvent, and if the assets are not slaughtered, the creditors will be paid in full.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: I was greatly impressed with your very appreciative editorial article in THE SATURDAY REVIEW on the death of my friend the late Prof. John Fiske. Will you, therefore, kindly allow me, in your paper, to lay a small chaplet of immortelles upon his memory?

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25-cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 end is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

HACKENSACK, N. J., July 12 -- Miss Mary Carlock will tell her correct age the next time she is in court. She and Ethel Van Blarcom had been employed by the North Jersey Title Guarantee Company. They were discharged in the middle of the month and tendered $11. They demanded $22 each, a full month's wages.
Henry D. Winans May have sold for Mrs. H.P. Wertheim to William S. Wyckoff the four-story brownstone-front dwelling 33 West Fifty-seventh Street, 23 by 100.

Besant and America. It was with a curious appreciation of things American that the late Sir Walter Besant began his article on The Burden of the Twentieth Century," which is published in the current number of The North American Review.

PHILADELPHIA, July 12 -- "Doctor Nikola" passes, just as Sherlock Holmes, through some posthumous papers, and is again to enlighten public curiosity as to his methods of detecting crime. The Lippincotts announce that the last of Guy Boothby's famous and ingenious doctor is at hand, as they now have on their presses his creator's account of his demise.

CHICAGO, July 12 -- Under the influence of continued drought, prices for all grains again soared upward to-day, and September corn closed 2@2 1/8 cents higher than yesterday Wheat closed 2 5/8@2 3/4 cents higher, and oats were 7/8 cent higher, with provisions ranging from 2 1/2 cents to 7 1/2 cents higher.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: AS THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW circulates widely in the Mohawk Valley, the scene of Sir William Johnson's romantic life and often of Brant's barbarities, the article in your last issue by Mr. Buell on the family of Sir William Johnson must have been read with much interest by many people in the valley.
Jacob A. Messner is messenger No. 1,789, and is attached to the Western Union Telegraph office at 8 West Twenty-third Street. He lives at 189 East Fourth Street.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., July 12 -- The Commercial Museum, which collects commercial and industrial information for merchants and manufacturers throughout the country, has been so seriously crippled by the opposition of Republican machine leaders that several departments will be closed up on the first of the coming month, and others will have to shut down in the near future for lack of funds.

To the Editor of The New York Times: If the Spate chairs must go, why should not hansom cabs go, parlor cars go, orchestra and all reserved seats go -- indeed, everything go that the disgruntled don't like? I cannot see but that the reserved chairs in the public parks are a great convenience and comfort, for which a small charge is made.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., July 12 -- Racing yachts of various descriptions are awaiting an opportunity to haul out on the marine railway at the different shipyards at this place. At the Jacob yard Charles Smither's schooner yacht Muriel was hauled out as soon as the yacht Katrina took the water.

When the United States Steel Corporation was formed the prediction was freely made that it was a Juggernaut under whose wheels the independent works venturing to establish or maintain a competition in the lines it sought to control would be ground into impalpable powder.

PITTSBURG, July 12 -- It was a fight every inning through to-day's baseball game between Pittsburg and Philadelphia, the only fourteen-inning game ever played on the Pittsburg grounds. Monte Cross won the game in the fourteenth inning by a long hit to centre when the bases were full.

Francis Houghtaling, Grand Chancellor of the Knights of St. John and Malta, was yesterday adjudged in contempt by Justice Bischoff or the Supreme Court for failing to obey an injunction. However, as Houghtaling based his refusal to comply on the advice of counsel, Justice Bischoff permits him to purge himself of contempt by complying with the terms of the injunction and paying the costs of the motion and a fee to opposing counsel of $25.

PARIS, July 12 -- Senator Jules Siegfried, ex-Minister of Commerce, has arrived here from his American tour. In an interview to-day he paid a glowing tribute to the immense commercial and industrial expansion of the United States, which, he said, would be further increased by the system of trusts.

With a fine breeze that sent the fifty-four competing craft over the several courses in a hurry, Larchmont's open regatta, the first of its race week series, was sailed yesterday on Long Island Sound.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- The Interior Department has taken notice of the fact that the Government is charged with running a lottery in connection with the opening of the Kiowa, Comanche, and Wichita Indian reservations to homestead settlement. The charge is denied, and Assistant Attorney General Van Devanter explains why the Federal law is not being violated.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I thank you for the articles you have published in relation to the tunnel under Fourth Avenue, on the line of the railroads terminating in the Grand Central Station.

That was a pathetic case that was tried, or rather prevented by a plea of guilty from being tried, in Recorder GOFF'S court on Friday. A young man who had been graduated from West Point, and had served, not without credit, through the brief and brilliant little campaign in Cuba, had to confess forgery, and very petty and mean forgery, if there be any distinction among forgeries.

Partisanship was thrust aside at the Brigton Beach race track yesterday, when the Western colt Alan-a-Dale, known by reputation alone to New York racegoers got to the winning post first by an exceedingly short head and won the biggest event of the Brighton Beach Racing Association's meeting, the $10,000 Brighton Junior Stakes.

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 13. -- The young athletes from the Hill School of Pottstown, Penn., piled up a total of 31 points in the National interscholastic two-day meet, which ended at the Stadium to-day, and won the championship. Their nearest opponent was Phillips-Andover, with 18 points.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is very good to hear that the Metropolitan Museum has had this splendid endowment left it by the will of the late Jacob S. Rogers, but American art needs something more than a wealthy museum. Mr. Charles de Kay has ably and amply shown that schools do more than museums for a country's art.

LONDON, July 13. -- David Bispham sang lago in Verdi's "Othello" at short notice for the first time last Wednesday night in Covent Garden and achieved a genuine success, both by his musical and dramatic treatment of the arduous role. Bispham visits the United States two weeks in the Autumn only to sing at the Worcester festival.

LONDON, July 13. -- It is said that the topic most keenly discussed in the houses of Parliament on Friday was the "noballing" of Arthur Mold, the cricketer, one of the most famous of living bowlers, who, in the opinion or Phillips, the Anglo-Australian umpire frequently throws the ball instead of bowling it.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 13. -- Prof. John B. Smith, New Jersey State Entomologist, whose headquarters are in this city, is devoting most of his time this Summer to mosquitoes. Every day or two he gets a bottle of the insects from various parts of the State, and, for the purpose of experiment, is breeding them.

Theodore Moss, theatrical manager, is dead. Over half a century ago he was connected with the elder Wallack in the management of the most famous playhouse of those days -- Wallack's -- at Broadway and Broome Street. He died last night at his country home in Seabright, N. J.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., July 13. -- New Haven and Orford had the fight of the day in the closing competition of the Connecticut golf championship tournament, which closed to-day on the links of the New Haven Country Club. AUSTIN, Texas, July 13. -- A posse of United States Deputy Marshals and State Rangers are pursuing "Bill" Taylor, the notorious train robber and murderer, who escaped from the jail at Brownwood, Texas, yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- Gen. Chaffee, at Manila, has informed the War Department of the death of First Lieut. Charles R. Ramsay, Twenty-first Infantry, who died from wounds received in the action at Lipa Luzon. June 10. The death occurred this morning. Ramsay was a private in Company A, Fifth Maryland Volunteers during the War with Spain, and was appointed, a Lieutenant in the regular amy in July,1808.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., July 13. -- One of the most interesting developments of the year at Yale has been the new Self-Help Bureau established last Fall under the direction of President Hadley to assist poor and deserving students to a livelihood while passing through college.

KILLARNEY, July 13. -- The University of Pennsylvania crew of Philadelphia easily won their race against the Trinity College of Dublin crew on Klllarney Lake to-day. The course was from Glena Bay to Castlelough Bay. The water was smooth and there was no wind.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., July 13. -- A holiday crowd numbering between 8,000 and 8,000 persons saw the St. Louis baseball team again defeat the New York team to-day by a score of 8 to 2, and with a very badly crippled team at that. PLAINFIELD, N.J., July 13 -- The third game in the tournament for the Fisk Handicap Cup was played yesterday at the Hillside golf grounds. Miss Ball won, making 109 net, with 15 handicap. Previous winners have been Miss Van Herwerden and Miss Elsberg. The players were:

PARIS, July 13. -- M. Santos -- Dumont again demonstrated to-day that with wind and weather favorable it is possible to steer, a balloon which has arisen several hundred feet above the surface of the earth. He failed to accomplish what he set out to do, but this was owing to a defect in the machinery.
The Massachusetts Republican State Nominating Convention is to be held at Boston, Oct. 4, and Gov. Charles H. Allen of Porto Rico has been selected by the State Committee to preside.

BIRMINGHAM, July 13. -- At the Birmingham Athletic Club meeting to-day the 120-yard hurdle race was won by A.C. Kraenzlein of the University of Pennsylvania in 15 2-5 seconds, beating his own Stamford Bridge record. In the 120-yard hurdle handicap Kraenzlein fell, and I.K. Baxter of the University of Pennsylvania (13 yards) and E.W. Gould of Newport (14 yards) ran a dead heat in 18 1-5 seconds.

NEWARK, N.J., July 13. -- Three linemen had a rather strange experience yesterday while they were seeking to ascertain the trouble on the wires of the New York and New Jersey Telephone Company in the vicinity of Washington and Jerolemon Streets. Subscribers had complained of a peculiar buzzing sound.
LONDON, July 14. -- The Vlakfohtein Incident has come near to spelling "Waterloo" for the Government.
To the Editor of The New York Times: How altogether puerile and contemptible is the fight against the "pay chairs" in the parks of the city!
Some members of the Board of Walking Delegates are now known as "business agents." There is, in fact, a movement on foot to do away with the designation altogether.

LONDON, July 13. -- One of the most interesting of the many functions which have marked the end of the season is the reopening of Apsley House. Piccadilly. For nearly half a century this enormous mansion," in which lived and died the great Duke of Wellington, remained closed, for ,the late Duke, through bad health, was unable to live in London.

PARIS, July 15. -- Paris is gayly beflagged to-night in anticipation of the national fete to-morrow, the anniversary of the fall of the Bastile. Throughout the city, especially in the districts inhabited by the middle and working classes, open air balls are being held in almost every square and in the spaces at cross streets, where bandstands have been erected.

Although Robert H. Newell, the onetime famous humorist, who was found dead in bed at his home, 128 First Place, Brooklyn, on Friday, was known to his neighbors as a bachelor, it was brought to light yesterday that in the long ago he married a woman who in her day was known the length and breadth of the land.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 13. -- The woman's championship cup of the Innis Arden Golf Club at Sound Beach was won today in a good match between Mrs. Hoyt and Mrs. Daniels by the latter by 3 up and 2 to play. At the commencement of the competition Miss Dale beat Mrs. Schavoir by 6 up and 2 to play; Mrs. Hoyt beat Mrs. Tuttle 3 up and 1 to play.

BAR HARBOR, Me., July 13. -- To-day was a busy one with society here, events following each other in quick succession. The first golf matches of the season were played at Kebo in the morning, the first of the season's yacht races took place in the afternoon, and in the evening the first dinner dance was given at the Kebo Valley Club and the first of the fortnightly dancing classes was held at the Malvern.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., July 13. -- Rendezvousing at Glen Cove, L.I., yesterday, the fleet of the Corinthian Yacht Club of Philadelphia raced from that port to this harbor to-day. There was a fairly good easterly wind for the run which was for the cups offered by Vice Commodore Robert J.W. Koons of the schooner Priseilla.

TOLEDO, Ohio, July 13. -- M.E. Ingalls, President of the Big Four, has been elected President of the Cincinnati Northern, succeeding F.W. Whiteridge, who succeeded Gen. Samuel Thomas last January. E.F. Osborn of Cincinnati was elected Secretary, and C.F. Cox of New York Treasurer.

NEWPORT, July 13. -- It was learned today that the Duke and Duchess of Marlborough will come to Newport in August. They will sail for America on Aug. 15 and remain for the rest of the season. Correspondence regarding the visit between the Duchess and her relatives in Newport is now being carried on.
VALPARAISO, Chile, July 13. -- J. Pierpont Morgan has bought the Chilean section of the Transandine Railroad for u90,000.

Harry Elkes of this city won the one-hour motor-paced cycle race with Robert Walthour of Atlanta, Ga., and "Jimmy" Michael of Wales at Manhattan Beach yesterday afternoon in runaway style, which would seem to amply justify the title of long-distance champion of the world bestowed upon him by his admirers.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It may be that an apology is due for another infliction so soon, but the figures are so startling after to-day's "apathy" that I cannot resist calling attention to the absolute absurdity which the situation develops. Taking twenty-nine of the prominent "insecurities" which are handled most freely -- most brutally -- I notice that the united capital stock amounts to $3,022,000,000.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 13. -- The woman's championship cup of the Innis Arden Golf Club at Sound Beach was won today in a good match between Mrs. Hoyt and Mrs. Daniels by the latter by 3 up and 2 to play. At the commencement of the competition Miss Dale beat Mrs. Schavoir by 6 up and 2 to play; Mrs. Hoyt beat Mrs. Tuttle 3 up and 1 to play.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 13. -- The will of Hugh Tevls, the young San Francisco millionaire who died at Yokohama recently of appendicitis while on his wedding journey, has been filed at Monterey. It divides his estate, estimated at $1,000,000, almost equally between his widow and his nine-year-old daughter by his first wife.
LONDON, July 14. -- The Vlakfohtein Incident has come near to spelling "Waterloo" for the Government.

TOLEDO, Ohio, July 13. -- M.E. Ingalls, President of the Big Four, has been elected President of the Cincinnati Northern, succeeding F.W. Whiteridge, who succeeded Gen. Samuel Thomas last January. E.F. Osborn of Cincinnati was elected Secretary, and C.F. Cox of New York Treasurer.

That was a pathetic case that was tried, or rather prevented by a plea of guilty from being tried, in Recorder GOFF'S court on Friday. A young man who had been graduated from West Point, and had served, not without credit, through the brief and brilliant little campaign in Cuba, had to confess forgery, and very petty and mean forgery, if there be any distinction among forgeries.

NEW BEDFORD, Mass., July 13. -- Charles Porter of Detroit defeated Harry Caldwell of Manchester, N.H., in a twenty-mile motor-paced race on Butterwood track this afternoon. Caldwell, after riding a mile in 1:354-5, went to his dressing room without giving any explanation. Porter rode on mile after mile in remarkably fast time.
VALPARAISO, Chile, July 13. -- J. Pierpont Morgan has bought the Chilean section of the Transandine Railroad for u90,000.

BAR HARBOR, Me., July 13. -- The first regular golf tournament of the season here was played over the course at the Kebo Valley Club to-day. A handsome trophy has been offered by T.G. Condon for the player winning the largest number of points during the season. The entry list to-day was a good one.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The most important matter now related to the seats provided for public usage in the parks is their unfitness, because of their being too high.

LONDON, July 13. -- It is said that the topic most keenly discussed in the houses of Parliament on Friday was the "noballing" of Arthur Mold, the cricketer, one of the most famous of living bowlers, who, in the opinion or Phillips, the Anglo-Australian umpire frequently throws the ball instead of bowling it.

PARIS, July 13. -- M. Santos -- Dumont again demonstrated to-day that with wind and weather favorable it is possible to steer, a balloon which has arisen several hundred feet above the surface of the earth. He failed to accomplish what he set out to do, but this was owing to a defect in the machinery.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- Secretary Root left this evening for a tour of inspection of the principal military stations in the Middle West. He was accompaniled by Gen. Gillespie, Chief of Engineers, and Col. Randolph, Chief of Artillery. They go from here to Buffalo.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., July 13. -- Rendezvousing at Glen Cove, L.I., yesterday, the fleet of the Corinthian Yacht Club of Philadelphia raced from that port to this harbor to-day. There was a fairly good easterly wind for the run which was for the cups offered by Vice Commodore Robert J.W. Koons of the schooner Priseilla.

Prices in corn on the Produce Exchange, which had been advancing steadily for five days, took a severe tumble shortly after the opening of the session yesterday morning.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I thank you for the articles you have published in relation to the tunnel under Fourth Avenue, on the line of the railroads terminating in the Grand Central Station.

Tuxedo Club ended here this afternoon with a brilliant match in doubles. Paret and Davidson, the former Southern champions, beat Frazer and Mollenhauer of the Kings County Tennis Club of Brooklyn after four sets of exciting play. Paret also won first honors in the handicap singles. The scores were:

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is agreeable to note the agitation in reference to the Park Avenue tunnel, as it may do some good, for in all fairness I am bound to say that the New Haven Road seems disposed to remedy existing evils as far as possible. I desire to express my appreciation of your recent editorial, wherein the use of soft coal is condemned.

NEW BEDFORD, Mass., July 13. -- Charles Porter of Detroit defeated Harry Caldwell of Manchester, N.H., in a twenty-mile motor-paced race on Butterwood track this afternoon. Caldwell, after riding a mile in 1:354-5, went to his dressing room without giving any explanation. Porter rode on mile after mile in remarkably fast time.

NEWARK, N.J., July 13. -- Leonard Vogel, twelve years old, of 121 Hamburg Place, was attacked by a bulldog to-day while swimming in the Morris Canal at the foot of providence Street. His. face, arms, and shoulders were terribly lacerated, and he was taken from the water in an exhausted condition.
ROME, July 13. -- Bishop Scalabrini of Piacenza will sail from Genoa on July 18 on the Italian steamer Uguria, on a tour of the Italian colonies and the mission establishments in the United States.
To the Editor of The New York Times: How altogether puerile and contemptible is the fight against the "pay chairs" in the parks of the city!

PLAINFIELD, N.J., July 13 -- The third game in the tournament for the Fisk Handicap Cup was played yesterday at the Hillside golf grounds. Miss Ball won, making 109 net, with 15 handicap. Previous winners have been Miss Van Herwerden and Miss Elsberg. The players were:

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- Secretary Root left this evening for a tour of inspection of the principal military stations in the Middle West. He was accompaniled by Gen. Gillespie, Chief of Engineers, and Col. Randolph, Chief of Artillery. They go from here to Buffalo.

WORCESTER, Mass., July 13. -- The most successful race meet ever conducted by the Worcester Driving Park Company closed at the Barbers Grossing track this afternoon. Three of the four events on the card were completed, the 2:13 pace not being reached.
LONDON, July 13. -- George V.L. Meyer, United States Ambassador to Italy, is staying for a few days in London, en route for Boston. In an interview to-day he "said:

BAR HARBOR, Me., July 13. -- To-day was a busy one with society here, events following each other in quick succession. The first golf matches of the season were played at Kebo in the morning, the first of the season's yacht races took place in the afternoon, and in the evening the first dinner dance was given at the Kebo Valley Club and the first of the fortnightly dancing classes was held at the Malvern.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is agreeable to note the agitation in reference to the Park Avenue tunnel, as it may do some good, for in all fairness I am bound to say that the New Haven Road seems disposed to remedy existing evils as far as possible. I desire to express my appreciation of your recent editorial, wherein the use of soft coal is condemned.

An instructive incident, pregnant with suggestions, occurred recently in a branch of the Supreme Court in this city. A citizen was adjudged guilty of contempt of court for failing to obey an injunction from which an appeal had been taken. As the facts showed, the citizen who made this mistake acted in good faith, "by advice of counsel."

EAGLE PASS, Texas, July 14 -- The consulting engineer of the International Boundary Commission, P.D. Cunningham, was drowned by the capsizing of his boat in a narrow rocky channel of the Rio Grande, about twenty miles below Eagle Pass, late last evening. He and his party left here yesterday morning in two boats.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., July 14 -- The case of the New York and Southfield Beach Railway Company and the New York and Staten Island Electric Company in the attempt of the latter to erect wires for the purpose of carrying electricity between the company's powerhouse, at Livingston and South Beach, where the beach railroad is to run, came before Justice Wilmot M. Smith at a Special Term of the Supreme Court here yesterday.

PITTSBURG, July 14 -- The Post to-morrow will say: "Fifty thousand miners employed in the many mines of the Pittsburg district are willing to lay down their picks, walk out of the mines, and assist the Amalgamated Association of Iron and Steel Workers in their fight against the Steel Trust.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- On the 1st of July the Division of Forestry and three other scientific divisions of the United States Department of Agriculture were advanced to bureaus. This was provided for by the last session of Congress, which appropriated for the expenses of the Bureau of Forestry during its first year $185,440.
OCEAN GROVE, July 14 -- Officials of the American Sabbath Union had charge of all the meetings to-day at this famous Methodist camp meeting resort, and thousands of worshippers were in attendance.

Those who have undertaken to launch a new National party with municipal ownership of public utilities as its chief issue doubtless expect to secure a generous following of well-meaning and normally right-minded citizens, for whom the idea of municipal trading, as they call it in England, is very attractive, and who believe, or think they believe, that the profits of enterprises now conducted by private corporations would extinguish local taxation and fill our municipal treasuries.

NEWARK, N.J., July 14 -- Mrs. Bessie Schott, wife of ex-School Commissioner Harry P. Schott, was waylaid late last night, beaten into insensibility with a weapon supposed to be a sandbag, and robbed of about $55 which she had concealed in her stocking.
LONDON, July 15 -- Andrew Carnegie has offered L3,000 for the erection of a free public library in Annan, Scotland.

CHICAGO, July 14 -- Bishop Anderson said to-day: "The Episcopal Committee of Bible Revision do not propose to submit a new translation. Their work has been done only with the object of furnishing additional marginal readings. The present texts are in many cases badly worded, and it is intended by the insertion of alternative readings, in the margin, to elucidate the obscurities.

The only issue not settled by the conference between the employers in the steel industry at Pittsburg and the union, and the one on which the President of the union ordered a general strike in the mills of the three corporations, was the refusal of the employers to compel men to join the union who did not wish to do so.

With several hundred passengers on board, the steamboat Julia which plies between Rockaway Beach and Canarsie went aground off Barren Island about 9 o'clock last evening. When the vessel struck, a panic immediately ensued, many of the passengers jumping overboard during the excitement and swimming for the island.

The crews of the Atalanta Boat Club and the Nonpareil Rowing Club, left yesterday for Philadelphia, where they will compete in the coming National regatta on Friday and Saturday of this week. The Atalanta representatives are Kafka and Mulcahy, who will compete in the intermediate pair-oared shells and intermediate double-sculls events.

JOHANNESBURG, May 28 -- I have taken a walk round Johannesburg's stores trying to discover to what extent English trade will benefit by our new acquisition. If the truth be told, the prospect is by no means an encouraging one. That the mines will be ours -- or rather that the country in which the gold fields are situate will be under British rule -- may be taken for granted.

-- Mr. SIDNEY GREEN of this city is in Washington looking after the interests of his device for swift communication between the bridge and other parts of warships. Mr. GREEN has made a few pointed remarks about the need of electrical experts in the navy. He says that a knowledge of the waste in the electric department of our warships would astonish most of us, and no doubt it would.

Following are the returns of foreign commerce at the Port of New York for the week ended Friday last, as compared with the corresponding week last year. In the case of the exports of general merchandise the returns are for the week ended Tuesday:

For the thirty-third time Charles Schmidt, thirty-seven years old, endeavored to obtain admission to St. Catharine's Hospital, but yesterday, instead of being admitted as a patient, he was locked up in the Stagg Street Police Station, Williamsburg. Schmidt was found at McKibben and Leonard Streets, where he lay on the sidewalk, apparently unconscious.

Lieut. W.E. McCoun, an officer of the Revenue Cutter Service, and who distinguished himself at Manila Bay, yesterday saved from drowning in the waters at the Narrows his comrade, Cadet Francis R. Shoemaker. Both are attached to the Revenue Cutter Gresham. Yesterday afternoon the two, Lieut. McCoun and Shoemaker, were sailing in the Narrows in a sailboat belonging to the Gresham.

NEWPORT, July 14 -- William C. Whitney and J.B. Haggin will soon come to Newport to visit Mr. Whitney's son and daughter-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. Harry Payne Whitney, who are the guests of Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt at the Breakers.

The week just passed was not a pleasant one to many people in Wall Street. Market values suffered a considerable shrinkage and many speculative interests were forced to close their accounts, some of them with not altogether pleasing or profitable results. In many cases not only were paper profits wiped out but they were followed by losses which ate into capital account.

SEA GIRT, N.J., July 14 -- The members of the First Regiment and the Essex Troop, both of Newark, now in camp here, listened to a sermon this morning by the Rev. John Keller of Arlington, who is Chaplain of the First Regiment, and who will spend a week in camp with the soldiers. The services were held in the open air on the spacious lawn adjoining Gov. Foster M. Voorhees's headquarters.

The reason for Lord Milner's return to England is this: He went up to Pretoria to assume the Government of the Transvaal, and he appointed subordinates. There he came in contact with Lord Kitchener -- a man of action -- who soon made it clear to him that he was a mere fly on the wheel, and that martial law would take the place of civilian rule so long as the war continued.

BALTIMORE, July 14 -- The body of Skipwith Wilmer, a well-known Maryland lawyer who died of Bright's disease late Friday night at Nahant, Mass., was brought to his home in Baltimore to-day. The funeral will take place at Christ Episcopal Church to-morrow afternoon. Mr. Wilmer's family comes from Kent County.

A woman who gave her name as Clara Smith, and her age as 24 years, was arrested last night at 1,600 Broadway, on the charge of grand larceny and lodged in the West Sixty-eighth Street Station by Detectives Trainor and Fitzgibbons. With her, in the same room, was Bessie Glenn, aged 20, a domestic of 329 West Twenty-ninth Street, who was also arrested and held as a suspicious person.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Having been out of town, my attention has just been called to a sermon published in your issue of July 8, and delivered by Pastor Neudewitz, in which Catholics are shamefully, unfairly, and unjustly criticised, and are, moreover, made to appear before their fellow-citizens in the untenable but ridiculous role of "aiming for a union of Church and State" in this country.

The Joint Commission on Marginal Readings in the Bible, appointed by the Protestant Episcopal General Convention in 1895 and reappointed three years later, has made its final report. The first report was made in 1898, but as that referred to the New Testament only, three years' further time was granted.

ST. LOUIS, July 14 -- Taylor, New York's pitcher, practically threw away his game with St. Louis to-day by giving passes to first at critical times. Over 20,000 persons witnessed the contest, which was prolonged far twelve innings, at League Park, resulting in a victory for the St. Louis team by a score of 6 to 5.

Frank McBride, a professional aeronaut of Meriden, Conn., had a narrow escape from death in an unmanageable balloon yesterday afternoon. He had been engaged by the Knights of Kolander, a Russian organization of New York, to give an exhibition at Ulmer Park, Bensonhurst, where they were having an outing.

PITTSBURG, July 14 -- From present indications it is probable that President Shaffer's strike order, issued last night to the Amalgamated Association members in the employ of the American Steel Hoop Company, the American Sheet Steel Company, and the American Tin Plate Company, will be obeyed, and the great struggle between the Amalgamated Association and the steel companies will be on in earnest to-morrow.

NEWARK, July 14 -- Floyd McFarland and "Tom" Cooper were shut out of the professional combination mile race here today, and the fact that the race was put on for the ostensible purpose of encouraging team work, a thing which is usually dealt with summarily if practiced in ordinary cycle contests, makes the defeat of McFarland and Cooper all the more surprising.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., July 14 -- Carlisle D. Graham kept his word again today and made another trip through the whirlpool rapids. This is the fifth notch in his stick of fame, for five times has he braved the water that flows through the narrowest portion of the Niagara gorge. The other times were in 1886, 1887, and 1889.
Three small boys, who sniffled and were sorry in Yorkville Police Court yesterday morning, figure in a story of a burglary.

ANDOVER, Mass., July 14 -- The collec- tion of 40,000 specimens for the archaelogical department at Phillips-Andover Academy which was shipped from Philadelphia has arrived here, and will be stored until it can be placed on exhibition in the proposed new building for the archaelogical department.

The increase of $7,597,850 in the surplus reserve of the Associated Banks of New York City reported in the statement made Saturday, bringing the surplus up to $12,809,400, improves the local situation, and the reduction of $21,001,500 in loans shows that the banks had resolved to improve it.

There was some fast work on the Harlem River Speedway yesterday morning, when several new aspirants for honors put in an appearance and forced the favorites to trot and pace their best to retain the laurels already won. A better roadbed could not have been desired, as the early morning shower had just toned it up to condition.

LONDON, July 14 -- What had seemed a promising outlook has grown worse from the day of the announcement of the failure of the Leipziger Bank. While at first this seemed an isolated event, it now appears to have involved Germany, Belgium, and even Paris in a severe depression. Germany, anxious to strengthen her financial position, threw securities recklessly on an unreceptive market.

PATERSON, N.J., July 14 -- The details of the new telephone combination, with the whole country as its field, are gradually coming to light. Some time ago a number of capitalists undertook the task of consolidating all the telephone companies in the East and South, going on the principle that although these companies separately might amount to very little, they would present a great front if they could be all combined.

LONDON, July 14 -- The week closed with consols at 92. Nothing else is necessary to indicate the condition of our stock markets. Nervousness increases daily, and it is difficult to estimate whether the state of the public mind is not itself producing the market paralysis or whether a serious financial weakness is about to come to the surface.

Three barefooted and hatless children, the oldest eight years old, spent half of Saturday night wandering in Central Park and seemed to enjoy the adventure, especially as it terminated in a treat to cakes and pie and a ride home in a Children Society wagon.

PARIS, July 15 -- Telegrams from all parts of France show that the national fete day, the anniversary of the fall of the Bastille, was celebrated everywhere throughout the country with much enthusiasm and without disorder. There were reviews at all military and naval stations, followed by illuminations, fireworks, and balls in the evening.

According to a special dispatch published yesterday morning a man who gives his name as John O. Johnson, and says his home is at 302 East Eighty-eighth Street, this city, is in a Chicago hospital suffering from what is believed to be leprosy. Special interest attaches to the case because of the unusual and thrilling story the man tells.
LONDON, July 14 -- The War Office has received the following dispatch from Lord Kitchener, dated at Pretoria:

The officers, commissioned and non-commissioned, at Forth Wadsworth were yesterday sorry for the day the post canteen closed up. One of the Sergeants averred that he had done nothing for forty-eight hours but chase drunken soldiers. There were two soldiers in the post hospital with badly cut heads, the result of being struck by a club or a bottle, and some of the soldiers on duty showed the effects of fights.

ORANGE, N.J., July 14 -- The regular quarterly conference of the congregation of St. Paul's A.M.E. in this city was held in the church last night. Because of important questions likely to be discussed by the congregation, it was deemed prudent to send a detail of policemen, under Roundsman O'Brien, to see that those present did not maul each other, as it was feared they would.

PITTSBURG, July 14 -- Willis L. King, Vice Chairman of the Board of Managers of Jones Laughlins, an independent corporation, did not hestitate to say, when approached to-day, that the inability of the conferrees at the meeting of steel men and workers to agree was a most unfortunate condition, and meant an immense loss not only to all concerned, but to the country generally.
The liveliest kind of a political fight is predicted over the selection of a successor to Judge Addison Brown, United States Judge for the Southern District of New York.

BERLIN, July 14 -- Last week ended with a new low record of quotations in most industrials, many showing violent falls. Complete pessimism marked the trading of the week. The news from the industrial centres continued unfavorable. The iron reports had a depressing effect, and so also had the coal reports.

CHICAGO, July 14 -- The Tribune to-morrow will say: With a capitalization of between $1,000,000 and $3,000,000, twelve of the chief vaudeville theatres between Chicago and the Pacific Coast are about to be merged into a single property. The principles employed in industrial combinations are being used to bring about the unification.

The recent shipment of $750,000 gold to Germany provoked Wall Street comment. While there was no need for fright over this incident, the condition of the sterling market indicating that Germany has special needs which it is willing to have supplied upon special terms, speculation may be pardoned for a little nervousness, being in a somewhat unstrung condition concerning the outlook for money generally.

Charles Frankie, thirty-two years old, who says he is a homeless man, was locked up in the East One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street Station last night on a technical charge of vagrancy. The real reason for his arrest was that he had appropriated a fine private residence at 11 West One Hundred and Twenty-fourth Street, which happened to be vacant.
The incurable Bryanites predict the defeat of the Democratic candidate for Governor in Ohio as the penalty of the ignoring of BRYAN and his platforms by the nominating convention.

BALTIMORE, July 15 -- Some of the stockholders of the Maryland Brewing Company will file exceptions to the fees allowed by the court to the receivers last Saturday. Ten thousand dollars was allowed to each of the five receivers, William H. Whitridge, E.N. Morison, F.H. Gottlieb, John A. Tompkins, and Bernard Carter.

The inquest by Coroner Zucca and a jury of twelve men yesterday into the ferryboat Northfield disaster of June 14. when five lives were lost, resulted in a verdict exonerating Capt. Johnson from all blame whatever, and Capt. Griffin of the Mauch Chunk is exonerated from all criminal charges, but was censured by the Coroner for maintaining full speed when nearing his slip at the foot of Whitehall Street.

The Bureau of Statistics has just issued its bulletin giving the advance figures for the exports of domestic products for the twelve months ending with June -- that is for the fiscal year just closed. These figures include the exports of breadstuffs, cattle and hogs, provisions, cotton, and mineral oils, and cover usually 98 per cent. of the exports as shown by the full and corrected returns.
BASKING RIDGE, N.J., July 15. -- Nathan Woodward, a colored man, familiarly known as "Uncle Nate," died this morning at the age of 110 years.

BERLIN, July 15. -- Failures continue in Saxony as a result of the Leipziger Bank collapse. The Gera Worsted Spinnery failed to-day, and another worsted spinnery failed Saturday. The Cologne Gazette prints a very pessimistic report as to the iron market.

An effort is now making to attribute the unusual prevalence of smallpox in the Bronx to mosquitoes which have crossed over to North Brother Island, sung to and bitten the patients in that interesting retreat, and subsequently came ashore to visit the hospitable people of our Westchester suburb.

ROTHESAY, Firth of Clyde, July 15 -- The final racing trial of the two Shamrocks to-day was over a thirty-six-mile course, from Craigmore to Skelmorlie, thence to Tomont End, off Largs, and back to the starting point. Shamrock II. Won by a scant margin, but the conditions were such as to keep alive the confidence in the new boat.

That is a particularly mean and shabby kind of blackmail which two men were arraigned in Magistrate FLAMMER'S court on Sunday morning upon a charge of committing. The two men were agents and one the President of what they call the "State Law and Order Society," and the charge is that they extorted money from a saloon keeper under threat of prosecuting him for violating the Raines law.

WICHITA, Kan., July 15 -- After a drought of four weeks, that has nearly caused the ruin of the entire crop, it rained here to-day. It was a curious crowd that stood in Main Street this morning, eagerly watching a dark cloud that was gradually obscuring the blue sky. At noon, however, the sky was again clear and hopes of rain were blasted.

Justice Samuel T. Maddox of the Supreme Court of Queens County yesterday handed down a decision annulling the marriage between Josephine Millang Beuer of Bayside and Charles Beuer, her husband, of Great Neck, L.T. Mrs. Beuer in her petition said that she had been deceived by Buer into marriage.

PHILADELPHIA, July 15. -- The depression in New York caused heaviness rather than weakness in the Philadelphia market. The local stocks stood up well, there being no selling pressure. In the Wall Street stocks, the Readings suffered most. Pennsylvania at one time was over a point off, but finally wiped out the entire shrinkage.

LINCOLN, Neb., July 15 -- In an extended comment on the platform adopted by the Ohio Democratic Convention, W.J. Bryan criticises the convention for its failure to reaffirm the Kansas City platform and for what he regards as the weakness of some of the planks it did adopt. Mr. Bryan insists that the convention made a mistake in making himself an issue, and says:

DETROIT, Mich., July 15 -- Perfect weather, splendid racing, and a large crowd combined this afternoon to make the thirteenth annual Blue Ribbon meeting of the Detroit Driving Club and the opening of the Grand Trotting Circuit, on the Grosse Pointe track, a success.

LONDON, July 16 -- Ouida (Mlle. Louise de la Ramee) has a long letter in The Daily News protesting against the treatment administered by the British in South Africa to Olive Schreiner. Ouida says in part:

PATERSON, N.J., July 15. -- Three additional caveats, making five in all, against the probate of the will of Jacob S. Rogers, the millionaire locomotive builder, were filed in the Surrogate's office here to-day. One was by Flora Rogers, daughter of Mr. Rogers's brother, Jason Rogers; another by her brother, Thomas Rogers, and a third by Helena Rogers Bradford, a niece of the testator.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 15 -- Met, courted, married, all within the short space of two hours-such is the record which was established for this neighborhood yesterday when Henry Kuhlke of New York City and Miss Irene Myers of Philadelphia, who had been introduced to each other at 8 o'clock in the evening, were made man and wife at 10 o'clock.

LONDON, July 15 -- Steel shares at the opening of the Stock Exchange were extremely weak, the common falling off 4 1/3 points and the preferred 5 points. Later the common rose to 39 and the preferred to 90 1/2.

The Magazine Supplement of THE NEW YORK TIMES contained last Sunday an interesting article upon the "record" for duration in the French Republic of the present Ministry. The wonder that this Ministry should have outlasted any of its predecessors is much increased by the circumstances in which it was hurriedly assembled. It was set up avowedly as a provisional Government, a makeshift, and almost avowedly as a Government of desperation.

With a great hiss and roar a big locomotive belonging to the Pennsylvania Railroad that had got beyond control plunged, cab end first, into the North River at the foot of West Thirty-seventh Street about 7 o'clock last night. J.W. Hegel, the engineer, clung to his post until his engine made its leap.

From all indications there are to be no "off days" at the Brighton Beach track this season. Nominally, the racing yesterday fell under that head, there being no stake fixture set for decision, but "off day" or otherwise, the attendance was again of huge proportions, the grand stand being filled, while the field stand was packed to the point of discomfort.

New indoor cycling records from one to fifteen miles, inclusive, were made last night by W.C. Stinson, the Cambridge, Mass., cycle racer in his motor-paced match with John Nelson of Chicago in Madison Square Garden. The first mile was ridden in 1:52 2-5, as against a previous best time of 1:54, and from that time on to the finish a record was broken at the completion of each mile.

Stripped of sail, spars, and rigging, with her bulwarks splintered and her deckhouses demolished, but with her stout hull still intact and in condition for any service, the three-masted schooner Theollne, Capt. Francis, bound with lumber from Brunswick for Boston, was towed into this pert yesterday by the Ward liner Matanzas.

RICHMOND, Va., July 15 -- The Constitutional Convention of Virginia was in session only twenty-one minutes to-day. A resolution offered by Mr. Pedigo, Republican, of Henry County, alms to prevent lynching.

ARLINGTON, N. J., July 15 -- The public meeting called by the Thomas G. Barker Defense Association was held in Arlington Hall to-night. About 200 persons were present. John Sumner, who has taken the most active part in the defense of the man who shot the Rev. John Keller, presided at the meeting.

PHILADELPHIA, July 15. -- Under the provisions of the will of Lewis Elkins, who was well known in financial and railroad circles, admitted to probate to-day, the bulk of his large fortune is left in trust to create a fund for the benefit of disabled female teachers who have taught in the public schools of the city for a period of twenty-five years and have no means of support.

BOSTON, July 15. -- The stock market was erratic and almost featureless. The early dealings showed a considerable recession for the Coppers, in which Amalgamated led with a break to 109 1/8. Copper Range at the same time fell off to 72, Baltic to 50, Trinity to 34 1/2, and Osceola to 88 3/4. Later a fresh buying set in, and prices all made good recoveries.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- There was a sudden and complete reversal to-day of Secretary Root's decision in the case of Capt. Putnam Bradlee Strong. The Secretary telegraphed to Acting Secretary Sanger to accept Strong's resignation by wire. This was done, just in time to enable Strong to avoid sailing for the Philippines on the transport Grant, and to carry out his original programme for his Oriental trip.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "RS" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25-cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

It is to be hoped that President SHAFFER'S public statement, which he is said to be preparing with the aid of an attorney, will disclose with clearness and precision the nature of the differences between the Amalgamated Association and the officers of the steel companies. The published reports have told us that the companies made many concessions and showed a very conciliatory spirit.

It was reported yesterday morning that the name of GEORGE C. HOLT of this city was being pressed on the President for appointment as United States District Judge for the Southern District, to succeed Judge BBOWN, and that Mr. HOLT is the choice of Senator PLATT.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 15. -- Charles Nordhoff, a well-known newspaper man, died on Sunday in this city. For several years Mr. Nordhoff and family have lived at Coronado. Owing to failing health Mr. Nordhoff several weeks ago came to a private sanitarium in this city, where he expired. His death was the result of diabetes.
WASHINGTON, July 15. -- Admiral Remey, aboard the Brooklyn, is at Albany, West Australia.

PITTSBURG, July 15 -- Reports received to-day from all sources connected with the strike of the steel workers indicate that the members of the Amalgamated Association had matters well in hand, and that the strike order was generally obeyed. Telegrams from various places where the mills of the American Tin Plate Company, the American Steel Hoop Company, and the American Sheet Steel Company are located, told of the shutting down of these plants.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., July 15 -- The New York baseball team took the last game of the series with St. Louis at League Park today with the aid of Pitcher Christie Mathewson, who was in rare form. Mathewson let the local team down without a hit, and the only St. Louis men who reached first base were those who were allowed their base on balls.

CINCINNATI, July 15 -- Donovan of Brooklyn's baseball team pitched in excellent form to-day in the game against Cincinnati, but the miserable support accorded him enabled the local team to win the game by a run. Donovan struck out ten men, and, while Phillips was hit hard, the hits were scattered.
LONDON, July 15. -- Money was not plentiful to-day, but the demand was fair. Discounts were quiet.

LONDON, July 15 -- At a special meeting of the shareholders of Bryant May, held this afternoon, the agreement to acquire the business of the Diamond Match Company of Liverpool for L480,000, to be provided by a new issue of Bryant May shares, was adopted.

It is estimated that fully 7,000 poor women and children from the Nineteenth Assembly District attended as his guests the outing planned by Magistrate E.G. Higginbotham of Brooklyn yesterday to Orchard Beach, on the Sound. Magistrate Higginbotham was also on hand early. He opened his court at 6:30 o'clock, so that the cases that came before him could be attended, and by 9 o'clock every prisoner had been disposed of.

John C. Barth has sold to Henry Briner the four five-story flats at the northeast corner of Amsterdam Avenue and One Hundred and Thirty-first Street, 109.8 by 100. The buyer gives, in part payment, the plot at the southwest corner of Seventh Avenue and One Hundred and Forty-eighth Street, 99.11 by 100.

In a hard-fought race of thirty miles yesterday, in the second day's racing of the Larchmont Club's race week, F.K. Brewster's Elmina carried off first honors in the class of seventy-five-foot schooners after Charles Smither's Muriel appeared to have them safely stowed. Muriel, who led her competitors handsomely over the course on the first round and well into the second, was finally badly beaten by Harry Lippitt's Quissetta.

The market for outside securities yesterday morning acted heavily and in sympathy with the sharp break scored in the Stock Exchange market at the opening of the session. Later, the decided improvement on the big board brought a measure of recovery to some of the curb shares, but in many instances the declines were not counteracted.

BOSTON, July 15 -- A petition in bankruptcy was filed to-day by Stephen M. Marshall, Secretary of the Tenth Congressional Republican District Committee of 1808. The petition includes all debts of that committee for which he, as one member of the committee, could be held liable. The debts of the committee are shown to amount to about $800.

PITTSBURG, July 15 -- "All of our men ere out, and the condition for which we have been preparing these three years and more, and against which we have repeatedly warned the manufacturers, now confronts the latter," said President T.J. Shaffer of the Amalgamated Association this morning.

OMAHA, July 15 -- The crop situation in Nebraska continues one of grave uncertainty. Some slight showers fell in Central and Eastern Nebraska to-day and last night, but at no place was the water more than sufficient to lay the dust. Dodge, Adams, Gage, and Dixon Counties report some rain for the day.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, July 15 -- The local officials of the American Steel Hoop Company were surprised this morning by the mingling with the strikers of several foremen from the mills of the Republic Iron and Steel Company. The Republic Company is independent of the United States Steel Corporation, and is gathering in many immediate delivery orders which formerly went to the Steel Hoop Company.

Jacob H. Hollander, Treasurer of the Island of Porto Rico, arrived here yesterday from San Juan on the steamship San Juan. Mr. Hollander, who holds the Chair of Assistant Professor of Finance at Johns Hopkins University, was sent to Porto Rico by the President to formulate a revenue system for the island.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The reference of your London correspondent in the cable dispatch which appeared this day to the resignation of the Most Rev. Dr. Walsh, Archbishop of Dublin, from the Board of National Education in Ireland, is utterly misleading. He states that the Archbishop resigned because he could not agree with his Protestant colleagues on the board.
PITTSBURG, July 15 -- The following showing of the mills affected by the strike order is made up from reports received by the Amalgamated Association and from dispatches from correspondents:

Among the large fleet of excursion steamboats and other craft caught and held for various terms in the clutches of the fog on the harbor and rivers Sunday evening, probably the most unfortunate was the Starin Line steamboat Mattawan from Glen Island. The Mattawan left Glen Island at about 7:15 o'clock on Sunday evening, and was due in New York at 9 o'clock.
NEWPORT, July 15. -- Mrs. Astor arrived from New York to-day. At Beechwood a number of floral tokens of welcome awaited her. She will probably begin giving a series of large dinner parties next week.

BALTIMORE, July 15. -- The market to-day presented an encouraging exhibition of resistance. There were declines, but the yielding movement was fought stubbornly, resulting in the downward trend being much slower than many anticipated. In view of the conditions in New York, a break in the Seaboard group was expected.

Ministers of the Gospel are often troubled to account for the growing disinclination on the part of educated and thinking men to go to church. Many sharp sermons are preached, and congregations are soundly scolded for the shortcomings of the male sex in this matter, but the ministers do not get at one of the most potent reasons, for they do not see their sermons as others see them.

The Lackawanna Railroad will probably be the first Eastern road to use the telephone instead of the telegraph for operating the trains along its lines. The engineering department of that road is now engaged in installing the telephone system all along the main line and branches, and it is expected that the system will soon be completed.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 16 -- The State Railroad Commissioners, after a hearing, announced that they had decided to grant a certificate to the Ridge Trolley Road from Rochester to Buffalo.

TRENTON, N.J., July 16 -- Chancellor Magie this morning appointed William Pennington, John S. Barkalow, and Theodore B. Rogers executors named under the will of Jacob S. Rogers, administrators of the estate pendente lite. They were placed under a bond of $500,000, which was furnished by the American Surety Company.

William Corter, eighty years old, who has lived on his farm, in Caldwell, N.J., ever since he was born, was dispossessed on Monday night. He is now trying to regain possession, and in order to preserve his rights he is camping out in the front yard on an old chair and refuses to leave the place, although his furniture has been removed.

The prospective shortage of corn in some of the large producing States, threatening to cut down the yield to a figure materially below the average for recent years, while in itself a sufficiently untoward development, has led to an absurd slaughtering of values on the New York Stock Exchange.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is really quite remarkable the solicitude the friends of Mrs. Barker display that Mr. Keller should vindicate himself, according to report, sending him letters of advice, and even offering to advance him money to prosecute a suit for defamation of character.
LONDON, July 16 -- Cardinal Gibbons was entertained at dinner to-night at the Brazilian Legation. Several distinguished peers and diplomats were present.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., July 16 -- The strike of the stationary firemen inaugurated to-day has tied up nearly all the mines in the Wyoming Valley, and a conservative estimate places the number of men idle at 43,000. This includes the men out in the Scranton district. Only about 800 of these are firemen.

BOSTON, July 16 -- Albert Champion won the triangular twenty-five-mile motor-paced race at Charles River Park, which was contested to-night by Champion, "Bobby" Walthour, and James F. Moran, by twelve yards over Moran in 30:45 3-5. Walthour was two laps behind Champion at the finish.

In the following list "mtg" stands lor mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2.500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

It is well known that most members of Congress of either party look on the system of appointments to the public service for merit with cordial animosity. They are generally ready at all times and in any way possible to evade or "beat" the system, where they can do so without too obvious offense to the sense of decency among their constituents.

Bishop Wesley J. Gaines of the Seventh District of the African Methodist Episcopal Church, whose home is at Atlanta, Ga., sails to-day on the American liner St. Louis. He goes as a delegate to the Ecumenical Council of Methodists which convenes in London on Sept. 4th next. While abroad the Bishop will lecture in the principal cities of England, Scotland, and the Continent on the social condition of the negro in the United States.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The Postmaster General has been forced to take a hand in the disputes which have arisen between the maker of free delivery boxes and the department. The Box Makers' Trust are becoming excited at the prospect of competition. They have not yet been able to secure an order from the department compelling the use of their wares on the star routes, which are to be equipped with boxes.

NEWARK, N.J., July 16 -- The Federal Trust Company with a capital of $500,000 was incorporated to-day. It is the culmination of a movement begun several months ago of which much has already been published. The incorporators are the subscribers to the stock.

COUNCIL BLUFFS, Iowa, July 16 -- President J.J. McCarthy made startling statements regarding the prevalence of the bribery of witnesses in American courts of justice in his address to the Iowa State Bar Association at its annual meeting in this city to-day. Among other things he said:
Army. Chances in the stations and duties of paymasters --

DETROIT, Mich., July 16 -- Ten thousand people saw Eleata, a four-year-old black mare, bred on the Palo Alto Farm in California, and owned by ex-Senator Frank Jones of New Hampshire, win the $10,000 Merchants and Manufacturers' Stake for 2:24 class trotters at the Grosse Pointe track this afternoon, and lower the record for the race from 2:10 1/2 to 2:08 3/4.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., July 16 -- A cave-in of earth and timbers at a cut made by workmen who were preparing for the foundation of the Uncowa Reservoir Dam,which is being built for the Bridgeport Hydraulic Company, killed three men and injured nine others, one of whom may die.

The North American Trust Company has decided to make an effort to collect or compromise the bonds issued by the Southern States during the reconstruction period following the civil war, and since repudiated in whole or in part by those States.

MAGNOLIA, Mass., July 16 -- The hot weather greatly interfered with good playing in the Magnolia Club's tennis tournament, which was continued to-day, and the matches, most of them, were uninteresting.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 16 -- The Independence still swings at her moorings inside Brenton's Cove, for though her topmast was finally stepped and rigged before 2 o'clock, the fog was so thick that it was deemed too hazardous to start for New London. Should the weather clear, an effort will be made to get away early in the morning.

A strange story of a mysterious Kidnapping twenty-five years ago and of years of fruitless search for long-lost parents came to light Sunday when Albert W. Lausterer of this city invoked the aid of the Philadelphia police in assisting him in his search for his father and mother, who, he says, he has reason to believe live in or near that city.

PITTSBURG, July 16 -- The miserable fielding of Pittsburg's baseball team lost the game to-day to Philadelphia. Each of Pittsburg's four errors netted a run for Philadelphia, and a base on balls, followed by two hits, scored the other two. Donahue pitched good ball, and received perfect support. The score:

GOSHEN, N.Y., July 16 -- George Morgan, Herman Strack, Arthur Weed, and Harry Dutcher, four young men of Goshen, missed the last train from Middletown and secured permission to ride home on a freight train.

BRISTOL, R.I., July 16 -- The Constitution came up from Newport this afternoon to refit in preparation for the annual cruise of the New York Yacht Club in which she is to participate. The craft was anchored close to the boat shops in a convenient place for loading her on the cradle in order to haul her out on the marine railway.

Mrs. Arthur Greaves. Mrs. Arthur Greaves, wife of the city editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, died yesterday morning of consumption in a sanitarium at Liberty, N.Y., where she had gone in the hope of regaining her health. Mr. Greaves was with her when she passed away.
LONDON, July 16 -- Charles Frohman, the theatrical manager, will, sail to-morrow from Southampton for New York on the Kaiser Wilhelm der Grosse.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Permit me the privilege of making known the following:
Ex-Senator Charles A. Towne of Minnesota is at the Hotel Victoria, where he was seen by a TIMES reporter last night.

LONDON, July 17 -- The Earl of Rosebery has issued a manifesto on the divisions of the Liberal Party. It is contained in a letter to the City Liberal Club, which had invited him to deliver an address.

PEKING, July 16 -- The Ministers of the powers now freely admit that the prospect of a conclusion of the negotiations is growing darker. The situation is most serious, as the dead-lock has continued for more than a month. The meeting arranged for to-day was postponed because it was apparent that the proceedings would be fruitless.

BAR HARBOR, Me., July 16 -- The heat at Bar Harbor to-day was probably the highest ever known here. At midday the thermometer showed 96 degrees. Society kept indoors all morning, the links at Kebo were deserted, and not a yacht moved across the waters of the bay. This weather has been a revelation to Bar Harbor people, who never believed that such a condition could exist.

"Major" Taylor, the cycle racer, has settled his differences with the National Cycling Association officials, and will ride at Manhattan Beach to-night. Manager Brady received a wire from the champion sprinter last night, and states positively that Taylor will take part in the championships.

BOSTON, July 16 -- The stock market was "draggy" for much of the time to-day, but generally showing an excellent undertone. Bursts of activity and strength came occasionally, but they did not last long. Amalgamated, for example, early in the day, was bid up to 113, but subsequently fell off, only to get another good lift just at the close.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 16 -- "Prof." William Muldoon has been made defendant in a suit for $2,000 damages for assault. The plaintiff Joseph Sude, who not only claims damages for the pain and ignominy of the assault which he claims was committed, but also the price of a tooth which he lost in line affair.
TROY, N.Y., July 16 -- The trotting meeting held under the auspices of the Park Club opened with a large attendance and most excellent performances. Summary:
NORTH BERWICK, Scotland, July 16 -- Norman Hunter of Oxford University, beat W.J. Travis, the American golfer, in a 36-hole match to-day by 2 up and 1 to play.

LONDON, July 16 -- E. Corrigan's Sea Flower (Charles Thorpe) won the Trial Plate, for three-year-olds and upward, distance one mile, at the first day of the second July meeting at Newmarket to-day. Richard Croker's Joe Ullman (L. Reiff) was second, and Far West finished third.
NEWPORT, July 16 -- Mrs. C.H. Baldwin held her regular at home this afternoon at Snug Harbor. Mrs. John R. Drexel entertained at dinner. Mrs. J.C. Mallery also gave a dinner for twelve guests.

"We are not," said a member of the Lorillard family yesterday, "disposed to contradict or discuss the half dozen rumors published to-day concerning the trill of Mr. Pierre Lorillard and our intentions or plans in regard to it. It is enough to say that the situation to-day is that set forth in THE NEW YORK TIMES in its issue on Sunday last.

The committee of the National Civil Service Reform League, appointed to inquire into the Federal Civil Service, made public its report to the Council of the League last night. The committee, in the course of its report, says:...
STILLWATER, Minn., July 16 -- Andrew Carnegie has offered Stillwater $25,000 for a public library. A site already has been secured and the Council will provide the required income.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., July 16 -- Four thousand people saw the bicycle races at the Coliseum to-night. "Major" Taylor did not appear for the championship events and announcement was made that he would not appear until July 20 at the Revere track.

As usual, there were some few people in town yesterday from the watering places. The hotels and restaurants were almost deserted. Mrs. James P. Kernochan is still in town and so is Mrs. John Jay. Both of these ladies are in deep mourning. Their carriages have been the only fashionable equipages on the avenue these midsummer days.

It would be interesting to know on, what ground the Magistrates having jurisdiction in cases where persons are arrested for violation of the Sanitary Code in spitting on the floors of public conveyances base the sage conclusion that an offender is subject to arrest for that disgusting and dangerous practice only when he has been warned.

It was announced at the office of the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company yesterday that the company would not return to the use of electricity on the elevated roads of the system until Sept. 1. There has been a delay in the work of constructing the transforming stations in various parts of the boroughs.
LONDON. July 16 -- A copy of the first folio edition of Shakespeare, printed in 1623, was sold at auction this afternoon for u1,720, the record price for a copy of this edition.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Yesterday morning's issue of THE TIMES contained an article under the title "Devil First Universalist," the same being an abstract of a sermon preached Sunday morning by the Rev. R.B. Smith of this city against Universalism. Knowing you do not wish false statements to go to the world through your journal.

ALBANY, N.Y., July 16 -- Ex-Judge Robert Earl, referee in the New York City franchise tax cases, reviewed the valuations placed on the franchises of the Electrical Subway Company, the New Amsterdam Gas Company, the Northern Union Gas Company, and the Central Union Gas Company of New York City this morning.

HOLLIDAYSBURG, Penn., July 16 -- The American Steel Hoop Works at Duncansville, this county, contrary to general predictions, have not closed down, and the officials claim they are not affected by the strike situation. It is denied that the works will close, and those in control of the plant say the men are working harmoniously and will not strike.

Leggat Brothers, dealers in old and new books at 81 Chambers Street, one of the oldest of the down-town houses in the book trade, have become temporarily financially embarrassed and their affairs have been placed in the hands of their creditors to protect the interest of all concerned.

There is good reason to believe that the scare respecting the corn crop and the damage it had suffered from great heat and drying winds, was deliberately started and systematically encouraged by false reports for purely speculative purposes. If sensational exaggerations get a fair start, it is usually some days before the truth overtakes them.

LONDON, July 16 -- Ida and Edith Yeoland, actresses, twenty-six and twenty-one years old respectively, committed suicide together by taking poison in their rooms in London this afternoon. They had both recently been without engagements and were bitterly disappointed at failing to secure an expected engagement to play in New York.
LONDON, July 16 -- Money was in good demand to-day, and considerable was borrowed from the Bank of England, partly in connection with the settlement. Discounts were sympathetically firm.

PHILADELPHIA, July 16 -- Railway and steel stocks were sagging in the local market to-day, but the strictly local list showed a better tone, notably the street railway shares. Union Traction was in good demand in the morning, over 3,000 shares being taken in scattering lots, all at 27. Philadelphia Traction was stronger, and the best gain was made by Electric and People's of America, which touched 96, against 94 3/4 yesterday.
