Thirteen prisoners were taken, and a truckload of poolroom paraphernalia and much other valuable evidence were secured in a raid yesterday afternoon in two places by agents of the Society for the Prevention of Crime, also known as the Parkhurst Society.

CHICAGO, July 16 -- When the Kiowa Reservation in Oklahoma is opened to the public Aug. 6, there is to rise from the ashes of the tepees of the Comanche, Kiowa, and Apache tribes a miniature Chicago, controlled by ex-members of the CooK County Democracy, and which, in time is expected to occupy the same relative position in the Territory that this city does to Illinois.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 16 -- The official call of the "Bryan Democrats" of Ohio was issued to-day. It is addressed to "The Bryan Democrats of Ohio," and charges that the Ohio Convention repudiated the two last Democratic National platforms, and that the action of the convention was the result of a conspiracy "mapped out at the headquarters in New York." The call concludes as follows:

With hundreds of gray-colored flags and pennants floating from the rigging and spars of more than a hundred yachts in the Horse Shoe, the Larchmont Yacht Club was no doubt the most attractive spot on the Atlantic Coast yesterday.

A large combination in the oil cloth industry was consummated yesterday, with the perfecting of the organization of, tha Standard Table Oil Cloth Company. All but three small plants have been acquired by the new company. The plants absorbed have a capacity of nearly double the amount consumed by the whole country.

The Rev. JOHN KELLER, Arlington, N.J.: Sir: We, the undersigned citizens, who desire the whole truth respecting the tragedy of Feb. 3 to be ascertained and established beyond dispute, beg to remind you that Mrs. BARKER, during the trial of her husband, testified under oath that you had committed a criminal outrage upon her person.

We have not been mistaken in assuming the correctness of reports attributing to President SHAFFER of the Amalgamated Association purposes and motives so high-handed and despotic that bis order calling out the employes of the steel mills as a means of enforcing his demands can be justly and temperately described as an act of infamy.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The annual reports of the engineers in charge of river and harbor work began to arrive at the War Department to-day. Heretofore the estimates and recommendations of the local engineers have not been made public until the estimates were sent to Congress, but this year this restriction was removed.

PARIS, July 17 -- A shot was fired in the direction of M. Baudin, Minister of Public Works, while he was driving to a Cabinet meeting at the Elysee yesterday morning. The person who fired the shot was a Polish woman, the Countess Olzewsky, whose husband is a naturalized Frenchman.

Police Captains whose names have often been before the public were involved in a "shake up" of considerable proportions, which was announced by Commissioner Murphy yesterday. He gave the time-worn reason for the changes -- "for the good of the service," except in the case of Capt. Edward Walsh, who was sent from the important station in East One Hundred and Twenty-sixth Street to Flushing Avenue, Brooklyn.

OMAHA, Neb., July 16 -- Bird Head, a Ponca Indian, aged eighty-six, and his squaw, aged eighty-one, to-day pleaded guilty in the Federal Court to manslaughter, committed on the reservation more than a year ago, and were released with suspended sentence.

To the Editor of The New York Times: You richly deserve the hearty thanks, as you are sure to receive the full recognition of your readers who are travelers in the cars of the New York Central Railroad, for your able and complete defense of their rights, especially in the matter of that dreadful sulphurous tunnel.

PHILADELPHIA, July 16 -- All the oarsmen of the Schuylkill Navy are taking the last days before the National regatta, which begins on Friday, as a time of rest, and from all Indications there is not the slightest danger that any of the local men will get to the races in any way overtrained.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read with Interest the communication of Mr. Alexander Rosenthal in THE TIMES of the 9th inst. on "The Remedy for Legal Delays."

NEWARK, N.J., July 16 -- The local branch of Cesare Conti Co.'s Italian bank in Market Street was robbed at noon to-day of about $800. The robbery is a most peculiar one. Scepitonni Conti has charge of the bank, which is a small affair, being maintained simply for the benefit of the Newark patrons of the New York bank.

Prof. Samuel McCune Lindsay of the University of Pennsylvania, and President of the American Academy of Political and Social Science, took charge of the sessions of the Summer School in Philanthropic Work at the United Charities Building in New York City for this week, and opened the session yesterday morning with an address on "The Influence of Politics in the Management of Institutions."

ARLINGTON, N.J., July 16 -- The friends of the Rev. John Keller say that the open letter, drafted last night at a public meeting of Thomas G. Barker's sympathizers and addressed to Mr. Keller, will have little or no effect in shaping the course which the wounded clergyman will pursue to refute the charge made against him by Mrs. Barker.

Details of the sale of the Koster Bial property to R.H. Macy Co. will be found in another column. Rumors were current yesterday affecting several valuable parcels, but in each instance inquiry showed that the property in question had not changed hands.

CHICAGO, July 16 -- Louis Kotte, son of the late George Kotte, a wealthy brewer of Cincinnati, is under arrest here charged with the embezzlement of $20,000 from the estate of his father. Kotte, who is twentyfour years old, was arrested to-night by detectives at his boarding house.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., July 16 -- Tidings received from Kingston, Jamaica, by relatives living in Orange, tell of the death of Prof. George R. Phillips, well known in the Oranges, Maplewood, and Brooklyn. Prof. Phillips died in Kingston yesterday.

TACOMA, July 17 -- By a feat novel in the history of mountain climbing on Mount Hood the life of Miss Bethel Rawson of Demoss, Ore., was saved yesterday. She was one of a party of twenty-five that at-, tempted the ascent of the mountain in the morning. Exhausted by the climb and succumbing to a blizzard at noon, when 300 yards from Crater Rock, she fainted.

It was announced in insurance circles yesterday that Jefferson Pearce, the general agent of the Potomac Fire Insurance Company of Washington, D.C., will manage the metropolitan business of that company, representing the interest of Mrs. West Pollock in the firm of Pollock Cortis, and that William Ellsworth who was associated with the late Mr. Pollock, will continue the metropolitan representation of the Caledonian and the Caledonian American Insurance Companies.

DETROIT, Mich., July 17 -- In the free-for-all pace this afternoon at the Grosse Pointe track, Coney, the favorite, went the fastest mile ever traveled in a contest on the track, going the distance in 2:02, which is three-quarters of a second better than the gelding's previous record.

BUFFALO, July 17 -- On a court that was lightning fast, and with weather conditions all that could be desired, play in the New York State championship tennis tournament, was to-day brought down to the semi-finalst Clothier, the crack Philadelphian, defeated Smither in a two-set game. Summary.

It is generally understood that the strike now in progress in the steel mills means more than appears in the public utterances of either the mill managers or the union leaders. Everybody identified with organized labor in a representative capacity has been waiting to see the Amalgamated Association "try a fall" with what is popularly known as the "Billion Dollar Steel Trust."
The market for outside securities was quiet yesterday, with some substantial gains in prices. Transportation and bank shares were practically neglected.

John W. Tomlinson, a Bryan Democrat of Alabama, said last evening that Grover Cleveland would win more votes for the Democratic ticket as the National candidate in 1904 than David B. Hill. Mr. Tomlinson was a member of the Platform Committee at Kansas City, and worked hard to carry out Mr. Bryan's views as to the planks which should be placed in the document.
Adrian H. Muller Son sold the following securities at auction at the New York Real Estate Salesroom, 111 Broadway, yesterday:

COERCION OF JURY -- A judgment on a verdict for Hiram V. Twiss in his action against the Lehigh Valley Railroad Company has been reversed by the Third Appellate Division on the sole ground that the declarations made by the trial Justice to the jury amounted to a coercion of the verdict rendered.

RED BANK, N.J., July 17 -- Forty horses from the training stables of Charles Littlefield at Eatontown broke loose about 2 o'clock this morning. They scattered in all directions. Five of them wandered on the tracks of the trolley company near Eatontown and got fast in the ties. Another tumbled from the trestle to the ground, a distance of twenty feet, but was not hurt.

WASHINGTON, July 17?-- Prof. Willis L. Moore, Chief of the Weather Bureau, today prepared a statement of the rainfall throughout the drought stricken region, covering the forty-eight hours from 8 o'clock Monday morning to 8 o'clock this morning. The statement is as follows:

More than 700 people were passengers on the Westfield and the Howard Carroll, that met in collision between the Battery and Governors Island yesterday afternoon. That the accident resulted in no fatalities was, according to eye-witnesses, little short of miraculous, for the colliding vessels, both steam paddle boats, were each built nearly forty years ago, and the crash with which they came together was a terrific one.

YONKERS, N.Y., July 17 -- "The idea of the funeral expenses of a recluse, a man not supposed to have any money or relatives in this world, amounting to $320, is simply extortion and extravagant," was the remark of Surrogate Silkman to-day while considering the settlement-of the accounts of Dr. J.T. Gibson, as administrator of the late William Bowers, who died here in March last.

NEWPORT, July 17 -- The evening of July 26 promises to be the busiest socially in July. On that evening there will be the vaudeville entertainment at Mrs. Fish's and a large dinner at Mrs. William E. Carter's Mrs. Elisha Dyer, Jr., Mrs. George L. Rives, and Mrs. George B. De Forest will entertain at dinner, and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt, Jr., will give a dinner for fifty at Beaulieu, followed by dancing.

ALBANY, July 17 -- Lieut. John A. Wilson of Company E. Twenty-third Regiment, Brooklyn, who, during the trolley strike on the lines of the Union Traction Company in this-city was in command of soldiers on a car from which a volley was fired, killing two citizens, gave testimony to-night before Coroner Girvin.

Squalls, rain fog, shifting breezes, and flat calms were the conditions contended with by skippers of racing craft in the open regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club, which was sailed yesterday on the Sound. It was the second open event of Larchmont's race week, and although the weather outlook was anything but promising before the start, a large fleet was an hand when the preparatory signal was given at 11:30 o'clock.

On the Sound one of the events of to-day is the cruise of the Corinthian Yacht Club of Philadelphia, which has Alexander Van Rensselaer's steam yacht May as its flagship. There will be a dance given in honor of the fleet on Saturday at Oyster Bay. To-day is also the date for the automobile race between Newport and Boston, in which a number of well-known young men will take part.

It is not right to say, as some interests in Wall Street yesterday said, that the substantial upward movement of prices on the Stock Exchange represented in large measure a bear panic due to a hasty scampering of shorts to cover. As a matter of fact, covering was little of a factor in the advancing prices.

Coney Island's "Old Mill," an attraction in Surf Avenue, was the place chosen for suicide by a well-dressed man supposed to be William Weiderhold of Ossining, N.Y., last night. He shot himself over the right ear, dying instantly, and by his act horrified a large crowd, principally of women and children, assembled about the place.

CHICAGO, July 17 -- Prof. Oscar L. Triggs of the University of Chicago, who some time ago compared John D. Rockefeller to William Shakespeare, to-day informed the class in English literature at the university that the hymns of the Protestant churches are doggerel, and that dime novels are literature when compared to Sunday school books.
LONDON, July 17 -- Lord Pauncefote, British Ambassador to the United States, made the following statement to-night:

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Postmaster General Smith to-day signed three orders amending in important particulars three postal regulations affecting second-class mail matter. The first order amends Section 276, which is the general definition, so as to exclude from the second class publications which, have the characteristics of books.
E.De Forest-Simmons and Whitehouse Porter have sold to J.A. Benedict the four-story brownstone-front dwelling, 42 East Sixty-fourth Street, 16 by 65 by 100.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., July 17 -- On account of the numerous robberies in New Rochelle and Pelham Manor the authorities of both places have offered a reward of $250, making a total of $500, for the arrest and conviction of any person captured. During the past two or three months numerous robberies have been reported to the police of Pelham Manor and New Rochelle.

PITTSBURG, July 17 -- Sheckard's batting was the feature of the baseball game here to-day between Brooklyn and Pittsburg, in which the former team was victorious by a comfortable score. The Brooklyn's left fielder batted out two three base hits and a home run, scoring three of his team's tallies.

CHICAGO, July 17 -- Mayor Harrison's 20 per cent, retrenchment order issued yesterday may soon be followed by another one of similar import. City Controller McGann is authority for the statement that a cut of 40 per cent, in the expenses of maintaining the city is necessary in order to enable the municipality to successfully disentangle itself from the financial straits in which it is engulfed.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The Italian Government has taken cognizance of a recent affray at Erwin, Miss., in which it is claimed two Italians were lynched and a third seriously wounded. The facts have been communicated to the Foreign Office at Rome, and the Italian Embassy here has made representations to the State Department.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R.S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25-cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.
LONDON, July 17 -- Money had an easier tendency to-day. Discounts were firm, the position of Americans making brokers cautious.

Plans for the "three-platoon" system soon to be installed in the Police Department, upon which a committee has been at work for many days, are so nearly complete that Commissioner Murphy yesterday announced the principal features in a formal report. He said, however, that he could not yet tell how soon they would be put in operation.

Efforts are being made to discover a will supposed to have been left by Col. Thomas E. Sloan of the Old Guard, who was killed while boating off Norwalk, Conn., on June 23 last. According to Capt. George H. Wyatt. Col. Sloan executed a will about two years ago, and this, with considerable jewelry, is missing.

ST. JOHN, N.B., July 17 -- The steamer Pawnee, which arrived here this afternoon from New York, reported having sunk the schooner Rowland, from Parrsborough, Nova Scotia, bound here. No lives were lost. The Rowland was on her way here from Parrsborough with a cargo of coal, and the Pawnee was coming here in ballast.
VIENNA, July 17 -- The Fremdenblatt, the organ of the Foreign Office, contains a leading article to-day on "American Industrial Competition in the Near Future." It says:

Vegetables are so scarce, so far as the choicer kinds are concerned, that some dealers say there may be a famine in New York City. Fruits are almost as scarce, except the poorer grades. The demand for the best grades by out-of-town hotels and resorts, with the small crops, is the cause of the scarcity.
PITTSBURG, July 17 -- "We have not heard from the other side at any time, in any way, or on any subject since we parted at the Lincoln Hotel last Saturday."

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Major W.L. Marshall, in charge of the river and harbor work at New York City, reports that the improved channel from deep water below the Narrows to the sea by way of Sandy Hook has a depth of 30 feet at low water and a general width of 1,000 feet or more throughout its length.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., July 17 -- Noah Rabey, the centenarian who for thirty years has made his home at the Piscataway poorhouse and boasts of having lived for more than 128 years, has the measles. Although Noah enjoys fairly good health, from time to time he has been subject to slight attacks of vertigo.

Some Gold Democrats agree with Mr. BRYAN in the belief that since the Ohio Democrats were willing to vote down an indorsement of the Kansas City platform they ought to have gone further and adopted a resolution declaring for the gold standard. This is a rather taking thing to say, but it is not reasonable.

When fire broke out on the fourth floor of the five-story brick building at 81 Nassau Street last night, the wife of Policeman Timothy Cronin of the Old Slip Station rushed through Nassau Street crying hysterically for somebody to save her pet dog she had left on the roof. The Cronins occupy the top floor of the building, which is owned by E. Ferris Son, who keep a shoe store on the ground floor.

MANILA, July 17 -- Friends of the insurgent Gen. Malvar, who is still at large, have telegraphed the former insurgent leader Trias, now in Manila, that Malvar is willing to surrender to the Americans.

A return game of baseball between the nines of the West New York Field Club and Hoboken will be played next Sunday on the Weehawken grounds, when the Hoboken team will make an effort to square accounts for the game of last Sunday. Then in a hotly contested game the West New Yorks won in the tenth inning.

In an interview with a representative of The New York Sun, certain anonymous gentlemen alleged to be high officials of the New York Central Railroad deprecate our recent editorial comments on the tunnel nuisance and attempt a correction, at great length, but with a discreet avoidance of specific statement on subjects relevant to the matter.

LONDON, July 17 -- The members of the University of Pennsylvania spent to-day at Stratford-on-Avon, looking up Shakespearean relics. Ellis Ward. Reginald Hart, and A.H. Flickwer subsequently returned to London and will sail for the United States July 21 on the Vaderland. The others will remain in London to participate in the banquet to be given in their honor July 25 by the American Society.

PLYMOUTH, July 17 -- The HamburgAmerican liner Deutschland, which left New York on July 11, arrived here this morning, passing Eddystone Lighthouse at 6:21 o'clock. The Deutschland made the passage from New York in 5 days 11 hours and 5 minutes, at an average speed of 23.51 knots an hour, over a distance of 3,082 knots.
CHICAGO, Ill., July 17 -- Chicago won to-day's baseball game from New York by a score of 7 to 4.

The gambler's theory of the equality of chances was demonstrated at the Brighton Beach race track yesterday when a balance was struck between the favorites that won on the day before and the favorites that were beaten yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 17 -- The Flint Glass Workers' Convention has sent a committee to Milwaukee to discuss with the green glass bottle blowers the question of forming a union between the two organizations. The delegates here are not very confident that the plan with go through.

BOSTON, July 17 -- State Street had a fairly active market, which displayed considerable strength here and there, but trading was not particularly well distributed nor did the copper shares participate as generally as would seemingly be in order. However, to the extent that they were traded in the coppers recorded excellent gains.

ASBURY PARK, July 17 -- Over one hundred New Jersey dentists, several of them women, assembled in the beach auditorium this morning, when the thirty-first annual session of the New Jersey State Dental Society was called to order by President F. Edsall Riley of Newark. The dentists will deliberate until Friday afternoon, when new officers will be chosen.

ORANGE, N.J., July 17 -- Should plans now being discussed by the hat manufacturers of New Jersey and Connecticut prove feasible another gigantic corporation will be added to those recently organized. The plan is to form a company to control the leading hat factories of the country, nearly all of which are situated in Orange and in Danbury, Conn., with a few in Philadelphia and Newark.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 17 -- The will of the late Rev. E.P. Widdemer, formerly of this city, who died here some time ago, was offered for probate to-day. Dr. Widdemer was the father of the late Rev, Howard T. Widdemer, and left an estate valued at $25,000. Mrs. Le Baron Hartt, daughter of the testator, is named as sole legatee.

PHILADELPHIA, July 17 -- The Schuylkill River was alive this evening with racing craft, singles, doubles, fours, and eights coming and going in every direction and at every degree of pace; but all were out-of-town athletes, who took the first chance for practice and the limbering up of muscles after long railway trips.

The registry of the racing colors of Willlam K. Vanderbilt with the registrar of The Jockey Club, the body governing racing and turf affairs on the tracks in the Eastern States of the United States, yesterday gave the first intimation of the intention of Mr. Vanderbilt to engage in racing in America.

ALBANY, July 17 -- The New York Dock Company to-day filed with the Secretary of State a certificate of incorporation, the capital being $17,000,000, consisting of 170,000 shares of the par value of $100 each. Of this amount $10,000,000 is to be preferred, paying a 5 per cent, non-cumulative dividend, and the remainder common stock.

PHILADELPHIA, July 17 -- The Schuylkill River was alive this evening with racing craft, singles, doubles, fours, and eights coming and going in every direction and at every degree of pace; but all were out-of-town athletes, who took the first chance for practice and the limbering up of muscles after long railway trips.

LONDON, July 17 -- Secretary Newburn of the English Lawn Tennis Association, when interviewed to-day by a representa-- tive of The Associated Press regarding special cablegrams from the United States alleging unsportsmanlike conduct on the part or the English lawn tennis team in not coming to the United States, said:

That is a very encouraging announcement from "Washington that the Postmaster General has prepared, and is preparing to execute, a pretty drastic order limiting the amount and quality of the matter admitted to the mails as "second class." Everybody knows that the classification, as it has hitherto been made, is generous even to the regular periodicals for the benefit of which, and of the readers and subscribers of which, it was intended.
COLD SPRING, N.Y., July 17 -- Gen. Daniel Butterfield died at his home. Cragside, at 8:30 o'clock to-night. He had been ill for more than a year. He leaves a widow, but no children.

Kicked by the feet of hundreds of persons, dampened by the big drops of rain that were beginning to fall, and shuffled all over the sidewalk, a certificate of stock for 100 shares in the United States Steel Corporation lay on the walk in front of Trinity Church, just at the head of Wall Street, last evening, until it was picked up by a messenger boy.

HACKENSACK, N.J., July 17 -- The lawyers for Mrs. Elizabeth Dormer Franksen, who objects to the acceptance of the accounting of her stepmother, Mrs. Julia W.L. Donner, as executrix of the will of John O. Donner, the sugar refiner, did not know local court customs, so the hearing in the case went ovep until Oct., 2.

POUGHKEEPSIE, July 17 -- Mrs. W.I. Quintard, a widow, whose home is at 150 Central Park South, New York, was taken off the Saratoga special train on the Hudson River Railroad at this city at noon to-day and conveyed in an ambulance to the Morgan House, where a consultation of physicians was held.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Upon the state of facts given in your two recent editorials on the steel strike, viz.: that the Amalgamated Association required that the United States Steel Corporation should require the men in nonunion mills to become union men; the soundness and wisdom of your position in these two editorials must be freely admitted.

Andrew Carnegie's gift of $5,200,000 to the City of New York for the establishment of sixty-five public libraries in the five boroughs was formally accepted at a meeting of the Board of Estimate yesterday. The meeting was held for the purpose of acting on the agreement and contract, which had received the approval and signature of Mr. Carnegie.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., July 17 -- The close of the second day of the stationary firemen's strike finds fully 33,000 miners idle in the Wyoming district of the anthracite coal region, which extends from Duryea to Nanticoke. The number of idle men was increased to-day by the suspension of railroad crews on nearly all coal branches.

Henry Gray, colored, twenty-three years, an escaped convict from the Penitentiary Annex on Riker's Island, was recaptured last night by Detective Parker of the West One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street Station after a desperate battle on the roof of the house where he lives, at 303 West One Hundred and Thirty-fourth street.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 18 -- A goodsized crowd witnessed the opening events of the three days' sporting carnival of the Gentlemen's Driving and Field Club, at Elkwood Hark, this afternoon. A letter of regret was read from Gen. Nelson A. Miles, who was expected to be present. A summary of trie-events decided to-day follows:

It is reported from England that the Duke and Duchess of CORNWALL have had to abandon a splendid country estate, Houghton Hall, and leave it to the bats and owls, for the reason that their tenancy is shared by a pair of ghosts who are neither considerate nor amiable. One is the spirit of a gentleman who, some three centuries ago, was killed in an altercation with his brother.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- A preliminary statement of the Chinese population, derived from the returns of the twelfth census, was issued by Director Merriam today. It shows that there are approximately 89,800 Chinese in the United States proper, as against 107,475 in 1890. About 67,700, or 75 per cent., are contained in the Western division of States and Territories, as against 96,844, or 90 per cent., in 1890.

But for the presence of mind of two policemen, a woman and a child of three years would have been mangled under the hoofs of a team of runaway horses attached to a truck last night. The truck was loaded with hides, and was being driven along New Bowery, when the horses became frightened at the rumble of an elevated train overhead and started at a wild gallop.

Almost all the ills of flesh were represented in the crowd of pilgrims which visited the Roman Catholic Church of St. Jean Baptiste, in East Seventy-sixth Street, near Third Avenue, yesterday, where the veneration of the relic of St. Anne continued under the direction of the Fathers of the Blessed Sacrament.

In his second Princeton lecture upon the settlement of the Venezuela boundary controversy ex-President CLEVELAND said it was to be regarded as a fortunate circumstance that the treaty of arbitration, though in fact dictated by the United States, was actually negotiated between Great Britain and Venezuela, thus escaping the necessity of submitting it to the Senate at Washington, a body that has on many occasions exhibited itshostility to treaties.

CHICAGO, July 18 -- Chicago won its third game of the week to-day by defeating New York by a score of 6 to 5. The local team was the first to score, tallying in the first inning after the visitors had been blanked. Hartzel knocked a single to centre, took second on Green's sacrifice, and third on Strang's poor throw to first of Chance's grounder.
WASHINGTON, July 18 -- A. cablegram has been received by the State Department announcing the death at Gibraltar to-day of Horatio J. Sprague, United States Consul there.

BUFFALO, July 18 -- Ohio Day will go down in Pan-American records as one of the biggest days at the Exposition. Promptly at 11 o'clock Gov. Nash with his party, under escort of the Eighth Ohio Regiment, arrived at the Lincoln Parkway gate and entered the grounds on foot.

Stocks in the market for outside securities showed some gains in strength in sympathy with Stock Exchange shared, the gain in the more easily affected issues being from 1/2 to 2 points. The volume of trading however, was comparatively light.

CHICAGO, July 18 -- The Hyde Park Stake to-day produced a stunning surprise in the defeat of the colt Abe Frank, the supposedly invincible two-year-old in G.C. Bennett's stable. He was beaten by both Sir Oliver and Memnon. Sir Oliver, the winner, is a true and game running youngster, belonging to Clay Brothers.

District Attorney Philbin directed the Grand Jury yesterday to make a thorough investigation into the prevailing uncomfortable conditions in the tunnel of the New York Central Railroad, under Park Avenue, reference to which has been made frequently in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Yesterday was dull, socially, everywhere. Even at Newport there were not many entertainments. Mr. and Mrs. William K. Vanderbilt, Jr., and Mrs. James P. Kernochan have left New York and returned to Newport. Miss Leary was in town and assisted at the ceremonies at St. Jean Baptiste's Church in the morning.

LONDON, July 19 -- The War Office issued late last night a dispatch from Lord Kitchener giving the correspondence between Mr. Reitz (Transvaal State's Secretary) and Mr. Steyn (President of the Orange Free State) that was captured with the latter's baggage near Lindley, on July 11.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The Navy Department has purchased from Spain for $185,000 the big floating steel dry dock which lies in Havana harbor. The negotiations were closed by Commander Lucien Young, Captain of the Port at Havena. The price at which the dock was originally offered by the Spanish Government was $250,000. It is stated by the chief naval constructor that the dock has been in constant use.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 18 -- Kansas City's whipping Justice, George L. Walls, to-day ordered twenty lashes to be applied to Nellie Thomas, a young girl whom he found guilty of petty thievery. This wax the first instance of a female being publicly whipped under the direction of the court.

CINCINNATI, July 18 -- Nat Emerson, the Ohio State tennis champion, twice winner of the State Cup, went down to defeat before the playing of R.D. Little of Princeton to-day in the tri-State tournament.

LONDON, July 19 -- Earl Russell, arraigned before the House of Lords yesterday morning for trial on the charge of bigamy, pleaded guilty after lengthy arguments for and against the jurisdiction of the Court, and was sentenced to three months' imprisonment as a first-class misdemeanant.

RICHMOND, Va., July 18 -- The feature of the Virginia Constitutional Convention proceedings to-day was the prayer, delivered, by the Rev. George H. Spooner of Trinity Methodist Church. When he alluded to the proposition to expunge from the Bill of Rights the words "Christian, charity," he used this language:

To the Editor of The New York Times: I beg to call your attention to one or two inaccuracies in your editorial of the 12th inst. concerning Judge Giegerich's conduct of the trial in the case of Mowbray vs. Gould, and the decision of the Appellate Division in the same case on appeal.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 18 -- With the jury impaneled and having been taken to the scene of the tragedy, the testimony of one witness concluded, and that of another well under way, and with the fatal bullet and the blood-stained nightrobe of the victim offered as evidence, the Government's case against Robert S. Fosburgh, charged with the shooting and killing of his sister.

MAGNOLIA, Mass., July 18 -- The feature of the tennis tournament was the strong playing of J.P. Paret, who won both his matches without apparent effort. Good weather and the fine condition of the courts added greatly to the interest of the spectators.
BAR HARBOR, Me., July 18 -- William C. Whitney left here to-night for Boston; and will, it is said, sail for Europe the first of next week. He has said that he will return in August.

There was an interesting mix-up of the identities of two prisoners named Smith in Recorder Goff's Court of General Sessions yesterday. Both Smiths were named John, and both were indicted for grand larceny in the second degree. The two were arraigned in a long line of prisoners to plead to the indictments against them.

NEWARK, N.J., July 18 -- Vice Chancellor Emery has granted a rule to show cause why a receiver should not be appointed for the Meyer Mercy Manufacturing Company, which has the largest hat factory here. The application was made in behalf of Meyer Mercy, President of the company.

A distinguished-looking man of middle age. wearing the garb of a Roman Catnolio priest, was arrested last night by Detectives Bernstein and McClusky of the Elizabeth Street Station, charged with impersonating a clergyman and collecting money under false pretenses.

An infernal machine, sent through the mails to John J. Kiatchka, exploded in the offices of the Brooklyn branch of the Board of Public improvements yesterday morning. It missed the man for whom it was intended, but blew the left hand off Edgar Schroeder, sixty-five years old, a fellow employe, who had offered to open the package.

May L. Fosburgh, eighteen years old, the daughter of Robert L. Fosburgh, a contractor, was shot some time before 1:30 o'clock on the morning of Aug. 20, 1900. At that hour the fire alarm whistle of the town began to blow, and it was found that the summons came from a box situated near the Fosburgh residence.

Judge Warren W. Foster, who recently granted a motion in General Sessions to transfer to the latter court from Special Sessions a number of cases of violations of the excise law, was criticised by Assistant District Attorney Le Barbier before Justice Blanchard yesterday.

From The Rochester Post-Express. Mr. Soldam, the Superintendent of Public Schools in St. Louis, gave a fair definition of an educational fad at the meeting of the National Educational Association in Detroit. "Anything on which stress is laid in excess of its real educational value and which for a time is overestimated," he says," is a fad.

HAMPTON, Va., July 18 -- At its second day's session here the Hampton Negro Conference devoted a large share of the morning to a discussion of disfranchisement and education. The views expressed on disfranchisement were moderate and carofully considered, and although there were arguments on both sides, yet the greneral sentiment seemed not unfavorable to a restriction of the ballot, so long as it was impartial and applied equally to all classes and races.

Sergt. Reinals was taking things leisurely in the Brownsville, Brooklyn, Police Station late last night, when an elderly German tottered into the room. "Sergeant, I wish you'd shoot me and put me out of my misery," said he. " I'm hungry and homeless, and I've just spent my last nickel in buying carbolic acid, and I haven't got nerve enough to take it."

To the Editor of The New York Times: In the belief that a wide range of discussion may possibly do some good and cannot do any harm, I desire to submit some considerations on the subject of "The Law's Delay." There is a great deal more in Mr. Rosenthal's letter than it is generally being given credit for, though his suggestions are not altogether practicable.

The principal grievance stated in President SHAFFER'S bill of complaint against the steel companies is this: "We simply ask that the three companies -- the Sheet Steel, Tin Plate, and Steel Hoop -- sign the scale for all mills, whether non-union or union, thus preventing discrimination in favor of the non-union plants during dull times."
OSCAR HOLLOWAY of Augusta, Me., for many years a Director in the First National Bank of that city, and its President since 1892, died yesterday.

The worst tie-up that has been experienced by the Metropolitan Street Railway Company occurred during the busy hours yesterday. From ten o'clock in the morning until three in the afternoon cars on the Second, Third, and Madison Avenue lines were practically at a standstill below Broome street.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Believing that many public abuses are righted by means of the press, and also believing with Mark Twain that the American public puts up with many annoyances needlessly, I herewith protest vigorously against the rudeness of the employes of the Metropolitan Art Museum.

PHILADELPHIA, July 18 -- All the amateur oarsmen of the United States and Canada who are entered for the several events in the National regatta, to be held on the Schuylkill River to-morrow and Saturday, are now on the scene of the coming contests. Nothing remains to be done in the way of preparing for the races, and all the contestants have completed their training.

POUGHKEEPSIE, July 18 -- George Marshall of New York, who was arrested in this city for stealing rides on cars, was arraigned before Recorder Morschauser this morning, and told the Court to write to Senator Timothy D. Sullivan for reference. When Marshall was araigned the Recorder said:

Some rare batting was done in the cricket match played at Bergen Point yesterday between the Knickerbocker Athletic Club and Brooklyn. The home team ran up a total of 189 for six wickets before it declared its innings closed, and Tyers, the professional, had the distinction of adding an even century to the long list of big scores he has made in his day.

-- The automobile, like the worm, if trod upon will turn and sting. It is as yet a young and tender thing, and it is extremely sensitive. It cannot bear slight. Furthermore, it has from its first appearance in this world of travel been the particular pet of select sbciety. It was admitted to the smart set instantly, and its position as a social leader was established very early.

MANILA, July 18 -- An act has been passed organizing the insular constabulary. A provision has been incorporated in the act empowering the chief of the system and either of the four district assistants to temporarily consolidate constabularies of two or more provinces, in cases of necessity.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., July 18 -- The Stanton mine of the Lehigh and Wilkesbarre Coal Company was saved from damage by fire this morning by one of the most daring acts on record in the coal regions. A bolt of lightning yesterday afternoon fired the timbers in the airshaft. The blaze was not discovered until midnight, when sparks were seen coming from the head of the shaft.

YONKERS, N.Y., July 18 -- Alderman John Southwick, who has figured in the newspapers many times since he won fame by his defense of the American flag up in Canada when it was insulted by a party of Canadians, is once more under the limelight. He married and made a political shift all in one day.

PITTSBURG, July 18 -- Most important of all news regarding the steel workers' strike, that reached Pittsburg to-day, was the action of the men employed in the Duncansville plant of the American Steel Hoop Company. A telegram was received by President Shaffer from the men in the morning, asking if they should strike.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., July 18 -- The coal operators and the striking stationary engineers of the Wyoming Valley take opposite views of the action of the Executive Committee of the United Mine Workers which met in Scranton to-day. The committee decided that all firemen who are members of the United Mine Workers' organization must return to work.

DETROIT, Mich., July 18 -- Cresceus, the chestnut stallion owned and driven by George H. Ketcham of Toledo, won the free-for-all trot on the Detroit Driving Club's track, at Grosse Pointe, this afternoon, and incidentally trotted the fastest heat and won the fastest race record ever made.

From The Baltimore Sun. "I think probably the most entertaining experience we had in Tokio," said Miss Lillian Giffin, 1,004 North Charles Street. not long since, in speaking of her travels in Japan," was a Japanese dinner.

BALTIMORE, July 18 -- The market today made a slight improvement in the matter of activity, with an upward tendency in price. The early strength of New York infused itself immediately into the Seaboard, group, the stocks and bonds of which all advanced. The best figures of the day, however, were not well held; the stocks fell to figures attained Wednesday, and the 4 per cent, bonds closed only a little higher.

Particulars of dividends declared by the St. Louis and San Francisco Railway Company, the Montana Ore Purchasing Company, the Corn Exchange Bank, the German-American Bank, and the Procter. Gamble Company will be found in the advertisement columns.

CHICAGO, July 18 -- Twenty-three Roman Catholic priests, pastors of churches in the Archdiocese of Chicago, have gone on record as opposing the Archbishop, Patrick A. Peehan, in his selection of Father P.J. Muldoon as Auxiliary Bishop. They have voiced their objections in a formal protest, which was sent to Rome, asking that the appointment of the young pastor be nullified. As a result Archbishop Feehan may suspend them all.

The will of Pierre Lorillard, Sr., was yesterday admitted to probate at Trenton, N. J. This formality by no means indicates that there will be no contest of the provisions of the will, or that a settlement has been effected with Mrs. Lillian B. Allien, to whom Mr. Lorillard bequeathed Rancocas.

LONDON, July 18 -- Money was in more plentiful demand to-day and easier. Business on the Stock Exchange opened with a more cheerful tone, prices moving up in several directions owing to the cessation of Continental selling. The Settlement was easier than anticipated, and there was a renewed disposition to purchase.

The worship of jockeys was strongly in evidence at the Brighton Beach Race Track yesterday. The worshippers were divided among several riders, however, and while the talk of racegoers seemed to be exclusively of Shaw, Spencer, Burns, Michaels, and O'Connor, it is extremely doubtful if the followers of any one of the popular riders finished the afternoon with a profit on his betting.

PHILADELPHIA, July 18 -- Fourth Vice President Samuel Rea of the Pennsylvania Railroad to-day refused to discuss his appointment to the directorate of the Northern Pacific Road. It was, however, officially stated at the general offices of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company that the selection of Mr. Rea did not mean that the Pennsylvania Road had any financial interests in the Western trunk line.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 18 -- Wagner lost to-day's baseball game with Brooklyn in the eighth inning by making a wild throw on Keeler's little hit to third, scoring Kelley from first and putting Keeler on third. Sheckard's hit then scored Keeler. This was the only feature of the game. The score:

BRISTOL, R.I., July 18 -- After good progress yesterday the Constitution's crew resumed work to-day on the underbody plates of the yacht, scraping and oiling them with a vigor which promised to have the boat ready to slide from the marine railway into the water by to-morrow morning.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- In the opinion of authorities on diplomatic matters there is more than meets the eye in the interview given out in London last night by Lord Pauncefote, on the subject of a Nicaraguan Canal treaty. The British Ambassador, as is very well known in Washington, is not given to idle talk.

Eugene C. Griffith of Pascoag, R.I., the amateur trap shooter who won the Grand American Handicap at 100 live birds at Inter-State Park last April, duplicated that achievement yesterday at the same place by winning the Grand American Handicap at 100 clay targets from a field of seventy-five competitors, with a score of 95 out of a possible 100 breaks.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The State Department is in receipt of interesting reports concerning the wheat crops of Russia and India. According to a report from Consul General Holloway at St. Petersburg, there are good reasons to hope that the wheat harvest of 1901 will oxceed that of 1900.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Henry W. Diederich, the American Consul at Bremen, Germany, has made a report to the State Department that shows the trades of Germany to be in very bad condition. In his report, among other things, he writes:

Twenty-five cents additional is rquired for each $500 of consideration over $:3,000.

CINCINNATI, July 18 -- J.A. Parker, Chairman of the People's Party National Committee, has issued a call for a conference of Ohio Populists and all those who favor the amalgamation of independent reform forces into an allied third party, to meet in Columbus, July 30, to place a State ticket in the field.

Recent reports from Washington are to the effect that the Administration is approaching, if it has not already attained, an understanding with the authorities of the Roman Catholic Church for do-operation in the settlement of the problem of the friars in the Philippines. It is very desirable that such an understanding, if of the proper sort, should be reached.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., July 18 -- Dr. Edward S. Brush was to-night nominated for Mayor by the Republican City Convention. His opponent will be Mayor Edwin S. Fiske, who is now gery his third term, and who will seek a fourth. Dr. Brush was the first Mayor this city ever had.
BERLIN, July 18 -- A Director of one of the best-known private banks of Berlin, in an interview to-day, said:

In connection with the publication on Wednesday of the letter of J. Plerpont Morgan to the various factions interested in Northern Pacific affairs, the report was revived that President Mellen of that railway would resign and that he would be succeeded by Col. Lamont, now Vice President of the road.

LONDON, July 18 -- In a foursome to-day on the links of the North Berwick (Scotland) New Golf Club, Miss Frances C. Griscom of Philadelphia, holder of the women's National championship of the United States, and Ben Sayres, the professional, beat Messrs. Bettle and Hinkle of Philadelphia by 4 up and 3 to play.

JOHANNESBURG, July 18 -- In the course of an inquiry conducted under oath here to-day various British non-commissioned officers and men confirmed the statement that the Boers shot the British wounded at Vlakfontein.
NEWPORT, July 18 -- Charles C. Waters of the Belgian Legation has taken apartments here for the season.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 18 -- The fifth international Epworth League convention opened to-day. Long before the hour fixed for the preliminary proceedings Mechanics' Pavilion, which will accommodate 15,000 persons, was practically filled. The first services connected with the convention were held this morning in the First Congregational, the Central Methodist, and the Howard Street Churches, in each of which communion was celebrated.

PHILADELPHIA, July 18 -- The better feeling inspired by the buoyant opening in New York tended to lift prices here, hut Wall Street's later recessions were responded to quickly, and only the local stocks maintained their gains. The anthracite stocks showed evidence of uneasiness over labor troubles.

We publish in another column this morning a letter from an engineer in a position to be well informed in the matter, conveying a suggestion as to the possible action of the Governor and the State Board of Health in relation to the nuisance maintained by the New York Central and Hudson River Railroad in their tunnel in this city.
BALTIMORE, July 19. -- Gen. Felix Agnus has written a letter to President McKinley, in which he says:

Those familiar with the political, social, and economic conditions existing in Germany will find no cause for surprise in the official reports from that country of industrial paralysis and commercial stagnation. It has been evident since 1898 that Germany was attempting to do more business than her capital justified.

Developments in the Union Pacific-Northern Pacific harmony plans continued to be keenly watched by financial and railroad men yesterday. The interest centred in a visit which Jacob H. Schiff of Kuhn, Loeb Co. paid to J. Pierpont Morgan shortly before noon. The conference between the two financiers did not last more than ten minutes, and at its conclusion they both declined to say anything about it.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 19. -- The body of George Rogers Wilson, the Consolidated Exchange broker who mysteriously disappeared from this place on Sunday night last, was found this morning in the sound at Larchmont Harbor, about a quarter of a mile from the spot where the hat and coat of Mr. Wilson were discovered on Monday morning lying on a rock.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 19. -- The trotting and running events at Elkwood Park this afternoon, under the auspices of the Gentlemen's Driving Club of Monmouth County, drew a large attendance, and the trotting races were especially fine. Two light showers and an accident in the free-for-all event threatened the success of the day's racing, but notwithstanding the programme was completed in satisfactory style.

LONDON, July 20. -- Terrific thunderstorms over the northern parts of England last evening presaged a break-up of the heat wave. At Nawcastle-on-Tyne the streets were flooded, and traffic of all kinds was temporarily suspended. The railway signal system was disarranged, the instruments burning out; in consequence trains were delayed.

If Lawyer John P. Donnelly of Bedford Avenue and Grand Street, Brooklyn, carries out intentions which he expressed yesterday afternoon there may be startling developments when the case of "Nick" Middleton, a bartender in the employ of "Mike" Minden, the well-known bookmaker, and the cases of William Ray and Thomas Colton are called in the Lee Avenue Police Court, Brooklyn, next Thursday.

The hearing of the contest of the will of Mrs. Edna C. McPherson, widow of United States Senator John R. McPherson, by their daughter, Mrs. Edia J. Muir, was resumed before Judge John A. Blair in the Orphans' Court at Jersey City yesterday. Mrs. Muir was present, but took no part in the proceedings, not having been called as a witness.

The old-time shibboleth of the Sand Lots, "the Chinese must go." has ceased to be of interest by reason of the fact that the Chinese are going. A preliminary statement from the Director of the Census shows that since 1890 the number of Chinese in the United States has declined from 107,000 to less than 90,000.

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- Concerning President McKinley's pardon of bank wreckers, a statement was made to-day by James S. Easby-Smith, the attorney in charge of pardons in the Department of Justice. It has been asserted that the President pardoned thirty-five bank wreckers during his first term, and of this Mr. Easby-Smith said:

The Catholic Missionary Union has for several years supported missionaries to non-Catholics in parts of the United States where Catholics are too few to support diocesan missionary bands, and while the work was at first experimental, it has now reached a stage where the results are very encouraging.

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- The Secretary of the Navy has decided that the third volume of Edgar S. Maclay's "History of the Navy," shall not be used as a text book at the Naval Academy unless the obnoxious language it contains in speaking of Rear Admiral Schley is eliminated.

CHICAGO, July 19. -- Corn led the markets in strength and activity to-day, closing with an advance of 1 3/4c. for September on the weather and crop conditions. Wheat was helped by cables and export sales, the close being 7/8c. higher for September. September oats closed 1 1/4@1 3/8c. up.

A great part of the speculative and investment public of Wall Street was very much mystified and disturbed yesterday morning when at 10 o'clock! the hour for opening of the stock market, the tickers of the New York Quotation Company, which furnishes quotations to many brokers' offices, stood still for the first thirteen minutes of business, not giving a single quotation.

Mr. Clute accomplishes the aim of his work, in assisting the student of fern lore first to know the names of ferns and then the details which are seldom found in textbooks regarding their varieties, haunts, and identity. Not only is the book valuable to beginners but as a reference book for those advanced, containing, as it does, almost 200 pictures of specimens, their haunts, and peculiarities for identification.

To The New York Times Saturday Review. In your review of Dr. Curry's "Account of the Civil History of the Confederacy" you say "all of the last section of the work is devoted to what the author has tried to show is a legal justification of the South in secession." You add that his line of argument is interesting and ingenuous, but not invariably convincing.

NEW HAVEN, July 19. -- The tug Gertrude brought into New Haven Harbor this morning the two survivors of a yachting party of seven and news of the worst yachting fatality that Long Island Sound has known in years.

Two interesting papers on the Quakers, "An Old Diary," by Logan Pearson Smith, and "Recollections of a Quaker Boy," by Roland E. Robinson, appear in the current Atlantic. Ann Whitall, whose diary was recently discovered among the papers of a Philadelphia, family, was by birth a Cooper, belonging to the family from which Fenimore Cooper sprang.

Although a Flamand by birth, no Parisian was ever more thoroughly imbued with the quintessence of "Parisianism" than the late Alfred Stevens. For him the whole horizon of art was within the bounds of the city in which he found both his inspiration and his audience.

The Free Public Library of Newark, N. J., of which Mr. Frank P. Hill has long been the head librarian, but who has been secured for Brooklyn, has just published the second issue of its new series of Finding Lists," that of "History, Travel, and Description." No. 1 of such lists, devoted to fiction, classified under title and author, was issued last year.

The Kemp Building, at the northeast corner of Cedar and William Streets, has been sold by the New York Realty Corporation for about $750,000. The property has been bought by a company now in process of organization, to be known as "No. 68 William Street," which will erect on the site a fifteen-story modern office building.

LONDON, July 19. -- The Duke of Marlborough is about to appear in a new role. There will be held at Blenheim Palace, on Aug. 10, one of the largest political demonstrations of recent times. Its object is to celebrate the third Unionist victory in the by-elections. Three thousand delegates from Conservative and Liberal Unionist associations throughout the country will be present, and the gathering will number in all about 7,000.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: Readers of fiction owe a debt of gratitude to THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW for establishing the practice of honest reviews by critics who are held to the duty of actually reading the novels which they express their opinions about.

The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is reqmired for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., July 19. -- The Corporation Counsel has rendered a decision that the appropriation of $20,000 for the purchase of a site for the fifty-thousand-dollar library building which Andrew Carnegie has donated for this city, was made illegally and improperly. The members of the Board of Education, which was to select a site, could not agree.

To The Editor of The New York Times: I read with interest and profit your editorial of the 12th relative to the MowbrayGould decision, feeling that it might well serve as a model for those editors who would like to, but dare not, criticise a judicial decision. It was, I thought, an excellent example of when and how to deal with such a subject.

A little volume from the pen of Elizabeth Upham offers an interesting description of the aims of the International Sunshine Society, told in the form of a brief story, which is more or less suggested by the following verses, which mark a dedication of the volume to the President of the society, Cynthia Westover Alden:

"The International Year Book" for 1900, while in every way as excellent as its predecessors of 1899 and 1808 as regards clearness of text and number and quality of Illustrations, shows in many ways the practicable development of the idea in which evidently the enterprise first had its being. The year 1900 was more than usually crammed with international events and movements of both wide and particular interest.

CHICAGO, July 19. -- The Chicago Club Won to-day by a score of 5 to 2, and had no trouble in hitting Mathewson's delivery. Taylor on the other hand, pitched a good game. The New Yorks made ten safe hits, but three of these came in the final inning, when the game seemed safe.

The franchises of the Union Ferry Company to operate five ferries across the East River were offered for sale yesterday. This is the second time these franchises have been put up for sale, but owing to a controversy between the city officials and the company, no bid was offered.

The police of the Adams Street Station, Brooklyn, were busy all day yesterday trying to solve the puzzle of the mysterious bomb which was sent through the mails to John J. Klatchka, an employe in the Brooklyn Branch of the Board of Public Improvements, and which exploded, tearing the hand off Edgar Schroeder, one of Klatchka's colleagues.

To The New York Times Saturday Review. Referring to the Baconian theory of the authorship of Shakespeare's playa -- as to which you have lately admitted several letters -- will you allow me to say that while I most emphatically prefer to remain with the Shakespearean majority myself. I am obliged to recognize it as a literary question, and not only a literary question, but a moat interesting one.

The names of Boer and Fillipino have been often linked together in the appeals of the anti-imperialists of England and the United States. Two small nationalities hopelessly struggling against two of the greatest powers presented to the view of the sympathetic a likeness of condition too obvious to be missed.

PHILADELPHIA, July 18. -- John Trotwood Moore of Columbia, Tenn., has broken away from the present-day historical story, without turning to the problem novel, and the result is a story or nature. Henry T. Coates of this city has issued the book in cool green and white covers, with type as clear as a June sky.

The Scene of "God's Puppets." Charles Scribner's Sons have published a map of old New York as the town was when the scenes of Imogen Clark's novel were supposed to take place. Those familiar with the lower end of New York are interested in tracing the plot through the maze of streets now covering what then was practically the whole of the early Dutch town.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 19. -- The strike situation to-night cannot be termed materially changed, although many rumors are in the air to the effect that a settlement of the troubles is imminent. President Shaffer of the Amalgamated Association says the workers have gained steadily while the manufacturers have lost continually since last Monday.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, N.Y., July 19. -- Robert Folger Westcott, organizer and ex-President of the Westcott Express Company, was instantly killed this morning while driving on Rum Hill, six miles from his Summer home. Mr. Westcott had gone for a drive to the Observatory with his niece, Miss Gardiner.

IN English poetry the ocean long awaited its lover. The Anglo-Saxons were not unmoved, but it was with a shudder: its grim, tragic side was ever before them, "rough billows," "wind from the north," "a war of waves" -- they were full of the dread "water fear."

The work of the Cranbrook Press is steadily increasing in the excellence of its mechanical details. Its latest issue. Tyndale's version of "The Revelacion off Sanct Jhon the Devine" is the most ambitious work the press has put forth. The book, which contains a page 11 by 8 1/2 inches in size, is printed on a fine handmade paper, bearing the Cranbrook water mark.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 19. -- The trial of Robert S. Fosburgh for manslaughter dragged along slowly to-day and developed but two startling features, while from a review of the testimony it cannot be said that the Government has made any real progress toward demonstrating the fact that Fosburgh killed his sister, May, on Aug. 20, and that her slayer was not one of three burglars, as he contended.

WAUKESHA, Wis., July 17. -- The twenty-third annual meeting of the American Library Association which has closed here has been the largest and one of the most notable in the history of the association. The attendance was over 450, and included delegations from the extreme East, West, and South.

Richard Drayton, a colored porter employed by the tailoring firm of Burnham Phillips, 119 Nassau Street, attempted to murder Manly A. Burnham, the senior member of the firm, yesterday by cutting his thoat with a razor.

Up and down and around the mast were the zephyrs at the Larchmont Yacht Club's regatta yesterday. The Regatta Committee boarded the tug C.P. Raymond, and were prepared to start the race at 11:30 o'clock, as arranged, but not a suspicion of a breeze was on hand to gladden the hearts of the waiting skippers, who puckered their lips and whistled every air in their nautical repertory in vain.

As a change from the regulation cheap selling and maiden races, the contest for the Islip Handicap at the Brighton Beach race track yesterday was warmly welcomed by the crowd, and the result excited something like genuine enthusiasm, as a spectacular contest ended with a victory by the popular horse Blues for the Fleischmann stable.

The Rev. Philip Cardella, S.J., who had served his order in many countries, died at St. Vincent's Hospital on Wednesday last from paralysis. Father Cardella had been Archbishop Corrigan's confessor. Father Cardella came to New York City about twenty years ago. He was well known among the priests of the city.

An apparently well-informed correspondent writes in another column on the action of the National Educational Association in the matter of a National University at Washington, at their recent annual meeting in Detroit.

BOSTON, July 19. -- To-day's market took an erratic course -- a weak start, a burst of strength, an interval of light trading, and then a bad break, with a feeble rally, just at the close. Union Pacific had a range of over 5 points for the day -- from 108 1/4 in the morning to 103 1/8 just at the close.

John W. Bookwalter of Ohio, after a unique trip through Great Britain and Europe, was a passenger on the steamship Columbia, which arrived last evening in this port after a most unpleasant voyage for this season of the year. Among other things, he had a two-thousand-mile bicycle trip, and, to use the vernacular of athletes, his flesh is "as hard as nails."

Polo for Juniors was inaugurated yesterday at the Rockaway Hunting Club, being the third annual competition for the Junior Cup presented as an encouragement to the young element by William A. Hazard. The tournament is open to boys under the age of twenty-one years, and five teams of Rockaway lads have entered for the trophy this season, as against three last year.

NEWPORT, July 19. -- More dinners were given this evening than on any other previous evening this season. Those entertaining were Mrs. Elisha Dyer. Jr., Mrs. Taylor Campbell, Mrs. Edwin Parsons, Mrs. George L. Rives, Mrs. George B. De Forest, Mrs. Charles F. Hoffman, Jr., Miss Josephine Johnson, Mrs. William E. Carter, Mrs. Lewis Cass Ledyard, and W.G. Roelker.

To The New York Times Saturday Review. As a work of literature, to be read in the closet, Shakespeare's plays commend themselves for their complete mastery of human life as no other work does. They are literature, though, of the Homeric school, not of the Virgilian. They lack the learning of the schools, make errors no scholar would make, use English no scholar would use, and look on life through no learned spectacles.

LONDON, July 19. -- Lord Rosebury's four-year-old brown colt Epsom Lad, by Ladas-Disorder, ridden by the South American jockey, Gomez, won the fourteenth renewal of the Eclipse Stakes of L 10,000, for three and four year olds, at one mile and a quarter, at the opening to-day of the Sandown Park second Summer meeting.

PHILADELPHIA, July 19 -- Oarsmen from every rowing centre in the United States and Canada combined to the successful opening of the twenty-ninth annual regatta of the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen of America on the Schuylkill River here to-day. Heavy rainladen clouds greeted the athletes when the races began.

The recent sale in London of the autograph collection of the late Townley Green included a letter of Coleridge which had a striking and important reference to Wordsworth's "Peter Bell.'' The collection was inherited by Mr. Green from his aunt, Miss Charlotte Reynolds, sister of John Hamilton Reynolds, sister-in-law of Tom Hood, and a friend of John Keats, and the letter had, therefore, an illustrious pedigree.

The end of the week always brings house parties and a general scattering of those who are in town. This week will see a great many going to the country. In the neighborhood there are dances at all of the casinos and country clubs. The Meadow Brook Club, at Southampton, had its dinner and dance last night.

Cornelius Vanderbilt, it is expected, will shortly enlist in the Twelfth Regiment, N.G.N.Y., and be elected immediately Second Lieutenant. In the past few weeks he has made many visits to the regiment's armory at Columbus Avenue and Sixty-second Street, and has been doing some hard studying in military matters.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: In THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW of July 13 I find an exceedingly witty and sarcastic communication signed "L. W. Kingman," setting forth that gentleman's views in regard to the authenticity of any existing copy of The Boston Gazette under date of March 12, 1770.
LONDON, July 19. -- Miss Eleanor A. Ormerod, the well-known entomologist, who had been ill for some time past, died at St. Albans, Hertford, to-day.

John Downey, for more than a quarter of a century master builder for the Astors, and who also conducted some huge building operations on his own account, died yesterday of apoplexy during the absence of his family at their Summer home at New Canaan, Conn. He was about seventy years old, and a native of Ireland, and the architect of his own fortune, which was so large that he was rated as a millionaire.

To The New York Times Saturday Review. There has been a great deal written in the last year or two concerning the efficacy of book reviews in the newspapers, but I have seen nothing on the question from the viewpoint of the newspaper reviewer. When you come right down to the point the newspaper review, whether it is eulogistic or the reverse, is an advertisement.

MUCH of Western Massachusetts adjacent to Williamstown may fairly be called Bryant's country, for his name is as closely associated with it as with old Greylock and many other mountain peaks of the Berkshires.

IN THE Beacon Biographies, the latest issue is a sketch of Ralph Waldo Emerson, which should have peculiar interest as the work of one of the last of the Concord group, Frank B. Sanborn, who knew "early, gradually, and intimately," not only Emerson the writer, but the man, whose Concord friendships and affiliations were among the strongest interests of his life.

To The New York Times Saturday Review. Lists of the best books in general literature by many hands are common; for instance, those by Sir John Lubbock in his "Pleasures of Life" and of Mr. Clement Shorter, which appeared in The Bookman of December, 1897, not to mention those of various libraries and others throughout the world.

Mrs. Nellie McGrann, the wife of Matthew McGrann, a watchman employed by the Department of Highways, was found dead, shot through the mouth, in her home on the second floor of 429 East Seventy-first Street, shortly after 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: We know that there are many persons that want and need a library of reference that have experienced the present lack of such facilities here. While circulating libraries may be very good for a community, a reference library properly equipped is much better in a large city.

Long Island City was the scene of a poolroom raid yesterday which has caused the gambling fraternity more real alarm than all the activity of the Committee of Fifteen and other reform bodies, and has precipitated a bitter fight between the "syndicate" and the "independents." The raid was made on a recently fitted-up poolroom in Patrick J. Gleason's old barn on Third Street, near Front, one block from the Long Island Railway Station.

SIR MARTIN CONWAY the author of this very entertaining book of travel called "Climbing and Exploration in the Bolivian Andes," is already well known as a courageous and successful climber of mountains in many parts of the world.

For the last two nights a young man claiming to be a member of one of the greatest families of France has occupied a jail cell in this city, accused by an agent of the Charity Organization Society of being a swindler. The young man gave his name to the police as Leon N. d'Este, but refused to say what family it was to which he claimed connection, adding:

ORANGE, N.J., July 19. -- The will of Oliver S. Carter of West Orange was offered for probate to-day. Mr. Carter was President of the Bank of the Republic, New York, and head of the house of Carter, Macy Co. of New York. The estate is a large one, and is divided among Mr. Carter's immediate relatives, there being no charitable or public bequests.
C.L. Crane Co. have been appointed St. Louis agents of the German American Insurance Company.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., July 19. -- The end of the strike of the machinists of the Lehigh Valley and the Central Railroad of New Jersey is in sight. The Lehigh Valley men met this afternoon, and the failures of the committees to induce the firemen, conductors, and trainmen to strike in sympathy were discussed.

LONDON, July 6. -- The Candid Friend, Mr. Frank Harris's new weekly after having accomplished the difficult feat of surviving its first number, has become, week by week, more entertaining and impertinent.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Permit one who has practiced continuously in bankruptcy since the present act became operative to indorse in toto most heartily the statements contained in your editorial of the I6th with reference to the candidacy of George C. Holt for the position of United States District Judge.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 19. -- Probably the biggest mortgage ever filed in the County Clerk's Office was handed over the counter to Deputy Clerk Cochrane last evening. The mortgage is executed by the Buffalo, Niagara Falls and Rochester Railway, and is for $3,500,000. It covers the entire trangible assets of the road.
W.D. Howells gives a delightful and intimate picture of the late John Fiske in the current number of Harper's Weekly. He says:

A NOVELETTE by Richard Hording Davis will be one of the features of the August Scribner. A certain interest is added to this announcement when it is recalled that about a year and a half have elapsed since the publication of a story by this author.

Elsewhere in this issue we print a report, received from a prominent librarian in the Middle West, of the recent annual meeting of the American Library Association, in Waukesha. Many readers will doubtless need to be told where Waukesha may be. It lies in Wisconsin, not far from Madison, nor far from Milwaukee, where it is known as perhaps the most delightful Summer resort in that part of the country.
LONDON, July 20. -- The Earl of Rosebery delivered an important speech at the City Liberal Club yesterday afternoon.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 19. -- W. Clayton Pickersgill, H.B.M. Consul General here, died to-day at a sanitarium in Alameda, to which he was conveyed last Sunday from his Summer residence in the Santa Cruz Mountains.

To The New York Times Saturday Review. There are thousands who glance with sorrow at the shelf in their book cases containing the volumes on American History written by John Fiske. The palace of Aladdin had only one unfinished window, but in the palace of John Fiske's wonderful mind who would venture to tell how many windows stand waiting the hand of the magician that will work no more.

PHILADELPHIA, July 19. -- There was a slight improvement in the Philadelphia stock market to-day. Asphalt bonds showed the greatest improvement, the first lives passing 57 and the seconds reaching 43 1/2. The trading was exceptionally large for this market, over $250,000 changing hands.

LONDON, July 19. -- Money had an easier tendency to-day on enhanced supplies, which enabled loans to be repaid to the Bank of England, and owing to the troublesome settlement passing unaccompanied by any important fallures.

MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., July 19. -- George Gilbert, the ticket agent of the railroad station at Hainesport, had a lively experience with two highwaymen last night. He was on his way home about midnight and was carrying the day's receipts in a bag, when a man grabbed at the bag containing the money.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: Seldom have I read of an experience so entirely in accordance with my own as that in "Elizabeth and Her German Garden," whose friends insist that, when she so stoutly declares that she finds so much happiness in her country home, she is merely defending her husband for keeping her there.

LONDON, July 19. -- D. Sidney Appleton, who arrived here late in June to take charge of the London branch of D. Appleton Co., has arranged with Gilbert Parker for the publication in New York next Winter of Parker's newest novel, entitled "Dick Donovan."

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- Judge Bradley to-day issued an order committing to St. Elizabeth Asylum Mrs. Catherine Clapp, wife of Robert Woodbridge Clapp, who recently made some trouble in New York hotels. Mrs. Clapp was brought to Washington by her husband, but she left the house one night and went to the Pennsylvania Railroad station, where she asked the employes to send some telegrams for her.

The present volume comprises twelve essays and lectures, most of which have appeared in various English periodicals during the last fifteen years. About half of them are on Max Muller's favorite subject of the "Science of Language." They are edited by his son. W.G. Max Muller, who promises a second series on the "Science of Religion," to appear in the Autumn of this year.

FEW lovers, of the man and his books will ever be able to visit Stevenson's grave in faraway Samoa; hence they will be interested in Miss Robertson's account of her pilgrimage to "that lonely grave, sacred to Scotchmen all the world over, which thousands have pictured in fancy and so few have ever seen," as contained in a recent English paper.

To The New York Times Saturday Review. There is no law against publishing books without suitable indexes, though public protest and indignation have been shown upon innumerable occasions. Yet what is the good of all this indignation and of all the protests? Writers and publishers continue to sin against that which is best and most desirable in the judgment of the rending public.

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- Well-informed officials of the War Department are beginning to have grave doubts as to the ultimate conviction of Charles F.W. Neely charged with embezzling postal funds of Cuba. It is doubtful even if he will be brought to trial. Many questions of jurisdiction, involving difficult points of law, have arisen, and new ones come up every day.

This little book is the more or less desultory account -- logbook, the author himself calls it -- of the adventures of an American war correspondent in South Africa. It does not pretend to military or historical importance, but the author's personal opinions and impressions are modestly stated and have the interest of an unbiased point of view.

VERY easy is it to write for the magazines. The trouble is to get the editors to accept what you write. And, having accepted it, to print it. And, it -- having printed it, to pay for it -- although this last is said merely to show how easy it is to be spiteful at the expense of truth.

It developed yesterday that the oil-laden full-rigged ship Commodore T.H.
