Robes and insignia will be much in evidence, and all kinds of ceremonial observances will be made a part of what promises to be a very interesting, if somewhat tiresome, programme.

VINELAND, N.J., July 20 -- During a heavy electrical storm last nignt four buildings were struck and several of the occupants injured by lightning, and Mrs. Sarah Pierson's house was set on fire and completely ruined.
PHILADELPHIA, Penn., July 20 -- Canada's sturdy oarsmen carried off the bulk of the honor on the Schuylkill River here to-day at the annual regatta of the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen.

RICHMOND, Va., July 20 -- Senator Daniel to-day presented to the Suffrage Committee of the Constitutional Convention his clause affecting the electorate and in presenting the paper he enjoined the members of the committee to secrecy. He said that the plan was not entirely completed, though in a speech of half an hour he outlined the provisions.

With a number of companions, Ernest Murray, six years old, who lived at 245 West Thirty-fifth Street, went to the foot of West Thirty-seventh Street yesterday afternoon to play on the Pennsylvania Railroad pier. The lads had been frolicking for some time, when one of the number suggested that they all go in swimming.

The feature of the monthly games of the Union Settlement Athletic Club, which were held on the club grounds on East One Hundred and First Street yesterday afternoon, was a tug-of-war between four men of the regular tug-of-war team of the club and a scrub team of five men. The four-man team won, pulling their five opponents 10 inches in the five minutes allowed for the struggle.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 21 -- When the trial of Robert S. Fosburgh for the shooting of his sister, May L. Fosburgh, is resumed to-morrow in the Superior Court it is expected that City Engineer Fobes will be called first to exhibit plans made by him of the Fosburgh premises.

CANTON, Ohio, July 21 -- Gov. Charles H. Allen of Porto Rico reached Canton to-day, attended services at the First Methodist Episcopal Church with the President, and spent the remainder of the day at the McKinley home. He left at 10:40 to-night for the East. He goes direct to Washington, thence to his home in Lowell, Mass., and from there he hopes to go to the Maine woods for a vacation.

Secretary LONG'S exclusion of the third volume of Mr. MACLAY'S "History of the United States Navy" from the curriculum textbooks used at the Naval Academy at Annapolis not only projects into the arena of public discussion an enlivening topic, but discloses the heart of a mystery that has too long baffled the curiosity of the literary world.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., July 21 -- In accordance with the advice of City Counsel Philemon Woodruff, the Assessors of this city have levied assessments on corporation property in the same manner as heretofore, preferring to await the final settlement in the Court of Errors and Appeals of the question as to whether corporation property should be assessed as real estate.

BALTIMORE, July 21 -- Under the new State census just completed, the results of which wore given out by the State authorities to-night, four counties, Washington. Dorchester, Prince Georges, and Montgomery will each be entitled to one additional member in the lower house of the Legislature.

A committee of 300 garment workers started at C o'clock yesterday morning through the east side tailoring shops to notify the workers to strike, in accordance with the decision of the Garment Workers' Trade Council on Saturday night. The members of the committee divided themselves rapidly into grouns, each group taking a section of the east side.

CHICAGO, July 21 -- Adhering to the walls of the Cathedral of the Holy Name to-day, and in packages on the sidewalk, just as the greatest crowds came to church, were circulars, signed with the name often ex-priest. The circular, which passed into thousands of hands, was couched in the frankest language and denounced the coming consecration of Father Muldoon as Assistant Bishop as a desecration.
NEWPORT, July 21 -- Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt, Jr., is arranging for a large dinner and Martha Washington dance, which will be held at Beaulieu some time in August.

NEWARK, N.J., July 21 -- The only first-class professional cyclists to compete at the Vailsburg board track to-day were Thomas J. Gascoyne, the English rider, and W.S. Fenn, the former amateur champion, as all the others refused to ride on account of the smallness of the purses. Gascoyne had come direct from Boston where he had raced on Saturday evening, and had defeated Marshall Taylor twice, both in a preliminary heat and in the final.

At the shrine of St. Anne, in the Church of St. Jean Baptiste, on East Seventy-sixth Street, near Third Avenue, yesterday morning, a boy and a girl discarded braces that had supported their crippled legs and told the awed and excited worshippers who crowded to touch the relic of the saint that they had been cured by it.

LONDON, July 22 -- "Owing to the telegraph hours on Sunday in Holland," says a dispatch to The Daily Mail from Hilversum, "Mr. Kruger was not informed of his wife's death until the evening. The news was broken to him by Dr. Heymans and Secretary Boeschoten. Mr. Kruger, who had just returned from Hilversum Church, wept bitterly and asked to be left alone.

CHICAGO, Ill., July 21 -- Chicago won the fifth straight game and the entire series from the New York team to-day by a score of 5 to 2. New York scored in the first inning on Van Haltren's double to left centre and outfield flies by Selbach and McBride. The visitors' second tally was secured in the fifth inning when Hartzel got squarely under Hickman's fly, but made a miscalculation and dropped the ball.

The Politische Correspondenz of Vienna "learns from Paris" that the difficulties of carrying into effect the plan of an effective European Customs League against the United States are considered insuperable. Probably the more closely the subject is studied the stronger will be the conviction of the insuperability of the obstacles to this plan.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., July 21 -- The stationary firemen's strike will soon be at an end. A meeting of the executive officers of the United Mine Workers of the three anthracite districts and the chief executive officers of the Stationary Firemen's Association was held in this city to-day, for the purpose of discussing the situation.

Dwellers on the wooded hills of Glen Cove, L.I., to-day will see the largest squadron of seagoing craft that ever mobilized on a peaceful mission. From far and wide the yachts of the New York Yacht Club will come hurrying to the rendezvous at Glen Cove, whence the annual cruise to the eastward will begin.

Every trolley car and railroad train and boat that went to Coney Island yesterday was crowded. Before night 200,000 persons had been at the resort, and one bathing pavilion alone accommodated 12,000. The police, including many extra officers detailed from the Central Office and elsewhere, took things easy.

A stubborn fire at 2:30 o'clock yesterday morning threatened the lives of the ten families in the five-story tenement house 356 West Street. It was a quick fire, and ambulance surgeons from Hudson Street Hospital were Kept busy dressing the scorched and injured, but no lives were lost.

A scientific test of the new storage battery of. Mr. THOMAS A. EDISON, lately announced with unusual modesty of proclamation, warrants the belief that it is at least a long step in the direction of a practical solution of the most important of the unsolved problems of electricity.

A preliminary meeting was held in the Commercial Museums Wednesday for the purpose of forming an organization of fire insurance men under the title of the Insurance Society of Philadelphia. Some of those in attendance discussed the insurance risks of the present as compared with those of the past and the advisability of organizing to promote the science and improve the methods of fire protection.

The last of the great races for horses of the matured division, and the most popular weight-for-age event known to the American turf, the Brighton Cup, at two miles fend a quarter, with a value of about $6,000, will be run next Saturday at the Brighton Beach race track, and the interest of horsemen now is centred in the contest promised for that fixture.

Although the imprudent, not to say impudent, tactics of Gen. SICKLES in trying to force the President to remove the Commissioner of Pensions, have destroyed what shadowy chance there was of bringing about that end, the campaign by and among the Grand Army of the Republic goes merrily on.

At least eight persons were injured last night shortly before midnight in a collision of trolley cars on the bridge over the Coney Island Creek. Seven were treated by an ambulance surgeon in Brooklyn, and one other, a woman, was found lying unconscious by the police after the accident. She was lying beside the trestle and had many bad cuts and bruises.

PATERSON, N.J., July 21 -- The executors of the estate of Jacob S. Rogers appointed to act during the pendency of the litigation resulting from the filing of the numerous caveats to the will have been examining into the value of the estate, which, it appears, is something like $6,000,000.

To the Editor of The New York Times: King Alfred died, according to the accustomed authorities, in October, 901 A.D., and as you are doubtless aware, it has been decided to hold at Winchester, during the third week of September this year, the one thousandth anniversary of his death -- an international commemoration of the King to whom the Anglo-Saxon race owes so much in many various ways.

BERLIN, July 21 -- Last week's Boerse showed a marked improvement. The recovery, however, was a purely speculative manoeuvre, nothing having occurred industrially to warrant the rise, and bona fide investors still holding aloof except in Government funds. Moreover, the volume, of business was light, and the rises and falls were out of all proportion to the business done.

Edward R. Heinbach, twenty-five years old, cashier for Dodd's Express Company's branch office, at Thirty-eighth Street and Seventh Avenue, was found in his room, 149 West Thirty-sixth Street, yesterday afternoon suffering from morphine poisoning. About 10 o'clock a servant girl in the house of Mrs. Stanhope, at the above address, where Heinbach had a room, heard groans, and immediately notified Mrs. Stanhope.

W.C. Carnegie, the Pittsburg golfer and a frequent competitor in metropolitan events, has just won another mixed foursome at the Myopia Club, near Boston, playing with Mrs. James White as his partner.

James Baum, twenty years old, of 31 Grand Street, was stabbed on the Staten Island Ferryboat Robert Garrett last night just after she pulled out of her Staten Island slip. There was a panic on board, and several women and children were injured in the riot, which was only quelled by the bravery of a few determined men.

PHILADELPHIA, July 21 -- The senior eight-oared shell crew of the Vesper Boat Club, which was defeated yesterday by the crew of the Argonaut Rowing Club of Toronto, Canada, is not satisfied with its showing in the race and wants to meet the Canadians a second time. Arrangements for another meeting are now being made, and unless a hitch occurs the rival crews will measure oars at the Canadian regatta early in August.

Lester R. Walten of 509 Fifth Avenue, the young chemist who was arrested on Saturday for the alleged theft of $50 from the room of Miss Josephine Curtis, who lives in the building, was arraigned in Yorkvllle Court yesterday.

The hot weather, to equal which in intensity the meteorological authorities have had to go back thirty years, had many mitigations that were not available to the last generation; and they were largely of an electrical nature. For example, great use was made of the telephone, enabling men to sit in their offices or country homes and transact business at a distance without any necessity to trudge the Saharan streets.

PHILADELPHIA, July 21 -- Joseph Manderfield, aged fifty years, of New York, was arrested here to-day charged with felonious assault and attempt to Kill Detective Sergeant Jeremiah Murphy of New York at Fourteenth Street and Third Avenue early Thursday morning.

Justice Garret J. Garretson of the Supreme Court has granted a writ of peremptory, mandamus directing Commissioner Henry S. Kearney of the Department of Public Buildings, Lighting, and Supplies to grant to the Seaboard Telegraph and Telephone Company a permit to repair Its poles and wires on its line in Queens Borough between Rockaway Beach, Arverne, Far Rockaway, Inwood, Springfield, and Jamaica to East New York.

ANOTHER BRITISH BOGY IN PARIS -- The fears recently aroused in certain political circles in Paris regarding the manoeuvres of a British warship in the Channel, which was said to be taking soundings off the French coast, were allayed when it was learned by "reportorial" investigation that these soundings had been made off the Channel Islands and were, with the subsequent establishment of bell-buoys, for the benefit of the maritime services of the world.

A number of persons were drowned and many were rescued from a watery grave in the rivers, and at various seaside resorts where the people crowded from the city yesterday in search of cooling breezes. Some of the rescues were effected under most exciting circumstances, in which the qualities of heroism and self-sacrifice were conspicuously exemplified.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- A hot wave of unusual and in many places record-breaking intensity is again prevalent over the central western part of the country, and is spreading eastward and northward. The Central West reported extraordinarily high temperatures to the Weather Bureau to-day.

Loss of life was narrowly averted yesterday afternoon when the sloop yacht Mary B., belonging to the Morrisania Yacht Club, with fourteen members aboard, capsized in Pelham Bay, about 500 feet off the Harlem Yacht Club boathouse, at City Island.

LONDON, July 21 -- It looks incongruous, but it is a fact that our market was shorter of credits last week than it was the week before. The explanation Is simple. By a great effort the market paid up nearly L6,000,000 of new consols ten days ago, and until yesterday fully half of this money was held by the Sank at the credit of the Treasury.

After a search of nearly a month Officer Doncourt of the West Side Court squad finally succeeded Saturday evening in arresting Martin Weinberg of 756 Wendover Avenue, Borough of the Bronx, charged by Mollie Giles, a colored girl, twenty-one years old, residing at 320 West Forty-fourth Street, with obtaining money under false pretenses.

There Is a Very good prospect that Jacquelin, the famous French cyclist, who has the title of champion of Europe, as well as of France, may be seen in a match race against Marshall Taylor for the championship of the world at Manhattan Beach next month. Manager Brady is in negotiation with the noted French rider, and the only obstacle to the meeting is the excessive amount of money demanded by the foreigner.

NEWARK, N.J., July 21 -- Three river pirates in a large flat-bottomed boat attempted to steal lead bullion from Balbach's Dock on the Passaie River early this morning. Patrick Harrington, the watchman, saw them and opened fire on them. He thinks he hit one as while two rowed down the river one of the men lay flat in the boat, although he had been rowing with the others.

OCEAN GROVE, July 21 -- Thirty thousand persons took part in the six services held to-day on the camp grounds and down on the beach. At both the morning and evening services in the Auditorium the children took prominent parts, it being children's day. The Auditorium was gayly trimmed with green and white bunting, and the stage was filled with palms, ferns, flowers, and orchids, the latter coming from India.

Local experts in electricity were much interested yesterday in the testimony given Saturday by two electrical engineers in Providence during a Coroner's inquest into the death of Edward Walsh, who was hilled by coming in contact with an ordinary electric incandescent lamp which, it was found later, was out of order.

After many years of good and bad fortunes the name of Koster Blal's, as applied to a music hall, becomes a thing of the past this week, and henceforth only a couple of places, one in the Tenderloin district and the other far down town, will do business under the well-known sign.
SIMON J. SCHERMERHORN, 73 years of age, died at 11 o'clock last night at his home in Rotterdam, N.Y., of apoplexy. He was stricken Thursday. He was elected to Congress in 1802 and served one term.

A remarkable operation was performed last week by Superintendent Hornaday and Curator Ditmars, assisted by a dozen keepers, on the thirteen-foot alligator which is kept in the west end of the reptile house in the Bronx Zoological Park. The alligator, which is a powerful animal, had shown signs of fierceness for some time.

The vacant United States Judgeship caused by the resignation of Judge Addison Brown is seemingly causing a great deal of trouble to the Republican leaders. The latest alleged candidate for the place is Robert C. Morris, President of the County Committee.
As a matter of curiosity, we should much like to know what Magistrate HIGGINBOTHAM of the Lee Avenue Court, in Brooklyn Borough, thinks is the purpose of the United States Navy.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The publication of the Custom House statistics for the fiscal year ended June 30 is likely to cause a renewal of the discussion as to what becomes of our foreign trade balances.
PITTSBURG, July 21 -- In an interview to-night President Shaffer at the Amalgamated Association said:

The rival Divver and Foley factions who are at war for the Tammany leadership in the Second Assembly District each had an outing yesterday to keep up the excitement of the war during the hot weather. The excursions were the first of a series of outing's to usher in the coming campaign, and they were first blood between the two factions.

The following letters to Mr. and Mrs. John L. Ham of Lewiston from friends in Alaska will be found, we think, of much interest. The writer went to Alaska at the age of fifty to repair broken health and fortune. He is now fifty-three years old. Letters covering three years are in the possession of Mr. Ham and are full of interest.

ST. LOUIS, July 21 -- On this, the day that Gov. Dockery designated for fasting and prayer that the present drought might be broken in Missouri, all records for hot weather in St. Louis were equaled, the Weather Bureau thermometer on the Custom House registering 106 degrees. On the streets and in exposed places the mercury went many degrees higher.

The late Arthur T. Colburn's sixty-foot yawl, the Venitzia of Philadelphia, which on Thursday afternoon was caught in a squall in Long Island Sound, as a result of which she capsized and five of the seven persons who were on board were lost, was raised Saturday and arrived at the foot of Twenty-sixth Street, Brooklyn, yesterday morning in tow of the Merritt Chapman tug Champion.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 21 -- The religious enthusiasm aroused by the International Convention of the Epworth League here had its culmination at the grand meeting held to-day, the last of the gathering, at the Mechanics' Pavilion. About 10,000 persons were in attendance and not a seat was vacated until the conclusion of the sermon preached by Bishop Joyce, President of the league.

Two stories were told yesterday about the disappearance from this city of Gen. Rafael Uribe Uribe, the Colombian revolutionary leader, of whom it is said that he slipped away from New York about three weeks ago, and is now actively engaged in preparing a filibustering expedition for the purpose of taking Panama.
The New York baseball team management has secured Pitcher George Villeman for the local team from Schenectady. He has been ordered, to report at the Polo Grounds to-morrow morning.

We do not remember any leader of organized labor who talked quite so foolishly as President SHAFFER of the Amalgamated Association. DEBS and IRONS and others of their class were ignorant men and foolish utterance was to be expected of them as often as they opened their mouths.

Seated on the side of an up-State canal boat which lies off the Long Island Railroad docks, in Newtown Creek, Long Island City, Capt. Sarah E. Stanton is to-day directing the removal of a cargo that she has brought here all the way from Whitehall. Every now and then, despite her sixty years, she descends from her quarterdeck and assists in the unloading herself.

The charges against Willis S. Paine and Waldo Grant Morse which have been before the Surrogate's Court for nearly five years in connection with their administration of the estate of Ruby Tilden Paine, wife of Mr. Paine, have been withdrawn. A stipulation to this effect, signed by all the counsel in the case, was filed with the Surrogate yesterday.

The Adder, the second of the five submarine torpedo boats being constructed on the Holland type by the Crescent Shipbuilding Company of Elizabethport, N. J., for the United States Government, was sent over the ways yesterday afternoon in the presence of a select gathering of torpedo boat enthusiasts and Government experts.

The development of a new corn, crop scare over Sunday, due to reports of extremely hot weather in the corn belt, and an absence of needed rains, was responsible for a sharp break in the stock market yesterday, in which such stocks as St. Paul, Union Pacific, Missouri Pacific, Rock Island, and Atchison broke from four to seven points, carrying the general list down with them.

BOSTON, July 22. -- The market went wrong again to-day. The selling at times was heavy, and prices broke sharply. Feeble rallies came at intervals, but they counted for little. The whole situation was tinged with blue. The market was still up against a combination of adverse influences, such as is rarely encountered.

Civil Justice Herman Bolte stopped the business of the Second District Municipal Court yesterday in order that he might attend the picnic of the association named after State Senator John F. Ahearn at College Point.
Already the Republicans are beginning to discuss the selection of Assembly candidates.

The cruise of the New York Yacht Club was the event of yesterday. The yachts started from Glen Cove. From the start until they reach Newport there will be one constant succession of interesting races. They stop on the way at the different Sound resorts, and much entertaining will be done for them.

FRANCHISE TAX. -- State Controller William J. Morgan assessed a tax of $101,873 against the New York Central and Hudson River Railroad Company upon its gross earnings of $20,374,602.60 for the year ended June 30, 1899. In this amount was included $1,654,182.48 paid the company by the United States for carrying the mails, the tax on which amounted to $8,270.91.

MANILA, July 22. -- The conference between Adjt. Gen. Corbin and Gen. Chaffee recently held here will probably result in radical, economical, and administrative reforms in the army of occupation. It is estimated the total cost of maintaining the American Army in the Philippines can be reduced to 60 per cent, in the course of one year.

CHICAGO, July 22. -- The second trial race for the Canada cup was sailed this afternoon in a northeast wind averaging twenty miles an hour, and was won by the Cadillac of Detroit, Detroit of Detroit second, Illinois third, Minota fourth, and Prairie fifth. The last three boats are from Chicago.

WASHINGTON, July 22. -- Commander Wainwright, Commandant of the United States Naval Academy under date of July 20, has mado the following reply to the Navy Department's inquiry concerning the use of the third volume of Maclay's history of the navy:
NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., July 22. -- There was a panic on a trolley car of the Union Company's line here this evening. Several persons were hurt.

PITTSBURG, July 22. -- Neither of the looked-for strike programmes for Wellsville or McKeesport were carried out today. At Wellsville the importation of men failed to materialize, and at McKeesport the attempt to resume at the Dewees Wood tube plant was not made. At both points, which are considered by each side to be the strik centres, the situation is in statu quo, neither of the parties to the controversy having made any decided move.

Dr. Benjamin F. Corwin of 583 Avenue F. Brooklyn, has turned his house into a temporary hospital, having taken into his home four victims of a trolley accident which occurred near by. The accident happened at Nostrand Avenue and Avenue F early yesterday morning.

LONDON, July 22 -- The Congress on Tuberculosis, for the prevention of consumption, was opened to-day by the Duke, of Cambridge, President of the congress. Four hundred foreign delegates attended to-day's session. They included a number of Americans and Canadians. Several Ambassadors and Ministers, including United States Ambassador Choate, were also present.
Bar silver was quoted in London at 26 7/8d per ounce and in New York at 58 1/4c. Mexican dollars at 46 1/4c.

CLEVELAND, July 22. -- Ideal racing weather, a large crowd, and a track as smooth as the top of a billiard table, characterized the opening of the Grand Circuit meeting at the Cleveland Driving Park this afternoon.

ELKINS, West Va., July 22. -- To-night the body of William Brooks, colored, swings from the limb of a tree in the City Park here, and Chief of Police Robert Lilly lies dying in a Cumberland (Md.) hospital from the effects of a bullet wound inflicted by the colored man.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The State Department received a dispatch to-day from Commissioner Rockhill, at Peking, announcing that a plan for the payment of the Chinese indemnity had finally been adopted.

BOSTON, July 22. -- The eleventh, annual tennis tournament for the Longwood Trophy, held by Whitman, began at Longwood to-day with forty-two entries, including Wright, Davis, Ward, Larned, and Hobart. All of these, except Davis, who was defending his Magnolia title, were seen to-day. Wright had an easy double win, though Pier pushed him for one set, Wright showed good form and seemed to have recovered from a temporary fit of ill condition.

Weakness characterized moat of the active prices in the market for outside securities, and a slightly lower range of values was reached as a result of the day's trading. Bank stocks and some of the copper shares were firm. As for transportation issues, they were for the most part neglected.

It is to be noted that the ordinary political aspirants for the Federal Bench are "backward in coming forward" in the case of the vacancy created by the resignation of Judge BROWN, Mr. MORRIS, who cannot at all be reckoned in that class, seems to have been "mentioned" by some of its members entirely without his authority.

Charges of evasions of the new tenement house law on the part of Michael Bernstein, an architect of 111 Broadway, and intimations of collusion on the part of certsin subordinate officials of the Building Department, were made yesterday by Robert W. De Forest, Chairman of the Tenement House Committee of the Charity Organization Society.

Ogden Clarkson have sold for the Milligan estate to a client the four-story buildings, running through from 1,261 Broadway to 526 Sixth Avenue, 59 feet north of Thirty-first Street, 21 by 145. The brokers say that the purchaser is not an owner of adjoining property.

Not long ago a New York newspaper, without ostentation, began the publication of a supplement devoted exclusively to literature. It contained no lurid pictures, no dismal attempts at humor. It was as far removed from the nightmare creations published by the yellow journals and known as Sunday art supplements as the East is from the West.

LONDON, July 22. -- Daniel Frohman, who sails for New York on the North German Lloyd steamer Deutschland from Southampton July 26, has engaged the Hungarian violinist Kubelik for an American tour, beginning in New York in December. Mr. Frohman has guaranteed that Kubelik's share of the proceeds from the tour shall not be less than $100,000.

PHILADELPHIA, July 22. -- The stock market held up tenaciously all the morning, but in the afternoon resigned itself to the disordered conditions in New York. Nearly everything yielded. Cambria Steel, Conemaugh stock receipts, and Philadelphia. Company all dropped over a point. The absence of pressure to sell was the only thing that prevented greater declines than were registered.

Late on Sunday night the brothers of a sixteen-year-old girl who had been missing from her home near Richmond, S. I., since the previous Wednesday, after an all-day search for their sister, found her wounded and unconscious in the cabin of their father's oyster sloop. On the boat was a wild-eyed boy of eighteen, with blood dripping from three wounds in his neck, whom they captured after a hard fight.

Much humidity and high temperature made yesterday very uncomfortable in the city, so the near-by coast resorts had their usual hot weather patronage. In the afternoon, after working hours, crowds of people who had not been able to get off during the earlier part of the day flocked aboard ferries and excursion boats, purposing at least to enjoy the evening in some cool spot.

WASHINGTON, July 22. -- Considerable surprise was manifested at the Nevy Department to-day because of the publication in The Baltimore Sun of what purports to be an interview with Rear Admiral Robley D. Evans, in which he defends Rear Admiral Schley from the charge of unnecessarily delaying his squadron at Cienfuegos during the chase after Cervera's ships.

Between the favorites that did win and the favorites that should have won the results of the races at the Brighton Beach race track yesterday made a complete triumph for the followers of form, so far as theory went, but the triumph had an alloy of regret in it for the majority of the betting crowd, as winners were so extremely easy to pick that prices against them naturally were short.

The largest pleasure fleet that ever mobilized in American waters was present yesterday at Glen Cove. L. I., when the New York Yacht Club squadron rendezvoused for its historic cruise to the eastward. As far as the eye could reach the dimpling expanse of blue was well filled with all types of yachts that gently rose and fell in the light waves that plashed musically against their shapely sides.

Two popular amusements at Coney Island were summarily stopped by the police last night the "Loop-the-loop" and the "Flipflap," or "Barrel of Love" -- though Capt. Driscoll of the Coney Island police force gave no reason for the action to the indignant proprietors except that he had been ordered to do it by Deputy Commissioner Bernard J. York.

The strike of the east side tailors was extended to all the shops yesterday, and according to the Strike Committee of the nine unions involved in it every shop in New York was tied up as far as the men were concerned. The only workers were several thousand girls who are employed as basters and fellers, and as their work depends on the men they are expected to become idle to-day.

The record of fire losses for the current year shows a gratifying reduction in the value of property destroyed, as compared with last year. The June losses were $9,599,000, as compared with $21,281,000 for the corresponding month of last year. For May, however, they exceeded $22,000,000.
LONDON, July 22. -- Money was in fair demand to-day and supplies were augmented and easier.

CHICAGO, July 22. -- In the grain pits this was a wildly bullish day. Impelled by the hopeless tone of advices from the parched prairies, wheat, corn, and oats scored sensational advances and closed excitedly strong, respectively 3 7/8, 4 3/8, and 3 1/8 cents higher for September delivery.
To the Editor of The New York Times: A friend in New York has just sent to me a copy of your edition of the 17th inst.

We fancy that a good deal of the next corn crop was harvested in Wall Street last week under the form of buying good stocks dog cheap. Wall Street has a habit of getting through with its harvesting before other people begin. -- The Hartford Courant.

The strike fever which has been raging in the tailors' shops of New York and Brooklyn and Brownsville since Sunday spread to Bayonne, N.J., and Astoria, L.I., yesterday. In Bayonne about 1,000 garment workers went on strike, and 5,000 left their work in Astoria, the demands in both places to be agreed on to-day.

The poolrooms in Long Island City were open yesterday afternoon and doing a lively business. Runners met every ferry boat from Manhattan. Cappers had distributed small cards to people along the street informing them of the location of the gambling places.

The mathematical precision with which the favorites at the Brighton Beach race track "averaged up" the string of successes by the best backed horses on the day before was somewhat distressing to form followers yesterday, but for all that the racing was of rather a restful nature, except in rare instances.

The market for outside securities recovered almost wholly from the weakness of the previous day and developed considerable strength in industrial and copper shares, while transportation issues were dull and bank stocks had but few inquirers. Despite the strength of prices, the amount of stock offered was much less than on Monday, and the volume of trading was much more contracted.

CHICAGO, July 23 -- Liquidation by "pyramid builders" was the feature of the grain trade to-day, September wheat, corn, and oats closing at declines of 2 1/8, 4 1/8, and 2 3/8 cents, respectively. The tone was that of nervous excitement.

Bishop Charles E. McDonnell, head of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn, and the Rev. Thomas Taaffe, rector of St. Patrick's Church, Willoughby and Kent Avenues, are both greatly disturbed over the action of the Rev. John Baxter who has ignored the Bishop's orders for hi mto leave the diocese and continues to occupy his rooms in the rectory of St. Patrick's Church.

TEST OF THE USE OF LAND -- Arthur C. Tucker and James P. McQuade, who own land in Rockland County adjoining that of the Mack Paving Company, obtained from the Special Term of the Supreme Court an injunction restraining the company from quarrying on its land. It being alleged that fragments of rock and stone were thrown on plaintiffs' land and the buildings injured by shock and jar.
The telephone bell rang violently at the Oakdale apartment house, 36-38 West Thirty-fifth Street, yesterday, and Super-intendent Monroe took down the receiver.

WASHINGTON, July 23. -- Rear Admiral Schley has accepted the gage of battle thrown down by his enemies. This evening he sent telegrams from Great Neck to two of his close personal friends informing them that he intended to ask Secretary Long for a court of inquiry and to bring suit for libel against Edgar Stanton Maclay for the assertions contained in the latter's "History of the Navy."

A.W. McLaughlin Co. have sold to a client four lots owned by A.G. Hyde, including 44 to 50 West Forty-fifth Street, and 43 West Forty-fourth Street, adjoining the New York Yacht Club. The site will be improved with a twelve-story apartment hotel.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- With the exception of scattered thunderstorms, the most important of which, so far at least as reports to the Weather Bureau show, was that at North Platte, Neb., where 8-100 of an inch of rain fell, the drought and intense heat continued to-day throughout the States of the corn belt.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- A St. Petersburg dispatch, dated July 23, to the United States Department of Agriculture, states that a temperature of 103 degrees was reached that day in Odessa, and that phenomenal heat was prevailing through all Northern Russia.

The midsummer games of the Pastime Athletic Club will be held at the Pastime Oval, Sixty-sixth Street and Avenue A, Manhattan, on Saturday, Aug. 24. The events will be as follows: 60-yard run, novice; 60-yard run, handicap; 440-yard run, handicap; 880-yard run, novice; 1,000-yard run, handicap; two-mile run, handicap; putting twelve-pound shot, handicap.

CHICAGO, July 23 -- The yacht Milwaukee crossed the line first to-day in the third trial race for the Canada Cup. Her victory was complete, as she led over the finishing line by over two minutes and beat the Cadillac and Illinois by about six minutes.

BOSTON, Mass., July 23 -- The open lawn tennis tournament of the Longwood Cricket Club was continued to-day on the club grounds at Longwood. An enthusiastic crowd of spectators gathered to see the play, and both morning and afternoon there was plenty of excitement. Davis and Paret put in an appearance in the morning and played off their first match, which had been held over for them because they were both engaged yesterday at Magnolia.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Following is the Weather Bureau's weekly summary of crop conditions:

The City Central Committee of the Citizens' Union, at a largely attended meeting last night, listened to a severe attack on ex-Mayor Charles A. Schieren of Brooklyn and fixed the dates for the several conventions.
LONDON, July 23 -- The supplies of money were larger to-day, and in view of the easier money conditions expected during the next few days discounts were weaker.

BALTIMORE, July 23 -- All the members of the Maryland delegation in Congress, Republicans and Democrats, will favor Congressional investigation of the Schley-Sampson controversy. Senator McComas is now out West, and his views on the matter could not be learned. Senator Wellington says he will stand by Schley in the future as in the past.

The responsibility which Secretary LONG promptly disclaimed Admiral SAMPSON eagerly assumes. The Secretary would not permit Mr. MACLAY'S statement that the proofs of the third volume of his matchless history containing the celebrated observations on Admiral SCHLEY had been read by him to go uncontradicted, and procured from the distinguished author a recantation of the error.

Politicians and lawyers of both parties are deeply interested in the argument which will be made before Justice McAdam in the Supreme Court to-day upon the motion of counsel for Fire Commissioner Scannell and "Agent" Marks, indicted for neglect of duty and conspiracy, to remove the actions from the Court of General Sessions to the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court.

Many widely-known men attended the funeral services of Alfred Van Santvoord, which were held at his late residence, 38 West Thirty-ninth Street, yesterday morning. The Rev. Dr. Edward B. Coe, senior pastor of the Collegiate Church in West Forty-eighth Street, officiated. A double quartette from the church furnished the music, singing a number of Mr. Van Santvoord's favorite hymns.

The announcement of the appointment of Mr. HUNT to succeed Mr. ALLEN as Governor of Porto Rico is an announcement that the existing system of government of that island is to be continued, not as a mere makeshift, but with some permanence. It is to be governed by the Executive Department at Washington.

The Keppel Gallery is arranged for the Summer with old and modern line engravings, etchings, mezzotints, and woodcuts of famous men of the law, statesmen, and politicians in Great Britain and Ireland, all of comparatively small size, adapted for the walls of library or office. It is made to please the busy horde of lawyers, who like to surround themselves with good likenesses of the eminent in their profession.

Plans for the new twelve-story apartment hotel, to be erected on the site of the Scottish Rite Hall, at Madison Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street, by Maitland G. Graves, were filed at the Building Department yesterday by Architect Henry Allen James. It is understood that a lease of the hotel for a long term of years has already been arranged, although the name of the lessee could not be learned yesterday.

ITHACA, N.Y., July 23 -- Commodore Sherman Collins of the Lakeside Yacht Club of Ithaca announced the programme to-day for the Interlake Yachting Association regatta to be held on Cayuga Lake from Aug. 5 to 16. The first series of races will take place at Bull's Grove. near Cayuga, Aug. 5 and 6.

MONTREAL, July 23 -- The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company of New York has taken over the entire business and existing policies of La Compagnie Canadienne, a Montreal insurance company which has a considerable amount of insurance in force among the French-Canadians of this province.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Since his return to Washington the Secretary of War has given his attention to the delay in the prosecution of Charles F.W. Neely, accused of stealing Cuban postal funds.

PITTSBURG, July 23 -- The combine forces have decided to carry the strike into the courts. It is learned to-night that Judge P.M. Smith of Wellsville, Ohio, has been retained by Persifor F. Smith, district manager of the American Sheet Steel Company, to prepare papers for presentation within a few days to a Federal court asking for a restraining order to stop strikers from accosting or in any way molesting non-union men on the highways.

It was to be expected that the new tenement house law would encounter the united opposition of the unreformed builders of unreformed tenement houses. But this opposition did not amount to much. It had in fact been frustrated in advance in the first place by the composition of the commission.

The North German Lloyd liner Kaiser Wilhelm der Grosse, from Bremen, Cherbourg, and Southampton, reached her dock at the foot of Gansevoort Street at about 5:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon. Among the 600 cabin passengers who landed from the ship were Mr. and Mrs. Harry Lehr, who were returning from their honeymoon trip to Europe.

LONDON, July 24 -- The principal feature of yesterday's session of the British Congress on Tuberculosis was Prof. Robert Koch's paper, which was listened to with the deepest interest by a big gathering in St. James's Hall.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 23 -- Mrs. Astor will give her dinners each Monday in August. Mr. and Mrs. F.H. Benedict of New York will not arrive at the Bennett place till to-morrow morning. Marshall R.R. Kernochan of Pittsfield is the guest of Mr. and Mrs. J.J. Wysong at Greystone.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July, 23 -- The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court for the Fourth Judicial Department to-day handed down a decision holding that the law passed by the last Legislature, forbidding traffic in railroad tickets by others than authorized agents of railroad companies, is unconstitutional and void.

Many pitiful scenes were witnessed at the Charities Department pier, at East Twenty-sixth Street, yesterday, when 600 or more blind persons gathered to receive their shares of $33,250, the city's annual dole to the poor thus afflicted, distribution of which this year was delayed for many days through red tape.
It is announced that the stockholders of the American Sugar Refining Company will receive a circular letter from the Directors shortly proposing an issue of $15,000,000 of new stock.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., July 23 -- The St. Louis Transit Company to-day posted a notice that caused favorable comment all over the city. The notices were put in each street car owned by the company. It reads:

Frank Moss, ex-Police Commissioner, reformer, and Vice President of the City Vigilance League, addressed the Hebrews of the east side in a mass meeting held last night in the main hall of the Educational Alliance, at East Broadway and Jefferson Street, in the interests of social purity in the city.

The exports of merchandise from the Port of New York for the week ended Tuesday, July 23, are valued at $9,799,711, against $9,450,833 the preceding week and $13,818,165 during the corresponding week last year. Since Jan. 1 they amount to $282,263,609, against $305,884,759 for the same period last year.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 23 -- Apparently without relatives and deserted by friends, Henry Stanynought, at one time a prosperous ink and pen maker, is lying critically ill at his home in Woodbridge township, within 400 yards of the Iselin railroad station. In the days of his prosperity Stanynought bought the house, and his neighbors called it a mansion.

GREAT NECK, L.I., July 23 -- Rear Admiral W.S. Schley declined to-day to be drawn into the discussion of the Santiago campaign restarted by Maclay's history. When seen, the Admiral, in the presence of his wife and his son, Dr. Schley, said:

Assistant District Attorney Charles E. Le Barbier took up in earnest yesterday the work of collating and putting into proper shape the mass of information and testimony he has in his possession tending to show that the New York Central Railroad's maintenance of the tunnel under Park Avenue in its present condition is a public nuisance and a menace to public health.

The bull clique in July cotton, which has been maintaining the price of that option at between 60 and 70 points higher than the next current month, suffered a heavy loss in the local cotton market yesterday, when July cotton, which had closed on Monday at 8.22@8.24, opened at 8.23, and then declined steadily until 7.85 was reached, closing at 7.88, a net drop of 35 points.

Senor Manuel A. Matos, one of Venezuela's wealthiest citizens, and until Gen. Cipriano Castro came into power, a prominent figure in politics there, is in this city. He arrived here on the Red D Line steamer Maracalbo Monday night.

TRENTON, N.J., July 23 -- Chancellor Magie, as Ordinary or the Prerogative Court, has given his decision in the Charles K. Landis will case. He sustained the action of the Orphans' Court of Cumberland. County in admitting the will and codicil to probate.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 23 -- ong card which the Grand Circuit resented to-day brought out an immense crowd. The stands were gay with the Summer costumes of the ladies, and the boxes were all filled.

An unfortunate accident marred the junior polo competition yesterday afternoon on the field of the Rockaway Hunting Club at Cedarhurst, L.I. This time, however, it was a pony that was injured and not the rider. In the final period of the match the pony ridden by Anson W. Hard, Jr., slipped, and in falling broke its leg.
Army. Major Frank L. Doods, Judge Advocate, will proceed to Omaha and report to the commanding General, Department of the Missouri, for duty as Judge Advocate of that department.

Some of our Democratic friends are discussing with more ingenuity than practical judgment the shaping of issues for the next National campaign on which the party can present a united front and have some hopes of success. It is an old process, in which partisans have been engaged, on one side or the other, with energy, but generally with no result.
BUFFALO. July 23 -- James F. Curtiss, ex-Police Commissioner, was found dead in bed this morning at his home. He retired last night in fairly good health. He was sixty years of age.
BOSTON, July 23 -- The harness horses opened their Boston season to-day at the track of the New England Breeders' Association, in Readville, and all the expected winners fell by the wayside. Summary:

After a two months' absence in Europe, during which time he has been busy looking after the interest of American theatregoers, Manager Charles Frohman yesterday returned to New York on the steamship Kaiser Wilhelm der Grosse, bringing with him a prospectus of his plans for the coming season, in both New York and London.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 24 -- The Republicans of Westchester County held their county convention in St. John's Hall here to-day. Mark D. Stiles of Mount Vernon was chosen Chairman. There were 211 delegates present from the twenty-two towns of this county. The convention was orderly and harmonious throughout.

NEWPORT, July 24 -- On Friday evening Mrs. Stuyvesant Fish will give the much-talked-of vaudeville entertainment at Crossways. Prior to the performance there will be a supper for about a hundred and fifty guests, Who Will be seated at small tables. The stage will be in the drawing room, and the main hall will be used for the audience, which will number about 250.

District Attorney Philbin, opposing before Justice McAdam in the Supreme Court yesterday the motion to transfer to the latter court from the General Sessions the actions for conspiracy and neglect of duty against Fire Commissioner Scannell and "Agent" William L. Marks, questioned the authority of the Supreme Court to order such transfers.

LONDON, July 25 -- The will of Baron Wilhelm von Rothschild, head of the Rothschild banking house of Frankfort, which was filed in London because certain properties in Great Britain were affected by the testamentary dispositions, leaves 2,200,000 marks (about $520,000) and two houses to Jewish charities.

In yesterday's issue of The Independent there appeared an article by Park Benjamin, entitled "'History' and Rear Admiral Schley." Mr. Benjamin is a graduate of the United States Naval Academy, and has been in close touch with the navy for thirty-eight years, although he resigned his commission some time ago.

The most serious accident which has happened to the structural part of the New York and Brooklyn Bridge since it was opened to the public May 24, 1883, occurred yesterday, paralyzing traffic. Egineer Probasco of the Department of Bridges, who is in charge of the structure during the absence of Chief Engineer Martin, said late last night:

PHILADELPHIA, July 24 -- The Philadelphia market was very quiet to-day. Such stocks as were traded in showed small improvements. Pennsylvania Steel preferred and Consolidated Lake Superior were more active than for some time. Yesterday's declines in Lehigh Valley and in Lehigh Navigation were overcome by slight gains on small trading.

Plenty of batting characterized yesterday's baseball game between New York and Brooklyn at Washington Park, and consequently the pitchers who started the game did not finish. Phyle lasted but one inning. Donovan, the Brooklyn pitcher, was hit quite hard in the opening inning. He then pulled himself together and for three innings kept the New Yorks from scoring.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 24 -- The fifth day of the trial of Robert S. Fosburgh, on a charge of manslaughter, for the alleged killing of his sister May, was marked by the appearance, as witnesses for the defense, of Robert L. Fosburgh, the father, and Beatrice, the fifteen-year-old sister of the defendant.

BOSTON, July 24 -- On the whole the bulls rather had the better of to-day's stock market argument. For a short time the bears had decidedly the upper hand -- that was at the opening of trading, when speculators were not feeling particularly well, as s result of the denial of the settlement of the strike and the manifest fact that somebody had stretched the truth as regards showers in the crop district on Tuesday.

CHICAGO, July 24 -- There was a diminution of excitement in the grain trade to-day, but the weather remained menacing and prices advanced, wheat closing 1 7/8 cents, corn 1 1/2 to 1 5/8 cents, and oats 3/8 to 1/2 cent higher for September delivery.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 24 -- The screeching of a shell that proved to have come from the United States steamship Kearsarge, and its explosion into fragments that broke a small piece of stone out of the new City Hall building on Broadway, and cut a limb from a tree near by, caused consternation among Newport residents shortly after 5 o'clock this evening.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Many of the statements which have been made by competent and responsible persons since the failure of the Seventh National Bank, have somewhat, I believe, surprised the public.

PITTSBURG, July 24 -- Two moves, it is reported, were made by the aggressive officials of the American Sheet Steel Company to-day toward the breaking of the strike. One was the shipping of some of the non-union men that have been employed in the Vandergrift mills of the company to Wellsville to assist in the starting of the plant there.

Bankers and speculators throughout the country are said to be on a still hunt for State bonds issued in the sixties, mainly by the Southern States, for the construction of railroads and levees. Several persons in New York are interested in the search. Only a few days ago one of the largest trust companies in the city issued a circular requesting holders of these bonds to communicate with its officials.

LONDON, July 25 -- The presentation on Monday to King Edward of a medal commemorative of the work of the hospital ship Maine, and the King's reply to the members of the Maine Committee, in which he thanked them for bringing their valuable services to a culmination by presenting the ship to the British Government, threaten to become an international incident.

The battle for the Junior Polo Cup at the Rockaway Hunting Club will bring together to-day in the third contest two at the strongest junior teams, and many of the critics expect that the victor to-day will capture the trophy in the final match on Saturday. The opponents will be the Junior No. 1 and Junior No. 2 teams.

LONDON, July 25 -- "A complete agreement has been reached between the Vatican and the United States Government," says the Rome correspondent of The Daily Chronicle, "with regard to the religious orders in the Philippines. According to this agreement, the Dominicans and Augustinians will remain for the present, but the Spanish monks will be replaced from time to time by others.

NEW LONDON, Conn., July 24 -- Constitution again marched home at the head of the New York Yacht Club fleet to-day in the squadron run of thirty-nine miles from Luddington Rock, New Haven, to Sarah's Ledge, at the entrance of New London Harbor. She covered the distance in 4 hours, 32 minutes, and 27 seconds, and beat the old champion Columbia by 8 minutes and 23 seconds on actual sailing time.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Secretary Long will to-morrow or next day issue a precept calling a court of inquiry to settle the controversy regarding the conduct of Bear Admiral Schley in the Spanish war. The Secretary came to this conclusion to-day after receiving the following letter from Admiral Schley:

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Secretary Gage and Assistant Secretary Spaulding to-day heard the representations of a number of New York business men concerning appointments and transfers in the office of the Appraiser of Merchandise of the Port of New York. The delegation numbered about a dozen men, representing the New York Board of Trade and Transportation, the Crockery Board of Trade, and the glass and glove manufacturers.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The majority of our army is now on duty in the Philippines. These "makers of history" comprise the children of parents who live in the United States. They are our dear boys, whether they be fathers, husbands, or sons; the same interest in their welfare, their doings, their good and ill, goes out to them as when they were with us at the home table.

LONDON, July 24 -- "Cash" Sloan, the American jockey, who has been riding in Russia, had an exciting experience at the Moscow races, where he narrowly escaped death at the hands of a furious mob. Sloan had been riding with such continuous success that his mounts were always favorites.

The United Garment Workers took formal charge of the strike of the east side tailors yesterday, and it was announced in the morning that unless the manufacturers accept the terms of the strikers, the clothing cutters will stop work. The manufacturers will have a reasonable time to notify the United Garment Workers of their acceptance of the conditions proposed by the Strike Committee.

The City Club has issued a small pamphlet devoted to a brief presentation of some of the chief events in the life of Mr. RICHARD CROKER. It is not a biography in the usual sense of the term; we doubt whether the materials exist, save in oral tradition, for a biography of Mr. CROKER. Out of his own recollection he might write the story of his own life.

MANILA, June 12 -- The passage to-day by the Philippine Commission of the act organizing the courts of the archipelago was preceded by two interesting incidents, both of which brought out authoritative statements from President Taft. The first was in reference to the wording of the oath of office to be taken by Judges.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps'. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25-cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,590 and Is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.
After 9 o'clock last evening there was little or no excitement at either terminus. The appearances were very much the same as when repairs are being made and only one roadway is in use.

The stock market yesterday, because of the apparent impossibility of obtaining any reliable news respecting weather conditions in the corn belt, moved with much irregularity -- now up, now down, and finally closed with quotations generally showing net declines. The chief of these, as might be expected, were in the Grangers, St. Paul showing a net loss of 3 3/8, Union Pacific of 3, Atchison of 2 3/8, and Missouri Pacific of 1 7/8.

Anthony Comstock and his lieutenant, Charles Bamberger, pounced upon the "Twentieth Century Fair" at 3 Park Row shortly before noon yesterday, and when the two men left an hour later, a police patrol wagon staggered away under the weight of nine picture machines, and the two proprietors of the place were on their way to court.

The American Locomotive Company announces that it will double its plant at Schenectady, thus enabling it to produce 900 to 1,000 locomotives per annum instead of 425 to 450, the present limit. The Schenectady plant will be the central one of the system. The other plants will also gradually be extended, and plans to increase their capacity are already under consideration.

CLEVELAND, July 24 -- The programme of the Grand Circuit races at Glenville to-day was not as heavy as might have been expected for the middle day of the meeting, although the two slow trots furnished good sport.

Trading in the market for outside securities was almost featureless. A few industrials obtained better prices, and bank stocks were firm, with no offerings. The volume of business was extremely light.
E. A. Cruikshank Co. have sold for the estate of R. G. Dun, to an investor, the plot of twenty-three lots bounded by Academy Street, Two Hundred and First Street, and the Harlem River.

The arrival of the yachts of the New York Yacht Club at New London was the chief suburban event of yesterday. There have been a number of entertainments given for those on the cruise. The polo at Somerset is interesting to a number of New Jersey players, and at Cedarhurst there was a large attendance at the polo games.

LEAVENWORTH, Kan., July 24 -- Michael Kelly, an insane man, to-day, at the office of the Robert Garrett Lumber Company, shot six people, killing one, probibly fatally wounding another, and more or less seriously wounding the four others. He was himself finally killed by officers who tried to overpower him.

NEWARK, N.J., July 24 -- The threemasted schooner William Heckman of New York while being towed past the Bridge Street Bridge to-night collided with the structure. The vessel tore away a part of the smoothing iron of the bridge.

BAR HARBOR, Me., July 24 -- The first Malvern ball of the season took place to-night. It was the first general indication of the big season, and there was an unusually large attendance for so early a dance. Preceding the dance, many dinners were given at the Inn and among the cottagers.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., July 24 -- Dispatches received here to-day told of a serious state of affairs at Osoeola, Ark., where, it was claimed, Sheriff Bowen and Circuit Clerk Driver refused to vacate their offices, although having been removed by the Governor. It was said that many persons were armed, and an outbreak was regarded as imminent.

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 24 -- The championship events of the international meet of the Athletic League of the Young Men's Christian Association of North America were decided in the Stadium at the Pan-American Exposition grounds to-day under the most favorable conditions. The weather was clear and cool and the track was in perfect condition.

A representative of Internal Revenue Collector Treat visited New Street yesterday and served notice on numerous "put" and "call" brokers to pay their tax as such. It is said that in many instances penalties for non-payment of the tax have already been attached.

CHICAGO, July 24 -- The sixth annual golf tournament of the Ontwentsia Club was productive of some excellent scores to-day in the qualifying rounds for the Ravin Oaks, Solace, and Tyro Cups. Half the eighty players made the round of eighteen holes in ninety-one strokes or better. W. J. Holabird, Jr., Glen View, broke the course record with seventy-eight.

The forces which in most Southern States have culminated in a demand for a revision of State Constitutions which the political managers could neither resist nor guide for their own purposes, and which have found their highest expression in the conventions now revising the Constitutions of Alabama and Virginia, have begun to work in Tennessee.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Scattered thunder showers in the northern tier or States in the Central West to-day gave some relief from the intense heat in that locality. These showers, which generally were light in character, occurred in the Dakotas, Southern Minnesota, Northwestern Iowa, the extreme northern portion of Illinois, in Minnesota, and in Michigan.

Officials of the New York Central, the New York, New Haven and Hartford, and the New York and Harlem Railroads have been subpoenaed by Assistant District Attorney Le Barbler to appear before the Grand Jury to-day and give testimony as to the condition of the Park Avenue tunnel, which is declared by many passengers and residents along the road to be a nuisance and a menace to health.

Army. An army retiring board is appointed to meet at San Francisco for the examination of such officers as may be ordered before it. Detail: Major Gen. Samuel B.M. Young, Col. James M. Marshall, Assistant Quartermaster General; Col. John B. Babcock, Assistant Adjutant General; Lieut. Col. John D. Hall, Deputy Surgeon General; Major Robert J. Gibson, Surgeon; Capt. David J. Rumbough, Artillery Corps, Recorder.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Three thousand persons attended the bicycle races at the Coliseum Park track to-night. In the second grand semi-final of the second event, "Major" Taylor and Tom Cooper were without pacemakers, the latter desiring one, but Taylor objecting, and they both rode in amateur style the entire distance, Taylor winning.

LONDON, July 25 -- The principal paper before the British Congress on Tuberculosis yesterday was read by Prof. Brouardel of Paris, who urged international legislation in regard to the notification of the authorities of the existence of tuberculosis, and the disinfection of hotels, railroad cars, and steamboats to prevent the spread of the disease.

To the Editor of The New York Times: You say well, "There is no party issue before the country of one-hundredth part of the importance that attaches to the question whether Mr. Shatter or Mr. Schwab is to be the responsible manager of the United States Steel Corporation."

NEWARK, N.J., July 24 -- The Right Rev. Dr. John J. O'Connor will be consecrated Bishop of the Catholic Dlocese of Newark to-morrow morning. The ceremonies will be held in St. Patrick's Cathedral, in this city, and although only a low mass will be celebrated, it will continue for about three hours.
NEWARK, N.J., July 24 -- The garment workers in this city stopped work this morning, and most of the principal shops are tied up as a result. There are at least 1,500 garment workers out.

We have not happened to read the story which three of our esteemed contemporaries printed on Sunday concerning a criminal case on trial in Massachusetts. Doubtless the Judge presiding over the trial was quite within his rights and his duty in turning the representatives of the three journals out of his court and giving orders that neither they nor any other representatives of those journals should be readmitted.
LONDON, July 24 -- Money was in moderate demand to-day and scarcer.

To The Editor of The New York Times: On Sept. 10, 1755, by "his Majesty's orders and instructions," 2,000 people of Grand Pre were herded together like convicts and driven at the bayonet's point aboard transports which were stationed in the River Gaspereau, to be scattered.

To The Editor of The New York Times: With much interest I have carefully read your editorials concerning the great steel strike which is now paralyzing American industry. I have regretted to see your defense of the principle involved in this strike attacked by some so-called conservative men.

BALTIMORE, July 25 -- Mayor Hayes intends to have a thorough investigation made in regard to the acceptance of patients by Baltimore Hospitals. The Chief of Police reported to him the case of Joseph Reines, a tailor, who died in jail of alcoholism after admission at a number of hospitals, including Bayview Asylum, the city institution for poor people, had been refused to him.

NEWPORT, July 25 -- The "Red Devil," Mr. W.K. Vanderbilt Jr.'s new German racing motor carriage, was out of commission for repairs to-day, as was his "White Ghost." The "Red Devil" has been tested for its greatest speed and has developed an average of 74 miles an hour, which gives it the claim to being the fastest machine in this country.

NORTH ATTLEBOROUGH, Mass., July 25 -- Miss Jennie Stanley, twenty-six years old, was fatally burned and several persons were injured this afternoon in a fire in a three-story building. Thomas G. Frothingham and William Smith of Frothingham Co., who were cut off by the fire, leaped from the third-story window.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Secretary Long has practically decided upon the make-up of the Schley court of inquiry, which will meet in Washington, Sept. 12. This morning he announced that he had selected Admiral Dewey and Rear Admirals Kimberly and Benham, but sent these officers no official notification of their selection.

DAVENPORT, Iowa, July 25 -- Fire laid waste an area of sawmills and residence property in Davenport this evening equal to twenty ordinary city blocks. The flames started in a big pile of kindling wood of the Rock Island Fuel Company, on the levee. A brisk wind was blowing, which carried the flames directly across the immense lumber yards of the Weyerhause-Denkmann Company, which were soon a seething mass of flames.
BERLIN, July 25 -- Ignace Paderewski arrived in Berlin to-night. The papers assert that he is negotiating for a performance of his opera, "Manru," at the Royal Opera.
CHICAGO, July 25 -- Twenty cents discount was the rate on New York exchange to-day. Money for call and time loans could be had at 4 1/2@5per cent.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 25 -- Without Calling either the accused or his wife as Witnesses, the defense in the case of Robert Stewart Fosburgh, charged with the killing of his sister, May, rested this afternoon after the defendant's mother had told her story of the events of the night on which her daughter was done to death.

NEWARK, N.J., July 25 -- The Rev. John J. O'Connor, formerly pastor of St. Joseph's Church, was to-day consecrated Bishop of the Diocese of Newark. The consecration service was held in St. Patrick's Cathedral. This was the second time that this old building has been the scene of such a service.

Three Sergeants were among the culprits who faced Deputy Commissioner Devery at the trial of delinquent policemen at headquarters yesterday, and they received no more consideration than those of less rank, rank.

All social interest centres to-day in Newport, where there will be a great number of entertainments, including the vaudeville to be given by Mrs. Stuyvesant Fish. A number of hostesses, including Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt, Mrs. Hermann Oelrichs, and Mrs. Gerry, will give dinners before this entertainment and then take their guests to Mrs. Fish's home, the Crossways.
