ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 5.-- John Walster, an expert oil well shooter, and his assistant, William Taylor, by accident this morning escaped death. They had been hired to shoot an oil well on the farm of George Wilson at Wellsville, and took with them almost 300 quarts of nitro-glycerine.
Controller Coler has decided that it is me that he should know just how many arsons are in the employ of the city, the salaries paid, and where there have been increases.

LONDON, Aug. 6 -- All the London papers appear to-day with mourning borders, and all publish editorials expressing deep sympathy with the two mourning royal houses, extolling the virtues of the Empress Frederick, and referring generally to the great difficulties incidental to her relations with the German Court, especially the bitterness displayed toward her by Bismarck.

Alfred Kaiser, a telegraph operator in charge of the Western Unon Telegraph office at the Claremont Avenue station of the Central Railroad, Jersey City, was arrested yesterday on a warrant obtained by Chief of Police Benjamin Murphy, charging him with aiding and abetting an alleged green-goods swindler named William Gray.

H. Morton Moore, builder, of 211 West One Hundred and Eleventh Street, has filed a petition in bankruptcy, with liabilities of $475,449 and no assets. Of the liabilities, $446,000 is for loans on bonds and mortgage, on which he is individually liable on some and jointly liable on others with Ida E. Moore and Margaret Hemple, and the balance of the liabilities is principally for building materials, contracted from 1896 to 1901 to forty-two creditors.

PORT OP SPAIN, Trinidad, July 31 -- President Castro has issued a proclamation to the Venezuelans, in which he recites the invasion "by an army of Colombians commanded by the traitor Carlos Rangel Calviras," tells of his reasons for announcing martial law, and asks the support of all patriotic sons of Venezuela.

William E. Whiteman, fifty-four years old, a wealthy dealer in milk bottles, whose place of business was at 144 Chambers Street, was found dead in his apartments at 32 East Forty-fifth Street last night under somewhat peculiar circumstances.

Dr. Alvah H. Doty, Health Officer of this port, began yesterday active work in what is to be a scientific object lesson in the destruction of mosquitoes. The operations will be confined to the basin in which is the malaria-infected village of Concord, S.I., and will end on Wednesday or Thursday.

The application of James F. Madden, a taxpayer, to continue an injunction granted by Justice Blanchard restraining the Board of Estimate and Apportionment, the New York Sanitary Utilization Company, and Commissioner Nagle from carrying out the agreement with the Utilization Company for the disposition of the city's garbage came up for argument before Justice Gildersleeve in the Supreme Court yesterday afternoon.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and Is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.
CRONBERG, Aug. 5 -- The Dowager Empress Frederick died at 6:15 o'clock this evening. The end was unexpectedly sudden. At 4 o'clock the physicians had reported no change in the patient's condition.

A curious tale was unfolded last night before Justice of the Peace Francios at North Bergen. It was the story of two women who wanted to hang a man. The man bared portions of his body to show the Court large welts where he had been beaten with rope ends.
A.S. Lampheor has sold for Hew Miller the seven-story apartment hotel 28 West Twenty-sixth Street, 25 by 98.9.

Army. First Lieut. John A. Murtagh, Assistant Surgeon, is detailed as a member of the examining oard convened at the Presidio of San Francisco, vice First Lieut. Christopher C. Collins, Assistant Surgeon, relieved.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5 -- That the peculiar insanity of the late Frank Howard Collier resulted from a blow received on the head from a supposed political antagonist several years go was practically decided to-day by several physicians, who removed Collier's brain for the purpose of a careful examination.

In old Westchester village, on the Mapes estate, close to the Van Nest railroad station, there has recently sprung up a thickly populated settlement of 150 two-story-and-attic frame houses of modern design. More than thirty of these are occupied by policemen and their families, for they are ideal suburban residences for men whose incomes amount to the pay of the city's guardians.
LONDON, Aug. 6 -- The naval manoeuvres were suddenly ended yesterday afternoon by orders from the Admiralty, and the enemy's fleet was declared the victor.

Much more activity appeared on the curb yesterday than on any day since the beginning of last week. Prices, however, were generally weak, and in most of the active issues quotations at the close were considerably below those of Saturday. The greater activity, accompanied by rather sharp declines, suggested that the general outlook induced many to liquidate their holdings in some of the more active issues notably the Can stocks and the Tobacco bonds.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 5 -- The first day's races in the National amateur championship meet of the National Cycling Association were held in the Stadium, at the Pan-American Exposition, this afternoon before a crowd that half filled the mammoth amphitheatre. The races well merited the large attendance.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- Notwithstanding the recent order of the Navy Department that officers must not discuss the Sampson-Schley controversy, naval officers who do not ask that their names shall be used do not hesitate to discuss some new aspects of the case.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 5 -- A terrific explosion in a block of six buildings on Locust Street above Tenth to-night completely wrecked five of the structures and caused the death of two persons. Over fifty others were more or less seriously injured. It is estimated that at least thirty-five persons were in the five buildings when the explosion occurred, and the exact number of dead is not known.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- For the last two days there has been an industrious revamping of an old story, published several weeks ago, about a letter written by ex-Secretary of the Navy Chandler to Secretary Long complaining of certain assertions and alleged abusive epithets referring to Mr. Chandler contained in Rear Admiral Evans's book, "A Sailor's Log."

PATERSON, N.J., Aug. 5 -- The people of Greenwood Lake Glens, a railroad station on the Greenwood Lake Railroad, near Sterling Forests, are stirred up over the death by poison of Hattie Cassell, seventeen years old.
ST. NICHOLAS GARDEN -- The Kaltenborn concerts maintain their popularity.

Because the parents of the girl he wishes to marry refuse their consent, Ottavio Arizovino, a good-looking young Italian, compelled them to produce her in the Supreme Court yesterday in response to a writ of habeas corpus. Concetta Colangelo is the young woman, and she lives with her father, Michael, and mother, Emanuele Colangelo, at 649 Morris Avenue.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Aug. 5.-- The body of Bishop Littlejohn, which arrived here from Williamstown, Mass., at midnight last night, is now lying in state in the Seo House, the late residence of Bishop Littlejohn. It will be In state to-morrow from 9 A.M. until 10 A.M., where it can be seen by the clergy and friends of the family.
BOSTON, Aug. 5 -- The loaning rate at the Clearing House to-day was 3 per cent., and New York funds sold at 20c discount. Exchanges, $17,470,144; balances, $1,341,801.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 5 -- The wholesale dry goods house of Hood, Foulkrod Co. has ceased to exist, after a business career of seventy-eight years. Having been unsuccessful in renewing its lease of the store at Eleventh and Market Streets, and having no other suitable place to move into without curtailing its trade, the firm concluded to go out of business.

On a side path in Washington Square, facing a vulgarly ornate frame cottage which has some purpose in connection with the administration of the park and the storage of lawn mowers, rakes, wheelbarrows, and the like, stands the beautiful memorial bust of ALEXANDER LYMAN HOLLEY, on a pedestal of unusual excellence.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Mr. Dawes, the Controller of the Currency, has issued the following statement regarding the results of the passage of the act of March 4, 1900:

SAVANNAH, Ga., Aug. 5 -- District Attorney Erwin to-day filed in the United States Court for the Southern District of Georgia an attachment suit against all of the property of ex-Capt. Oberlin M. Carter within the jurisdiction of the court. Carter's former attorneys here are made parties to the suit for purposes of holding certain funds supposed to be in their hands paid on notes in Carter's favor.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 5 -- A long, tedious race of twelve miles out and back with the wind at all times very light and nearly always abeam was won to-day in the ninety-foot yawl class by the Navahoe and in the seventy-foot class by the Rainbow.

The statement that Receiver Naylor has in his possession an alleged contract tending to show that James Shevlin, ex-Senator John McCarty, and Thomas F. Nevins had entered into a stock speculative pool with G. Edward Graff as their representative, and had therefore been acting in the nature of partners of the concern of G. Edward Graff Co., gave rise to some interesting talk yesterday among those interested in the case.

PITTSBURG, Aug. 6. -- President Shaffer of the Amalgamated Association this evening issued the long-talked-of general strike order, to take effect after the last turn of the mills on Aug. 10. The strike call includes practically all Amalgamated men in the United States Steel Corporation's employ not now on strike.

Detective George Bissert of Capt. Diamond's precinct, who was convicted last Thursday of accepting a $550 bribe from a Stuyvesant Street disorderly house keeper, will be arraigned for sentence before Recorder Goff, in General Sessions, to-day. The maximum penalty for the crime of which Bissert is convicted is ten years' imprisonment or a fine of $500, or both.
WORCESTER, Mass., Aug. 6. -- The August meeting of the Driving Park Company opened at the Greendale track this afternoon with the 2:17 pace, 2:33 trot, and 2:32 pace on the card.

TAMPA, Fla., Aug. 6. -- Eighteen leaders of the Resistencia Cigarmakers' Union have been seized and spirited away. A number were picked up to-day about the Court House. It is impossible to learn what becomes of these men, many of whom have been prominent here in labor circles. Those to whom the matter was intrusted declared, however, that they are being sent where they cannot get back to Tampa in a long time.

NEWPORT, Aug. 6. -- The leading social event to-night was the dinner dance given by Mr. and Mrs. Charles M. Oelrichs in honor of their daughter, Miss Lily Oelrichs, and her fiance, Peter D. Martin of San Francisco. The entertainment was given at the Clambake club at Easton's Point, which is becoming more and more popular for dinners and other social events.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 6. -- The resourcefulness of the tennis experts gathered here was tried to-day in the opening matches of the Long Island championship tournament on the courts of the Meadow Club. The turf of the courts was wet from the drizzling rain, which was blown across with the ocean mist by the strong breeze from the ocean.

After being promoted from the position of office boy to that of a trusted stock clerk, Benjamin J. Scheiber, twenty years old, of 514 Second Avenue, Jersey City, was arrested yesterday and confessed, the police said, to stealing over $2,500 worth of goods from his employer. August Torchia, thirty-five years old, of 67 Fifth Avenue, Brooklyn, was also arrested, charged with receiving the stolen articles.

LAWTON, Oklahoma, Aug. 6. -- When Miss Mattie Beals, who drew No. 2 in the great Indian land lottery, stepped up to the booth where the Government officials were ready to record her choice of land, she met with the bitterest disappointment of her life. In front of her was James R. Wood, the very luckiest of all the homeseekers, for he had drawn No.1 and had first choice.

The cruiser Columbia, which is to be used temporarily as a receiving ship in place of the old Vermont, arrived at the Brooklyn Navy Yard yesterday from Philadelphia, after a rather hard trip. Some of the sea valves of the cruiser became loosened after she left Philadelphia, and considerable water was let into the interior compartments.
Army. Second Lieut. Norris Stayton, Artillery Corps, is attached to the Fifty-first Company, Coast Artillery, and will join that company at Fort Hamilton, N.Y.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Aug. 6. -- The Selby Smelting and Lead Company has been robbed of about $280,000 worth, of gold bullion. The theft occurred some time last night and was not discovered until morning. The thieves tunneled from outside the building to beneath the vault at the Selby works, which are located on the bay shore, about thirty miles from San Francisco.

VICTORIA, B.C., Aug. 6. -- From an unimpeachable source, the Nagasaki papers say they learn that Gen. Gribski, the military Governor of Blagovestchensk, committed suicide on July 14 as he was approaching that city on his return from St. Petersburg.

Herman Colell, wholesale dealer in tobacco at 10 Chatham Square, has filed a petition in bankruptcy, with liabilities $94,474, and assets $50,072. Of the liabilities $75,204 are secured, $9,269 unsecured, and $10,000 accommodation paper. The assets consist of real estate, 1,023 Third Avenue, Brooklyn, $7,000, mortgaged for $8,500; accounts, $39,725; stock on hand, $8,000; equity in tobacco pledged unknown; fixtures, $100; shares of stock of the Bedell Leaf Tobacco Company, $4,000; cash. $247.

The officers of the different Republican committees in Greater New York met informally yesterday afternoon at 1 Madison Square to make arrangements for the holding of the meetings of the committees to call conventions.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 6. -- A conference was held at the Lafayette Hotel to-day of representatives of the six reform organizations of the city, at which it was resolved that all of the organizations should support a full fusion ticket, State and city, to be run under the name of the Union Party.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. -- A few days ago the Treasury gave expression to the opinion that National banks could be organized in Porto Rico, under the authority of the Foraker law, provided officers could be found who were eligible under the terms of the National banking law, applied to Porto Rico.

Through the completion of the heavy new bridges over the Hackensack and the Passaic Rivers, the Lackawanna Railroad has been enabled to run much heavier equipment over its Morris and Essex Division. The first tangible benefit due to these improvements is now to result to the inhabitants of Newark, the Oranges, Morristown, and other important suburban towns along the Lackawanna.

The Board of Commissioners of Cook County, Illinois, which, as is generally known, means the City of Chicago and its environs, is making it unpleasant for the Judges of the Circuit and Superior Courts because these gentlemen follow the judicial custom and indulge themselves in vacations of unreasonable length, to the neglect of public business.

BOSTON, Aug. 6. -- Perfect playing of the hit-and-run order enabled Boston to defeat Philadelphia in to-day's baseball game. The visitors could do nothing with Dineen's delivery except in two innings, the second and ninth. Long and Lowe fielded brilliantly. The score:

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 6. -- Ben de Lamos, a United States prisoner from Alabama, in the Ohio Penitentiary here, is preparing a unique request to the United States authorities. He offers to give a bond for $100,000 if permitted to attend the Grand Army of the Republic encampment at Cleveland.
LONDON, Aug. 7. -- The House of Commons last night discussed a vote of u6,500,000 as a grant in aid of the Transvaal and Orange River Colonies.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 6. -- The dullness in the New York stock market caused weakness here, where the dealings were confined largely to the Readings and the Steel stocks. The declaration of a 2 per cent. dividend on Reading first preferred helped the Reading group, and they closed higher.

A suit over a note which is said by lawyers to be without precedent has been brought by R.S. Howard, a traveling salesman of this city, against the Bank of the Metropolis. Nominally the suit is for $5,000 damages. The case in another phase has been tried with another defendant, but was thrown out because of an error that did not permit the question at issue to be passed upon.

Reports from Newport, Bar Harbor, Southampton, and other resorts indicate that the season has reached its gayest stage. At Saratoga the races are attracting many, some of whom, like the Clarence Mackays, have left Newport for this season of sport. Polo is to begin shortly at Saratoga, and at Richfield Springs there will be held this week a kermess.

"We have caught the anopheles, the malaria-spreading mosquito, red-handed," said Dr. Alvah H. Doty, the health officer of this port, with enthusiasm, last night." It has been an important day on that account. Hitherto we have had the mature and larval anopheles in the minority, with specimens of the culicidae, but not in circumstances that associate it directly with malaria.

Dealings in securities yesterday were materially reduced in volume, less than 450,000 shares being traded in, but there was a distinctly favorable change in speculative sentiment. Early encouragement was afforded by the quotations from London, which were substantially above New York parity for all active issues, with the single exception of United States Steel.

BUFFALO, Aug. 6. -- On a track pronounced by visiting horsemen to be one of the best and fastest they have found this year, the Grand Circuit harness meeting of the Buffalo Driving Club opened to-day, and was full of interesting events. The attendance, too, was good, about 5,000 persons being present.
LONDON, Aug. 6. -- Supplies of money were fairly large to-day, notwithstanding the fact that the bulk of the recent heavy borrowing from the Bank of England had been repaid. Discounts were steady.

Commissioner George Kraft of the State Civil Service Board yesterday made an investigation into the complaints against George E. Waldo, as Commissioner of Records of Kings County, by William Doggrell. Doggrell held a position as computer in the records office up to last Fall, when he was suspended by Commissioner Waldo.

There is a great searching of heart going on at present, among the officers of the United States Army, about the appearance of the troops of that body. They may be good when it is a question of fighting; we know perfectly well that they are good. But it is admitted that "nobody would think it to look at them."

We are indebted to an anonymous correspondent, evidently a zealous and disinterested female devotee, for a pamphlet containing the prospectus of a Summer school of Christian Science, with a syllabus of the lectures and an outline of the course of study. To say that it interests us is to convey a very imperfect idea of the enthusiasm which this prospectus inspires.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. -- Hezekiah A. Gudger, United States Consul General at Panama, to-day cabled the State Department the following:

The courtship troubles of Ottavio Anzevino and young Concetta Colangelo ended suddenly in their wedding in the Supreme Court by Justice McAdam yesterday, where the girl was produced by her father and his lawyer in obedience to a writ of habeas corpus obtained by her sweetheart, who charged that she was virtually held a prisoner in her home because of her desire to become his wife.

In the outside market yesterday there was a considerable falling off from the activity of Monday, but at the same time prices in the case of some of the active stocks moved up substantially. These rallies followed naturally upon the sharp declines of the opening day of the week, but beyond these recoveries the market showed little sign of any new strength.

The postponed Newport series races of the New York Yacht Club will be sailed at Newport on Aug. 10, 12, and 14. Next Saturday will mark the first meeting of Constitution with Columbia since the alterations to Constitution's masts, and the renewed struggles of the big sloops will be watched with great interest by yachtsmen to note what improvement has been gained.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6. -- William Cecil Price, Treasurer of the United States under President Buchanan, died here to-day at the home of his son-in-law, William S. Newberry, aged eighty-six years. Mr. Price settled in Springfield, Mo., in the early thirties. He became prominent in the ranks of the Democratic Party, and when Buchanan was elected he was chosen United States Treasurer.

The Rev. Dr. Arthur B. Kinsolving, rector of Christ Church, Clinton Avenue, Brooklyn, is said to be more likely than any other man to succeed the late Bishop Littlejohn. Two points appear to be pretty well settled. One is that the convention to elect a new Bishop will be held at an early date, probably early in November.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Aug. 6. -- Senator McLaurin's reply to the State Democratic Executive Committee's action of July 25 condemning his course in the Senate and demanding his resignation was received today. It contains about 5,000 words, devoted to ridiculing the committee and pouring hot shot into Senator Tillman. The letter is, in part, as follows:

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 6. -- The Newport City Council this evening granted permission for the automobile races to be held on Friday afternoon, Aug. 30, on Ocean Avenue, in spite of the protests of Theodore M. Davies, Samuel E. Huntington, and Alexander Agassiz, owners and occupants of houses on that avenue.

CRONBERG, Aug. 6. -- Emperor William had a long conference with Count von Bulow to-day regarding the arrangements for the funeral of Dowager Empress Frederick. The Emperor later drove from Homburg to Schloss Friedrichshof, and soon after his arrival at the Schloss the following official announcement was made:

BALTIMORE, Aug. 6. -- Republicans met here in State Convention to-day, nominated Hermann S. Platt of Baltimore for State Controller and Thomas Parran of Calvert County for Clerk of the Court of Appeals, and adopted a platform which clearly defines the issues upon which the fight will be made against Arthur P. Gorman to defeat him in his aspirations to return to the United States Senate.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. -- The vacancy in the Schley court of inquiry caused by the inability of Rear Admiral Kimberly to serve on account of ill-health has been filled by the selection of Rear Admiral Henry L. Howison, whose appointment was announced by Assistant Secretary Hackett to-day. At the same time it was announced that this appointment would be agreeable to Admiral Schley.

Developments yesterday indicated a possibility that the contract entered into beween the city and the New York Sanitary Utilization Company for the disposal of the garbage of the Borough at Manhattan might be declared void. The corporations opposing the Sanitary Utilization Company understand that their bids were many thousands of dollars lower than the one accepted, and are prepared to put up a stiff fight to secure the annulment of the contract.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. -- The Weather Bureau's weekly report of crop conditions is as follows:

For several days past complaints have been reaching the National Wholesale Lumber Dealers' Association, at 66 Broadway, that a coal and ice company doing business in Hoboken, N.J., had been ordering large consignments of lumber, potatoes, grain, and hay, and that the shippers had sent them to the company, but had not received any compensation therefor.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 6. -- Mrs. James W. Gerard, nee Daily, gave her first large dinner party to-night. It was a brilliant affair, and the most notable event of the kind thus far this season. It was given at the Malvern in the palm garden.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6. -- While union molders are walking the streets because their employers refuse to pay them $3 a day, these same employers voted to-day to replace them with non-union men, who are to receive wages of $4.50 and $4.75 a day. The decision of the manufacturers to pay the higher rate to non-union men was reached at a meeting of the local organization of the National Founders' Association.

LONDON, Aug. 6. -- The remaining members of the Pennsylvania University crew which took part in the Henley regatta -- Ralph R. Zane, F.L. Davenport, and L.J. Smith -- sailed for the United States to-day. They declared it was not likely that Pennsylvania University would enter another crew in the regatta for several years, at least.

ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 6. -- Guarded by three companies of State militia called out by Gov. Candler for his protection, Raymond Ross, a negro charged with assaulting Mrs. Miller, was carried to Canton, Ga., from this place to-day to stand his trial. A special session of the Cherokee Court was called by Judge Gober, who asked for the troops from Gov. Candler.

Three steam yachts anchored off Twenty-sixth Street, East River, at the anchorage of the New York Yacht Club, were in collision at flood tide yesterday morning. The yachts were J. Pierpont Morgan's Corsair. Howard C. Smith's Saghaya, and Frank Tilford's Norman.

BUFFALO, Aug. 6. -- Rain interrupted a splendid programme of bicycle races at the Stadium this afternoon. It was the second day of the two weeks' meet of the fastest amateur and professional riders of the country under the auspices of the Pan-American Exposition and the National Cycling Association.

According to a dispatch received from Washington on Monday, the Secretary of the Treasury informed representatives of the Rapid Transit Commission in this city that he had no right to give them permanent permission to build the tunnel in such a way as to interfere with the Post Office vaults at the easterly end of Mail Street, off the northeast corner of the Federal Building.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. -- Senator Stewart of Nevada is here on a midsummer visit, and has discoursed cheerfully about Senator Hanna as a Presidential candidate in 1904, and somewhat gloomily about the attempt made now and then to revive the free silver issue. He is a great admirer of Mr. Hanna, and is of the opinion that the people will acquire a taste for him when they know him better.

NARRAGANSETT PIER, R.I., Aug. 6. -- Myopia won the first polo game in the series for the Point Judith Cups this afternoon, defeating Philadelphia Country Club 15 to 5 3/4 goals. It was a lively game, with a large audience to applaud the dashing plays of Kennedy and Rosengarten. Philadelphia lost through loose team work, the brilliant work of the two players mentioned really going to naught as far as scoring was concerned.
M. L. Hess have sold for Thomas Nelson to Daniel B. Freedman 63 to 69 East Eighty-second Street, four four-story brownstone-front dwellings, each 20 by 102.2, between Madison and Park Avenues.

PATERSON, N.J., Aug. 6. -- The loomfixers, twisters, weavers, and warpers on strike at the Enterprise Mill here sent notices to the firm to-night that if their demands were not granted by Thursday they would call out the same line of workers at the Reynoldsville (Penn.) Mill, run by the company.
SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 6. -- The second day's racing here was uneventful. It towered during the afternoon, but not enough to affect the track to any extent.
WESTCHESTER, Penn., Aug. 6. -- David Hood, a banker, dropped dead in the bathroom of his residence here to-day. He was about sixty-five years of age.

The Right Rev. Abram Newkirk Littlejohn, D.D., LL.D., Bishop of Long Island, was buried yesterday in the family plot at Great Neck, L.I., after funeral services of a most impressive character, at which eleven Bishops and nearly 150 clergymen assisted, at the Cathedral of the Incarnation, Garden City.

BRUSSELS, Aug. 7. --Mr. Chambers, a representative of American capitalists, who is negotiating to acquire the Charleroi Glass Works, had a three hours' conference with the proprietors of the works this afternoon. The result of the meeting was not announced. The glass company owns forty furnaces and values them at 500,000f. each.

BERLIN, Aug. 7 -- Prices on the Boerse to-day were irregular. Home funds were weaker. Foreign securities were firm, except Spanish fours, which declined. Bank shares were active. Iron was in good demand on the more favorable iron trade reports. Best prices were not maintained, owing to realizations.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 7 -- In the lawn tennis tournament for the Long Island championship on the courts of the Meadow Club, at this place, the first round of the men's championship singles was completed late this afternoon, with the result that C.F. Watson. Jr., Stewart Waller, Richard Stevens, and Ford Huntington won places in the semi-final round.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 7 -- The four days' meeting of the Hudson River Driving Park Association opened to-day, when the trotting and pacing races, postponed from yesterday, were run off. The track was in excellent condition and good time was made, but the attendance, owing to the threatening weather, was small.

BAR HARBOR, Aug. 7 -- The Malvern ball to-night marked the busiest day society has had thus far this season. It was the event of the week, more than 300 persons being present. A large number of dinner parties were given previously, both at the inn and among the cottagers.

SCRANTON, Penn., Aug. 7. -- The Executive Boards of Districts Nos. 1, 7, and 9 of the United Mine Workers of America have serious questions to determine at the important joint conference which they have called for to-morrow at Hazleton.

PITTSBURG, Aug. 7. -- Secretary Williams to-day explained the cause of the delay in issuing the strike order. He said that if the order had been sent out when negotiations were broken off last Saturday the sudden closing of the steel mills would have resulted in serious loss of property to the United States Steel Corporation.

BOSTON, Aug. 7 -- At the Clearing House this morning money between the banks was in good demand, both old and new money being quoted at 4 per cent. This advance from 3 per cent. does not entirely represent an increased strength in money. The fact is, some of the larger banks are more and more indisposed to loan their balances at the Clearing House.

The tax rate for this city in the year 1901 has been virtually settled, and it will be .696 of 1 per cent higher than it was last year in this borough. The other boroughs also show an increase. The new rate is embodied in the report to the Council and Board of Aldermen yesterday of the Joint Finance Committee.
LONDON, Aug. 7 -- The abundance of money in the market tends to depress discounts, but bill buyers are awaiting developments.

In order to save the lives of a number of children, John Biggers, driver of Fire Engine 74, which was responding to an alarm from its headquarters at 204 West Seventy-seventh Street yesterday morning, drove his triple team through a brick wall at the foot of West Sixty-ninth Street, where there is a sheer drop of thirty feet to the tracks of the New York Central Railroad.

Responsibility for the long delay in advertising for bids for the disposal of garbage for Manhattan and the Bronx yesterday reverted to Commissioner Nagle. It was learned that the Commissioner sent out the five-year contract for garbage disposal for examination and approval on April 20, and it was returned to the Street Cleaning Department approved on May 17.

It was an off day yesterday for the Concord, S.I., malaria infected district because of the rain. This, however, did not interfere with the collection of samples of water with the larvae of gnats or culicidae, some of which may develop the anopheles, or malaria-spreading mosquito. Health Officer Alvah H. Doty secured five live specimens of anopheles in the house of the malaria-stricken family from which four, dead specimens were secured on Tuesday.

NARRAGANSETT PIER, R.I., Aug. 7 -- Westchester won the Rhode Island polo cups to-day by defeating Point Judith 10 1/2 to 10 in the final game of the series. Rain came down heavily all the forenoon, and the field was soggy. As on Monday La Montagne proved a great goal-getter for Point Judith.

NEWPORT, Aug. 7 -- Mrs. Frederick W. Vanderbilt, for the ninth successive year, to-day entertained the members of Whomsoever Circle of King's Daughters, of which she is a member, and with whom she worked. The entertainment consisted of a luncheon and musicale at the Vanderbilt villa, at Rough Point.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 7. -- Fred J. Williams, Vice President of the Amalgamated Association of Iron and Steel and Tin Workers, for this district, returned from Pittsburg and New York to-day, where he had been in attendance upon the conference of the Executive Board of that association.

PITTSBURG, Aug. 7. -- In the big stee strike honors are easy in this section to-night. The Amalgamated Association succeeded in closing down the big steel plan at Newcastle, and the manufacturers partially broke the strike by starting up the Clark mill in this city. Up to this hour not the slightest trouble has occurred at any point in this immediate territory.

Two small fires on the White Star liner Majestic, which arrived from Liverpool yesterday afternoon, were discovered in the linen closet of that vessel early in the morning. Neither was serious, and the fire crew had no difficulty whatever in getting both under control as soon as they were located.

It is natural that Gen. MAXIMO GOMEZ should describe as "madness" the report that while in this country he had spoken in favor of the annexation of Cuba to the United States. It would be impossible for Gen. GOMEZ to remain in politics in Cuba if it were known that he is an annexationist.

The Henley regatta seems so long ago that Americans may well be surprised to learn that at the date of the last English mails it was a prominent topic for writers of letters to English newspapers, fairly dividing honors with the concentration camps in South Africa, and the burning question whether a pound a week is enough to get married on.

Three boys -- Lester Schultz, twelve years old, of 254 South Third Street, Brooklyn; William Persky, ten years old, of 251 South Third Street, and Harry Buxhand, twelve years old, whose parents live on Marcy Avenue, near South Third Street -- were badly shocked and burned on the hands yesterday afternoon while swinging on a broken telegraph wire at Marcy Avenue and South Third Street which came in contact with a trolley feed wire.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial to-day as to the Junior Senator from South Carolina will have wide reading. What he shall elect as his course, now that the Democratic State Committee has called for his resignation, will show the temper of the man, whether he is "made of sterner stuff" out of which statesmen are fashioned.

Capt. Thomas J. Diamond's ward man, George Bissert, convicted of accepting a bribe from a Stuyvesant Street disorderly house keeper, was not sentenced by Recorder Goff in General Sessions yesterday, although he demanded, through his counsel, that a sentence be pronounced upon him at once.
CEDAR RAPIDS., Iowa, Aug. 7. -- The Iowa Republican State Convention yesterday nominated this ticket for the coming State election:

PERTH AMBOY, N.J., Aug. 7 -- One man was killed and three injured by the blowing up of a vat of creosote in the works of the American Wood Preserving Company here to-day. The vat was sixty feet long and eight feet in diameter. It lay lengthwise. Into it the wood to be preserved was placed.

Henry Neuenchaglen, who says he lives at 165 East Eighty-fourth Street, was remanded by Magistrate Brann in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday morning until to-morrow to enable Chief of Police Frank Titus of Englewood, N.J., to secure a requisition to take him to New Jersey to be tried there on the charge of horse stealing.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- No report has been received at the Navy Department regarding the condition of the Columbia on her arrival at the Brooklyn Navy Yard, and the department officials are unanimous in expressing the opinion that she is not in as bad shape as reported. One of them said: "There seems to be a movement to 'knock' the Columbia."

President SHAFFER'S order to strike gives no convincing statement of reasons. The members of the Amalgamated Association "and other union men in name and heart" are called upon "to join the movement to fight for labor's rights." What rights? The foundation rights of labor are, first, to get employment at the highest obtainable wages, and, second, to organize in unions or associations for better protection and the common welfare.
PITTSBURG, Aug. 7. -- The Times to-morrow will say:

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 7 -- Allan A. Hinman is the step-son of Mrs. Lillis A. Hinman, a bookkeeper in the State Excise Department in this city. Mrs. Hinman brought her family here from Wellsville, Chenango County, five years ago. Subsequently Allan secured employment in New York City.

The temporary withdrawal from business activity of the plunger who has gained on the Chicago Board of Trade the popular title of Corn King may serve to show who organized the recent corn panic and for what purpose it was engineered. If the showers concerning which it was so difficult to get information for several days had held off another fortnight the corn speculators would have made a great deal of money.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- An order was issued by Acting Secretary of the Navy Hackett to-day for the gunboat Machias, now at the Boston Navy Yard, to proceed without delay to Hampton Roads and there to prepare for departure to Colon, near the eastern terminus of the Panama Railroad.

NEW LONDON, Aug. 7 -- The Pequot Chapel in the Pequot Summer colony was the scene of a brilliant naval wedding at 4:30 o'clock this afternoon. Miss Esther Grubb Beall, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Bond Beall of New York, became the wife of Lieut. George Tucker Smith of the United States Navy.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 7. -- The Central Passenger Association, embracing representatives of the leading railways east of the Mississippi River, has been in session at Lakewood, on Chautauqua Lake, to-day. The principal business transacted was the establishment of a schedule of passenger rates from all points to the Pan-American Exposition at Buffalo.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- The Department of Justice has not authorized the District Attorney of Indiana to compel witnesses to testify against C.F.W. Neely, awaiting trial for embezzling postal funds in Havana. The testimony now being gathered is purely ex parte and voluntary. It will not be introduced as evidence in the trial.
BERLIN, Aug. 7. -- The German antarctic expedition, under the leadership of Prof. Ehrich von Drygalski of Berlin, noted for his study of arctic glaciers, will sail from Kiel on Aug. 11.

The cooler weather brought an unusual number of fashionable people to town yesterday. Mrs. Seth Barton French was with her mother, Mrs. Falker Fearn. Mrs. French came in from Newport, where she is spending the Summer. Mrs. Richard Lounsberry, the Misses Ives, and Miss Louise McAllister were also in town.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7 -- "No more corn pools for me," said George H. Phillips to-day. "I knew I was standing over a can of gunpowder all the time, and it was only by the merest chance that I escaped total annihilation. I was forced into the May pool, but I won't be forced into another. They're too risky and not at all to my liking."

The Greater New York Development Company was incorporated at Albany yesterday, with a capital stock of $4,000,000, to deal generally in real estate. The Directors for the first year are William E. Harmon and Leonidas Keever of New York, Frank Bailey of Brooklyn, John H. Storer, Arthur Lyman, Robert T. Paine, Second; Herbert Lyman and Robert T. Paine, Jr., of Boston, and Russell Tyson of Chicago.

A.L. Mordecai Son have sold for Henry L. Felt, from the plans, the twelve-story apartment hotel to be erected on the south side of Forty-seventh Street, 216.8 feet east of Broadway, on a plot 70.10 by 100.5. Mr. Felt purchased the site from the Longacre Realty Company only ft. few weeks ago, through Messrs. Mordecai Son, and the plans for the new structure have just been filed.

BUFFALO, Aug. 7 -- A crowd of 6,000 persons witnessed the National amateur championship bicycle meet to-day on the new four-lap board track in the Stadium of the Pan-American Exposition. The features were the ease with which Marcus Hurley of the New York Athletic Club disposed of Frank Denny in the final of the one-third-mile championship, the first race on the card.

BOSTON, Aug. 7 -- One world's record was broken at Charles River Park to-night, it being in the first heat, one mile, of the match race between Albert Champion and "Major" Taylor, the former covering the mile in 1:29 4-5 from a flying start. The previous record was 1:30, held by "Jimmy" Michael.

The St. Louis Exposition of 1903 has begun preparations early, but none too early, by appointing certain important Directors. F. Wellington Ruckstuhl having been made Director of Sculpture, a General Director of Art has now been added in the person of Halsey C. Ives, manager of the local Art Museum, who was favorably known for his services at the Chicago World's Fair.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Figures have just been compiled bringing down to date statistics showing the sources and amount of agricultural imports into the United States. Among the countries from which the United States purchased agricultural products during 1900 Brazil, the leading source of our coffee supply, stood foremost.

McKeesport, Penn., contained, according to the census of 1890, twenty thousand and odd hundred inhabitants. At any rate, it is quite big enough to contain a considerable proportion of civilized citizens. Every one of these citizens must be as deeply ashamed of the Mayoralty of Mr. R.J. BLACK as the like citizens of New York are of the Boss-ship of Mr. RICHARD CROKER.

Transactions in the market for outside securities yesterday were smaller than any recorded within recent months. Not since the extremely dull days of last Summer has the market shown as little activity as it did yesterday. The mood at the moment seems to be a waiting one, and both buyers and sellers are withholding from the market.

At the opening of the security market yesterday there was some brief hesitation because of the desire to see what effect would be produced by the issuance of the formal order for a general strike to take effect Aug. 10 by President Shaffer of the Amalgamated Association. The Steel shares declined 3/8 for both the common and preferred, the former touching 39 5/8, and the latter 89.

BERLIN, Aug. 7. -- The return of Count von Waldersee from China has been quite overshadowed as an event of importance by the death of the Dowager Empress. Some of the papers comment on the Field Marshal's career in the Far East in somewhat disappointed tones. His work is highly praised, but, running through the commendation is the admission that the German Nation a year ago greatly misconceived the scope and character of his mission.

The successful run of "Florodora" at the Casino has led to unexpected trouble, which came to light yesterday in the Supreme Court, where Justice O'Gorman, in a suit instituted by John Dunne against Thomas W. Ryley and John C. Fisher, signed an order for the defendants to show cause why an injunction should not be granted restraining them from transferring any rights in or making any contracts with regard to the production.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- W.F. MacLennan, Chief of the Division of Bookkeeping and Warrants of the Treasury Department, has just returned from Honolulu, where he served as agent of the Treasury in paying $4,000,000 of Hawaiian debt assumed by the United States as one of the obligations incurred by annexation.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7. -- The machinist em-, ployers made another unsuccessful effort to-day to break the strike of the union molders, who demanded $3 a day. The employers made special inducements of wages far in advance of those demanded by the unions. Molders were tempted with pay as high as $4.75 a day, while $3 is the figure demanded by the union men.
The Rev. George S. Miner, who has been for some years at the head of a private school system in and around Foochow, China, arrived here yesterday.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Aug. 7. -- Exploding gasoline in the cellar of the house at 17 1/2 Washington Avenue, this city, caused severe burns and injuries to Mrs. Louisa Cuch and her daughter Mary, eleven years old, last night.

The Federal Grand Jury yesterday morning resumed its investigation into the affairs of the Seventh National Bank. Capt. W.S. Ball, and William M. Hardt, one of the experts designated to assist the United States District Attorney in the examination of the books of the bank, went before the jury.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 7 -- The Philadelphia market was weak, though the Readings and United States Steel, following New York, strengthened sharply at the close, after declining early in the day. Philadelphia Company declined 1/4, and Pittsburg Consolidated Traction lost 1 3/4 on a single transaction.
SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 7 -- Horses that can run in the mud without inconvenience had an inning to-day, heavy rains during the previous night having made the track very deep in mire.

PITTSBURG, Aug. 7. -- The steel manufacturers generally do not view the strike order with alarm. The trust officiate preserved the same reticence shown from the beginning of the trouble, but privately commented upon it, refusing to be quoted. One prominent manufacturer said that he was very sorry that President Shaffer had taken the step.

The new Brunswick and Birmingham Railroad will be opened for regular business on Aug. 18, when schedules will go into effect between Brunswick and Savannah without change. Arrangements have been completed for running trains on the Seaboard between Jacksonville and Brunswick, as well as between Savannah and Brunswick.

BERLIN, Aug. 7. -- It has been decided that the body of Dowager Empress Frederick will be deposited in the Friedenskirche (Church of Peace) mausoleum, near Potsdam, in which is the body of Emperor Frederick.

LONDON, Aug. 8. -- The British Consular report regarding trade at Marseilles, issued yesterday, asserts that the most vital recent development, from a British point of view, is the determined attempt of Americans to obtain a monopoly of the coal imports at that port.
A practical joker inserted the following advertisement in a morning newspaper yesterday:
VICTORIA, B.C., Aug. 8. -- Peter Jackson, the famous negro pugilist, died July 23 at a private sanitarium at Roma, near Sydney, N.S.W., of consumption.
LONDON, Aug. 8. -- Money was in active demand to-day in connection with the consols' installment, though the pressure did not equal anticipations.
The associated cycling clubs of the City of New York will meet at the Knickerbocker Athletic Clubhouse, Forty-fifth Street and Madison Avenue, on Monday evening at 8 o'clock.
CHARLES BULL TOWLE, United States Consular agent at Saltillo, Mexico, died on Wednesday. His body will be sent to Boston.

PITTSBURG, Aug. 8. -- The contending sides in the steel strike are centring their energies for a show of strength on the day that the general strike order becomes effective. The United States Steel Corporation is reopening mills closed by the first strike call, and the Amalgamated Association bends its energies to the extension of its membership and to obtain the support and co-operation of the American Federation of Labor.
VIENNA, Aug. 8. -- A dispatch to the Tageblatt from Sterzing, in the Tyrol, announces the death of Gen. Baratteri, the ex-Governor of Erythrea.

William J. Walsh, a lawyer, at 49 Chambers Street, announced yesterday that in behalf of a claimant he was about to bring ejectment proceedings against the present owners of some 280 pieces of property in that part of the town lying between Eleventh and Thirteenth Streets and Fourth and Sixth Avenues: also some lower Fifth Avenue property and large parcels between Thirty-first and Thirty-third Streets and Sixth and Eighth Avenues.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 8. -- At the Crescent Tin Plate Works to-day carpenters were engaged in enecting a large building, which it is said will be used as a boarding house for non-union men to be employed at the plant. Union men visited practically every merchant in Newburg to-day and asked all to decline to sell supplies for the use of the non-union men.

YONKERS, N.Y., Aug. 8. -- Mayor Leslie Sutherland of this city, who is away on his vacation, on Tuesday aided in saving the life of an old man. A friend, who is with the Mayor, has written to Yonkers telling all about it.

There was to have been a march of city officials across the narrow footpath of the new East River Bridge yesterday. It was the day fixed for the official inspection of the structure, and invitations had been extended to Mayor Van Wyck and all the other city officials to make the journey. Mayor Van Wyck declared soon after taking office that he would cross the East River Bridge before he ceased to be Mayor.

BUFFALO, Aug. 8. -- Marcus Hurley of the New York Athletic Club was again the star in to-day's bicycle races in the Pan-American Stadium. He won both the half-mile and mile championships in an easy manner. Hurley won the final heat of the half mile by a length from Ingraham of Chelsea, Mass.

Justice Bischoff yesterday, in refusing to punish Alfred B. Sloane for an alleged contempt in publishing the song "For Exchange," in violation of an injunction obtained by Marcus Witmark and others, musical publishers, considers at some length the composition of "coon songs." The plaintiffs had asserted that they had the exclusive right to publish all of Sloane's musical compositions.
HAVANA, Aug. 8 -- Estrada Palma, in the course of a long letter, to Senor Figueredo, which is published here to-day, makes the following statements:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- Admiral Kempff has forwarded to the Navy Department an official report, thrilling in its details, of the biting off of the leg of Quartermaster S. McKie, third-class, of the gunboat Annapolis by a shark or other sea monster.

The branch of industry which has thus far chiefly felt the effects of the strike of the steel workers is tin plate manufacture. The rolling departments of all the tin plate mills have been closed since July 13, with the single exception of the Monessen plant. The tinning departments are not included in the shut-down, and up to the present time they have had enough black plates to meet exigent current orders.

PARIS, Aug. 9. -- M. Santos-Dumont, the aeronaut, had a narrow escape from death yesterday morning. His balloon burst and fell with tremendous speed. Had it not been that the framework caught in the coping of a building, the plucky Franco-Brazilian would almost certainly have been killed. As it was he was unhurt.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 8. -- Aaron Hawkwark, a laborer, sixty-five years of age, of Trenton, was knocked down in front of his home, 297 Washington Avenue, Woodside, last night by a bicycle ridden by Andrew Hill, a colored man. Hawkwark was so badly hurt that he died this morning. Hill was thrown over the handlebar of his wheel, but was not thought at the time to be much hurt.

The method of the people of Tampa, Fla., in dealing with strike organizers and labor agitators is original and interesting. Eighteen leaders of a local cigarmakers' union have been rounded up and conveyed to parts unknown. The same fate has overtaken the editor of a paper printed in Spanish which made itself unpopular by inciting the cigarmakers to quarrel with their employers.

To-day and to-morrow begins the end of the week rush out of town. There will be more men at Newport within the next ten days than at any other time during the present season. The boat races, the polo, and tennis week coming together will prove a triple attraction. The series of dinners at Newport will give more or less place to dances, which have been rather few and far between.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 8. -- Keen interest was manifested in the harness racing at Elkwood Park this afternoon. It required six heats to decide the 2:20 trot, the opening event on the afternoon's card. W. H. Coville's Marion, who up to the close of the third heat had not made a better showing than fourth, displayed a wonderful burst of speed in the stretch in the fourth and fifth heats.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- Ex-Senator Thurston's avowed favor for Rear Admiral Schley was expressed publicly a day or two ago, and now Senator Burton, from his neighbor State of Kansas, declares in positive language his opinion that whatever the outcome of the naval court of inquiry the people will continue to regard Rear Admiral Schley with favor because he accomplished results.
SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 8. -- Small fields went to the post in each of the five events decided here this afternoon. The track was heavy and holding and the speculation was light.

Fighting in their station house in the presence of an entire platoon will cost Roundsmen John Finley and J.H. Kane their places in the Police Department if the sentence of Deputy Commissioner Devery, who presided at their trial and that of others at Police Headquarters yesterday, is carried out.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- Just before the Navy Department closed to-day, an order was sent to Capt. George C. Reiter of the battleship Wisconsin, now at Anacartes, near the Puget Sound naval station, to proceed to San Francisco, from which point the battleship will be dispatched to Panama, in case the State Department requests the presence of a warship on the Pacific side of the isthmus.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 8. -- About 7,000 persons were disappointed in the exhibition by the champion trotter Cresceus at the Hudson River Driving Park this afternoon. Paced by a running horse and driven by his owner, George H, Ketcham, the champion went his mile in 2:06 1/4. He started shortly after 4 o'clock, after Mr. Ketcham had driven him three warming-up heats in 2:48, 2:32, and 2:17.

Delegates of the rock drillers', engineers', and blacksmiths' unions made a complaint yesterday that men in these trades are employed on the extension to St. Patrick's Cathedral, in Madison Avenue, at less than union wages. A committee has been appointed to ask Archbishop Corrigan to use his influence to have union conditions observed.

The representatives of Tammany Hall yesterday made no attempt to explain why there had been an increase of from 7 to 13 cents per $100 of assessed valuation in the tax rate on an increased assessment roll. But Alderman McInnes of Brooklyn, the minority leader of the Board of Aldermen, proposes to ask some very pertinent questions at the adjourned joint meeting on Wednesday next.

The question why the District Attorney has asked for and obtained a postponement of the sentence of BISSERT, the wardman convicted of blackmailing the keeper of a disorderly house, naturally interests the public. It "advertises mystery and invites speculation." And a natural hypothesis is that the District Attorney hopes, by means of BISSERT's evidence, to net much bigger fish than BISSERT.
ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 8. -- The National Circuit bicycle meet at the athletic grounds this afternoon attracted 3,000 spectators.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- The annual report of Major Gen. MacArthur, dated July 4, 1901, the day that he relinquished command of the Division of the Philippines, has been received at the War Department. In it are given statistics of casualties from May 5, 1900, to June 30, 1901, during which time there were 1,026 meetings between American troops and insurgents: Americans killed, 245; wounded, 490; captured, 118; missing, 20.
BOSTON, Aug. 8. -- Money loaned to-day at the Clearing House at 4 per cent., and New York funds sold at 30c discount, with the demand unimportant. Exchanges, $22,945,212; balances, $1,704,212.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 8. -- Capt. Seymour of the local detective force has disclosed the identity of the man whom the Police Department has in custody on suspicion of being implicated in the robbery of $283,000 worth of gold bullion from the Selby Smelter Works at Vallejo Junction.

After an exciting chase of several blocks, in which they were aided by a motor vehicle, Henry S. Stanford, Jr., a lawyer, with offices at 149 Broadway and living at 324 West Fourteenth Street, and Patrolman Slavin of the Charles Street Station, last night captured an alleged thief in the ferryhouse at the foot of West Fourteenth Street, just as he was about to get aboard a boat for Hoboken.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- Senator Burton of Kansas admits that it may be necessary to make some changes in the tariff at the next session of Congress, but he does not think there is much favorable sentiment in that direction.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 8. -- Owing to an order issued by the Sand Teamsters' Union the drivers on the wagons employed in hauling street sweepings did not report for work to-day, and it was, therefore, useless to send out the sweeping gang. The result is that the streets, especially in the downtown district, are becoming filthy, to the dismay of business men and city officials and the annoyance of passersby.

WASHINGTON, N.J., Aug. 8. -- Addie Smith, fifteen years of age, and Edward Snyder were married yesterday at Belvidere. Snyder is about eight years older than his bride. He is employed at the St. Cloud Hotel. The bride is the daughter of a well-known resident. Yesterday, during the absence of her mother the girl went to the home of the bridegroom's sister and put on a long dress.

Regarding the continued reports of opposition interposed by the New York Central to the North River Bridge plans of the Pennsylvania Railroad, a representative of the latter interests stated yesterday that while the New York Central had not as yet openly objected to the plans, it had not showed a disposition to look favorably on the Pennsylvania plans.

An effort is being made to secure from the United States Government some two millions of dollars, said to be the principal with compound interest of money deposited in Washington by Baron Ludwig Napoleon Dembitzky, who was compelled to leave Poland in 1862 because of his part in the revolutionary movements of the Polish people against the Russian Government.

As far as the amateurs are concerned, the third annual championship of the Western Golf Association, to be held at the Midlothian links from Tuesday to Saturday of next week, will be a trying-out experience to determine how many of the Westerners will come on to the National amateur championship at the Atlantic City Country Club, the second week in September.

District Attorney Philbin announced yesterday that he had received information from a patrolman, now on the force, regarding police affairs in the Fifteenth Police Precinct, which, he expects, will produce a very important effect not only upon the cases of Capt. Thomas J. Diamond and his convicted ward man, George Bissert, but upon many officials higher in authority.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 8. -- The stock market was excessively dull to-day. United States Steel was the feature, following the course in New York. Susquehanna Steel showed extraordinary activity at fractionally lower prices. Cambria Steel was weak and the other local steel stocks lost slightly. Lehigh Valley was slightly higher.

Mysterious features attach to a raid which was made at 1:30 o'clock this morning on the house at 148 West Thirty-third Street, in the Tenderloin precinct, by the Society for the Prevention of Crime, of which Frank Moss is the head. Only one prisoner was taken, Laura Mulaw, twenty-seven years old, a Frenchwoman, yet it is reported that there were several other inmates in the house, who were permitted to go.

The highly protected sugar and tobacco interests of the United States will read with alarm the threat of the Merchants' Union of Havana to go in for annexation and free trade if the protectionists of the Senate refuse to ratify a reasonable treaty of reciprocity with Cuba.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 8. -- There were no very large entertainments in Newport society to-day, except Miss Leary's first reception of the season. Heathe Gregory sang there, and the Misses Kieckhoef rendered a number of instrumental selections. There were tasteful decorations of American Beauty roses in the several rooms and on the lawn at the rear of the house.

QUEENSTOWN, Aug. 8. -- The White Star Line steamer Oceanic, Capt. Cameron, which sailed from Liverpool yesterday for New York via Queenstown, arrived here this morning and reported having been in collision in a log in the Irish Channel with the steamer Kincora of Waterford, Ireland.

Republicans believe they see in the confidential letter sent out by the Citizens' Union to the members of the Campaign Committee, asking for suggestions of adaptable nominating material, a plan to tiring about the nomination of Seth Low as the anti-Tammany candidate for Mayor.

WORCESTER, Mass., Aug. 8. -- Nearly 3,000 persons saw fourteen hotly contested heats here to-day on the Worcester Driving Park track, and even at that the programme for the day was not finished, as four different horses have won heats in the 2:27 trot, which is put over until tomorrow. Summary:

-- Some interest will be felt in seeing whether the recently rather taciturn group of anti-imperialists will transfer to MIGUEL MALVAR, who, according to report, has now assumed the role of the Filipino Washington, the vehement affection with which their hearts were once filled for the former player of that lofty part.

CRONBERG, Aug. 8. -- The body of the Dowager Empress Frederick was placed in a coffin early this morning, and in the afternoon a funeral service was held at Schloss Friedrichshof. It was simple, but highly impressive. It was performed, following a request of the late Dowager Empress, by the Bishop of Ripon, her own chaplain, assisted by the Rev. Thomas Teignmouth Shore, canon of Worcester Cathedral.

Along about the first of last July Mary Elizabeth Schwahl, known on the local stage as Mabel Lawrence, secured a divorce from her husband, Augustus Schwahl, a horse owner of Newark, N.J. The wife was awarded $300 counsel fees and alimony of $30 a week.

The first presentation of Leo Ditrichstein's new play, "The Last Appeal," will be accomplished at the Broad Street Theatre, Philadelphia, Sept. 9, instead of Sept. 23 at Washington, as originally announced.

OSSINING, N.Y., Aug. 8. -- The seventieth annual Methodist Episcopal camp meeting, known as the "Sing Sing Camp Meeting," until the name of this village was changed to Ossining, began this evening on the camp grounds northeast of this place. The meeting will continue for ten days, closing on the night of Sunday, Aug. 18.

BUFFALO, Aug. 8. - -After a postponement of one day on account of rain the Grand Circuit harness meet, under the auspices of the Buffalo Driving Club, was resumed at Fort Erie race track this afternoon. The feature of the day's racing was the Iroquois Hotel Stakes for 2:24 pacers, which was won by Shadow Chimes.

Some slight increase in activity showed in the market for outside securities yesterday, but the total for the day was again a small one. Prices, in sympathy with the greater strength of the Stock Exchange market, made a number of small gains, but the volume of business was too small to result in many substantial changes in, quotations.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 8. -- Ex-Gov. William A. Newell died at noon to-day at his home in Allentown, N.J. The ex-Governor was in his eighty-fourth year and had been in poor health for some time owing largely to his advanced age.

London quotations furnished yesterday before the opening of our security market showed some striking advances in American stocks, but were probably mainly influenced by the sharp rise in consols, due to the issuance of Lord Kitchener's ultimatum to the Boers. However, the advances in London exerted considerable influence upon the opening here, which was very firm, with short covering a conspicuous feature.

FORMING part of the bicentennial anniversary of Yale University in the Autumn of this year, a series of volumes known as the Yale Bicentennial Publications has been prepared by a number of the professors and instructors of the university as a "partial indication of the character of the studies" in which they are engaged.

CANTON, Aug. 9 -- Arrangements were made here this afternoon for "President's Day" at the Pan-American Exposition. President J.G. Millburn and Director General W.I. Buchanan of the exposition, Mayor Diehl of Buffalo, and John I. Scatherd, came here for the purpose. They were met at the station by the President's carriages, and taken to the Elks' Club for luncheon.
SAIGON, French Cochin China, Aug. 9 -- Prince Henri d'Orleans died at 3:30 P.M. to-day.

The trait distinguishing Mr. Francis Churchill Williams's "J. Devlin, Boss," from all other novels dealing with the corruption of American politics is the ingenious permutation of race, religion, and party by which the author has avoided anything capable of being construed as an attack upon anything but "the machine."
LONDON, Aug. 9 -- Money was more plentiful to-day and in less demand.

Katharine Tynan, author of "The Dear Irish Girl," and other Irish tales, in her new book, "That Sweet Enemy," essays to rejuvenate a very old plot with new surroundings and situations. Family feuds have always had irresistible possibilities in love stories. Mrs. Hinkson has merely added a new version to a rather generous list of them.

BUFFALO, Aug. 9 -- Two rear cars of the Lehigh Valley Railroad's "Black Diamond Express," which left this city at noon for New York and Philadelphia, jumped the track and broke loose from the rest of the train near North Leroy, ten miles east of Batavia, at 12:53 o'clock this afternoon. The train was making over fifty miles an hour at the time.

NORFOLK, Va., Aug. 9 -- Richard L. Page of this city died at his Summer home at Blue Ridge Summit, Penn., to-night, in the ninety-fourth year of his age. He became a midshipman in the United States Navy in 1824. In 1861 he resigned his commission as Commander in the United States Navy and joined the Confederate service.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 9 -- The New York baseball team was absolutely helpless before the superb and masterly pitching of the youthful Townsend this afternoon, and lost to Philadelphia by the score of 13 to 2. Only five scattered hits were made by the visitors, that of Selbach's for three bases in the opening inning being the only clean drive made off the delivery of the local man.

SOME years ago there was a battle of the giants in Berkeley, Cal., at the State University. The giants were Profs. Howison, Royce, Le Conte, and Mezes. The ground of their contention was the conception of God.

Seth Low, President of Columbia University, who was the Citizens' Union candidate for Mayor of New York in 1897, was in the city yesterday. He came here admittedly to consult with friends relative to his again becoming a candidate.

ALTHOUGH there is a general fear that no money will be made "on the road" before Christmas, owing to the labor agitations and the crop conditions, nevertheless the theatrical season will open early. In New York the production of new plays will begin on Aug. 19 at the Criterion Theatre, when Mr. William Faversham will make his debut as a star in "A Royal Rival," Gerald du Maurier's adaptation of "Don Caesar de Bazan."

SOME New Yorkers who nave been accustomed for a number of years past to spend their Summers either in Europe or at Newport, and who have consequently not had occasion to travel during the seasons of outing off the beaten lines or in the more remote country districts, decided to take a driving trip through the Green Mountains of Vermont.

BAR HARBOR, Aug. 9 -- Society is enjoy- ing itself hugely. The forecasts of the earlier season have been realized, and August will be gay beyond description. Dinners are painfully numerous. It seems as though society is most happy when it is eating. Luncheons and teas and late suppers carry off the burden of the entertaining.

For four days of the voyage that began in England, one week ago yesterday, the American liner St. Louis and the Cunarder Umbria, both of which arrived in port yesterday afternoon, were in sight of each other. The St. Louis steamed past the Hook at 2:15, the Umbria following her 17 minutes later.
The New York Journal, (Morning.) From the begining of the war against police corruption the Journal's motto has been: Strike at the top.

Edgar A. Whitney and Ernest Burgdorf, private detectives, charged by Parkhurst Agent Dillon with conspiracy and aiding and abetting gamblers, were arraigned promptly at 9:30 yesterday morning before Justice Jerome, sitting as a Committing Magistrate in his Chambers.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 10 -- The pony races held this afternoon by the Southampton Horse Association on the Great Plains Road in front of Henry G. Trever's residence produced excellent sport. All of the fashionable cottagers came to witness the races and formed a stand with their four-in-hands, drags, breaks, and automobiles.

CRONBERG, Aug. 10 -- The body of the Empress Frederick was to-night taken from Friedrichshof to the Protestant Church here. Only a privileged few were permitted to stand along the route taken by the cortege.

Edgar A. Whitney late last night consented to talk with a reporter, being allowed to come to the barred door of the Tombs to do so. He was haggard from long and fatiguing examination by Justice Jerome, Mr. Moss, and the District Attorney's representative. He was asked if the statement which he had made during the afternoon would incriminate any one.

LONDON, Aug. 10 -- "I am going to retire from the interviewing business permanently," said United States Senator Depew today. "I have served my full term, and have generally enjoyed it, but there have been so many fictitious and erroneous reports of my sayings and speeches since I arrived in Europe this Summer that I have concluded to give up the job.

ON the estate of Lord Ilchester, at Abbotsbury, England, is one of the most ancient game preserves in England, and perhaps the most famous swannery in the world. The game preserve is believed to have existed about 800 years, the swans in mediaeval times having been the property of the abbots from whom the place gets its name.

TENNIS week at Newport has been for years the clou of the season. Recently, however, that season has been prolonged, and it is now the Horse Show which will close it with all the eclat it decerves. This latter event is now nearly a month away, and in that time there will be given at the City by the Sea many dances, dinners, luncheons, and entertainments of all kinds.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 10 -- What is regarded as an attempt on the part of a Boer sympathizer to blow up a British transport took place shortly after midnight, when there was a terrific explosion at the stock landing, where the Harrison steamer Mechanician is moored. The Mechanician is to carry mules to South Africa.

DANCING is the universal social diversion of the genuine Westerner. From the isolation of the mining camp, the cattle range, or the wheat field he is always eager to turn to the music of the violin or piano that instantly set his feet in motion. He may be attracted by the iniquities of the saloon, the gambling house, or the public dance hall; but these diversions bring out the worst elements in his character.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 10 -- Jack Winters, who was arrested as a suspect in connection with the Selby Smelting Works robbery, has confessed, and, so far, $141,500 worth of bullion has been recovered from the bay where he had sunk it.

THE most highly protected industry in this country is that of the production of woolen goods. It is regarded by tariff specialists that the American system of import duties has its keystone in the duty on wool and woolens. The woolen industry is the most important in the United States next to the manufacture of the products of iron.

Mr. FRANK Moss has caught the entire Police Department in his trap -- there can be no doubt of that. The proof of corruption and collusion with the lawbreakers that has been so long and diligently sought for he has obtained. Whether he has obtained such proofs against individuals as will suffice for indictment and conviction is at present less clear.

During the first few weeks of installation in their cage the lance-heads, true to their reputation, became veritable fiends. On opening the door of this cage, the keeper was generally greeted with a low whirr, as the angry reptiles rapidly vibrated their tails. This was soon followed by the flash of white mouths from the shrubbery.

AN old Adirondack guide was in the rowing seat of his favorite canoe. Near him in the boathouse at Wawbeek Inn were a score of handsomely pressed young women, with bronzed faces that would have made Maud Muller of Summer day fame envious. The sun was only an hour above the horizon, and the tops of Whiteface Mountain, of McIntyre, end the Saddleback were bathed in white mist.

BAT SHORE, L.I., Aug. 10 -- The second and last day of the first annual horse show of the Bay Shore Horse Show Association ended to-day. The grand stand and boxes were filled by many prominent persons on Long Island. Summaries follow:

NOTHING goes to waste in New York City. This may appear as a remarkably strong assertion, but if one stops to consider for a moment he will find that it is true. Even the paper on which this is printed will have some future use, possibly in wrapping up a bundle.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- A fire in the rear is to be opened on the Steel Trust. Plans are forming for the prosecution of the trust in the courts as a corporation existing in violation both of the Federal and State statutes. The American Anti-Trust League is in charge of this flank movement to engage the attention of the trust while the strike is on.

A park which promises to be a most attractive feature of East Orange, N.J., has grown out of a millpond. The history of its evolution from pond to park includes a tale of experiments in another direction which were costly and disappointing to a degree.

LONDON, Aug 10 -- The death of the Empress Frederick has had the effect thus far in England of curtailing the programme of the yachting week at Cowes and the departure of the King and Queen last night at an hour previously unspecified to attend the funeral at Cronberg.
"OH, dear, oh, dear," cried the woman having her first experience of a New York flat. "Not a single closet large enough for me to get into in a thunder shower."

AMERICAN economical fisheries are in a precarious condition. Mackerel are becoming more and more scarce each year, the lobster industry is already on the verge of ruin, and unless effective measures are adopted for the protection of the Grand Banks fisheries the cod that are so numerous there may before many years follow the example Of the mackerel and seek other waters.

The invitation four-oared barge race, which was the prinicpal event at the twenty-eighth annual regatta of the Bloomingdale Boat Club, held on the Hudson River off the clubhouse, at the foot of West One Hundred and Second Street, was won by the Valencia Boat Club of Hoboken, with the Atlantic Boat Club of Hoboken second and the Active Boat Club, also of Hoboken, third.

MANILA, June 25 -- Work is so well advanced toward the establishment of a civil service system for the Philippines as to make possible at this time a forecast of what that system will be when the new Government shall get into full operation. The framework devised represents the sum of experiences elsewhere, modified my local conditions or adapted to them.
The rapid transit tunnel work on Lenox Avenue is being objected to by the residents of that avenue.

Painters and sculptors of New York, Philadelphia, and Boston have been thinking much of late years on the subject of the Paris Salon and the lack of such an annual prize show on this side of the water, with all its medals and honorable mentions, its purchases for the Luxembourg, and its Legion of Honor.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- Army officers who have had time to reflect since the close of active operations in the West Indies and in Asia over the efforts that have been made to distribute distinctive honors are admitting that the seekers for honors have succeeded too well in infecting the officers of highest influence with the desire to confer distinctive rewards where they were not fully merited.

Burglars have been holding high revel in the house of Myron Sulzberger, a lawyer, at 207 East Seventy-second Street, during the Summer absence of the family at Arverne, L.I. Their work was discovered because they left the area door ajar.

Mgr. Scalabrini, Archbishop of Placenza and founder and head of the San Raphael Society for the Protection of Italian Immigrants, inspected and consecrated the new Italian mission house at 219 Bleecker Street yesterday. Signor Rossi, the Italian immigration agent, and several priests were present.

The rivalry that is developing in the Postal Department between the Star Service and the Rural Free Delivery Service is promising to strengthen the rural service rather than help the other. The rural free delivery experiment, costing this year something like $3,500,000, may be expanded next year to cost $7,000,000.
