The first prize will be a handsome cup, and there will be other awards for second and third places.

MRS. WILLIAM PAYNE THOMPSON wore one day at the tennis court of the Newport Casino a gown of rose pink organdie cross-barred with white. The trailing skirt had a deep flounce, and above it were horizontal insertions of white lace. The blousing bodice had a short yoke of white lace, and in the lower half were lace insertions.

The winning career of Robert Walthour, the Atlanta (Ga.) cyclist, who has swept everything before him in middle-distance motor-paced cycle races this season, and who was already hailed as the champion in that form of cycle racing, received a sudden check on the Manhattan Beach cycle track yesterday when he was defeated by four and three-quarter laps, or over a mile and a half, in an hour race by Harry Elkes of this city.
Concerning the condition of the streets on the lower east side the following communication has been received from a resident of that neighborhood by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

On board the Cunard Line steamship Campania, which arrived at this port on Friday night and came up to her pier yesterday morning, was W.G. Jameson, the amateur yachtsman, who will manage the Shamrock II. in her races for the America's Cup. The Campania, in honor of her passenger, set the Shamrock, flag on her spring stay.

The indictment against Police Captain John D. Herlihy, for neglect of duty in failing to suppress 109 disorderly houses in the "Red Light" district, dismissed by Recorder Goff Friday, is to be resubmitted to the September Grand Jury.
ACTORS, especially noted ones, are sometimes sensitive upon being Imitated, and nono was more particular in this respect than Charles Fechter.

Some time ago Bradstreet's, with a view to obtaining the present condition of cornas to whether or not, that is, it has been benefited by what was claimed to be late favorable growing weather -- sent out to all its offices and correspondents inquiries asking for information on the subject.

Representative Wall Street bankers and brokers continue to express their confidence in the stock market, and generally are predicting much higher prices in the near future. Herewith will be found a few opinions on the subject:

HIS attire was so conventionally picturesque that it seemed modeled after that of the tramp on the vaudeville stage. Soleless shoes planted with wavering inexactitude supported a trembling frame. Trousers through which bits of flesh dirtily leered led up to a buttonless vest.
LONDON, Aug. 31. -- A dispatch from Lord Kitchener, dated Pretoria, to-day, says:

HAVANA, Aug. 31. -- Mr. Barden has written a letter to the municipality of Havana to the effect that Governor General Wood approved changes in the specifications and conditions for letting the contract for the sewering and paving of Havana.

A CANVASS of the smart tailors and haberdashers in New York revivals the fact that there are to be some radical innovations in men's wear this Fall and Winter. The word innovation is to be understood only in a comparative sense, for the changes will be as compared with last year Father than as related to what men have ever worn years before.

TO-DAY being the first day of September -- a month with an "r" in it -- marks the beginning of the oyster season. The oyster market in New York was very busy all of last week, but not until to-day will chefs throughout the country place oysters on their menus. The bivalve will be quite the proper thing for a dinner course from now until the 1st of May.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 1 -- It was the most thoroughly rainy day of the season to-day. The rain did not interfere, however, with the luncheons which had been arranged for the afternoon nor with the dinners at the Casino in the evening. There was a much smaller attendance than was anticipated at the concert, but the dinners were in the enclosed grill room and the weather had no depressing effect upon the diners.

Two companies of the Twelfth Regiment, numbering about 125 men, who have been encamped on the King estate, City Island, for several days past, clashed with the police last night. Incidentally they gave Mathew Moore, Commissioner of Bridges of the Bronx Borough, and his friend James P. Trout, a very unpleasant hour.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 1 -- With the breaking of dawn this morning the citizens of Cleveland awoke to look upon a scene of unparalleled devastation and destruction caused by a raging flood. While the entire city was more or less affected, the great volume of water vented its force over miles of the eastern portion of the city, and caused an amount of damage approximated at $1,000,000.

To The Editor of The New York Times: Since I am driven by THE TIMES to argue the merits of my suggesting the use of "aerograph" for wireless telegraphy, "autocart," or "autowheel" for automobile. I shall do so, much as I dislike offending etymologists and other word sharps, amateur, professional, or journalistic.

-- Nothing except a desire to provoke a war between Great Britain and the United States could have prompted the writing and printing of an article which appears in a recent issue of The London Express, and only by the exercise of the firmest self-control in this country can the fiendish purpose be foiled.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Trade relations between the United States and Spain have resumed the conditions existing prior to the war between the two countries. The exports from the United States to Spain in the fiscal year just ended were larger than in any preceding year, with a single exception, 1883, and show an increase of $6,000,000 over 1899, while our imports from Spain also show a marked increase over 1899.

Local links will witness a grand reopening of the season to-day, and, as has always been the custom on Labor Day since the advent of golf into America, competitions will be played on every metropolitan course. The events include every variety known to the golf world, together with one or two additions which enter into the freak class of contests.

BERLIN, Sept. 1 -- Last week's Boerse was very dull, but the undertone was somewhat firm. The public, which recently showed a disposition to resume Boerse business, did nothing last week. Transactions accordingly were confined exclusively to professional dealers. A favorable symptom, however, was that the week's untoward political events did not produce any marked effect.

BERLIN, Sept. 1 -- It is now very doubtful, according to a dispatch to the Lokalanzeiger from Basel, Switzerland, whether Prince Chun will come to Berlin to make formal apology for the murder of Baron von Ketteler. Members of the expiatory mission say:

The local rowing season will end to-day with the annual Labor Day regatta of the Middle States Regatta Association on the Harlem River. The entry list is the largest but one in the history of the association, and with favorable weather the event will bring a brilliant close to an unusually interesting and active rowing season.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Some figures relating to the export and import trade of Cuba for the first seven months of this year, as compared with a similar period last year, just published by the Division of Insular Affairs, War Department, indicate that radical changes are going on in that trade, and that the United States and other North American countries are the sufferers in this turn of trade.

MONTREAL, Sept. 1 -- Kent and Daley of Boston, on a motor tandem, established a record here to-day for five miles, going the distance in 7:01 4-5. The race was two motor tandems against Champion's motor cycle. Champion's machine broke down. In the twenty-five-mile race between Champion of France and McEachren of Canada, the Canadian's wheel broke down in the second mile, and the Frenchman gained almost two laps.

Mrs. Carrie Nation arrived in New York yesterday morning. Before the day was over she had attended church at St. Patrick's Cathedral, made an effort to penetrate the interior of the Democratic Club, toured the Tenderloin, been arrested on Eighth Avenue, and delivered a lecture at Carnegie Hall on the subject, "The Lord's Saloon."

One man was killed and another wounded during a quarrel between Italians early yesterday morning at Columbia and Commerce Streets, Brooklyn. The two men who were shot were spectators standing on the other side of the street from the contestants.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It seems to me that, now that Senator Platt has spoken, there is left to the anti-Tammany forces but one thing to do, namely, to nominate Controller Bird S. Coler for Mayor without faltering.

The Philippine Information Society, of which James J. Putnam, M.D., of Boston, is Chairman, issues advance sheets of facts about the Filipinos which deal with six phases of the question: Pre-Election Period -- A Time of Hope for the Insurgents, Drastic Measures, Peace Movement Among the People, Beginnings of Civil Government, The Latter, End of the Fray, and the Status Quo.

Charles Steckler, who, with a party of friends, has been on a six weeks' tour of Great Britain's colonies on this continent, with an incidental trip to the Adirondacks and the Buffalo Exposition, is back again, well pleased and greatly benefited by his journey and at the same time assured that one expedition to New Brunswick, Nova Scotia, Cape Breton, and Newfoundland is about enough in an ordinary lifetime.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Of the various gentlemen who have been mentioned as the possible candidate of the Citizens' Union, Republicans, and Independent Democratic organizations for Mayor, I am strongly of the opinion that Mr. George Foster Peabody is the most likely to defeat Tammany.
ALBANY, Sept. 1 -- An unusually large number of new laws went into effect today. There are twenty-three of them, the greater part being code amendments.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Sept. 1 -- David Scott and John Stevens, negroes, were found murdered this morning in their room in the attic of the Siwanoy Golf Club's house, on the outskirts of the city, near Bronxdale. They were, respectively, steward and head waiter of the club. They had been slain with a butcher's knife, which lay on the floor beside the bodies.

Two close special events were decided at the Canarsie Yacht Club races yesterday off the clubhouse of the organization, at Sand's Point, Canarsie, L.I. The wind blew from the east at the start, a good full sail breeze, while on the second round of the journey it shifted to the south. The course was triangular, ten miles in length.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Sept. 1 -- The principal interest in strike matters to-day was centred in the Duquesne plant, where it was expected the strikers would make a decided move toward closing down the entire works. The report from there to-night says the situation is critical. Two boss melters and all first helpers went to work as usual this morning, and all twelve furnaces were charged.

The Rev. Mr. Hugh Black, associate pastor of St. George's United Free Church, Edinburgh, Scotland, who, though a young man has a wide reputation as a preacher, occupied the pulpit at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church yesterday morning. A large congregation assembled to hear him.

NEWPORT, Sept. 1 -- Sir Thomas Lipton arrived shortly after 5 o'clock this afternoon on his steam yacht Erin from New York, having made the run against an easterly wind in eleven hours. Accompanying Sir Thomas are Capt. Sycamore of Shamrock II., G.L. Watson, David Barrie, W.C. Jamieson, J.B. Hillard, Dr. Reid Mackay, and the Hon Charles Russell.

E. Kunath of the Anchor Athletic Club of Jersey City made a new world's record for rope climbing at the open gymnastic competition held at the Pastime Athletic Club grounds, East Sixty-sixth Street and Avenue A, yesterday afternoon. The previous record for a climb of twenty-five feet was 0:06 3-5.

There are now pending in the criminal courts of this city several cases against police officers in the final outcome of which the people of this municipality are very deeply interested. If the accused men are guilty it is the hope of all good citizens that they be punished to the full extent of the law.

Relatives of Isaac Peoples, who died on Thursday in the Brooklyn Hospital, and whose death was ascribed to a fall, claim that he was really the victim of police brutality. They charge that Officer James J. Keating of the Fulton Street Station, Brooklyn, pushed the old man to the pavement, and it is said that a formal accusation will be made to the authorities today.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Sept. 1 -- A private letter from New York brings a report that E.P. Bryan, General Manager of the Rapid Transit Subway Construction Company of New York City has been asked to take the Presidency of the Southern Pacific. Mr. Bryan formerly lived in Frankfort, and served as station agent here.

An alliance for mutual interest and advantage has been concluded between THE NEW YORK TIMES and THE LONDON TIMES which secures to this journal the exclusive right to the entire news service of its London namesake for the Continent of America.

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., Sept. 1 -- Twelve thousand or more Methodists gathered in the Auditorium at 9 o'clock this morning, and participated in the annual "love feast." Bishop Fitzgerald, President of the Camp Meeting Association, presided. The choir and orchestra, led by Prof. Tali Esen Morgan, sang a number of hymns and anthems before and after the feast.

The other day Deputy Commissioner DEVERY, in the course of one of his rambling lectures at police trials, took occasion to berate the men who are trying to clean New York of its unspeakable official filth because of the damage they were doing to "business." He has lately invented, or borrowed a term of contempt for men engaged in this work which he evidently enjoys, and repeats in season and out of season.

WELLINGTON, N.Z., July 25 -- The Federation Commission appointed by the New Zealand Government was generally expected to report against union with Australia, for Mr. Seddon, the Premier, has made no secret of his desire to maintain independence, and is much too clever a politician to appoint a commission likely to report adversely to his wishes.
SEA CLIFF, N.Y., Sept. 1 -- The New York Christian Conference, which began here yesterday, was continued to-day. About five hundred persons attended the services to-day.

MILWAUKEE, Sept 1 -- Charges that the National officers of the Amalgamated Association had misrepresented the attitude of the United States Steel Corporation toward organized labor in order to get the members of the association on strike were made by former Vice President J.D. Hickey at a meeting of the Bayview Lodge today.

ISLIP, L.I., Sept. 1 -- George C. Taylor, guardian of Lena Head, who married Frederick Bodley, his overseer, said to-day he would not forgive the pair under any circumstances. He said he had not made a will, and that the claim that the young woman had been benefited by a will was false.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Solomon Berliner, United States Consul at Teneriffe, Canary Islands, and Miss Jennie Ottenberg of Washington were married this afternoon in Carroll Institute Hall by the Rev. Dr. Stern in the presence of a large number of friends and relatives of the contracting parties from this city and from New York.

BUFFALO, Sept. 1 -- The ceremonies and other formal functions which will mark President McKinley's visit to the Pan-American Exposition have been finally arranged by the Committee on Reception. President McKinley and party will arrive at the station of the New York Central Railroad from Canton about 6 o'clock on the evening of Sept. 4.

To the Edito of The New York Times: The collapse of the Tripler liquid air bubble leads to the question: Should there not be some protection for a gullible public against irresponsible promoters and their methods of getting the people's money on false and exaggerated representations?

OFFICIAL ITINERARY OF THE CZAR'S FRENCH SOJOURN -- Nearly every paper in Paris has printed one or more programmes which give something of an idea of the details of the coming visit of the Czar to France. But of these programmes, no two are alike. At the proper time a semi-official announcement of the itinerary will be published, which, it is believed upon good authority, will include the following programme:
ALBANY, Sept. 1 -- Mrs. Wilbur Alexander and her daughter lost their lives this evening through an explosion on a launch belonging to Mr. Alexander, a contractor of this city.

A drunken policeman in full uniform stole a cab from in front of the Parker House, at Thirty-ninth Street and Broadway, early last night. Then he took a drive up Broadway, down Seventh and Eighth Avenues, and across various side streets. His fellow policemen said afterward that the break-neck run was one of the most spectacular exhibitions of driving that had taken place in the Tenderloin in years.

The concluding days of last week were marked by strength in the stock market which, to the average professional trader, was altogether unexpected and surprising, inasmuch as it was quite without precedent. Professional Wall Street had been educated up to the belief that preceding a triple holiday, such as Stock Exchange members are now enjoying, market values should show shrinkage.

Members of the Benchmen's Association, the organization of journeymen butchers, to the number of some three thousand, from Manhattan, Brooklyn, and Long Island City, patrolled the streets of the city yesterday, looking for violators and violations of the new law that went into effect yesterday, making the sale of meat or its exposure for sale a Sabbath-breaking offense.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 1 -- Joseph Nelson, brother of John Nelson of Chicago, Ill., easily won the ten-mile motor-paced race at the cycling meet at the Vailsburg track to-day, from Henry Edwards of Brockton, Mass. A two-mile open professional race was won by Floyd A. McFarland. There were several amateur events.

There was plenty of life and color at Sulzer's Harlem River Park yesterday when the second annual Austro-Hungarian National Festival was celebrated. Fully 5,000 persons participated in the event, many of the societies being in uniform, and the women and children in national costume.

LONDON, Sept. 2 -- Much astonishment is expressed in China, the Peking correspondent, of The Times says, at the story that Prince Chun is expected to kotow to the Kaiser. All the envoys to Peking have refused to perform this barbarous ceremony for more than a century, and for the past twenty-eight years there has been no dispute about the matter.

ASBURY PARK, Sept. 1 -- There are signs on every hand of the waning season in Asbury Park and Ocean Grove, and the railroad companies are counting on a tremendous outgoing business on Monday morning. The departures nowadays outnumber the arrivals. Thousands came in yesterday to spend Labor Day by the sea, but the passing of that holiday will be the signal for a general exodus.

SEA GIRT, N.J., Sept. 1 -- Fresh from their work on the Rockliffe ranges through the last week the members of the All Canada Rifle Team arrived at Sea Girt, N.J., this afternoon. They are quartered alongside the Irish team in the front row of tents near the clubhouse, on the New Jersey State camp ranges.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE TIMES of Sunday, Aug. 25, appeared a communication signed J.L.H. Mosier, in which the writer stated that in May, 1860, being in South Carolina, he learned that the remains of Gen. Nathaniel Greene had been removed from their first burial place and reinterred at Kingstree, S.C., in a Presbyterian churchyard.

LONDON, Sept. 1 -- This has been a very uneventful week in our money market, without a single incident of particular importance, but with, on the whole, a gradual hardening tendency. At first credits were again fairly abundant and the supply of bills very moderate, so that it looked as if we would see a further movement toward ease.
PEKING, Sept. 2. -- H.G. Squiers, Secretary of the United States Legation, started for home to-day on leave of absence.

The team of the District of Columbia, made up of twelve men, won the Hilton Trophy match at the Sea Girt ranges today from the ten teams of twelve men each who shot for this prize, and the contest was so keen that the result was in doubt until the last bullet bored through the target.

BAYONNE, N.J., Sept. 2. -- Lovers of track and field contests among amateurs enjoyed a varied programme, replete with interesting events, at the Labor Day carnival of the Knickerbocker Athletic Club at Bayonne to-day. Threatening weather did not prevent a large attendance.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The sale during this last week of the property on Broadway and Murray Street, opposite Park Place, known as No. 241, was one of unusual interest and deserving of more than a passing notice.

Deputy Commissioner of Police York is going to reform Coney Island. He said so on Saturday last when he refused to sanction the applications of fifteen hotel keepers for all-night licenses for last night. Just why he selected this time of the season to begin his latest crusade is not known, as he has issued over 100 during the season.

-- So well has The London Times been served by its Havana correspondent, ever since it became evident that the United States was about to intervene in Cuban affairs, that its letters from this source have come to be generally recognized as those of an accurate and impartial observer whose praise is worth having and whose blame cannot be lightly put aside.

Official conservatism is very clearly illustrated in the fact that the important and apparently conclusive experiments made in Cuba under the direction of Surgeon REED, United States Army, regarding the conveyance and propagation of yellow fever have thus far made little or no impression upon the conventional methods of quarantine.
The following sales at auction are down for to-day at 111 Broadway:

A new world's hammer-throwing record was established yesterday at the annual games of the New York Irish-American Athletic Association, held at Celtic Park, Long Island City. John Flanagan, the pride of all Irish athletes, covered himself with glory and threw his friends into ecstasies of enthusiasm by throwing the sixteen-pound hammer 171 feet 9 inches, creating a new world's record.

MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 2. -- Vice President Roosevelt participated to-day in the exercises of the opening day of the State Fair. Speaking from the grand stand of the fair grounds, to a large and enthusiastic audience, he made an address, in the course of which he said:

All the things that go to make up a holiday's racing were present in accentuated form at the Sheepshead Bay race track yesterday, where a crowd numbering close upon 20,000 people gathered for the holiday outing. There were sensation, surprise, satisfaction, and disaster quickly following each other, with such a mingling of effects and results that no crowd ever left the track in moods more varying than the gathering of yesterday.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 2. -- A quantity of valuable jewelry was stolen from the house of Charles H. Earle, at 161 Mount Prospect Avenue, on Saturday afternoon. To-day, with the exception of a man's diamond ring, it was all returned to the house by mail. The package was mailed in the Newark Post Office.

WELLINGTON, N.Z., July 25. -- The Government of New Zealand is contemplating a discontinuance of the subsidy granted to the mail service to San Francisco and its diversion to the service at Vancouver, B.C.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am an independent voter whose aspirations do not run in a political strain, but who has this city's best interests at heart, and although I have little practical political experience, feel that the few words I may say are not only my sentiments, but also of many other independent voters.

CEDARHURST, L.I., Sept. 2. -- Under lowering clouds and with a rain at intervals lasting all day the annual Horse Show of the Rockaway Hunting Club was held here to-day on the club's grounds. The polo field was turned into a show ring, and proved a most excellent place for showing the finest horses ever seen in the vicinity.

Chief Croker, a nephew of the noted Richard Croker, is here attending the international fire Chiefs' convention. He said last night that he thought Chief Hale was about right as to politics and fire departments.

Carried nearly two blocks on the fender of an unmanageable electric car down the steepest incline traversed by any railway in the city, then rolled beneath the iron guard, to be saved with only trifling injuries as the wheel was about to crush her head was the startling experience of Lena Alma Casey, four years old, in upper Amsterdam Avenue yesterday.

BOSTON, Sept. 2. -- In spite of the lowering clouds and occasional dashes of rain, the annual Autumn festivities of the Myopia Hunt Club at Hamilton were most successful. The old-fashioned clubhouse, with its wide piazzas and the masses of great trees surrounding it, never looked more cheerful and hospitable.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 2. -- Two interesting matches occupied the attention of the Fairfield County golfers to-day. In the club championship, 36-hole medal play, Dr. Carl E. Martin won the gold medal with a score of 180, and Charles Truesdale and R.C. Carroll tied for the silver medal, and will play off at a later date.

The threatening aspect of the weather did not tend in the least to deter those of the general public who had planned excursions yesterday to the seashore, beaches along the Sound, and near-by resorts, and trains, trolley cars, and boats were crowded all day.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Sept. 2. -- The efforts to solve the murder of David Scott and John Stevens, the negro steward and the head waiter of the Siwanoy Country Club, in the Chester Hill section of this city, led to the arrest to-day in Yonkers of Peter Buckenhoff, a colored caterer, and the departure of Detective Lynch to-night for New York, where it is thought he will search for two colored waiters.

NEWPORT, Sept. 2. -- Mr. and Mrs. George B. De Forest gave a dinner at the Train villa to-night. The table decorations consisted of aquatic flowers and fancy foliage, chiefly lotus flowers and the night-blooming lilies of the Nile, combined with long stalks of papyrus. The hall and drawing room were decorated with palms.

From The London Pall Mall Gazette. ST. PETERSBURG, Aug. 18. -- A correspondent of the Novosti has boldly raised the question: Does torture prevail in Russian prisons? In order, as far as possible, to get at the truth of the matter, barristers who have had charge of the defense of political prisoners, and have had frequent intercourse with their clients in the period preceding their trial, have been interviewed.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2. -- Marked activity in banking and investment circles is looked for since the vacation season has closed, according to James H. Eckels, President of the Commercial National Bank. Mr. Eckels has just returned from a week's visit in New York, and, discussing the outlook to-day, he said:
Conductor George White of the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company, by his presence of mind in lifting a live wire from the Coney Island trolley track, did much to prevent a panic in his car yesterday.
To the Editor of The New York Times: A minister's remarks about church organizations have caused comment in your columns, and perhaps you have room for further consideration of the subject.

BOSTON, Sept. 2. -- The yacht Independence, built at a great cost, some say of a quarter of a million of dollars, for Thomas W. Lawson, who hoped to use her as a candidate for America's Cup honors, and which purpose failed, went out to-day for what was to be her last sail. As the breeze failed, and the fishermen's races were not held, she will have a try to-morrow.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read in this morning's TIMES what is reported to be an interview with Bishop Turner of the African Methodist Church, in Atlanta, Ga., and it seems to me plausible that, at his age, he should be seeking notoriety which in the end will do him more harm than good.

The local rowing season reached a brilliant climax yesterday with the twelfth annual regatta of the Middle States Regatta Association held over the Speedway course on the Harlem River. The regatta was a fitting end to an unusually active and interesting season, as it was the largest but one in the history of the association and one of the most successful.

NEWPORT, Sept 2. -- The Newport Horse Show was opened this afternoon at the Casino. The sky was cloudy, but no rain fell, and everything passed off in a very satisfactory manner. The exhibition of fine horses has rarely been equalled here, and the seventeen events on the programme for the afternoon brought out in nearly every instance full lists of entries.

In plain view of thousands of persons out for the holiday and several policemen, the body of a well-dressed man, supposed to be that of Philip Mauscher, lay for hours at Thirty-first Street and Surf Avenue, Coney Island, yesterday.
J.W. HAWKINS, for many years Assistant State Treasurer of Kentucky, died yesterday from general debility.

Seven riders were severely injured, three of them so badly that they were taken to a hospital, in a smash-up at the finish of the annual cycle path handicap road race, held by the Associated Cycling Clubs of Long Island on the Coney Island cycle path yesterday morning.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Sept. 2. -- The twelfth annual convention of the National Association of Letter Carriers met here to-day. The Committee on Credentials reported that the attendance is larger than at any previous convention. A street parade was the feature of the day. The letter carriers were escorted by the city officials and a division of labor organizations.

ESSEX, Mass., Sept. 2. -- The athletic games in connection with the picnic of St. Joseph's C.T.A.S. of Lynn, at Centennial Grove, to-day were the chief ones in this part of New England. The winners: 75-Yard Dash. -- Arthur J. Duffy. Georgetown University, (1 1/2 yards.) Time -- 0:07 4-5. 440-Yard Run. -- James H. Stewart, Hillside A. C., (14 yards.) Time -- 0:35 2-5.

Mrs. Carrie Nation -- reduced from 50 cents to 25 cents -- made her debut at Coney Island yesterday as a lecturer. Not more than 100 people considered her lecture a good investment, even at the reduction made at the eleventh hour, when the prospects of a fair-sized audience, were more gloomy than the weather.

New York and Chicago broke even in their Labor Day games at the polo grounds. The first game went to the local team, through a combination of hits at opportune times and errors by Dexter, Doyle, and Hartzel. Eason, who pitched for the Chicago team in the second game, was too much for the locals when hits were needed.

PASADENA, Cal., Aug. 18. -- With nerves collapsed, by the effects of altitude and fright, at the canyons which yawned beside him as he went up the trail, haunted by an uncontrollable impulse to fling himself into the abyss, Horace N. Seaver found himself physically and mentally unable to undertake the descent of Mount Wilson, and was put under the influence of an anesthetic and carried down on a litter.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 2. -- Friends of Miss Marie Josephine Eastwick learned with surprise to-night the story of her trouble in London. Although she has only been an occasional visitor to Philadelphia in recent years, she is well known in local social circles. Miss Eastwick is about thirty-two years old. She is a granddaughter of the late Harrison Eastwick.

MANILA, Sept. 2. -- There were appropriate ceremonies in the palace this morning at the inauguration of Dr. Pardo de Tavera and Benito Legardo as members of the Philippine Commission. Jose Luzuriaga, the third Filipino member, was unable to take the oath, owing to illness.

All the capitals of Europe are just now more or less excited over the visit of the Czar of Russia to witness the Autumn manoeuvres in Prance and to meet President LOUBET. It is not surprising, though it is not gratifying, that some of the English papers are particularly suspicious and ungracious on this occasion.

LONDON, Sept 2. -- Marie Josephine Eastwick of Philadelphia was arraigned in the Guild Sail Police Court to-day charged with having forged a railway certificate of the value of u100,000. The defendant, who is slight and wag shabbily dressed, was accommodated with a chair, and sat the whole time, listlessly, in the dock.

Mr. John Drew began his tenth season in this city last night, when he appeared at the Empire Theatre in a new play entitled "The Second in Command." The auditorium of the popular house presented an appearance now familiar to all who are sufficiently interested in the fortunes of Mr. Drew to remember them from season to season.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 2. -- The second official trial race of the Columbia and the Constitution to-day had practically no result. The yachts, for lack of wind, were unable to finish within the time-limit of five and one-half hours. At 6:30 o'clock this evening the contest came to an inglorious conclusion, two miles to the eastward of Brenton's Reef Lightship.

After being outsailed over half of the course at Larchmont yesterday by her rival, the Muriel, the schooner yacht Elmina won the race in her class by one minute. It was the second and final of the special series, and the Quissetta was third of the schooners in the class.

NIAGARA - ON - THE - LAKE, Ontario, Sept. 2. -- The Niagara international tennis tournament was continued here to-day. R.D. Little, the holder of the international championship, successfully defended his title against B.P. Fischer of New York, the challenger, and the international challenge trophy now becomes his personal property.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 2. -- An innovation in the shape of a match motor tandem race was the feature of the Labor Day cycle meet at the Vailsburg track to-day. The two teams were Shults and Bennett and King and Hunter, and the conditions called for heats at one-quarter of a mile, five miles, and two miles.

It is time the comedy in which the Board of Health and the managers of the New York Central and Hudson River Railroad are joint performers was brought to an end. It has ceased to be amusing and now presents itself in its more serious aspects.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Sept. 2. -- The polo match this afternoon for the Colby loving cups on the grounds of the Rumson Polo Club was by far the most interesting of the Summer and attracted the largest and most fashionable company of the season. It was a spirited strife between the Freebooters and the Rumson four for four silver loving cups offered by Everett Colby.
LONDON, Sept. 2. -- Money was plentiful to-day, and discounts were steady.
KANSAS CITY, Sept. 2. -- William J. Bryan delivered the Labor Day oration here to-day. Taking for his text the Scriptural words, "Muzzle not the ox that treadeth out the corn," he said:

PITTSBURG, Sept. 2. -- The big labor day demonstration monopolized the attention of workmen and strikers here and in the surrounding towns, fully 10,000 parading in this city, but steel manufacturers went on making preparations for the opening of the plants that are shut down by the strike, and increasing the number of men at the mills already in partial operation.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Sept. 2. -- Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Huger Pratt of New York gave the first affair of the month at the Kebo Valley Club to-night. It was a large dinner and was followed by a cotillion. The entire house was decorated with palms and potted plants and cut flowers. The dinner was attended lay the elder set, and the cotillion, which was given for Miss Eleanor Sedley, brought all the young set.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Sept. 2. -- Junior golfers carried off the honors to-day in the reopening of the competitive season at the Morris County Golf Club. The Labor Day event was an eighteen-hole handicap against bogey for two prizes, given by the Greens Committee. It was the first regular club contest for nearly two months, and over forty members started.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 2. -- In the Indian Harbor Yacht Club's special handicap race to-day, eleven yachts participated, catboats, yawls, sloops, raceabouts, and sailabouts making up one class and sailing under handicaps ranging from scratch to five minutes for the smaller boats. It was a ten-mile race over the club course, and the boats made good time in a fair breeze from the east.

UTICA, N.Y., Sept. 2. -- There were two Labor Day parades here to-day on account of four non-union bands which headed some of the labor organizations. They were the Italo-American Band, the Ashcraft Band of the Church of the Holy Cross, and two drum corps. There were two union bands in line, the Germania and Shremp's Bands, both members of the Musical Union, which is affiliated with the American Federation of Labor.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I might commence my present epistle with the assurance that once upon a time I have "forsworn" ever again to write or touch upon the subject of street signs, because -- well, because the matter is getting so stale it is apparently of no use, and also, Mr. Editor, because you are not, I think, as convinced of the necessity of street signs as I am.

There is one feature in the recent turn given to the strike situation that is extremely encouraging and gratifying. It is the open and severe criticism of the action of the President of the Amalgamated Association by trades union members on the ground that he has not kept good faith and has put the affiliated unions in the position of not keeping faith.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In my letter of Aug. 24, my reason given why church services are so poorly attended in Summer was that many of the members possessed the idea that there was no harm in using the Lord's day for their own pleasure; their plea for so doing being that they need the fresh air.
HAVANA, Sept. 2. -- Civil Governor Nunez has suppressed a French play, translated into Spanish, which has been presented at the Payret Theatre by a Spanish company.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Sept. 2. -- Thomas Donahue, one of the most dangerous insane criminals ever confined in the asylum, has escaped from the State institution at Morris Plains. Donahue was committed to the State Prison at Trenton in November, 1900, for "tapping a till" in Mills's saloon at 127 Ogden Street, Newark, and on March 20 last he was transferred to Morris Plains, as an insane criminal.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 3 -- The finals in the ladies' lawn tennis tournament were played at the Casino this morning between Miss Busk and Miss Nora Iselin, the former winning. There was a large gathering of society people, who had come to the Casino with the expectation of seeing a good match, and they were not disappointed.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 3.-- The market generally was heavy to-day, though there was strength in a number of the low-priced local stocks. The notable incidents were a sharp decline in Cambria Steel, after six days of successive advances, and a spirited revival of activity in Philadelphia Electric, the latter establishing the leadership in volume of transactions.

The most interesting event in the real estate market yesterday was the authoritative announcement that Charles M. Schwab is the buyer of the New York Orphan Asylum's block on Riverside Drive. The transaction is referred to in more detail in another column.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 3 -- The Grand Circuit meeting at Charter Oak Park was opened to-day by the races in the 2:30 class for trotters and pacers, respectively, and in the 2:19 class for trotters. The purses in each were $3,000. There was an attendance of 2,500, and the day was ideal for racing.

LONDON, Sept. 4 -- Tables printed in The London Gazette yesterday show that the receipts of the British Exchequer for the five months from April to August, inclusive, were u48,952,625 and that the expenses during the same period were u98,077,491.

BALTIMORE, Md., Sept. 3 -- The market to-day opened with a fair promise of increased activity, but when New York lost its steadiness the buying ardor here ceased. No weakness developed, but trading was brought to an abrupt halt. Cotton Duck probably took the lead on the bull side. It had been suspected that a sudden forward movement would follow when this stock struck the low figure of last week.

SWANSEA, Wales, Sept. 3 -- A commotion was caused at to-day's session of the Trades Union Congress here by the action of some employers in endeavoring to recover damages, under the House of Lords' decision of July 22 last, from labor organizations for picketing by their members.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 3 -- The second day of the horse show was not so satisfactory as to weather conditions as the first, but there was nearly as large a crowd in attendance. Half an hour before the show began there was a heavy rain which lasted fifteen minutes and threatened to cause a postponement, something the Newport horse show has never encountered.

BASEL, Sept. 3 -- Prince Chun's first invitation to visit a foreign Government was from the United States, and was followed by invitations from Italy, Belgium. Great Britain, and Japan. They have all been accepted.

D. Le Roy Dresser, President of the Merchants' Association, yesterday sent another letter to Police Commissioner Murphy in reply to the one in which the Commissioner said that New York was far more orderly now than it has ever been; that politics influences press accounts, and that he was ready to co-operate with the Merchants' Association in anything which it might suggest.
ST. JOHN'S, N.F., Sept. 3 -- The Rev. Moses Harvey, the well-known historian and scientist and discoverer of the famous devil-fish now in the Smithsonian Institution, Washington, died this morning.

NORWICH, Conn., Sept. 3 -- Thieves last night boarded the Sound steamer Block Island at her slip in this city and secured booty in the shape of cash to the amount of $1,500. The robbery was discovered this morning and the police were at once notified.

WASHINGTON. Sept. 3 -- During Secretary Hay's recent visit to Washington on Aug. 24 a telegraphic message was sent to the Ministers at Caracas and Bogota desiring them to inform the Foreign Secretaries of Venezuela and Colombia of the distress with which the President had heard of the likelihood of a disturbance of the relations between those two republics.

It was livelier in social circles yesterday than on Labor Day. A number of men came back from the resorts and from house parties, and there was a general bustle about the clubs. The Bar Harbor season is breaking up, and every day those are departures.

DENVER, Sept. 3 -- It is reported here that Gen. H.C. Merriam of the Department of the Colorado will probably be succeeded upon his retirement by Gen. Arthur MacArthur, late Commander in Chief of the American forces in the Philippines. Gen. Merriam retires from command of this department next November on account of age limitation.

For a day following two big holiday crowds, the racing at the Sheepshead Bay track yesterday was uncommonly good and the attendance remarkably large. Favorites won to five of the six races.

BERLIN, Sept. 3 -- It is said in official circles that the interview between Emperor William and Prince Chun must take place to-morrow or Thursday, as his Majesty goes to the manoeuvres on Friday.

BERLIN, Sept. 3 -- Several papers comment to-day upon Vice President Roosevelt's reference in his speech at the Minnesota State Fair to the part the United States should play among the great nations.
LONDON, Sept. 3 -- The supplies of money were large to-day, partly as the result of preparations for the payment of the installment of consols due Sept. 5. Discounts were easy.

Many cash bequests are made in the will of Louis Thurston Hoyt, filed for probate in the Surrogate's Office yesterday, though the bulk of the stated property will go to the widow, Frances M. Hoyt. She is to receive the residence 392 Madison Avenue, with the jewelry, furniture, and horses and carriages for life, the property then to revert to the residuary estate.

ALBANY, Sept. 3 -- The State Board of Equalization met to-day and equalized the value of real estate in the several counties of the State for the basis for the State tax levy during the fiscal year which commences Oct. 1. The total valuation of real and personal property on which such tax will be levied is $5,686,921,678, as compared with $5,461,302,752 for the current fiscal year.

LONDON, Sept. 4 -- The sole topic of Conversation among Chinese and foreigners in Peking, according to the correspondent of The Times in that city, has been the demand of Emperor William that Prince Chun and the other members of his mission kotow to the Kaiser.

BOSTON, Sept. 3 -- The yacht Independence practically went out of commission this afternoon, after she had raced over a course in Massachusetts Bay and beaten a fleet of fishermen, ten miles on a twenty-five-mile course. The race was in almost ideal conditions, a twelve-knot breeze in a smooth sea.

CANTON, Ohio. Sept. 3 -- President and Mrs. McKinley attended the county fair this afternoon. It was children's day, and hundreds of little ones from all over the county were present. Preparations for the start for Buffalo in the morning and for a two weeks' trip made this a busy day at the McKinley home.

LONDON, Sept 3.-- Sterling Balm (Maher) won Champion Breeders' Biennial Foal Stakes, (of 1,000 sovereigns, added to a sweepstakes of 10 sovereigns each for starters only, for two-year-olds.) distance, five furlongs, straight, at the Derby Summer meeting to-day.

YONKERS, N.Y., Sept. 3 -- John Francesco Dura, a hotelkeeper of Railroad Avenue, Mount Vernon, was found murdered this morning in the woods near Mount Vernon Avenue, not far from the Empire City race track. Robbery was evidently the motive for the crime, and it is supposed that Dura was enticed to the lonely spot and then killed.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Sept. 3 -- Society people doing vaudeville turns made the affair given at the Marlborough to-night the most unique of the season. It was called a "Vaudeville Evening," and was arranged by Miss Violet Whelen and Mrs. Charles S. Whelen. Well-known society people appeared as song and dance artists, prestidigitators, chorus girls, and Irish comedians.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- The outrages committed by armed guerrillas and bandits against innocent Filipinos continue to he rigorously dealt with by the authorities in the Philippines. The records in about twenty cases were received at the War Department to-day. They show that the death penalty was inflicted upon thirteen murderers by military commissions, and that five offenders were sentenced to hard labor of from fifteen to thirty years.

Marie Josephine Eastwick, the young Philadelphia woman who was arraigned in the Guildhall Police Court, London, Monday on a charge of having raised a certificate of Canadian Pacific stock from 5 to 1,000 shares, has two brothers living in this city, and is well known at the Waldorf-Astoria, where she lived with her father during the Summer of 1900.

BEVERLY, Mass., Sept. 3 -- Frederic Warren, Jr., Boston representative and one od the owners of the Warren Steamship Company, died early this morning from the effects of injuries received last night in a carriage accident near his Summer home at Beverly Farms last night.
BOSTON, Sept. 3 -- Money at the Clearing House to-day, loaned at 3 1/2 per cent. New York funds sold at 16 2-3 to 25 cents' discount. Exchanges, $15,148,391; balances, $1,209,005.

There is trouble impending in the Board of Aldermen, due to an effort that has been made to rush through that body an amendment to the Building Code which would wipe out the provision requiring the use of fireproof wood in the interior construction of skyscrapers.

The September Grand Jury was sworn in yesterday by Judge Warren W. Foster in General Sessions. Sixty-nine cases of more or less importance await action. Of the persons accused in these cases, forty-eight are prisoners in the Tombs. Twenty-one are out on bail.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- Thomas Graham, one of the party of visiting British craftsmen, went yesterday with his companions to Glen Echo to attend the celebration of Labor Day by the local organizations. He compared the celebration here with the "demonstrations" in England, where, as at Leeds last year, there were thousands of men, with eighty bands, in a procession four or five miles long.

Trading in the market for outside securities yesterday was, with one exception, much restricted in volume, but more extended than, for come time in the number of stocks, whose closing bid and asked quotations underwent at least fractional change. Few of the copper shares figured in the transactions, and industrials far the most part absorbed the attention of traders.

ASBURY PARK, Sept. 3 -- William B. Gourley, Chairman of the Democratic State Committee, has issued a call for the State Convention, which will be held in Taylor's Opera House, Trenton, on Tuesday, Oct. 1, at noon, for the purpose of nominating a candidate for Governor, and also of electing a new State Committee.

There was an exciting time at the New York Zoological Park, in the Bronx, yesterday afternoon, when two huge bull buffaloes fought to a finish for the supremacy of the range. The contest, which lasted for hall an hour, took place in the presence of hundreds of spectators, and resulted in the goring of Antonio, who attempted to usurp the powers of the leader of the herd, Black Beauty.

The Evening Post reminds us that the Metropolitan Museum is about to be enriched, not only by the "spoils of time," but by the actual spoils of war, if that can be called war which "Christendom" has been waging from Tien-Tsin to Peking, and, centrifugally, in the form of raids, around the latter capital.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Sept. 3.-- The great international yachting bet of $400,000 between an English syndicate, represented by Walter J. Kingsley of London and a group of patriotic Pittsburgers, represented by William I. Mustin, was finally arranged this afternoon.

The annual report of the New York, Ontario and Western for the year ended June 30 last was published yesterday. The income account had already been made public. Of dividend prospects, President Fowler says it is hoped that the position of the company is gradually approaching the time when some annual return on its share capital can be begun and continued.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Sept. 4. -- To enforce a demand for a uniform scale of wages and the restriction of the number of apprentices all the art glass workers in this city who are members of Glass Workers' Union No. 9 struck to-day. For several months the union has sought to secure a minimum wage of 25 cents an hour for glaziers and 30 cents an hour for cutters.

The return rush of New York's migratory population from village and mountain and seaside is on. The man with the dress suit case and the tan and the woman with the freckles and the heavily strapped trunk are coming back by tens of thousands, to take up the grind for another year. They are swarming out of every railway station in the city, and their belongings are choking up the baggage rooms.

PITTSBURG, Sept. 4. -- Agitation and uneasiness prevail in the ranks of the strikers to-night, caused by the apparently unfavorable developments of the day. The leaders, however, profess to be satisfied with present conditions and claim that ultimate victory will be theirs.

MUNICH, Sept. 4. -- Mme. Nordica made her first appearance in Germany at the new Prince Regent Theatre in this city to-night, singing Isolde in "Tristan and Isolde," before a brilliant audience, which included many Americans. She met with a notable reception. She has been engaged to sing in the operas of the Nibelungen Ring here next year.

FORT WORTH, Texas, Sept. 4. -- The Cotton Belt passenger train south-bound, due to leave Texarkana at 9:25 o'clock last night, was delayed in its departure and did not get out until 11 o'clock. The utmost good-fellowship prevailed during the match, which was very close up to the last stage.

PARIS, Sept. 5. -- A dirigible balloon invented by a Frenchman named Roze was tried to-day. The balloon, which was built at Colombes, a suburb of Paris, consists of two cigar-shaped gas bags, from which is suspended a big basket car, having two floors. The upper floor is a sort of salon, elegantly furnished, for the Captain, who controls the five rudders.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5. -- The Congressional act apportioning representatives in Congress under the new census may be reviewed by the United States Courts, which means that finally the Supreme Court of the United States will pass upon the constitutionality of the law.

CHICAGO, Sept. 5. -- The Meyerhauser-Ruttledge syndicate has purchased Jesse Spalding's interest in the Edward Hines Lumber Company, one of the largest concerns in the country. Mr. Spalding has been the controlling factor in the Hines Company, and held about two-thirds of the stock, the capitalization being $300,000.

VINELAND, N.J., Sept. 5. -- Society women of this place and Philadelphia tried hard to-day to keep a band of men from putting up electric light poles in front of their lawns. The women were led by Mrs. J.B. Lukens and Miss Winnie Leach of this place and Mrs. Beaumont and Mrs. Hotaling of Philadelphia.

The annual report of the Chicago Great Western Railway Company for the year ended June 30 last was issued yesterday. The report shows a deficit of $9,106 as compared with a surplus of $143,786 for the previous year. Although there was a large increase in gross earnings, net earnings showed a decrease of nearly $50,000, due to the heavy expenditures charged to the operating account.

LONDON, Sept. 5. -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes: Total reserve decreased u633,000, circulation increased u310,000, bullion decreased u323,537, other securities increased u61,000, other deposits decreased u940,000, public deposits increased u162,000, notes reserve decreased u530,000, find Government securities unchanged.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 5. -- The yacht Columbia, champion of 1899, has been chosen to race against the Shamrock II. in defense of the America's Cup. This decision was reached at noon to-day after a conference of two hours between the members of the challenge committee, on board the schooner Corona, flagship of the New York Yacht Club.
BUFFALO, Sept. 5. -- The Northwestern Hotel, at Military Road and Lansing Street, has been destroyed by fire. The loss is estimated at $40,000.

LONDON, Sept. 5. -- While a section of the British press has been printing sensational New York, specials lately, representing that all America despairs of keeping the America's Cup, and that even the New York Yacht Club members are betting on the Shamrock II., the stories give little real encouragement in English yachting circles.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., Sept. 5. -- The Staten Island Cricket Club visited Haverford to-day to play the final game of its tournament with the Marion Cricket Club. The islanders have been considerably handicapped during their visit owing to Cobb and Ireland, two of their chief bowlers, being ill and unable to take their share of the trundling with Kelly.

LONDON, Sept. 6. -- The selection of Columbia to defend the America's Cup is a matter of great satisfaction to the British press. The chances of the race are now regarded as even, but there is no disposition to express overconfidence in the result. It is generally conceded that Constitution might still have proved the faster boat had there been sufficient time for further experiments and tuning up.

Nathan Co., $5,006, and S.G. Estabrook Co., $63.
PITTSBURG, Sept. 5. -- The prevailing opinion in Pittsburg to-night is that the steel strike is practically settled. The day was spent by the Amalgamated Advisory Board in secret conference.

NEWPORT, Sept. 5. -- Racing under the auspices of the Rhode Island Jockey Club began to-day at the Westchester Polo Club at Bateman's Point. It was the first opportunity Newport has had in many years to attend a race meeting, and there was a large outpouring of the society people, who filled the grounds and grand stand.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5. -- A cablegram was received here to-day from an authoritative source in Cali, Colombia, near the Ecuadorean border, stating that Ecuador had intervened as against Colombia, with an army well equipped and with vessels of war. Under these circumstances the cablegram states that it will be necessary to meet the move of Ecuador by having Colombian war vessels in Pacific waters near the Colombian-Ecuadorean frontier.

Henry D. Winans May have sold for the estate of John R. Ford the plot on the north side of Seventy-fifth Street, 165 feet east of Fifth Avenue. The buyers, William Hall's Sons, will erect thereon two-modern fire-proof dwellings. This property has been held by the Ford family since 1868.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 5. -- The Socialist Party of Iowa in State Convention to-day nominated the following ticket: Governor, James Baxter of Hiteman; Lieutenant Governor, W.A. The burden of their song is that President McKinley will not die as the result of the bullet wounds inflicted upon him by the Anarchist Czolgosz.

BUFFALO, Sept. 9 -- While Czolgosz committed his crime here and will be prosecuted and punished here, the operations of the Secret Service officers who are attempting to ferret out an Anarchist conspiracy of which his attempt to assassinate the President was the climax, are in the main being conducted away from this city.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 9 -- Golf of an unusually grand character was seen to-day on the links of the Country Club of Atlantic City, when the qualifying round at thirty-six holes was played as the opening event in the annual amateur championship tournament of the United States. Of 140 entries, 124 started and over 100 finished the double round.

The Clearing House Committee may be regarded as having been in continuous session since Friday night when it met yesterday morning at the Buckingham Hotel at the instance of J. Edward Simmons, the member in seniority in the city, Messrs. Tappen and Cannon being away, the former at Lenox, Mass., and the latter in the Adirondacks.

Capt. Ervin L. Philips, Thirteenth Cavalry, will proceed to Fort Myer for temporary duty in connection with obtaining receipts for property turned over to his successor, now Quartermaster at Fort Myer.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 9 -- The city to-night is thronged with veterans of the civil war here to attend the thirty-fifth annual encampment of the Grand Army of the Republic. The one topic of conversation wherever is gathered a group of the old soldiers is the attempt on the life of President McKinley.

To the Editor of The New York Times: On my return to-day to the city I have been made aware that my name has been presented as that of a possible candidate for the Mayoralty. This has been done wholly without my agency or knowledge, and without any action by my friends, who all know that I have duties to fulfill which preclude me from any active part in politics at the present time.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 9 -- On favorable reports as to President McKinley's condition local stocks had a decided recovery over Saturday's slump. On the first transaction Union Traction advanced 1 1/4 over Saturday's close. Cambria Steel improved in the same measure. Choctaw preferred was up a point, and Lehigh Valley 1 1/2, Philadelphia Coal also moved 1 1/2, Philadelphia Electric 1/2, likewise Consolidated Lake Superior.
From now on until the date fixed for her to be dry docked with her rival, Columbia, in the Erie Basin, the Shamrock II, will go out for a trial spin every day, wind and weather permitting.

The public schools of the City of Greater New York threw open their floors yesterday, and it is estimated that more than half a million children, applied for admission. Two new school buildings in Manhattan Borough were thrown open, and in Brooklyn nine new buildings and additions received registrations.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 9 -- The crisis has passed. The strain on the heart-strings of the Nation has been relieved. It can to-night be stated with all but the assurance of absolute certainty that President McKinley will fully and speedily recover from the wounds inflicted upon him by the Anarchist Czolgosz.

There is much movement in town now, the avenue is filled with cabs and carriages, and wagons laden with trunks are rushing here and there. Some of the handsome residences are beginning to be opened and servants are preparing them for their owners. Next week will bring in many for the cup races.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 9 -- Thirty-five Amalgamated Association men returned to work at the plant of the Illinois Steel Company in Bayview to-day. Three out of the six of the company's mills, the top and bottom, the 12-inch and rail mill, were started this morning. There was no trouble whatever.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 9 -- William J. Bryan to-day telegraphed The Times as follows:

The cornerstone of the new Stock Exchange Building was laid yesterday afternoon with simple and appropriate ceremonies before the members of the Exchange. Much of the original programme was not followed, because of the present state of public feeling. The exercises consisted of speeches by R.H. Thomas, Chairman of the Building Committee, and President Rudolph Keppler, and the laying of the cornerstone, followed by three cheers for President Keppler and the Exchange.
According to Chicago dispatches, railroad rates are firm but traffic with most of the Eastern lines is unsatisfactory, although heavier than for a number of weeks.

LONDON, Sept. 10 -- The attack upon President McKinley and its consequences still form the leading topic of the British newspapers. The question how to deal with Anarchy is discussed on every side. It is felt that, if the President happily recovers, he will not have suffered in vain if the outrage results in stronger measures to suppress anarchism.

A marked improvement in prices characterized the trading in outside securities yesterday as compared with the weakness of last Saturday. While there was much less activity, business did not lag, and the volume of transactions for the day was fully as large as it was under the exceptional conditions of the previous trading day.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 9 -- Mayor Hayes announced this afternoon that he had received an offer from a syndicate to pay $8,000,000 for the city's interest in the "Western Maryland Railroad. He declined to give the names of the members of the syndicate, and added that he had procured an opinion from the city law department to the effect that the interest of the city comprised practically the entire system operated by the road.

With Mathewson's arm in fair condition once more, the New York baseball team easily won the first game yesterday afternoon at the Polo Grounds. The usual defeat, however, was experienced in the second contest, St. Louis winning much as she pleased by batting the New York pitchers hard and often.

Enthusiasts in the matter of intercollegiate contests have perhaps been misled by the statistics complied by Dr. JAMES W. WHITON, an alumnus of Yale of the class of '53, which show that at the end of nearly forty-nine years 46.29 per cent, of that strenuous class are living in good health, and that of the twenty-seven students who took part in the first Yale-Harvard boat race 55.55 per cent, survive.
Among the arrivals from Buffalo yesterday were the officers and men of Company C. First Heavy Artillery. They were within 150 feet of the President when he was shot.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 9 -- Senator Hanna is simply bubbling over with happiness and good nature, and has been so ever since he became satisfied that the President would get well. He is the life of the Buffalo Club, where he makes his headquarters, and every visit he makes to the Milburn residence results in a renewal of his good spirits.

Seventy-two motor carriages, propelled by steam and gasoline, yesterday morning left the headquarters of the Automobile Club of America, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-eighth Street, on the 465 mile endurance run to Buffalo. The scene of the start was one of unusual animation and the departure attracted much attention.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 9 -- Secretary Wilson of the Department of Agriculture, who is President McKinley's closest personal friend in the Cabinet, said during the course of an interview with the reporter of THE TIMES to-night:

WASHINGTON, Sept 9 -- Second Assistant Postmaster General Schallenberger today summarily canceled the contract of a mail carrier for expressing satisfaction over the shooting of President McKinley. The name of the person who was thus dealt with is Charles F. Cortright, and he had a contract for carrying the mail between Homer, Cortland County, N.Y., and Spafford, in Onondaga County, the same State.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Sept. 9 -- Another effort to settle the steel strike has failed. The General Executive Board of the Amalgamated Association adjourned this evening without date and without either accepting any of the peace propositions which have come indirectly from the United States Steel Corporation or without making any counter propositions, according to the official statement.

The outflow of money from New York to the interior at this season of the year is an incident of annual recurrence, to be expected and prepared for by the banks. It has this year set in more briskly and in larger volume than usual. The loss of cash, specie and legal tenders, by the Associated Banks since Aug. 10 amounts to $18,159,300.

BUFFALO, Sept. 9 -- President McKinley continues to show improvement in his condition. All the official bulletins showed great gains and inspired those near the President to state positively that he would recover rapidly. The last official bulletin, issued at 9:30 o'clock P.M., was as follows:
BUFFALO, Sept. 9 -- Dr. Charles McBurney of New York said after the issue of the 3 o'cloc bulletin on the President's condition that all the indications continued favorable.

LONDON, Sept. 9 -- Money was easy today, supplies were abundant, and the demand was moderate. Discounts were firm in view of the contingencies, especially the prospect of shipments of gold to New York.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Sept 9 -- Gov. Odell to-day decided to cancel all his public engagements for such time as President McKinley's condition shall remain critical. The Governor's secretary, James G. Graham, to-night said:

Stimulated by the encouraging reports from Buffalo telling of the President's improved and improving condition and further assured in respect to the general financial situation by the financial leaders who had rallied to prevent a panic on Saturday, the stock market yesterday opened up decidedly strong and with scarce any irregularity, and not only maintained that strength, but steadily improved until the last moment of trading.

The disintegrating strike of the Amalgamated Association, like most happenings which have their origin in the operation of forces generated by the friction of conflicting interests, promises to result in benefits to those engaged in it far greater and more substantial than those which were sought by the leaders who brought it about.

The death of JOHANNES VON MIQUEL, for ten years the Prussian Minister of Finance, was probably hastened by his virtual dismissal from the Government by the Emperor, whose confidence he had long enjoyed and whom he had served with remarkable fidelity and with brilliant success.

HAVANA, Sept. 9 -- La Lucha says the statement of Governor General Wood that the United States Government has not changed its intention, but intends to establish the Cuban Republic must settle all doubt on the subject, although it supposes the electoral law will have to go to Washington.

Yesterday's market was a superb exhibition of the inherent strength of American securities. Prices opening at considerable advances from Saturday's close and steadily advancing, the professional Wall Street element was bewildered, and such interests attempted to account for the remarkable strength by stories of pool support, combinations of bankers, and other artificial devices.

The remarkably high tides and the tremendous surf that have prevailed all along the Atlantic coast for the past few days, according to marine and weather experts, are not to be explained by atmospheric or astronomical causes. Unusually high tides prevail both in the Spring and Fall, but almost invariably during the last quarter of the full moon and not on the first quarter of the new moon.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 9 -- The opening of the Grand Circuit meeting at the New York State Fair Grounds to-day furnished excellent sport. The track was fast and a crowd of 10,000 saw the races. Shadow Chimes was favorite in the 2:23 pace, Empire State Stakes, and won after a five-heat contest.
LONDON, Sept. 9 -- A dispatch from St. Petersburg to a news agency says the Russian Government has decided to build five battleships, each of 20,000 tons, in Russian shipyards.

AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 9 -- Mayor R.E. White said to-day that shortly after the visit of President McKinley to Austin several months ago he was informed by an Italian of this city that a plot had been formed for the assassination of the President at this place, but that at the last moment it was abandoned. Mayor White at the time paid little heed to the statement.

LONDON, Sept. 10 -- Cardinal Vaughan, who does not often speak in public, made a striking address at the opening of the Catholic Conference in Newcastle last evening. He implored Catholics to call themselves Catholics -- Roman Catholics, if they pleased, but preferably Catholics.
LA PAZ, Sept. 8, 1901 -- President McKinley, Washington: I keenly deplore the nefarious crime committed on the person of your Excellency and make sincere wishes for your speedy and happy recovery.

Entire harmony did not characterize the proceedings at the meeting last night of the Joint conference of the representatives of the fifteen anti-Tammany associations. The conference from the organizations affiliated with the Republican organization dominated the situation and the Citizens' Union was defeated in an attempt to secure the throne and have the other organizations come to it or to a committee appointed by the Citizens' Union for the final instructions.

"It is to the honor of the European Journals," says the Paris Matin, referring to the attempted murder of President McKINLEY, "that on such an occasion their comments resemble each other closely; the language of one is the language of all."
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 9 -- Nixon Zimmerman's new Chestnut Street Theatre opened for the season to-night with Klaw Erlanger's Troubadours in the new musical comedy. "The Liberty Belles."
The trial of Policeman Edward O'Neill before Second Deputy Commissioner Bernard J. York was marked by unexpected developments yesterday.

BOSTON, Sept. 9 -- Mr. John Mason made his debut as a star to-night at the Hollis Street Theatre in a new play by Madeleine Lucette Ryley, entitled "The Altar of Friendship." The hero of the play. Rlchard Arbuthnot, is living in London, sharing his chambers with Arnold Winnifriun, a young barrister, who is about to be married to Arbuthnot's sister Florence.

BRISTOL, R.I., Sept. 9 -- Bare of flags and sails and out of commission the Constitution arrived this afternoon from Newport in tow of the tender Mount Morris. The craft is here to be dismantled. She was hauled alongside the wharf, that her spars may be taken out the more readily. The Constitution, as soon as dismantled, will be towed to New London.

OTTAWA, Ont., Sept. 9 -- For the first time in over twenty years the annual cricket match between Canada and the United States was played on the grounds of the Ottawa Cricket Club here to-day. The capital appreciated the honor of having the game in preference to Toronto, where the match is usually played, and there was a large attendance.

NEWPORT, Sept. 9 -- With the continued improvement in the President's condition and the probability of his ultimate recovery, society entertainments in Newport have been renewed, and to-night there were fully as many dinners as on any other night this season. Judging from present indications there will be no lack of luncheons and dinners during the week, unless there should be a change for the worse in Mr. McKinley's condition.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 9 -- Chairman M.A. Daugherty of the Democratic State Executive Committee to-day addressed a letter to Chairman Charles Dick of the Republican State Committee suggesting that, as an evidence of respect to the President, all political speeches for the campaign in Ohio be canceled, adding that a similar arrangement had been made at the time Garfield was assassinated.

Justice Jerome, Assistant District Attorney Garvan, and Frank Moss, accompanied by detectives from the Society for the Prevention of Crime, last night raided an alleged gambling house at 2O7 1/2 East Ninth Street. Five arrests were made.

John Pool Hardenbergh, for over twenty years in the fire and life insurance business in this city, died at the residence of his son, Henry J. Hardenburgh, at Bernardsville, N.J., yesterday. He was eighty years old. For about eighteen years Mr. Hardenbergh had an office at 146 Broadway, but recently he had been in the building at 135-137 Broadway.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 9 -- The audience gathered in the Broad Street Theatre tonight for the first performance of Leo Ditrichstein's "The Last Appeal" manifested general satisfaction with the entertainment. It was not a representative first night gathering; so, it is not unreasonable to believe that the applause was as sincere as it was liberal.
E.J. Moloughney has sold for Louis Lese, for about $12,000, the three-story brown-stone-front dwelling and stable 430 and 432 East One Hundred and Twenty-first Street, on plot 39 by 100.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 10 -- Owing to threatening weather a small crowd witnessed the Grand Circuit races at the State Fair track this afternoon. The first on the card was the unfinished 2:14 pace, which was won by The Hero in 2:10 1/2, lowering his mark. Summary:

The spleen was removed from Michael Vitele, six years old, at Harlem Hospital late yesterday. This is one of the rarest of surgical operations, and It was said that there are only Three other known cases of its having been performed successfully. Many doctors called at the hospital last night to learn what they could of the matter.

The Secretary of the Treasury has determined to add to deposits of internal revenue in the National banks about five millions, which is the margin between the present deposits and the par value of the bonds held as security. The amount, it is understood, will be distributed throughout the country, and between one and two millions will go to the banks of this city.

Eagerness for business on the part of two ambulance chasers brought joy to Lawyer Emanuel M. Friend in the Harlem Police Court yesterday, where he took an active hand in sending one of them to prison for striking at the other with a club.

The Municipal Assembly yesterday adopted two sets of resolutions regarding the shooting of President McKinley. One set originated in the Council and was adopted and sent to the Board of Aldermen, and by that body adopted. Another set of resolutions was passed by the Aldermen and sent to the Council.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Commenting upon his offer to buy $20,000,000 of Government bonds and his order directing that $5,000,000 of internal revenue receipts be placed in national banks, Secretary Gage said to-day:

To the Editor of The New York Times: At this time, when the public is so deeply concerned as to the outcome of our esteemed President's affliction, and his deeds are being recorded on the pages of history. It would not be out of place to narrate a little incident which occurred at the time of our war with Spain, and which reveals to some extent the very affectionate and considerate disposition of our President.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 10 -- There was a uniform betterment in the stock market today, with snappy trading in the first and last hours. The best spot was Cambria, for which there was a steady demand, carrying it up a half point, Philadelphia Company advanced to the same extent, on the outlook for an early consummation of the long-promised Pittsburg consolidation.
