The Ward Liner Morro Castle, which arrived here yesterday from Havana, brought in her cabin thirty-four Cuban school teachers, who are going to take a year's course at the State Normal School at New Paltz, Ulster County, N.Y. The young women were chaperoned during the ocean trip by Mrs. Varzaga.

The North German Lloyd steamship Koenigin Luise, which arrived here yesterday from Bremen, had on board a hero -- August Liemann, a German who unhesitatingly jumped sixty feet from the hurricane deck of the steamer into the water on Monday to save a poor drink-crazed steerage passenger who had thrown himself overboard.

MAY'S LANDING, N.J., Sept. 10 -- In his charge to the Grand Jury when the September session of the Atlantic County Court convened to-day. Supreme Court Justice Hendrickson instructed that body in an exhaustive and emphatic manner regarding the violations of the Sunday liquor law in Atlantic City.

BUFFALO, Sept. 10 -- There is much in the nature of wild speculation being published concerning the progress made by the local and Federal police end prosecuting officers in establishing a conspiracy among Anarchists which resulted in the shooting of the President by Czolgosz. Nothing has developed in the situation here to justify any direct statements along this line.
LONDON, Sept. 11.-- The Paris correspondent of The Times says:

PATERSON, N.J., Sept. 10 -- Six Secret Service men were in Paterson yesterday, in the effort to learn whether or not there was an Anarchist plot here to take the life of the President. All the haunts of the Anarchists were visited. What evidence the Government detectives gathered is not known.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I read in the New Testament that Jesus went about doing good; that He never ceased in His work of love. Homeless and with scarcely an earthly friend, His mission never ended. His whole earthly career was one round of ceaseless labor. He was the friend of the poor, the outcast, and the sinner.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10 -- Emma Goldman, whose Anarchistic harangues are alleged to have "fired the brain" of Leon Czolgosz, was arrested here shortly before noon today and is held on a warrant charging her with conspiracy to assassinate President McKinley. C.J. Norris, at whose home Miss Goldman was captured, was arrested later.

Results of the telegram sent on Monday by Chairman Frederick D. Tappen of the Clearing House Committee to Lyman J. Gage, Secretary of the Treasury, at Buffalo, in regard to the money situation were had yesterday. Secretary Gage directed that about $5,000,000 of internal revenue receipts be placed with National bank depositories, and gave notice that he would consider proposals for the sale of not exceeding $20,000,000 of Government bonds.

Aside from that chance of being left at the post, it is doubtful if ever a favorite in a horse race was beaten so quickly and summarily as was the strong public choice Charagrace in the Mineola Hurdle Handicap, one of the stake features of the programme at the Sheepshead Bay race track yesterday.

YONKERS, N.Y., Sept. 10 -- Andrew Archibald, one of the best-known manufacturers of this city, lost $7,000 on Friday last on Broadway, New York City, between City Hall Park and Battery Place. Whether he dropped the money out of his hip pocket, or it was stolen from him he does not know.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Sept. 10 -- The Democratic State Central and Executive Committees, by a vote of 11 to 7, to-day, defeated the proposition to nominate a candidate for United States Senator by a popular primary election, and referred the matter to the next Democratic State Convention, which will meet in 1903.

William Brock Shoemaker, who was manager of the Columbia football team last year, has been elected manager of the University hockey team for this season. Mr. Shoemaker was in the early part of the season renominated for footballl manager, but, in order to make college political matters serene, he resigned.

PITTSBURG, Sept. 10 -- While a settlement of the steel strlke was again rumored to-day and again denied by trust officials and officers of the Amalgamated Association, the day was full of action, violence, and mob rule. Women sympathizers with the strikers, too, furnished work for the police.

BUFFALO, Sept. 10 -- The condition of President McKinley to-night is told more eloquently than by the doctors' bulletins in a few plain statements of fact. The members of his Cabinet, under an agreement reached to-day with the doctors, will meet around his bed on Friday afternoon at 3 o'clock to submit to him such matters of official business as they deem necessary.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 10 -- Sixteen players are now left of the thirtytwo championship eligibles who earned their way into the match-play class yesterday, when the annual championship golf tournament of the United States was opened on the links of the Atlantic City Country Club.

The Stewards of The Coney Island Jockey Club's meeting, now in progress at the Sheepshead Bay race track, held a meeting after the races of yesterday, and later sent out the following official announcement:

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 10 -- A serious and possibly fatal runaway accident occurred on Bellevue Avenue this afternoon. Gen. Joseph Wheeler, whose portrait was recently painted by a young Newport artist, William H. Leavitt, has on several occasions loaned his handsome black horse Alabama to Mr. Leavitt for a horseback ride, and this afternoon the horse was sent to the artist's house.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Sept. 10 -- A large contingent of the Lenox cottagers attended the opening day of the fair of the Berkshire Agricultural Society in Pittsfield to-day, and took part in various track events. A hurdle race over four-foot jumps was cleverly won by Charles Astor Bristed's gray jumper.

PITTSBURG, Sept. 10 -- From McKeesport it is repotted that to-night three workmen were set upon by strikers or strike sympathizers and badly beaten. Henry Weir, a water tender at the tube works, when he came from the mill, was warned not to return in the morning. He started to run, followed by a crowd of Hungarians.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 10 -- An investigation of the local record of Antonio Maggio, the Italian who is said to have predicted the death of President McKinley, and who is under arrest in New Mexico, reveals the fact that he was the leader of a considerable band of Anarchists in Kansas City two years ago.

BERLIN, Sept. 10 -- Everybody here rejoices in the reassuring dispatches about the condition of President McKinley. Public interest in the outcome of the assassin's attack has in no way abated. A fine picture of Mr. McKinley in the window of the office of the Lokal Anzeiger attracted Crowds to-day.

WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 10 -- The September meeting of the Worcester Driving Park Company opened to-day with the 2:17 pace, 2:35 trot, and 2:29 pace on the card. The favorites were dumped in the first two races, but Naniwa, who was picked to win the slow pace, got away with it in straight heats.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In less than twoscore years three times has the assassin's blow fallen upon the supreme head of our dearly bought Nation. The man who shot our beloved President last week shot with intent to kill, and only regrets that he did not kill. He glories in his deed and is upheld, Justified, and applauded by the brotherhood of whom he is a representative.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 10 -- Michel Schuttz, a member of the First Austrian Sick Benefit Society and a supposed Anarchist, was ignominiously expelled from the organization by his fellow-members last night, and Capt. Edwards of the Fourth Precinct, with his reserves in citizens' clothes, was on hand to back them up in case their action led to trouble.
In the opinion of many of the best-in-formed politicians in the city, the nomination for Mayor on the anti-Tammany ticket has narrowed down to CoL E. M. Knox, John D. Crimmins, and Eugene A. Philbin.

If a mascot really counts for anything in a yacht race, Sir Thomas Lipton ought to win beyond peradventure, for he has enough mascots on board the Erin to start a menagerie.
The trial of Policeman O NEILL, before Deputy Commissioner YORK on Monday resolved itself, in some sense, to the intense discomfiture of Mr. DEVERY, into a trial of the First Deputy Commissioner.

The Hoboken Land and Improvement Company yesterday began the erection of a 1,000-foot crib bulkhead at the foot of Fifteenth Street. None of the company's officers would give any information on the subject, but some of the workmen said that the bulkhead was the first step in the construction of a new railroad terminal to be established at that point.

BOSTON, Sept. 10 -- Miss Lydia L.A. Very, teacher and author, died at her home 154 Federal Street, Salem, this morning after a brief Illness. She was born in this city on Nov. 2, 1823. She was a teacher in the Salem public and private schools for thirty-four years. Among her books were "Sayings and Doings Among Insects and Flowers," "Slyph, the Organ Grinder's Daughter," "A Strange Disclosure," and "An Old-Fashioned Garden."
To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read with much interest a recent communication to your esteemed paper concerning dogs in the city's streets.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 10 -- There is but little life in social circles; many of the cottagers are leaving for the Adirondacks, Lenox. or Long Island, and the season, one of the most successful on record, is rapidly closing. There is tennis still at the Casino to furnish entertainment for the morning and for a few in the afternoon; there are a few luncheons daily and still fewer dinners at night.

A continued improvement in prices and a very general restriction in the volume of trading marked the course of industrial and miscellaneous shares in the market for outside securities yesterday. Activity was most noticeable in the bond division, while copper shares were dull and bank and gas stocks were neglected.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- J.R. Garrison, the Auditor of Porto Rico, said to-day that Information received by him from the Deputy Auditor of the island, Mr. Rockwell, who is acting in Mr. Garrison's absence, shows that the collection of revenues under the tax law of Jan. 31, 1901, passed at the last session of the Legislative Assembly, is highly satisfactory, exceeding in amount what was expected.

LONDON, Sept. 10 -- Money was easy today and discounts were quiet. The fall in New York exchange enhanced the caution which the banks exercised in discounting bills. The applications for L2,000,000 twelve months' Treasury bills amounted to L6,613,000.

WASHINGTON, Sept 10 -- With the detail of Solicitor of the Navy Edwin P. Hanna to assist Judge Advocate General Lemly in the Schley court of inquiry, the list of counsel, at any rate, so far as the early sessions are concerned, is complete. While Rear Admiral Schley is represented by a strong array of lawyers, no counsel of National fame is likely to oppose them.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10 -- The largest grain elevator in the world, with a capacity of 4,000,000 bushels, is to be built at Weehawken, N.J., by the Chicago firm of George M. Moulton Co. for the West Shore line of the New York Central Road.

BOSTON, Sept. 10 -- Lending rates are still largely nominal. A 5 per cent basis underlies practically all classes of loans, with the general tone quite firm. Call money ranges from 4 1/2 to 5 per cent. or over; time money from 4 1/2 to 5 1/2 per cent., and business paper from a minimum of 4 1/2 to 6 per cent.

All known Anarchists are to be forthwith driven from the City of New York, according to Police Commissioner Murphy, who, with the purpose avowedly in view, yesterday ordered a careful census to be compiled of all adherents to the murderous cult. This will be utrned over to the Detective Bureau, and the Central Office detectives will join with the precinct policemen in making conditions disagreeable for the persons named.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 10 -- Augustus Thomas's new musical comedy, or farce, "Champagne Charley," was given its first public presentation to-night at the Court Square Theatre, and met with a cordial reception. While "Champagne Charley" is not more coherent than, other musical farce-comedies, it contains an abundance of bright lines with dialogue, new jokes, and puns, of which full advantage is taken by the star, Peter P. Dailey.
PARIS, Sept. 11 -- It was announced yesterday that Turkey has paid the claim of M. Tubini, after direct negotiations between the Porte and the claimant.

The City Trust Company, the depositary for the stock of the Telephone, Telegraph and Cable Company of America, announced yesterday afternoon that at noon over two-thirds of the stock had been deposited, in accordance with the recent offer of Charles W. Morse to the stockholders, and that the offer has become operative.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 10 -- The Naval Veterans took first place in the festivities, attendant upon the Grand Army Encampment to-day. The eighty-seventh anniversary of Oliver Hazard Perry's triumph on Lake Erie was fittingly celebrated in a grand parade of naval veterans and a naval display on the lake.

Some of the public schools of the city got fully under way yesterday, but this could not be said of many of them. The pressure for admittances and the complications of organizing part-time classes so clogged the wheels of the schools that in numerous instances little or no progress could be made.

It is rather an extraordinary statement to make, but it is a fact attested to by the largest financial interests in Wall Street, that the stock market to-day is actually in a sounder and stronger position than it would have been at this time had the attempt on the President's life not been made.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept 10 -- Nearly all of the automobilists who left Poughkeepsie this morning arrived in good time at Albany this evening. There were only a few minor accidents, but five -- miles out of Poughkeepsie a steam machine, it was reported turned upside down and caught fire, being badly damaged.

The Pan-American Exposition Company of Buffalo has been sued in the Supreme Court in this city by the Mayo Rohrer Co., dealers in electrical supplies. In addition to the action here, a mechanics' lien for $2,929,65 has been filed by the plaintiffs Erie County. This lien is for the amount said to be due and is placed on all the buildings of the exposition.

-- What at first sight looks like a rather difficult question is raised by The Philadelphia Ledger. Fifty-six men, it says, were rescued by life saving crews from vessels wrecked on Lake Huron by last Saturday night's fierce gale, and the news dispatches told the story in not many more words than are here used.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Now that we have about recovered from the first shock of the assault on the President, and are anxiously hoping that the life of our beloved Chief Executive may be saved, two questions necessarily occur to us: Upon whom devolved the duty of guarding the President; and was that duty properly performed ?

Armed with warrants for seven members of a family of Joneses, agents of the Society for the Prevention of Crime invaded Capt. Moynihan's precinct, the West Twentieth Street Station, yesterday afternoon and raided an alleged poolroom at 121 Eighth Avenue, capturing three of the men who were called for in the warrants.
LONDON, Sept. 11 -- The supplies of money were fairly large and easy to-day.
S. Osgood Pell Co. have sold for William H. Smith to a client the four-story brownstone-front dwelling 20 East Sixty-fifth Street, 25 by 100.

LONDON, Sept. 12 -- In the third round of the gentlemen's singles yesterday at Eastbourne, in connection with the South England Lawn Tennis championship tournament, W.J. Clothier was beaten by H.S. Mahony.

BOSTON, Sept. 11 -- Dr. Henry G. Beyer, Chief Surgeon at the Charlestown Navy Yard, returned from his visit to Admiral Sampson this morning. He said the Admiral's condition was about the same as when he left the yard. He would not state whether the Admiral would attend the court of inquiry or whether he would return to the yard to take up his duties.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 11 -- Prominent stocks were not much dealt in to-day, and much of the activity was in issues hitherto neglected. The market was irregular. Prominent issues were generally a shade lower at the close. An improvement in bond trading was noted, and this in a measure also diverted attention from the stock list.

The grain market yesterday advanced much less than was expected in many quarters in view of the Government report on corn. Wheat opened strong and advanced half a cent, only to react to Tuesday night's figures on profit-taking. Selling orders were also executed for Chicago, because of the receipt of 958 cars in the Northwest, as against 438 cars last year, and, at primary points, 1,514,000 bushels, as against 1,318,000 bushels last year.

Mayor Van Wyck yesterday, at the first meeting after his Summer vacation of the Board of Estimate, forced through a resolution appointing Horgan Slattery, the Tammany Hall architects, to complete the work on the new Hall of Records, which until his death was under the supervision of John R. Thomas.

JOLIET, Ill., Sept. 11 -- An attempt will be made to reopen the Illinois steel mills here Friday morning, with or without the consent of the Amalgamated Association. This fact was made plain at a protracted meeting of the strikers to-day. Two of the head Superintendents of the mills were permitted to address the session.

BOSTON, Sept. 11 -- The Rev. Dr. William McDonald, a prominent Methodist clergyman, evangelist, and author, died this morning at his home in Somerville. He was taken ill on Thursday, Aug. 20, and sank steadily.
GIBRALTAR, Sept. 11 -- The United States cruiser Chicago has arrived here. She will sail for Genoa to-morrow, and will there await the arrival of the Nashville and Albany.

Contracts aggregating $1,500,000 have been awarded by the Rapid Transit Subway Construction Company to the Allis-Chalmer Company and the Babcock Wilcox Company for the construction of eight 7,500 horse power stationary engines and forty-eight 600-horse power boilers to be used in connection with the forthcoming rapid transit underground railroad in this city.

BUFFALO, Sept. 11 -- The condition of the President has continued favorable throughout to-day, and nothing occurred to shake the faith the attending surgeons and physicians have expressed that he will recover. After a consultation to-night the physicians announced that a microscopical examination of blood taken from the President showed no trace of blood poisoning.

TARRYTOTVN, N.Y., Sept. 11 -- Play in the annual tournament of the Sleepy Hollow Tennis Club, which began on Monday, reached the semi-finals to-day in both the men's singles and men's doubles, and a beginning was made in the mixed doubles. In the men's singles the finalists are R.D. Little of Princeton University and H. Hackett, who will meet in the final to-morrow.

BOSTON, Sept. 11 -- Money on call is slightly firmer; the 4 1/2 per cent. minimum is accorded to fewer borrowers and as high as 5 1/2 per cent. is paid. Some of the trust companies are accepting choice time loans at 4 1/2 per cent., but the general range is from 5 to 5 1/2 per cent. Business ranges from 4 1/2 to 6 per cent.

Miss Bertha Galland, who was last season the principal woman in the company associated with Mr. Hackett in the performance of "The Pride of Jennicb," appeared as a "star" at the Lyceum Theatre on Tuesday night. She was received with cordiality by a large audience, and may be said to have achieved a personal success.

A fair degree of activity with normal conditions generally attended the trading in the market for outside securities yesterday. Advances were scored in most cases, although some of the industrial and miscellaneous shares underwent declines. Throughout the list, however, no violent fluctuations were registered.

Delegates to the third annual conference of the Association of Hospital Superintendents, meeting at the Murray Hill Hotel yesterday, heard various reforms urged in papers read by Byron M. Child, Superintendent of the State and Alien Poor of the State Board of Charities, on "The Relation of the State to the Hospital" and by Dr. H.A. Fairbairn on "The Hospital from the Standpoint of the Visiting Physician."

HERKIMER, N.Y., Sept. 11 -- Wet weather encountered the automobiles to-day on their run from Albany to Herkimer in the Buffalo endurance journey. The rain, with poor roads, put fully a dozen motor vehicles out of the run, and one big machine was left badly wrecked at Mohawk. In crossing a trolley track the front axle and one wheel were broken and its passengers thrown to the street, but they were uninjured.

WILLEMSTAD, Island of Curacao, Sept. 11 -- The French cruiser Suchet, which left Porto Colombia, near Barranquilla, Sept. 5, arrived here yesterday. On her way here she stopped at La Hacha, Colombia, a town at the mouth of the Rio Hacha, on the west side of the Guajira Peninsula, about 100 miles northwest of Maracaibo.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- The following message was received to-day from United States Minister Conger at Peking, China: "Earl Li on behalf of himself and Government sends sympathy and prayers for President's recovery."

Unexpectedly high prices were realized in the peremptory sale of silks conducted yesterday by Townsend Montant in the auction rooms at 87 and 89 Leonard Street, and many large buyers who expected to bid in quantities of goods contented themselves, because of these high prices, with small purchases.

-- Friends of Mr. HERBERT SQUIERS, the Secretary of the United States Legation at Peking, were much offended and grieved, naturally enough, at the recent application of the word "loot" to the art treasures which he has collected in China, and which, it is said, he intends to present to the Metropolitan Museum.

CONNEULSVILLE, Penn., Sept. 11 -- The long-continued efforts of the daring rescue party at Port Royal were crowned with success to-day. Seven of the thirteen bodies that have been entombed since June 10, When the explosion in the coal mine of the Pittsburg Coal Company took place, were recovered and brought to the bottom of No. 1 shaft.

HELA, Prussia, Sept. 11 -- Emperor William and Emperor Nicholas met to-day on board the German imperial yacht Hohenzollern. The Kaiser put to sea at 7 o'clock in the morning in order to meet the Russian imperial yacht Standart, which brought the Czar to German waters. The Czarina, on the imperial yacht Pole Star, did not accompany the Standart, but went to Kiel.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Rear Admiral Howison reported at the Navy Department to-day. He said:

First Lieuts, Van Leer Wills, Twelfth Infantry, and John McClintook Fifth Cavalry, will proceed to Omaha and report to Brig. Gen. John C. Bates, commanding the Department of the Missouri, for duty as aides de camp on his staff.

According to the report submitted to the School Board for the Boroughs of Manhattan and the Bronx by Borough Superintendent John Jasper, last night, 2,029 children were refused admission to the public schools on the opening day, Sept. 9, and 15,069 pupils have already been put in part-time classes.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In view of the dastardly attack upon President McKinley, permit me to make the following suggestions as my humble contribution in the way of preventing the recurrence of similar outrages.
The anti-Tammany nomination for Mayor, at this time, seems to have been narrowed down to Col. E.M. Knox, John D. Crimmins, Capt. F. Norton Goddard, and District Attorney E.A. Philbin.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 11 -- Jacob R. Davis, a wealthy resident of the Township of Mansfield, Warren County, has brought action in the Chancery Court by which he seeks to have his wife Rosa, deprived of her dower rlghts in his estate should he die before her. The complainant is seventy years old, and his wife is forty-four years his junior.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Sept. 11 -- The New York Council of the National Tube Company met with the local council at Pittsburg to-day to discuss the strike. It was announced that the council voted without taking final action and will probably meet again to-morrow. It was practically settled, however, that no long shut-down would be tolerated, and that the next attempt to start will be a determined one.

BUFFALO, Sept. 11 -- Superintendent of Police Bull to-night telegraphed to Chief O'Neill at Chicago that requisition papers for Emma Goldman were being prepared and would be forwarded as soon as possible. This telegram was sent after a consultation with District Attorney Penney, who assured Superintendent Bull that he believed there was sufficient evidence to warrant him in bringing Miss Goldman to Buffalo for trial for conspiracy to assassinate the President.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Sept. 11 -- The International cricket match between Canada and the United States was decided here to-day on the ground of the Ottawa Cricket Club, where for the nineteenth time since the annual series began the United States proved victorious.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Secretary Gage has received a number of offers of bonds for the Sinking Fund under his announcement of yesterday, but he has decided not to give cut any information as to the amounts offered or prices until his offer expires to-morrow afternoon.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11 -- Magistrate Prindiville to-day decided that Emma Goldman, the Anarchistic lecturer under arrest here, should be held without bail pending the decision of similar cases in the Superior Court.

The London Times is printing every day a short extract from its issue of the same day a hundred years ago. Many of these reprints are so interesting that the practice, we should suppose, will never be abandoned. The Revolutionary period is skipped under the conditions of the scheme, which is unfortunate, as some of the incidents of that time have a bearing upon present-day eyents.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Now that the intense excitement and indignation over the awful tragedy at Buffalo last Friday have in a measure abated and the people are in a mood to listen to reason and not advocate absurd measures that can never be carried out, let us see if some Constitutional means cannot be devised for meeting just such an emergency in the future.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Sept. 11 -- An unexpected strike to-day forced the silk mill of Givernaud Brothers to close its doors. The strikers were Italians, who objected to a German foreman, of the mill. They want him discharged for showing, as they allege, favoritism to the German and the American workmen.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 11 -- The new Russian battleship Retvizan, one of the most formidable war craft in the world, left Cramps' shipyard this morning for her preliminary or builders' trial trip. This test is merely for the purpose of ascertaining whether her machinery and hull are in proper condition and the screws properly poised.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 11 -- Eight players now remain to battle for the amateur golf championship of the United States, and while most of the favorites won to-day in the second match play round at the Atlantic City Country Club, there were two or three surprises. To one of these the Chicagoans were treated when they saw their best golfer, the wonderful junior, Holabird, put out of the event by the Bostonian, A.G. Lockwood.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- The Reorganization Committee of the Seventh National Bank of New York has an appointment to meet Controller Dawes here next Friday, when it is assumed it will submit plans of reorganization for his approval, or at least state what progress has been made toward reorganization.

"Major" Taylor's extraordinary work at Boston on Friday and Saturday, where he captured three of the double-point races in the National Cycling Association grand circuit, places him only eight points behind Kramer, who has been the loader ever since the grand circuit started. Only two more championship races are to be contested on the circuit, which will close at New Haven on Tuesday night.
GLASGOW, Sept. 11 -- The annual meeting of the British Association began here to-day.

There is a regular rush from Newport and Bar Harbor, and each day there are more arrivals in town from the different watering places. This afternoon at Newport will take place the wedding of Mrs. Gwendolyn King and E. Maitland Armstrong. The ceremony will take place at Trinity Church, and the Rev. Henry Morgan Stone will officiate.

BERLIN, Sept. 11 -- The German, Austrian, and even the Russian papers unanimously recognize in the meeting of the Czar and the Kaiser further proof of the friendly relations between the two powers and a guarantee of the preservation of the peace of the world.

CAPE HENLOPEN, Del., Sept. 11 -- The handsome steam yacht Rapidan, owned by Robert Hall McCormick, of Chicago, went ashore on the point off here late last night, and probably will become a total wreck. Two guests, the Captain, and a crew of seven men landed in surfboats after considerable difficulty.

With her cabins full or people, the big White Star liner Oceanic, from Liverpool, steamed into port yesterday morning after a passage that, with the exception of about twelve hours, was about as pleasant a one as a voyager could wish for. The unpleasant part was due to some rather strong head winds and heavy seas that the great liner had to contend with on her second day out.

BUFFALO, Sept. 11 -- A beautiful floral piece, in the form of an American flag on an easel made of roses and evergreens, arrived at the Milburn residence at noon. It was fully 6 feet high, and was the gift of the Italian colony in New York, in whose behalf it was presented by the Italian Consul here.

CAMDEN, N.J., Sept. 11 -- Ethelbert Stone, who was arrested here last night on the charge of "aiding and abetting in the attempted assassination of President McKinley," was released late this afternoon. He says he is not an Anarchist and never had any intercourse with the "Reds." He insists that he was always a Republican and that he voted for President McKinley.

LONDON, Sept. 11 -- The one hundred and twenty-sixth race for the Doncaster St. Leger Stakes was run to-day and won by Leopold de Rothschild's Doricles, after a sensational finish, by a short neck from the popular favorite Volodyovski, the Derby winner and the representative in the race of the American millionaire "William C. Whitney.

There are around New York Harbor a great number of vessels that are very old and yet are to all appearances safe enough for the ordinary traffic on excursions on the rivers, harbor, or upper bay, which are not to be trusted to meet the conditions that are apt to prevail outside of Sandy Hook, where the cup races are to be held.

Inability to bit the ball was the main reason why the New York baseball team met defeat yesterday, but stupid base-running had something to do with it. With the exception of the first inning, the New Yorks could do nothing with the pitching of Stimmel, one of the new recruits of Cincinnati. Phyle, on the other hand, while not hit particularly hard, seemed to be rather easy for Cincinnati when hits meant runs.

When Sir Thomas Lipton said yesterday morning, "The Shamrock is going out to stretch her new mainsail," he little thought, nor, did any one of his party, what kind of a stretching; it would get, for the yacht ran up against a Yankee squall in the lower bay that gave her the worst "knockdown that a ninety-footer ever got.

LONDON, Sept. 12 -- Money was in improved demand to-day, partly in connection with the settlement, and supplies were abundant. Discounts were easier. There was less apprehension of early shipments of gold to New York, in view of Secretary Gage's action in offering to buy $20,000,000 of outstanding Government bonds.

BUFFALO, Sept. 12 -- The President's progress had been so rapid and encouraging that a bulletin issued at 8:30 o'clock to-night announcing that he was not so well and that his food had not agreed with him caused a shock. The experiment of nourishing the President through the mouth was forced on the physicians earlier than they had intended to try it.

The attendance of yachts at the approaching international yacht races promises, according to well-known yachtsmen, to be the largest known. The anchorage of the New York Yacht Club in the East River, between Twentieth and Twenty-eighth Streets, is the gathering place of the yachts, and at present there are about seventy vessels, representing a value of about $40,000,000, at anchor.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12. -- At the close of the first day of the Schley court of inquiry the inquiry stands indefinitely postponed, because of the elimination from the court of Rear Admiral Henry L. Howison, upon the challenge by Rear Admiral Schley of his fitness to serve.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- The State Department has received the following, under date of Philadelphia, Sept. 9: President McKinley, Buffalo: A delayed cablegram to me from Cardinal Rampolla, Secretary of State to Pope Leo, dated Sept. 7, says:

Superintendent John Jasper of the public schools of the Boroughs of Manhattan and the Bronx, is putting into operation a new plan to relieve the congestion in the schools of the city. On the opening day of the school year 2,395 children were refused admission, while 15,069 were put in part-time classes, with a promise of both these numbers increasing by the end of the week.

The appointment by the Board of Estimate of the Tammany architects in place of the late Mr. THOMAS to finish the Hall of Records confutes the adage that it is only the unexpected that happens; we must be thankful that Messrs. GUGGENHEIMER and COLER opposed the indecent haste shown by the Mayor to turn the morsel over to these sinister instruments of Tammany.

LONDON, Sept. 18 -- The farce "Are You a Mason?" now running at the Garrick Theatre, New York City, was produced at the Shaftesbury Theatre last night by an almost purely British company under the management of Charles Frohman and George Edwardes. In contrast with the treatment meted out recently to wholly American productions, it was well received.

BUFFALO, Sept. 12 -- The President had had a restful night, and the beef juice which the doctors gave him yesterday had been relished so keenly that this morning for the first time solid food was given him. He was bathed and then enjoyed a breakfast of chicken broth, toast, and coffee.

The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

Under the auspices of the United Real Estate Owners' Association the first of a series of mass meetings to express condemnation of the new tenement house law was held last night in the New York Turn Hall, Lexlngtoh Avenue and Eighty-fifth Street. The large assembly room on the third floor, was packed to overflowing, many of the audience having to stand in the doorways while the speaking was in progress.

About 200 subscribers for stock in the United Consumers' National Bank met yesterday afternoon in the Lexington Opera House, Fifty-eighth Street, near Third Avenue, for the purpose of perfecting the organization of what is to be the first co-operative banking institution established in this country, upon the model of the famous co-operative banks of Germany, and notably of the City of Bremen.

LONDON, Sept 12 -- The disposition to spoil American theatrical productions by organized, "booing" is made more evident by the clamor in the gallery at the production of "The Whirl at the Town" at the Century Theatre last night. The reception accorded to William Gillette in his production of "Sherlock Holmes" on Monday at the Lyceum Theatre was at first considered to be a detached incident.

It is not the purpose of the attorney, for the estate of John R. Thomas, who designed the new Hall of Records, to take any action looking toward superseding Horgan Slattery, the Tammany contractors who were appointed on Wednesday by the Board of Estimate and Apportionment to succeed Mr. Thomas as supervising architects of the building.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept., 12 -- The National Convention of the Grand Army of the Republic opened this morning at the Euclid Avenue Opera House. The feature of to-day's session was the report of Commander in Chief Rassieur, in which he advocated the preparation of charges against Pension Commissioner Evans and their submission to the President.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- Monsignor Stephan, Director of the Catholic Indian Missions since 1884, died here to-day.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept. 12 -- The Right Rev. Bishop Whipple is dangerously ill at his home in Faribault, and as he is past eighty years of age his friends fear he will not survive. Dr. Stone of St. Paul has been called in consultation with the local physician, and a trained nurse has been sent to the Bishop's bedside.

BOSTON, Sept. 12. -- The nominal range on call loans is from 4 1/2 to 5 1/2 per cent., but on new loans 5 per cent. generally-prevails as the minimum. Time money generally ranges from 5 to 6 per cent. The market for commercial paper is dull; the supply is moderate, but of mediocre quality, and rates run from 4 1/2 per cent., on exceptional names, to 6 per cent.

BUFFALO, Sept. 13 -- Superintendent Bull was advised by wire at midnight that the Chicago police have arrested Dr. Isaac Saylin of Buffalo, who is known to be a friend of Emma Goldman, and who left Buffalo hastily on the night of the attempted assassination of the President.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 12 -- Wet weather and muddy roads gave no end of trouble to the automobolists to-day who are making a six-day endurance test run to Buffalo. Their arrival at this place this evening completed 307 miles of the total of 464 miles, and the hardships of the day's run put a few more motor vehicles out of commission.

The tract of about sixty-five lots, owned by the Yorkville Bank, lying between the Port Washington Ridge Road, and the Boulevard Lafayette, just north of One Hundred and Ninety-fifth Street, is reported lo have changed hands. Inquiry at the bank failed to elicit any further information regarding the transaction.

With her awnings housed and her yard taken down, H.H. Rogers's steam yacht Kanawha, which was beaten by the Central Railroad of New Jersey's fast steamboat Sandy Hook Wednesday morning in a race from Sandy Hook to a point off Castle Williams, Governors Island, hovered off the Hook yesterday morning, awaiting a chance to retrieve her lost laurels.

Policeman John Marrinan of the Madison Street Station, who was one of the principal witnesses for Policeman O'Neill last Monday, was one of those on trial before Deputy Commissioner Devery yesterday. He was charged by Inspector Cross with appearing for inspection in trousers that were soiled.
MILBURN HOUSE, Buffalo, Sept. 13 -- President McKinley experienced a sinking spell shortly after 2 o'clock. The physicians are administering restoratives to him with the hope of reviving him.

The application of Policeman Edward G. Glennon, indicted for neglect of duty in failing to suppress a disorderly house, for a change of venue to another county, on the ground that it will be impossible for him to secure a fair trial here, was placed on the calendar of the Supreme Court, before Justice Truax yesterday.

No change in the Bank of England's rate of discount. According to London cables, the output of gold from the Transvaal for August was 28,225 ounces. Standard National Bank of Pittsburg organized, with $2,000,000 Capital. New Orleans dispatches stating that the New, Orleans City Railroad, controlling thirteen lines, will be leased to a New York and Philadelphia syndicate, which will control 186 miles of surface railroad in the vicinity of New Orleans.

The anti-Tammany Committee of Eighteen at a meeting held at the Down-Town Association's quarters, 60 and 62 Pine Street, yesterday afternoon eliminated from the possible list of candidates for Mayor the names of the following men: Eugene A. Philbin, John-D. Crimmins, E. Ellery Anderson, Rastus S. Ransom, C.V. Farnes, Ludwig Nissen, Thomas F. Dunham, and L. J. Callanan.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE NEW YORK TIMES of Sunday, Sept. 8, I found a most interesting article under the heading of "New York's Unique Charities." It was doubly interesting to me because it appealed so directly to my heart.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- The court convened promptly at 1 o'clock, the hour prescribed, and when it was called to order all the members were present. Admiral Dewey occupied a place in the centre of the court table and was flanked on either side by Read Admirals Benson and Howison, the associate members of the court.

Mayor Van Wyck's heads of city departments are now filing with the Board of Estimate the departmental budgets for 1902. The requisitions being made will be acted on by the Board of Estimate in September and October and the amount of money which can be expended on all city departmerits should be determined in the usual course of events before election day.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 12 -- The marriage of Miss Gwendolen King, daughter of Mrs. David King, to Edward Maitland Armstrong in Trinity Church and the reception which followed at Kingscote, the residence of the bride's mother, on Bellevue Avenue, were the principal social events of the day in Newport.

Johann Most, the Anarchist, and editor of the Anarchistic organ, Freiheit, was arrested last night in a saloon at 69 Gold Street, over which are the oftices of his newspaper. Most had consumed one glass of beer and had called for another when Central Office Detectives Krauch and Ferneisen stepped forward and told him he was under arrest.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I read with some surprise some remarks of the Rev. Dr. MacArthur in his sermon last Sunday, which appeared in your issue of Monday, in which the reverend gentleman has attempted to fasten a certain responsibility for the murderous assault upon the President upon "the anti-imperialists."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- Capt. Shoemaker, Chief of the Revenue Cutter Service, to-day made public the following rules and reflations which will be enforced by the United States revenue cutters during the uinternational yacht races.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 12 -- This was a crucial day for the eight golfers who were left this morning in the contest for National championship golf honors, and all of the matches were close and exciting. The sensation of the day was the defeat of Boston's pride, A.G. Lockwood, by young Charles H. Seeley of the metropolitan district, and champion of Connecticut.

OAKLAND, N.J., Sept. 12 -- Three explosions occurred at the works of the American E.C. and Schultze Powder Company at this place at 1:30 this afternoon. Five persons were killed, two probably fatally injured, and many others badly hurt.

The professionals had the racing at the Sheepshead Bay race track practically to themselves yesterday, few of the amateur element caring to brave the weather conditions that prevailed, but nevertheless there was a crowd, and when, late in the afternoon, the skies cleared, only good racing was wanting to keep up the excellent average of the meeting.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 12 -- Choctaw led an otherwise tame and uninteresting local market. Other stocks with some activity, were the Readings, Cambria Steel, and Consolidated Traction of Pittsburg. All these made gains, but were unable to hold them, except Choctaw, which closed 1 1/4 higher. In the early trading Union Traction was elevated 1/2 but later receded to last night's price.

It is not easy to form any opinion as to how his expulsion from the Union League Club affects the feelings of Senator, WELLINGTON of Maryland. He has shown himself, by his cruel and crazy expressions of "indifference" as to the fate of Mr. McKINLEY so hopelessly out of sympathy with all decent people that it may be he will not care for the grave public condemnation passed upon him.

The market for outside securities experienced extremely dull trading yesterday. Few outside orders for industrial and miscellaneous shares were executed, and there was practically no news in regard to an of the usually active issues. Fluctuations as well as net changes were for the most part fractional Bank and transportation stocks were neglected and copper share were listless.

SARATOGA, Sept. 13. -- Vice President Roosevelt, when he passed through Saratoga last Wednesday, en route to the Tahawus Club, ninety-five miles distant in the Adirondacks wilderness, said that he expected to leave there to-day for his Oyster Bay home. The Vice President, it is understood, yesterday changed his plans, as he desired to remain with his family at the club until next Monday morning.

NEW HAVEN, Sept. 13. -- Contracts for the electrical display at the Yale bi-centennial were given out to-day. Two firms received the contracts. A New York firm will light Pheips Gateway, in College Street, which will be the central point in the illumination scheme. The gateway will be completely outlined with electric bulbs, after the method adopted with such success at the Pan-American Exposition, and will be loaded with lanterns and electric bulbs.

Justice Collins in the Hudson County Supreme Court at Jersey City yesterday granted a certiorari to review a judgment for 6 cents damages, $120 debt, and $10.40 costs. Some time ago Richard C. Since then his condition had been considered critical, though his strong recuperative powers gave hope of possible recovery.

FALMOUTH, Mass., Sept. 18. -- According to the affidavit of a citizen of this village, Michael Conway, coachman for Richard Olney, ex-Secretary of State, in commenting upon the shooting of President Mc-. Kinley said:

The stockholders of the American Sugar Refining Company in Jersey City yesterday approved the recommendation of the Directors to increase the capital stock of the company from $75,000,000 to $90,000,000 by the issuance of $7,500,000 additional common stock and $7,500,000 preferred.

BALTIMORE, Md., Sept. 18. -- Judge Frederick Stump, who died a week ago at his country estate in Cecil County, was one of the most popular men on the bench in Maryland. His family was distinguished. He was noted for his clearness of perception, legal knowledge, sound judgment, and wit.

LONDON, Sept. 19. -- The British demonstration of sympathy on account of the death of President McKinley is the wonder and talk of all the American visitor. The number of half-masted flags is increasing and a majority of the people are in mourning. The omnibus and cab drivers have crape on their whips.

CANTON, Ohio, Sept. 18. -- Those who had known William McKinley best to-day received his body at his old home. They had forgotten the illustrious career of the statesman in the loss of a great personal friend, who had grown dearer to them with the passing of the years. They hardly noticed the President of the United States or his Cabinet or the Generals or Admirals in their resplendent uniforms.
LONDON, Sept. 18. -- Money and discounts were steady to-day.

News was received at the District Attorney's office yesterday of two desperate attempts to commit suicide made Tuesday night by Charles F. Jones, valet to W. M. Rice, and one of the alleged conspirators in the murder of his employer. Jones, since the hearing in the forgery case of Lawyer Patrick, his alleged partner in the crime, has been confined at 200 West Forty-fourth Street, a private sanitarium.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your article in yesterday's issue under the heading "Mr. McKinley's Doctors Disagree on the Case" will provoke no end of discussion and criticism. It is a matter of surprise and disappointment that such eminent scientists as the President's physicians offered so little explanation for the peculiarities of the case, yet all arrived at the conclusion from various theories that the wound was essentially fatal.

By The Associated Press. COMPIEGNE, Sept. 18. -- The Czar's first day on French soil passed without untoward incident, except a delay of a couple of hours in docking the Standart, the Russian imperial yacht, at Dunkirk.

In preparing the decorations which form one of the many manifestations of National grief, it would have been well to remember that propriety and law alike guard the National flag from additions and alterations. It can, indeed, form a part of a decorative scheme, but the distinctively mourning emblems should not be sewed or otherwise fastened to the banner.

In dripping, dismal weather, with the certainty of a heavy track and every promise of withdrawals that would alter completely the results of the day's events, the regular racegoers made the trip to the Gravesend course yesterday and put in the afternoon guessing at the winners with an equanimity that nothing short of an earthquake would have disturbed.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 18. -- The steam yacht Varuna, with her owner, Eugene Higgins on board, arrived here this morning, ten days from Southampton, England, and is anchored in the outer harbor. Mr. Higgins brought over with him as guests Count Leon de Laforde and Dr. Gautiez. Mr. Higgins immediately upon his arrival called upon his sister, Mrs. H. Mortimer Brooks, and then, with his guests, registered at the Casino.

The New York Medical Journal will deal at length this week with the surgical aspect of the case of President McKinley. The Journal is not disposed to find fault with the surgeons who attended upon the late President. It believes that all that human skill could do for him was done.

The London Times gives prominence to the letter of a contributor who has evidently made some study of the social creed of the Anarchists and therefore writes with a fuller understanding than the hasty diagnosticians who have of late prescribed so many remedies for this direful disease.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18. -- Alfred A. Winslow, Consul for the United States at Liege, Belgium, has sent a report to the State Department on the trade in Indian corn with Belgium. The report says:

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 18. -- The stock market was strong but dull throughout the day, the only activity being in the last hour. Nearly everything improved, but the range was narrow, Chootaw's advance of one point being the extreme movement. There were slight advances in Consolidated Traction, the Readings, Lehigh Valley, Consolidated Lake Superior, and Philadelphia and Erie.

F.R. Cooley, captain of the Hartford golf team, is the latest victim of the poorly driven golf ball. While playing on his links the other day, Howard Morton sliced his drive from the fourteenth tee in such a manner that it struck Mr. Coolly in the forehead, inflicting an ugly wound.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 18. -- The delegates representing seven political parties of reform, who came here to "The Allied Third Party" conference, held their first joint session to-night, after two days of separate conference meetings behind closed doors. All the preliminary work of launching the new political party, which is to be a union of all reform parties, was done by the conference committees of the several delegations before the delegates met to-night.

After some early hesitation and irregularity yesterday the stock market in the afternoon became suddenly and aggressively strong under the leadership of the Vanderbilt issues, the coalers, Union Pacific, St. Paul, Baltimore and Ohio, and the Southern group, all of which showed substantial appreciation.

Michael Crowley, who was arrested some weeks ago on the complaint of Henry Cantwell that he had failed to make any return for $300 which the complainant had paid him with the expectation of being awarded a place on the police force, was arraigned for the first time on the charge in the Court of Special Sessions yesterday.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 18. -- The second day's attendance at the Oakley meeting was more than 2,000. The unfinished 2:24 pace went to Terrace Queen in the first, heat of the day. Harold H. got another heat in the 2:29 pace and took first money. The race for three-year-olds was the first on the regular card.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The announcement in the real estate news of the sale of this Revolutionary relic as the site of a residence is a sore blow to those who have been hoping that this beautiful spot, fraught with such deep interest to all Americans, might be preserved in its present state.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18. -- Justice Prindiville to-day decided to allow Emma Goldman, the Anarchist, her freedom until the case comes up for hearing, under bonds of $20,000. Her attorneys said they had secured $15,000, and immediately left the courtroom to seek the additional money necessary.

BROCKTON, Mass., Sept. 18. -- At Avon, on the main line of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad, a switch not properly set this afternoon threw together a passenger express and a heavy freight train, killing six and injuring twenty-five passengers. The express left Boston at 1:08 P. M., and it was running forty miles an hour at the time of the accident.

MONTREAL, Sept 18. -- The Duke and Duchess of Cornwall journeyed from Quebec to Montreal to-day and were greeted with another affectionate demonstration from the people of Canada. They reached Montreal at 3 o'clock this afternoon.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 18. -- Loran L. Lewis and Robert C. Titus have accepted the assignment of Judge Emery in the County Court to act as counsel in defending Leon F. Czolgosz upon his trial for murder in the first degree in killing President Mckinley. Judge Titus will return from Milwaukee on Friday; and will then consuit with Judge Lewis and determine the line of defense to be pursued.

DUNKIRK. Sept. 18. -- Before 5 o'clock this morning the streets of Dunkirk echoed with the measured tramp of infantry marching to take up positions in the cordon thrown around part of the docks and along the route from the Prefecture, in which President Loubet staid over night, to the side of the dock. The weather had cleared considerably, and by 7 o'clock, the hour fixed for President Loubet's embarkation, the sun was shining.

With only two votes in the negative -- those of Herman Ridder and Charles Lutz the joint conference committee of the anti-Tammany bodies last night agreed to present Seth Low as the fusion candidate for Mayor of New York.
BOSTON, Sept. 18. -- Money was in good supply at the Clearing House to-day at 4 per cent., and New York funds sold at 25, 20, and 15 cents discount. Exchanges, $24,266,668; balances, $2,038,828.

In accordance with the orders of President Miles M. O'Brien of the Board of Education, exercises in honor of President McKinley were held yesterday afternoon In the various public schools of the city. After the exercises the schools were closed until Monday. There were singing, readings from the dead President's speeches, and addresses.
All of the theatres in this city will be closed to-day.

"Are Bachelor Apartment Houses Tenements ?" was the question which Magistrate Pool was called upon to decide in the Jefferson Market Court yesterday afternoon, and, after listening to the arguments of the attorneys on both sides for an hour, he came to the conclusion that they are not.

To-day in New York will be given over to observances honoring the memory of President William McKinley. In all city churches there will be services. Mr. McKinley will be the subject of eulogy, and in many cases his favorite hymns will be features of the musical services. There will be no distinction as to denominations or creeds in these observances.

LONDON, Sept. 19. -- The ceremonies in connection with the national commemoration of the one thousandth anniversary of the death of King Alfred the Great began in Winchester yesterday. A lecture on the life of the King was delivered by Frederic Harrison and a reading from Tennyson's "Becket" was given by Sir Henry Irving.

Jeremiah C. Lyons has sold the plot, 100.5 by 125, at the southwest corner of Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street, for about $700,000. It is reported that the property had been acquired by a syndicate as the site for a new hotel, although regarding this phase of the transaction neither Mr. Lyons nor his attorney, E.G. Stedman, would make any disclosures yesterday.

CANTON, Ohio, Sept. 18. -- The funeral train ran more slowly after leaving Harrisburg shortly after midnight, and daylight was dawning as it arrived at Altoona, at the foot of the eastern slope of the Aileghanies. But through the semi-darkness the forms of many people could be seen strung along the track.

The Second Assembly District was qule yesterday. Mr. Foley's saloon, In Centre Street, was the Mecca of a few of his sup porters, who cherished the hope that their parched throats might be comforted gratui tously. They found, however, that the place was run on strictly business principles. The fighting spirit of the day before had died out, and Foleyltes and Divverites frater nized.

BERLIN, Sept. 19. -- A memorial service for Mr. McKinley was held in the American Chapel here at noon to-day. All the imperial and Prussian Cabinet Ministers were present, except the Imperial Chancellor, Count von Bulow, who is absent from Berlin. He was represented by Privy Councillor von Guenther.

WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 19. -- Ten thousand people were turned away from the exercises in memory of President McKinley in Mechanics' Hall this afternoon. It was the greatest demonstration of the kind there ever has been in Worcester. Senator George F. Hoar, President G. Stanley Hall of Clark University, the Right Rev. Mgr. Thomas Conaty, President of the Catholic University of America, and Congressman John R. Thayer were the speakers, Mayor Philip J. O'Connell presided.

CANTON, Ohio, Sept. 19. -- The friends of Mrs. McKinley do not, to-night, regard her as being upon the verge of a collapse. On the contrary, they express themselves as quite confident that she will be spared to them for a long time in at least as good a state of health as she has enjoyed for the last five years.

Although the Carlisle Indians will play a game of football to-morrow, the real opening of the football season of 1901 will not occur until the following Saturday, when eight important matches will be played. Three members of the "Big Four," Harvard, Yale, and Pennsylvania, will begin their seasons on that date, and Columbia, Cornell, Brown, and Lafayette as well.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 19. -- Philadel- phia's tribute to the martyred President was paid to-night at a great memorial meeting in the Academy of Music.

The memorial services in the crypt of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, on Morningside Heights, at which the Right Rev. Henry C. Potter, Bishop of this Diocese, assisted, were of such interest that more than 16,000 persons endeavored to attend them. Of this multitude only about 1,200 obtained admission to the crypt, which has accommodation for a seated congregation of 800.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 19. -- Ex-President Cleveland spoke twice to-day upon President McKinley. The morning address was made before the Faculty and students of the university, in Alexander Hall. This afternoon he made an informal address before the citizens of the town.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 19. -- It is an- nounced authoritatively that an under- standing has been reached through the efforts of National Committeeman Guffey by which a satisfactory fusion ticket will be put in nomination by the Democratic and Union Parties on Philadelphia. Fusion in the city will be followed by fusion in the State.
PARIS, Sept. 19. -- A memorial service was held this afternoon in honor of the memory of President McKinley in the American Church in the Avenue de I'Alma.

In Brooklyn yesterday there was mourning that found expression in prayer and voiced itself in sacred song; and there was, too, throughout the borough a mute but impressive story of a people's grief, in the crape-hung buildings and in the sus- pension of all business. Everywhere, the spirit of mourning manifested itself, in the church, in the home, on the street.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Sept. 19. -- Gov. Voorhees was the principal speaker at the memorial service held in the historic First Presbyterian Church to-day. The pastors of almost every church in the city were present, as was Chancellor Magie and Congressman Fowler. The veteran organizations and Government employes also attended.

Given over to a holiday of sadness yes- terday New York grieved for the dead President in her own way. The day began and ended with the booming of cannon, the National Guard batteries firing a salute of 13 guns, and continuing the firing at half-hour intervals until sunset, when a salute of 45 guns roared a last farewell.

One of the most impressive services ever held in this city by the Sons of the Revolution were those in St. Paul's Chapel, Broadway and Fulton Street, at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon in honor of the dead President. Descendants of the men who helped to make the Republic were gathered together from all over the State, and the historic edifice held scarcely one-fifth of the eager throng who clamored for admittance about its doors.

CHICAGO, Ill., Sept. 19. -- Players on the Midlothian Golf Club links, near Blue Island to-day, were threatened for a time, by the residents of that suburb who considered the playing of golf a desecration of the day. An extemporaneous indignation meeting was held and plans for forming a posse to visit the links and deal summarily with the players were discussed.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 19. -- Memorial services were almost universal to-day throughout this State, many congregations meeting and uniting in other than their own places of worship.

LONDON, Sept. 19. -- The turbine torpedo boat destroyer Cobra has foundered in the North Sea as the result of an explosion.

ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 19. -- Never has there been such an expression of sympathy as was shown in Orange to-day. Business was entirely suspended in retail stores and factories, and the saloons and bootblack shops closed at 10 o'clock and did not reopen until 4. It was no perfunctory closing of the saloons as is the case on holidays and Sundays.

In every city, town, and village in the United States there was mourning yesterday. Wherever an American flag floated it hungs at half-staff, and wherever there was a church it was filled with mourners gathered to hear some great man or the local preacher tell of the glorious life of the dead President, William McKinley.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 19. -- A dispatch from Oklahoma City, O.T., says: "One man was dragged through the streets Here to-day by an angry crowd for maligning his country and President, and narrowly escaped lynching, and another man who spoke ill of the police was compelled to flee for his life.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Sept. 19. -- Experts are busy computing the cost of the strike to the steel corporation and to the workers. On an estimate that 50,000 men have been idle for two months and a half, their loss in wages approximates $10,000,000. Gross earnings of the constituent companies have been cut off to the extent of nearly $15,000,000.

MONTREAL, Quebec, Sept. 19. -- As a tribute to the memory of President McKinley, the Duke and Duchess of Cornwall refrained to-day from participation in public functions and limited their movements to a round of visits to religious, charitable, and educational Institutions.

ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 19. -- The track at the second day's racing of the Tompkins County Fair was heavy. In the 2:20 trot Addie Fritz B. won the first, third, and fourth heats and Pearola the second heat. Best time -- 2:29 1/4. Anteea and Jesse Day also started.

LONDON, Sept 20. -- The memorial service commanded by King Edward in honor of President McKinley was held in Westminster Abbey yesterday, and was attended by many Americans and Englishmen of distinction.

CANTON, Ohio, Sept. 19. -- As the time approached for bearing the body of the dead President from the McKinley home to the church, the little cottage on North Market Street was the centre of a vast concourse of people. Regiment after regiment of soldiers, acting as guards, were in triple lines from curbs back to the lawns.

VIENNA, Sept. 19. -- Two services in honor of President McKinley, one official and another for the resident Americans, were held here to-day.

COMPIEGNE, Sept. 19. -- Emperor Nicholas passed a day full of interest. The morning was spent in witnessing the final operations of the grand western manoeuvres, at which the Czar for the first time saw the French army operating under war conditions, and not merely in parade uniform.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 19. -- Memorial services for Mr. McKinley were held at Music Hall this afternoon. The hall was crowded with a sorrowing audience, which listened to the glowing eulogy of Senator Foraker with aching hearts.

Crowded with people, the White Star liner Teutonic, which arrived at Quarantine late Wednesday evening, came up to her pier on the North River yesterday morning. As the ship neared the Nantucket Lightship on Wednesday morning Capt. McKinstry had the vessel's course changed so as to get close enough to the lightship to receive intelligence of the President's condition.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 19. -- The people of this, the home of President Roosevelt, devoted the entire day to compliance with his proclamation that it should be observed as a day of mourning for the death of President McKinley. All business was suspended after the early hours.
Richard H. Getting has sold for Mrs. S. L. Palmer to Dr. E.C. Collins, for about $25,000, the five-story American basement dwelling 667 West End Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19. -- Washington gave evidence to-day in most impressive manner that its heart was with Canton in the solemn hour of President McKinley's funeral. At exactly 2:30 o'clock the city ceased from labor, practically from locomotion, for five minutes. Men, women, and children, white and black, came to a sudden halt, whatever they were engaged in.

It was learned yesterday that John Flanagan of the Irish American Athletic Club, who holds the world's record for throwing the hammer broke the discus record by over two feet at St. James's Parish and london St. Louis, Mo., last Sunday. Flanagan hurled the discuss his former record of 118 feet 9 1/2 inches, made at the Union.

Business in the outside market yesterday was somewhat broader than it has been recently, and while a larger number of stocks were traded in, prices at the same time advanced considerably in some parts of the list. Some attention was given to several issues which recently have remained very dull, and cases where the trading was accompanied by recessions in prices were exceptional.
CRANFORD, N.J., Sept. 20. -- William Drysdale, the author and journalist, died here to-day.

L.M. Myers, owner of the filly Leonora Loring, winner of the $24,000 Great Filly Stakes at the Sheepshead Bay meeting on Sept. 7, yesterday stated that he had appealed to the stewards of the Jockey Club from the decision of the stewards of the Coney Island Jockey Club meeting, under which his filly was disqualified for the stakes mentioned because of irregularity in the making of the entry to the race.
Bar silver was quoted in London at 27d per ounce and in New York at 58 1/8c. Mexican silver dollars at 45 1/2c.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 20. -- Business in the stock market to-day was heavy, with little advance, the sales being quiet and steady. The feature was the buoyancy of Consolidated Lake Superior shares, the stock advancing over 2 points to 26 1/4 on large purchases and closing at the top. Another feature was a further rise in Asphalt of America us to 56 1/2 and in National Asphalt 5s to 42.

Nicholson Kane, Chester Griswold, and Newbury D. Lawton, As already announced, the races will be sailed on Thursdays, Tuesdays, and Saturdays, beginning next Thursday, Sept. 26.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Would you kindly suggest to the public not to rush ahead and build a monument to our dear departed President too soon. No monument in bronze or stone could replace the one he has built in the hearts of every true American, and it would seem almost a sacrilege to hurry about erecting a monument in material substance.

This may be true, also, of the Ambassadors from foreign potentates and republics to Washington.
The anti-Tammany ticket as thus far made up by joint conferrees of all the anti-Tammany organizations consists of Seth Low for Mayor, and Borough President Edward M. Grout of Brooklyn for Controller.

It was fully expected that he would drive to Pierrefonds and visit the castle in the morning, and that afterward he would go shooting in the great park attached to the Chateau Compiegne.

LONDON, Sept. 20. -- Money was in slightly improved demand to-day and the supplies were large. Discounts were weak, on the Continental demand for bills, the strong bank return and the belief that the American demand for sold has been diverted temporarily to Paris, whence u100,000 is reported to have been engaged.

At least three religious bodies are preparing plans to establish churches in that section of the city lying south of One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street, north of One Hundred and Tenth Street, and west of Lenox Avenue. The lists of passengers going abroad are small, and there are few well-known names on them. The town is filling up quite rapidly with fashionable people on the way to the country or stopping a few days to do shopping.
OTTAWA, Ont., Sept. 20. -- The Duke and Duchess of Cornwall reached the Canadian capital to-day and received an enthusiastic welcome.

Senator Samuel S. Slater has been designated by the State Attorney General to prosecute the cases of condensed milk dealers and manufacturers who are charged with transgressing the law in allowing harmful milk to be sold. It is claimed that much sour milk and milk that is otherwise injurious, especially to young babies, has been sold of late.

HONGKONG, Sept. 20. -- Viceroy Tao-Mu of the Provinces of Kwang-Tung and Kwang-Si, and Viceroy Liu-Kun-Yi of the Provinces of Kiang-Si and Kiang-Su, have forwarded their resignations to Sian-Foo, accompanied by a protest against the usurpation of power by the anti-foreign conservatives.

After an absence of several days, and for the first time since his arrest on charges of oppression and neglect, Deputy Commissioner of Police William S. Devery returned to his office at Police Headquarters yesterday morning. He looked over his mail, and then started for Col. Murphy's office.

CANTON, Ohio, Sept. 20. -- Shortly after noon to-day Mrs. McKinley expressed a desire to be taken to the cemetery. This request was readily acceded to by Dr. Rixey, who, with an attendant, escorted her to a closed carriage. They were accompanied by Mrs. Barber.

READVILLE, Mass., Sept. 20. -- Over 8,000 persons saw the trotter Lord Derby defeat Boralma without apparent effort this after-noon in straight heats. Thomas W. Lawson's horse seemed to be outclassed and utterly unable to hold Lord Derby on the homestretch, and in the last two heats Gears eased the Hamlin horse up perceptibly.

Pierpont Morgan has given 50,000 francs to the hospital here moved a literary gentleman who was talking with me to an eloquent and perhaps amusing comparison between American wealth and American literature. Orison Swett Marden, the editor of Success, having secured for his magazine a series of "Late Stories of Successful Men Told by Themselves," has been sufficiently encouraged by their reception to issue them in collected form. Detectives from the West Thirtieth Street Station made a descent upon an anarchistic resort at 130 West Twenty-seventh Street last night. They arrested one of the men present and locked him up on a charge of disorderly conduct. They also learned of the whereabouts of the leader of the band, and his arrest followed.

The latest bulletin of exports and imports issued by the Bureau of Statistics brings the figures down to the end of August, the returns being corrected to Sept. 14. In this bulletin a comparison is made not only with the eight months of the current calendar year, but with the entire period of twelve months ending with August as far back as 1896.

BOSTON, Sept 20. -- Rear Admiral and Mrs. Sampson have returned to the Charlestown Navy Yard from Lake Sunapee. N.H. The Admiral, it is said, has derived a great deal of benefit from his sojourn in New Hampshire.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 20. -- By winning today's baseball game from St. Louis the Brooklyns tied with Philadelphia for second place. Powell lost his effectiveness in the fourth and fifth innings and Brooklyn made eight hits. This netted seven runs and led to the retirement of Powell, Joyce, a lefthander from Montreal, succeeding him.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- The transport Ingalls left Aden to-day for Manila via Colombo and Singapore.

DR. MITCHELL'S new novel, which will be published by the Century Company Oct. 5, will bear the title "Circumstance." The author is said to make use of a most effective contrast, for nothing could be more incongruous than a well-dressed, consummate adventuress in the highly respectable setting of Philadelphia society.

SEVERAL men who have risen from the rank to places of importance in the world of commerce and finance have recently expressed opinions to the effect that success in life is not dependent on higher education, and their remarks have evoked wide comment.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- The Schley court of inquiry resumed its sessions today, completed its organization by the prompt substitution of Rear Admiral F.N. M. Ramsay in place of Rear Admiral Howison, heard four witnesses, and adjourned until to-morrow. There was plenty of indication that Admiral Dewey intended to make good his promise that the work of the court should not lag.
LYNCHBURG, Va., Sept. 20. -- On July 19 a stranger of somewhat striking appearance arrived at Lynchburg and put up at the Arlington Hotel.

Miss Jekyll's name on the title page of a "garden book" is an indication of superiority. This beautiful volume is not quite so inviting to the general reader as the preceding "Home and Garden," with its fascinating suggestions of home-making after methods artistic, individual, and ingenious, but it contains a wealth of practical directions for using plants, frequently ignored in gardening, to produce beautiful effects.

LONDON, Sept. 20. -- Mr. Robertson Nicoll annunoces this week the early publication of a new biography of Tolstoi, by Dr. E.J. Dillon, who is supposed to be identical with "E.B. Lanim." whose recent book on Russia created quite a sensation here.

LONDON, Sept. 10. -- Mr. Hall Caine's "Internal City" has been slated with unanimous enthusiasm by nearly all the London papers. On the other hand, some of the provincial papers have praised it warmly. Mr. Caine's admirers are to be found chiefly among the religious people of the nonconformist variety.

WILLEMSTAD, Island of Curacao, Sept. 20. -- The Red "D" Line steamer Philadelphia, which arrived here to-day, brings advices from Caracas to the effect that Dr. Bruzual, counsel at Caracas for the New York and Bermudez Company in the asphalt litigation, was thrown into jail last month by the Venezuelan authorities, who pretended that the arrest was made.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., Sept. 20. -- The Anchor Line steamer Furnessia, Capt. Young, from Glasgow and Moville, for New York, which arrived here to-day, reports that when 300 miles off Newfoundland she fell in with the Inter-Colonial Railway Ferry steamer Scotia, which left the Tyne Aug. 28 for Port Mulgrave, Nova Scotia.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Citizens' Union has adopted as a canon of good government the retention of faithful and efficient officers in office, irrespective of party considerations. All are agreed that Mr. Coler has made, an excellent Controller. Why, then, would it not be an abandonment of our principle not to renominate him?

BOSTON, Sept. 20. -- At the Clearing House to-day balances between the banks loaned at 4 per cent, and the New York funds sold at 23 cents discount. The Exchanges were $31,389,085, against $15,104,943 a year ago to-day, and the balances were $1,991,208. There was an active market in Amalgamated, but a quiet one otherwise.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Sept. 20. -- On a wicket which decidedly favored the batsmen, eighteen Philadelphia colts met Capt. Dosanquet's entire team of English cricketers, twelve men, to-day on the grounds of the Philadelphia Cricket Club, at Wissahickon Heights, and when stumps were drawn for the day the colts had scored 173 runs, while the Englishmen had scored 5 runs, without the loss of a wicket.

"The Life of Robert Louis Stevenson." which at the request of the family has been prepared by his cousin, Graham Balfour, is to be issued in two volumes by Charles Scribner's Sons uniform with the "Thistle Edition" of Stevenson's writings. The book will be one of the most important of the Autumn issues, and will be found rich in unpublished manuscripts and letters, diaries of travel, reminiscences of friends, and an interesting fragment of autobiography.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 20. -- This was the day of the cannon rush at Princeton University, and all day there have been clashes between the members of the two lower classes. The Freshman class held its election of officers in the gymnasium at noon and the Sophomores gathered around the building to prevent the first year men from entering it.

BALLSTON, N.Y., Sept. 20. -- Ex-Congressman George West, one of the wealthiest citizens of Central New York, died here to-day.

Dr. John Taylor Brown, who died recently at an advanced age in Edinburgh, leaving behind an important but miscellaneous library, was in the habit of speaking regretfully of specialism in book collecting as seen at the present day. He had little sympathy with the modern collector who devotes attention to one or two departments or to one or two authors, forming with care and discrimination a choice and complete, though limited, collection.

Arthur Lee, ex-Military Attache to the British Embassy in Washington, and Conservative member of Parliament from South Hampshire. Capt. Lee and his wife have, been in this country for a month visiting in Maine at the old home of Mrs. Lee, who is an American.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Col., Sept. 20. -- Charles C. Delmonico, who was for a number of years manager and proprietor of the famous Delmonico restaurants in New York City, died at his home here this morning. Mr. Delmonico had tuberculosis, and when he came here last June for his health was failing quite rapidly.
WASHINGTON. Sept. 20. -- After a suspension of three days, as a mark of respect to the dead President, the business of the Government at Washington was resumed at 9 A.M. to-day.

BUFFALO, Sept. 17. -- Some 300 books written by American negroes form a part of the negro exhibit at the Pan-American Exposition. The collection contains the best work of the race in the field of authorship, and is unique. Examination of these book furnishes new data by which to rate the civilization of the negro.

Second Lieut. Curtis G. Roebuck, Artillery Corps, recently appointed, with rank from July 1, is assigned to the Fifty-eighth Company, Coast Artillery and will join that company at Fort Monroe. Va.
