THE ALLEGED SPANISH STEEL TRUST. -- The cable dispatch last week which announced the formation of a Spanish trust to develop the iron mines in the Biscay district of Spain, has not been regarded seriously by persons in this city who are in touch with spanish affairs and who have a knowledge of the Spaniard's methods of doing business.

Detective Lewis of the Leonard Street Station noticed a man walking up and down the block on Thomas Street, between Broadway and Church, last night and acting in a suspicious manner. The man would go to one door after another and try the knob, peering through the windows at the same time.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Congressman Hepburn should be sustained in his objection to the remittance of duties on Cuban sugar and tobacco.

The Rev. ROBERT L. PADDOCK, ProCathedral, 130 Stanton Street, New York City -- A word from me I realize is of very little value, but I feel it my duty to tell you that THE TIMES is to my mind the best daily paper in the world, and that It comes nearer to being what I think a newspaper should be than any paper I imagine we might have for fifty years to come.

To the broad and enlightened mind of Representative HEPBURN of Iowa it seems impolitic to grant any tariff concessions on Cuban sugar and tobacco. He has little sympathy with that suggestion. Mr. HEPBURN will be remembered as the statesman who grasped the canal bull by the horns.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29. -- Dr. William C. Gray, the editor of The Interior, a publication of the Presbyterian Church died to-day at his home at Oak Park. Dr. Gray underwent a surgical operation just before he left Chicago for his Summer vacation in the Wisconsin woods. When he returned, a few weeks ago, he was in a weakened condition, due not only to the operation, but to the growing. nfirmities of age.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 30. -- Notwithstanding the extreme heat of the day, the "Varsity" had fast and furious practice to-day. In preparation for the first game of the season, next Wednesday, against Villa Nova, the team is being "whipped" into shape as rapidly as possible. So far, the men are in good condition for the time of the year.
LONDON, Sept. 30. -- Money was much wanted to-day for the quarter-end. About two millions changed hands in connection with calls and dividends.

BOSTON, Sept. 30. -- Money at the Clearing House loaned to-day at 3 1/2@4 per cent., mostly at 4 per cent. New York funds sold at 12 1/2 and 10 cents discount. Exchanges, $16,852,029; balances, $1,316,576.

The Executive Committee or Tammany Hall met in the Wigwam yesterday at 4:30 o'clock P.M. Richard Croker wan absent from the meeting, as was also Senator Timothy D. Sullivan. Secretary Thoman F. Smith said after the session that only routine bustness had been transacted.

Police Commissioner Murphy said yesterday that he would announce probably today the action he would take on the Merchants' Association's charges against his deputy, William S. Devery. It was pointed out to the Commissioner that the Corporation Counsel's opinion gave him the choice of three lines of action: To give the merchants a hearing, to deny them one, or to remove Mr. Devery summarily.

THE EDITOR AND PUBLISHER, (New York CITY.) -- THE TIMES has been found on the right side of nearly every question that has come up for discussion. It has not feared to speak the truth when to do so meant a loss of advertising patronage either from the Municipal Government or from business houses.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- Rear Admiral Schley called at the Executive Mansion early to-day, and paid his respects to the President. Other visitors were Senators Proctor, Mitchell, Hansborough, and Foraker; Representatives Grosvenor and Brownlow.
Beth Low, fusion candidate for Mayor, is in daily receipt of a mail the size of which would appal the average politician.

The Democratic City Committee met again in the Democratic Club last evening and discussed candidates for the Mayoralty nomination. Richard Croker maintained an absolute silence during the discussion. The Brooklyn delegation, under the leadership of James Sheylin and ex-Senator John McCarty and Senator McCarren, stuck to Controller Coler and argued that he should be nominated.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- An unusual case has been reported to the War Department. It is that of Private Peter J. Devine, Troop R. Eleventh Cavalry, who was tried by a general court-martial at Fort Ethan Allen, Vermont, on the charge of "using disrespectful words against the President of the United States, in violation of the nineteenth article or war."

Henry S. White, ex-United States District Attorney, with offices in Jersey City, and Past Commander of the Grand Army of the Republic, Department of New Jersey, died at his home in Red Bank, N.J., Sunday night of typhoid fever. He was fifty-six years old.

It is the opinion of Dr. PARKHURST that the Tammany administration under which we live is "anarchy from the top down; solid, unmitigated, devilish." It is not anarchy, of course, or anything remotely resembling anarchy, but Dr. PARKHURST wanted to say that we have a very bad City Government, and chose this way of making his statement emphatic and startling.

Jockey John Bullman, for insubordination at the post in the start of the fifth race at Gravesend yesterday, was suspended for the remainder of the meeting, which means for the remainder of the present week.

A boy's rejection of the advances of his mother served to make a scene in Part II., Special Term of the Supreme Court, yesterday. The mother is Mrs. Adeline Estelle Sullivan Oakes, who, pending divorce proceedings instituted against her, sought to have the custody of her son, Paul Sullivan Oakes, nine years old.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 30. -- Stocks were heavy here to-day to a fractional extent, in sympathy with the trend of the more important markets. Choctaw sold at 72 and the preferred at 54; a few months ago they commanded 75 and 60 respectively. Cambria Steel receded 1/2, to 25 3/8. This means a decline of 3 points from the top.

College Point had its annual Monte Carlo, on a cheap scale, yesterday. Martin Engel was there, and with him all his Tammany cohorts from the Eighth Assembly District, of which he is the leader. "Little Buck" was Master at Arms, describing himself as "a sort o' seckerterry to Mister Engel, seey" Timothy D. Sullivan, State Senator and Tammany leader in the Sixth, was the guest of honor.

After two days of rest following the great race off Sandy Hook Lightship last Saturday, everything was made ready yesterday aboard the Columbia and the Shamrock for the second race of the series which is to take place over a triangular course of thirty miles. The contest will begin from the same starting point this morning.
The schooner Hannah F. Carleton of Bangor, Me., Capt. Hardy, bound from South Amboy to Bangor with 300 tons of soft coal, went ashore last night at Flynn's Knoll, off Sandy Hook.

Whether the man made by the nine tailors was successful, tradition does not say, but theatrical history must record that nine authors and composers have succeeded in making "The Liberty Belles" very vivacious and prosperous personages.
The Sterling Realty Company has resold the four-story dwelling 22 East Sixty-fourth Street, 25 by 100.5, purchased from William C. Tefft about ten days ago.

To the Editor of The New York Times: My attention has been called to the following heading in your issue of Friday, Sept. 27: "Question of Diocesan Division Again Referred to Committee," "The Defeat of Dr. Ritchie." (?)

The nominees of the Citizens' Union for county and borough offices were formally notified last night at largely attended meeting at the Citizens' Union headquarters, 34 Union Square East. The greatest enthusiasm prevailed, and all confidently predicted the election of the fusion ticket.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Sept. 30. -- Major Gen. Arthur MacArthur within a short time will be stationed at Chicago in command of the Department of the Lakes. In taking this assignment the Milwaukee officer, who recently returned from the Philippines, again succeeds Major Gen. Otis, who was for quite a time in general command in the Philippines, and who came to Chicago when Major Gen. MacArthur was placed in charge at Manila.

The yacht races have brought many people to town who otherwise would not be in New York until later in the season. The Autumn weddings are now beginning. Tomorrow afternoon at Grace Church Miss Nanette Widdleton, the daughter of the late William J. Widdleton and Horace Barnard are to be married.

MONTREAL, Que., Sept. 30. -- John Chariton a member of the Joint High Commission, delivered an address before his constituents of South Norfolk, at Fisher's Glen, yesterday, taking as his subject "The Past, the Present, and the Future of Canada," in which he touched on the country's relations with the United States.

Activity in the outside market yesterday was confined to two or three stocks, while the rest of the list was traded in to only a small extent. About half of the business was supplied by the stocks of the American Can Company, which were more than usually active. As a whole, prices were fairly firm, but in one or two of the issues in which transactions were the largest prices declined rather sharply.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 30. -- Among the departures for New York to-day were Mrs. James P. Kernochan, Mrs. Elisha Dyer, Jr., Mr. and Mrs. C.F. Hoffman, Jr., Mrs. Edwin Parsons, Mr. and Mrs. Francis B. Swayne, Mrs. Thomas Hitchcock, Mrs. George T. Bliss, Mrs. W.H. Sands, Mr. and Mrs. W.W. Tompkins, Mrs. George L. Rives, Francis J. Otis, Mr. and Mrs. C.A. Baudoine, and R.L. Fowler and family.

To everybody who desires that horse racing should be a sport which shall commend itself, simply in virtue of its picturesqueness and excitement, to respectable and fastidious persons, Mr. W. C. WHITNEY'S letter, which we print elsewhere, will be of interest and encouragement.

MANILA, Sept. 30. -- A new branch of the Katipunan (a Filipino secret society) has been discovered at Tarlae, capital of the province of that name. The object of the society is the slaughter of whites, Marcelino Marivilla, President of Banoang, is the chief of the new branch, which includes numbers of the native constabulary, who were recently armed.
J.E. DURYEE, 64 West Sixty-eighth Street, New York City -- I send my heartiest congratulations on the fiftieth anniversary of your truly great and high-standing paper.

LONDON, Oct. 1. -- The correspondent of The Times at Vienna says a deep and widespread impression is likely to be caused both in Austria-Hungary and Germany by a statement published in the Budapesti Hirlap and reproduced and confirmed yesterday by the Magyar Nemset, the Hungarian semi-official organ.

Three hundred Columbia students gathered on South Field yesterday to watch the Columbia football players in their first home practice of the season. In the developments of the day they found one or two happenings more encouraging than those which have so far marked the season's progress in Columbia football.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 30. -- Not in years has there been so much activity the night before a State Convention. Hundreds of delegates who are to take part in to-morrow's Democratic State Convention to nominate a candidate for Governor, are here, and were busy to-night. Mayor Seymour of Newark, who is making a fight for the nomination, is not here, but will arrive to-morrow morning.

-- Terrible as is the loss of American lives that resulted from the attack on the garrison in the town of Balangiga, Island of Samar, it will not divert attention from the fact that the rebels were able to catch the Americans completely off their guard, all unarmed, and thinking of nothing except breakfast.

CANTON, Ohio, Sept. 30. -- The officers and men of Company C of the Fourteenth United States Infantry, on duty at West lawn Cemetery, guarding the resting place of President McKinley, worked diligently to-day investigating the strange story in which Private De Prend, who was on duty at the top of the vault Sunday night, figured so prominently.

It was well worth the journey to the Gravesend race track yesterday to see the finish for the fourth event, a nose and nose fight to the last stride between three horses, with victory in the final jump for the outsider of the trio, a triumph so well earned that the spectacle recompensed even the backers of the beaten horses.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- Rear Admiral Robley D. Evans, Capt. T.F. Jewell, and Commander James M. Miller were the witnesses before the Schley court to-day. All were called by the Navy Department, and were assumed to be hostile to Rear Admiral Schley. Admiral Evans's testimony confirmed the assumption, but Commander Miller surprised everybody by giving strong testimony in Schley's favor.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 30. -- The market to-day, while including a slightly wider range of securities, in aggregate business scored a record of exceeding dullness. Only 960 shares of stock and $91,000 worth of bonds were dealt in. The bond purchases were mostly of an investment character. The general tone was fairly steady, and the closing showed net declines in only three securities.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I think it necessary to ask sufficient space to state, in my own way, my reasons for withdrawing from racing abroad. The publication of the fact was made without my knowledge and during my absence from town at October Mountain. It was premature and has given rise to incorrect inferences and conjectures.

The project for a new hotel on the St. Cloud site at the southeast corner of Broadway and Forty-second Street, a deal which has been in negotiation for several months, is assuming definite form. Some minor details have yet to be arranged, but all of the essential terms of the transaction have been agreed upon, and some formal announcement in regard to it will probably be forthcoming within a few days.

LONDON, Sept. 30. -- It is announced here that in spite of William C. Whitney's offer to allow Hugging, his trainer, the Heath House establishment rent free, and although there was a disposition on the part of several owners to intrust horses to his care, Huggins has determined to return to America.

A wedding trip has caused a great deal of trouble for the owner of an up-town apartment house. Incidentally the tenants of the house are in somewhat of a quandary as to whom to pay their rent. A receiver for the property has been appointed, although the owner says such proceedings are not necessary.

The threatened break between the fusion forces in Brooklyn over the nomination for Borough President was averted last night by the Citizens' Union accepting as a compromise Candidate J. Edward Swanstrom, who is a member of both the Citizens' Union and the Brooklyn Democracy, the so-called Coffey organization.

MONTREAL, Sept. 30. -- According to well informed railway men here, it is very likely that Charles M. Hays, who has just resigned the Presidency of the Southern Pacific, will join the New York, New Haven and Hartford. A close friend of Mr. Hays said to-day that Mr. Hays has three offers from Eastern lines, but it could be stated almost with certainty that he will accept the offer of the New Haven company.

Justice Gildersleeve, sitting in the extraordinary term of the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court, yesterday dismissed the indictments against Fire Commissioner John J. Scannell and William L. Marks.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 30. -- To-night was "Bloody Monday" at Harvard, and it was the occasion of one of the fiercest rushes in years between the sophomores and freshmen. Rush followed on rush between the two classes, but it was the general opinion that the sophomores cot the better of them.

The New York and Port Chester Railroad Company yesterday scored its first victory over the allied railroad companies that are opposed to the construction of the proposed four-track electric road between New York City and the Connecticut State line at Port Chester.

Yesterday's Stock Exchange quotations were interesting in a variety of ways, but in no wise more interesting than as reflective of the influence of attacks upon value through attacks upon individuals. The Vanderbilt railway issues had conspicuousness; they were all day under assault; all the professional speculative crowd were violent against them.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 30. -- A detailed account of the capture of Miss Ellen M. Stone, the missionary, by brigands in Turkey has been received in a letter from Mrs. H.C. Haskell of Samokov, Bulgaria, to a relative here. Her letter says Miss Stone had been holding her usual Summer school for Bible workers at Bansko, Macedonia.

In due time we shall have from official sources such information as the survivors of that ill-fated company of the Ninth Infantry can furnish concerning the manner in which they were ambushed, entrapped, and massacred. But we may be pretty sure, on the bare announcement of the disaster, what the explanation will in effect be.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 30. -- It was announced to-day from the Southern Pacific office here that E.H. Harriman had been elected President in New York and that General Manager Julius Kruttschnitt would be assistant to the President, which means that he is to manage affairs of the big company here, referring all important questions directly to Mr. Harriman for settlement.

The strange story of a woman who preferred to pass for a man was revealed by the death of Miss Carolina Hall of Boston, a cabin passenger on the steamship Citta di Torino, which arrived from Naples and other Mediterranean ports on Sunday. On the passenger list Miss Hall appeared as "Mr. Charles Winalow Hall," and with her on the ship was Mrs. Hall, whom she spoke of as "my wife."

Charles W. Morse yesterday acquired a majority of the stock of the Telephone, Telegraph and Cable Company of America. This is said to be the first step in the formation of a far-reaching independent telephone system. Not only New York City, but New England and several Western States are already included in the territory in which Mr. Morse and his fellow-promoters expect to operate.

It is a curious and impressive document that the Merchants' Association has sent out to the 14,000 firms with whom it is related. In substance the circular is a very emphatic argument addressed to business men to show that it hurts business in a large town to have gambling, prostitution, and other forms of vice under the paid protection of the police.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30. -- Secretary of the Treasury Gage, who is staying a few days at the home of his son in Evanston, before going to Colorado to spend his vacation, said to-day in regard to the present large surplus in the Treasury:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- Commander Southerland was the first witness on the stand in the Schley court to-day. He was asked by the Court whether, if the fleet of Cervera had been in the harbor at Clenfuegos, it could have been seen by the vessels blockading the port. He replied:
It is indeed highly important that all who vote for me shall understand that, if elected, the actual as well as the nominal head of the City Government will be in the City Hall -- SETH Low.
According to Louisville dispatches six of the breweries of that city are to consolidate with $2,000,000 capital.

Official action of the Board of Directors of the United States Steel Corporation yesterday, deserving the applause of every man believing in sensible and honest industrial management, is destined to exert influence reaching far beyond the company's own affairs. In declaring current dividends the Trustees issue to their shareholders a statement of operations covering a period of six months.

Dr. Francisco Rivera and Jose M. Rivera, brothers and natives of Colombia, were passengers yesterday on the steamer Al- liance, which arrived from Panama. They are exiles from their country after having served long terms of imprisonment for simply, as they claim, giving utterance to ex- pressions favorable to the revolutionists.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 1 -- The stock market to-day was very dull in the bond, department, but more active in the stocks. A little extra selling of United Railways common provided the bulk of business in stocks. That selling was due to the announced application of a new railway company for a franchise on rather liberal offerings to the public generally.

DETROIT, Oct. 1 -- Miss Blanche Bates, who is playing in Frohman's "Under Two Flags" at the Detroit Opera House here, was taken to Grace Hospital to-day. She is suffering from a severe attack of malarial fever. Her physician announced to-night that it would be several days before she would be able to resume her work.

BOSTON, Oct. 1 -- A well-known Boston architect, J.R. Hall, is the father of Miss Caroline Hall, the artist, who died at sea while disguised as a man, and whose body is now in New York. Mr. Hall is not, however, a retired army officer. He has designed several important buildings here, including one of the theatres.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Oct. 1 -- The manufacturers have refused the 5 per cent, advance in wages asked for by the cotton mill operators here. It is not possible at present to forecast definitely action by the operatives. After full consideration by the Textile Council the answer of the manufacturers probably will be laid before a special meeting of five textile organizations, with whatever recommendations the Textile Council sees fit to make.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 1 -- Theodore C. Search, President of the National Association of Manufacturers, said to-day that the prospects for a National Reciprocity Congress to be held in the near future are most encouraging.

ALBANY, Oct. 1 -- Every New Yorker who visits the Pan-American Exposition will echo the words of the late President, William McKinley, who upon being conducted through the beautiful marble palace which is known as the New York State Building, remarked: "It is something the State may be proud of, and it is satisfying to feel that something permanent is to remain of all this beautiful Exposition."

Thomas Francis Murphy, one of the oldest of the Sandy Hook pilots, died suddenly sometime during Monday night on board the Panama, steamship Allianca while the latter was anchored off Quarantine. Heart disease is believed to have been the cause of death.
TERRE HAUTE, Ind., Oct. 1 -- The second day's races of the closing meeting of the Grand Circuit drew a larger crowd today, and the events were of a more sensational nature than on the opening day.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1 -- The annual meeting of the Chicago and Alton Road was held here to-day and the old Directors re-elected. Following the stockholders' meeting the Directors re-elected the present staff of officers. The statement of earnings shows an increase in the gross amounting to $1,240,205.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., Oct. 1 -- Two of the thirty-footers, the Esperanza and the Hera, have been dismantled and laid up in the yacht shed at the Jacob yard for the Winter. John B. Mills's sloop yacht Kestrel, New York Yacht Club, arrived from the eastward and hauled out at the Woods yard to lay up for the season.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 1 -- The Court of Appeals to-day decided that the proceedings instituted by Attorney General Davies against the American Ice Company, to determine whether it is an illegal combination in reatraint of trade and is violating the anti-trust law of the State, shall be continued.

Manager Sherer of the New York Clearing House Association in his report presented at the annual meeting yesterday showed an increase in exchanges this year of over $23,000,000,000, as compared with 1900. George F. Baker was re-elected President, Henry P. Davison Secretary, William Sherer Manager, and William J. Gilpin Aseistant Manager.

LONDON, Oct. 2 -- Within two weeks the war in South Africa will have entered upon its third year; and, in the face of the recrudescence of organized operations by the Boers and of the impossibility of carrying out War Secretary Brodrick's promise to reduce the expenses by sending home some troops, the Government organs are again becoming restless.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 1 -- Mayor James M. Seymour of Newark was nominated to-day as the Democratic candidate for Governor of New Jersey in a convention that at times was turbulent in the extreme, but which, for all that, was freer from displays of ill-temper than is frequently the case with State Conventions.

-- It has recently been suggested -- in connection with what we do not remember -- that now would be a good time to rearrange the numbering of the city's houses and shops, in accordance with a system that would make each number tell more definitely than at present the exact location of the edifice it designates.

ALLENTOWN, Penn., Oct. 1 -- A consolidation of all the independent telephone companies of Easton, Penn., which is to be a formidable rival of the Bell system, was effected in this city to-day, and is to be followed by the merging, of all the independent systems of the entire State of Pennsylvania with those of New Jersey and eventually to connect with a proposed system between New York and Boston.

Plans were adopted last evening by the New York Historical Society for its new one-million-dollar building. This action was taken at the first monthly meeting of the society since the Summer, vacation, after an exhaustive report had been presented by the Building Committee.

LONDON, Oct. 2 -- A dispatch to The Times from Paris says the Opposition press has raised a violent outcry against the Government because of the removal of the Due d'Auerstadt from the office of Grand Chancellor of the Legion of Honor and the appointment in his stead of Gen. Florentin.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 1 -- The stock market was very dull, and had it not been for the fast selling of Reading common it would have been one of the most listless days experienced for more than a month. The tendency was slowly downward all day. One local house unloaded a block of 2,600 shares of Reading common stock, but it all found ready buyers.

LEXINGTON, Va., Oct. 1 -- The Trustees of Washington and Lee University have elected Dr. George H. Denny, now acting President and Professor of Latin, President of the university, to fill the vacancy caused by the death of William L. Wilson last October.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 1 -- The Philadelphia baseball team won two games from Cincinnati again to-day by rather good margins. In the first game the visitors shut the local team out without a run.
BOSTON, Oct. 1 -- Money loaned to-day at the Clearing House at 3 1/2 to 4 per cent., and New York funds sold at 10c discoiint. Exchanges, $25,250,119; balances, $2,426,364.

It is with sincere regret that we learn of the position which Mr. CHARLES W. DAYTON thinks it his duty to take with reference to the candidacy of Mr. Low. He is reported in The Evening Post of yesterday as saying: "I cannot give my services to the fusion candidate for Mayor.

Police Commissioner Murphy, after waiting a week, yesterday refused to hear the charges preferred by the Merchants' Association against Deputy Commissioner Devery to the effect that he had conducted himself improperly while presiding at trials of delinquent policemen at Headquarters and had brutally oppressed and insulted the men under him.

The complication in the fusion situation in Brooklyn caused by the nomination of Robert Baker for Sheriff by the Citizens' Union on Monday night was not straightened out yesterday. It was expected that Mr. Baker would withdraw as a candidate for the shrievalty and thereby open the way for a satisfactory adjustment of matters, but this expectation was not realized during the day.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The Senate Committee on Military Affairs to-day resumed its hearing of the charges against Lieut. Col. H.O.S. Heistand. Major Hawkes, continuing his testimony, asked that Col. Heistand produce a memorandum made in May, 1899, by the Colonel and himself, in which $150,000 of the promoters' stock of the Manila Rope Company was apportioned.

The racers were at the lightship at 10 o'clock, and the Regatta Committee's boat, the Navigator, hoisted the international code flag signifying that the race would be triangular. The wind at this time was extremely light from the eastward, and the tide was at the first of the ebb. The swell was very light and from the southeast.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The most sensational incident of the day at the Schley Court of Inquiry was a flat-footed impeachment of the veracity of Rear Admiral Sampson by Capt. Charles D. Sigsbee, who was on the stand. Mr. Rayner read parts of a letter from Admiral Sampson to Secretary Long in which Sampson charged Schley with maintaining a blockade twenty-five miles from shore and gave Sigsbee as his authority.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 1 -- The water has been turned onto the wheels of the plant of the St. Lawrence Power Company at Massena, in the northern part of St. Lawrence County, and started the largest power-producing plant in this country. Even the Niagara Falls power plant is surpassed by this one, both in the amount of power produced and as an engineering achievement.
Two plaster models are being erected in the Justice's chambers in the County Court House. One of these models will show the proposed interior changes and the other the exterior.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 1 -- James M. Seymour, nominated to-day by the Democrats of this State for Governor, has long been a familiar figure in this city. He was born in New York City about sixty years ago. He learned the trade of mechanical engineer at the Novelty Iron Works in New York.

Texas and California are both learning from experience that there are conditions under which industrial combinations are necessary, and that what are popularly known as trusts are sometimes the outgrowth of tendencies which, if unchecked, may become permanently inimical to National development.

With a dozen millionaires at the ring side and a crowd in attendance such as no horse sale of the Fall season has attracted, the last consignment of the thoroughbred horses from the estate of Marcus Daly was sold by the Fasig-Tipton Company at the Fasig-Tipton sales paddock at Sheepshead Bay yesterday, beginning the three days' combination offering of horses through that company.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Consul Ridgely forwards to the State Department from Malaga, Aug. 29, 1901, a clipping from The Mining Review, an important industrial journal of Spain, noting that a steamer which recently took a cargo of iron ore to the United States has just returned with a cargo of steel rails.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The monthly statement of the public debt issued to-day, shows that at the close of business Sept. 30, 1901, the debt, less cash in the Treasury, amounted to $1,031,524,365, a decrease for the month of $4,825,401.

Police Captain Thomas J. Diamond's "wardman," George Bissert, convicted Aug. 1 last of accepting a bribe of $550 from Lena Schmitt, a disorderly house keeper was yesterday denied a certificate of reasonable doubt by Supreme Court Justice Warren B. Hooker, and in consequence must begin the service of his sen- tence in Sing Sing within the next few days.

The first statement of the financial condition of the United States Steel Corporation submitted since its organization was made public yesterday, following a meeting of the Directors of the company, at which the regular Quarterly dividends of 1 3/4 per cent, on the preferred stock, and of 1 per cent, on the common, were declared.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 1 -- The twenty-first annual tournament of the Intercollegiate Lawn Tennis Association to decide the championship in singles and doubles was begun to-day on the grounds of the Merion Cricket Club at Haverford, near here. All the contests played in singles were most spirited, the last set between Roche of Howard, and Colket of Pennsylvania, being particularly so, it taking thirteen games to the set before the former could claim a victory.

VINELAND, N.J., Oct. 1 -- Dr. George Cunningham to-day reported to the authorities a peculiar experience he had yes- terday. He says that he received an urgent call, which was sent by telephone from Alliance, some miles from this place, ask- ing him to visit Mrs. David Levine.

Peter M. Sullivan, who was disbarred for irregularity in practice by the Appellate Division of the Fourth Department of the Supreme Court, appeared before Justice O'Gorman yesterday as his own counsel in suits for damages aggregating $200,000, brought against the Justices who disbarred him and the lawyers interested in the proceedings.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Col. John P. Irish of California, a member of the Indianapolis Monetary Conference, has suggested in a tall he had before his departure for the West to-day, a programme of legislation to be recommended to the next session of Congress by H.H. Hanna, President of the Monetary Conference, intended to effect some needed reforms in the banking system of the country.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., Oct. 1 -- After being a fugitive from justice for three years until his recent capture in Florida, Isaac Mitchell, the young negro accused of killing Edward Kane, a telegraph lineman, in a general fight in James Gilroy's barber's shop on the night of April 2, 1898, was placed on trial for his life to-day before Justice Gummere in the Hunterdon County Court House.

LONDON, Oct. 1 -- Money was easier today on the month-turn, bankers lending their surplus balances more freely. With the large dividend and interest payments, the aggregate distribution was L7,000,000 to L8,000,000. On the other hand, besides repayments to the bank, about L1,000,000 is being transferred to the Government in connection with the estate duty of the late Baron Hirsch.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- As usual, immediately after the opening of the Schley court of inquiry former witnesses were called for the purpose of making such corrections as they desired in the record of their completed testimony. The only witness to respond was Capt. Miller, who commanded the collier Merrimac before she was sunk by Hobson.

Richard Croker and Senator Patrick H. McCarren of Brooklyn spent nearly all of yesterday together. From breakfast in the morning until after the theatre in the evening, these two leaders talked politics, and both seemed to be in a happy frame of mind. At a late hour the list of available men from which the Tammany candidate for Mayor was likely to be chosen was narrowed down to a few names.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 1 -- The special train bearing J. Pierpont Morgan and his guests, who are delegates to the Episcopal Convention, which opens in this city on Wednesday, arrived here to-day after a pleasant trip across the continent.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The State Department has received a report from Frank H. Mason, Consul General at Berlin, comparing Patent Office practice in this country with that in Germany.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Following is the last weekly summary of crop conditions to be issued by the Weather Bureau this season:

The betting crowd at the Gravesend race track yesterday seemed to have found the myth for which learned men of the Middle Ages sought unavailingly, for, with the readiness with which the philosopher's stone was supposed to act, they turned everything they touched into the equivalent of gold, a more convenient medium of exchange in the shape of ready money.

ALBANY, Oct. 1 -- Sept. 30 being the close of the fiscal year in the State Government, Controller Erastus C. Knight has made an examination with reference to the enforcement of the corporation, organization, and transfer tax laws during the year last past and finds that the total receipts from the corporation tax law have been $4,966,680.93, whereas the receipts for the year 1900 aggregated $2,624,508.05, which shows an increase for this year of $2,342,172.88.

Another day of watching the contest for the cup. There were many yachts with merry parties down the bay yesterday, but notwithstanding this attraction the fair at White Plains was not neglected. Today the Horse Show will be largely attended. There will also be a number of dinners and luncheons given at the various restaurants, for the town is full now and will be to the end of the week.

An attempt to sail the second race for the America's Cup, over a triangular course off Sandy Hook, was made yesterday, and failed for lack of wind. The first leg of the course was laid to windward, but owing to the shifting of the light and baffling breeze it became what yachtsmen call a close reach before the first mark was turned, and the British yacht led the way.
Cooper Union's large hall was uncom- fortably crowded last night on the occasion of the holding of the City, County, and Borough Conventions of the Greater New York Democracy.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The following cablegram was received at the Colombian Legation to-night:

LONDON, Oct. 2 -- The Paris correspondent of The Times remarks that Count Tolstoi has for many years been an object of enthusiasm on the part of the French press. The Revue Blanche recently asked the famous Russian for his opinion on the Franco-Russian alliance, and the correspondent sends the reply received by the paper.

ALLEGED TRESPASS BY CITY SURVEYOR. -- Edward M. Laws, Jr., a civil engineer in the employ of the Board of Public Im- provements, entered upon the premises at Elmhurst, L.I., owned by Clarence Edwards, Jr., a lawyer, for the purpose of making a survey for a city map. Mr. Edwards ordered Laws off his place, but the latter showed his badge and refused to go.

Mr. CROKER pretends, in these days, to be looking for a "figurehead" for Tammany Hall. What he is really looking for is a stalking horse for RICHARD CROKER. This is a distinction very worthy to be observed by wearers of the hitherto respectable names which the Tammany boss is alleged to have "under consideration."

The Board of Estimate and Apportionment started to work yesterday on the budget for 1902. Mayor Van Wyck announced his policy in regard to the appropriations for the city departments, and during the session he made many remarks on public matters.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 2. -- The triennial convention of the Protestant Episcopal Church of America began here to-day. Bishop Dudley of Kentucky was elected President and the Rev. Samuel Hart of Middletown, Conn., Secretary of the House of Bishops the Rev. Dr. John S. Lindsay, rector of St. Paul's Church, Boston.

D. Le Roy Dresser, President of the Merchants' Association, was taken suddenly ill while visiting relatives at 166 Madison Avenue shortly before midnight last night. There was considerable excitement in the house and Policeman Burke was called in and asked to summon a doctor at once.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 2. -- Harvard's football team won from Bowdoin this afternoon in a game characterized by slow and listless playing. The game started off with a rush, but wound up poorly. On the kickoff Graydon caught the ball, threw aside the opposing ends, and dashed down the field for a brilliant run of fifty yards.

ALBANY, Oct. 2 -- Gov. Odell arrived here this afternoon from Newburg and was a surprised man when he reached the Executive Chamber. He found on his desk two letters requesting him to commute to life imprisonment the sentence of Czolgosz, the murderer of President McKinley.

In the following list "mtg stands for mortgage and "US" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law as amended, provides that a twenty-five-cent stamp shall he placed on all conveyances here the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 2 -- State Superintendent of Banks Kilburn to-day issued a statement showing the condition of the banks of deposit and discount in this State from reports made at the close of business on Sept. 12. Reports were submitted by 195 banks, as compared with 198 banks reporting in June, when the last statement of this character was published.
TRENTON, N. J., Oct. 2. -- The committee which has been investigating the State Insane Asylum met again to-day for the purpose of examining Warden P. Hayes.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 2 -- Except for Untied States Steel and reflected strength in Cambria Steel, the stock market was stagnant; most of the issues closed with fractional losses. The opening was full of promise, but demands soon were satisfied, and the rest of the trading was dull. Cambria Steel, strong at first, drifted with the rest of the market, and closed weak.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 2. -- The University of Pennsylvania football eleven had difficulty to-day in defeating the Franklin and Marshall team on Franklin Field, winning by the narrow margin of six points to none. Pennsylvania's greatest fault was her slowness in getting off her plays. The visiting team was about as heavy as the home eleven, and was able to withstand the rather weak onslaughts of the Pennsylvanians.

The outside market yesterday remained dull, and there were few important change in quotations. In two or three issues transactions did reach a fairly large amount, but this activity was so exceptional that it did not serve to change the general dullness, of the market. It happened that several issues advanced substantially, but this was principally true in Stocks not much dealt in, which are easily influenced one way or the other.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 2. -- Princeton won her opening football game to-day against Villa Nova by a score of 35 to 0. At no time of the game was Princeton's goal line in danger of being crossed. The home team's work was above reproach, and fumbles were conspicuous by their absence.

Up to the present only one thing has been proved by the three meetings of Columbia and Shamrock II. This is that the challenger is a remarkably good boat in light winds and smooth water. With a light wind and a rolling sea she is heavy, sluggish, and slow. That was shown by the first attempt to sail a race.
PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 2. -- Pittsburg played its last game of the season on the home grounds to-day, and celebrated it by easily defeating Boston in a rather fast game.

Mayor Van Wyck yesterday received a letter from Gen. Charles H.T. Collis, who was Commissioner of Public Works under Mayor Strong, comparing the cost of asphalt paving in this city under the two administrations. In the letter a strong contention is made that the paving contracts awarded under the present municipal regime are excessive and at a much higher figure than similar contracts let during the Strong administration.

Many property owners in the Bronx and Westchester County yesterday testified before the State Railroad Commission, in session at the Fifth Avenue Hotel, that the proposed New York and Portchester Railway is a necessity, and will be a convenience and that present transit facilities are utterly inadequate.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- The proceedings of the Schley court of inquiry to-day began with the usual recall of former witnesses for the correction of their testimony in the official record. After these came Chief Yeoman Becker, who had begun his testimony yesterday and was on the stand when the proceedings closed.

PEKING, Oct. 2. -- Dispatches from Sian Foo announce that the Chinese Court is preparing to start for Peking about Oct. 6. The temporary palace at Sian-Foo is being dismantled and all the furnishings will be carried for use en route. The officials and servants will constitute a caravan numbering from 3,000 to 5,000 persons, with 1,200 carts and several thousand horses and mules that have been collected in the Sian-Foo district.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 2. -- Amherst's football eleven treated the Yale team to a surprise this afternoon in holding the latter down to a single touchdown in a game of twelve and ten minute halves.

There is said to be great doubt about the anti-Tammany forces in Kings renominating County Judge HURD and Surrogate ABBOTT -- two judicial officers of quite exceptional fitness. As to Surrogate ABBOTT the claim is that in order to conciliate COFFEY and secure the votes of his Democratic following, they must give him the office of Surrogate, and his nominee is JAMES C. CHURCH, who is probably qualified to fill the office.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- At to-day's session of the Schley court, Judge Advocate Lemly produced two of the cards which he has been reported to have had "up his sleeve." One was an effort to prove that when Commodore Schley ordered to be printed for distribution a copy of the notes taken during the battle by Lieut.

The Board of Estimate continued the work of making up a budget for 1902 yesterday. Controller Coler was absent from the meeting, and it was said that he, had gone to Philadelphia to remain until Saturday. Mayor Van Wyck presided. The budgets considered were those of the Fire Department, the Department of Public Charities, and the Department of Correction.

Charles W. Morse, Vice President of the New Amsterdam National Bank, and formerly President of the American Ice Company, yesterday acquired a controlling interest in the National Broadway Bank of 237 Broadway. Francis A. Palmer, who has for many years been at the head of the Broadway Bank, will retire from the Presidency and be succeeded by Miles M. O'Brien of the H.B. Claflin Company and President of the Board of Education.

LONDON, Oct. 3. -- Lord Kitchener yesterday reported that two British officers and thirty-one men had been killed in a Boer attack on Col. Kekewich's camp at Moedwill on Sept. 29. The Boers, who were under Commandants De la Rey and Kemp, had 14 officers and 114 men wounded. After two hours' night fighting the Boers were driven off.

There will be many events to-day which will occupy the attention of society. In the first place there are the yacht races. There is also the wedding of Miss Caroline Livingston and Maxwell Stevenson.

VICTORIA, B.C., Oct. 2. -- The steamer Kaja Maru, which arrived here this morning, brought among her passengers Marquis Ito, formerly Premier of Japan, and the Hon. K.Tsuzuko, who was Under Secretary of Education in the Ito Ministry. A doctor and two secretaries accompanied the party.

Grant and Fornes were formally Informed by delegations from no less than six different anti-Tammany organizations that they had been selected as their nominees.

Commissioner Murphy had refused to take any official cognizance of the changes beyond replying to the association that they were not of sufficient importance to require a hearing or a trial.

John Neville, whose, death was reported yesterday, was well known in financial circles in this city and abroad. He began his business career in 1871, having served an apprenticeship with financial editors of various New York papers.

Perry Tiffany of 152 Madison Avenue, son-in-law of Theodore Havemeyer, who filed a petition in bankruptcy on Dec. 24, 1900. with liabilities of $83,897, applied several months ago for a discharge in bankruptcy. His application was opposed by the First National Bank of Hoboken, one of his creditors, and the hearing on the specifications was referred to Nathaniel A. Hay, straw, and excelsior stored in the sub-cellar of the five-story brick and stone building, 56 Murray Street, and used by the Consolidated Lamp and Glass Company for packing, took fire from some unknown cause shortly after the opening of the day's business yesterday, and in a few seconds the place and the cellar above were filled with flame.
NEWPORT, Oct. 2. -- Mr. and Mrs. A. Livingston Mason have closed their Newport cottage and gone to New York, where they have taken a house for the Winter.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- The President to-day appointed Col. William H. Bisbee a Brigadier General of the regular army. He was recommended highly by Major Gen. Wheaton and Major Gen. MacArthur for his recent service in the Philippine Islands.
The wedding of Horace Barnard and Miss Nannette Widdleton, daughter of the late William J. Widdleton, was celebrated at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon in Grace Church by the Rev. Neilson Poe Cary.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- The Secretary of the Treasury announced to-day the intention of the Treasury Department to discontinue, for the present, purchases of bonds for the sinking fund. The amount of $20,000,000, for which proposals were invited Sept. 10, was reached at noon to-day. By the terms of the Secretary's announcement to-day no further proposals, in the existing circumstances, will be considered.
BOSTON, Oct. 2 -- Money loaned at the Clearing House to-day at 4 and 3 1/2 per cent. New York funds sold at 10 and 5 cents discount. Exchanges, $32,941,027; balances, $2,621,329.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- The Controller of the Currency has prepared a summary of the returns relating to the organization of National banks under the provisions of the National currency law, as amended by the act of March 14, 1900, statistics being brought down to the close of September, 1901.

Capt. James Gannon, recently transferred from the East Twenty-second Street Station to the Central Park Station, was called to the witness stand before Justice Jerome, in Special Sessions, yesterday during the examination of Lizzie Mack and Catherine Brown, charged with maintaining a disorderly house known as the Webster Hotel, at 140 East Fifteenth Street.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- The Secretary of War has made an allotment of $100,000 for the purpose of preparing the military post at Washington Barracks for the use and occupation of the Army War College, the School of National Defense, and the Engineer School of Application.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 3. -- In connection with the second day's session of the triennial convention of the Protestant Episcopal Church of America to-day, a thanksgiving service was held in Grace Church at which the missionary offering of the Women's Auxiliary, amounting to $104,295, was presented.

The sharp break in the industrials, which is to be regarded as Wall Street's rather tardy protest to blind pool management, was the overshadowing feature of the trading in yesterday's stock market. OSSINING, N.Y., Oct. 3. -- Gilman P. Tiffany won the low-score prize to-day in the Qualifying round, of the open tournament given by the Mount Pleasant Field Club. The event was a thirty-six-hole round, and with thirty starters. Tiffany led the field with 176 strokes. That was six ahead of the second best -- 182 -- made by H. Auchincloss of the Highland Golf Club.

ALBANY, Oct. 3. -- By a decision of the Court of Appeals, Patrick J. McNulty of New York City will receive from the municipality $209,382.41 and costs. The case has been before the courts for a long period. McNulty brought suit to recover wages due drivers and other employes of the Street Cleaning Department for working overtime.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 3. -- At the meet of the Island Park Driving Association to-day. Dariel, driven by Miss Nina Phelps of Waterville, Conn., beat the world's record for women drivers by 3 1/4 seconds. The horse trotted the mile in 2:09 1/4. The best previous record for a woman driver was 2:12 1/2.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 3. -- Transactions in the stock market to-day were trifling, and the course of prices showed no important change. The close generally was a little lower than on yesterday, but the tone was firm. Lehigh Valley and Consolidated Lake Superior recovered half a point. United Gas Improvement was off a quarter.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 3. -- Edward M. Shepard arrived in this city this evening and will remain at the Hotel Ten Eyck until to-morrow morning, when he will go to his Summer home on the banks of Lake George. He will remain there for some time. He is in quest of a much-needed rest.

The annual report of the New York Central for the year ended June 30 last, which was made public yesterday, shows the largest freight and passenger and gross earnings in the history of the company, even if the operations of the Boston and Albany are excluded.

In an afternoon of dismal disappointments at the Grayesend tracq yesterday the victory of Autolight in the race for the Oceanview Handicap and Jockey O'Connor's ride on the winner stood out as conspicuously as the aurora borealis in an arctic night.

The order of Commissioner Murphy to all policeman on post to refuse to serve warrants issued at the request of anti-vice societies was obeyed to the letter yesterday morning by a policeman of the West Twentieth Street Station, who was asked to serve a warrant issued by Justice Jerome for the Parkhurst society against a woman charged with abduction.

Wood Benson, ninety-five years old, probably the oldest locomotive engineer in the country, who ran for many years over the New York Central Railroad, died in the Almshouse on Blackwell's Island yesterday. The closing years of his life were spent in east side lodging houses, where he was remarkable for the neatness of his attire.

A gold medal struck in recognition of the services of Abram S. Hewitt in the cause of civic rapid transit under municipal ownership, was presented to the ex-Mayor yesterday at the monthly meeting of the Chamber of Commerce by President Morris K. Jesup.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- Major Gen. G. W. Getty, one of the heroes of the Mexican war and the war of the rebellion, is dead at the family residence at Forest Glen, Md. He will be buried with full military honors at Arlington Cemetery to-morrow.

CHICAGO, Oct. 3. -- Sir Thomas Lipton will be royally entertained during his coming visit to Chicago. Elaborate preparations are being made by the committees appointed for the reception and banquet at the Chicago Athletic Association Clubhouse. The date has not yet been set, awaiting the time to be chosen by the distinguished guest.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- According to a report issued to-day by the United States Geological Survey, the total value of minerals of all kinds produced in the United States in 1900 was $1,070,108,899. The total production for 1899 was $1,211,361,861, and for 1898 $861,751,017. BALTIMORE, Oct. 4. -- The market to-day was more active in the stock department, but dull in the bonds. Of the total sales in stocks, however, Seaboards constituted more than two-thirds, and they also furnished three-fifths of the bond sales. The market early in the day was somewhat heavy, due entirely to the conditions in New York.

TAMPA, Fla., Oct. 4. -- Twenty buildings in the heart of West Tampa were burned this morning. The property loss amounted to $200,000. The fire was discovered at 10 o'clock in the large cigar factory of O'Halloran Co., and as the water supply was inadequate, the flames could not be checked.

Grout, and C.V. Fornes of their nominations. Mr. Lindinger was quoted as having said that Justice Divver had decided to bolt the Tammany nominations and support Mr. Low.

The third and last race of the series for the America's Cup was sailed yesterday and concluded with the most magnificent finish ever seen in a yacht race in this country. After starting practically together in a run down the wind, both yachts crossing the line after the handicap gun was fired, and being timed at 11:02, they crossed the line at the finish really neck-and-neck after a hammer-and-tongs struggle of thirty miles.

From The Popular Science Monthly. The sardine manufacturers ostensibly employ only two kinds of oil in their canning operations -- olive oil and arachide or peanut oil. TOPEKA, Oct. 5. -- Fred Wellhouse, the apple king, is so busy in his orchards these days gathering his apple crop that he hasn't time to come home Sundays and attend church. He is a devout Christian, too. He began to pick his apples last week. He will not finish for at least three weeks yet with the most favorable weather.

WICHITA, Kan., Oct. 5. -- Kansas has gone wheat crazy. Just as her Prohibitionists went wild over the saloon-smashing crusade, the farmers are now exhibiting the same spirit of industry in planting wheat this Fall. The acreage will be the largest ever known in the history of the State.

AKRON, Ohio, Oct. 5. -- A force of telephone linemen imported to take the places of local strikers was surrounded by a howling mob who threatened personal violence when they attempted to go to work to-day. Police had to be called to guard them. The new men were unable to secure meals or a place to sleep last night, owing to the strong union sentiment.
